desc: Head up a face~ to hand crack to a slabby face. Crux is passing the last two bolts.

location: Pywiak Dome > Tuolumne Meadows > Yosemite National Park > California
desc: Starts from third class ledges~ up and left from the "Dike Route".   Climb past 5 bolts to a two bolt belay.   Follow 7 bolts passing a 5.10a bulge to a two bolt anchor.   Run out 5.6 (no pro) to another two bolt anchor.   Move up and right to the base of a steep corner.   Descend 3rd and 4th class to the right.

location: Eagle Lake Buttress > Eagle Creek Canyon > West Shore > Lake Tahoe > California
desc: Awesome finger crack on a small crag beneath the east side of Eagle Lake Buttress. Crux is in the first 8' or so before the route levels out~ so place good pro early~ as a fall would be rather unpleasant here.
protection: Nuts and smallest cams you got

location: Beach Boys > Beach > Kamloops > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Climb first 2 bolts of Lady Writer and finish on Yayiee's anchor.  Good for first time leaders.

location: 3 Bolt Wonderland > White Mountain > Yukon Territory > Canada > North America > International
desc: There are 2 bolts that lead to a ledge and goes no where. There are no anchors at the top.

location: Syrian Revolution Wall > Al Qaeda Area > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: Right most route on the wall~ some exfoliating rock off the ground leads to some better quality and some memorable moves.

location: Syrian Revolution Wall > Al Qaeda Area > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: Hard bolted route on a great looking face.

location: Syrian Revolution Wall > Al Qaeda Area > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: Awesome route some hard pulling and stellar rock.

location: Syrian Revolution Wall > Al Qaeda Area > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: Follow a wide crack~ starting in a dihedral.  Some fist jams and ledges to the top.

location: Syrian Revolution Wall > Al Qaeda Area > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: An improbable looking boulder problem off the ground that passes through a roof and across a fin like feature.  It doesn't get any better after that.  Might be a closed project (no red tape)

location: Syrian Revolution Wall > Al Qaeda Area > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: Start in a small dihedral and some burly moves through an overhang.  Gain a flared handcrack and work up past a couple of big moves to better holds and a section of wall with some cool sloping rock with great finish jugs.  Full value.

location: Fantastic 4 > Terrace Mountain > Terrace > Northern BC > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: An easy face climb that takes you up to the fixed lines. Now has bolts for a easy lead. Great to start new climbers on.
protection: Two hangars at top. (have to check for rings)

location: Lower Tier > Bear Mountain (AKA Bald Hill) > New Brunswick > Canada > North America > International
desc: This route was solo'd~ so the pro is uncertain~ although the static line can easily be used as protection if you so wish. A good method for getting to the top of the cliff. Still a bit loose and dirty.

location: Electric Avenue > Chek > Sea to Sky (Squamish to Whistler) > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: A very easy~ short route on the West Face.

location: The Big Gulp > Mount Nemo > Golden Horseshoe > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: Climb up blocks to a big ledge then continue up the easy crack. Easy~ blocky climbing.

location: Bon Echo > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: The first pitch provides enjoyable climbing on small holds. The remainder of the climb is disappointing so it is common practice to rappel after the first pitch.
protection: Bolted rappel station at the top of first pitch.

location: The Hex Wall > Eagle Rock > Welsford > New Brunswick > Canada > North America > International
desc: This climb follows the broken looking corner under a slightly over vertical wall. The corner offers good protection all the way to the last ledge where the chimney is.when you get to the final ledge step down into the chimney make a few awkward steps up onto some chock stone/rocks and exit out of the top.
protection: Bring a rack. The chimney takes a big nut you can place from the ledge and then a #4 cam at the top.

route: Things To Do When It Rains
location: Funarama- The Nursery > The Smoke Bluffs > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Start by a tree in the middle of The Nusery. Basic short~ low angle~ crack climb.

location: The Great Roof Area > Eagle Rock > Welsford > New Brunswick > Canada > North America > International
desc: This is a stunningly marvelous rock climb.  Everything about it is perfect; the movement~ the rock~ the gear~ variety~ etc.~ etc.  Absolute must do.  History: This route was put up in 1976 by Tom Butz and the original grade was 5.1.  It has been adjusted to reflect current grading practices. This is also the oldest recorded rock climb in New Brunswick.

location: Main Cliff > Eagle's Nest > Nova Scotia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Short corner right of Evening Wall.

location: Mount Baldy Crag > Kananaskis > Alberta > Canada > North America > International
desc: Move up and to the right on the obvious ledge system past 3 bolts to a bolted anchor.

location: a. Yoga > Lac Gervais > 15. Laurentians > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Traverse sale dans du rocher douteux protégée par 4 plaquettes pour se rendre à la base du secteur de 'Diligente Indigène'.

location: 10 - La Petite Bière > Montagne d'Argent > 15. Laurentians > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Right most route on this slab. Eleven bolts.  Voie de droite sur cette dalle. Onze plaquettes.

location: (c) Go-Anywhere > (f) White Walls > Skaha > Okanagan > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Very easy climb up the steps~ and some fun and easy moves up the large flakes.

location: Simpson Wall > Cochrane Lane Cliffs > Welsford > New Brunswick > Canada > North America > International
desc: Start on a beauty hand crack that leads to a ledge. From here you have two options. Climb either just the off width crack (5.8) or the nice cracks and features left and right. Climb the feature to the top of the block. Tree anchor. This and Finger Eleven are nice~ easy~ well protected trad climbs that would be great first leads for a new trad climber.
protection: Standard rack. Tree anchor. Rap the route or walk off.

location: Electric Avenue > Chek > Sea to Sky (Squamish to Whistler) > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: A short and easy route wandering up the triangular slab.  Slightly harder than it's next door neighbour.

location: Old School Wall > Devil's Glen > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: Short route that quits due to rock quality.

route: The Grand Master, The Bar Tender and the Clown
location: Old School Wall > Devil's Glen > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: Climb the blocky start to a ledge~ clip the bolt.  Keep following the crack and face to anchors.

location: Limestone Wall > Cedar Point - Trifecta Wall > New Brunswick > Canada > North America > International
desc: right most route~ An excellent warm up route
protection: 3 bolts and an anchor with chain

location: The Matrix > McQuirks Mountain > New Brunswick > Canada > North America > International
desc: This is a fun little climb on vertical and horizontal cracks.

location: Lower Hidden Walls > New Crest Creek > Crest Creek Crags > Strathcona Provincial Park > Vancouver Island > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Follow the flake up to the top.  It's a low angle climb that can be a bit awkward at times.  It had four bolts and could be lead safely with just quickdraws.
protection: Four bolts and maybe a .3 BD cam to protect the flake down low.

location: Tight Canyon > Devil's Glen > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: Dingy~ dirty crack right of Your Wife.

location: The Golf Course > Grassi Lakes > Bow Valley > Alberta > Canada > North America > International
desc: Slabby pocket pulling.  Good near for new climbers. Really easy.

location: Los Sabinos > La Presa Francisco Zarco > Durango > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Easy 5.6 face climbing to a 2-bolt anchor.

location: Sunshine Wall > Kinnaird Bluffs > Castlegar > Kootenays West > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: none listed

location: Burgers and Fries > The Smoke Bluffs > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Step up blocky granite steps.  Climb a hand crack to a ramp.  Follow ramp left to anchors.
protection: SR. 2-bolt anchors with rappel at the top. So you can rappel off or walk off.

location: Krack Rock > The Smoke Bluffs > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Start off with a short~ fun~ and perhaps sandbagged crux with great hand jams and awkward body position. That's where the good times end... The second half of the climb is dirty~ tedious~ and the rock quality is poor. Rotten roots and grime clog the wide cracks and it seems no amount of cleaning could save this thing. The anchor bolts are easy to miss (far out right on the upper slab. If you make it to the trees~ you've gone to far).     Some users on other sites have made the case that the start of this route is much harder than the guidebook proposes. It definitely requires some solid hand crack technique. While I wouldn't argue with an upgrade~ it's certainly no harder than 5.7
protection: Standard Rack with an emphasis on large hand size pieces. Easy to protect throughout~ except when the crack becomes clogged with roots and grime. Crux protects beautifully. Two-bolt anchor at the top right~ easy to miss.

location: Burgers and Fries > The Smoke Bluffs > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Climb the easy crack until it ends~ here head up a thin L-shaped crack on the low angled rock.

location: Upper Cat Wall > Cat Walls > Castlegar > Kootenays West > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: none listed

location: Ahren's Rock > Sunrise Crags > Crest Creek Crags > Strathcona Provincial Park > Vancouver Island > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: This route is a good challenge on the first flake and then levels off above. The bolts are quite spread out~ so having a bit of gear along can add to the comfort level when leading. Can be accessed from the top~ so technically could be top-roped as well.

location: Main Wall > Rattlesnake Point > Golden Horseshoe > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: Climb up over a small roof~ move up and right across a ledge. Continue up and right to a small pillar above a large roof and then head back left and up to the top.

location: Main Wall > Rattlesnake Point > Golden Horseshoe > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: Through open book (climb the face for 5.8) to the roof~ move left to Final Finale belay~ then back right and up past the cedar

location: Nicolum Knob > Fraser Valley > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: In between Dead Soles and Kyle Hudie Route is an obvious thin flake and hand crack. Climb this crack for 25m to a rap anchor. Stop here~ or move left past a bolt on a slab to the anchor for Dead Soles (31m).

location: Lumberland > The Smoke Bluffs > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Awkward start to left leaning diagonal crack.

location: Mount Baldy Crag > Kananaskis > Alberta > Canada > North America > International
desc: Slabby climbing up 4 bolts.

location: Los Sabinos > La Presa Francisco Zarco > Durango > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Easy 5.6 face climbing to a 2-bolt anchor.

location: Call It A Day > The Smoke Bluffs > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Climb any of three short cracks in the middle of the wall up to the horizontal break.  Aim towards the base of the right-leaning ramp feature~ and climb up that to the top.
protection: Protection is somewhat sparse and wandering~ depending on what you choose to climb.

location: El Fin de Semana (Weekend Wall) > El Potrero Chico > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Walk into the canyon and stare in awe and intimidation at the 5~000 ft Scariest Ride in the Park ridge which summits El Toro. Turn your attention left toward the similar~ although less impressive and intimidating knife blade ridge which begins in the super clean Craig Luebben dihedral and climbs several traverses and head walls to a pointy summit adjacent to the summit of Estraillita.     This is a fantastic outing and an excellent first limestone ridge climb in the canyon~ although the danger factor for yourself~ and more so for the parties below you~ should not be under estimated. The ridge is LOOSE~ and a large percentage of your day will be spent tip-toeing on the rocks that make the least amount of noise. Luckily~ the rock quality improves on the head walls~ and protection may be found throughout if you are willing to search. Just be careful~ and you'll have a great time! It is recommended to belay short of the base of each headwall in case something does become dislodged~ although you may have to fight some drag before you find something you're willing to use as an anchor. Simul-climbing is not necessary or recommended given the relatively short length and loose factor~ making a fall on easy terrain much more probable. Pitch it out 6 or 7 times over the double-exposed ridge until you reach the cool summit and belay at the super-comfy anchor on Will the Wolf Survive. From here it is four easy raps to the ground. Finally~ be careful not to pass the anchor on the first rappel~ which is approximately 30 feet below the summit~ beneath the overhang. A 70m will NOT reach the next anchor if you attempt to pass this station.
protection: Single rack of cams (to #3 C4) and nuts. C3 size cams are useful. Long slings and cordellette. Doubles of any size would be way overkill.

location: Weeskinisht Peak > Seven Sisters Provincial Park > Terrace > Northern BC > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: 13km steep approach to snowfields and ridges leading to summit. 24 hours highway to highway.
protection: A small rock rack for the exposed ridge traverse and final step to summit

location: i. Gemini-Jumelle > Mont-Césaire > Val-David > 15. Laurentians > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: A long meandering slab with lots of holds. Great beginners' route.

location: Tranchant - Middle > Montagne du Tranchant > 14. Lanaudiere > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: P1~ 5.5 13m   Climb the dihedral on the right of the angled cracked face.   P2~ 5.6 18m   Keep climbing towards the left until you see a face on the right with a bolt to linkup to another dihedral to the belay.
protection: Standard rack   Bolted raps and belays

location: Paddock Wall > Sunshine Rock > Banff National Park > Alberta > Canada > North America > International
desc: Nice long warm-up route.  A bit runout between 2nd and 3rd bolts.  Just climb the corner all the way up.  We came out after a rainy day and this area of the crag was drier than the rest.

location: Downtown Eastside > Comox Lake > Comox Lake > Vancouver Island > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Star right of hemlock tree.

location: Moe Wall > McQuirks Mountain > New Brunswick > Canada > North America > International
desc: The first crux is near the bottom of the first pitch getting established into the bigger cracks. Gear is a little tricky and there are some not so reassuring pinches. A bolt protects a slight run out. Second pitch is low fifth to the tree ledge. There is a one move wonder off the tree ledge that goes at 5.7 then it is easy again. This is a great line with tons of variety and will feel like a longer climb.
protection: Single rack to 4". The 4 is not absolutely necessary but nice. No need to double up if you climb this route in three pitches. One bolt on pitch 1. Bolted anchors. Rap the route.

location: X Wall > McQuirks Mountain > New Brunswick > Canada > North America > International
desc: This is a nice direct line to the top of the cliff.  Makes a great link up with Fake Right-Go Left.  Very straight forward climbing on good quality stone.
protection: Standard rack to 3".  Two bolt anchor/rappel station at the top.

location: Cranberry Meadows > Golden Canyon > Yukon Territory > Canada > North America > International
desc: Start in a right-leaning hand crack and climb upwards through flakes to a two bolt anchor. Better as a top rope. Anchors can be accessed by walking up on climbers right.
protection: small rack of cams and nuts~ 2 bolt anchor~ rap from sharkfin or walk off.

location: Manzanita Wall > South Peak Crags > Chinese Mountains > Quadra Island > Vancouver Island > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Fun route with ample bolt protection to encourage the beginning leader. Begin up the short lower block on the brown rock to the ledge (5.7) (take care with loose rock on the ledge). Climb up the steep wall above the ledge on positive holds and generous bolt protection (5.7). Make a committing step right to gain an angled ramp and arête. Follow the ramp leftward (5.5) with increasing exposure & stunning views on good rock and big holds.

location: Main Cliff > Eagle's Nest > Nova Scotia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Up wall and arete right of Sea Gully. Gain the big ledge then finish on Sea Gully.

location: 8.Le Sommet > Dalquier > 08. Abitibi-Temiscamingue, Nord du Quebec > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Voie sportive sur dalle. Crux situé vers le milieu au passage du gros bloc à la dalle lisse plus foncé.  Sport route on slab. Crux is located in the middle~ the crossing from the large block to the slab.
protection: 6 ancrages + 2 pour le relais  6 bolts + 2 bolts anchor

location: a. Gauche de l'aiguille > L'Aiguille > Val-David > 15. Laurentians > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Follow a series of flakes and cracks going up a dihedral.

location: Jellyfish wall > DFO (The Skerries) > St John's Area > Avalon Peninsula > Newfoundland > Newfoundland and Labrador > Canada > North America > International
desc: Start the same as Moon Jelly but follow the crack up and to the left.

location: Outhouse Wall > The Back of The Lake > Lake Louise > Banff National Park > Alberta > Canada > North America > International
desc: Climb the obvious crack before traversing right to clip the four bolts above to the anchor.

location: Buffalo Crag > Rattlesnake Point > Golden Horseshoe > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: Loose face through tree branches

location: Yellow Card Wall > The Swamp > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: none listed

location: 16 - Sector Local > Jilotepec > Central Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Crux over the bulge

location: Ground Zero > Nuevo Bayamón > Puerto Rico > North America > International
desc: Big holds to the first bolt. Clip the second bolt from below and match hands on the slopey ledge. The crux comes from the second bolt to the fourth. Use the vertical slot with the right hand~ move your feet up and use the huge flake as an undercling to get you up and thru. From there it is easier.    Note after the 5th bolt it is very runout but easy.

location: Chuck Chuck Creek > Squamish Valley > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Big moves through big holds to a roof. Nice basalt features at the top.

location: Slhanay > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: This line shares the first two pitches of Birds of Prey. It is characterized by a steep handcrack~ a few exposed traverses~ delicate footwork~ and a weird groove to finish the route.  Pitch 1   An awesome finger and hand crack goes for a whole rope length that ends at a bolted station. 70m 5.8  Pitch 2  Aim for the hand crack on your right then delicately step left into exposure and traverse until you reach a bolted anchor. 30m  5.10b  Pitch 3  Move left to the easy slab and then around a tree. Climb up to a ledge and then traverse left~ there should be a bolt at the traverse and then a bolted anchor. 20m 5.9  Pitch 4  Climb into the perplexing corner system. Face holds and desperate crack moves take you to a bolted anchor. 25m 5.10c   Pitch 5  A groove above will test your balance and footwork it arcs to the right~ crank on the wobbling hold to escape onto the slab finish above. 20m 5.10d  Walk off
protection: double rack of cams from purple metolius to #3 camalot and a single set of nuts

location: East Wall Trail > Harrison Bluffs > Fraser Valley > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Recleaned route at left end of the Smoked Salmon/Babolious crag. Climb face to left of left-leaning seam. Left hand on arete~ right hand in seam~ bear hug moves in a few places.
protection: Two bolts~ small nuts~ #2 camalot. Rap anchor on top.

location: La Selva (Jungle Wall) > El Potrero Chico > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: As with other Jungle Wall climbs~ the first pitches are straight forward exercises in light crimping and nice hueco pulling. The 4th class scramble pitch in the Garden of Bleedin' breaks up the vertical. The crux is the part right before the overhang. Thin~ crumbly rock makes getting to the larger holds on the overhang more difficult than it at first appears. Surmount the actually easier overhang and then you come to another very fun and unique pitch. There are deep dihedrals that completely block out your left/right view of the canyon. This pitch was my favorite. A few more pitches later and you are at the summit ridge. Rappel the route the same way you came up using the same belay stations.    Pitches:    1. 5.9   2. 5.10b   3. 5.6   4. 3rd class through Garden of Bleedin'   5. 5.9 flakes~ start of long~ black streak   6. 5.10 big roof   7. 5.10d   8. 5.10b dihedral pitch   9. 5.9 to ridgeline
protection: 14 quickdraws usually works for most routes in the Potrero. A single 60 meter rope is the minimum length you should climb on here.

location: Black Forest Wall > Old Baldy > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: Thin crack system left of French Revolution. One bolt and some protection will get you to the top. Just left of the very obvious crack system.

location: Right Teta > Cerro Las Tetas (Cayey) > Puerto Rico > North America > International
desc: Pitch 1 is 5.10a~ has 8 bolts~ and is about 90 feet. There are two sets of chains: first for top rope~ second for belaying the second pitch.    Pitch 2 is 5.10d~ has 15 bolts~ and is about 95 feet. There's a nice belay ledge at the top of this pitch.    Pitch 3 is 5.9~ has 8 bolts~ and is about 55 feet. It's best to be lowered down to the ledge to belay the second~ avoiding an awkward hanging belay.

location: Breakfast Club Peak > Tarahumara Pass > El Potrero Chico > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Climb 5am Breakfast to access the garden below the east face of the Breakfast Pillar. Blackstar begins to the right of the large corner and ascends a series of blocky ledges and corners to a ribbon of rock below the P2 anchors. Just after the 4th bolt on P3~ step off the ribbon and onto the corner and climb up the summit block. Bring a couple of slings if you aren't comfortable with 5.8 runout terrain. Named after the David Bowie song of the same title. FA: February 16~ 2017 by Brian Tickle and Frank Madden. FFA: February 20~ 2017 by Brian Tickle and Evan Larsell.   P1: 5.10d~ 9 draws~ 75 ft.  P2: 5.10d~ 10 draws~ 86 ft.  P3: 5.8~ 7 draws~ 74 ft.
protection: Bolted. Stainless 1/2" x 2.75" powers 5-piece rawl + stainless climbtech hangers.

location: Graceland Area > Grassi Lakes > Bow Valley > Alberta > Canada > North America > International
desc: Long sustained face climbing. Crux up high at small overlap around third last bolt.

location: Tower of Tails > Okanagan > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: From the approach from the road~ go around to the north side of the tower and find a wide overhanging crack on the north face. Start up the offwidth crack and jam or layback the overhanging crack until it turns into a nice hand or thin hands crack. Continue jamming or laybacking up the pumpy face to a good stemming rest before coming over the initial lip of the climb (be careful of swinging away from the wall here if on TR as it is very overhung). From here follow the finger cracks and face to the large tree sitting on the ledge above.
protection: If leading~ BD #.3-4 with optional #5 and/or a #6 for the start (if you don't like offwidths). Large cordelette and two #2 and one #3 camalot to set up a TR

location: Morphine Ledge > Mount Nemo > Golden Horseshoe > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: Gear at the bottom~ bolts up top~ anchor. Starts on easy terrain with plenty of pro and gets harder beginning at the slanted crack under the roof. Exit right to a small ledge and the first bolt. Continue up to the anchors on bolts. Bring an alpine draw for your last piece under the roof~ and perhaps a somewhat longer sport draw to minimize rope drag at one bolt
protection: Standard rack; a 0.5 cam will protect the roof~ along with an alpine (120cm) draw. Sport draws for the upper section~ though a single longer one partway up will prevent the rope from running over a small edge.

location: (b) Kid's Cliff > (e) Northern Crags > Skaha > Okanagan > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Good climb with a solid looking pin for the third bolt (May 2015).

location: El Escalon > Jalisco > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Still unknow. Further research is needed.

location: Into the Shade > Devil's Glen > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: Easy cruising to an exceptional step move~ tricky mantle and overhanging crux finale.

location: The Courtyard > Mamquam FSR > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Shared start with "Dirtbaggers". Fork left after the third bolt and head up the nose-shaped feature.

location: Graceland Area > Grassi Lakes > Bow Valley > Alberta > Canada > North America > International
desc: Great face climbing with a low crux and building pump.

location: Pasillo > Nuevo Bayamón > Puerto Rico > North America > International
desc: Beautiful route with beautiful moves.  Finding a few key holds could mean the difference between an on-sight or red point.
protection: 8 bolts to chain anchors at top

location: Viejo Bayamón > Puerto Rico > North America > International
desc: What a great route~ a must do.  Great holds and moves all the way to the top.  The move from the forth to fifth bolt can be done as a tough static move or an exhilarating dead point to a jug.

location: Chibougamau > 08. Abitibi-Temiscamingue, Nord du Quebec > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Monter sur la terrasse et grimper au centre de la face.

location: 01. Jagueyana > Mogote del Valle > Vinales > Cuba > North America > International
desc: This route looks super easy but will offer a good fight.

location: Sector 1 > Lake Amatitlan > Guatemala > North America > International
desc: Newest route in Amati as of April 2019. This route may still have some chossy holds so tread carefully.

location: Mota Wall > El Potrero Chico > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Climbs through a small alcove.

location: Grand Central > Comox Lake > Comox Lake > Vancouver Island > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: A blocky start with a thin middle section (small nuts) finish with a nice crack and good rests.

location: Viejo Bayamón > Puerto Rico > North America > International
desc: Interesting with exciting top moves~ can be done from Pringamosa start for an extended line~ moss covered rocks won't get in the way.
protection: 4 Bolts and chain anchors. Belay anchor.

location: Salt and Pepper Wall > Barrier Bluffs Sport Climbs (Mount Baldy) > Kananaskis > Alberta > Canada > North America > International
desc: This is a crimp heaven or nightmare~ depending on your crimp tolerance.     Climb to the same anchor as salt and pepper.

location: Foundation Wall > Chek > Sea to Sky (Squamish to Whistler) > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: This fine face looks pocketed from below~ but once you're on it you realize that what looked like pockets are actually shallow dishes.  The climbing is technical~ sequency~ footwork intensive and sustained despite the short length of the climb.  If 10d is your limit~ this will be a proud and rewarding send.
protection: six bolts to a two bolt anchor

location: Los Chileros > San Isidro Canyon > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Climb the orange rock crux down low.  Climb the diagonal jugs and then finish up some grey rock to the anchor

route: Ponte el casco y aprieta el culo
location: Dante > Nuevo Bayamón > Puerto Rico > North America > International
desc: consistente

location: Air Jamaica Wall > Old Baldy > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: Follow the layback flake to the bulge. Go left around it and a cedar tree~ then continue up the face to anchors.

location: (d) Upper Red Tail > (b) Red Tail Group > Skaha > Okanagan > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Lots of bolts~ fine consistent face~ sustained first half~ great exposure.

location: Sector 1 > Lake Amatitlan > Guatemala > North America > International
desc: Be careful on this route as some of the falls could have an awkward landing. The Crux is at the last 2 bolts.

location: Lower Virgin > Virgin Canyon > El Potrero Chico > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: The route starts easy in the flake up to a high first bolt.  The route gradually gets more difficult with the crux going over a slight bulge.

location: Little Russia > Nordegg > Alberta > Canada > North America > International
desc: Harder than it looks. Start on easy slabby moves and get into overhanging arete puzzle. Solve it and finish on easy jugs! Named after Ryan Musteca.

location: Navajas > La Huasteca > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: No information

location: 01. Jagueyana > Mogote del Valle > Vinales > Cuba > North America > International
desc: After the second bolt~ this one goes straight up in the half-pipe. The route finishes at the same anchor as Arco de Josué.

location: Sector 3 > Lake Amatitlan > Guatemala > North America > International
desc: Great example of slab climbing. tricky balancy moves all the way to the top. The route sits in the shade for most of the day.

location: Hig's Zone > Higgyland > Powell River > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Newly bolted after many holds had broken~ the lower half sequence creates a very new line of great movement. Use a few long draws to make it easier to clean as it zig zags quite a bit.
protection: 8 Bolts~ long draws or slings advised for the 3rd and 4th bolts.

location: Sunnyside Wall > Sunnyside > Welsford > New Brunswick > Canada > North America > International
desc: Very short route at the right end of the wall.

location: a. Grandioso gauche > E. Grandioso > Lac du Cap > 14. Lanaudiere > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Classique menant au sommet  P1 (5.10b) Trad PG~ 3 bolts~ 50m (35m au 1er relais)    Progressez dans le dièdre largement fissuré à gauche de Cape et D'Épée~résolvez les passages avant et sur les bolts~rétablissez l'inconfortable vire puis lancez vous dans la fissure à mains. Vous pouvez linker les 2 premières longueurs pour un pitch de 50m.  FA Pat P./Bénédict Morin 31 mai 2015   P2 (5.5) Trad PG/R~ 15m   Poursuivez dans le dièdre/fissure au rocher instable(protections précaires) jusqu'au relais sur le 'chilling ledge'.   FA  Pat P./François Gosselin 11 octobre 2015   P3 (5.11a) Trad PG~ 5 bolts~ 15m   Quittez ce confort et suivez les bolts vers la gauche puis dans une section légèrement déversante jusqu'au relais sur une petite vire.   FA Pat P./Marie-Ève Généreux/François Gosselin 11 octobre 2015   P4 (5.10+) Trad G~ 3 bolts~ 35m   Suivez les systèmes fissurés~traversez vers la droite sous les feuillets et affrontez le dièdre aérien en 'jugs' et ''hand jams'. Sortez par un autre petit dièdre et faites votre relais sur un des arbres.    Il est préférable que vous assuriez le second sur les arbres en sortant du petit dièdre final plutôt que sur les plaquettes/anneaux de rappel sur le muret à quelques mètres à gauche...vous éviterez ainsi de mal pouvoir communiquer et minimiserez la friction de la corde.   FA Pat P./Isabelle Courcy  17 juin 2016    FFA Éric Tremblay 17 juin 2016
protection: Rack de base (Metolius #00 à BD #3 -2x BD #2)   BD #5 optionnel 1er pitch sinon 5.7R.   Relais équipés sauf sommet(arbre)   Rappels équipés(plaquettes/anneaux)

location: Culo De Gato > Las Ventanas De Mina > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Line follows left of the black streak~ right of Cat Gut. Thin holds appear as you climb so another great steep slab route. Rap to the bolts just right of the black streak during the descent.

location: Bulletheads North > The Bulletheads > The Chief > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: This is an excellent route that offers incredible position up the arete just right of Eurasian Eyes.   From the start of Turkey ledge~ climb into a tricky flare (bolt protected) and work your way up until reaching a nice hand crack.  Somewhat moderate climbing leads up and slightly left before a pumpy layback finish before the chains.
protection: A single rack should do it~ but a second #2 camalot might be handy

location: Quercus Cliff > Murrin Park > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: The route's name is a cool mash-up of the FA's last names...    This is a fun~ short exercise in laybacks and underclings. At the start~ good gear will be had but you'll need to go up a bit to get it (be mindful of that big hollow sounding block you're putting pro in). As the line arcs left~ obvious underclings with good footwork take you to the small ledge and the anchor. If you want more~ there's a mixed gear/bolts extension to another anchor (Four Inches Radder~ 5.11).
protection: Gear to 2" but some people may want doubles around finger sizes...

location: 15. Cueva Cabeza de Vaca > Mogote del Valle > Vinales > Cuba > North America > International
desc: Line to the RIGHT of the tree. Overhanging jugs to a crimp crux this one will keep at you the whole way.

location: The Watchtower > Porteau Cove > Vancouver Area > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Easy start leading to a steeper headwall.

location: Shannon Falls Wall > Shannon Falls > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: New multipitch that starts on Cardhu Crack and keeps going. A mix of different styles and difficulties.  This could use some traffic. It was fairly dirty when we climbed it~ though I imagine we were one of the first parties of the season. Plenty of pine needles and detritus caught in the cracks~ so take a nut tool as you climb.  P1: Cardhu Crack. You'll want to climb past the Cardhu anchors up to a ledge with rap rings. (5.8~ 45m)  P2: Climb up and right~ then traverse left along an easy hand crack on a ramp. Tree anchor. (5.6~ 15m)  P3: Climb right up a diagonal finger crack. The FAist describes this as a hand crack~ but you'd need pretty small hands for that to be accurate. Balancy and tough - will get easier when it cleans up with more traffic~ but will get harder again when the stumps eventually fall out. When clean~ this will be a very nice line. Bolt anchor~ belay in a hole. (5.10-~ 25m)  P4: The crux pitch is a beautiful and sustained line with tough~ engaging climbing. Traverse right~ clip a bolt~ chimney up through easier ground on larger gear. Clip two more bolts as you begin tackling the main feature: a thin seam in a little mini-dihedral (like two inches of left-facing corner) . Looks improbable for the grade as the seam is almost slammed shut~ but eventually the crack does open up slightly to take some small gear (yellow C3s to purple C3s). After your first piece of gear~ tips locks and eventually a finger lock or two begin to reveal themselves as the angle eases up. The crack peters out at the top~ so slab climb past 2 more bolts at a mid-10 grade. This pitch is very balancy and technical in nature. I'd read that you could easily aid through the thin section~ but I don't know - you probably could aid through it with enough RPs~ but this isn't a french-free-through-a-few-moves sort of pitch. Bolt anchor. (5.11-~ 40m)  P5: Climb a short~ steep and juggy right-leaning crack to a tree above the belay. Slab and a cool dyke traverse up to the bolt-anchors. 2 bolts~ and few cracks for gear every now and then. (5.9 - 35m)  P6: Walk into the forest~ then climb a fun~ long and easy pitch. Starts off sporty~ with many jugs and foot holds and lots of different gear options. As you climb higher~ the pitch becomes lower angle and slabbier in nature. Near a bolt there is a 5.8 slab move. I think there was 2 bolts on this pitch~ but there may have been 3. Bolt anchor. (5.8 - 40m).  To descend~ traverse left~ then right up a ramp. From there a faint trail leads south to the Skywalker walk-off.
protection: Double rack from red C3 to #2 Camalots~ single #3 Camalot~ green C3 and purple C3. Slings for the upper pitches.

location: El Escalon > Jalisco > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Hands to fingers at the start~ the crux is bulge with fingers to tight hands

location: West Side > El Reliz de los Venados > La Presa Francisco Zarco > Durango > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Coming soon

location: Tunnel Mountain > Banff National Park > Alberta > Canada > North America > International
desc: A very blank crux

location: Old World > The Swamp > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: none listed

location: Corn Flakes > 08. Abitibi-Temiscamingue, Nord du Quebec > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Petit dièdre au début

location: Applebee bouldering > The Bugaboos > Purcell Mountains > Columbia Mountains > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Applebee Crack is a fun diversion on a rest day or if the weather is a bit sketchy.
protection: Either free solo the route~ with occasionally a snow patch below to provide "protection"~ or bring a few cams in the BD #2/3 size.

location: First Face > Nova Scotia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Climb directly up a series of ledges to the top of a large block on your left. Step right to gain the corner and stem and/or face climb your way up to gain a right-angling ramp. Watch for some loose blocks at the top of the corner. [Note: an alternate start is to climb the diagonal hand crack in the large block just to the left (5.8). First climbed by Dan Price in 1990.]

location: Night and Day Wall > Suicide Bluff > Sea to Sky (North of Whistler) > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Face and Corner climbing. Shared anchor with Raven.

location: House of Cards > Cougar Canyon (Creek) - CONSTRUCTION IN PROGRESS > Bow Valley > Alberta > Canada > North America > International
desc: Good climbing for a long time. The easiest way to clean is to use your second~ lower to the SPF anchor and then to the ground

location: Main Wall > Comox Lake > Comox Lake > Vancouver Island > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Stem and finger jam the cracks up the the daunting roof~ undercling out left.

location: La Source > Kékéko > 08. Abitibi-Temiscamingue, Nord du Quebec > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Cote à confirmer

location: Hail Mary Wall > Kinnaird Bluffs > Castlegar > Kootenays West > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Left facing corner.

location: Lonely Boy > Lonely Crags > Okanagan > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Follows two aretes and shares a finish with Miss Carriage. Juggy climbing on the first half and a slighlty committing move towards the end.

location: Queen Wall > Kingston Crag > New Brunswick > Canada > North America > International
desc: A small 8 scramble will bring you to a wet ledge at the base of the crack. This beautiful crack ranges in size requiring various crack climbing techniques and is a great asset to the area.

location: Pika Palace > White Mountain > Yukon Territory > Canada > North America > International
desc: Start in the left side of the crack off the ground~ and use large holds to gain the ledge. From here~ enjoy the filthy chimney! You can use a combination of face holds on the outside and squeezing up the inside to progress upward and gain the anchor. Its dirty in there~ but trust me~ it used to be much worse. Bring a broom!
protection: Bolted top anchor~ with rap ring. 5 bolts on the way up.

location: Auntie Gravity > The Smoke Bluffs > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Varied face climbing to a mantle 3/4s of the way up.

location: Crapaud de mer > 03. Quebec City, Charlevoix, Portneuf > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Unknown difficulty.  Difficulté inconnue.

location: Shelf Road > Cal-Cheak > Sea to Sky (Squamish to Whistler) > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Well featured slightly right trending route. Fun!

location: Main Face > Flatrock > Avalon Peninsula > Newfoundland > Newfoundland and Labrador > Canada > North America > International
desc: Climb a face past seven bolts~ with an inobvious cruxy traverse in the middle. The route has been cleaned heavily but staying in line with the bolts is advised - the rock to the right and left of the route is pretty loose.

location: (b) Rattlesnake Ledge > (h) Small Eastern Crags > Skaha > Okanagan > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: A fun crackline offering good finger to tight-hands jamming~ with ample rest positions utilizing footholds surrounding the crack. Would warrant more stars if it were a tad longer. Splitter by Skaha standards.

location: Grand Central Station > Rock Gardens > Yukon Territory > Canada > North America > International
desc: Follow the crack where Crucifix starts but instead of heading straight up head right to the arete following the crack system to the top of the cliff.

location: Parc Récréoforestier de Saint-Mathieu > 04. Mauricie > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Départ intéressant dans un coin légèrement déversant; mène à une vire avec un pin. Le toit menant à la vire est intéressant mais encore un peu sale. Le topo recommande de finir la première longueur ici~ mais les deux longueurs peuvent être facilement faites en une. Rejoindre le relais de "Tu m'embêtes". Il est possible d'utiliser les 3 plaquettes de la fin de "Tu m'embêtes" dans la deuxième longueur.  Interesting start in a slightly overhanging corner. It goes up to a ledge with a pine tree. The roof getting to the ledge is interesting but still a bit dirty. Topo says to belay from the ledge~ but can be linked as one full pitch to the top with the anchors from "Tu m'embetes". Towards the end there are about 3 bolts from that route.
protection: Standard rack. A C4 #4 is useful for the second pitch. Long slings to link the 2 pitches in one.

location: Sector 2 > Lake Amatitlan > Guatemala > North America > International
desc: Bolted By: Luis Amezquita  Black #1 on Sector 2 Topo Picture  As its name suggests~ it is a super short route. It could be done as boulder if you brought a crash pad. Easy crack climbing with a little spice to be worth doing the route.
protection: 5 Quickdraws Needed. 3 bolts. 1 chain protects the top. More than enough considering you wont be taking factor 2 falls from this route.

location: East End of Rundle (EEOR) > Bow Valley > Alberta > Canada > North America > International
desc: A great route on generally good rock.  The climbing on the water runnels mid-route are fantastic.  The climbing is 5.7-5.8 for the most part~ with 3 pitches of 5.9~ and many bolts for protection.  There is a picture below of a topo from Im assuming the FA.   P1: 55m 5.6 P2: 45m 5.7 P3: 50m 5.7 P4: 40m 5.8 P5: 40m 5.6 P6: 40m 5.9 P7: 40m 5.6 P8: 50m 5.9 P9: 50m 5.8 P10 50m 5.7 P11: 55m 5.9 P12: 50m 5.6 P13: 15m 5.5

location: Genesis walls > Playa Frontón > Dominican Republic > North America > International
desc: Follow the obvious crack line ascending left side of Genesis wall

location: Yellow Sling Wall > Kinnaird Bluffs > Castlegar > Kootenays West > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: none listed

location: AMO Wall > Shannon Falls > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: This is the left-most pitch off the upper ledge and is about 10m left of the third pitch of The Relish Route.  Technical and fun traversing dyke feature.

location: Hans Lollik, Black Diamond > Virgin Islands > North America > International
desc: Start as with Slalom (start bottom right of Black Diamond~ go up and right to white vein) but continue past white vein and folow a weakness up and eventually right to the top. Gainer off the top??!!!

location: Tulip Falls > Castlegar > Kootenays West > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: It’s just like Gimli Peak except 15m high and crappy.

location: The Gnar Wall > Gnar Wall > Nova Scotia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Start at waters edge and traverse left~ over the lake~ through sidepulls & underclings to reach a bolt. Climb up a flake to a 2nd bolt. Pull crux move to gain left trending ramp. Follow the ramp left to reach an easy (and runout) slab that leads to the top of Mr. Gnarwhal. Finish at Mr. Gnarwhal tree anchor or traverse right on crimps to Gnarchetype rap rings.  Variation:  Immediately after crux~ traverse right to finish on Mr. Gnarwhal.
protection: Mixed: 2 bolts~ standard rack. Tree anchor or rap rings.

location: Old Goat Crag > Bow Valley > Alberta > Canada > North America > International
desc: Easy climbing up to a headwall~ then some fun moves up to the anchor.  The crux is the final move before the anchor.  Second pitch is 5.7 (Dancing with Mr. D).

location: Kanga Creek South > Bow Valley > Alberta > Canada > North America > International
desc: Godzilla is the newest addition to the fun short multipitch routes bolted by Brandon Pullan at Kanga Crag. It climbs some great rock but as a new-ish route there is still some loose rock so like any rockies climbs a helmet is strongly recommended. The route can be done with 10 quickdraws and a 70 meter rope although might be possible with a 60 meter as all pitches are just about 30 meters.  As mentioned above~ helmets are a must but please be careful not to throw any rocks down on the road below.  P1: 5.7~ 10 bolts. This pitch starts next to a tree and follows an arrete until you get to a comfortable belay ledge. The tree at the end of the pitch is good to grab.  P2: 5.9~ 6 bolts. The crux pitch~ follow a leftward line of bolts to a small roof~ around the arrete to a few exposed moves on a slab. Once over the ledge~ walk to the anchor.  P3: 5.8~ 8 bolts. Start up a sweet right facing corner onto some face climbing. You'll reach a steep bulge eventually~ at this point clip the bolt and trend left for some more fun climbing. Mantle to belay ledge.  P4: 5.9~ 10 bolts. Arguably the best rock of this climb. Pass some trees (right or left doesn't matter) to a corner slab. Stay left of bolts until stem move that leads you into thin slab climbing to belay ledge.  Descent: 4 30 meter rappels. For the third rappel~ aim to rappel straight down the chimney instead of around the crux arrete. Be careful of falling rock when pulling the rope.null
protection: 10 quickdraws~ 70 meter rope~ helmets. Fully bolted.

location: Neat and Cool > The Smoke Bluffs > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Thin .4 bomber finger crack. The start to reach the first lock is the 'crux' . Then its a short sequence of bomber locks. No bolts as anchor. But the crack continue on the top so a gear anchor is doable to clean. But seriously~ just bring a crash pad ans solo it:)
protection: No anchors. All small gear .4 and smaller.

location: d. Côté droit > Lac Gervais > 15. Laurentians > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: 6 feet left of the flake route

location: A. Banlieue > Lac du Cap > 14. Lanaudiere > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Beautiful trad line which will test your jamming skills~ a classic!  Bel itinéraire trad qui requiert quelques coincements de mains...à ne pas manquer!

location: 04. Prestation > L'Amphitheatre > Saint-Andre-de-Kamouraska > 01. Bas-Saint-Laurent > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: first bolt is a bit high

location: g. Champs-Élysées > Mont-Césaire > Val-David > 15. Laurentians > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Belle voie un peu soutenue~ avec de bonnes prises tout le long  Nice route a bit sustained~ with great holds all along.

location: B. School > St-Alban > 03. Quebec City, Charlevoix, Portneuf > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: The slight overhang at the start is the main crux~ once past the first bolt it's a cruise.

location: D. Gendarmes > Lac du Cap > 14. Lanaudiere > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Départ en contorsions puis suivre le dièdre peu incliné.   Les choses se corsent à l'approche du toit.   Superbe voie naturelle ouverte 'ground up'!
protection: Full rack en doublant les tailles moyennes.    Relais équipé

location: Caliche (Ciales) > Puerto Rico > North America > International
desc: A fun route worth a go~ especially to experience the great holds and moves at the top. The crux is at the bottom. Climb through two bolts and hard-to-find holds. From there the holds gradually get bigger and much better.
protection: Bomber steel glue-in bolts to chain anchors.

location: Le Paradis > 02. Saguenay-Lac-St-Jean > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Follow the beautiful corner to the top! Comfy belay before the last section. Whatch the sharp edges on the top of the route~ use rope protectors or hike down.  Suivre le beau dièdre jusqu'en haut! Relais confortable avant la dernière section. Attention au rebord coupant en haut de la voie~ utiliser des protections de corde ou redescendre à pied.
protection: Good pro. Standard rack.  Bonne protection. Rack standard

location: a. Main Wall > Vieux-Stoneham > 03. Quebec City, Charlevoix, Portneuf > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Climb the right hand crack to the decidely too large crack (large dulfer or knee jam) protected with 2 bolts.

location: Boondocks > The Pillary > Area 44 > Sea to Sky (Squamish to Whistler) > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Fun and easy. Nice crimps~ edges~ and jugs after the first half. A bit reachy at the top.

location: Timberwolf > Sudbury Area > Ontario North Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: Stay in between the parallel seams in the rock~ following the bolts.

location: C. Central > St-Alban > 03. Quebec City, Charlevoix, Portneuf > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: First moves are the crux...passing the first lip after the first bolt gets you onto easy ground to a fun but often dirty or slimy finish.
protection: 5 Bolts~ recommend a stick clip.    5 Plaquettes~ Stick Clip.

location: Crag X > The Smoke Bluffs > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Climb a short 5.8 hand to finger crack and mantle onto an enormous ledge. Clip a bolt on the left side of the arete and then make bouldery moves off the ledge~ firstly on the right side of the arete~ but moving left to the crest of the arete at the top. Pull onto a slab and climb easily up to the top ledge. Sling trees for an anchor.  An obvious line but spoiled by the huge ledge midway up which basically turns it into two separate boulder problems. Bolt exists only to prevent groundfall from the second boulder problem if you pitch leftwards off the arete. It doesn't do much to keep you off the ledge~ so a pad there can help if you're unwilling to commit. Originally done as a solo with no bolt.
protection: Bottom crack takes gear in the 1" range. The bolt will keep you from grounding but the climb is basically a boulder problem off the upper ledge so you might find a pad on the ledge as useful as the bolt~ if not more so.

location: Dirt Bag Corner > McQuirks Mountain > New Brunswick > Canada > North America > International
desc: Climb the crack to a sloping ledge then ascend a right leaning crack to the top.  Fairly sustained. Slightly run out at the top.

location: Cabin Boy's Office > The Smoke Bluffs > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Fun moves out a nice finger crack lead to some thinner climbing and a crux at the finish.     Start up either side of the large~ detached block in the center of the wall. At the top of the block trend left~ following a finger crack.  Eventually the crack peters out~ leaving a few moves of face before topping out.

location: Right Teta > Cerro Las Tetas (Cayey) > Puerto Rico > North America > International
desc: < To be completed. Please submit an edit / suggestion. >

location: Penny Lane > The Smoke Bluffs > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: This is a classic Smoke Bluff crack.  Start with a few boulder moves off the ground.  Move up into the shallow corner by stemming and jamming~ it eases up as it gets higher. Over the years~ a top anchor is cyclically installed and chopped. It is currently in the "chopped" condition and thus you must traverse the cliff top to the left and rappel from above Crime of the Century.    If you happen to know who is doing this~ tell them to cut that shit out. It's ridiculous and unwarranted - the Smoke Bluffs done been discovered~ it's a world-class destination for Pete's sake!

location: La Lulu > La Huasteca > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: No information

location: La Lulu > La Huasteca > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: No information

location: b. Secteur multi-pitch > Lac Gervais > 15. Laurentians > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: P1 5.7  P2 5.8 P3 to the left 5.9~ to the right 5.?
protection: Sport~ bolts + belays~ but~  first two pitches can be climbed mostly trad.  P1 Trad protection is excellent  but it's bolted crack P2 Mostly trad (good + 2 bolts) but it's bolted cracked face P3 Left and right are sport bolted faces  Sport~ bolts + relais~ mais~  les deux premières longueurs peuvent être grimpées en trad.  L1 La protection trad est excellente~ mais c'est une craque équipée en sport. L2 En majorité trad (bon + 2 bolts)~ mais c'est une face fissurée équipée en sport. L3  Vers la gauche ou la droite c'est une face équipé sport.

location: Rusted Goat Wall > White Mountain > Yukon Territory > Canada > North America > International
desc: Pitch 1: Consistent 5.9 slab climbing for 32m. This is the most difficult of the four pitches. 8 bolts. Pitch 2: Easiest of the four: Easy climbing leads to a short 5.6 section below the bulge. 4 bolts (25m) Pitch 3: First part is 5.9 slab again~ followed by more easy climbing. Heads to a sidewall on the left. 6 bolts (25m). Pitch 4: Just when you think it's all over~ this climb provides you with some spice for the last 2 bolts. 6 bolts (30m).
protection: Well placed bolts and rap rings at belay/rap stations.

location: Mount Athelstan > Sea to Sky (North of Whistler) > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: This route climbs the lower part of the very prominent arete between Selective Cut and Lillarete before moving left to join Lillarete below that route's crux pitch.    Climb 6 pitches on the arete~ to sustained 5.8/9~ with solid rock but minimal protection~ then traverse left into Lillarete near the diagonal crack pitch on that route. Finish up Lillarete.
protection: Wired nuts and cams to 3" plus a few thin pins. Crampons and ice axe for descent.

location: Prickly Pear Canyon > Kamloops > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Climb the crack to the right of beware and finish at the shared anchor

location: Phyllis' Engine > Garibaldi Park > Sea to Sky (Squamish to Whistler) > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Phyllis’ Engine – South Face Variation (5.9)  There are three obvious cracks on the south wall under the highest smokestack. Climb the rightmost crack next to the corner. Begins with a few meters of hand jams and quickly widens into an offwidth. This continues for a couple meters before solid hand jams~ ring locks~ and finger locks can be found. Traverse right afterwards to follow the low angle hand crack up to a slanted ledge – first belay.  Second pitch goes straight up the vertical cracks to the ledge. Traverse right into a hand crack and continue straight up. Mostly low angle except for the start and a small section in the middle.  Traverse around the summit smokestack to the east side and follow the hand crack to the top.  Rappel off slung blocks.  -------------- If climbing in the Spring~ the approach on skis is quite reasonable. Definitely climbable~ but expect ice and snow on the route. You will want to consider racking an ice axe to hack ice out of the cracks.

location: Mount Gimli > Valhalla Mountains > Kootenays West > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: none listed

location: Serra 2 > Serra-Stilletto Group > Waddington Range > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Hike uphill from Sunny Knob. Low 5th class interspersed with snow fields leads to the base of Phantom Tower in about 3~000 vertical feet. Traverse the right side of Phantom Tower and rappel a horribly loose pitch to the large notch. An excellent bivy can be found here. Climb the snow field up and right to a smaller notch and climb the rock buttress to the ridge crest (several pitches up to 5.9). Traverse the ridge crest (loose blocks and very exposed but easy climbing) to the notch below the summit block. The summit can be climbed in one long traversing pitch. Return to the notch and rappel the ice and snow gully on the back side of the notch to the Upper Tellot Glacier.
protection: A medium sized rock rack~ bail gear for raps~ maybe a picket or two.

location: Nesakwatch Spires > Western Chilliwack Range > Fraser Valley > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: This route climbs immediately right (north) of the Priest-Coupe couloir that divides Rexford from South Nesakwatch Spire. It is a fun 9-pitch rock climb~ but requires a long snow slog to reach and is best done early in the season before the snow melts. Crampons and ice axes are required for the approach. Most of the climbing is 5.7~ but there are a couple of short 5.9 sections that can be avoided. A very full day out~ especially if descending west into Nesakwatch Creek and then returning to a vehicle parked in Centre Creek
protection: A light rack from nuts to 3" cams is sufficient. Bring a 4" or 5" cam or big balls if climbing the offwidth summit block on South Nesakwatch.

location: The Apron > The Chief > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: If you have done Over the Rainbow  this older classic slab route is worth a try. You are guessing correctly that since it was done in 1970 it is sparsely bolted.    P1. Start same as Diedre and Rainbow~ where you pass the horizontal crack  Over the Rainbow goes straight up the greasy slab~ Sparrow goes a bit more to the right and follows the path of least resistance up ramp like right traverse heading for a lonely bolt~ clip and head for a small tree about level with the bolted belay of Rainbow on a faint horizontal dyke.    P2. About 40-50' above belay head left toward small trees( if you go up slab it is a run-out 10b variation) cross several overlaps angle back right toward big tree island and left facing corner.    P3. Either go straight up using water pockets~ or descend corner( original route) maybe 20' till you can go up obvious crack which peters out to a tricky slippery slab move up to big tree covered ledge.    P4. It can be confusing here which bolted line to follow. If you took the original route below it is the first line of bolts you come to going up the ledge to your left~ but maybe hard to spot bolts. The 2nd bolt line is the Delicious Dimples ( 10c) with more newer bolts. If you go all the way to your left you will hit the Over the Rainbow bolts.    P5. Wander up slab passing 2 bolts in like 100'~ going back and forth following path of least resistance till you see some crescent cracks but belay below on bolt and gear.    P6. Traverse left till you come to a good crack on right facing corner passing the Dimples route~ if you find yourself going up a steep slab you may be on Dimples( 10c). Go up this crack~ as it peters out go out onto slab on the left~ go up slab till you can belay on bolts below a left facing corner. McLane calls this pitch 10a~ Bourdon calls it 5.8~ I guess I would say it is 5.9.    P7. Follow corner up and go right out onto white slab ~ comes out near base of Boomstick crack.
protection: standard rack to 2".Lots of slings even for bolts to help with wandering nature of the route.

location: Tranchant - Left > Montagne du Tranchant > 14. Lanaudiere > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: P1: 5.7~ 2B+Trad~ 22m/72ft   Start on the top platform under 2 bolts and head up to a flake and cedar.    P2: 5.9~ Trad~ 15m/49   Go up the slightly overhanging corner and exit the roof to your right.

location: Cat Wall > Virgin Canyon > El Potrero Chico > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Another of the Cat Wall's high quality climbs that consists of jug hauling to a crack crux.

location: Gappage Zone > Higgyland > Powell River > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Although one of the only routes requiring a full rack at Higgy Land~ this is one of the best. The gear can be poor~ bring some slings. A bolt takes some of the fear out of the crux but it would still be a huge whip if the gear pulled. Pumpy with a steep crux.     Both free ascents to date were worked out on TR first~ but watch the swing in the first half~ as you can hit the wall on the other side.

location: Main Wall > Comox Lake > Comox Lake > Vancouver Island > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Climbs a slightly overhanging rounded face. Tough climbing on crimps through the technical crux leads to a moderate crack and fun knobs/face to finish.

location: Main Face > Flatrock > Avalon Peninsula > Newfoundland > Newfoundland and Labrador > Canada > North America > International
desc: Technical face climbing with interesting exit moves. Stay out of the corner up top for full value.

location: Top Shelf > Mamquam FSR > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Thin and technical sums it up.  Use twin cracks and the occasional face hold to make your way up.  The cracks have decent locks~ but are also a bit flaring.  I was able to get several "finger lock + flared hand jams" and the occasional layback.  Focus on your footwork as you can get good feet in the pods and flares.  The climb broke down to having three hard sections (each harder than the last)~ separated by good~ active rests.  Once you hit the arete~ there's still some pumpy finger locks that get you to the chains.
protection: Mostly thin up to a 0.5 camalot.  Stoppers.  You can place a #1~ but it will get in the way of the only real hand jam!  Fixed anchors.

location: Chibougamau > 08. Abitibi-Temiscamingue, Nord du Quebec > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Même départ que Tipus mais à la troisième bolt continué tout droit sur l'arrête. Le crux est à doigt entre la 3 et la 4.

location: Snowpatch Spire > The Bugaboos > Purcell Mountains > Columbia Mountains > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: This route is a direct (and easier) version of Minotaur and follows a number of old aid lines as well as new terrain including the 1st 4 pitches through the large rock scar. Fully bolted belays and easy to rappel~ this is a nice sustained adventure up the east face of snow patch. It needs more gardening/scrubbing to reach its full potential~ and for a party that has the time fully excavating the cracks on the upper pitches and scrubbing off some of the lichen could make this as clean as Sunshine Crack! Full story of the first ascent and good beta found here: alpinestyle.ca/locations/bu….    P1 and P2: Start off the snow at the base of the wall on the left side of the obvious scoop in the rock scar. Climb up hand cracks (5.10-)~ cross the scoop (possible gear belay) then continue up the slabby but thinner corner (5.10+) to a two bolt anchor. This can be climbed in 1 pitch with a 70m (60m may work early season). Difficulty and length dependent on the amount of snow at the base.    P3 5.10+~ 30m: Climb the corner above and pull through a small overhang. Step left and up a shallow left facing corner~ until an easy ramp leads to flakes back right. Hand traverse these until you reach a two bolt belay.    P4 5.11+~ 35m: Great long pitch with three distinct crux sections. Pull through a thin section of tips down low that changes into a stem corner~ at the top of this corner move left clipping a bolt and pulling face moves onto the arete out left~ then cut back right into the corner. A few very thin stemming/ chimney moves (small gear) bring you up to another two bolt anchor.    P5 5.10+~ 50m: This is what you (maybe) brought the #5 for. Climb the steep fist crack off the belay and then layback over the bulge with the wide pod. Once you are established above this bulge~ look up above you for the bolt~ clip it and climb up and left into the right leaning corner above with a nice handcrack. Follow this easier climbing up and right until you reach the big ledge~ then traverse this up and left to a two bolt anchor with rings~ beneath a rightward trending groove.    These first five pitches are shared with Welcome to the Machine (a route that should definitely be added by someone who has climbed it). The Welcome to the Machine anchors are just to the left beneath the obvious flake.    P6~ 5.10+~ 30m: climb up into the groove~ clip two knifeblades and then face climb up to a two bolt anchor.    P7~ 5.11+~ 35m: Climb the finger crack~ traversing left and then back right into the main crack. Get some gear at the roof and then pull it. Mostly 5.10 fingers other than the roof pull. Anchor to the left on the slab above.    P8 5.11a~ 30m: Climb up and clip the bolt~ then traverse the slab to the right~ until reaching the base of the left leaning~ left facing corner. Head up this (micro cams and rps) until reaching two pins. Climb up into the main corner (another pin and 2 bolts followed by gear) and continue up to a bolted belay.    P9 5.10~ 55m Look up and right to the steeper~ left facing wall with a number of good looking cracks~ you are headed to the base of this. Mostly easy climbing with a short finger crack crux. Climb up the corner until just below the grassy ledge. Step right and traverse up on ledgy terrain until reaching a two bolt anchor. This is a nice bivy ledge for those who might want more time to do the route.    P10 5.9~ 20m: Climb up the best of the cracks~ belay station on the left but easy to link with the next pitch.    P11 5.11a~ 30m: Climb the right crack on good hands until it slims down to a thin finish into the alcove and a bolted belay.    P12 5.10+~ 35m: Climb up the crack on the left for 5m and then make a reachy moves with some face features to the crack on the right that parallels the arete. Follow this crack up over the lip to a bolted belay. This pitch might feel harder and could use a good scrubbing.    P13 5.9~ 30m~ Climb the chimney (easy but runout) to the top of the pinnacle. Can link this with P12 with a 70m.    P14 5.11c~ 30m: Pull bouldery moves in the thin left slanting crack off the belay~ passing 3 bolts. The crack then eases in difficulty and takes you up to a nice belay ledge.    P15 5.11~ 30m: This is the pitch that made me want to do this climb. Follow a fist crack up the left side of the pillar~ then look up in awe at the splitter thin hands crack through the headwall above. Rest up then punch it up thin jams. You could place 3x #0.75 or #1 camalots on this pitch~ but for the strong crack climber a double rack from #0.5 to #1 would be adequate.    P16 5.10~ continue up the crack as the angle kicks back and it gradually widens. Step right around the bulge and continue up a groove to a bolted belay.    You could scramble up to the summit (4th class?) or just start rapping the route. 2x 60m required to rap. Not all bolted anchors have rings/quicklinks so pay attention on the way up to figure out which to skip. From the top of P4 a 60m rap will take you to the top of P2~ then one more rap back to the snow (note that this won't be where you started~ so think about where to leave the packs~ we threw ours down onto the glacier to make them easier to get back to).
protection: Double rack from #0 C3 to #3 Camalot~ + 1x #00 C3~ Set of nuts and RPs and an extra 0.3 tips piece.    Optional: #4 (may help protect P15 fist crack~ placeable but not particularly useful on any other pitch) #5 (may help protect P5 pod moves~ can be left at P5 anchor) and an extra 0.75 or #1 for the thin hands splitter~ maybe an extra 0.4 for the fingers sections. We could have done without all of these pieces but neither of us fell on lead.

location: El Escalon > Jalisco > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Obvious splitter-off width  to the right of La Tamalera. Waiting to be done

location: Cueva de la Cumbia > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Right most route

location: The North Walls > The Chief > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: FA: 11/2013 - Danny Guestrin~ Jon Rigg~ Ben Stanley~ Dave Brown~ Dom Ngo~ Chris Dinner~ Will Kahlert FFA: 05/2016 – Danny Guestrin~ Jon Rigg~ Laurent Janssen  Nanook follows steep cracks and corners on the lower-left side of the North Walls. This well-protected route features wild and varied climbing with exciting positions. It was first climbed as a winter adventure and upon reaching the top it was clear this line needed to be cleaned for its free climbing potential.  Pitch 1 (5.11d~ 30m): Clip a bolt and climb right to gain a partially bolted left-facing offwidth corner to a ledge. Make slabby moves up and left to a thin crack in a shallow corner. At the top of the corner~ step right and face climb to a bolted belay on a ledge.  Pitch 2 (5.11b~ 35m): Climb the double corners above the belay and move right to gain the major left-facing corner system. Near its top~ climb right under a small roof to an overhanging finger and hand crack. Bolted belay at a tree stump on the corner above. Burly and exposed.  Pitch 3 (5.11b~ 25m): Continue up the corner through a roof (bolt). Delicate face climbing and stemming past three bolts leads to a steep crack that climbs out of the huge roof that looms above to a bolted belay at a stance.  Pitch 4 (5.9~ 30m): Climb the offwidth to its top and move left to climb the left leaning gaping crack (fixed piton). Bolted belay. Those uncomfortable with wide climbing may find a second 6” cam useful.  Pitch 5 (5.10c~ 15m): Climb a narrowing finger crack in a clean left facing corner.
protection: Doubles to 3”~ singles 4”-6”~ small nuts.    Well protected and cruxes can be easily aided.

location: Cavern > Cougar Canyon (Creek) - CONSTRUCTION IN PROGRESS > Bow Valley > Alberta > Canada > North America > International
desc: A really thin~ blank looking face which goes up a right facing ramp after that.

location: Cachi > Costa Rica > North America > International
desc: To the right of No Soy Chino. Pretty strait. Has small overhangs. 1 dyno.
protection: Safe bolts~ chains and a carabiner at the top.  Quick draws are rentable.

location: Tranchant - Left > Montagne du Tranchant > 14. Lanaudiere > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Take off on a small ramp. After passing between the 2 trees~ go up the ridge on the left side up to the top.
protection: 13 bolts~ Stick clip start.   Single rap down with a 70m rope or use the next anchor to the left (Vérités Dérangeantes) to do 2 raps to the ground.

location: Revolución > Chiapas > Southern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: En el crux directo con el filo~ si se escala demasiado a la izquierda es mas facil (11b).

location: 3 Le Cosmodrome > d. Southern Area > Lac Long > 03. Quebec City, Charlevoix, Portneuf > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Resolve the start in the arch~ then follow the left-hand line (bolts). The crux is in the final meters~ on the overhanging arete.    Resoudre le départ dans larche~ ensuite suivre la ligne de gauche (bolts). Le crux se trouve dans les derniers mètres~ sur larete surplombante.

location: 4 La Cour > b. Northern Area > Lac Long > 03. Quebec City, Charlevoix, Portneuf > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Start on the tip of the big ledge (same start point as Tour de siège.) Stick clip. The view is amazing.    Le départ sur la pointe de la grande vire située en haut à droite de La Cour~ qui est également le point de départ de Tour de siège. Stick clip.
protection: two glue-ins~ then natural protection    deux scellements ensuite pro naturelle

location: Cedar point > New Brunswick > Canada > North America > International
desc: Face climb the first few bolts heading for the 'funny angle overhang'. At the overhang follow the horizontal seam smearing your feet and pull the lip on the left by doing a combination of crimping and laybacking.
protection: 9 bolts~ well protected   Shared Maillon anchor

location: Roadside Attraction > Fraser Valley > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: The farthest left of all the free routes at the crag~ also the most difficult. It starts with a couple unprotected moves to a juggy rail~ traverse right on the rail to the first bolt and from there it is hard to the top. The crux starts at a bulge near the 5th bolt. Very thin and technical climbing to the chains. Originally graded 11d until a hold broke at the crux.

location: 16. Paredon De Josue > Mogote del Valle > Vinales > Cuba > North America > International
desc: Start to the right of the boulder.    (NOTE: Detail of route from Cuba Climbing Guidebook 2009. Star rating was adjust based on the 4 star MP rating)
protection: 12 Bolts.  Bolt Anchors maybe be offset bring slings to equalize if setting up for Top Rope.

location: Horne Lake > Vancouver Island > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Less steep than many of the other routes at Horne Lake.

location: Escalera No. 10 > Parque Mirador del Sur > Dominican Republic > North America > International
desc: Esc 10

location: Proximus > 14. Lanaudiere > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Quelques beaux mouvements sur la dalle pour atteindre le toit. Ensuite~ passez celui-ci afin de vous rétablir sur la dalle au-dessus. Le rétablissement est engageant et c'est à cet endroit qu'il faut être poli.  A few delicate moves on the slad below the roof~ then pull over it and do a commiting mantle to get established on the slab above. From that point~ remember to be polite.

location: Merchants and Thieves Wall > Lion's Head > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: This is the leftmost sport line on the ledge you rappel to and climbs up a sustained face.

location: Monasterio > El Reliz / Cerro de las viboras > Sonora > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: La equipamos de abajo para arriba entre la Wera y Yo~ la línea natural se va por la izquierda de los techos~ tienes un bolt difícil de clipear para entrar a la parte vertical. Hay unos bolts que quedaron muy a la izquierda usa slings largos.  This route was bolted ground up~ climb to the ledge~ clip 1st bolt~ move your way up through the crack slab thing~ to reach vertical terrain entering the zone of the roofs. You will keep to the right of them. When the angle changes a bolt will be difficult to clip~ from there keep right of the roofs to the anchors. Some bolts are far right so use long slings.
protection: Quickdraws. Yellow sling at the anchors.

location: The Crest > Chek > Sea to Sky (Squamish to Whistler) > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Once you figure out the beta~ the crux is not quite as hard as it looks.

location: Lakit Lake > Kootenays East (Kimberly/Cranbrook) > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Fun climb on the arete hope you can hold on!

location: Latvian Boulder > Lion's Head > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: This is the middle line and is also the longest of the three.

location: Titan Wall > Lion's Head > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: Start the same as for Dr. Zeaus but continue up the dihedral after the second bolt.

location: The Upper Tier > Cochrane Lane Cliffs > Welsford > New Brunswick > Canada > North America > International
