desc: Follow bolts up a black~ very technical face to questionable rock and a good stance below the roof. Good gear in a crack that splits the roof and face above. Pull the roof and continue past one more bolt on the face above.
protection: 4 bolts~ small to medium cams. rap ring anchor

location: Viejo Bayamón > Puerto Rico > North America > International
desc: Bouldery~ powerful moves on a lower overhang to a top vertical section.

location: Cachi > Costa Rica > North America > International
desc: One of many routs. Has many small overhangs. Can be done in lead or top Rope. 18 draws.
protection: Bolts along the whole route~ chains at the top with a carabiner. 18 draws needed.

location: Fern Hill > Mamquam FSR > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Easy climbing to a tricky crux on the arete. If you puss out left you lose a letter grade. High crux as well. High first bolt~ but easy climbing.

location: The Last Stand Wall > The Swamp > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: none listed

location: The Rectory > Grassi Lakes > Bow Valley > Alberta > Canada > North America > International
desc: One of the easier at the wall~ start climbing and stop at the chains.  No distinct crux and lots of equally mediocre holds to choose from.

location: The Surf Bowl > El Potrero Chico > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Start up chossy rock for the first few bolts~ be careful not to knock anything off here.  Around the 4th? bolt a hard reach is encountered~ from a sidepull up to a jug~ I thought this was the crux.  From here traverse left on easier ground to a seemingly detached pillar~ surmount this and enjoy the no hands rest.  There are two bolts you can clip here~ seemed to me like clipping the right one would be a better fall.    From the ledge~ make a few powerful moves on mostly good holds avoiding the pump on your way up to the anchors.  Most people seemed to think the crux was in this section~ in particular getting too and moving off a small three-finger pocket.

location: e - Les surplombs > Mount Orford (Pic aux Corbeaux) > 05. Estrie - Eastern Townships > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Very classic and popular line~ its two pitches make for the longest link on the wall (barely possible to lower off from the top with a 70m rope).    Mostly done only up to the middle anchor to tick off that classic~ juicy 12a~ which puts it at the forefront of many endless grade debates~ it is nevertheless a very interesting climb with varied moves up to a unique and awkward crux sequence.    The start is easy enough~ up to a balancy section in the dihedral~ to a rock over on a slab~ up to a good rest at the base of a little overhung arete/bulge. The sequence up this feature is the crux~ and has been the scene of many failed redpoint attempts. A hard clip and a tricky sequence up the arete might keep your ego in check for a few tries too many if you underestimate this climb.    The second pitch is a classic and varied face climb~ taking full advantage of the wall by zig-zagging through it up to an exposed finish.    The original line has two excellent variants~ both climbing up and left from the rest below the bulge (instead of right and up the arete):    a) 4x4 (12a)~ which climbs slightly up and left past a small roof then joins the original line at the first anchor;    b) Go-Kart (12b)~ which branches out further left to tackle the upper roof and joins the second pitch directly without the pit-stop at the middle anchor.     BMW is the sleek curvy~ proud line that the rock seems to dictate~ 4x4 is the route taken through seemingly rougher terrain~ and Go-Kart will have you make obnoxious little engine noises as you wail time and again through its runouts and spanky cruxes.    Mostly considered easy for the grade (especially if you're tall)~ it is a great choice if you wish to break into 5.12.
protection: Pitch 1: 11 bolts to fixed biners at the anchor   Pitch 2: 5 bolts to lower-off

location: Dixon's Wall > Cayman Brac > North America > International
desc: The continuous line of tufas~ flowstone and pockets suddenly peters-out at the bulge at 3/4 height (crux).  Sustained~ steep~ and continuously interesting~ it's one of the best routes on the wall.

location: (f) Off White > (f) White Walls > Skaha > Okanagan > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: May need rebooting and cleaning

location: The Outrage Wall > El Potrero Chico > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: British Invasion starts in the same corner as Mothership Connection and goes left after climbing about 2/3 the way up the corner.  Moderate climbing with a few hard sections leads you to the perplexing crux which appears to have a couple different options.

location: The Fin Wall > Lion's Head > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: Start as for Bareback but move left after the first bolt. Climb the right side of the roof and move through the interesting finish.

location: 01. Jagueyana > Mogote del Valle > Vinales > Cuba > North America > International
desc: Start by pulling the roof with athletic moves. Easy climbing for a few bolts then attack the arete. The line is hard to figure since there is a route so close on the left. Some of the holds belong to the two routes.

location: La Palma (The Palm) Sport > El Salto > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: great  old  shcool route..

location: Right Wall > 02. Cueva Larga > Mogote del Valle > Vinales > Cuba > North America > International
desc: This is a harder variation to the second pitch of Fernando's Hideaway. You can lower to the ground from the top amchor.

location: Big Boy Wall > The Swamp > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: Hard crimping to start on a high first bolt.  Dynamic movements get you to a bulge.  Go right around the bulge to another crux.  Easy finish with a view.

location: Backside Crags > The Papoose > Shannon Falls > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Climbs a direct line to the attractive handcrack. 3 bolts protect the moderate climbing to a ledge. from here~ tricky slab climbing using pockets and dike holds gains the easy but fun crack. Pulling on the quickdraws at the crux brings the grade down into 5.10 A0 if you cant get your shoes to cooperate...  A variation moves left from the hand crack to gain a separate finger crack and keeps things a little more sustained.
protection: Bolts~ a few cams from #.75-2 for the crack

location: El Arco > Don Rayo Hills > Sierra de Juarez > Ciudad Juarez > Chihuahua > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Coming Soon

location: Fern Hill > Mamquam FSR > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: A good and varied climb that's harder than it looks.  It starts casually~ toughens up to a bulge which is the first crux and then moves into a crux corner with strange~ slick holds.  To finish~ a few easy but intimidating layback moves take you to the anchor.
protection: Bolted. Fixed biners and chains for anchors.

location: Mota Wall > El Potrero Chico > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Climb an obvious grey streak near snott girls. Easy climbing to the 2nd bolt then engage a nice crux on small crimps and techy feet to the fourth bolt. This climb is a little contrived due to a massive flake feature that runs next to the face for the first three bolts. If you want a nice twelve face climb avoid using the flake at all. If you use the flake it goes around mid eleven. The upper half of the climb is pretty spicy but relatively safe (except for the move to the fourth clip blowing it could wreck your ankles.) Heady bolt spacing 15 to 20 feet between the bolts. Very fun technical climbing on this route with a bit of spice to boot.enjoy

route: Kiss Me Where it Smells Funny
location: Exchamsiks > Terrace > Northern BC > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Climbs the black dike feature all the way to the top of the overhang.

location: Tulip Falls > Castlegar > Kootenays West > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Don't know the grade or FAs~ but looks like a fun climb!

location: Talladega Nights Wall > The Swamp > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: none listed

location: Club Mex Wall > Las Estrellas Canyon > El Potrero Chico > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: A great route up the vertical face in the center of the Club Mex Wall.  It is the most closely bolted line~ located just left of the tufa of Conflict and just right of Fear of Flying.  The route is great~ but plenty of juggy rests leave it feeling soft for the grade.

location: Pasillo > Pasillo Frío (Juana Díaz) > Puerto Rico > North America > International
desc: < not filled out yet >

location: Air Voyage > The Back of The Lake > Lake Louise > Banff National Park > Alberta > Canada > North America > International
desc: A memorable climb~ the pump builds and builds but good rests are available and much obliged.  Start near the base of the ramp~ just next to the yellow block.  Start up moderate ground linking a combination of face holds and good jams/locks.  Some strenuous moves deposits you beneath the mini roof where good gear and a comfortable stance helps you prepare for the crux.  Surmount the roof and get established in the thin crack above; move quick (fixed wire).  Continue up and left past a bolt and a perfunctory pin to the anchors of Air Voyage (P1).     Variations and extensions are legion~ described above is the most common practice.
protection: Wires and cams to 2".  This peach eats the wires.

location: Central Wall > Mount Nemo > Golden Horseshoe > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: Chossy start including a suspect flake at the first clip. Difficult crack climbing leads up to a roof.

location: (e) Little White > (f) White Walls > Skaha > Okanagan > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Technical movement up a left-leaning crack. A great climb with a nice variety of features and moves. Mindfully bolted but consider bringing a stick clip.

location: Nightmare Rock > Murrin Park > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: The classic hard finger crack at Murrin.     Ascend a steep 10a crack on the face above some blocks and past an intermediate anchor. Traverse to a stance below a right leaning splitter finger crack on the headwall. A short~ but thin and technical crux(12a) lies above. Fight on to the chains. Watch for the rope getting stuck in the crack to the left of the mid-height ledge.    Do "Sentry Box Direct" for~ in my opinion~ a better~ more sustained version~ but beware of the difficult gear placements. There is serious ground fall potential in the first 5m of this variation.
protection: singles to #2 Camalot~doubles of yellow and green aliens~ stoppers.

location: Left Wall > La Bleue > Val-David > 15. Laurentians > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Interesting and aesthetics from beginning to end.   Climb past 4 bolts to a long horizontal crack. Finish on a face with a bolt near the top.

location: Sector 2 > Lake Amatitlan > Guatemala > North America > International
desc: Bolted By: Felipe Garcia  Black # 8 on Sector 2 Topo Picture.   Super pumpy short route that resembles a boulder problem. Be careful since its super exposed and if you fall before the 2nd bolt you can hit the deck.
protection: 7 Quickdraws needed. 2 bolts at the anchor

location: La Fortaleza Escondida > Tarahumara Pass > El Potrero Chico > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Seven Deadly Stems climbs up and into the water notch at the top of La Fortaleza Escondida. The climb has a sub-anchor just inside the water notch for those who might be climbing with a shorter rope.

location: (a) Great White > (f) White Walls > Skaha > Okanagan > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: A cryptic route best attempted in the morning when shaded. Start on jugs and pull the small roof to establish yourself on a compact ledge. Crimp your way up to more relaxed climbing~ saving a bit of power for the finish.
protection: 7 bolts and chains. Long draws below the roof are nice.

location: Lower Cliffs, Lower Tier > Indian Springs > I-80 Corridor > Lake Tahoe > California
desc: Climb the face next to the right facing wall. The move through the wide crack about 45' up is 5.5. Or you can start on the knobby face off to the right~ climb up next to a left facing wall and do a lie back move through the right hand crack. This move is 5.6.     The climb goes low angle for a bit after these moves. Climb the low angle up to the steeper section of the wall and climb up the obvious vertical crack. The 5.8 crux is in this section of the climb and you can get good pro in the crack to protect the crux move.     At the top of the crack is a left leaning slot. Climb the left leaning slot to the top. Not as many Pro placements in this section but protectable and no runout.
protection: Cams .75"-3.5" 1-2 each. No bolts on this climb or fixed anchor at the top.

location: Penny Royal Arches > Tuolumne Meadows > Yosemite National Park > California
desc: Fun climbing that leads nowhere.  Pitch 1 - climb the discontinuous finger crack(5.7) that is first pitch of Myopia to a two-bolt anchor with quick links and chain links.  Pitch 2 - climb straight up past six bolts to a two bolt anchor with quick links and chain links. Gear up to 2" can be found between a few of the bolts and keeps the distance between protection reasonable.  The first bolt is near the right edge of the overlap above the belay.
protection: Stoppers and small gear to 2" for the finger crack on pitch 1 and to supplement the bolts on pitch 2.

location: Hogwild > Hogsback > Lover's Leap > Highway 50 Corridor > Lake Tahoe > California
desc: I don't really know what this route is named or what the rating is.  I just called it Hogwild Mystery Route #6 (HMR-6).  I hope somebody can improve on this post.  HMR-6 is a fun romp up a low angled arete with with some intriguing moves pinching some long "fins" past a couple fat bolts~ a good cam placement~ and an old ring-iron piton that looks solid (the pin can be backed up with a size "0" metolius TCU just above~ but good luck extracting it).  Continue up easy terrain and optional gear placements to a decision - slightly easier trad protected crack and dike climbing through a small overhang on the left or exposed crimping past 2 more bolts sticking to the arete on the right.  Once past the cruxy bits~ slither up the dike-covered slab to the right of a wide-ish crack to an anchor with Mussy hooks.  A 60 meter rope should make the round trip back to the ground but it will be close -  knot the free end.  You can top rope a fun~ easy flared crack ("2-pin crack") to the left off this anchor.
protection: Depends if you take the crack or the arete option.  If you climb the crack it would be good to have 2 x #2 camalots~ 2x #3 camalots~ and maybe even a #4 if you have angst about an easy runout up high.  If you take the bolted arete~ a single rack to #3 is good... with the same caveat about the #4.

location: Spring Wall > Horseshoe Piles > Horseshoe Lake Area > Mammoth Lakes Area > Sierra Eastside > California
desc: Climb the obvious broken dihedral.   Tricky moves midway up the first section and another tricky section at the top of the second are easily protected.

location: Dark Side Dome > Daff Area > Tuolumne Meadows > Yosemite National Park > California
desc: Great knobs and nice climbing until the last bolt.  It gets a little dirty above that.    Start on a broad ledge~ climb up and over an easy overhang to three bolts and great knobs lead to a small bulge.  Two well spaced bolts above protect easier climbing.  Diagonal up and left to the Who's the Bosch's bolted anchor after the fifth bolt.
protection: Five new ASCA bolts and a bolted belay / rappel anchor.  Rappel with one sixty meter rope.

location: 2. Black Wall - Center > Black Wall > Donner Summit > I-80 Corridor > Lake Tahoe > California
desc: Walk past "Slipstream" to the "Full Tilt" ledges. This is the left chimney of the huge detached tooth that forms "Full Tilt". Climb up a short easy corner to the top of a flake. Stand on top of the flake and burrow into the secure chimney. There is a cool cave behind the tooth. Climb to the top of the tooth and back out on the face to a chain anchor. Belay here and toprope "Full Tilt" or continue up a thin crack with incipient pro to ledges and more climbs.     This climb has pitches below and above which are dirty and less traveled.
protection: A few cams. The squeeze section is secure but unprotectable.

location: Locals Only Rock > Benton Crags > Eastern Hills > Sierra Eastside > California
desc: Negotiate the crux start.  Ascend blocky ledges through reasonable small gear.

location: Hogwild > Hogsback > Lover's Leap > Highway 50 Corridor > Lake Tahoe > California
desc: It's Better with Bacon is a good route on a nice slab on Hogwild.  The star rating is for the first 3 pitches.    P1:  start up a thin right trending crack.  when it peters out~ step right into another very thin right trending crack.  The cracks are very thin~ and take small nuts~ but the moves are slab moves.    P2:  Straight up a 5.6 slab past 3 protection bolts.    P3:  Up a 12' crack to a bolted 5.6 slab.  There is a 5.8 roof that must be surmounted at the end of the pitch~ very fun!
protection: bolts~ gear to 1"~ small nuts and micronuts.  All anchors bolted.  You can rap the route with one 60m rope

location: Owl's Perch Area > Bishop Peak > San Luis Obispo > Central Coast > California
desc: Starts right of 'K-B Trip.' Look for bolt 1 just below the large flake. Rap back to the base or move out right from the top and scramble to the base of “Private Pepper” (5.7) on Jam Crack Wall. - John Knight~ Bishop Peak eGuide 2010
protection: 5 bolts + small gear if you want to protect the easy terrain at the top

location: Poker Face > Big Hunk > Echo Rock Area > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: Begin four feet right of The Gambler (eight feet right of Pit Boss) at a left facing corner. Climb the corner and crack for about 25 feet to reach a right facing corner. Climb the corner as it steepens (bolts) to the top.
protection: Carry a couple medium sized cams to supplement the three bolts on the climb. Rappel or lower from the anchor.

location: Upper Valhalla Area > Danland > Sequoia & Kings Canyon NP > California
desc: Astrid starts at a vertical gray dike and follows it for it's entire length. The thin start is a crux as well as the section before the bulge. The bolts have a bit of space between them but they're in all the right places and you'll need a couple of pieces for the crack three-fourths up the climb. The Gray dike offers thoroughly ascetic climbing~ with great friction~ lie-backing and side pulls.
protection: Mostly bolts~ with a 3" piece and finger sized piece for the crack part way up. 11 or so draws.   two 60m ropes to get down while one 60 will only work if you swing left the whole way down. One 70m Works swell.

location: Upper Walt's Rocks > Walt's Rocks > Queen Mountain > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: This route starts up hill and left of white rain~ a hand crack goes out the left side of a huge chimney with chockstones. Follow this straight up through a nice jamming section to a slot with a nolina. Continue past the bush to the top.
protection: Standard trad rack up to 2.5 inch~ nuts too. Runners.Trad anchor . Rap off bolts for nearby sporty climb with 60 m rope.

location: The Real Cloud Ripper Tower > Cloud Ripper Towers > The Others > Tahquitz & Suicide Rocks > California
desc: AP can be described as a bitchen jug and sloper haul~ up a beautiful canvas of a face. Although protection is sparse it is all there. There are two variations to start this route. The first being just right of the start of Moon Dike. The other start is the same as Meteorology but before the crux of this route follow a left trending diagonal crack/mini ledge system. Both variations merge just before the wild edgy face climbing~ before crossing the end of The Moon Dike.

location: South Prowler Rock > Prowler Rocks > Pinnacles South > Holcomb Valley Pinnacles > Big Bear North > Big Bear Lake Area > San Bernardino Mountains > California
desc: Climb a fun slab past 2 bolts to a ledge and then follow the obvious zigzag crack that ends below the top and finish with the last bolt of Tubbie.
protection: 3 bolts~ gear to 2.5 inches~ chain anchors (shared with Tubbie).

location: Wailing Sax Wall > Sheep Pass Group CG Area > Sheep Pass Area > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: This name reeks of nostalgia.  However~ nostalgia ain't what it used to be~ and this is a route to avoid.  It is a hand crack~ with a loose flake in the crack making the climbing unpleasant and the protection unreliable.

location: Al's Garage > Mammoth Lakes Area > Sierra Eastside > California
desc: Climb up the wall to the left of the obvious corner~ until possible to stem the corner and hand jam the crack.  The corner is the crux.    After the corner fun climbing on jugs follows all the way to the anchors.

location: Dozier Dome > Tuolumne Meadows > Yosemite National Park > California
desc: To the left side of the Ripple boulder there is a small ledge.  Start there~ put in a piece at the crack near the start of the dike and go up a bit to the first bolt (5.8R). Clip another bolt and continue straight up.  You can get another piece in the left facing feature before you get to bolt #3.  Continue up nice face climbing with another 5.8ish move at bolt #4.
protection: 6 bolts to anchors~ with a couple of pieces of gear in the 1-2" size.

location: (o) Right of the Escalator > Suicide Rock > Tahquitz & Suicide Rocks > California
desc: This climb follows a prominent right-facing arch.  A large flake has fallen off~ and is standing on edge at the base of the route.  This is the "axe."  A difficult~ unprotected undercling start leads to hand jamming and then face climbing.  If you can handle the start~ this is a fairly nice route.  Rappel from the top.

location: Warm Up Wall > Central Gorge > Owens River Gorge > Bishop Area > Sierra Eastside > California
desc: Pumpy face climbing

route: Baby Atlas (aka The Chickens are Restless)
location: Shute-Mills Area > The Far Side > Mount St. Helena > Wine Country > San Francisco Bay Area > California
desc: Climb the right side of the face to a double bolt anchor. The climb is steep and clean~ but easier than it appears. A photographer can get a great photo from the ledge on the right.

location: Little Hunk - NE Face (Right) > Little Hunk - NE Face > Little Hunk > Echo Rock Area > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: per Miramontes: "Start up a flake/crack~ then traverse right on a shelf~ to a crack and face."

location: The Negativity Cave > The Benches > The Emeralds > Bowman/Emeralds > I-80 Corridor > Lake Tahoe > California
desc: Cast in Stone is a Two pitch climb (see Negativity Slabs Area for a description of first pitch) To get to the start of the second pitch of this climb~ climb the first pitch of "Cast In Stone" (See Beta Photo #4) When you get to the top of the first pitch you will arrive at a bench area that is at the base of Negativity Cave. Move to the left side of Negativity cave.  Move up to the first bolt and traverse left past the fixed draw.  There is a bolt with a chain protecting the move over the lip. Climb to the next bolt then down climb to lip bolt and remove draw to reduce rope drag.  Although only 5.8~ climb has great exposure and a few tricky moves up top.
protection: bolt protected with musseys at the anchor.

location: Negativity Slabs > The Benches > The Emeralds > Bowman/Emeralds > I-80 Corridor > Lake Tahoe > California
desc: 5.8 move down low. The rest is cruiser. There is a second pitch to this climb that will get you to the top of the cave. From these anchors you can set up a top rope to climb the harder routes to the right if so desired. To do the second pitch~ when you get to the top of the first pitch you will arrive at a bench area which is at the base of Negativity Cave~ move left to the leftmost set of bolts. Paul Brabham did the first ascent of this climb while wearing a cast on his arm~ hence the name. (I have no idea why he was wearing the cast)

location: Negativity Slabs > The Benches > The Emeralds > Bowman/Emeralds > I-80 Corridor > Lake Tahoe > California
desc: Crux low.  Climb still a bit dirty.

location: Castle Rock Slab (West Face) > Castle Rock Slab > Castle Rock Area > Big Bear South > Big Bear Lake Area > San Bernardino Mountains > California
desc: Scramble up onto a large flat ledge and climb the prominent widening crack in a flared corner. The crack starts off a nice size but at the top you will want a larger piece or two.  * As an alternative you can climb the crack start of Big Bear Roots to the large ledge which bumps the grade up to 5.10a.
protection: Gear to 4 inches~ bolted anchor (shared with Big Bear Roots)

location: The Saddlehorn > Saddle Rocks Area > Sheep Pass Area > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: As you approach The Saddlehorn Formation (which is the huge block just right of The Kid) this route can be seen as the arete on the right side of the north face of the block. It joins the route Redskin at Redskin's 5th or 6th bolt. At the 4th bolt you have an option: up and right (5.8~ slightly more runnout) to Redskin's 6th and final bolt(5 bolts total)~or~ straight up (5.9) to Redskin's 5th bolt for a slightly more difficult variation (6 bolts total).One star out of five. 70 foot rappel off the overhanging north face.
protection: 5 or 6  bolts~ 2 bolt belay/rappel anchor 70 ft.

location: Triple Play Cliff > Upper Gorge > Owens River Gorge > Bishop Area > Sierra Eastside > California
desc: Up the arete past a cam to a bolt and the crux~then cruising up the arete first on the right then taking the path of least resistance~ whatever that may be.
protection: One inch cam~ four bolts~ two mussy hooks. EDIT: 7 bolts no cam needed.

location: (v) North Face > Suicide Rock > Tahquitz & Suicide Rocks > California
desc: This is a very obvious line (huge right-facing corner)~ but an unpleasant climb.  It has a long squeeze chimney and dirty rock.  Walk off from the top.

location: Cap Rock - Southeast Face > Cap Rock > Cap Rock Area > Sheep Pass Area > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: This fun pitch is on the sunny south side of Cap Rock.  Climb an obvious right angling crack until it peters out~ then make a 5.8 face move past a bolt to the top.  This route is deservedly popular and odds are you will find a gang of people here.

location: Main Wall > Mission Gorge > South San Diego County > San Diego County > California
desc: Start slightly right of crack of dust following a thin crack as it curves right.  Near the top you clip a bolt from a ledge and mantle straight over onto a second ledge.  Rap rings are to the right (shared with crack of dust~ fingerrip and the owl).
protection: Small cams~ nuts~ and 1 quickdraw for the bolt.

location: Main Wall Left > Box Springs Mountain Park > Inland Empire > California
desc: Devil Man climbs up across the obvious zig zag cracks in the center of the wall.  A nice moderate mix of face and crack climbing with good pro~ and a brief respite from the other routes for your fingertips!.  Fun TR if you forgot to bring the trad gear.  Walk off right to descend.

location: DXM Wall > The Ghosts > Alabama Hills > Lone Pine Area > Sierra Eastside > California
desc: Fairly obvious thin crack/seam.  Takes small nuts and the occasional cam.  Lead is mixed~ and encourages you to move to the left half way up the seam to a series of three final bolts.  An unbolted lead would command an R or X rating due to marginal gear and unprotectable top half of climb.
protection: Set of small nuts~ cams to 0.75 Camalot~ draws for up to 5 bolts.

location: Midway Rock > Sugarloaf Area > Highway 50 Corridor > Lake Tahoe > California
desc: This route is an often overlooked Sugarloaf classic splitter. It's difficult to see from the approach trail but once you see it~ it's one of those routes you just have to climb. Thin fingers and hands start the route and quickly turn into perfect hands. As you near the top the crack continues to widen into rattley fists and keeps it on you right to the top.

location: Northeast Face > Granite Basin > Sagehen Summit Area > Eastern Hills > Sierra Eastside > California
desc: Climb the obvious vertical dike on the left side of the Northeast Face. After clipping the last bolt~ either continue straight up the dyke that slowly diminishes (10a) or step 5' right and continue up a much easier dyke that goes directly to the anchor (8). This is a fun route.    Anchor: chain links that need to be threaded to lower down (or walk off right).

location: Midway Dome > Shuteye Ridge > Southern Sierra > California
desc: A nice clip-up on a highly featured and steep face~ this route is a wonderful climb that would have a huge line if it were alongside the road rather than in the middle of nowhere.     Locate the detached pointy boulder to the right of the water chute in the center of the face.  Climb this~ clip a bolt under a bulge~ then trend up and left toward the water chute past six more bolts to a pair of bolts with quicklink that serve as an anchor for this and Bullroarer~ the .11b to the left.

location: Monkey Wall > Stealth Pillar Area > Rattlesnake Wash Hillside > Rattlesnake Canyon > Indian Cove > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: 4 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor Stealth Pillar area. On a N. Facing wall right of the Stealth Pillar. This climb goes up tiny knobs most of the way~ and is a cool climb.

location: PSOM Slab > Scheelite Crags / PSOM Slab > Pine Creek Canyon > Bishop Area > Sierra Eastside > California
desc: Fun mixed climb. Starts with a short slab below a small roof~ continue over the roof and through a dirty broken crack to more face. 8 bolts to Mussy Hook anchors. Double rope rappel.

location: Up The Wash > Eastside > Downtown > Margheritaville > Apple Valley Crags > High Desert > California
desc: Follow the dihedral up to a bolted anchor.  Let me know if you know the real name or the FA
protection: Standard Rack to 3 BD. Bolted Anchor.

location: Up The Wash > Eastside > Downtown > Margheritaville > Apple Valley Crags > High Desert > California
desc: An awkward start following two bolts leads you to a fun little layback up to a solid stance below a bolted anchor. Fun but grainy.   If you know the Original FA or name~ let me know!

location: Sunlight Rock > Towers of Uncertainty > Geology Tour Road > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: A fun steep climb on positive holds makes this a fun route to do if in the area. Well-thought-out bolt placements that are not scary or overbolted. Pretty solid jugs.
protection: Three bolts (3/8")~ natural anchor (sling a boulder) up top.

location: Nap Wall Area > Slick Rock Dome > Highway 50 Corridor > Lake Tahoe > California
desc: A thin finger crack / undercling / lieback leads you around and up this smooth granite block. Features on the face make it easier than it looks. Note that it is difficult to see your placements when leading. Continue on up past flakes and onto the face to the anchor at the apex. Easy to TR from apex anchor (you can lead Slick Rock Cracks to get to anchor).

location: Tiger Cage > Courtright Reservoir > Southern Sierra > California
desc: Climb direct-start slab or come in from the right off a block into diagonal cracks for easier climbing. Gain a small ledge~ climb featured face above~ then transition into the crux slab near the top. Guidebook rates 5.8+.
protection: Bolts~ pro to 3". A single bolt only is at the top; you can back it up with gear. For top rope~ an alternative to setting a gear anchor is to utilize the 1-bolt "anchor" for this route and the 2-bolt anchor for the route immediately left~ functioning as a TR for both routes.

location: Hippo Wall > Tollhouse Rock > Southern Sierra > California
desc: Shared start with Hippo in a bathtub. Splits after the third bolt and goes straight up instead of right and ends at the same anchor. More features than Hippo~ and I thought it was easier even though the guide rates it harder. Both are worth doing!

location: Short Wall - Left Side > Short Wall > Indian Cove Campground > Indian Cove > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: This route is located on the far left side of the Short Wall between Double Trouble (5.10a) and Belay Girl (5.10c). Climb up an easy crack system Mad Race (5.4) for about twenty feet and then cut right via a right-slanting flake system (pro to 3"). The rock is somewhat dubious so load up on gear~ and then smear your way up past two bolts to the top (it's easier to cut left for a move or two and then back right above the last bolt). Bolted anchor on top and easy downclimb via several options.      This climb is a testament not only to the powers of cleaning via traffic~ as when this route was first done it was terribly grainy~ but also to Todd's vision to see a fun route despite all of the chossy rock. One star out of five.

location: The Cove > Bowman Valley > Bowman/Emeralds > I-80 Corridor > Lake Tahoe > California
desc: Insecure start with a poor landing. You may actually end up in the water if you botch the first clip (stick-clip useful). This climb was bolted ground up and has some 30' runouts between bolts albeit on easyish terrain. Not a beginner lead. Need a 70m rope.
protection: 6 bolts painted white to a 2 bolt anchor with closed shuts (gated).

location: Lower Cathedral Rock > Lower Cathedral Area > Valley South Side > Yosemite Valley > Yosemite National Park > California
desc: A long shallow right facing dihedral with a good crack running the whole way to the anchor.  Mostly a thin hands and fingers crack.  There is a blocky start to reach the main dihedral.  Lower off a two bolt anchor with a 70m rope a 60m will not work.

location: Emigrant Wall > Silver Lake > Carson Pass Highway (88) > Lake Tahoe > California
desc: Route can be climbed separately or used as an alternate start for the multi pitch routes "The Pass" or "Three Springs." Full route shares an anchor with the first pitch of "The Pass."  An anchor was added that allows the section of route before the dike to be top roped. This anchor shares a ledge the first pitch anchor for "Three Springs". Both anchors are equipped with quick-links to facilitiate rappelling.  If one was so inclined it is easy to set up two top ropes from this ledge with a 70m. A great opportunity to get an inexperienced climber some time on slab without committing to a multi pitch.  For "Three Springs" continue straight up from TR anchor~ "Follow the River" itself continues passed this point and left up a six inch dike. (Also note~ directly right 8 feet or so from TR anchor is "Three Springs" direct start anchor.)  IMO the climbing on the dike is some of the most enjoyable at Emigrant wall. I highly recommend this as an alternative start to the Pass.  If you do the full route and decide not to continue up "The Pass"~ descend by rappelling to the ledge at the start of "The Pass" with at least a 70M.
protection: 12 Bolts to Anchor shared with the first pitch of "The Pass"

location: Big Face > LTA > Sonora Pass Highway (108) > California
desc: Fun movement on small edges and jugs. 140ft to two bolt anchor above the lip. Very dirty and has moss growing in patches over the route. Evidence of recent rock-fall and exfoliation. Check all holds before committing. One glue-in bolt midway up has been smashed by rock-fall. Still usable but suspect.
protection: Bolts and small to medium gear. Two bolt anchor at top.

location: Conan's Corridor > Jumbo Rock Area > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: Fool's Gold is the first (leftmost) route on the Corridor Face proper.  It follows a prominent trough past a single bolt into and into a double crack system.    The cruxes are down low~ at ten and twenty feet.  The first is pretty much unprotected~ but with a reasonably clean fall if you're well spotted.  The second is slightly above your first gear.    The double cracks don't take gear the way you might hope~ so don't pass up all of the pockets on your way up the trough.    All in all~ a committing~ relatively sustained~ fun route at its grade.
protection: Standard rack through #3 Camalot.    Pro is adequate~ but not abundant.  Passing up any of the good placements will probably set you up for a groundfall.

location: Lower Tier > Stonewall Peak > North San Diego County > San Diego County > California
desc: A slabby start forces you to not place any protection for the first 15-20 ft of the climb. After placing your first piece~ continue up the obvious line to the right of the first roof-feature seen.  The crux of the climb comes just underneath the first roof~ as the shrubbery growing out of the small finger crack makes it hard to secure a good jam.  Continue ~60 ft up the route to the second (and final) roof.  Traverse left with some extreme exposure and finish out the final 10 ft with awesome hand jams!
protection: Pro to 2.5"   Protects really well with .4-2 C4 ranges and one set of nuts will get you safely to the top!

location: Moonshine Pillar > Alabama Hills > Lone Pine Area > Sierra Eastside > California
desc: Laughably bad rock gives a funky boulder problem start. Clip a few bolts where giant dinner-plates have been removed and move left crossing over towards Sparge past two more bolts (squeeze job) and shared anchors.

location: Icehouse Canyon > Mount Baldy Road > Angeles National Forest > Los Angeles Basin > California
desc: I rope soloed this route~ so the description~ gear~ rating~ etc reflect that. I gave it a Grade II rating~ though a small team familiar with bad rock could climb this much faster than myself having to do all the work associated with rope soloing.    Anywho~ this route heads up the right side of Sheep Canyon~ left of Kimchi Ridge~ past Sheep Canyon Spire. The terrain is kinda complicated looking~ but really if you go to the base of the headwall and go up the right side on the easy looking slabs below Sheep Canyon Spire~ the climbing is obvious. Go too far right and you'll be in some class 3 looking super loose gully. To the left is much steeper and often difficult to protect ground. Follow the best line up.  P1: ~100ft easy slab to tree anchor   P2: ~200ft+ past Sheep Canyon Spire to tree anchor in low-angle slab/mini dihedral thing   P3: ~100ft up right facing dihedral with easy slab    The two 'cruxes':   1. To the right of Sheep Canyon Spire~ a 10ft long section of kinda insecure 5.8ish.   2. Start of last pitch~ 5.7ish up a right facing dihedral then moving right over easy slab with crappy fall potential.    Be careful of loose rock~ especially at belays. I got rid of a lot of more dangerous blocks (usually on purpose)~ but the whole place is very loose.    FWIW~ a 5.8 here is different from a 5.8 elsewhere due to the loose rock. It's a little more mental. Same gymnastic level.
protection: -Single rack to #3~ with Wild Country Zeroes and BD X4's coming in very handy as always. Brought half set of DMM alloy nuts~ only placed one nut.   -70m rope   -Lotta slings~ some trees up to 2ft diameter.   -Helmet

location: Windy Wall > Backside Crags > Buttermilk Crags > Buttermilk Country > Bishop Area > Sierra Eastside > California
desc: Steeply up to stand in a pocket (bolt). Up to an undercling then a fun little traverse right to stand in another pocket (bolt)~ the slab to the top.
protection: Two bolts on the climb and two (hangers only) for the anchor.

location: Suess Wall (South Face) > Seuss Wall > Children's Forest > Keller Peak > Running Springs Area > San Bernardino Mountains > California
desc: Located on a small tower at the right end of the south face. Climb cracks to an interesting two bolt face above and finish atop the summit of the formation.
protection: Gear to 2.5 inches~ 2 bolts~ chain anchors

location: Ponderosa Wall / Black Tower > Rattlesnake Canyon > Indian Cove > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: Hop sing is an awesome 5.8 crack! Cool slashes decorate this crack.    Great~ hard ~almost polished rock for 115 ft or so. Splitter for the grade. you will love it.   Nice jams~ classic movement.   Do it!
protection: cams lots of #3's~I placed a 3.5 and a 4. Nothing smaller than #1.    The anchor in the cave above sucks CHOSSS! maybe belay a little lower. Walk off left

location: Glory Dome > Roadside Rocks > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: A high quality finger crack (crux) leads to easier moves above.  It gets shade for most of the day.
protection: Standard rack~ with emphasis on smaller pieces

location: Top Rope Wall > Horse Flats > Angeles National Forest > Los Angeles Basin > California
desc: Start at a easy sloppy crack and top out onto a ledge (or walk up around the side)~ then reach up and jam an fist in or undercling a fang hold and continute up the crack with hands and fists. Then the crack gets thin and you have to do some finger jams and then follow it up and use the arete at the top.
protection: Easy TR off the sappy tree. Or lead with a normal rack.

location: Seuss Wall (West Face) > Seuss Wall > Children's Forest > Keller Peak > Running Springs Area > San Bernardino Mountains > California
desc: Climb "alligator skin" face with a thin crack (optional pro to 1") to a ledge and clip a high first bolt. Stem upwards~ make some tricky moves past the 2nd bolt (crux) and then finish up fun plated rock and a short bit of slab to the anchors.     Originally done without bolts~ it was bolted a few years later not knowing it had been previously done. If skipping the bolts you'll want several large (5-6") pieces.
protection: 3 bolts~ chain anchors (shared w/ The Lorax). Optional pro to 1" for the bottom.

location: Atlantis Wall - Right > Atlantis Wall > Atlantis Area > Lost Horse Area > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: a fun climb - steep face with some crack moves

location: Hodgepodge Rock - North Face > Hodgepodge Rock > Group Campsite  8 > Group Campsites Road > Indian Cove > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: This route starts to the far right of Hodgepodge 5.4. It is a short~not very fun route and the way off is a short rap off of two bolts above another bolted job on the other side. It was in the shade in early afternoon so it was cooler. The two routes behind it (Names ukn to me) are much more fun. So in a small area there can be a good warm up and such. Good bolts! three bolts..........
protection: 3 bolts~ pro for anchors up top (Medium cams)

location: Wrangler Rock > Buttermilk Crags > Buttermilk Country > Bishop Area > Sierra Eastside > California
desc: Climb the crack and buckets on the left side of the rock.

location: Campfire Crag - North Face > Campfire Crag Area > Indian Cove Campground > Indian Cove > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: This is on the far right of the North Face.   Climb an obvious~ short crack through a brown hole.

location: Middle Earth > Mission Gorge > South San Diego County > San Diego County > California
desc: Climb the left diagonalling fist/hand crack just left of the offwidth. Not much a wide crack climber but feel Art Messier's rating of 5.8+ to be drastically wrong. Definitely felt more in the 5.5-5.6 range.
protection: Short gear lead~ a #4 in the crack will probably be the only piece you need. Gear anchor up top.

location: Caesar's Palace > Jumbo Rock Area > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: Climb a slab past two reasonably spaced bolts (5.8) before making a runout on easier ground to the anchors.     This is the original route on the face~ and the route actually cuts way right to a third bolt well right of Pizza Pizza before ending at the top of the wall. Most seem to ignore this last bolt as it seems poorly located and just finish straight up to the anchors on Pizza Pizza.
protection: 3 bolts~ optional bolted anchor/rap (shared with Pizza Pizza). The first two bolts have been replaced and are 3/8".

location: Sunshine Wall > Horseshoe Lake Area > Mammoth Lakes Area > Sierra Eastside > California
desc: Start a few feet right of the toe of the buttress.   Climb up rightwards following the groove until possible to move directly up the steepening slab.    Climb directly up the wide shallow groove feature to gain quartz dike holds above.    Follows these holds up the wall to just below the top~ then finish direct to the right of the pine tree.
protection: 8 bolts~ double ring anchor  (equipped with Mussy Hooks).

location: Southwest Base > Base Routes > El Capitan > Valley North Side > Yosemite Valley > Yosemite National Park > California
desc: Start by scrambling up to the start of the short finger/hand crack in the left facing corner~ and follow this to a small ledge at the base of the 3-4" crack in the corner. I found getting established in the crack to be the crux.  Follow this to bolted anchors.  I was barely able to jam my fists in the small constrictions~ and I have somewhat large fists.

location: Southwest Base > Base Routes > El Capitan > Valley North Side > Yosemite Valley > Yosemite National Park > California
desc: About 120' uphill from Moby Dick-Right Side is this 160 foot slab with a tree at the top.   This climbs a  right facing corner with a small roof~ 20' up. Continue up to a belay.   Continue up cracks to "The Improbable Traverse"~ to the left.   Belay at the base of a shallow~ flared dihedral~ leading to the top.

location: Mystical Tricks Cliff > Central Gorge > Owens River Gorge > Bishop Area > Sierra Eastside > California
desc: Good warm up face climbing. Crux is above 3rd bolt.

location: Great Flake > Buck's Bar Dome > Cosumnes River Gorge > Placerville > Highway 50 Corridor > Lake Tahoe > California
desc: Fun crack that is a good first gear lead. The crux comes right off the ground but can be easily protected. The rest of the climb is a very fun and straight forward crack

location: Grey Giant > Grey Giant Area > Wonderland North > Wonderland of Rocks > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: This route goes up the right side of a giant boulder just before you get to the Grey Giant.
protection: Two or three bolts and a sling on a horn near the top.

location: Caveman Wall > William's Canyon > Colorado Springs > Colorado
desc: Pull off the ground by stemming off the wall to your left. Move up easy ground clipping two bolts as you go. From here~ stem your way through the crux bulge and mantle onto the ledge below the anchors.
protection: 4 quick draws plus something for the anchors.

location: Mountain Rose > Boulder Canyon > Boulder > Colorado
desc: Just left of the big corner~ climb small cracks up to the face~ then go up past 3 widely spaced bolts~ with the crux after the second. Continue climbing up and right past horizontals with great smaller cams (not tiny)~ then look for a hidden anchor on the left at the top.    KNOT your rope ends when you lower. It's right at the end of half of a 60m rope.    Be careful with hollow rock particularly at the top.
protection: Cams to 1.5" (red Camalot)~ 3 bolts~ and a 2 bolt anchor.

location: West Ridge - part C - Pony Express to Long John > The West Ridge > Eldorado Canyon SP > Boulder > Colorado
desc: This climb is named after what may be the most bawdy and crude song ever written.  The only thing I can think of that comes close is Whores of Balitimore.  Remarkably~ both can be found on the same album: Rogue's Gallery~ a collection of Pirate Ballads~ Sea Songs~ and Chanteys.    This climb actually has good climbing down low and up high.  There is also plenty of solid rock for gear- too bad you have to focus on staying on that and dodging choss.  Otherwise it would be a better climb.    Access the ledge from the corner to approach for The Side Wall~ Practice Climb 101~ and Rhombohedral~ move left 10+ meters to below a system of dirty-looking parallel cracks in chunky rock that go perhaps 15m to a tree.  Start up the left-most of these with surprisingly good holds and protection (crux) and work progressively to the right to avoid bad rock and the looming tree above.    Clip a sling to the anchors on the tree and look up and right to a tree at 110' off of the ground.  Climb up mixed cracks and face trending generally rightward to reach that tree and the fixed raps slings on it.    Per Dave Holliday: the second pitch of this route goes up the right-facing corner just to the left. The top of the second pitch ends at another good ledge.     Rap ~100' to the ground.  If you have a short 60m~ watch out at the end.    Per Dave Holliday: after 2 pitches~ one could rappel off trees (70m rope useful to get to the ground from the tree atop the first pitch)~ but given the amount of loose rock in this area~ consider traversing climber's right to the Long John Wall/Sooberb descent route.
protection: A standard trad rack from med sized nuts to #3 Camalot.  A #4 Camalot is optional~ but I didn't have it and was fine.  Lots of 2' runners though~ as this route winds it's way up multiple cracks through ledges and bulges.

location: The Castle > Buffalo Creek > South Platte > Colorado
desc: This route ascends the cleft between the two big chunks of the Castle itself. Look for a big chimney feature in a right-facing flake feature directly below some blocky roofs. All pitches are between 100' & 140'.  P1~ 5.8. Chimney your way up miscellaneous stuff for about 125' to a ledge.  P2~ 5.9-. Follow the main corner/cracks up and slightly leftwards to a belay ledge.  P3. Head up & right across the main chimney system to more a more appealing looking crack. Continue up to a roof which is passed on the right side (crux) and then up to a belay.  P4. Head left towards a right-facing corner and then up a crack system to the final slabs.

location: Shanahan Crag > South > Flatirons > Boulder > Colorado
desc: With some traffic this will become a much better route~ but for now it's a bit .... adventurous. This route climbs the pretty huecoed face just left of Identity Theft (the line marked in Rossiter's guide as the "South Face"). Both pitches are 5.8/5.9.    P1. Start in an obvious left-facing corner and climb easily to the roof~ then do cool moves left under the roof and stand up at the far end. Angle left across huecos and neat underclings (Tri-Cams useful for pro)~ then up to easier ground on a faint prow. From here~ either keep going a few feet left into a nice left-facing corner (easier and better protected)~ or tackle the steep wall above via faint double cracks (good climbing but the cracks are discontinuous~ a bit dirty and difficult to protect). Belay at a small ledge by a large old nest.    Pitch 2: Angle right over an easy bulge to a stance~ then climb steep rock via discontinuous double cracks to reach the top. Adequate but not great pro. (As with the first pitch~ the pro will improve if the cracks get more traffic.)    Descent: Downclimb about 75 feet of low 5th class to a ledge with a rap anchor (125-foot rappel)~ or climb to the summit.

location: Lower Mother's Buttress > Mother's Buttress > Main Canyon: Unaweep Granite > Unaweep Canyon > Grand Junction Area > Colorado
desc: This routes climbs up a giant arete system directly about lower mothers buttress.  The suggested approach pitch to climb to begin this route is "Cowabunga".  I would agree with that statment.  From here five more excellent pitches grace the route.  The rock is solid~ and requires all the climbing disciplines.  After five pitches~ get into hiking/scrabling mode till the last 80' of the buttress.  There is a 5.7ish pitch to the summit.  I was confused where this pitch was~ but I did find it~ and here's the best was to explain its location.  When you come up from the saddle (looking at the topo on pg 126 in the guidebook)~ don't look for a straight lined offwidth like that in the drawing.  The last pitch starts in a crack that goes up for about 12' then forces you the traverse right via face holds towards a right upwards arching off width.  The rest is easy to follow.  Rumor at Grand Junction REI is that the upper 1/3 of this route fell off.  Do not believe their beta! Fun route~ more like a mountaineering ascent after the first 2/3.  The leader MUST know how to place directional gear to keep the rope out of loose rock.  I wouldn't suggest this route to beginning leaders.  Bring helmets.
protection: One set of TCUs~ one #4 Camalot or #4.5 Camalot~ 2 or 3 #3 Camalots~ lots of slings.

location: Rapids Rock > South Fork of St. Vrain Canyon > St. Vrain Canyons > Lyons > Colorado
desc: Go up inset to right-leaning ramp on right with crack then to a slab and wall~ continue left on slab with crack to small overhang with crack~ and lieback to gain the pedestal. Pull the overhang on to slab~ & continue another 50 feet to single bolt.

location: Ship's Prow > Long's Peak > RMNP - Rock > Alpine Rock > Colorado
desc: This is a moderate route that can go down quickly with a mere half~ or nay... quarter-day's work~ and not hard labor. It took us just over 2 hours bottom to top on this one. The rock is mostly solid~ the protection is mostly good (though well-spaced at times)~ and the line is mostly obvious.    Half Day's Work starts up in the right-facing corner system to the left of the start of Man Overboard and Portal. The route starts by ascending up this system in 2 pitches total continuing up and left the entire way past some old pins~ particularly 3 old pins in a tight group near the top~ near a crux~ and just before a grassy ledge. With judicious use of slings~ this can all be linked in a single pitch just under 60m long.    From  belay on that ledge~ the route goes slightly left and then up and right on slightly lower angled rock with an easier technical grade but occasional short runouts. The route leans hard right here and crosses up and over a peerless slab of rock to reach a large ledge with another old pin belay from the 1960s aid ascent. This lies just to the right side of the last 20' of the major buttress that lies up against the main cliff~ and can be backed up with gear. It is perhaps 120' for this pitch.    The next pitch climbs up from the pin belay and left onto solid rock. The right-facing corner to the right of the belay is overhung~ separated from the main wall~ and dirty/chossy. Go up and left then back right at the very peak of the buttress~ then pull up to and into a chimney on the right (poorly protected in spots~ but moderate) or a left-facing corner on the left (more technical~ but less of a grunt)~ and shoot up more than 60m to the top of the wall~ belaying if you feel the need~ or simul-climbing for a way otherwise~ unless you have an 80m rope.    Arrive on the top~ and find something to belay off of that you feel good about.  It took me some searching to get a long cord around some big boulders that were bomber.    You can read more or check out a few pictures here:  fixedpin.com/blogs/news/548….
protection: A light alpine rack with a full set of stoppers~ a full set of cams to 3"~ and some long slings.  Take some extra cams in the finger to hand sizes if linking pitches as we did.

location: Mechanical Man > South Fork of St. Vrain Canyon > St. Vrain Canyons > Lyons > Colorado
desc: An interesting climb on good rock~ but needs a little cleaning yet. Start at the leftmost bolt-and-gear belay at the base of Tier Two~ having rapped in from the standard ledge atop Tier Three to the slab chains~ then down and left of the slab chains to the comfortable belay ledge.    From there~ you will be looking just right up into Emissions Testing corner~ or up into the shallow~ hanging dihedral of The Tooth.  Move left to a crack as for The Tooth and start climbing~ but instead of coming out right around the blunt corner and into the hanging dihedral of The Tooth~ stay left~ reaching a solid flake that bends left and becomes a secure hand traverse for 20 feet or so.  Climb this feature on solid hands~ passing a somewhat annoying bush midway. Continue up cracks in a corner for the remainder of perhaps 90 feet in all to a belay ledge with a bolt.    You can continue directly up on Job Site (5.7~ not very clean yet) or belay here.    The best climbing is to be had by belaying here or one station to the left on the same ledge~ then doing a second pitch consisting of Mr. Goodwrench continuing into Auto Repair. (150'~ 5.10-~ take a 4" cam.)
protection: A standard rack perhaps with doubles around hand-sized cams~ especially if continuing the route through and adding on Job Site as an extension.

location: Turtle Rock: A Crag for Kids > Boulder Canyon > Boulder > Colorado
desc: Take the overhang directly in the center of the crag and struggle over it to gain the small crack that splits slab above.    Perhaps this is best climbed with a top rope.
protection: Trad rack. Use the anchor at top of Fiona's Route.

location: Little Twin Owls > Lumpy Ridge > Estes Park Valley > Colorado
desc: The zig-zag crack just right of the obvious wide crack~ on the north little Owl.  Undercling and jam from the ground at 5.9~ or step in higher up off of a ramp at a 5.8 thin crack.  A good little route.    [Eds. Interestingly~ there are 3 ways to do this route.  S. Kimball's guide describes a 5.8 version which starts on Knee Catcher.  R. Rossiter's guide describes this as Flake~ 5.8+.  He also describes starting with a thin seam (challenging) on the right.  B. Gillett's guide describes starting up the awkward zig-zag crack as 5.9+.]
protection: Bring a light standard rack to a #2 Friend.

location: Sunday Wall > The Access Fund Trailhead > Main Canyon: Unaweep Granite > Unaweep Canyon > Grand Junction Area > Colorado
desc: This route has a good section of climbing with good rock and good gear.    Start as for Bandito~ and as soon as established off of the ground~ head sharply left into a curving and wandering hand-crack.  Curve and wander with it to an overhang/bulge 10-15 meters up~ jam over that (crux) to a good stance~ then wander up and right over easy terrain to the anchors as for Bandito.  Step right just before passing a large shrub to arrive at the anchors.
protection: From small to large hands and a few 2' runners.  Rap from chain-anchors on Bandito.

location: Fourth Buttress > Elephant Buttresses > Boulder Canyon > Boulder > Colorado
desc: This is a moderate climb that must surely have been done before~ but it does not match any documentation we could find. The crux lies in some fun and secure jamming and jugs coming out a left-leaning overhang at the right side of the old aid roof.  The remainder of the climbing is mostly easier~ mostly solid~ and it is all well-protected.    The route starts up a steep crack system (5.7) just below and right of the old aid roof. This lies just to the right of a lower angle system that might be more commonly used.  Despite its steepness in a few spots~ it is not hard.  It may be about 5.7 or 5.8 with good protection.  The angle reduces as you approach the roof~ and you may notice a fixed angle in a horizontal crack in the last small bulge before the roof.  Come up and into the roof and place a hand-sized cam in an overhanging~ left-leaning crack behind what looks like a huge chockstone that forms the right-hand side of the roof and climb out that on jams and jugs.  This is surprisingly easy given its appearance~ with a grade of perhaps 5.9- for only a move or two~ and has good protection.    Continue up over the bulge and get established on the crack system at the right hand edge of the rib of rock you are now on~ following that line to just below a summit where a cable anchor with aluminum rap-rings can be accessed.
protection: A standard rack from small to 3" with several long slings.    A fixed cable rap anchor up top (as for the aid roof) allows retreat to the gravelly ledge with a 60m or 70m rope.

location: Picnic Rock > Poudre Canyon > Fort Collins > Colorado
desc: A Buzzworm sat at the top of the route.    Climb the right-facing dihedral and crack to a shared anchor.    CAUTION: there is a massive block halfway up the pitch that we could not budge~ but it appears to be detached. You can climb around it.
protection: A standard rack including TCUs and nuts. Per Guy H.: bring up to a #3 C4.

location: Combat Rock > Big Thompson Canyon > Estes Park Valley > Colorado
desc: Follow moderate rock to the tree.  Load up on gear and run it out to the only bolt. Follow the thin crack and one more piece of gear to a set of anchors.

location: The Lion's Den > The Monastery > Big Thompson Canyon > Estes Park Valley > Colorado
desc: Thought provoking climbing leads to the crux at the third bolt. More interesting route finding lead past two more bolts to the top.
protection: Five bolts lead to a two bolt anchor with twisted quicklinks for rappel.

location: Psycho Tower > Big Gypsum - Dolores > Naturita and Paradox Valley > Colorado
desc: The crux is near the start. It has some offwidth and stemming moves with delicate rock. Some nice handjams and feet put you on a ledge into a corner. From here~ you can continue up the small crack or layback the corner with nice pro leading up to underneath a blocky~ dirty roof with not so nice pro but easy traversing over left to the last bolts on Nameless Face.
protection: A single rack from small TCUs to a #3 BD and extra runners.

location: Redgarden - Lumpe to the top > Redgarden Wall > Eldorado Canyon SP > Boulder > Colorado
desc: Just left of the main Darkness 'til Dawn dihedral is a very obvious groove that continues past a small tree. This route is not in the guide~ but I've eyed it more than once over the years. We finally climbed it~ thinking it might be 10 or so~ but since the gear looked to be good~ so why not have a go? It turns out it's 9- or so with very good gear and very good climbing. What looks like the crux~ moving left where DtD starts its real climbing~ turns out to be easy. The actual crux is above the tree in the green corner. The corner eventually blanks out. Move up and right to get some decent holds. From here~ the best choice is to continue right into upper DtD. We chose to move left around the arete into a left-facing corner and up to a questionable anchor. Chuck tried to continue up the corner to the DtD anchors~ but it got hard~ and he had little gear~ so we ended up backing up the anchor in the corner and rapping from there. This anchor seems to exist for those who rap from the top of Grandmother's Challenge with a single rope.    Route details: start as for Darkness 'til Dawn or just left and climb up to where DtD enters the crack system on the right wall. Instead~ move right and layback up to gain the groove. Moderate climbing leads to a small tree. You could move left here into the left facing corner~ but instead~ continue up the green corner above. Where it starts to blank out~ make a move up and right to get some decent hand holds. Either move right to DtD or stem left to the arete and then left around the corner and up to the anchor.
protection: Standard rack to #2/gold Camalot. If you continue to the Darkness 'til Dawn anchors~ you'll need a 70m or double ropes to get down~ or will need to downclimb a bit. If you finish to the left~ be prepared to back up the fixed anchor.

location: Bridge Wall North (Practice Rock) > Beige Tube Area / The Narrows > Big Thompson Canyon > Estes Park Valley > Colorado
desc: 1.2 miles west of the Beige Siphon tube in the Narrows on Practice Rock.  The right side of the wall has two cracks~ the one on the left is Safety in Numbers~ 5.11.  [US 34 Bypass] is the broken wider more vertical crack on the right.    Jam and edge up the crack~ good placements at good stances~ to the small roof.  Reach out left~ and smear up the face (crux) to a good stance.  It is easy to the anchors.
protection: Good protection with small nuts and cams~ and a 2 and 3 inch cam or top rope.

location: Analog Alcove > Devil's Head > South Platte > Colorado
desc: This is a fun climb. The crux is reaching the good hold left of the overlap.
protection: Bolts.  The anchors are off to the right of the tree.

location: Mushroom Massif > South Fork of St. Vrain Canyon > St. Vrain Canyons > Lyons > Colorado
desc: Stem to the base of the body-sized crack~ push over to the north wall~ and climb the wide crack to the ledge connected to Farmer's Maggot (route). The book recommends stopping on this ledge and rappelling rather than continuing up the crack line to the top of the wall~ because the top portion depends on the integrity of a huge~ detached flake. We ended up finishing the line this way and walked over to the bolts on top of Raven's Nest to rappel.
protection: Small pro for the bottom of the crack (RPs~ TCUs) and bigger gear for the top. We did it with 2 #4 Camalots~ a #3~ a #2~ and large nuts~ but the crack would also take bigger gear (#5 or #6 Camalot).

location: West Face > Spoof Rock > Top Of The World > Buffalo Creek > South Platte > Colorado
desc: Climb a brief but quality splitter from hands to 5"~ and top out. If the crack were longer~ it would get more stars. This could be a boulder problem~ but the landing is so bad that a fall could be catastrophic.

location: Nip and Tuck > Boulder Canyon > Boulder > Colorado
desc: Climb straight up a clean face~ just right of an arcing~ very defined~ left-facing dihedral. A vertical crack runs right up the middle of this face~ providing some excellent finger jams.
protection: Small stuff for lead~ slings for TR.

location: Water Slabs > Upper Dream Canyon > Boulder > Colorado
desc: The crux is down low on the face. There is a rusty old ring pin you can clip in the middle of the face which could be backed up with gear~ but the climbing is easy at this point. The upper roof move is about 5.7.    If anyone knows the FA or name~ let me know~ and I'll edit this listing.
protection: 6-8 modern bolts plus an old pin to a two-bolt anchor.

location: Water Slabs > Upper Dream Canyon > Boulder > Colorado
desc: The thin slab moves are the crux. The roof above can be pulled at about 5.8 on clean rock.    If anyone knows the FA or route name~ I'll add it to this posting.
protection: 6-8 bolts to a two bolt anchor.

location: The Industrial Wall > The Narrows > Carbondale Area > Colorado
desc: Start where the fixed line ends~ below an obvious chimney halfway up the cliff. Climb up the steeper rock for a few moves before making your way into the corner below the chimney. Climb good features on the right side of the chimney to the anchor.

location: Devil's Kitchen > Colorado National Monument > Grand Junction Area > Colorado
desc: Pitch 1:  Climb sandy fingers and face for 15' and then tight hands in a left facing corner.  Pass the offwidth to a couple of drilled angles and loose I-bolt.    Pitch 2:  Move right off the belay and make 5.7 moves on soft rock to the top of the formation and clip a bolt. Walk right to the edge of the formation and either lower or down climb 6' of exposed class 4 to a small ledge.  Reach across the chasm to the detached tower (great exposure) and clip the first pin of a six bolt ladder.  Aid up the bolt ladder to a horizontal #1 Camalot placement above the last pin and grovel to two drilled angles.  This is a very nice summit with great views and definitely worth the first 10' of mank on pitch 1.
protection: Pitch 1:  Stoppers~ (BD) (2)#0.75~ #2~ #4.  QD if you want to clip the sketchy 1/4 inch bolt.   Pitch 2:  1 bolt~ 6 fixed pitons and a #1 BD.  60 meter rope for rap.

location: The Riviera > The Bihedral Area > Boulder Canyon > Boulder > Colorado
desc: This is the [eighth] route from the right. It is a fun line with several variations.  It can be done as a 5.8 if you take the easiest line~ or a 5.10 if you take the hardest line.     This route is a bit of a squeeze job (stay left of the bolt line or you'll trespass on Topless Etiquette!) in between Topless Etiquette and Silver Glide. Not included in the Rossiter guide.    Climb straight up a face past three bolts.  Move up right and reach left to clip the fourth bolt above the lip of a roof.  You now have three options:    1. Traverse left to a good crack to surmount the roof (8).   2. Tackle the roof straight on via a finger pocket and a reach up left to the good crack (10b).   3. Climb the roof on the right (9).    Continue up to the second roof at the fifth bolt.  You now have two options:    1. Move right around the roof using a groove (8).   2. Tackle the roof directly using thin holds (10b to 10d). The more you stay in line with the fifth bolt~ the harder the climbing.    Continue up past a final bolt to the anchor.
protection: 6 bolts~ 2 bolt anchor (shared with Topless Etiquette).

location: The Lower Tier > The Bihedral Area > Boulder Canyon > Boulder > Colorado
desc: This route is not marked in Rossiter's Bihedral section of the Boulder Canyon book and is not apparently described on this site yet. This seemed to be the buttress 'below' route #1 in Rossiter's topo. From the normal approach to the Bihedral~ just before the scrambling starts off of the trail~ take a sharp left and go west to a short buttress with several bolted routes on it. This is the second bolted route from the right~ starting about 15' left of Leave No Trace.  See ?beta photo?. We found this route after the westward walk-off from the Bihedral route.      The route is safely bolted~ but without long slings~ the rope runs funny~ particularly between the 2nd and 3rd bolts (or was it 1st and 2nd) where the rope goes sharply left over a dark sharp corner/flake. Using 2' sling on the lower and upper kept this a little better. It's not a bad climb~ there's just not much to it. Rap from the rings to keep from abusing your rope; don't lower off.     Does anyone know the history of this route?   Addendum: There is a 2nd pitch with 3 bolts~ a #1 Camalot & orange Alien can be useful~ 5.8~ 70'~ 2-bolt anchor. See Like a Wonk.
protection: A set of 4 draws + some for the anchor.

location: West Ridge - part D - Xanadu to Pony Express > The West Ridge > Eldorado Canyon SP > Boulder > Colorado
desc: Refer to the directions to "P3 of Working Class Hero" to locate the "Upper Construction Zone" buttress.  This is in the general vicinity of rock above Positively Fourth Street.    At the very left hand side of the Upper Construction Zone~ a large evergreen stands at the base of a rotten looking wall~ just left of a rotten~ shrub-choked~ left-facing dihedral.  This wall is even worse than it looks.  The cracks directly behind the tree on the wall which become three parallel cracks (within reach of each other) are called "Three Lane Highway (5.8~ S)"  To the right~ the rock is generally better.  The first good rock to the right about 10'~ is the route~ Bottlenecks (5.9~ *).  It is the first~ nice dihedral~ which starts very small~ but grows larger.    Bottlenecks is a route with a cruxy start and then an additional crux or two as you move upward.  The rock is reasonably solid~ but need a little lichen removal before it is truly "clean." The pro is reasonable the whole way~ although not always in your face.  Many horizontals along the way make great "thank god" holds for rest.  This route can be lead with a light rack.  You will reach the top of the Upper Construction Zone buttress after 60 feet of interesting~ but not great climbing.    To descend:  From the top of the vertical rock~ you scramble up and left (W/NW) to a large pine tree~ at which there is a solid fixed rap station.  This station is presently 2 independent tied slings around a solid tree and a single leaver biner.  It needs a quick link or two added or to replace the single biner present.  Rap from this to the base of the Upper Construction Zone~ then walk off in reverse of the description as for approach #3.
protection: A Standard Eldo Rack can protect the route~ although getting started is rather tough and there is a potential to twist an ankle from the opening moves if your belayer is not attentive~ you may fall 5' to the ledge despite having gear.  This is a subjective hazard~ not an objective one~ so I have not rated the route "s."

location: Achean Pronouncement > Central > Flatirons > Boulder > Colorado
desc: A cool boulder problem to another big Flatiron slab and ridge.    Climb up under the bulging flakes and set high feet- Pull up on underclings and set a solid piece (one piece) and then get fingers above that in the remaining part of the hold. Pull up and over into horizontals and up onto the slab on solid rock.     There was some old webbing hanging from a rotten flake- it was decayed and had lichen growing on it- it was removed. Continue as you please (many possibilities) to reach the ridge. Up and right you can reach a deep channel and crack (5.2?) that will intercept the East Face route at the intersection of the summit ridge~ 210' total.  Up and left is a direct shot at the ridge~ but is not a distinct describable line. I can not say what difficulty might be encountered~ but it seems reasonable if you are willing to wander.   If you went Right~ finish on the ridge as for the East Face.  If you went left~ figure out a belay somewhere and work it out.  Terrible place for simul-climbing though....
protection: The crux is protected with a 0.5-0.75" TCU~ Alien~ etc.... I used a green Alien.  The rest is standard light rack and is a little runout.

location: Pup Tent of Solitude > Main Elk Creek > Glenwood Springs > Colorado
desc: Climb up a bouldery block clipping one bolt to move right to a black face. Clip another bolt~ play with some pockets~ pull through a bulge (crux)~ and continue up on well featured rock to chains. It is usually shady by noon.

location: Skinner Mountain > Buffalo Creek > South Platte > Colorado
desc: This route starts about 10 feet left of the 105869658  and shares an anchor with that route as well. The crux came between the 3rd~ 4th~ and 5th bolt and the rest of the route seemed to be much easier~ 5.6 maybe. The route trends generally up and right~ gaining the same ledge as the route on its right. It provides a great chance to practice precise footwork.

location: Main Wall > Blob Rock > Blob Rock Area > Boulder Canyon > Boulder > Colorado
desc: This ascends an interesting corner about 15' left of Shimmer~ with 3 bolts up high (plus a variation with 1 bolt). There is a distinct crux at the second bolt. It has fun stemming and interesting climbing.
protection: 3 bolts~ pro to 3"~ and a bolted anchor (independent anchor~ not the Shimmer anchor which is shared with 2 other routes).

location: Krishna West > Lower Dream Canyon > Boulder Canyon > Boulder > Colorado
desc: Start up the black groove on good natural gear to the one-bolt roof! Continue up beautiful cracks to the finishing left-facing dihedral!
protection: Gear to 2" and 1-bolt roof.    Per Jason Haas: this was ascended without the bolt in 1981.

location: The Acrophile > South Fork of St. Vrain Canyon > St. Vrain Canyons > Lyons > Colorado
desc: Dead Deer follows the obivous crack system to the left of Iced Tea.  Head up past a wide section and jam the twin crack system to the top.    Descend from a 2-bolt anchor....
protection: A single set of cams to #4 C4....

location: Four Blocks Crag > Nine Mile Hill > Unaweep Canyon > Grand Junction Area > Colorado
desc: Climb up over two ledges on sloping holds.

location: Wizard's Gate > The Crags > CO Hwy 7 & Tributaries > Estes Park Valley > Colorado
desc: Below The Guillotine~ on the right-facing dihedral is a series of cracks. 'Dead End' ascends these cracks and ledges~ eventually reaching the newly installed chain anchors (shares chains with 'Crystal Staircase') which might warrant a name change. Previously one would climb above said anchors and then downclimb 20 feet to a chockstone to lower off.     As this climb cleans up~ its quality will increase. For enjoyable movement and something completely different than 'Crystal Staircase this is worthy. This climb can be top roped after one leads 'Crystal Staircase'~ and vice versa.

location: Rough Canyon > Grand Junction Area > Colorado
desc: This is a good looking flake/corner.  There is no fixed anchor. It i an easy walk off back to the car.

location: Gilpin Lake Amphitheatre > Mt. Zirkel Wilderness > North of Town > Steamboat Springs > Colorado
desc: Traverse down and left off a good ledge into a gully. Follow this gully to a ledge about 20 feet higher. This would be a good spot to belay. From the ledge~ follow a thin crack system aiming up and right for the obvious~ wide crack. After a fun traverse into the main crack~ follow as the crack widens past #6 Camalot-size before the undercling traverse above. You may want to belay in the chimney above on small gear unless you have a big piece left. From the chimney~ move right again to the twin cracks leading to a ramp up and left. From the huge ledge above~ you can unrope and scramble up and left to the ridge~ where you will be able to meet the trail.
protection: A full rack from fingers to blue Big Bro. There is no fixed protection.

location: Cats vs. Dogs Wall > Clear Creek Canyon > Golden > Colorado
desc: Follow the black bolts and jugs over a v-shapped notch in the right side of a wide overhang. Head up a rounded arête angling slightly to the left. Watch out for the runout between the 4th and 5th bolt (a bolt has been added~ no need for gear now). There is another fun overhang at the 7th bolt. 2 more clips lead to a nice stance and the anchor.    A 5.6 ish 2nd pitch can be climbed on gear. It's fun and well-protected with a single set of cams up to a #4. You can head over to the Out of the Blue anchor to get down.    The big roof left of pitch one has been toproped~ maybe 11a? It's filthy but fun.

location: The Fish Bowl > Clear Creek Canyon > Golden > Colorado
desc: Somebody left a stick clip (MacGyver'd with tape and plant stems). I tried without it~ backed off~ and then used it. It was a bit awkward~ insecure~ and friable (YMMV). I know these routes will clean up and enjoyed it after the opening move. See what you think.
protection: 8 bolts plus something for the chains.

location: Low Wire > Clear Creek Canyon > Golden > Colorado
desc: This is another easy warm-up for the area with some traversing that also allows you to hang the draws for Fly Low (and even Land of the Lost~ if you're adventurous!).      Belay from the second set of anchors for the fixed line being careful not to knock down loose rocks on climbers below. You are given the 1st bolt as soon as you set out heading left.    The first "exit" up an easier dihedral ramp to a set of anchors is yours for this route. They are shared with Fly Low. Should you wish to continue traversing on good horizontals~ you'll reach the last couple of bolts and be able to head up to the anchors for Land of the Lost.

location: Gnome Dome > Buffalo Creek > South Platte > Colorado
desc: I don't usually give routes bomb ratings~ but this route deserves one. You make a mantle move to the first bolt~ and then head up a thin crack above and a little to the right.
