There is a hole in the rock at the notch on top~ that can be slung for an anchor.    The Chicken Ranch is a licensed brothel located in Pahrump~ Nevada~ about 60 miles west of Las Vegas.
protection: Pro to 2.5". A protrusion of rock with a hole can be slung for the top anchor. Bring some long slings.

location: Discovery Wall > East Side > Pinnacles National Park > Central Coast > California
desc: Pretty fun chimney which goes pretty straight up then out to the left for an easy but fairly runout slab/scramble up to the top. Decent rock with the crux being getting yourself through a narrower constriction in the chimney.
protection: One fixed pin and two bolts. Takes standard set of hexs and nuts for further protection. Two bolts and hangers at top.

location: The Grack Area > Glacier Point Apron > Valley South Side > Yosemite Valley > Yosemite National Park > California
desc: Follow the double crack system ~ 120' to a good belay ledge. No fixed anchors. Second lead traverses left and follows the left edge of a large roof-flake system. There are rappel bolts. Need 2 60 meter ropes to descend. There is an intermediate rappel anchor~ also bolted.
protection: First pitch~ standard light apron rack plus runners and draws; second pitch a few medium cams. Second pitch is slightly unprotected and runnout.

location: Foothill Crag ("The Foot") > Hwy 33/Ojai > Central Coast > California
desc: A few tricky moves come right off the deck.  Ask for a careful spot from your belayer.  Then~ an easy wide crack with good pro leads to a ledge with a bush.      Place gear high as leaving this ledge and the bush is the crux of the route (perhaps 5.7).  Look for face holds on either side of the crack.    Steep crack and face climbing (5.4) with good pro take you to the top of the route.  Look for the fixed anchor immediately atop the crack on the left.  Be very suspicious of the two older bolts in the summit boulder.
protection: Gear from small (#1 TCU) to 3.5".  You might want to double up on medium-sized gear (1/2"-1").  The crux is protected by a solid 2" cam.  New fixed anchors atop the crack: two 1/2" Rawl-style five piece expansion bolts (2006).

location: Two Eagle Peak > 09 - Palisades & Surrounding Peaks > High Sierra > California
desc: A not climbed very often semi-classic - which has some loose sections to negotiate.  The triangular face has a ramp which runs diagonally from the bottom left corner to right of what looks like the top. There's a shattered wide chimney at the start which as some loose rock~ climb this and follow the ramp up and rightwards~ with some high exposure~ for a few pitches. Route finding is a challenge towards the end of the ramp~ find the path of least resistance until the right ridge of the face can be followed leftwards to the top of the face.  From here there's a towered ridge which leads to the summit~ which will require more pitches/simul-climbing.  Descent from the summit is via the Class 3 East Ridge.  If pressed for time one can descend a gully between the top of the face and the towered ridge westwards to a steep drop off~ where a 100' rappel gains less technical ground.
protection: Standard trad rack of nuts and cams~ no need to double up.

location: Little Lebowski Urban Achievers Crag > The Playground > Santa Barbara > Central Coast > California
desc: Climb featured face past 3 bolts to 2-bolt anchor.  A good beginner lead.

location: (o) Schoolhouse Rock > Riverside Quarry > Inland Empire > California
desc: Start in the recessed area and climb the slab that steepens to a bulge at the top. Fun moves on good rock and one of the best at the grade in the area.

location: (d) Northwest Recess > Tahquitz Rock > Tahquitz & Suicide Rocks > California
desc: This route follows the first crack system to the right of the North Buttress~ angling left after four or five pitches to the broken ledge system with two large trees on the North Buttress.  From there~ you can finish via either the North Buttress route or the Uneventful.  A 150 long 4th class pitch leads to a nice belay spot on a ledge.  The second pitch is the crux~ and the best pitch on the climb.  It is well-protected~ and involves underclinging right around a horn and then going over an overhang and up to a belay ledge.  From the left end of this ledge~ two pitches up a wide crack system (5.3 and 5.5) lead to the easy traverse that takes you left to the North Buttress/Uneventful routes.

location: (n) Rebolting Face > Suicide Rock > Tahquitz & Suicide Rocks > California
desc: This is a poor climb~ with an unaesthetic crux section down low~ then 3rd and 4th class scrambling up a long~ low angle chimney.  However~ it is a very useful way of getting up to the Godzilla and Sunkist faces~ and can be used as a descent after routes such as The Shadow.

location: 3. East Wall > Pigeon Cliff > Northeast California > California
desc: Start up a crack system right of High C and follow the sandy~ blocky and somewhat low angle crack to the top. A good route for beginning climbers.  Shares anchors with High C but requires a directional piece or two.

location: Circle Crag > Indian Cove Campground > Indian Cove > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: Climb a short thin and shallow crack to a ledge.  Here the crack widens to splitter wide hands.  Follow the crack to the top.
protection: Small gear for the bottom (aliens or nuts) and wide gear for the top and anchor (#2-3 camalots).

route: Able Was I Ere I Saw Ellesmere
location: Ellsmere Island > North Wonderland Approach > Wonderland North > Wonderland of Rocks > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: A crux wide hands start leads to hand jamming and then a corner with finger jams.  The rock quality is good.

location: Dilbert Dome > Comic Book Area > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: Climbs to one bolt to the left of two cracks.

location: Crystal Lake Crag > Angeles National Forest > Los Angeles Basin > California
desc: This is a good route for beginning trad leaders and mixed climbers~ as there are several easy ledges to place gear from. This route is blocky and easy. Lichen makes smearing difficult. Once you figure out the simple sequence of moves~ it's a very easy route.
protection: Standard rack of cams and nuts. The cracks in the lower half of the route work great for cams and large nuts~ and a flake up top is good for small nuts. Anchor up top is a Granite/Quartz crack~ good for nuts and smaller cams. Bring a long length of cord (+/-20ft)to extend the anchor out over the edge of the rock to cut down on ropedrag. Pad the edge with something to protect the cord. There is a class 3 walkoff to the left of the anchor.

location: Corral Wall High Buttress > Corral Wall > Rattlesnake Canyon > Indian Cove > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: This route climbs the thin~ pancake flake left of Dead Man's Hand. It is actually a continuation of the same crack and shares the same belay.

location: The First Corridor > Texas Canyon > Angeles National Forest > Los Angeles Basin > California
desc: To the right of Agua Negro are several TR anchors and 4 bolts leading up to one of the anchors. The bolted route is 5.7. The various top rope anchors in this area access climbing from 5.7 - 5.9. Climbing is on knobs and features with many good solution pockets. Whoever put the bolted route up the middle of Acme Top Rope Wall is welcome to post or advise on their name for the route.

location: Hitman Rock > The Outback > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: A very clean~ deep V-slot with fun chimneying

location: Manure Pile Buttress (aka Ranger Rock) > El Cap Picnic Area > Valley North Side > Yosemite Valley > Yosemite National Park > California
desc: Great moderate climbing with increasingly beautiful views of the valley.    Pitch 1 - (5.6) This is the crux of the route. Jam and stem up a right facing dihedral to belay at a tree above. Move the belay up and across 3rd class for forty feet to the base of a wide crack. (120')    Pitch 2 - (5.5) Climb the wide crack to the top of a pedestal and then continue slanting right across 5.4 territory to an alcove. (180')    Pitch 3 - (5.3) Slab climb up a knobby face to a large ledge. (120')    Pitch 4 - (5.5) Climb up the face to a right facing flake then either climb to the large roof and move right under the roof~ or move right into a crack and avoid the roof entirely. Belay at a small tree.    Pitch 5 - (5.6) Climb up the crack and onto the face to the top of the buttress.    Descend by walking off into the gully on the left.
protection: Set of nuts~ small cams to 2 inches.

location: (t) Eagle Pinnacle > Suicide Rock > Tahquitz & Suicide Rocks > California
desc: Starts in a left facing corner~ one piece of pro here in the crack~ then follows an obvious water streak with three bolts.
protection: One smaller cam plus three draws.

location: Claim Jumper Wall > Central Pinnacles > Holcomb Valley Pinnacles > Big Bear North > Big Bear Lake Area > San Bernardino Mountains > California
desc: Jam~ chimney~ stem and wiggle your way up the wide crack passing a few chockstones near the top and then continue up to belay in the notch and then circle around to rap anchors.    As an alternative you can cut right and move past the last two bolts of Chaps My Hide to anchors on that route which bumps up the grade to 5.9 or so.

location: Coyote Crag > Central Pinnacles > Holcomb Valley Pinnacles > Big Bear North > Big Bear Lake Area > San Bernardino Mountains > California
desc: This high-quality route was one of the very first bolted routes at the Holcomb Valley Pinnacles~ and to this day remains a popular classic.    Climb well-featured face to arete past six bolts utilizing the amazingly good holds that sprinkle this route. A classic and recommended route for the grade at this area.    The FA was orginally done with 2 bolts~ a few pieces and some tie-offs for plates; years later the original bolts were replaced~ more bolts placed and an anchor added so that 5.7 climbers might better enjoy the route.
protection: 6 bolts~ chain anchor (all bolts 1/2" SS)  * Bolts replaced 2019

location: Split Dome (North Rock) > Split Dome > Split Rocks > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: This is a hand crack on excellent rock.  It is not in the 1992 Vogel guide.

location: The Loading Zone > Warner Valley > Northeast California > California
desc: Perhaps the most popular climb at the crag~ a great way to get on the rock and shake the cobwebs from your trad rack. Fun.
protection: Gear to 3"~ a couple of shoulder length slings~ nuts.

location: Prairie Squid Wall > Central Pinnacles > Holcomb Valley Pinnacles > Big Bear North > Big Bear Lake Area > San Bernardino Mountains > California
desc: Start below the double crack system at the far right end of the wall - either start up on the right and traverse left (awkward 5.6) to the left crack or start on the left side of the slab (maybe 5.7)~ straight up to the left crack.  Follow the crack over very easy ground to the crack that splits the small roof.  Climb the roof (the crux) and walk back and left to a block/crack system where you can set up a gear anchor.  Because of the grotty 5.easy climbing between the start and the roof~ no stars.  Since MP requires that I give a star rating and 0 stars is not an option~ I chose 1 star rather than a bomb~ for the tricky start and finishing roof.  Walk to the right (south) to descend and turn right at the end of the wall to return to the base.

location: Peapod and Right > Eagle Peak > Lassen National Park > Northeast California > California
desc: The bottom half of this route ascends a shallow right-facing corner that has the approximate outline of the west coast of California. The top of the corner presents a nasty crux encounter on flaky rock. Past this~ jam through a small roof and continue up easy ledges to the top of the wall.  To descend~ walk to the right and rappel from the chained tree at the top of Second Wind and Foxtrot.

location: Lost Orbit Rock - East Face Left (Angry Inch Wall) > Lost Orbit Rock - East Face > Lost Orbit Rock > Pinnacles South > Holcomb Valley Pinnacles > Big Bear North > Big Bear Lake Area > San Bernardino Mountains > California
desc: Start on the arete then head into the left trending crack with a variety of placements. Tricky moves over bulge to a rest on some plates to the left where you contemplate your next moves. Surmount the roof with a few awkward moves into a wide crack (#4 C4 placement) that heads to the right and narrows the higher you go. Higher up the steepness lessens as the crack widens. Use anchors for Stand up comedy or build anchor using gear.
protection: Gear to 5"~ largest piece i carried was a #4 C4. Two #3's were nice to have. If building an anchor wide gear is necessary.

location: Camel Toe > Land of the Lost > Fairview Mountain > Apple Valley Crags > High Desert > California
desc: Climb up a corner on the low angle buttress on the west side of camel toe to a ledge and then climb past two bolts to the top.  At the top you can either move left to the anchor of Great Divide~ or continue to the top and belay from the anchor of Hang Time.

location: Camelot Crag > Castle Rock Area > Big Bear South > Big Bear Lake Area > San Bernardino Mountains > California
desc: The splitter crack on the West Face of Camelot Crag is one of those fun~ short routes that leaves you wanting more and is over way too soon.  Great hand and foot jams with plenty of face holds for the feet make this a fun little romp.
protection: Gear to 3 inches.  No top anchors~ and only a very wide crack on top for gear.  Alternately~ belay from below and behind the summit boulders.

location: Main Area > Buck's Bar Dome > Cosumnes River Gorge > Placerville > Highway 50 Corridor > Lake Tahoe > California
desc: Candy Corn Boulder starts just right of Beginner's Cracks where two obvious large crack systems angle towards each other and meet about 12' up.  Climb left~ right~ or both to get to easier ground above.  I gave this a one star as if you try various starts~ you get lots of practice using different crack techniques.  By using just the left crack~ or just the right crack~ or using both cracks~ all go at 5.7 or so.  Jamming the right crack as a straight-in hand jam goes at 5.9. A good finish to this climb continues up on ramp/large flake above to where you can step left onto the large knob on face.  Angle up and right for an easier finish (5.7) or step left further on the two large knobs and continue straight up as on the finish of Popcorn (5.10a depending on height).
protection: Candy Corn Boulder is usually done as a toprope but the climb could be protected with medium to large pro up to the beginning of Popcorn but is probably not worth it.  Leading up even the easy variation of Popcorn would be run out.  Anchors on the top of Beginner's Cracks could be used for toproping this climb.

location: Left Teta > Cerro Las Tetas (Cayey) > Puerto Rico > North America > International
desc: Starts with seven bolts of steep slab on thin holds with delicate moves. This leads to an in-cut section and a good rest.  After shaking out climb the bulge on good holds to gain the head wall for one last crux move which leads to easy climbing to the chains.

location: Into the Shade > Devil's Glen > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: Awesome moves on an an even awesomer crack.
protection: Stick clip first bolt.   bolts   anchors

location: B. Secteur oublié > Baldy > 15. Laurentians > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Rusted Rawl bolts .No details for now.  Bolts Rawl rouillés. Pas de détails pour l'instant.

location: Yak Peak > Fraser Valley > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: A four year project from Lyle~ Gary and Rob finally reaches fruition.    This route climbs sustained slabs and flakes between Reality Check and Hole in My Heaven. It reaches Yak Crack at the top of that route's 8th pitch~ then climbs left of the finish of that route~ and right of the upper pitches of Reality Check/Yak Check~ to the summit.    The grade can be reduced to 10c A0 by yarding on bolts through the cruxes. The bolts are significantly  closer together on this one than on Reality Check.
protection: Most pitches are bolted~ but 6 pitches take gear. All stations are fixed.

location: Cueva de la Cumbia > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: crux towards the top`starts with amazing stalctite steaming not that hard but wild.    In a small cave to the right of the first cave.

location: La Primera Plancha > Virgin Canyon > El Potrero Chico > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Climb the thin face up to the ledge (crux) and then choose either of the two finishes (the corner or the arete).  Both variations are good and are about equally difficult (~ 5.10ish).

location: Scimitar Pinnacle > Old Baldy > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: Start on Exit Stage Right and follow the left bolt line to a few hard moves and anchors.

location: Boondocks > The Pillary > Area 44 > Sea to Sky (Squamish to Whistler) > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Shares anchor and final bolt with Colin de Bin.

location: Main Wall (Center Face) > Red Rock Mountain > New Brunswick > Canada > North America > International
desc: Climb through broken up section~ the rock quality improves dramatically after 3rd bolt. Some easier climbing on gear.  Then follow the bolts through cruxy slab moves.
protection: Quick draws and a few small cams.

location: (b) East Face > (a) Diamondback > (g) Southern Crags > Skaha > Okanagan > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Start the climb on a low bolt and follow a right traverse to gain a corner. Clip a couple of bolts and move right around the arete. Continue up edges and flakes~ very Skaha-style to the anchors.
protection: ~7 bolts and fixed chains for an anchor.

location: Tranchant - Middle > Montagne du Tranchant > 14. Lanaudiere > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: on the right of Ying/Yang   Climb up to the ledge below the first corner~ climb it up and clear the roof to the next corner.

location: Deputy Wall > The Chief > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: La Gota Fría is a long mostly free route on the Deputy Wall~ on the Squamish Chief.  The route features mostly gear climbing~ with a few bolts on some pitches~ two bolt ladders (or free at 12+) and entirely bolted belays (except one which is a tree).  Pro is plentiful and bomber.    The route has excellent pro~ a wide variety of climbing (from finger-to-hand cracks~ a short wide crack~ a slab traverse~ etc)~ some wild positions and a cool finish.    It is possible to rappel the route from P12 down.  From the top of P2~ one can rap 30m to a station~ and from there 25m to the ground.    P1:  Climb a v-slot or arete to right of V slot.  Then either straight up (10d bolts and gear) or up and slightly right (11b gear) to a bolt and right to belay.    P2:  Up and right to a flake-crack~ up and right~ then down and right past bolts.  5.9    P3: MONEY!  Awesome 30m of fingers to hands.  5.11b bomber gear    P4:  MONEY!  Hands to fists. 5.10c bomber gear.    P5:  Up the dihedral (5.12d or 5.9 A0) past bolts.    P6: Traverse 30 right past bolts on the wildly exposed Green Line ledge 5.5    P7:  MONEY!  Up and left through the leaning corner.  Often wet 5.12    P6 and P7 bypass: traverse halfway along the Green Line Ledge (5.5) then up the bolt ladder to the top of P7    P8:  Do an awkward set of moves past a few bolts~ a tree and some gear placements~ mantle~ then up and left past bolts (5.10d).  OR head left after tree and follow a finger crack and other moves up to station (5.11a)    P9:  Up the nice corner 5.9    P10:  Scramble up and right past bolts and brush 5.5    P11:  MONEY!  Up the widening corner past a few bolts.  An 11+ variation heads right about 10m up  5.10d    P12:  Go to blocks on right side of ledge~ then up past bolts and gear. 5.10a    P13:  Straight up to under roof~ then left past bolts to a short crack.  Belay on tree.  5.10b    Walk left about 30 m on forested ledge.    P14:  Follow a blocky right-trending crack to harder moves off bolts past a short roof.  5.10d    P15:  MONEY!  Up the yellwo flake~ then undercling in a cool position into the base of the massive V-slot 5.8    P16:  MONEY MONEY!  Up the 5.3 offwidth for 10m past one bolt~ then stem and jam the awesome steepening V-slot hand and fist crack to a ledge.  Move up and slightly left past ledge to station. 5.10c or feels harder if you didn't bring enough water    P17:  Step to right side of ledge~ and wander up for two pitches on either slabs with occasional bolts~ trees and gear~ OR head up and slightly left through a gnarly ugly 4th class bypass to top of 2nd summit.  The route tops out on fairly close to Ultimate Everything.
protection: 60 m rope   2x Camalots from .3 to #3   1x #4 and #5 Camalot   1-2x blue alien/tcu or equivalent   extra draws and slings for ladders   med + small nuts

location: 7 - Kilowattito > Lower Tier > Cuarto Dinamo/Acoconetla > Los Dinamos > Central Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: One of the testpieces at La Coconetla. Rated 5.10d back when only a few climbers could do 5.12. A very physical line~ will test how athletic you are.    Start at the left finger crack and up to a small roof/bulge which you must exit to the right~ following a finger crack that widens until reaching a small stance. Continue up a tight hands crack in a dihedral (crux) until another small stance with a few cracks. Follow a handcrack up to a roof with a short OW section to reach the top of a pillar.    DESCENT: Bring an extra rope for one rappel from the top of the pillar or use the anchors of "Shirley Temple" for two rappels with a single rope.
protection: Standard rack up to #4 Camalot. Doubles from finger to hand sizes. As the name suggests bring your pair of cojones.

location: Palenque wall > El Palenque > Vinales > Cuba > North America > International
desc: This route also shares the first bolt of Confiscado and moves right where Allez~ Allez~ Allez! branches off. This route traverses farther right than Allez~ Allez~ Allez! before going up.

location: Pasillo > Pasillo Frío (Juana Díaz) > Puerto Rico > North America > International
desc: < not filled out yet >

location: Piez Descalzos > San Sebastian Tutla > Central Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Short but pretty sustained with good movement and a couple spots where you have to trust some tiny holds.

location: Cap Blanc - Pointe-au-Pic > 03. Quebec City, Charlevoix, Portneuf > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: It starts to the right hand side of the corner~ the first bolt is strangely placed to the left~ but this is the way of doing it~ so you'll understand the name of the route (La poule in french means The hen). This is an excellent route with balancy moves.  La voie débute dans le dièdre de droite~ le premier scellement est étrangement positionné~ mais c'est la façon de faire~ vous comprendrez alors le nom de la voie. C'est une excellente voie avec mouvements d'équilibre.

location: Mini Super Wall > El Potrero Chico > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: mini super is a great place for 10s but theres not much in the way of quality 11s except for the very fun la presa...ramp up to bulge directly under cool tufa~ crux 1 has you cranking to the tufa using a right handed sidepull then off to crimps on bulge/face.  moderate vertical face climbing to a 2nd crux and then back to the cruisin!  fun fun.

location: Culo De Gato > Las Ventanas De Mina > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Short n sweet! A powerful~ bouldery route that goes up the left side of the wall.

location: B. Mur du Capitaine > Weir > 15. Laurentians > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Right most climb of section~ based on 2009 beta I have.

location: The South Gulley Left Side > Esler Bluffs near Williams Lake > Interior Plateau > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Climbs out of the cave. Short and stout.

location: Paintings Wall > Grotto Canyon > Bow Valley > Alberta > Canada > North America > International
desc: Start at a polished corner to clip a high first bolt then traverse out right to the next bolt. Trend right on nice edges and sidepulls to the crux below the bulge. Pull the small roof and make a few more moves to the anchor.

location: Los Chileros > San Isidro Canyon > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: A big move off a rail and then some hand crack and jugs.

location: Lower Virgin > Virgin Canyon > El Potrero Chico > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Really good climbing and a beautiful clean face. Climbs straight up on rusty bolts and trends a bit right. It's somewhat runout~ but with good clips.

location: El Monasterio > Central Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Buenos agarres pero hay que buscarlos.
protection: 11 placas y la reunion.   11 bolts + anchor.

location: Lakit Lake > Kootenays East (Kimberly/Cranbrook) > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Part roof~ part lay back and 100% fun. A must try.

location: Little Russia > Nordegg > Alberta > Canada > North America > International
desc: Non-stop~ technical sequence of crimps~ heelhooks and two finger pockets. Crux are pulingl onto the crux buldge mid way with finish on easy holds to the top. Named after Nathan Fok.

location: Lower West Wall > Golden Canyon > Yukon Territory > Canada > North America > International
desc: This is an obvious beautiful hand crack that goes all the way from the bottom to the top.

location: Great Expectations Area (FTGU Left Side) > From The Ground Up > Harrison Bluffs > Fraser Valley > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: This route starts on a small pocket between Carmen and Murder in the Dark. The first crux starts just past the first bolt. Use a good pocket to set up into an iron cross using thin edges that will lead to another good pocket. The next crux is at the second bolt where a left foot~ no hands dyno will get you onto a thin ledge. Traverse left from here to clip the 4th bolt on Carmen and finish as for Carmen.
protection: 5 bolts and an optional cam for the finish. A possible ground fall before clipping the second bolt~ but the climbing is not too difficult between the cruxes.

location: Blank Canvas > Devil's Glen > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: Alot like its partner climb to the left~ although may seem more difficult for shorter climbers.

location: Goat wall > Bow Valley > Alberta > Canada > North America > International
desc: FFA Tyler Kirkland and Mark Carlson    June 20~ 2017    This is a very modern addition to a big wall historically known for stout traditional climbing. This route tackles the face right of the Goat Buttress. It actually starts up an obscure and likely unrepeated route~ established by Peter Gatzsch and Andy Genereux in 2001~ called “Gatzsch Your Goat” for pitches 1 and 2 and again for part of pitch 7~ which was only realized after the drilling began. Fluffy Goat Butt-face was established ground up over the course of a few months~ starting early in the season owing to a particularly dry~ warm spring. Originally climbed at 5.10 A0~ it was then exstensively cleaned~ refined on top rope and later freed at hard 5.9. The result of all the work is a well bolted~ multi pitch adventure with rock quality better than most single pitch sport climbs in the valley. Keep in mind it is still the Rockies~ solid holds become lose in time and there are a couple of ledges that hold rubble. The climbing is technical and steep with wild exposure on the upper pitches. Cruxes are often puzzling and the path of least resistance is seldom direct or obvious. A single 60 meter rope~ 12 quick draws~ 6 shoulder length slings and 2 anchor slings is all you need. Tough finger pads will also help! The route has a long season coming into shape on average years by May and is often good until late September/ early October. It is in the sun from just after sunrise until about 3:30 PM. Parties can expect to take anywhere between 9- 13 hours on ascent depending on your ability to solve the puzzles and your skills as a limestone ninja. The descent is straight down the route via 30 meter rappels which takes 2-3 hours. Double rope rappels are not recommended on most of the route due to the number of non-plumb rappels and prickly stone. Your ropes will likely get stuck. With the hike in and out taking around 3 hours~ a single day~ car to car trip would likely be in the 14-19 hour range. There is a pleasant bivi site just uphill of the start of the route that keeps things more casual if used. The site is good for 4-5 people but no spot is large enough for a tent.   The climbing;   P1: 5.6~ 8 bolts 30m.   Start up the large gully moving onto the face on the left side passing two bolts to a ledge. A third bolt~ which is hard to see from below~ is up and left above the ledge. Step up left of the third bolt and climb a shallow right facing corner leading to stepped ledges and belay to the right.*Good to link with P2.   P2: 5.7~ 7 bolts~ 30m.   Climb up and left on increasingly solid rock.   4th class belay move 20m.   Scamper up slab above belay to the scree ledge finding 2 ring bolt a few meters to the right at the base of the slab above.   P3: 5.0~ 3 bolts~ 30m.   Climb the perfect slab above with the belay at the base of a shallow gully on the left.*Good to link with P4.   P4: 5.6~ 6 bolts~ 25m.   Follow the broad~ shallow gully up and left past two bolts before exiting the gully on the right up initially fractured slab to the belay at the base of the steep wall.   P5: 5.10+~ 18 bolts~ 35m.   The pleasant warm up is over. This pitch is sustained throughout with the puzzle beginning as soon as you clip the first bolt. Moving past the second bolt on the left will give a good start to the cryptic dance above. Watch out for rope drag by using slings (racked at 30cm works well) on some of the bolts under bulges.   P6: 5.10-~ 14 bolts~ 35m.   Follow the right trending ramp above the belay for two bolts before traversing right across a ledge. Climb the steep crack with good feet up the side of a giant leaning flake making an airy 5.9 move on jugs onto a ledge. Traverse right across the ledge staying as low as possible with your hands in the wide horizontal crack and your feet on low suspect looking holds(10-) making a final stemming move into the cave with the belay hidden below the roof on the left.* Pitch 4 belay of Gatzsch your Goat   P7: 5.10-~ 16 bolts~ 40m.   Make a steep move out right from the belay cave into the chimney. Continue up the stepped chimney with wide stemming moves~ exiting left when a notch between the chimney is visible above. Follow a ramp up and left to a 10- move pulling around a shallow right facing corer with the belay up left around a bulge.   P8: 5.10-~ 11 bolts~ 30m.   Carefully move up and left over lesser quality rock to better steep~ prickly rock above~ weaving around as necessary to find the best holds.   P9: 5.10~ 12 bolts 30m.   Slither down and left from the belay around an outside corner into a large right facing corner. Steep moves up the corner (10-) through a notch to gain a ledge and another few meters in a corner to another ledge. Climb up and right from this ledge to a few steep bulges (crux) below the belay. There is a sinker jug under the right side final bulge which is very useful but hard to see.   P10: 5.11~ 12 bolts~ 20m.   Delicately traverse left from the belay towards a right facing corner. Close to the corner climb straight up~ laybacking tiny crimps with small feet to a two finger crimp left hand and gaston pinch right hand. Luckily a jug is a grunt away. There are still some harder moves getting to the belay so be sure to take advantage of the rest stance!   P11: 5.10~ 14 bolts~ 30m.   Climb up the right side of the corner moving leftwards at the fifth bolt up excellent compact rock. Another sustained pitch with fun movement and great exposure! The pitch ends on a nice ledge with the belay up to the left.   P12: 5.11-~ 10 bolts~ 20m.   Cross the ledge over to the right facing corner. Tricky moves lead up the corner to a good rest below the roof and crux sequence. A few meters above the roof is the “golf ball ledge” and belay.   P13: 5.10-~ 8 bolt~ 15m.   Climb up on the left side of the belay towards a chimney above. Climb the outside edge of the chimney avoiding stepping right to the belay until it is at head height and can be clipped from the chimney.   P14: 5.11~ 15 bolts~ 30m.   Continue up the right edge of the chimney as it peters out into the roof above. Follow the bottom of the roof to the right before making a series of burly moves over the bulge on the right edge of the roof. Look for a good jug up and right from a good crimp and pinch just over the roof. Suspect looking but firm flakes await on a small ledge above the bulge. A final bolt and short wall above gain a great belay ledge.   P15: 5.10~ 12 bolts~ 25m.   Climb up and right over blocks to where a few tricky moves lead to a crack. A few jams and laybacks are followed by a blocky roof below a short chimney.   P16: 5.9~ 10 bolts~ 18m.   Carefully mount the choss tower at the top of the chimney~ finding good~ solid holds out right as you leap off the tower into the corner above. Follow the corner up to a small ledge where a delightfully slabby wall is climbed on the right side up a small arête to a belay ledge. *Good to link with P17   P17: 5.9~ 8 bolts~ 12m.   Continue up the corner left of the belay. Climb the corner generally on the left until it is time to carefully move right to gain the ledge~ finding the belay on the far right.   P18: 5.9~ 14 bolts~ 30m.   Step right across the gap staying as low as possible at first. Traverse right a few meters before following excellent featured rock up to an amazing layback flake. Follow the flake to a large ledge.   P19: 5.10~ 11 bolts~ 30m.   Climb above the belay avoiding lose rock~ traversing right after a couple bolts (manage rope drag with slings!). Climb past a shallow dihedral and up its right side pulling a steep move left around an outside corner on large jugs to a small belay above.   P20: 5.11~ 14 bolts~ 30m.   Move up above the belay stepping left at the second bolt. Don’t get sucked into the ugly corner right of the bolts! Finesse up side pulls and crimps through progressively harder moves~ finding the path of least resistance to the left of the bolt line~ to the first crux (11-) between the 5th and 6th bolts. Above is a rest which should be milked before entering the second crux. Follow thin~ sharp crimps to a right hand open hand pinch below the roof. Clip from the pinch and get ready for a pumpy sequence pulling the roof on more razor sharp crimps (11)~ eventually slapping out to a flaky pinch once above the roof. But wait~ it’s not over yet! A few side pulls up flakes lead to a dubious looking undercling. Move off the undercling up and right to a deep jug/hole. A second jug/hole to a hand jam leads to lower angled rock and a delicate step right onto the belay ledge.   P21: 5.8~ 8 bolts~ 20m.   Easy but somewhat loose climbing up the left side of the shallow dihedral to a small choss bulge before the belay.   4th class summit scamper 20m.   Scamper up from the left side of the belay~ crossing a small scree gully finding a final set of ring bolts up and right on a nice flat spot to enjoy the top!   Descent;   All rappels are 30m or less (linking pitch 16 and 17 is 30m) and down the way you came up except from the top of pitch 7. Rappel down and slightly climber’s right to find a ring bolt anchor at the lip of the massive roof. Another rappel from here gets you to another ring bolt anchor down and climber’s right of the pitch 5 belay.   Note;   There are alternate pitches 6~7~13 and 14. These alternate pitches were the original line of ascent but it was decided that the route as described above makes for the nicest line and the alternate pitches are not described. Keeping right at any bolt junctions is the way to go.
protection: 12 Quick Draws~ 6 should length slings~ 2 sets of 2 bolt anchor belay slings with carabiners.

location: Main Face > Flatrock > Avalon Peninsula > Newfoundland > Newfoundland and Labrador > Canada > North America > International
desc: Not a typical Flatrock route. Climb the arête to the right of Medicated Drama Queen. Although appearing blocky this climb was quite solid when established. You may be surprised how overhung it gets in the middle and the crux has the wildest pinch move in Flatrock.  Stay on the arête and out of the chossy dihedral for belayer safety.

location: 1 La Croisée des Chemins > d. Southern Area > Lac Long > 03. Quebec City, Charlevoix, Portneuf > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Long sport route that begins directly above the grotto where emergency equipment is stored. Can be done in one pitch but long draws are mandatory to reduce drag.  Longue voie sportive qui part directement au-dessus de la caverne avec les équipements d’urgence. Peut être faite en un seul pitch~ 2-4 dégaines longues nécessaires dans ce cas.  P1: 5.11 P2: 5.11+

location: La Boca > El Salto > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Climb a difficult bulge to easier mossy tufa climbing and hard finish.  There are two extensions above the first anchor below the roof that go at around 5.12d.  I haven't climbed this since we bolted it so sorry if I'm being vague.  The tufa system was mossy but might have cleaned up if it's been climbed.

location: Secteur Nord-Ouest > Val-Bélair > 03. Quebec City, Charlevoix, Portneuf > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Gateau à quatre étages~ court mais intéressant.

location: Goblin Wall > The Back of The Lake > Lake Louise > Banff National Park > Alberta > Canada > North America > International
desc: From the far left side of the tree ledge (bolt) climb some less than enjoyable rock for ~10 meters past a few bolts.  Where it begins to steepen~ keep going straight up (one can also go left~ which is less fun) through steep~ juggy terrain.  Cut right under the roof onto the face and execute a few thin face moves for the route's crux.  Belay at a stance.   The succeeding 2-3 pitches are stellar arete and face climbing.  It is easy to head off right to Love at First Sight (11-) and weave between face and arete~ which I think offers the best climbing of both routes.   The final pitch on the arete (10c) is spectacular~ thin and exposed with great stone to a grassy ledge.  Wonderful views of chubby water floating tourists and the Back of the Lake.
protection: 18 draws and a single rack to 1 inch offers the best options to pick your own path between the arete and Love at First Sight.  Double ropes aids in this tactic~ but a single 70 is likely the best alternative.

location: Black Slabbeth Wall > Cedar Point - Trifecta Wall > New Brunswick > Canada > North America > International
desc: 3rd route from the left and currently the hardest route in the area. after clipping the first bolt~ trend right on tiny sloping crimps until the rail past the second bolt~ then straight up from here. Be aware that the limestone sections have a lot more friction :)
protection: 3 bolts and anchor with rap rings

location: W Side > El Reliz / Cerro de las viboras > Sonora > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Crux entre 4ta y 6ta plaqueta. Un poquito sucia abajo en el primer bolt a la izquierda. Es una arista con pockets.

location: Peace > La Grande Falaise > Kékéko > 08. Abitibi-Temiscamingue, Nord du Quebec > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Première longueur 5.11~ la deuxième avec les deux prises collé au rocher ~5.13

location: Nightmare Rock > Murrin Park > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Start on the 5.9 ramp in the corner under the huge roof~ then traverse left via tips underclings.  Anchors at the lip.

location: Into the Shade > Devil's Glen > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: Fun traversing of big holds~ climb the face leftward to reach anchors shared with Ginsu.  Rated at 11a~ a broken hold in 2016 yields a harder climb now.  Again~ in June 2018 the bottom on this climb fell off.  Potentially changing grade once again.

location: Atlantis Wall > The Lookout > Echo Canyon > Bow Valley > Alberta > Canada > North America > International
desc: Short~ marred by not so beautiful opening moves but worth getting on. Not a warm up~ as it is very cruxy for the grade and strenuous.     Start near the benches~ there is a bolt that you clip after an opening mantle move.

location: The Main Cliff > Oregon Jack > Kamloops > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: An easier start will get you to a ledge~ climb the boulder problem off the ledge and finish on some larger holds to the anchor.

location: Avalon Wilderness Reserve (Cape Pond Head) > Avalon Peninsula > Newfoundland > Newfoundland and Labrador > Canada > North America > International
desc: This is the leftmost~ and easiest~ climb on the overhanging wall. The route climbs through steep terrain past a few bolts to a rest mid-way up. Milk the rest~ then climb through a cryptic sea of small holds (crux?) to the anchor~ which is easier to clip if you don't try to clip too low...

location: Gros Bonnet > 03. Quebec City, Charlevoix, Portneuf > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: « C'est à partir de Grimpe dans le Piton à l'automne 2011 que mes yeux se sont portés vers le secteur à gauche du grand gully et que cette ligne verticale marquée par plusieurs petits toits a attiré mon attention. Francis Perreault et moi y sommes retournés avec nos raquettes et tout l'arsenal d'artif pour l'ouverture en mars 2012. (Hugo Drouin)  P1 : 5.10+ 40m Start on broken rock to join a vegetated ledge. Take the ramp leading to an obvious corner (some chimney moves can be done). Delicately traverse right under the roof. Hanging belay.  Départ dans un rocher fragmenté pour rejoindre une vire végétale. Emprunter la rampe menant à un dièdre évident (quelques mouvements de cheminée sont possibles). Traverser délicatement à droite sous le toit. Relais suspendu.  P2: 5.11b/c 25m Make a few moves in the corner above the anchor and traverse right towards the orange arch. Climb over the roof (technical crux) and enjoy a long finger/Layback crack. Bypass a second roof by the right and join a small ledge with an anchor.  Faire quelques pas dans le dièdre au-dessus du relais et traverser à droite vers l'arche orangée. Surmonter le toit (crux technique) et profiter d'un long passage en fissure à doigts/dulfer. Esquiver un deuxième toit par la droite et gagner une petite vire avec relais.  P3: 5.10+ 30m Climb the corner up to a cavity~ reach a hold in the center of the face and mantle on three good edges. Finish off the corner and mellow out on the slab up to the bolted anchor.  Gravir le dièdre jusqu'à une cavité~ atteindre une prise au centre de la face et rétablir sur trois bonnes tablettes. En terminer avec le dièdre et finir en douceur sur la dalle jusqu'au relais bolté.
protection: Standard rack with micro-cams and doubled #0.4 to #2 (#0.75 really useful)~ bolted anchors.  Rack standard avec micro-cams et double 0.4" à 2".(0.75” très utile)~ relais équipés.

location: Arcotete > Chiapas > Southern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: With sit start 5.12b

location: La Ola (The Wave) > El Potrero Chico > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: This route begins with 90 - 100 feet of typical Potrero climbing~ and a mix of thinner technical moves between large holds. After going over (or around) the large block at the top of this section~ you come to the best part of the route (and the crux). Use the pockets out right of the huge tufa (you won't miss it)~ finishes just above the tufa. The moves are memorable and tend to keep you off balance. One of my favorite routes in the Potrero.
protection: 11 Bolts~ anchors above tufa. 70 METER ROPE NECESSARY (a 60 meter will NOT get you back to the ground)

location: Free and Easy > The Smoke Bluffs > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Very slabby climb that starts with a few nubs that will hold decently.  Initial bolt is kind of high~ 3rd bolt is kind of reachy from the right~  Harder route (11b/c) is to go at the slab head on. Easy route (11a) is to avoid the slab and go right.  Climb a thin finger crack on the right of the bolts as you get sucked into the offwidth cave between the rocks that allows decent fist jams at the crux.  Climb up to the 4th bold for a bouldery move to a bowl-shaped sloppy area where the 5th reachy bolt is at.  Continue climbing up right for small edges and bouldery moves to the anchor.
protection: 5 bolts with the bolted anchor with rappel rings

location: La Palma (The Palm) Sport > El Salto > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: first  route ever  bolted  in la Palma cave back in 2001.

location: La Boca > El Salto > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: This is a fun little route I bolted with Alex Catlin and Edgardo Baca. It's just right of a fuzzy Tufa route we established.  Stem up the dihedral past 5 or 6 bolts to an anchor on the left.

location: The Monastery > Chek > Sea to Sky (Squamish to Whistler) > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Start on the black rock and pull hard to gain the rest before entering the groove and steep roof above on jugs.   Extension is 5.13b~ 5m~ 3 bolts to 2nd anchor – extension FA Remy Larocque

location: The Sheriff's Badge > The Chief > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Pitch 1. 5.10c-11a. Beautiful~ sustained~ gently overhanging hands. Over graded in current guidebooks.    Pitch 2. 5.11c. challenging hands and fingers. As the crack peters out make a committing reach (dyno for the short) to a decent hold and pull over the arete. Very exciting~ but safe with good pro.     Pitch 3. 5.5 easy slab climbing to the top.
protection: Double set of cams~ 4-6 gold camalots for pitch one. No bigger than #3 camalot.

location: Carrot Creek > Bow Valley > Alberta > Canada > North America > International
desc: Climb book worm and continue straight up past a small roof to a cruxy bulge.

location: The Crest > Chek > Sea to Sky (Squamish to Whistler) > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Follow the rounded flake up on good hand holds~ or alternately tackle the "technical start with a hidden hold" as Bourdon's~ 2012 book describes. Move up big holds through increasing steepness and sequence-y movement.

location: Tiger Wall > Swift Current > South Coast / Burin Peninsula > Newfoundland > Newfoundland and Labrador > Canada > North America > International
desc: Excellent sport line up unique features. This route takes the right start of the two close lines of bolts. Climb a series of slanting undercling rails to a layback crack/feature. Climb this past more bolts to a sloping ledge and to the top.    From the third bolt onwards is shared with "Calvin"    NOTE: there are two bolts right above the sloping ledge. This is not the anchor~ the leftmost bolt is a spinner and shouldn't be clipped. Clip the rightmost bolt at this point and continue up 5 feet to the anchor.
protection: 7 bolts + anchor with rappel hardware~ shared with "Calvin"

location: (a) Great White > (f) White Walls > Skaha > Okanagan > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: A couple clips of good face climbing leads to a fun arete.  Fun hand jams provide respite before a balancy arete.  If the barn dooring doesn’t get you then the pump just might.

location: Meathooks Area > Grassi Lakes > Bow Valley > Alberta > Canada > North America > International
desc: As the name implies - lots of holes~ but definitely not shit.  More great steep pocket pulling up a sea of holds

location: Grand Central > Comox Lake > Comox Lake > Vancouver Island > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Climb easy start then up left facing corner before pulling right around the roof. Steep side pulls lead to easier finish.

location: Cueva de la Cumbia > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Left most route on the left tufa wall where the trail arrives

location: Sector 2 > Lake Amatitlan > Guatemala > North America > International
desc: Bolted By: Felipe Garcia  Black # 8 on the Sector 2 Topo Picture  Incredible route with varied climbing. Start on the right side of the draws using the crack until you get to the 4th draw. Be careful as there is a big loose boulder that you will need to use in order for you to traverse above the roof. Once there~ you will enter a beautiful crimpfest that wont end until you clip the anchors. 5 star route.
protection: 12 Quickdraws needed. 2 bolts protect the anchor

location: Left > Roche Lake > Kamloops > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: This route is the most left route at Roche.  Many people feel that this route is easiest~ however it is easy to find yourself wandering a bit.  Well protected with lots of bolts.  Good for the novice leader.

location: La Escalera > Nuevo Bayamón > Puerto Rico > North America > International
desc: Harder start leads to easier climbing higher up.
protection: 6 bolts to chain anchors. Beginners may want to stick clip the first one.

location: Baby Face > Manuels > Conception Bay South > Avalon Peninsula > Newfoundland > Newfoundland and Labrador > Canada > North America > International
desc: Climb the centre of the face through and obvious scar where a block was removed and an awkward mantle move.

location: Orange Cave > Cayman Brac > North America > International
desc: Fun route with the crux at the last move
protection: 5 Titanium bolts + 2 Titanium bolts at the anchors

location: The Circus > Chek > Sea to Sky (Squamish to Whistler) > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Start in a chimney. Climb through big jugs and flakes to a set of chains halfway up the wall (Squamish Select)    Flakes~ blocks and jugs. Easy~ particularly good warm-up for beginners since there's a general lack of decent easy routes in Chek. Big holds~ really big~ but still pumpy for the grade.     Not a good lead if it's your max...it's a bit of traverse and a slip at the wrong place could be an ugly fall into sharp blocks.
protection: Six clips and a sport anchor.

location: Baby Wall > Mount Maxwell > Salt Spring Island > Strait of Georgia > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: The leftmost climb on the wall. Start up the crack and finish up the juggy face to a fixed anchor.    Baby Wall

location: The Monster Ledge > Lion's Head > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: Find the easiest way you can up the cliff~ plugging gear along the way.

location: Lakit Lake > Kootenays East (Kimberly/Cranbrook) > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Lakit has a 5.8! Lower angle it's almost trying to be slab but Lakit style . Great route! crux is right after the first bolt.

location: Gibralter Rock > Nova Scotia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Good little climb~ sustained.

location: Main Wall > Mont Rigaud > 16. Montérégie > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Follow line of bolts to a fun finish.

location: Eastern Bloc > Gatineau Park > 07. Outaouais > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Climb up to a very high first bolt (potential for some good gear placements)~ then climb on good holds until you hit a small~ interesting hueco. Figure out the techy / balancy / crappy feet /crappy hands crux. Surmount the exciting exit and finish on good (compared to the rest) holds to the anchor. Very stiff for the grade.
protection: 4 bolts. Optional medium size gear for the start if you aren't comfortable. Bolted anchor.

location: The Dihedrals > The Chief > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: This route is a recent project that has generated a lot of online (and likely offline) debate in the last couple years. The goal was to clean a line that beginners could climb that basically tops out on the chief. It actually ends at Bellygood Ledge~ and I think the easiest finish to summit the first peak would be 4 pitches on the Upper Black Dyke at a sportingly bolt protected 5.10b rating.    I found it enjoyable~ and fairly 'adventurous' for  mostly 5.7 climbing. There are some loose flakes and blocks on the route and gear placements are not always simple. All of the pitches are 100 feet long or longer.    Pitch 1 - 5.7 Start about 100 yards to the right of the Black Dyke~ up a blocky chimney/corner crack system that is packed tight with table sized flakes.  There is a spacious belay ledge. Gear belay.    Pitch 2 - 5.8 Head up a pretty nice hand crack right off the belay ledge~ probably the crux of the climb and quite nice for about 30ft. Follow ledges and cracks to a belay at a large fir tree.   Pitch 3 - 5.7 Finger crack crux near the top.    Pitch 4 - 5.5 Climb up a tree to the top of a large flake. Traverse right and climb up into a chimney with terrible protection and brittle nasty feeling rock. Gigantic Bolted belay. This is apparently the start of a rap line to use during falcon closures and can be rapped with a single 60m rope.   Pitch 5 - 5.6 Mostly easy climbing.   Pitch 6 - 5.7~ A0 Starts with a nine bolt ladder to reach a hand/fist crack. Belay below the chimney. (Apparently there is a free variation that goes to the left of the belay station up a protectable chimney corner then traverses back right into the start of the hand crack. I am not sure what the grade goes at but I'd guess no harder 5.10-?)   Pitch 7 - 5.6 Fun series of chimneys to the top.
protection: Doubles to #2 Camalot~ 1 #3. I didn't use much gear smaller than a purple cam. Mostly gear belays.

location: Simpson Wall > Cochrane Lane Cliffs > Welsford > New Brunswick > Canada > North America > International
desc: Same start as Marge but instead of climbing the crack step right and climb the bolted slab. Small holds make for some enjoyable techy moves that require good footwork. Bolts are somewhat spaced apart making it a wee bit spicey.
protection: Standard rack. Bolted achor. Rap the route with a 70 meter rope.

location: Mini Super Wall > El Potrero Chico > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: More juggy face climbing on Mini Super.
protection: 8 bolts.  First one missing hanger~ but it's easy climbing at that point.  Shares anchor with routes to the left

location: Champion Crag > Castlegar > Kootenays West > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: none listed

location: Valle Azteca > Baja California > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Fun face climb on one of the pillars.

location: The Loft > Terrace Mountain > Terrace > Northern BC > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Fun climb with many good holds the whole way up. Shares the first bolt with Hatchet Man. Put up by JD and JB
protection: Two hangars with rings at top. 9 bolts.

location: La Source > Kékéko > 08. Abitibi-Temiscamingue, Nord du Quebec > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Bonne voie pour s'initier au lead extérieur.

location: Los Sabinos > La Presa Francisco Zarco > Durango > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Main crack is a left-facing dihedral~ but a multiple crack system is greatly used on the face.

location: Buffalo Crag > Rattlesnake Point > Golden Horseshoe > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: Through a roof~ thin crack to easy groove

location: Labedan - Right > Julien-Labedan > 15. Laurentians > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Head up the face with the glue-ins left of Beding Bedang corner~ at the fourth glue in~ traverse a bit left and head straight up some sweet flakes and holds.
protection: Mixed~ 4 bolts~ single rack up to #.75~ bolted belay/rap anchor.

location: 1. Amphitheatre > Mont-King > Val-David > 15. Laurentians > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: 1. Cross slab (little to no pro) and mantle up ledge on the left end. follow ledge to the right and climb up the thin cracks to a mantle on the next ledge.   2. Climb up to a small roof/corner with a crack in the back~ sloping ledge to the right~ get up on ledge (crux) and traverse right to sloping ledge with a big crack.   3. traverse right to corner (exposed) and (V1) keep traversing right to last vertical crack and head up over to a ledge (possible to belay here to see your second) and to the top of the cliff.    V1 - Head diagonally up the crack.    1. Traversez la grosse dalle (pas grand protection) et surmontez le petit mur pour atterrir sur une vire~ suivez la vire jusqu’à un relais sur pro.   2. Montez le petit surplomb/coin avec une grosse craque dans le fond~ rétablissez sur la tablette en pente et traversez a la prochaine tablette pour y faire un relais.   3. Traversez a droite jusqu'au coin (expose) et (V1) continuez de traverser la face jusqu’à la deuxième fissure que vous suivez a la vire (relais possible pour voir le second) jusqu'au sommet.    V1 - Suivez la craque diagonale
protection: Protect your second!!!!   big pieces are nice to have on the second and third pitches.

location: Main Wall > Val-Bélair > 03. Quebec City, Charlevoix, Portneuf > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Ridge climbing and you can also use a hand crack just right.   --   Grimpe sur l'arête et tu peux utilisé la fissure de main juste à droite.
protection: Easy~ anchor at the top.   --   Facile~ relais au sommet.

location: 05 - Antre du dragon > Montagne d'Argent > 15. Laurentians > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Welcome to a bit of undercling layback moves! Be careful~ falling on a cam can probably flex the flake enough to have some other pieces of protection fall out.  Bienvenu au dulfer inversé ! Faites attention~ tomber sur un coinceur mécanique peut probablement faire fléchir l'écaille suffisament pour faire tomber d'autres morceaux de protection.
protection: 3 bolts and a couple big pieces two #3 and one #4 or #5 and a #.75 for the exit. Glue-in anchor/rap.  3 plaquettes~ quelque gros morceaux deux  #3~ un #4 ou #5 et un #.75 pour la sortie. Scellements avec anneaux de rappel à l'ancrage.

location: a. Main Wall > Vieux-Stoneham > 03. Quebec City, Charlevoix, Portneuf > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Variations of the first pitch of Le bloc. 5.6 to 5.9  Différentes variantes de la première longueur du Bloc. 5.6 à 5.9

location: La Selva (Jungle Wall) > El Potrero Chico > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Es una buena ruta para calentar y escaladores nuevos~ esta exactamente a la derecha de Yankee Clipper    A new~ juggy climb~ good for warming up or for new climbers. Just right of Yankee Clipper.

location: LingHall Wall > The Left Side > Eagle Rock > Welsford > New Brunswick > Canada > North America > International
desc: This climbs the left most crack on the LingHall wall. Start on a thin crack that widens as it goes up the cliff. Start on this thin finger size crack~ the first few move will make you work then the crack widens providing better rests. Follow the crack up to the awesome chock stone and pull the lip. There is a fur anchor
protection: Take small to large cams~ a #3 cam is nice to have

location: b. Secteur multi-pitch > Lac Gervais > 15. Laurentians > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Superb crack! It's a classic.   A third pitch can be done sport: left (dirty) or right 5.9'ish    Superbe fissure! C'est une classique   Une troisième longeur possible en sport: à gauche (sale) ou à droite environ 5.9
protection: Single rack up to C4 #3~ bolted belays~ you may bring all your gear if you want!     Ensemble simple de protection  jusqu'a C4 #3~  relais fixes~ apportez tous vos cams si ça vous le dit!

location: La Escalera > Nuevo Bayamón > Puerto Rico > North America > International
desc: Slab start to pocketed vertical face.

location: 19 - Le Fou > Montagne d'Argent > 15. Laurentians > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Start with the diagonal crack then join the second one that is a bit higher to continue to the right.  Commencez dans la premiere fissure en angle puis rejoignez la deuxième fissure un peu plus haut pour continuer vers la droite.
protection: Multiple cam of the same size around 0.4 (x4) and two #1 (c4). One bolt to protect the exit.  Plusieurs petite protection de la même grosseur autour de 0.4 (x4) et 2 #1 (c4). Une plaquette pour protéger la sortie.

location: Escalera No. 10 > Parque Mirador del Sur > Dominican Republic > North America > International
desc: Esc. 10
protection: 4 Stainless steel bolts 2 Stainless steel bolts with 3/8" chains on top

location: Metcalfe North > Metcalfe Rock > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: This route has some tough moves down low but then eases up a bit around the third or fourth bolt. Mostly jugs up to the very top and then one hard move again at the anchors.

location: El Diente > El Diente > Jalisco > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: one of the classic rotes of the el diente area~ located at the "el colmillo rock"

location: The Courtyard > Mamquam FSR > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Starts near "Slab Your Face"~ but head left over the bulge to easy finish.

location: Cementera > Sonora > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Most climbed route here~ it's getting kind of polished now. First high bolt~ a bit spacy but fine.

location: Wall Area > The Smoke Bluffs > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: From the top of Mosquito~ step slightly right~ then continue up thin~ parallel cracks to the top.  Consistent~ interesting 5.8 finger jams and stemming the whole way.
protection: Gear to 2"~ emphasize wires and small cams. The gear is great to the top~ but every placement looks like it will be your last.

location: Crag X > The Smoke Bluffs > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: On the main Crag X wall~ climb up the pie shaped piece of rock using the large crack between it and the main wall. At the top of this pie shaped rock is an anchor with rap rings. Past the anchor is another route called Side Street that continues to the very top.

location: Waterfall Walls > Castlegar > Kootenays West > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: none listed

location: Morro Bluffs > Morro > Jasper National Park > Alberta > Canada > North America > International
desc: The difficulty will gradually increase from an easy corner to a small bulge to fun smearing at the end of climb. Short~ but enjoyable climbing.

location: The Breeding Ground > Little Tobago > Virgin Islands > North America > International
desc: Easiest way up The Breeding Grounds. 5.8 out of the water and up top~ 5.5 in between. Poor rock quality up top. Nerve-racking!

location: Lac Larouche > 05. Estrie - Eastern Townships > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Starts in a shallow corner and straight up to an over-hanging crack. Mantle up and move right~ then back to the left and straight up a small dihedral.  Débute dans un petit coin peu profond. Suivre la fissure jusque dans le dévers et faire un rétablissement vers la droite. Quelques mouvements vers le haut et la droite~ ensuite vers la gauche et terminer dans un petit dièdre.
protection: Basic rack with nuts and cams.    Équipement de base; coinceurs passifs et mécaniques.

location: Pyramid Wall Area > Cochrane Lane Cliffs > Welsford > New Brunswick > Canada > North America > International
desc: Climb a small buttress to a ledge. Follow a shallow right-leaning ramp up and right to a face split by a thin crack. Up this face to easier climbing up and right. Head left at the top to some nice flakes and end at a tree. A very fun route with interesting climbing.

location: Flying Coconut Crags (Ciales) > Puerto Rico > North America > International
desc: A long pitch with continuous climbing and a variety of styles to make for a long classic at the grade. Stick clip the first bolt and Getty ready to belay the cruxes near the ground as well as near the anchors. It's a long ride to the top.
protection: 11 bolts to a two bolt anchor with lowering carabiners.

location: (h) Garden of Eden > (h) Small Eastern Crags > Skaha > Okanagan > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Many~ many bolts. Slabby.

location: Mountains near Santiago > Baja California Sur > Mexico > North America > International
desc: A HQ left angling crack that hangs over deep water~ safe falls all day. Crux is at the beginning~ but some zapatos para roca might help
protection: Send er with deep water style

location: Plum Wall > Las Estrellas Canyon > El Potrero Chico > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Follows some vertical cracks up the east face of the pillar. Originally climbed on gear.
protection: Bolts.    Trad gear with a PG13 grade. Small cams and nuts.

location: Pasillo > Pasillo Frío (Juana Díaz) > Puerto Rico > North America > International
desc: Easy climbing from bottom to top on good holds and good feet. Good warm up route.
protection: 4 bolts to chains with locking carabiners

location: Lower Hidden Walls > New Crest Creek > Crest Creek Crags > Strathcona Provincial Park > Vancouver Island > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: A highly enjoyable moderate. Climb the obvious crack up to a small ledge. Head up onto the headwall. A bolt protects the crux move~ then take cracks to a bolted anchor.
protection: Gear to 3" + quick draw for the bolt

location: Los Lobos Wall > Los Lobos Canyon > El Potrero Chico > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Fun limestone holds that don't pinch too much. Nice bolted route up to a chain anchor.  Rope wants to snag on small ledge with greenery trying to grow from older stumps when pulling from rappel.  Easy to re-lead & down lead from this point.
protection: Can't remember if I used 8 or 10 draws.  Good chain anchor.

location: The Raven's Castle > The Chief > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: P1 5.7 Climb straight up the  bolted belay.    P2 5.8 Head right (up is P2 of The Bow) then up a trough to the top.    Descend with 2 ropes or walk of to the south (left).

location: Agua Verde > Baja California Sur > Mexico > North America > International
desc: There are a couple of moves on iffy holds that add a bit of intrigue~ otherwise the rock is good and well protected.  It is fun to get out of the dark and still canyon when you top out in a sea breeze.
protection: Four quick draws and four runners gets you to a two bolt anchor.  One 50 m will do.

location: Yellow Sling Wall > Kinnaird Bluffs > Castlegar > Kootenays West > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: none listed
protection: Lots of small gear. Limited placements in areas. Two bolts down low. Chain anchors.

location: Funarama > The Smoke Bluffs > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: A high quality crack that takes great gear.  The start is the crux and looks harder than it is.
protection: Finger to hand sized cams and nuts.  Bolted anchor.

location: 5 Fougère à me plaire > c. Central Area > Lac Long > 03. Quebec City, Charlevoix, Portneuf > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Big Gunks-style dihedral with lots of natural protection. Very popular.    Grand dièdre à la saveur des Gunks avec beaucoup de protection naturelle.   Très populaire.

location: 16 - Controverse > Montagne d'Argent > 15. Laurentians > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Little slab work to practice on~ one slab of the ledge~ followed by another ramp/slab to the anchors.  Petit travail de dalle pour s'entraîner~ une dalle à partir de la vire~ suivie d'une autre dalle/rampe vers l'ancrage.

location: Volcan Acatenango '72 wall > Guatemala > North America > International
desc: This route begins on slabby boulders and protection can be hard to find~ you'll blow all your alpine slings here. After a short chimney you'll anchor just 25m up. From here is the crux of the climb~ a slightly overhung section but the holds are big and all there~ again protection in this section can be sparse.
protection: I took a double rack of Metolius UL Cams and a double rack of DMM Wallnuts. Also at least 7 alpine slings. Almost everything requires extension.

location: Sector 5 > Nathan's Wall > Spillimacheen > Rockies > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: G.E. Crack is at the right side of Nathan's Wall.  It is the obvious~ incipient crack that runs up the wall.  The crack terminates at a cove.  At this cove is a roof with a crack running up through it.  Traverse right to the anchor station.  This route shares an anchor station with Salmonella Ecstacy.
protection: Trad.  There is no pro off the ground through the first 15 or so feet.  Strongly recommend any trad climbers be proficient at 5.9 or 5.10 trad before attempting this route.  The pro is quite tricky after the unprotected section through committing moves.  The 2nd half of the route is well protected.

location: Back Alley > Grey Mountain > Yukon Territory > Canada > North America > International
desc: * Submitted by Alex Weber **   This route is just left of a very large crack in the wall. I can't remember~ but you may use the crack at the beginning of the climb. About halfway or three-quarters of the way up you will be standing on this slabby wave feature~ and have no idea how to move up. And you'll ask yourself 'this is a 5.8?' Balance your way left and find some holds and go up.

location: Palissades de Baldy > 15. Laurentians > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Find the passage into the mountain and follow it until the narrowing ends.  Then climb up following the crack~ squeeze and chimney system until an anchor maybe 30m up.  Second pitch is short and gets you to the nice scenery.
protection: Trad gear.  No big gear required.

location: Secteur Latin > Val-Bélair > 03. Quebec City, Charlevoix, Portneuf > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Tout droit sur la face moussue~ à partir du milieu aller en diagonale vers la gauche.

location: La Siuranella Central > Valley Crags > Siurana > Catalonia > Spain > Europe > International
desc: A excellent route~ hard for the grade with a little bit of everything. Boulder problem off the ground~ leads to some easier bolts~ then crux starts where the rock color changes from orange to grey~ and doesn't stop for next 4 bolts.

location: Rifondazione Strapiombista > Domusnovas > Sardinia > Italy > Europe > International
desc: Fantastic face climbing past cool~ small features up the to big triangular roof in the middle of the wall. Pass the roof on the left side on steep~ fingery climbing to the anchor above the roof.
protection: 13-14 bolts to anchor with lowering hardware

location: Eggum > Lofoten > Norway > Europe > International
desc: A steep and juggy climb that requires plenty of power and less technical work~ Commando will give you full license to pull on your biceps and make noise.  Start at the same spot as for Joker Nord~ heading right at the first fork in the bolts~ but go left at the second. Get established on a solid hold and use small feet to make a big move off a slopey rail. More fun big moves will take you up and right~ and then back left through a fun sequence of unlikely holds. A final crack and side pull (Some jamming will come in handy. Good thing you are in Lofoten!) will get you to the chains.  The bad news is that the upper holds can seep~ making those jams and the last hold very slimey. Also~ this entire section of cliff is also popular with the sheep when it rains. Someone told them the beta that Eggum is dry in the rain. Expect to be in and amongst a good volume of sheep turd.

location: Ankatalwand > Ankatal > Frankenjura > Germany > Europe > International
desc: This super route has a bit of status to it~ and is therefore a little polished~ but it doesn't detract from the quality. The climbing is technical with small pockets and crimps to start with~ a nice tricky section up high~ and then a difficult overhang on pockets to close it out. Consistently difficult the whole length of the climb~ with short sections of slightly increased difficulty followed by good rest positions.

location: El Camino > Mascun > Rodellar > Aragon > Spain > Europe > International
desc: The route just left of Toma Castanazo.  This is another of the 7A+ routes on this fun wall.  I found it notably harder than Toma Castanazo and equally as good.  A must do.  It has a tough crimp move to get to the 3rd bolt and some powerful moves to get to the jug above he 4th bolt. The remainder just provides a completion for the good pump (although the rest are there to be had).

location: Sex Shop > Chulilla > Valencia > Spain > Europe > International
desc: A great route with a relatively easy slabby/vertical climbing up to a crux section with a bolt's worth of cruxy climbing. The rock quality is excellent and the climbing is really fun and engaging. Another long Chulilla classic. This route splits in the middle~ make sure to go left. The right variatioin is 'Happy End' 5.12d.
protection: This route is very closely bolted for the most part~ bolts up to a carabiner anchor.

location: Can Codola > Valley Crags > Siurana > Catalonia > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Bouldery start~ then crux after ledge~ then another couple hard sections up higher.

location: Raco de la Finestra > Margalef > Catalonia > Spain > Europe > International
desc: It's a proper slab~ this one. - Anonymous British climber.    If its polished limestone slabs that you've come for~ saddle up--you've hit paydirt.  This line is quite sustained~ with several engaging~ cruxy bits that slab aficianados will enjoy.  If you're not one of those~ move along to one of the many other fine routes on this wall.    Stick clip the first bolt and make tenuous moves to gain the slab.  Ooze upwards on disappointing rounded edges & shallow dishes.  A brief bulge at mid-height offers some respite~ with nice juggy pockets before the slabbin' resumes above.  The final bit to the anchor also offers a few nice incut pockets on steeper rock.

location: Diabólico > Cahorros > Andalucia > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Start up the short wall to a sloping ledge and from there make your way up a pyramid shaped tufa feature.   From the top of this continue direct until a short rightwards traverse gets a good edge and a high step up to the anchors.

location: El Camino > Tamadaba > Gran Canaria > Canary Islands > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Route 20

location: Oasis > Paredes del Pantano > Chulilla > Valencia > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Nice techy climbing with some good jugs for resting - you just have to find them!

location: Saint Nicholas Left Side > Saint Nicholas > Leonidio > Peloponnese > Greece > Europe > International
desc: Monks In The Gym 70 5.12b starts by scrambling up a series of small ledges to reach a large shelf. Pull powerful moves on extremely over hanging rock to get off the rest. Traverse right on pockets and fight your way up a very sustained 10 m sequence. Continue up easier ground to reach a anchor located at the back of a large ledge beyond the top of the steep face. A helmet is recommended and a fall could be quite scary.

location: Schillingsflüe > Switzerland > Europe > International
desc: 7a+   Bouldery start to a stance in the corner (can clip the first bolt from the uphill slope)~ then figure out a way up over a bulge. Continuous 6b-ish climbing after that. Fight the pump for the 35 m to the chains.

location: Corvo Spaziale > Isili > Sardinia > Italy > Europe > International
desc: Start a bit morpho~ then diagonally on good holds: few repeats

location: Schaukelwand > Reinhäuser Tal Nord > Göttinger Wald > Germany > Europe > International
desc: Follow three bolts straight up to the anchor. I would rap the route an make sure that it's really clean. Clipping of the third bolt is dicey.  Either extend the third bolt with a long runner or clip after you climbed through the section and clip from above.

location: Condominio Fechado > Arrabida Region > Portugal > Europe > International
desc: Start off on a slightly overhanging tufa~ then grab your way up to a mix of pockets~ then finish easy by throwing off a few jugs. The rock is super sharp and glassy~ and the climb isn't all that special~ but that DAMN VIEW!

location: Il Transatlantico > Pian Dela Paia > Arco and Surrounding Area > Italy > Europe > International
desc: The pitches are quite short and in some cases may be combined.  The third pitch crux follows an interesting dihedral/groove. Rock quality improves as you get higher.

location: Micro Theos > Theos > Leonidio > Peloponnese > Greece > Europe > International
desc: Fun juggy climbing leads to a bouldery traverse crux. Pull through the crux to more stellar climbing! This route has definite heel hook potential.

location: Mettmenalp > Switzerland > Europe > International
desc: 7a+    Very different character from the rest of the climbing here. For one thing~ you walk into the dark and cool canyon between blocks D and E~ so not the open gym feeling that the rest of the climbs have.    Two routes are marked~ numbers 18 and 103 (I think). The former refers to another 7a+ which goes straight up on some rusty mank.    Instead go up~ make the easy first clip~ then start working right on fairly easy terrain. Head straight up~ and find the short crux at the roof.     Huck for it! Nothing but air underneath~ anyways.

location: Ash Tree Wall > Burbage North > Burbage Valley > The Peak District > England > United Kingdom > Europe > International
desc: Climb the side wall to a right hand finish.

location: Summer Wine > Summertime > Kalymnos > Greece > Europe > International
desc: This is a short bouldery route starting on the right edge of the cave. It's overhang all the way but on mostlty good holds. The crux is pretty high and short (2 or 3 moves). If you have strong fingers you might find it soft. Fun to do.

location: Schwender Wand > Frankenjura > Germany > Europe > International
