desc: Cool technical moves up a vertical to slightly overhanging face~ until the end which pulls through a nice bulge.

location: Jupiter > Leonidio > Peloponnese > Greece > Europe > International
desc: Warum Warum scrambles up a moderate slab to achieve a technical face of slopers and crimps. High quality movement on a technical face will set the rhythm for the climb. Follow black streaks that lead into more pockets and crimps before hitting a large set of holes on the route. No real good rest but it feels good to get there and shake out. Continue on a relentlessly sustained upper section with thin moves all the way to the chains.

location: Breitenberg Nordwand > Breitenberg > Gößweinstein > Frankenjura > Germany > Europe > International
desc: Great steep climbing up the highest tower.  Two variations at end; going right to the corner makes it a bit easier.

location: Galatinani > Kalymnos > Greece > Europe > International
desc: This climb is serious~ difficult~ and all around rad. The two 6c pitches (pitch 1 and 4) seemed to be the mental cruxes~ sometimes making difficult and/or tenuous moves well above questionable bolts. The physical crux was on the second pitch~ but at least the bolts~ although corroded~ were a little closer spaced. There is a fair amount of sharp rock on this route~ especially as you get closer to the top. We had to leave behind new slings and hardware at the top of 5 and 3 to facilitate our rappel. The slings that were there were completely bleached and shredded. If you climb this~ bring a few extra slings and large quick links or carabiners to update anchors. Maybe a blade as well to cut off old tat. We rapped 5 to 3~ 3 to 1~ and 1 to ground with one 80 meter rope. Be aware that 3 to 1 could leave you in space if you don’t kick out and keep a swing going for the bottom 50’ due to steepness.
protection: Plenty of bolts~ but most of them are very corroded along with very corroded nuts. All hangers look good. Results of mixing metals in an area that sees water runoff and seepage. This route is super good and needs to be updated with new SS bolts or modern glue-ins. The belay at the top of the first pitch is solid~ well designed~ and free of corrosion. The rest of the belays have two bolts (some are questionable and/or rusted) but are not rigged for descent.

location: Wampe > Reinhäuser Tal Nord > Göttinger Wald > Germany > Europe > International
desc: Bouldery moves pass two bolts and lead to the anchor to the left.

location: Krottenseer Turm > Frankenjura > Germany > Europe > International
desc: This ultra-popular climb sees non-stop traffic on busy days.  The attention is justifiable. With impeccable rock~ incut pockets~ and an airy position~ this climb offers the masses a taste of the excellent climbing found on the classics to the left.    Begin up on a ledge accessed from the left end of Maximilianswand.  Take care clipping the first bolt(s)~ and move left~ under a slight bulge~ to gain a short dihedral.    Continue up and left~ past many sinker mail slot pockets~ into another dihedral which is followed up to easier ground and the anchor.

location: Lungern > Switzerland > Europe > International
desc: Pretty straightforward crimping up to an anchor (7a)~ and then for bonus points head left for two measly bolts that add a letter grade with much less obvious moves (7a+).

location: La Maison de Chevres > Leonidio > Peloponnese > Greece > Europe > International
desc: Tufa yarding to a reachy crux then an amazing headwall.

location: Odyssey > Kalymnos > Greece > Europe > International
desc: Ya Agori Mu is a nice and steep climb that is highlighted by a fragile tufa and bolder problem half way up the route.  Hard to onsite.

location: Fruto De La Mierda > Tamadaba > Gran Canaria > Canary Islands > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Route 7

location: Ivy Buttress > Polney Crag > Craig-a-Barns > Highland Outcrops > Scotland > United Kingdom > Europe > International
desc: Pull up from the good hold at the start to gain a small crimp for your right hand.   Pinch the arete with your left hand and whip your feet onto the starting hand hold and slap up for the under cling.    Now you are in the groove~ the difficulties ease a bit~ as you stem up the groove towards the capping overhang.    Make some more hard move to pass the overlap~ and sink you hand into the good crack above.    Polneys best hard route.

location: Jurassic Park > Kalymnos > Greece > Europe > International
desc: A great route with mostly jugs.  Houfta means jug.  From the fixed belay climb easy ground to the first few feet.  Low in the route there is a tricky move on some sidepulls.  Continue up on mostly jugs with a few big moves.  As the angle backs off the climbing eases to the anchors.

location: Volx > Provence > France > Europe > International
desc: A classic too   Good holds but overhanging.   Ends with columns.
protection: Well protected.   Last bolt is far from the anchors~ you get tired~ you fly 30fts ! (but no danger)

location: Can Toni Gros > Village Crags > Siurana > Catalonia > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Challenging yet doable climbing leads to hard crux section up top. The local guidebooks rate it 12a~ but the top is stiff for the grade. I vote 12b.

location: Secret Garden > Kalymnos > Greece > Europe > International
desc: Easy tufas to start then stem your way up a HUGE tufa fin!  The thing will play a different musical note every time you touch it.  So freakin cool.  I broke off a tufa before the fin so be careful what you yank on.  If you sort out the feet sequence this will feel easy.  One last move at the top may get you.    "Dong"...... "Dong"....

location: I Gumbi > Valle del Vero-Toirano > Val Varatella > Oltrefinale > Liguria region > Italy > Europe > International
desc: Starts easy. After a slightly tricky overhanging section on good holds~ pulls over the bulge and into a great rest stance. After which~ the real business starts.
protection: Glue-ins~ and an anchor that consisted of two glue-ins~ one with a quicklink on it. We left a biner at the anchors to prevent the rope twisting~ but it may not sty there long. The anchors are visible from the ground~ decide what you want to do before you head up.

location: Corvo Spaziale > Isili > Sardinia > Italy > Europe > International
desc: Hard move then sustained. After the interesting and very powerful first part~ there's a roof which often has rocks in the hole~ which has helped to make this route less popular than its neighbors

location: Ca la Marta > Margalef > Catalonia > Spain > Europe > International
desc: On 'Instint Animal' you'll find a nice boulder problem which leads to fun~ sustained~ and sequential climbing.  The crux comes between the 2nd and 3rd bolts on long moves between pockets. The third clip is a little tricky~ but the movement from this clip to a jug a body length above were incredible.  Scads of fun 5.11- climbing led from here to the anchor.

location: Desván > Tamadaba > Gran Canaria > Canary Islands > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Route 3

location: La Selva > Camarasa > Catalonia > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Awesome.   Starts of with near vertical techy moves and then begins to get steeper.   Crux is around the 6-8 bolts.   Some positive crimps and small footholds lead to huge undercling flakes and pockets to a pod at the anchors that you can practically climb inside!   Great quality.   There's an extension that goes from here to the top of the cliff.

location: Ankatalwand > Ankatal > Frankenjura > Germany > Europe > International
desc: This brilliant wall climb pierces the center of the nearly featureless Ankatalwand.   The rock is ideal~ speckled with tiny horizontal edges and a smattering of shallow~ incut pockets.  This the essence of technical face climbing~ where footwork and balance are king.    The route begins with wandering sequences up the dead vertical wall~ characterized by long cranks between crisp edges.  A slight depression provides a good shake below an intimidating bulge at 40 feet.  Long moves between good holds work over the bulge to a final test on the headwall.
protection: The first bolt is dangerously high.  The climbing to that point is not trivial~ but also not super hard.  Bring a long stick clip.

location: Sector Castrojo > Zona de las Frontales > El Chorro > Andalucia > Spain > Europe > International
desc: This route is just to the left of Little Brown Baby. It starts off on some easy slab climbing the crux is about midway up on some steep powerful moves on crimps and a couple two finger pockets. The crux was great. The fall is safe but the bolt that you will whip on leaves a lot to be desired~ so I guess the fall is safe as long as the bolt doesn't pull out. Until they get replaced It is not recommended to climb this route. I did anyway and had fun doing it but the guide said that the route is highly decomposed and it is not advisable to repeat this route. So you have been warned. There were anchors at the top when I climbed it.
protection: Maybe a hammer drill and some new bolts. Quick-draws.

location: Scholle > Reiffenhausen > Göttinger Wald > Germany > Europe > International
desc: Climb the overhang on the right side of the crag. Save some strength for the crux near the top.

location: Big Cliff > Hamor > Hungary > Europe > International
desc: Follow a big~ easy flake up to the business. Crux is a series of hard moves to a glorious dyno to a jug. Hard 3rd clip.

location: Oberes Diebesloch > Diebesloch (Thieves' Cave) > Kleinziegenfelder Tal 1 > Frankenjura > Germany > Europe > International
desc: Climbs directly under the roof with obvious cruxy section pulling up and over it to the the anchor.  Bouldery and so a bit different from the PE climbs on the left side of the cave.  3 bolts protect the face down low~ with a reachy move or two~ then a hard pull to get up and over to the chains.

location: Jetlag & Guacamole Section > Tartareu > Catalonia > Spain > Europe > International
desc: This route is not quite as sustained as some of the others in the area.   It starts off with some moderate climbing up to the gray stone.   You can get a good shake here~ and then its a crimpy and bouldery crux that leads to another good shake at a horizontal break.  From here~ climb up a short flake  to reach the anchors.

location: Visoke Pole > Omiš > Croatia > Europe > International
desc: Excellent route and already a classic one in this area. It begins with delicate crimps and balancy steps to a mid-section rest. From there~ its a feast of technical moves in small pockets~ and tufas. Save some juice for the awkward and tricky finish. Definitely a must do at this area!
protection: 10 bolts to a chained anchor with a fixed lowering carabiner.

location: Oberes Diebesloch > Diebesloch (Thieves' Cave) > Kleinziegenfelder Tal 1 > Frankenjura > Germany > Europe > International
desc: Decent holds to a crux revolving around a giant undercling.

location: Ourania > Kalymnos > Greece > Europe > International
desc: Similar to it's neighbor~ Captain Caveman~ this climb ascends very chossy looking rock yet somehow it all stays in place offering fun and increasingly difficult moves up the ever steepening wall.       A combination of holds that aren't as good as they look and some tricky sequencing give this climb it's difficulty.

location: Grand Boveda Left > Grand Boveda > Mascun > Rodellar > Aragon > Spain > Europe > International
desc: A series of long tuffa pipes basically take you from the ground to the anchors on this route. You almost always have two so it is possible to knee scum the whole way.    The starts is a bit odd. Then you get into the long section of double tuffas that goes all the way up to a break where the angle kicks back a bit. A bit more climbing on tuffa features leads to where it really gets steep and blocky jugs take ytou to the anchors and some depressing finishing holds~ slopers.

location: Spartacus > Kalymnos > Greece > Europe > International
desc: This namesake climb for the area has easy climbing out of the cave to a no hands rest then a crux through the pockets and huecos.  finish out on pockets.  Likely easier than the 7b+ rating it gets.
protection: Bolts to fixed steel biner anchor

location: Limeri > Leonidio > Peloponnese > Greece > Europe > International
desc: Big pulls off smaller holds down low~ then a nice engaging slab on immaculate grey rock above.

location: Boneyard Wall > Skaljari > Kotor Bay > Montenegro > Europe > International
desc: The leftmost of the Austrian routes~ "Speci" has small boulder problems broken up by good rests.    Stays dry in the rain.

location: Snatch Area > Cala Barques > Mallorca > Spain > Europe > International
desc: This line tackles the awesome set of tufas on the cave's right side. Begin either on the Snatch start pillar (traversing over the arch)~ or~ more logically~ from the ledge on the right side of the arch. Head up and right. Heading left into the end of snatch gets 8a and is known as Stranger Than Paradise.

location: Panorama > Kalymnos > Greece > Europe > International
desc: This is a fabulous extension to the classic 5.10~ Carpe Diem. Climb Carpe Diem to the anchor and prepare yourself for an additional 25ish meters of some of the best steep athletic tufa climbing in Kalymnos. Start the extension pitch with a bouldery crux (v3-4ish) traverse that links to a single tufa. Jug bash this beautiful feature until the anchor finding unique rests along the way including an incredible one ~35m up the route. I was blown away by this climb~ hope you enjoy the experience as well! This is a full 40m pitch~ please remember to knot the end of your rope!
protection: 25ish draws including some long ones to reduce rope drag

location: Merişor (Cranberry Section) > Solomon Rocks (Pietrele lui Solomon) > Brasov > Romania > Europe > International
desc: This line goes right up through the bulge and is always in the shade. Climb up the first crux at the bulge~ then hit some steep features above.

location: Siuranella Este > Valley Crags > Siurana > Catalonia > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Sustained~ vertical crimp line on slightly sharp orange rock. This route has several difficult sequences moving past the small roofs throughout.

location: Los Buitres > Zona de Arriba > San Bartolo > Cadiz > Andalucia > Spain > Europe > International
Main Wall > Jarlsberget (Jarberget) > Dokka > Oppland > Norway > Europe > International
desc: This is an excellent route on incredible stone. After pulling the initial crux-bulge you have miles of technical climbing to get to the 2nd anchor. The first anchor clocks in at 7b~ though this is certainly a sandbag.  !!!80m rope required. Knot your ends.!!!
protection: Bolts. Often fixed to the first anchor

location: Sincholagua > Ecuador > South America > International
desc: none listed
protection: 50 or 60 meter rope. Slings for horns and for rap stations. The rock quality is poor so don't expect much for good pro. Depending on the amount of snow at the time you may need light crampons and an ice axe. If you don't know bring them in case.

location: Illiniza Sur > Ecuador > South America > International
desc: A big ridge of crumbly volcanic rock on a fine Andean summit.  Lots of 4th class and easy 5th class climbing and possibly mixed sections depending on conditions.   Traverse above the Refugio on a bench heading south to scree slopes below the prominent first buttress of the east ridge. Gain the top of the first buttress by climbing directly up the face above the scree slopes on loose 4th class rock or gain it from the left in harder loose mixed terrain.  Either way~ traverse a knife edge of loose rock and volcanic dirt around a prominent tooth of rock and climb up more 4th class rock on another buttress to gain the crest again.  Push on through a nice section of easy 5th on bomber cracks to reach the summit ridge.  Rappel or down climb to the right about 50 meters to gain the top of the ice field on the regular route and finish up to the main summit.  Descend the regular route.  Below freezing temps for this route are optimal as it would freeze the loose rock and mud together allowing for more secure footing.
protection: Double length runners and single cams to red Camelot should suffice. Bring 3-4 screws for potential ice pro and for the decent. Bring a selection of double length runners for rigging rappels if necessary and for slinging blocks for pro on the way up.

location: Ruco Pichincha > Pichincha Massif > Ecuador > South America > International
desc: none listed

location: Guagua Pichincha > Pichincha Massif > Ecuador > South America > International
desc: This is an amazing day out.  Because you start and end in arguably not the same place...it is best to treat this as a travel day as much as a day in the hills.   Bus to Lloa from anywhere in Quito~ from Lloa walk uphill upon cobble street and dirt road~ trending right at forks and various utensil shaped intersections.  One could also talk to people and get a ride/hitch hike up to the hut.   From the hut~ slog up the obvious slanting trail to Guagua's summit.From here~ go north towards Padre Encantado~ encountering a charmless grass/pumice sub-peak along the blaze.  Should you be able to see through clouds~ you can easily see the southern scree slopes of Ruco from here~ if not~ utilize your elf eyes to find the path(s) of least resistance.  For best value~ continue down Ruco's east ridge and back to the teleferico.
protection: Compass and kilometer signposts throughout the paramo.

location: Cerro Aconcagua > Aconcagua Provincial Park > Mendoza > Argentina > South America > International
desc: A classic route that ascends the Polish Glacier up the East side of the mountain.  This route is not to be underestimated or taken lightly. This is a serious~ technical~ high altitude climb with serious risks. Due to the warming climate each season~ the climb is becoming riskier and riskier~ with fewer teams summiting or even attempting this route. Years go by when this route is not climbed~ and each year it is becoming more difficult to do so. If you attempt this route~ it is very likely you may be the only one to do so for the entire season. Above Camp 1~ you will be on your own. Make sure you are competent at climbing and navigating up technical ground~ while above 6000m/20~000ft.  The route can have a wide variety of conditions based on the weather conditions of the year. The route can have extreme avi danger~ large seracs and terrible loose rock. If possible~ consult local guides to get as much beta as possible about current conditions.  It is recommended you pre-acclimatize on other nearby 6000m peaks beforehand so you are able to ascend the 1000m+ of technical climbing from Camp 2 to the summit in one push. Summit day is generally 14-20 hours.
protection: Pickets~ Screws~ Standard Glacier Travel Kit. Two hybrid ice tools or one mountaineering axe and one hybrid ice tool. Avi gear.

location: Muela del Diablo > Bolivia > South America > International
desc: Climb up from a small cave in between a big boulder and the tower (with lots of trash and beer bottles)~ heading directly up the face (in the section facing the rest of the Muela del Diablo). There are far more bolts than could possibly be needed~ but this can also be done as a trad climb if you´d prefer to make it more interesting.
protection: Trad gear~ any size~ or bolts~ you know~ bolt-size. Two rappel anchors~ with the lower one providing a better path for your rope

location: Sector 2 - Pedra Jonas A > Floresta Nacional de Ipanema > São Paulo > Brazil > South America > International
desc: nice route in the shadow

location: Sector 2 - Pedra Jonas A > Floresta Nacional de Ipanema > São Paulo > Brazil > South America > International
desc: the first move is a little bit 'boulderist' and beautiful

location: Sector 1 - Gênesis > Floresta Nacional de Ipanema > São Paulo > Brazil > South America > International
desc: it's better to use the clip stick

location: Genesis > Cerro San Martin > San Carlos de Bariloche > Rio Negro > Argentina > South America > International
desc: A nice route to teach someone to lead on

location: Aviv Sector > Confluencia > San Carlos de Bariloche > Rio Negro > Argentina > South America > International
desc: Really enjoyable pocketed climb. Named in honor of Aviv Bromberg who first explored this canyon with the idea to build routes here. He passed away in Peru on July 20~ 2015.

location: Vescho Wall > El Chalten > Santa Cruz > Argentina > South America > International
desc: Work the crack and then switch to face climbing

location: Aguja Gillaumet > Cerro Fitz Roy Group > Chalten Massif > Santa Cruz > Argentina > South America > International
desc: Climb the furthest right couloir on the east face of Guillamet. This can be snow~ alpine ice or somewhere in between. The schrund can be the crux later in the year. Screws could be useful but there is some rock gear on the sides of the couloir. To exit the couloir~ climb a short mixed step which puts you at the col. Finish by climbing the Cosmena-Fonrouge to the top. If the rock is dry~ it is easy. If it’s cold and snowy~ the dry tooling is engaging (harder than M3) but is usually well protected. In general~ you want to trend right on the ridge and follow the path of least resistance. The crux is the 20m obvious dihedral. The summit snowfield usually requires crampons. Descend the way you ascended on fixed anchors of varying quality. Inspect the tat and reset the pitons! Or descend the couloir directly to the left of the Amy which also usually has fixed anchors. This rappel route starts a few meters to the climber’s left of the bottom of the crux corner.
protection: Double ropes~ single rack~ stoppers~ and a few ice screws. If the route is in winter conditions~ a few extra mid sized cams might be nice

location: Zona 10 > La Mojarra - Cañon del Chicamocha > Colombia > South America > International
desc: none listed

location: La Piedra del Peñol > Colombia > South America > International
desc: ZONA III

location: Tehuelche Inferior (Norte) > Cerro Ventana > San Carlos de Bariloche > Rio Negro > Argentina > South America > International
desc: Face climbing gives way to fun pockets up high

location: Ventana Sur Lower Sport Sector > Cerro Ventana Sur > San Carlos de Bariloche > Rio Negro > Argentina > South America > International
desc: Similar to all the other routes on this wall

location: Exodo > Cerro San Martin > San Carlos de Bariloche > Rio Negro > Argentina > South America > International
desc: A fun route with big holds

location: Frade e a Freira > Espirito Santo > Brazil > South America > International
desc: This is an adventorous climb that requires some experience. The climbing is easy~ but require planned logistics to the way back. This route is the upper chimney in the first ascent line to the Freira's (Nun's) summit~ and was named in tribute to a local climber called Amâncio Silva who died triyng to climb the Freira on the opposite face. Usually climbers approach climbing the Frade (Friar) via Normal Route and Graciliano Ramos route reaching the medium upper chimney and skipping the wide chimney start.  P1 - The first pitch goes up the chimney protected with old original bolts to a vegetated ledge. Watchout for loose blocks! Belay from a tree. P2 - Climb a clean slab with two bolts to under some blocks~ sling a tree and go up through the blocks. Belay from a tree. P3 - Climb up the easy clean slab to the summit with fixed anchors.  The way back is the crux~ and can be done in 3 different ways. A) Jumaring the back to the Frade's summit and rap the normal route. When you rap~ leave fixed ropes. B) Rapelling to the west face via Chaminé Itapemirim. This way you have a long hike back up to the car. C) Via a rap line opened by me and Naoki arima with fixed anchors in the southeast part of the vegetated crest between the two summits. Back in the base of the Frade's rappel hike between the vegetation to the south face until you reach a clean slab. Search for fixed anchors. Rap down and to the left to a whole/ledge with anorher fixed anchor and rap again to the base. Cross the woods to a pasture that will lead to Chalés do Frade hotel.

location: Itatiaia National Park > Rio de Janeiro > Brazil > South America > International
desc: Chaminé Idalício is located on the south side of the Prateleiras~ in the upper part of the Itatiaia National Park~ between the states of Rio de Janeiro~ São Paulo and Minas Gerais~ in the Mantiqueira mountain range.   Leaving Rio de Janeiro~ access to the upper part of the park is through BR 354~ entering BR 116 (Rodovia Presidente Dutra)~ just after the border between the states of Rio de Janeiro and São Paulo~ and heading in the direction of the cities of Itamonte~ São Lourenço and Caxambu.   Following 26 kilometers (about 30 minutes) by BR 354~ before the city of Itamonte~ is the Garganta do Registro. At this point you need to access the road to the upper part of the park~ which is on the right of the road~ so that it climbs towards Itamonte. The road is dirt and winding~ which follows for about 13 kilometers to the entrance of the park (Posto Marcão)~ where you need to identify yourself and then proceed to the Rebolças shelter for another 3 kilometers.   The Rebolças shelter trail to the Shelves is very crowded and relatively easy. The entire route is approximately 3 kilometers~ which takes about an hour to walk to its base.   The base of the Chimney Idalicio is on the south face and is easily located~ since there is a plate fixed in the rock and the first meters of the track follows a negative cleft with many staples in sequence.   The track is relatively short~ has four rope strings~ where the chimney technique predominates. Its first thread is followed by a stapled slot~ where it is possible to make a fixed artificial~ but at the end there is a compulsory free throw to the double stop. That bid is a half-body slit~ quoted in third degree~ but it's not that simple.   The second one is short and goes in a chimney to a simple stop~ after a block is trapped in the chimney.   The third strand is longer and goes inside the Shelves~ following an easy and natural path~ always using the chimney technique to a simple stop very close to the summit.   The fourth and last row starts with a short chimney throw and then follows an easy ramp~ then make a bid up to the summit.   The best descent option is the normal south face~ which is practically a hike~ with some easy climbing.   Difficulty: 3 IIIsup E3 D1 150m   Conquerors: Carlos Carrozinho~ Etzel Von Stokert and Giuseppe Pelegrini   Year of Conquest: 1964

location: Zona de la Nariz > Suesca > Colombia > South America > International
desc: This is an awesome start if you are headed up to La Nariz. Begin up the easy face where you can place pretty good protection. Make your way up to the next roof and take the line of weakness moving out left. Eventually you will reconnect to the line by move right and you should be directly under the diving board.
protection: Double rack from purple metolius to #2 camalot.

location: Sector Arriba y Visera > Cerro Ventana > San Carlos de Bariloche > Rio Negro > Argentina > South America > International
desc: Fun~ steep jugs and huge pockets to easier but still ok climbing  on pockets and edges.
protection: 7 bolts to rings. I used 3 17 cm Spirits and a small locker to get an equalized point for toproping.

location: Rucu Pichinca - Zona Politecnica > Ecuador > South America > International
desc: Check the descriptions: mountainproject.com/photo/1…

location: Zona de la Abeja > Suesca > Colombia > South America > International
desc: Straight up to a tree~ two pitches

location: Zona 8 > La Mojarra - Cañon del Chicamocha > Colombia > South America > International
desc: Nice long and sustained route
protection: 8 bolts + one biner to two bolts anchor

location: Zona de El Vivac > Suesca > Colombia > South America > International
desc: Three-pitch multipitch route. With a 70m rope you can combine the first two pitches but rope drag can be a pain. When rappelling~ you can rappel all he way down from the 2nd belay station. However~ a doubled 70m rope will barely reach the ground.
protection: All trad. Three bolted anchors. The first and second pitch is well-protected. The last/third pitch can be a bit run-out at the top when traversing over to the right to arrive at the final anchor.

location: Ana Chata > Sao Bento do Sapucai > São Paulo > Brazil > South America > International
desc: A classic on Ana Chata~ it's a mostly bolted moderate with a trad pitch in the middle. The guidebook 50 Classic Climbs in Brazil has an excellent topo and breakdown of the route.
protection: 8 draws~ most of them runners and a few cams

location: Entrada (Entrance) > Pedreira do Dib > São Paulo > Brazil > South America > International
desc: Keep your balance on this slab route where the first couple bolts felt the trickiest~ moving off the crack and onto the slab.

location: La Placa Verde > Hatun Machay > Huaraz > Peru > South America > International
desc: Shared start with Melissa. Get off the ground then traverse left until you're on the face. Take the bolts that continue to angle up and left. Eventually they end up going straight up. Enjoy fun climbing up edges~ flakes and pockets that is very typical of Hatun Machay. Good warmup route.
protection: Bolts to 2 bolt anchor with rings

location: Zona del Euqas Oluc > Suesca > Colombia > South America > International
desc: Follow the wide crack up from the base I would bring triples in 2 or you will have to do a lot of bumping. Follow it past a strange lieback move and work out good hands to a roof. The route ends there.
protection: Doubles from .4 to 3 with triples in twos.

location: Esandi > San Carlos de Bariloche > Rio Negro > Argentina > South America > International
desc: Bouldery 5.10a move at the start

location: La Placa Verde > Hatun Machay > Huaraz > Peru > South America > International
desc: Arete with the best climbing near the start.  Jugs bring you up and the angle eases to a much easier slab romp.

location: La Cueva de Los Gauchos > Inca Wakanka > Huaraz > Peru > South America > International
desc: A fun roof leads to huge huecos that don’t stop until the anchors.

location: Chabela > Cerro Castillo > Chile > South America > International
desc: Crimps and slopers bypass a bulge. Shares a few of the same moves with the route to its left at the top.

location: Setor Boas Vindas > Falésia Paraíso > São Paulo > Brazil > South America > International
desc: Probably the most classic route in the area. Crux between second and third bolts~ and after that a breeze to climb. Crowded on most days.
protection: 8 fixed bolts plus double bolted anchor.

location: Setor Chegada > Pedreira do Marmeleiro (São Roque) > São Paulo > Brazil > South America > International
desc: With an anchor showing rust~ a loose second bolt and some loose rock this route could use a bit of work.

location: El Naranjo > Inca Wakanka > Huaraz > Peru > South America > International
desc: Climb up the huecoed wall and move up to a small bulge. Climb left and then layback to the anchors.

route: Con la ayuda de mis amigos
location: Toconao (Quebrada de Jerez) > Chile > South America > International
desc: Nice blank face climb with a bunch of 2-3 finger pockets and some crimps and a bunch of fake-out holds that look good but.... crux may be between second and third bolt. Also has a chimney variation just to the left using the same bolts~ that's probably a 5.8

location: Ventana Sur Lower Sport Sector > Cerro Ventana Sur > San Carlos de Bariloche > Rio Negro > Argentina > South America > International
desc: Super fun and nice face climbing in the chimney of the leaning tower. The last two bolts can be stemmed which is easier than directly climbing the face 5.11a/b.

location: Aguja Carlos Daniel > Grupo Carlos Daniel > Los Arenales > Mendoza > Argentina > South America > International
desc: * IN PROGRESS **

location: Setor Parede Esquerda > Pedreira do Garcia > São Paulo > Brazil > South America > International
desc: Creepy start~ but overall nice climb with average sized crimps in a slighly slabby face.
protection: 5 bolts and an anchor at the top

location: Bauzinho > Sao Bento do Sapucai > São Paulo > Brazil > South America > International
desc: Sustained 5.10a/b climb with a tough crux (potentially 5.10c) on the 3rd pitch. Variety of fun and technical moves throughout the 3 pitches. Bolted anchors for 1st and 2nd pitches. Top out and hike down the trail.
protection: mostly trad with some bolts. bolted anchors on 1st and 2nd pitches. bring standard rack.

location: Sporting climbs Vina del mar > Chile > South America > International
desc: Crux is getting to and past the first bolt.  good holds after the first bolt~ but still very pumpy till the anchors.

location: Escenario > El Morro > Cholila > Chubut > Argentina > South America > International
desc: About three moves of spice around the overhang.

location: Sala de Aula > Lapinha > Serra do Cipó, Lapinha and Rod > Minas Gerais > Brazil > South America > International
desc: The crux is clipping the anchor at the top right after a well protected roof. An improvised etrier may be useful in cleaning the overhanging anchors.
protection: 3 fixed pieces plus a two-piece anchor

location: El Rodadero E35 > Ecuador > South America > International
desc: Crimpy start~ the crux is the first three bolts~ after that it gets pretty mellow

location: Sector 1 (right) > Shupluy > Huaraz > Peru > South America > International
desc: Climb up a slab until you reach a large cave. Balance your way up and then right through a fun sequence of movements until you reach jugs and an anchor.

location: Principal > El Maitenal > Rio Ibanez > Chile > South America > International
desc: The crux is in the 3/4 of the route. The beginning is on the ledge (12 feet high)~ so you and your belayer can clip to the first bolt. Or you can start the tall bouldery ledge from the ground without protection. I've seen crazy chilenos doing that too~ in the rain~ and strong wind ...  As I said~ the beginning is the same for this route and the next one~ Entre sombras~ which goes left from the first bolt.  Small one finger pockets~ tiny crimps and long legs is what makes this route a must!
protection: Mechanical bolts to the top~ which is protected with two chains for an easy rappel or just lowering on quickdraws.

location: Ruca Cura (Bomberos) > San Carlos de Bariloche > Rio Negro > Argentina > South America > International
desc: Somewhat awkward face/arete climbing. Avoid using the far left easier terrain to keep the route in the 5.10 range.

location: La Faraona > Paute > Ecuador > South America > International
desc: Long route up a pillar and through an interesting bulge. Beware an epic runout below the bulge - easy climbing but a couple holds that look a little fragile. Fun and varied climbing.

location: h) Chichis Pa' La Banda > El Escarabajo > Mendoza > Argentina > South America > International
desc: Interesting moves on not so great rock. Be careful with loose blocks.

location: Potrerillos > Mendoza > Argentina > South America > International
desc: The crux is passing the first two bolts. It's more of a tricky boulder problem with a nice finish along a crack to the top.

location: Fideo Bricheo > Hatun Machay > Huaraz > Peru > South America > International
desc: Start up a small pedestal~ move left and climb through a series of liebacks and underclings. Reach a strange crux but move left and finish on the arete above.

location: Sambo-Rondon > Cojitambo > Ecuador > South America > International
desc: Fifth bolted route from climber’s right.

location: Zona Del Espino > Las Chilcas > Chile > South America > International
desc: Don't cheat left. The route start easy and gains speed quickly

location: El Bosque > La Peña de Abejorral > Colombia > South America > International
desc: See topo. Can be found here.

location: Riverside Sector > Pichileufu > San Carlos de Bariloche > Rio Negro > Argentina > South America > International
desc: Fun~ interesting pockets and positions

location: Panza Roja > Hatun Machay > Huaraz > Peru > South America > International
desc: Long~ technical but moderate route that wanders a little

location: Zoologico Vertical > Banos Zoologico Sport > Ecuador > South America > International
desc: No information
protection: No information on bolts~ 2 bolts on top for anchor

location: Rucu Pichinca - Zona Politecnica > Ecuador > South America > International
desc: Check the descriptions: https://cdn-files.apstatic.com/climb/116799708_large_1556498123.jpg
protection: Trad gear. Nuts #2 and #3. Unsure what else.

location: El Circo > Piedra Parada > Chubut > Argentina > South America > International
desc: Delicate slab with traverse

location: Los Olivos > Huaraz > Peru > South America > International
desc: Climb to the anchors of Golpe and then above to a terrace. Some homemade hangers will protect you right after the terrace but you will then need to do some runout climbing on dirty rock. Reach a cool crack that is slightly vegetated and continue climbing clipping bolts that are relatively hard to see from below. The last bolt is missing a hanger and there is no anchor. You can either bring your second up and walk off by wrapping your rope around a large boulder on the ledge above. Otherwise you can wrap your rope around the boulder and downclimb to an anchor below the ledge and then lower off.

location: Principal > El Maitenal > Rio Ibanez > Chile > South America > International
desc: Very favourite route and also often climbed. Almost everyone has been up this one~ so it's very clean and great quality. Offers few good rests and a lot of fun.
protection: Mechanical bolts to the top~ which is protected with two chains for an easy rappel or just lowering on quickdraws.

location: La Tapia > Hatun Machay > Huaraz > Peru > South America > International
desc: Lower half of route requires delicate balance and good finger strength using small pockets.  Traverse left and up (crux) to reach midway ledge~ then fun climbing to slight roof/overhang and anchor

location: Cuyuja Crag > Ecuador > South America > International
desc: One of Cuyujas first routes! A combination of endurance and techy moves.

location: Anfiteatro > Piedra Parada > Chubut > Argentina > South America > International
desc: Follow the left-facing shallow corner to fun pockets and a two-bolt anchor.

location: CAC > Frey > San Carlos de Bariloche > Rio Negro > Argentina > South America > International
desc: p1: Start in a slightly dirty crack until you can traverse right on big edges to gain the first bolt on the clean face. Clip a couple more bolts en route to a ledge with a two-bolt anchor. 5.10b    p2: Follow the line of bolts up a spectacular face past thin edges~ weaving left and right to follow line of least resistance. Two-bolt anchor at small ledge/stance on the arete dividing East and North faces. 5.10c    p3: Follow the arete~ crux is passing the first two bolts~ then traverse right below the small roof is part of the summit block. Clip a bolt and crank over the roof~ continuing up the short headwall to the summit. Bolt anchor on the top. 5.10d    To descend~ do two single-rope raps down the back (South) side of CAC to an easy scramble down and around the South side to get back to your pack.
protection: Protection is mostly widely-spaced bolts (nice~ new~ recently replaced). Supplement with stoppers and a few medium-sized cams.

location: Aguja Frey > Frey > San Carlos de Bariloche > Rio Negro > Argentina > South America > International
desc: Climb up past the bolts and either join into Lost Fingers or go right and rappel off of Diedro's first set of anchors.
protection: bring doubles to #3 depending on when you choose to enter Lost Fingers.

location: East Face > Zona del Cubo > Las Chilcas > Chile > South America > International
desc: Pull the initial overhang to mount the platform block and cruise up the face to the chains

location: Las Palestras > Cajon del Maipo > Chile > South America > International
desc: Starts at a shallow left facing corner~ then gradually bends right up to a small roof.  Head around the roof to the right (do not go straight through the roof~ despite the orphan bolt) and to the chains

location: Wendell Spire > Castlewood Canyon SP > Denver South > Colorado
desc: There are two routes that complete the sector of Wendell Spire just before the boulders on the left. Cheesedick Soiree is the right of these two.    Begin with a hard move right off the deck~ or use some funky bypass traverse (cheater's option). A good option is to stick clip the first draw and take the move right off the deck. A line of cobbles and pockets leads to a final crux at 5.12 only 5 feet from the anchor. Crimpy~ squarish~ and polished this last key hold can be a stopper if you don't chill first because it comes following a complex and fingery section.    This is one of the best routes in this sector.

location: Menses Prow > The Gallery > Shelf Road > Canon City > Colorado
desc: Climb the face right of "First Strike" to an arete~ then over the roof right of a prow to join the ""First Strike" at the last bolt.  Climbing directly to the first bolt can be sketchy~ but it is easy to pre-clip by coming in from the left.  This is shown as "A Sheep in Wolf's Clothing (5.12a)" in William Prehm's photo topo.
protection: Six bolts to a rap anchor (shared with "First Strike").

location: Overhang Area > North Table Mountain/Golden Cliffs > Golden > Colorado
desc: Early in 2002 or late in 2001 Dan Hare added a fine new line immediately to the right of Mrs. Hen Places a Peck. This route starts out in the seam and either slips left to the large hole or picks off a move or two on the right. Chase the slippery seam/crack to a good rest at 20 feet. In principle~ a very thin (!) sequence follows with a good jug just out of reach. In February~ Pat Burwick flashed the route using these tiny holds; however~ there is a good hand to be found to the right and almost in the chimney and this hold could knock off some of the thin crimps. A large wing span will gain the jug from this edge. While this is a good route on solid stone~ it will probably be done most often using a stem into the adjacent chimney for the first half of the route. Nontheless~ it's clear that Dan's intent was to run the crack.
protection: Ten draws and a rope. Double bolt anchors exist at the top of Mrs. Hen and ten feet higher where a second double bolt anchor has been placed.

location: Cactus Rose Cliff > Shelf Road > Canon City > Colorado
desc: To find ths route~ look under the description for '[The Omen] (10d)'~ this route is just to the left of it and shares anchors.    We TR'd this really quick at the end of the day.  I noticed that the bolts were placed very well so that you can clip off of good holds.  This would be a good first 12 for the aspiring hard person.    Start up through the first 2 or 3 bolts on positive but reachy holds.  Fun moves in this section and the bolts are at chest or waist for harder moves.  Once you get to the horizontal break~ take a good look above you to determine a strategy for getting through this blank section.  I found this section to be brutally hard~ until I noticed a hold that I hadn't used.  This lead to a good sequence that was quite different than I had been trying before.  This will get you to good holds.  A few more moderate moves will get you to the anchors.  Nice shady route for the warmer times of the year.

location: Redgarden - Lumpe to the top > Redgarden Wall > Eldorado Canyon SP > Boulder > Colorado
desc: Jump! Jump!  This pumpy line takes the bolt line to the right of Darkness 'til Dawn~ then crisscrosses The Color of Pomegranates to join back into Darkness 'til Dawn above its crux. Shorter folks may have to Jump! Jump!
protection: 5 bolts~ a couple RPs for the start of the crack~ and cams from 0.3" (blue Metolius or green Alien) and up. We used a single rack up to #3 BD.

location: The Great Black North > Shelf Road > Canon City > Colorado
desc: Chuana Chavaria ascends a mossy water-streak~ and so is rather dirty by Shelf standards.  There are quite a few enjoyable sections~ but the inconsistent nature of the climbing combined with somewhat dirty rock detract from the experience.  Begin behind an ornery thorn bush~ with easy moves between the large flake & the main cliff.  Things get serious at the ledge~ with a nice introductory boulder problem on great water-sculpted pockets.  Crimps appear where the pockets thin out~ leading to a subtle scoop below a bulge.  Exit the scoop by moving either right or left~ to a crux encounter turning the lip of the slight bulge.  Once established above the bulge~ one more hidden bolt and a few easy moves lead to the anchor.
protection: Bolts to 2 bolt anchor.  High first bolt.  Stick Clip highly recommended!

location: Chuting Gallery > The Halidome > Empire > Colorado
desc: Presently the first bolted route in The Chuting Gallery~ Chute 'em Up climbs a nice 92 degree wall on very good stone. Scramble up to a flat tree and then shoot up a steep wall through three .11/.11+ sections before a rest at a crack/flake (gear) @ 55'. At 6' tall~ there are no real .12 moves~ but the accumulation of .11+ probably merits a .12a rating (under 6' tall uses a slightly harder~ alternate sequence).    The moves just below the flake (bolt 7) involve a blind toss that could stymie an onsight attempt... A final .11- section at the last bolt tops it off.
protection: 8 bolts~ 2" cam and 1" cam~ and mid-length slings.

location: The Graveyard > Clear Creek Canyon > Golden > Colorado
desc: This route is one of the longer routes at the crag with the crux at the top. Begin up the route on some technical face which then turns into two sections of thoughtful slab. Take a rest before the final hand crack roof. Crank through the roof~ and fire up some hidden jugs to the anchor.

location: Primo Wall > Clear Creek Canyon > Golden > Colorado
desc: Short but stout~ this is a slightly overhung route with somewhat powerful moves and not much of a rest. I won't divulge the beta~ but know that it's not just an overhang haul - it requires some careful balance.
protection: 3 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor with quicklinks. Third bolt is drawn incorrectly in the Rolofson guidebook; you can't see it from the ground~ but it's just over the lip of the ledge. To prevent horrendous abrasion of your rope~ clean on rappel.

location: West Ridge - part A - Verschneidung to base > The West Ridge > Eldorado Canyon SP > Boulder > Colorado
desc: P1 5.9~ 120': From a solid tree on a comfortable ledge~ scramble up and right onto a gentle slab and pull over a rotten bulge.  Move slightly left and join a finger crack to a ledge then up and right around an awkward 5.9 corner to the left end of a large slab system.  Climb the arête to your immediate left onto a face and up into an open alcove then up through the rotten bulge past a small pine tree and onto a large slab at the top of the ridge.  Establish a belay on the far left side of the slab near the base of the tower with the shallow~ left-facing dihedral.    P2 5.12a ~60':  Psyche up for the shallow~ left-facing corner on the tower.  First 35' packs a wallop with a bouldery .12a funky corner/face sequence into a dead vertical power-endurance finger crack with poor feet.     First pitch previously climbed by Steve Levin (AKA 'Dog Patch') but included here with permission.  The second pitch was done ground up and involved some cleaning.    Thanks to Rob Kepley for lending a helping hand in this endeavor.
protection: SR with extra finger-sized cams and one Camalot #3 to supplement the last belay at the top of the tower.

location: Red Devil > Central > Flatirons > Boulder > Colorado
desc: The first pitch starts above the trail at the last switchback below the upper south face of Red Devil~ 10a/b; 95'; 11 bolts. A boulder problem start leads to lots of fun~ juggy 5.8 - 5.9 climbing. The second pitch starts off the ledge and ascends a cream colored face to a powerful~ steep short arete with improbable moves in great position~ 12a; 35'; 4 bolts.    There are two variations to the second pitch. Hellzapoppin (11c/d) climbs the first 2 bolts on the second pitch~ traverses left around the corner~ and face climbs to the anchors. Hellacious (11d) climbs the arete and face 8' left of the second pitch and joins Hellzapoppin where it hits the west face.
protection: Pitch 1:  11 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor. Pitch 2: 4 bolts to 2 bolt anchor.

location: Free Form Wall > Sand Gulch > Shelf Road > Canon City > Colorado
desc: Another fine line at one of the better walls at Shelf.  This route used to be 12b in Van Horn's old book~ but has been slightly downrated.  Perhaps (much like the Mutant on Incredible Hulk boulder) the traffic over the years has taken the edge off of a few holds.  God knows there are a few routes at Shelf where the crux is taking the pain.    To find this route~ hike up the Sand Gulch canyon to the Freeform Wall.  Towards the left end of the wall is a bolted chimney with red homemade hangers.  This is Barney (5.9).  Two bolted lines to the right is Helter Skelter.  There is a very slight V-notch near the second bolt.    This is another route that can really sap your strength~ especially if you don't stand up on your feet.    Crank past 7 bolts worth of very nice moves.  If the razor crimp near the top is still hones~ you will be the first to know.  Have fun.

location: The Trough > The Narrows > Poudre Canyon > Fort Collins > Colorado
desc: This nice face climb is just right of the obvious crack feature. Crimp edges down low lead to a slightly overhung face that is higher quality than one might expect.

location: River Wall > Coal Creek Boulders > Carbondale Area > Colorado
desc: Make a dynamic move to the first bolt. There is a dynamic crux at the second bolt (a difficult clip)~ and then it is easier climbing to the top.
protection: Three bolts to chain anchors with fixed 'biners.

location: Cave Area > God's Crag > Gunnison > Colorado
desc: Starts just left of Smuggler. A long route and a tad run-out. Pulling the roof crux leads to an excellent~ sustained dihedral.    A 70m rope or some serious creativity is needed.

location: High Wire Crag > Clear Creek Canyon > Golden > Colorado
desc: Climb directly upwards to the first bolt (hard)~ then turn the roof with a fun move. Enjoy at least one pleasant surprise. Compose yourself. Head up a pretty face following bolts. It is generally solid and clean except for a bit of sandiness towards the top.    The bolt spacing is reminiscent of the Red Slab.    This route does NOT go to the midway anchor shown in Mark Rolofson's guide~ although with some shenanigans you could probably get there.    Rappelling with a 60 meter rope will only get you to the 2nd bolt. A 70 meter will reach the ground with rope stretch~ but tie a knot in the end!    It is difficult to belay from the top and bring up a second climber~ as they are invisible below the roof and inaudible because of traffic noise. If they fall before the first bolt~ rope stretch drops them onto the pointy rocks at the base.    This is a fun sport and adventure route which is worth doing.
protection: 11 bolts~ mostly coldshuts with a few modern hangers for variety.    Stick clip the first bolt or don't fall. It's a very bad landing!

location: Technicolor Wall aka Techno Crag > Ouray vicinity (rock) > Colorado
desc: Great climbing up through good holds leads to a crimpy crux sequence either directly on small incuts or staying right on better holds and a difficult reach back left and then a jug. More techy climbing~ good body-english here will see you confidently to the anchor.

location: West Side > Bird Rock > West Creek > South Platte > Colorado
desc: Start up the featured and vertical face~ placing a 0.5 to get to the first bolt. Really fun climbing gets you to a no hands rest. Place gear as desired on the way up and right to an arete/groove. Clip a 2nd bolt~ and pull another cruxy move. The intended line is climbed on the right side of the arete~ and the bolt is placed to suggest so; however~ it's still possible to climb left with an easier sequence. Either way feels in line with the route~ with the right option being on better rock. Look for smaller gear in a horizontal if desired (nice to protect a toprope). Scramble up and slightly left to a bolted face. If you place gear to get you to the next bolt~ be sure to have some double length slings. The next bolt is a little ways~ but the climbing is easy. Crimp and smear your way up an intermittent seam. Look for a good~ small~ and necessary nut placement on your way. It has sustained~ challenging~ and excellent climbing to the chains.    The meat of the climbing on this is excellent and on great rock. Too bad there is a large ledge in the middle breaking it up. Regardless~ I think the climbing is some of the best I've done at this crag.
protection: 5 bolts & 0.2/blue Metolius #1. Depending on your small nut selection~ you may want to bring some brass nuts to sort out the placement on the final face. Bringing that selection of cams should give you enough options to protect about as much as you could.

location: Sesame Street > Bear Creek > Telluride/Norwood area > Colorado
desc: Start right of Mr. Snuffleupagus. It goes through the left side of a car-size flake up high.

location: Sesame Street > Bear Creek > Telluride/Norwood area > Colorado
desc: A choss pile. It is kind of runout~ because the rock is too hollow for bolts. It climbs fun though.

location: Apple Cider > East  Animas > Durango > Colorado
desc: This is a great new route~ taking a nice line to the top of the cliff. Bouldery start and continuous techy moves characterize the first pitch. This route pushes the mind a little after the second bolt then turns more moderate for the second pitch.  Can be done in one pitch.
protection: The first pitch is all bolts.  The second takes some gear with a few bolts.

location: Riverside Zone > Grandpa's Bridge > Poudre Canyon > Fort Collins > Colorado
desc: This is an excellent~ short overhang. Start by following a left-leaning crack for 2 bolts to the base of the overhang. Continue out the short~ steep wall on underclings~ sidepulls~ and slopers. A final pumpy mantel brings you to the chains.

location: The Dark Side > Shelf Road > Canon City > Colorado
desc: Papillion was added for re-bolting effort beta.

location: Crosswinds > The Crags > CO Hwy 7 & Tributaries > Estes Park Valley > Colorado
desc: Nothing hurts quite like a splash of Parrot Bay after a late night with the good 'ol Captain Morgan. You'll be gripping crystals right from the get-go on this shorter Crosswinds endeavor. Climb up the pillar/ramp to the left of 'High Tide' to clip the first bolt and start cranking. Thin holds and accurate footwork characterize this sustained climb.

location: Dinosaur Rock > Central > Flatirons > Boulder > Colorado
desc: This is a 35-meter lead on the north face of Dinosaur Rock~ right off the Mallory Cave trail. It climbs nice tan and maroon stone down low to a long black streak/rib that goes to the top of the wall. You must ABSOLUTELY USE A 70-METER ROPE FOR THIS CLIMB!!!    Originally done as a toprope~ this is now a 14-bolt lead. Climb the first five bolts of The Shaft to a resting pod~ then step right to the other~ wider black streak/tufa thing. Follow this past nine more bolts all the way to the top of the wall on nice dark rock~ with a handful of intricate cruxes separated by 5.10/5.11 climbing and some other rests. Definitely a voyage...Double-bolt anchors are a bit left at the lip so the rope will run better; unclip the last draw while lowering to reduce wear on your cord.    There are a few no-hands rests ("pods") here and there~ but plenty of cruxes in between~ including one at the top. We named all the pods~ too -- seemed funny at the time.    Pre Pod~ Pinkler Pod~ Love Pod~ Post Pod....    Many thanks to the Flatirons Climbing Council~ OSMP~ and the Access Fund for making it possible to install new climbs and update old ones in the Flatirons.

location: River Wall > Elevenmile Canyon > South Platte > Colorado
desc: This climb starts out by working your way through a 2 ft long flared crack in the rock.  Gaston over the crack and head up and slightly right over very small crimps.  Climbing eases considerably after the 3rd bolt.  Really nice moves and well protected.  Worth doing if you are in the area.

location: Mural Wall > The Gallery > Shelf Road > Canon City > Colorado
desc: Just right of the Mural Wall~ pass one bolt on low 5th class climbing to reach a blonde face. Climb the crimps and other sharp holds to reach the crux bulge protecting the chains. Both current guidebooks list this as 12a. Maybe it was just the proximity to Motif~ but to me~ it felt easy for that grade.

location: Strategery Wall > Lime Park (a.k.a. Lime Creek) > Eagle/Vail/Minturn/Red Cliff > Colorado
desc: One of the better routes in this area.

location: Master's Wall > Cunningham Gulch > Silverton area > Colorado
desc: A hard start followed by sustained climbing on good rock. Classic.

location: 3. Trailhead Wall > Monitor Rock > Independence Pass > Colorado
desc: Don't doubt me~ there is some good climbing on this route.  P1: 5.11b. Boulder up to the first bolt~ and continue past interesting moves~ better than it looks from the ground. A good stance by a bush sets you up for the great finish on small crimps~ 70 feet.  P 2: 5.11 b/c. Climb right clip a bolt~ then bust left into a steep~ slanting~ right-facing corner. Pull through roof onto to a beautiful~ gently overhanging plaque of stone. Finish pitch with a fun boulder problem to the lip of the wall~ 70 feet.  P 2.5. Move belay up and left below pitch 3. Pass a tree and a 2 bolt anchor~ then make a short 4th Class move to a upper ledge system. Traverse ledge 30 feet down and left to a 2 bolt anchor below the 3rd pitch.  P 3: 5.12. Climb left off the belay ledge. Encounter a thought provoking slab crux trending left to a left-facing flake system. Pull through a wildly exposed roof~ P.D. climbs square on the bolts~ making for a fun boulder problem mid-pitch. Bust up and right~ climbing amazing varnished jugs on gently overhanging rock~ 120 feet.  P 4: 5.11-. Pull moderate boulder problem off belay ledge. It is a good idea to protect the leader with one of the anchor bolts. Follow pro though multiple slab cruxes~ spectacular flake system~ and a vertical dike. Finish this pitch with the last 2 bolts of "Meltdown"~ 155 feet.

location: Lion's Den > Boulder Canyon > Boulder > Colorado
desc: This is a great little route that packs a lot punch in short distance~ hence the name. On the right side of the cliff~ just right of a hanging arete is a line of bolts up a very steep wall. Stick-clip the first bolts and make a series of hard finger jams up to a solid handjam. Clip the second bolt and lay-back up a shallow seam~ past the 3rd and 4th bolts to a semi-good-rest. Clip the 5th bolt and crank up to the  anchor. Excellent and pumpy climbing for such a short route.
protection: Five bolts lead to a two-bolt anchor.

location: Iron Curtain > Sheep Mountain > The Narrows > Poudre Canyon > Fort Collins > Colorado
desc: Steep and fun climbing on dubious rock leads to the anchors.

location: The North Gym > Shelf Road > Canon City > Colorado
desc: According to legend~ this was the first route at The North Gym~ and this section of the cliffline is named for this route.  Established ground-up in October 1985~ this was also one of the very first routes at Shelf Road.    This steep slab begins with some intriguing~ off-balance liebacking but ends in a brutal slab crux with tiny slopey holds.  Not sold yet?  This line sports a piton and a 1/4" Star-Drive as well~ though both are backed up by 3/8" angle-iron bolts that are only 25-or-so years old.  Despite the old-school nature of the climb~ the rock is excellent~ and the first half is enjoyable and novel.    Lieback & fingerlock up the offset seam.  When the seam peters out~ make some difficult moves to the horizontal break and a great rest.  After a body length of trivial moves~ weave desperately between uninspiring edges that all seem to face the wrong way.  After the high horizontal break~ a few big jugs lead to the top.
protection: 8 bolts with red~ angle-iron hangers~ an old piton~ a Star Drive~ to a 2 bolt ring anchor.

location: Trojan Bunny Buttress > South Fork of St. Vrain Canyon > St. Vrain Canyons > Lyons > Colorado
desc: The Temptation Arete is an amazing line with a bit of agonizing history. It has been called~ "perhaps the best line in the South Saint Vrain Canyon". The climbing moves were originally freed by rope solo (RW) on jugs~ and the bolts were placed accordingly. My own first lead was very scary. Subsequent attempts by Greg Purnell~ Alan Nelson~ and Mark Rolofson (all very strong climbers and much better climbers than myself) led to the consensus demand for re-bolting~ with new placements described in detail. Before this could happen~ and unknown to anyone~ Rob Pizem led the line and claimed a 5.12 something redpoint. After this~ the line was re-bolted as consensus had earlier demanded. Now~ it is well (over?) protected.    The Temptation Arete begins on the furthest East face of TBB in a thin crack and seam. This section can be done on bolts or trad with small wires. Exit the crack/seam to a ledge just below a short technical slab. The arete proper follows after 20 to 25 feet. The top of the arete has a double bolt stance for toproping~ and the descent anchors are another 15 or so feet higher. The arete itself has at least two good solid 5.12 sections~ and overall the climbing never drops much below 5.11.    My own last attempt in December 2000 still evinced a pair of hangs. Nonetheless~ with the redpoint in the bag (?)~ the route should be considered open to all. The Temptation Arete easily gets three stars for the climbing moves~ the continuity~ the quality of the rock~ and diversity of technique used.    In addition~ it provides convenient access to the 5.13c project to its left. This line was bolted and led by Greg Purnell in September 2000 and should be considered off limits until he has a chance to pull the redpoint or until he opens it up to all comers. I tried it by top-rope~ and it is indeed hard.    Per Laura schmonsees: the main anchor is the the first one. It is loose~ easy junk to the second anchor. You can get off the first anchor easily with a 60m. Two ropes are not necessary and only deter other climbers.
protection: QDs only. This route has two anchors~ one at 115 feet and another at 130 feet. It is a double ropes only route. That said~ it may be possible to get off from the lower anchors using a 60 m rope by angling up-slope since the base here is quite steep. Protected by bolts~ it needs at least 15 draws to get to the lower anchor. A short section at the start was done on wires and curved stoppers.    Per Mark Rolofson: the route has 22 bolts and a 2 bolt anchor.

location: Blanco Basin Crags > Pagosa Springs > Colorado
desc: This is on the Lower Tier: Right Cliffband.    This is the bolted line to the left of Hummingbirds on Crack.  The direct start to this climb hasn't been done yet and feels very hard (and a bit contrived)~ in the 5.12- range.  If you use the crack of Hummingbirds on Crack~ it's a 5.10.

location: Convenience Cliff > Clear Creek Canyon > Golden > Colorado
desc: This begins on the right-facing flake above the ledge.  The crux is at the last protection bolt.
protection: Six bolts to a 2 bolt anchor with biners.

location: The Sapper Cave > Rifle Mountain Park > Rifle > Colorado
desc: This is located 100 feet to the left of the Sapper Cave all by itself.  This route climbs more like a trad route than the usual Rifle route.  I would have given it more stars~ but a couple of the flakes on the route scare me a little.  I don't think they are going to rip off~ but they are definitely hollow.  The bolts are pretty far apart~ but they are closer when you reach the crux at 2/3 height.  It is easy for the grade.

location: J-Crack Slab Area > The Book > Lumpy Ridge > Estes Park Valley > Colorado
desc: This beautiful pitch is located just left of Fascist Drill and shares the same first 25'. Climb up the little left facing corner past the bush~ and stem up into the roof on your left. Desperate underclinging leads out under the roof~ with small tips pods~ and smaller feet. When the roof ends~ turn the corner into the beautiful hanging dihedral (11c) and climb up it for a couple body lengths. Then step right up onto the face of Fascist Drill and climb it past a few bolts to an anchor. This pitch was first sent by Bernard with two fixed pins. It now sports a shady looking knifeblade and a wire.
protection: Mostly smallish stuff~ RPs~ small stoppers and little cams to 2".  There is a dicey looking pin and a fixed wire in the business area.

location: Cadillac Crag > Eldorado Canyon SP > Boulder > Colorado
desc: Begin in the attractive dihedral around the corner and to the left of Highway of Diamonds. Saunter easily up to the angular roof passing a small tree. Bomber gear can be placed here. Climb up and right with thin holds and very small gear~ turning the roof where it meets the arete. Join Highway of Diamonds to belay at a horizontal crack on the arete.     Finish the "5.9+" second pitch of that route to a two-bolt anchor atop the wall.
protection: P1: 1 each of cams #0 Metolius - #2 Camalot~ #1-#2 Loweballs~ and RPs.         P2: add a second set of cams from #0.4 - #1 Camalot.

location: Trojan Bunny Buttress > South Fork of St. Vrain Canyon > St. Vrain Canyons > Lyons > Colorado
desc: The Bruise Collector begins in the light~ tan colored rock in the center of the TBB formation. It is just to the right of the TBB slab and directly above the steep gully. It has a good flat stance for belay. Don't be fooled. This route~ originally imagined as a warm-up~ is much harder than it looks. At 75 feet~ The Bruise Collector can fork right for an easier finish or left for a second 5.12b crux that finishes up a narrow groove/dihedral with a roof move that gets you into the dihedral. The anchor on the right is shared with Europithicus. The main crux comes somewhere near 65 feet and involves some awkward moves around very blank bulges and felt 5.12b to me (this rating may come down if consensus demands). Overall~ The Bruise Collector felt very "Rifle-esque" with lots of body position and awkward stances. Two stars for the climbing moves~ the overall rock quality~ and the relentless pump. There is a section of loose-looking rock at about 60 feet that is left of the actual climbing. But it is still worth watching out; someone could bail out here for a chill before the crux.
protection: QD only. This route has alternative anchors at 85 ft on the right and at 100 ft on the left. It requires about a dozen draws and something for the double bolt anchors right or left.

location: Vertical Wall > Vallecito Crags > Durango > Colorado
desc: This route climbs recessed crimps~ a mantle move and a few pinch-holds following bolts to the top. It is really enjoyable cruxy-climbing.
protection: Fully protected with 6 bolts and two bolt anchor.

location: Sunday Wall > The Access Fund Trailhead > Main Canyon: Unaweep Granite > Unaweep Canyon > Grand Junction Area > Colorado
desc: The crux comes after a nice rest halfway up the route. There is a blocky arete and face that continues to below the roof. These moves are thin and tough. The moves through the roof are pumpy. Great route on awesome rock.

location: South Rim Routes > Black Canyon of the Gunnison > Gunnison > Colorado
desc: The crux is a thin~ stemming corner just like the enduro 2nd pitch on "Tague...". This is a really good and shaded route. It is .11b/c R! A pitch up high will get your heart racing. There are lots of hands and finger cracks like "Black Snake" or "Dragon Rider".
protection: RPs~ doubles to a #4 cam~ and nuts.

location: Sunday Wall > The Access Fund Trailhead > Main Canyon: Unaweep Granite > Unaweep Canyon > Grand Junction Area > Colorado
desc: This is a gem of a route that exemplifies the best that Unaweep can offer. The route gives you a bit of everything. The first third offers some steep climbing up a few devious holds. Gain a good rest and go up a shallow corner. The next few bolts navigate you through some great slab climbing and a high step on an awesome tooth jutting out of a rock band. The last quarter of the route follows easy terrain on gear to a ledge up and left. Excellent!
protection: QDs~ a single set below #2 Camalot. One #4 Camalot for the beginning.

location: Zappa Wall > Escalante Canyon > Grand Junction Area > Colorado
desc: Through the ever present Chinle~ do some small jams and crimps past the calcite. Climb fingers to a pod~ then gun for the anchors where it gets really small....
protection: Finger size cams and maybe a nut at the beginning. The end gets down to green and blue Alien size.

location: Big Rock Candy Mountain > South Platte > Colorado
desc: Childhood's End nearly caused me to voluntarily quit climbing. Or maybe it was involuntarily. My partner and I found ourselves in the middle of a full blown thunderstorm 10 pitches up this thing. In a feat of amazing poise and~ well~ luck~ he climbed one of the upper pitches~ runout almost an entire ropelength and climbing directly through a veritable river of water pouring off the slab... ever wonder how those huge~ vertical channels form? A pitch from the top~ unsure of whether bailing could even be done from that high on the climb~ we decided to anyway.  We did learn a few things though. First~ nothing will take years off your life quicker than multiple double rope raps from star drives. Second~ never forget to untie the knots in the ends of your rope before pulling them... Never! Third~ if you take a crap on a climb~ like my partner did~ it will come back to haunt you. Especially if you have to rap the route. The good news? With enough spare biners you can bail off Childhood's End~ even from pitch 11.  The climb is great though~ and I'll never forget it. Characterized by runout slab climbing the whole way. I felt every pitch except the 5.12 and 5.10 pitches were PG+ rated~ *if* the bolts don't fail. With one exception~ every single bolt is either a button-head or a star drive. That includes every belay (most of which are semi-hanging~ by the way). Hanging from a pair of ancient 1/4 inch bolts high on the wall~ I wondered what would happen if my partner slipped on that 5.7 R section... 100+ feet out with zero gear between him and the belay... Really~ it would be a great service to replace all these bolts - at least the belays - with modern hardware. That said~ the climb really is quite good. It's a definite adventure to climb such a huge piece of granite outside of RMNP. This area in the South Platte is absolutely beautiful~ and chances are you'll be the only ones for miles around. Enjoy!  Double ropes are an asset on this climb as many of the pitches wander~ as would be a few screamers for peace of mind.  P1 & 2: Begin a few meters right of the large boulder at the base of BRCM. Immediately right of this boulder is Fields of Dreams Running Wild - you can see a few modern bolts if you look carefully. A little further right is a very low-angle crack with a tree growing out of it. Climb this for a pitch or two all the way across the face to a two bolt anchor at the base of a short chimney (6-10" crack) at the right side of the buttress.  P3: Climb the chimney (#4 Camalot down low or #2 a bit higher)~ then the slab above past 5 bolts. 5.9.  P4: Step right off the belay to a crack. Up this for 20 feet~ then step left onto a slab with 3 bolts (5.9).  Or~ for a more difficult variation~ step up off the belay then sharply left past two bolts and into a water groove. Up this past another bolt to join the slab above (5.11).  P5: Clip a bolt out left~ then go around the corner and up the slab past two more bolts~ then run it out to the anchor. 5.8 PG13.  P6: From the anchor reach up and clip the first bolt~ climb right to gain the arete and a couple of bolts. Move up and left making a long reach (height dependent) to reach a nice ledge with a two-bolt anchor.  Belay here to avoid rope drag.   P7: Climb about 20 feet up to the first bolt. Traverse directly right about 15 feet to the next bolt (hard to spot).  Continue traversing horizontally right over a ridge to locate the next bolt.  From there spot and climb to two bolts up and a third up and left before the anchors for the crux (12) pitch.  Long draws would reduce rope drag somewhat but the zig-zag nature of each pitch makes combining them likely to add rope drag.  P8: The crux. Climb up off the belay to a finger crack and undercling~ clip a bolt and head around to the steep right side of the wall~ underclinging and clipping bolts along the way. Continue straight up. All in all 11 bolts on this pitch. 5.12-something and easily aidable~ but you'll still have to do 10/11 moves between bolts higher up.  P9: A great lead. Head up off the belay~ clipping bolts. Perform a difficult step left into a water groove and then continue up on easier ground. Sustained 5.10 and 9 or 10 bolts.  P10~ 11~ & 12: There are now new 2-bolt anchors at the top of pitches 10 and 11.  From the belay atop P9 climb slabs up 30 meters and left to find a single bolt. This bolt is out left of the direct line by about 20 feet. Next~ climb up and right 20 meters to locate a 2-bolt anchor. Either belay or plan on simul-climbing.  P11: Continue up thought provoking slab climbing clipping one bolt before reaching a 2-bolt anchor. P12 has no bolts~ no gear~ and ends at a large tree or at the top of the cliff.  Keep in mind this is not a trade route~ the only gear are the bolts and that crystals snapping of or damp lichen make this a focused if not difficult lead.  After topping out~ hike/navigate the summit rock slabs and ridge north.  Locate the anchors at the edge of the NE corner of the formation. It is recommended that you set-up an anchor and belay each other down to the fixed rap station. Down climbing the slab solo is potentially fatal. Make two 30-meter raps to reach the ground off bolted stations.
protection: 15 draws/slings.  A set of Aliens is adequate but a big cam is nice to have for the pitch 3 chimney.

location: The Brown Wall > Thunder Ridge > West Creek > South Platte > Colorado
desc: Approximately 100' to the right of the Reptile Butress is another... well~ big brown buttress! You can't miss this one~ 8 bolts take you up the left side of a brown prow.
protection: 8 bolts plus the anchor next to the dead tree.

location: Lincoln Lake Slabs > Mt. Evans > Alpine Rock > Colorado
desc: Start on the ledge.  Two options to start: either carefully climb jug flakes up and right to the first bolt (big holds~ one 5.9ish move)~ or start on the far right end of the ledge~ plug some bomber small cams in the flake~ then make a move up and left to the first bolt.   Pull through the bulge and climb the slab (crux). Tackle a short~ steep section before the anchors. There is an optional cam placement before the final bolt.
protection: 5 bolts~ optional microcams for the beginning~ and a 2 bolt anchor.

location: The Blank Check Wall > Lime Park (a.k.a. Lime Creek) > Eagle/Vail/Minturn/Red Cliff > Colorado
desc: This ascends the finger crack to the right of the "Blank Check" project. Climb fun fingerlocks and sidepulls to a good rest~ and surmount a small bulge to gain the anchors.

location: Pleasure Dome > Buena Vista > Colorado
desc: There are 2 variations to this route~ if you stay to the left of bolts~ it's a hard 12~ but if you stay right it's a soft 11.

location: Right Gully > Blob Rock > Blob Rock Area > Boulder Canyon > Boulder > Colorado
desc: Ginseng Rush is in the gully area of Blob Rock~ just right of Jolt Cola.    It feels scary between the 3rd and 4th bolt~ but it is not really dangerous. This is runout on 10a ground between the 4th and 5th bolt - gear can be placed here if desired.     It will work your forearms~ fingers~ footwork~ and lead head all at once! Nice climb.
protection: 5 bolts~ small wires and cams can also be placed if desired.

location: The Mission Wall > Clear Creek Canyon > Golden > Colorado
desc: In the summer of 2000 Greg Purnell put up a route through the main black sector of the Mission Wall. Gneiss Route starts roughly in the middle sector of the wall~ in the main section that has been cleared of undergrowth.  The climbing starts just left of the pegmatite band; this band holds a nice route in its own right.     P1. For Greg's route~ angle up left toward a small overhang and a tricky 5.11 crux 15 feet off the deck. Some interesting climbing in the 5.10/5.11 range gets you to a double bolt anchor at 90 feet. This makes a fine 5.11 pitch all by itself~ although it still needs a bit of cleaning at the belay ledge--you'll need two ropes to get down from the 120' anchor though.    P2. The second pitch jumps left a bit immediately for a questionable flake~ straightens out and heads for the black overhang above. The overhang can be negotiated on some remarkably huge holds at 5.12a. You can stop just over this roof or continue up the slab for 40 feet more. This provides good access to the Surette Ledge without the hair-ball scramble used when approached from above. Two stars for a lot of good climbing~ largely but not completely good stone~ and the well constructed bolting job.
protection: QD only. This two pitch route can be done with a 60 m rope~ but double ropes makes much better sense all around both for the raps and for the potential to string pitches together. The first pitch is 5.11 and the second is 5.12a/b.     The first pitch anchor is at 120' so be careful if you're only doing the first pitch.    Two finishes can be had for the upper pitch. One ends just above the overhang. Alternatively~ you can continue through the black slab above for another 40 ft and pick up a third double bolt anchor at the Surette ledge.

location: The South Slabs > Greyrock > Poudre Canyon > Fort Collins > Colorado
desc: This is one of Craig Leubben's favorite offwidths! It's only about 15' of climbing to the crux pivot at the lip~ but continue climbing the next 20' to a tree. Walk off.    Approach by the Grey Rock summit trail. Start looking towards Grey Rock about 5 minutes past the meadow~ and you will see the steeply angled offwidth boulder to the left up the slope. It takes about 1 hour to reach Go Spuds Go from the parking lot.
protection: A #5 and one or two #6 Camalots (c4s).

location: Meat Wall > Rifle Mountain Park > Rifle > Colorado
desc: This is a very nice addition from Martin~ a typical Rifle start with pocket and sidepulls leads to the second half where stemming and intricate corners prevail.
protection: 16 bolts - fixed anchors at top.    Rope length = I used a 70m but was told that a 60 m is just enough (but didn't check myself).

location: Cactus Rose Cliff > Shelf Road > Canon City > Colorado
desc: The crux is pulling the roof.
protection: 3 bolts~ to a two bolt anchor.

location: Rock Of Ages > Fern Canyon Rocks > RMNP - Rock > Alpine Rock > Colorado
desc: Hats Off is located on Rock of Ages.    P1. Climb the first pitch of Days of Heaven and belay.     P2. Do the first few moves of the second pitch then continue straight up a thin tips crack (12a). Climb up this seam until you are eye level with a row of grips heading right.
