Place a good piece of gear high in the crack and campus right. The hand holds are pretty good~ but the feet really suck. One can place a medium wire about halfway out the traverse. Continue traversing until you slab out on the far right shoulder of the cliff. The gear on this route is not easy to place. The RPs and TCUs are all solid but require some jiggery-pokery.    Hats Off is a hard route to on-sight! One has to be good at placing small pro and moderately  bold. The crux pitch is a good candidate for a pre-load. There is no fixed anchor on top.    Descend down the east slabs.
protection: This route requires small TCUs and RPs. Double up on TCUs purple through yellow. Several #4 and #5 RPs would also be a good idea.

location: The Bank > Shelf Road > Canon City > Colorado
desc: This is a beautiful line up the left side of Surreal Estate Wall (the third big clean wall reached from the standard North side approach). The belayer relaxes on inclined rock as the leader tackles the continual cruxes. A few shakeouts can be found and will certainly help. The first crux pulls through on pockets~ a mid-bouldery crux pulls edges before reaching a final overlap and the third major crux overlap. It is sequential~ pumpy~ and awesome!

location: The Gym > Shelf Road > Canon City > Colorado
desc: Start as for Butt Flambé~ and free solo up the low angled/slab ramp to a set of anchors at 35 feet. From here~ hang a long sling and traverse right to clip the first bolt of the route. After clipping the first bolt~ easily reach back and unclip the anchor sling. From the ledge~ climb straight up the striking arête~ using opposing sidepulls in the crack and the arête. At about 80 feet~ surmount a chossy ledge (tons of loose rock) and look up. From here~ a few more clips on a looming/ overhanging white and black streaked bulge protect the chains. Although the holds are very positive and juggy~ a pump sets in due to the steepness. Feel the exposure as you crank the overhanging prow at the top with the river far down below.    Despite never seeing anyone on this thing in all the years I have been going to Shelf~ I thought it was quite fun movement and spectacular position.    CAUTION - a 70 meter rope is required to lower to the ground.

location: New Economy Cliff > Clear Creek Canyon > Golden > Colorado
desc: This may be the chossiest route at New Economy~ so you know it's bad.

location: Pup Tent of Solitude > Main Elk Creek > Glenwood Springs > Colorado
desc: In my opinion~ this is one of the best routes at the Pup Tent.  The rock is bomber and it has great~ engaging moves all the way to the anchors.    Climb a colorful face past well-spaced bolts to a heartbreaking crux right at the anchors.

location: 5. The Middle Ages > North Side > Volunteer Canyon (The Cwm) > Sycamore Canyon > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: A long and unique basalt climb.  It is kind of a direct version of Edge of an Age.  Starts with Edge of an age P1 and follows same line past the first 2 bolts.  At this point Edge of an age splits right~ and STT goes left.  Step across into a stance at the base of a small left facing dihedral and climb to good holds on a flake feature.  Move up into a low-angle dihedral with an undercling rail feature.  From here~ climb towards and through a hanging dihedral with gymnastic movement to a smooth face with small features.  The smooth face ends in a hand jam pod and meets up with Edge of an Age to climb the last 80' of that climb's beautiful finger crack on arete.
protection: FA done without clipping any bolts.  The protection on this line can be sparse and difficult to place~ and some placements are unreliable.  Bring cams from 00C3 to #2 C4~ up to 4 0C3 size~ 4 1C3 Size~ and triples of 0.3 and 0.4.  Double 0.5 and single 0.75~ #1~ #2 C4.   2 sets of offset RP's~ a set of square RP's~ and a set of regular nuts.

location: The Pond > Queen Creek Canyon > Central Arizona > Arizona
desc: The harder line to the left of Desert Devil. Apparently holds have broken...

location: DWS West Side > DWS East Clear Creek > East Clear Creek > Winslow- Hwy’s 87 & 99 Corridors > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Great low crux for those who have super pinch strength and a sustained bit of rock climbing follows.

location: The White Wall > The Pit (aka Le Petit Verdon) > Flagstaff Area > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: This is an all natural variation to Total Recall that breaks off to the right at its crux and finishes just left of Fruit Bowl. After the jug rest of TR (7th bolt~ use runner) set up for the crux but continue cruxing to the right with a few ambitious and improbable long moves. Chase a couple more clips up thoughtful climbing up to and over smooth bulges.
protection: A dozen bolts if starting with Total Recall. Probably the same if starting with Joker

location: The Grail > Lime Kiln Canyon > The Arizona Strip > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Climb up and right out of a pod and through some easy (and at time questionable) terrain. A short section of ledges leads to the first crux trending left and to a shared rest with Horse Platitudes. From here enter the routes crux through very tight pockets and small edges. The climbs red point crux then comes several bolts higher with a strange right hand imaginary hold and a big move up and left to a gaston. Carry on to the chains. Only seen 2 repeats at time of writing. Originally suggested as 14a. A brilliant pitch!

location: West Side > Winslow Wall > East Clear Creek > Winslow- Hwy’s 87 & 99 Corridors > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Back-to-back boulder problems on bullet rock followed by delicate climbing to the top. Route name largely attributable to Winslow prison inmate who demolished his cell window with two successive punches.

location: Beaver Wall > 4 - Windy Point West > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Dead By 30 begins with a longer than it seems pull to an obvious jug and the first bolt.  A hard~ thin and insecure sequence or a 6 foot dyno gains the jugs in the ripples and the second bolt.  After a rest in the ripples~ clip bolt 3 and head up and slightly left through a wild ~V9 crux section involving slopers~ an undercling~ and a 3 points off dyno to a full pad rounded edge.  Carefully clip bolt 4 and encounter a very non-trivial sequence establishing on the slab above.  With the last bolt clipped~ either walk off up the slab after untying or move a few feet left to use the anchors for Last Supper.    A skilled and implicitly trusted belayer is required to climb this route safely.  The fall off of the end of the crux and getting established to clip bolt 4 has the potential to be quite serious.  A hard catch might be painful on the vertical wall~ but will be necessary to keep the climber off the deck should they fall while clipping.  The 3rd bolt is as high as it could reasonably be and it would be nigh impossible to clip in the middle of the crux even if a bolt were added.  Be cognizant of the risk and manage it appropriately.    Big thanks to Liam Oden and Alex Kirkpatrick for envisioning and equipping this line.  It had been previously scouted by Eric Rhicard (the current last bolt was added as a directional) but passed over as too difficult.
protection: 5 bolts.  You can either walk up the slab~ untie and walk off~ or move up and left up easy ground to the Last Supper anchor to lower and retrieve your quickdraws.

location: Main Wall > The Asylum > Jacks Canyon > Winslow- Hwy’s 87 & 99 Corridors > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: A cool looking line that manages to break through the large roof capping the lower tier of the crag. Off the ground~ two engaging sections of climbing lead to a technical and unique crux entering into the dihedral on the left side of the hanging double arête/pillar. Climb to the top of the dihedral and to an obvious rest at the horizontal. Recoup and fire the potentially heartbreaking last boulder problem over the roof. Follow the large flake feature leading to an interesting mantle to clip the anchor.
protection: 12 bolts to anchor with fixed carabiners. Stick-clipping the second bolt is nice.

location: Beaver Wall > 4 - Windy Point West > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Mt. Lemmon's hardest route to date.  Has seen very few ascents despite a lot of attempts by some very talented climbers.   A lot of very difficult and technical climbing packed into roughly 65-70ft.      Bring your power and your skin to play on this one.  Best to work on when its nice and crisp or say goodbye to your fingertips.

location: Mentor Cave > Virgin River Gorge > The Arizona Strip > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: A brief boulder problem compared to many of the other routes in the VRG.  Long pulls through the first few bolts lead to a very powerful and sustained V9 boulder problem crux.

location: The North Forty > Horseshoe Canyon Ranch > Arkansas
desc: Moderate climbing. The start is the "pumpiest" move that can be easily protected with a #4. Traverse left to the A. H. anchor

location: Coup D'etat Wall > West Main Bluff > Sam's Throne > Sam's Throne & Surroundings > Arkansas
desc: Climb the slabby face and dihedral to the point where the dihedral crack becomes a chimney.  There~ 1. climb the left side of the chimney to gain the clifftop~ or 2. go right on the face to top out.  I prefer option 1.  Good rock.
protection: Pro to 3.5".  Rap off trees or hike to the rap near the Chickenhead Wall or Diet Pepsi.

location: VD Wall > Jamestown Crag > Arkansas
desc: Begin in a crack just left of arête~ jog right at the break and go for the top. 60m rope is a must
protection: Will need a full rack mostly small to med gear.

location: The North Forty > Horseshoe Canyon Ranch > Arkansas
desc: Left facing dihedral crack right of Narwhal (the offwidth chimney route).
protection: Standard Rack~ optional #4. There are now anchors up top.

location: Coup D'etat Wall > West Main Bluff > Sam's Throne > Sam's Throne & Surroundings > Arkansas
desc: Climb up an easy dirty section to reach the acute left-leaning crack with a small roof move. After squirming up and over the ledge run it out to the top.

location: Ren and Stimpy > Horseshoe Canyon Ranch > Arkansas
desc: Easy dihedral with a few face holds. Gear is ok.

location: Climbing for Money > Stack Rock > Richland Creek Area > Arkansas
desc: It is unusual to face climb with passive pro~ so that makes this an excellent route for the cheap climber.  No need for those expensive~ new-fangled spring loaded camming devices.  Passive pro all the way!
protection: Hexagonals~ nuts~ and slings.  Nothing more.

location: Haw Creek East > Haw Creek > Arkansas
desc: Offwidth left facing corner with lots of face holds requiring no offwidth technique. Kind of a fun little route. Would be awesome if the crack went for a 100 ft. or more.
protection: Bring the big cams( #5 and #6 camalots )plus a few small cams for the horizontals. Bolted anchors are up on the left about 3/4 up the wall.

location: Fun Alley Wall > The Throne Proper > Sam's Throne > Sam's Throne & Surroundings > Arkansas
desc: The bolts up top (on the boulder above) have been equipped with steel chain and steel biners.

location: The North Forty > Horseshoe Canyon Ranch > Arkansas
desc: This is a steep jug haul route that has a black streak running down the middle of it.

location: Centerfold Wall > Mt. Magazine Proper > Mount Magazine State Park > Arkansas
desc: Start behind a large boulder. Stem up past the boulder to a nice crack. Good gear. Mostly face climbing around a crack.

location: The North Forty > Horseshoe Canyon Ranch > Arkansas
desc: Another short route with large holds to the top.
protection: 2 bolts to anchor (shares anchor with Chica Bonito)

location: The North Forty > Horseshoe Canyon Ranch > Arkansas
desc: Short wide crack. Traverse left for belay tree or traverse right to use Towley anchors.

location: Large Boulder > Jamestown Crag > Arkansas
desc: Slopey holds to the top of the boulder.

location: Crag Central > Mt. Magazine Proper > Mount Magazine State Park > Arkansas
desc: Climbs obvious right leaning crack that gets steeper right below the ledge. Everyone climbs this baby. There is even a cam stuck way down in the flake on the lower part of the climb waiting for someone to free it-be my guest!

location: Wall of Calamity > Horseshoe Canyon Ranch > Arkansas
desc: The crux is near the top

location: Psychology Wall > Area 51 > Bigfoot Hollow > Fayetteville Region > Arkansas
desc: Follow the path of least resistance as you zig zag your way up the route.  Keep right until you gain the ledge and the bolt will be in your face.  Then move up and left to the blunt arete when the holds on the face disappear.  Head up the arete to solid finish jugs and clip the chains.
protection: 4 bolts plus 2 bolt anchor with chains

location: Box Canyon > North Side > Lake Lincoln > Fayetteville Region > Arkansas
desc: Follow the thin seam up the dirty~ moss covered wall as you struggle to find gear.  The 1st piece is almost halfway up the route and it isn't exactly solid.  After that~ the gear gets better as the crack opens up a bit but the rock is suspect and a bit crumbly as many pieces have already broken off and some more are ready to break off.  The crux is convincing yourself to climb up the first half of the route with no gear placements available.
protection: Bring small and medium cams.  Traverse left at the top and use the anchors on Tormentor.

location: Cool Breeze Area > Cave Creek > Sam's Throne & Surroundings > Arkansas
desc: Rotten start~ probably why its a PG rating. There is a horizontal slot about 20' up. But everything up to it is hollow and flaky. Above is solid chickenhead and plates...good pro.
protection: Few pieces~ normal rack. The Fennel guide incorrectly states that there is a bolted anchor~ which there is not.  You must build a tree anchor or traverse to the anchors on neighboring routes.

location: Metal Wall > Jamestown Crag > Arkansas
desc: Easy climbing on jugs and flakes into a slopey end.

location: The North Forty > Horseshoe Canyon Ranch > Arkansas
desc: Previously a trad route exclusively~ this fun route can be climbed by gaining the low ledge and moving up the crescent flake.  Layback the flake and climb the face to the anchors.
protection: 6 bolts lead to a two bolt anchor

location: Western Chicken Ranch > Stack Rock > Richland Creek Area > Arkansas
desc: Begin in tight dihedral or pull jugs just to the left  of it. After the end of the short crack follow slopey chicken heads using horizontals for protection.

location: Crackhouse Alley > Horseshoe Canyon Ranch > Arkansas
desc: Good hands to some blocky climbing. Finish up a dihedral with wide cups or fists.
protection: 0.5" to 4"   Rap rings at the top

location: The Land Beyond > Horseshoe Canyon Ranch > Arkansas
desc: Just right of Tufantastic. Climb the right side of the chimney~ pulling a roof about half way up.
protection: 3 bolts~ 2nd one has a fixed draw. Fixed anchors.

location: The Footstool > Mt. Magazine Proper > Mount Magazine State Park > Arkansas
desc: Head to the roof then traverse right approx 5 feet then to large cedar tree at top and rap off tree.  Says two pitches but can be done in one with a little rope drag

location: The North Forty > Horseshoe Canyon Ranch > Arkansas
desc: Pull the start on Groovy but head straight up the face after clipping the first bolt on Groovy.
protection: 1 bolt then finger sized gear. Tree anchor at the top or step right to the Groovy bolted anchor.

route: Too Short for the Short Bus
location: The North Forty > Horseshoe Canyon Ranch > Arkansas
desc: A reachy crux at the first bolt~ followed by a slabby 5.6-ish arete to the top-out anchors.  Fun and relaxing.

location: Blind Man's Bluff > The Throne Proper > Sam's Throne > Sam's Throne & Surroundings > Arkansas
desc: Climb the vertical hand and fist crack on good rock 35 feet to the top.
protection: Gear to 3.5 or 4".  Rap off trees or hike over to the walkdown behind the Throne Proper.

location: Fun Alley Wall > The Throne Proper > Sam's Throne > Sam's Throne & Surroundings > Arkansas
desc: This previously X rated climb has been retro'd with 2 bolts to protect the runout on the last half of the climb and give the route a new G/PG rating. Climb through the small 2ft roof in the middle of this wall~ placing gear until you get just past half way up~ then clip the 2 glue-in bolts. After you top out~ there are anchors on the boulder above and right.
protection: Rack to #2 camalot~ 2 quickdraws for the bolts.

location: North Wall > Stack Rock > Richland Creek Area > Arkansas
desc: From guidebook

location: The North Forty > Horseshoe Canyon Ranch > Arkansas
desc: none listed

location: The North Forty > Horseshoe Canyon Ranch > Arkansas
desc: The small roof midway up yields the crux. Near the top~ the bolt line merges with Lion Tamer and uses its anchors.

location: New Roman Wall > Horseshoe Canyon Ranch > Arkansas
desc: Flaring wide crack with a tough move or two near the top.
protection: Gear - a couple finger sized pieces (you could place wide gear if you wanted to). Bolted anchor.

location: The Holiday Block > Rock Creek > Cowell/Deer Area > Arkansas
desc: A bouldery start leads to easier terrain with a pumpy finish. Finish on the diving board.

location: The Doomsday Wall > Horseshoe Canyon Ranch > Arkansas
desc: Nice line past ledges and a bulge to jugs.

location: The Arcade > Horseshoe Canyon Ranch > Arkansas
desc: Climb fun moves on a mild overhang at the start~ to a slight slab above. Finish on the right with a mantel over the ledge~ or left by continuing on the face a bit longer.

location: The North Forty > Horseshoe Canyon Ranch > Arkansas
desc: Quite a fun face route with thin climbing up to a bulge in which you pull to gain the anchors.  There is a plate about halfway up the route that is a little loose~ stay off of it.   Someone rated it 5.10 at one point~ but has been downgraded in new guidebook.  Agree with the new rating.

location: Seed Wall > The Outback > Sam's Throne > Sam's Throne & Surroundings > Arkansas
desc: Pumpy start leads to rest then traverse slightly left and top out.  Tricky placements.....

location: Mr. Magoo Rock > Horseshoe Canyon Ranch > Arkansas
desc: Sustained jug haul on steep rock.
protection: Five bolts and a two bolt anchor.

location: The North Forty > Horseshoe Canyon Ranch > Arkansas
desc: Pull up a gentle overhang on chickenheads and micro-jugs~ with somewhat awkward body positioning.  Sustained with no particular crux.

location: Upper Pilots knob > Pilots Knob > Arkansas
desc: start the left of the arête trending straight up to the large green rail around the fourth bolt. fixed anchors

location: Nomar Wall > Stack Rock > Richland Creek Area > Arkansas
desc: A series of tough moves protected by bolts leads to a break halfway. Shake out and cruise the chickenhead highway to the top.

location: Confederate Cracks > Horseshoe Canyon Ranch > Arkansas
desc: This varied climb requires a wide range of skills.Start by scambling to the top of the obvious block. Climb up the dihedral~through the chimney and into the crux hand and finger crack gaurding the anchors.   Description from Cole Fennels Rock Climbing Arkansas
protection: Rack to #4 camalot although i found the 5 usefull

location: Natural Disaster Area > Jamestown Crag > Arkansas
desc: On arête just to the right of Heat Wave

location: Dardanelle Rock > Arkansas
desc: Hard start fun finish. Named after the best dog in the world.

location: Candy Mountain > Sam's Throne & Surroundings > Arkansas
desc: Face away from the rock as you stem up to the ledge above the first bolt (looks harder than it is~ as long as you find the feet).  Then make a bold move as you grab the ledge~ and bring both feet over to the bolted cliff face.  Shimmy over to the arête to clip the second bolt~ and enjoy the fun climbing to the top with a couple of crux sequences in the middle.  A fun and (somewhat) heady lead for moderate climbers.
protection: 6 bolts and anchors. Rebolted with SS by the ARCC in 10/2019.

location: Breakfast Wall > Mt. Magazine Proper > Mount Magazine State Park > Arkansas
desc: Although a little too late for breakfast~ this is a quality new addition to the wall. Climb easier terrain to a high first bolt and follow the orange streaked arete past a small roof. Above the roof~ the difficulty eases off. Shares anchors with "Multi-Colored Poptart."

location: Fish Wall > Steel Creek - Upper Buffalo River > Buffalo River Region > Arkansas
desc: Follows the dihedral clipping the same first four bolts as Fish Butt. The route then trends right across the face through a cruxy series of crimps to good holds. The route then follows a line through a series of airy and tricky bulges.

location: Hero Maker Wall > East Main Bluff > Sam's Throne > Sam's Throne & Surroundings > Arkansas
desc: Using your wide crack skills run out the lower slab (a 6 would fit but it's easy). the crack reaches a corner becoming a roof crack with one power move; place gear~ pull move.
protection: Large cams and cordalette for tree anchor.

location: Valley of The Blind > Sam's Throne & Surroundings > Arkansas
desc: Start back in the deep chimney and with back against the wall climb up 20 feet or so for some gear. Keep working the chimney until the crack starts arching over you. Work your self to the front of the opening~ while plugging gear and approach the lip of the roof. Pull the roof and power through to ledgy territory and belay off a tree.

location: Meat Walls > Cave Creek > Sam's Throne & Surroundings > Arkansas
desc: A quality~ slightly overhanging arête feature~ naturally sweetened by a healthy runout above the last bolt.

location: Happy Wall > Fern > Fayetteville Region > Arkansas
desc: Start up the wall just left of the dihedral on easier moves which give way to thin holds and a difficult reach up to the chains.
protection: 4 bolts plus 2 bolt anchor with chains

location: The Far East > Horseshoe Canyon Ranch > Arkansas
desc: Stick clip High first bolt. Opening move is a short boulder problem on thin holds. A few good shake spots and then continued climbing to another short lived pull before going for the anchors. There’s a huckleberry shrub about 2/3 of the ways up~ if it’s in season~ enjoy the mid climb snack and save some berries for others.

location: Valley of The Blind > Sam's Throne & Surroundings > Arkansas
desc: A slabby climb situated between two cracks that will make you think the whole way up. decent rock leads to jugs and a small crooked tree at the anchors.

location: Dead Dog & Energamata Walls > East Main Bluff > Sam's Throne > Sam's Throne & Surroundings > Arkansas
desc: Climb the chimney to the base of the offwidth roof.  Pull through~ remembering the wall behind you~ on to easier terrain above.  Pulling another offwidth roof and slopey face gets you the the top of this big route.
protection: Gear to the biggest stuff they make.  Belay on trees and rap to the left on Inherit the Wind's bolts.

location: Main Wall > North Side > Lake Lincoln > Fayetteville Region > Arkansas
desc: This one is strenuous and hard to find/place gear on. I would think you should be a solid 5.10+ trad leader to try to lead this but I could be wrong. Pulling over the roof may be tough but since there are no anchor bolts on it you have to if you lead it.

location: Hippie Wall > Cave Creek > Sam's Throne & Surroundings > Arkansas
desc: Start on the large flake and follow it until it peters out.  Move through the strenuous but short face section then continue up the crack to the top.  Make an easy traverse out left to use the anchors on top of Sunshine Divine.
protection: SR to a #1 Camalot.  Tree anchor or traverse to Sunshine Divine's bolted anchor

route: In The Crack Or On Your Back
location: Confederate Cracks > Horseshoe Canyon Ranch > Arkansas
desc: I can't believe this route isn't on Mountain Project! This is a major classic!    The route begins in an easy dihedral with lots of stemming options. After about 20 feet the walls smooth out to form a perfectly blank corner split by a 4-5 inch crack. No faking it. Off width technique is mandatory. Near the top~ the crack widens up and you can wiggle inside a pod and cop a rest before continuing to the chains.
protection: I placed one #2~ one #4 and two #5 Camelots~ and a #4 Helium Friend. You could probably find a #3 Camelot down low. You can place a #6 as well~ though I'm not sure it's worth hauling up. This route is equipped with a bolted anchor.

location: Dead Dog & Energamata Walls > East Main Bluff > Sam's Throne > Sam's Throne & Surroundings > Arkansas
desc: Climb the sweet face~ following the bolts.  After the bolts~ climb the vertical crack~ heading up and left to top out.  Great rock.
protection: 5 or 6 bolts~ gear to 1"~ slings.  2 bolt anchor.  Rap or lower.

location: Chickenhead Wall > East Main Bluff > Sam's Throne > Sam's Throne & Surroundings > Arkansas
desc: One of the best moderate sport routes at Sam's    Begin on section of rather crumbly rock until you reach a steep headwall. From here a fun v1 boulder sequence gets you through the crux and onward to chicken head bashing up top.    The route used to have a fun little run out at the top but has since been retro bolted and is completely safe.     Classic

location: Main Amphitheater > Cougar > North of Town > Steamboat Springs > Colorado
desc: This route has tempted many a climber over the years; the several leaver biners are a testament to its deviousness. It was bolted as a project years ago and seemingly abandoned and largely forgotten.     Due to the strange placement of a few key bolts~ I believe the route hasn't seen a previous ascent. In July 2011~ the bolts were moved to make the route leadable.    It starts with some 10ish climbing~ then it cruises on easy climbing to the roof. Here starts a series of thuggish boulder problems which continue through the next 3-4 bolts. A mossy jug haul brings you to the anchors.

location: Twin Owls > Lumpy Ridge > Estes Park Valley > Colorado
desc: This is an incredible arete pitch which sits just right of the Tiger's Tooth offwidth.  The second pitch is rarely done but makes for a great summit adventure on the Twin Owls.  Approach the first bolt from the left and get ready for the exciting thin crux at the 5th bolt which is very thin.  Runout 5.10 climbing takes you to the first pitch anchor.
protection: All of the bolts and the bolted anchor were replaced with ASCA hardware as of 4/05.

location: Little Dude > Golden Gate Canyon SP > Golden > Colorado
desc: This powerful climb ascends a very thin roof crack.  Thankfully there are some jugs.  Begin from a right side of a big~ long ledge.  Climb up a short corner to the roof.  Move right out of the corner & onto the face.  A thin crack crux~ protected by Aliens~ leads out the ceiling to reach a jug.  Place stoppers & power out the ceiling on good holds to gain a ledge & the bolt anchor.
protection: 0.5" - 1.5" Aliens. Two green~ one-two yellow~ one red~ & one orange. #6~ 8~ 12 stoppers. Lower from two Fixe rings.

location: Pup Tent of Solitude > Main Elk Creek > Glenwood Springs > Colorado
desc: Crack of Despair is super desperate with a crux that will stymie you. Its moves are hard. This looks like you can jam above crux~ but don't unless you like your hands chewed up by the sharp rock. Just layback on it. Good luck through the crux...feet are key to unlocking the sequence.

location: The Hangdog Cafe > Devil's Head > South Platte > Colorado
desc: Hangdog Cafe really splits into three main features as you look at it.  There is a massive roof in the middle~ with mostly vertical walls on either side.  Crank Du Jour is on the right side of the vertical wall to the left of the massive roof. From left to right~ it is the second route on the crag.    This route is really all about a burly boulder problem between the first and second bolts.  Puzzle it out and the route is yours - after the steep crux~ the route turns to pleasant 5.11 vertical climbing.
protection: 7 bolts -bring a stick clip for the first bolt.

location: Greedy Gulch > The Narrows > Poudre Canyon > Fort Collins > Colorado
desc: Crossing Over is sustained and powerful.    P1) 5.12b. Climb the thin crack to the roof~ pull the crux~ and continue to the anchors.

location: Middle Ice Caves (CHUD area) > Ice Cave Walls > Rifle Mountain Park > Rifle > Colorado
desc: Not the best route in Rifle but definitely worth a try~ this unnamed route is great for those who are trying to avoid the crowds~ want something unpolished~ or have done everything else.
protection: Five quickdraws~ plus 2 for the anchors.  To lower off the anchors~ you will need at least a 50 meter rope.

location: Haus Rock > Keystone a.k.a. Montezuma > Colorado
desc: On the South side of Haus Rock~ start on an undercling and climb an obvious~ diagonal seam up and right to hanging chains.  An optional and exciting move to a jug past the chains adds a little bit of spice to the experience.  Grabbing the chains to clip the anchors is bad form.  There is also a direct start a few feet to the right of the traditional start which also goes at 12b but is a bit easier.

location: Candy Caves > Rifle Mountain Park > Rifle > Colorado
desc: Another great headwall in Rifle guarded by some steep powerful cave climbing. Cursed with a geological nightmare of choss~ spending approximately 219 hours digging through millions of years worth of about 38 cubic tons of old corral and  the shattering of a beautiful crystal by a greedy FA-ist this route has now been lifted of the curse and has become a very worthy tick in a very cool position perched on the morning side of the canyon.  Expect sustained power endurance climbing on mostly good holds followed by a very fun technical slightly past vertical headwall.   Stick clip the second bolt. There is also a belay/dog/child bolt if needed.

location: The Wild Westerlies > The Dark Side > Ophir > Telluride/Norwood area > Colorado
desc: Cueca Para los Gringos is a bouldery route on the slab that shares an anchor with Reggae on Broadway .

location: Spray Wall > Elevenmile Canyon > South Platte > Colorado
desc: Start up the slab just right of Only Entertainment and mantle onto the ledge (which is currently really dirty).  Head straight up utilizing multiple sidepulls.  At the 4th bolt~ there is a huge flake on the left that is really hollow and flexes - BE VERY CAREFUL - it will come off and probably wreck your belayer.  The route is actually pretty fun and has relatively sustained climbing.  For full value~ avoid stemming out right or traversing to stand on the ledge. If it wasn't for the corner on the right~ this route would be just as classic as the rest of the routes on the Spray Wall.

location: Buoux Block > Castlewood Canyon SP > Denver South > Colorado
desc: This is short but sweet. It contains a radical dyno just before the lip. This can~ and has~ been bouldered out.

location: Camp Bird Mine Rd/Mountain Rescue Cache Crag > Ouray vicinity (rock) > Colorado
desc: We tried to keep this route as "trad" as possible and at the time the boys were inspired by the film "Hard Grit"~ but we weren't quite willing to go that far with our style of ascent.  The bolts are spaced~ but if I remember correctly~ Chris Parker blew the second clip and still didn't hit the ground~ so I guess it doesn't get an "R" rating.  Anyway~ the climbing if fun~ the rock quality is great. It's a spicy~ tricky lead though~ so you may want to check it out on toprope first (which is easily accomplished).

location: The Whale's Tail > Eldorado Canyon SP > Boulder > Colorado
desc: Located on the south-facing~ west-side of the infamous Whales Tail Cave~ this severely overhanging~ gymnastc overhang involves a dynamic move to gain the central hold~ which is then utilized by using a toe hook~ then a swing out to the lip~ which is then heel hooked and surmounted via a rolling forward thrust move from out under the lip. This popular route is mostly top roped~ rarely lead~ and has been free-soloed only once. It has a variety of variations to gain the summit including a strenuous~ direct~ static version.
protection: Small stopper~ RPs~ and a fixed pin.  Two bolt Belay~ mostly used for top-roping.

location: Castle Rock > Boulder Canyon > Boulder > Colorado
desc: 4 pitch route right of South Face.    P1 & P2: Crux pitches. Traverse right over 2 bolts underneath the obvious~ thin crack (optional belay). Climb the crack to the first belay of Athlete's Feat. Logical to combine as 1 pitch.    P1 variation: climb straight to the crack past 1 bolt 20ft up (a bit spicy but secure).    There's now a 2 bolt anchor where the crack ends.    P3 & P4 (I haven't done them): follow dihedral left of belay to P2 of Athlete's Feat~ then move left again to easier climbing.
protection: Small-medium stoppers~ small cams to #1 Camalot and a few draws.

location: The Dungeon > Staunton Rocks > Staunton State Park > South Platte > Colorado
desc: This is probably my favorite route in the Dungeon. The pump is arm-numbing and the features are wild! While the crux is low~ I have seen many of strong climbers punt at the last bolt. Manage yer pump!  Boulder past 3 bolts~ place good pro~ then follow a few more bolts up the overhanging dihedral. When the crack dies~ face climb left then climb straight up on jugs. Clip a final bolt~ step left into the chimney and finish.  Cleaning Beta: Don’t try to play chicken with a tree... the tree will most likely win. Tram in cleaning all your gear/draws. When you get to your last piece above bolt 3~ clean it but stay trammed in. Have your belayer lower you out depositing you safely on the ground.

location: Main Crag > The Bowling Alley > Boulder Canyon > Boulder > Colorado
desc: Just right of "Frothing Green" is "Next to Nothing".      A pumpy line with three distinct cruxes~ each successively harder than the last.  The first crux is 11d~ the next 12a~ and the last 12b.  Involves intricate stemming and lunging and some significant power at the last crux to avoid the barn door effect.    There is a 2nd pitch.    Per Aeon Aki: The second pitch of this route is a choss pile. It is sketchy if not flat out dangerous reaching the first bolt after the break and the slab that follows drops down to about 5.8 until a dirty~ flaky exit sequence presents itself. Better to clip the Amazing Face chains and call it good.

location: Upper Wall > The Clock Tower > The Sport Park > Boulder Canyon > Boulder > Colorado
desc: If you climb 5.12 or if you are looking to grab your first one~ try this route out.  Very cool and  fun moves carry you up and over a prominent roof on an obvious line up the Clock Tower's Upper Wall.    The climb starts directly in front of the tree that's about 10 feet out from the wall~ at the bottom of a prominent triangular flake covered in bat crap. If you are wondering why there are no branches on the tree on the side that faces the wall~ just fall off the route while on TR. Swinging out from under the overhang and into its upper branches will give the term "tree hugging" an entirely new meaning. Once you tire of battling the tree while trying to swing back onto the rock~ clip the rope through the bolt just beneath the roof. This should keep you from swinging out while practicing the lower part of the route. The tree will thank you. Again~ I'm sorry to report that there is a chipped hold in the middle of the route below the large horn.
protection: 10 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor.  Quickdraws only.

location: Contest Wall > Sand Gulch > Shelf Road > Canon City > Colorado
desc: Start just right of Farts of Horsemen and ascend the same inset wall. How can two routes so close together be so different? No Tomorrow starts off in a pale~ nearly sandy looking crack. The crack is solid and kicks up very continuous and tenuous climbing for two thirds of the route's length. Above the crack the wall returns to Farts style climbing on flat cobbles and shallow pockets. No Tomorrow offers another superb challenge~ out of the sun~ and on largely very solid stone. I usually prefer Farts to No Tomorrow for the quality of the moves themselves~ however~ climbing feels just a bit more uncertain on No Tomorrow and the pro feels a bit more spaced. Nontheless~ No Tomorrow stacks up as an excellent and atypical route for the Shelf. This is definitely worth the struggle.
protection: Ten or so draws and a rope.

location: Ruckman Cave > Rifle Mountain Park > Rifle > Colorado
desc: Like most routes in Rifle~ Noble Wife climbs much better than it looks.     Do the semi-difficult start of Call The Cops~ then with a ledge looming below~ make a hard~ committing move to establish in the steep~ blocky corner.  Continue making awkward~ strenuous~ and off-balance moves until the angle eases off~ and the climbing becomes more subtle~ and technical.     It is a great route for anyone looking for something with a traditional feel.
protection: Lot of quickdraws.  The anchors have carabiners.  A 60 meter rope will get you to the ground from the anchors.

location: Dinosaur Rock > Central > Flatirons > Boulder > Colorado
desc: This is the leftmost tufa feature on the north face of Dinosaur Rock. It shares its first 45 feet with Patience Face~ but where Patience Face moves right~ head straight up onto "The Shaft." Love it up... continuous and physical.

location: Bell Buttress - Main Crag > Bell Buttress Massif > Boulder Canyon > Boulder > Colorado
desc: The Spoils is located off the big west-facing ledge on Bell~ just left of Cosmosis.  This was apparently the first 5.12 route sent in Boulder Canyon. It follows a very exposed and overhung line on a beautiful portion of the cliff. It is fairly sustained down low with many technical and sequential moves.  The upper half is easier but still sustained and pumpy~ with occasionally tricky gear placements.     Start at the big chalked flake and work your way up the finger crack to the overhanging~ shallow~ left-facing corner system.  The climbing is solid 5.11 or harder from the ground until you can get into the hand crack about 20 feet up.  I felt the crux was getting into the hand crack at the end of the small corner~ but some feel getting stood up on the flake down low may be the crux.      From the top of the corner~ continue up the crack system with fun and steep liebacking and jamming (5.10+ or 11)~ moving left at the fork in the crack.  At the top of the crack~ you can go left to the anchor on Bell Buster~ or go right to the Cosmosis anchor to rappel.      Very high quality rock and moves~ with excellent protection!  Not necessarily a "serious" route as suggested by some guidebooks... the gear is definitely there if you can hang out to place it.
protection: I used 4 green Alien-sized pieces~ plus one Camalot each from fingers (gray) to hand sized. A gold Camalot is the biggest size needed but a blue Camalot could be placed too if desired.  Nuts could be used in spots but are not recommended due to the pumpy nature of the pro stances.  At the top of the crack~ there's an old pin~ and if you move left to the Bell Buster anchor you'll pass (as of 9/07) a cordelette that could be clipped.... It appears to have been set as a directional for top roping.

location: Death Rock > Clear Creek Canyon > Golden > Colorado
desc: This is an excellent climb that has old-school bolt spacing (~10-12 feet between bolts).  All of the difficult climbing happens after clipping a bolt~ so it's relatively safe.  There are a few loose looking handholds between the first and second bolts~ so beware.  Stick clipping the second bolt may be a good idea.    Climb the overhanging face for four bolts to reach a rest ledge.  Power up good holds for two more bolts and then solve the final roof moves to gain the anchors.    The rock on this route looks like it's brittle and crumbly~ but it's actually pretty solid; however~ the rest ledge has some loose rocks on it that end up on some of the holds directly below it.
protection: 6 bolts~ there are lowering biners at the anchor.

location: Seal Rock > South > Flatirons > Boulder > Colorado
desc: This route was established as the first pitch of The Yellow Door. It also accesses The Hinge. The pitch is worthy as a stand alone climb~ so Phil agreed to the separate posting. Be aware that the anchor is a potential bottleneck if parties are on the upper headwall pitches.  Climb a short~ left-trending crack (place a #0.75 or #1 Camalot~ or make a long stick clip to the first bolt)~ then gain a stance at the first bolt. Climb up and right to gain a long~ undercling flake~ and traverse across the flake. Now the fun begins! Climb the line of bolts through continuous and technical terrain to the roof. At the roof~ climb out the rail to the right~ then step left across the roof~ and reach far left to a hold on the face. Easier terrain leads up~ trending left initially~ and then back right to the two bolt anchor.  Due to its traversing nature~ the route must be followed to be cleaned. The anchor is 30 meters from the ground (rap with a 60m rope)~ but a 70m rope is mandatory to lower to the ground through the draws.
protection: 14 bolts to a two bolt ring anchor; a 70 meter rope is recommended; and use an optional cam (or stick clip) at the start.

location: Mill Creek Block > Dumont vicinity > Colorado
desc: Natural History teaches that when a big cat makes a kill it is often via a powerful~ accurate~ focused strike to back of the neck~ severing the cervical spinal cord. This seems about right for the crux sequence on The Strike.     The Strike begins on the left overhang. Power up to a rail system and swim out right to the arete. The first crux comes in standing up at clip four. Moving past clip five is the technical crux and entails a number of tricky and powerful moves. The crux ends when you stand above clip six. Bolts above guide the rope away from snags on the ledge.
protection: Eight draws and something for the double bolt anchor at the top.

location: The Skillet > The Frying Pan > Carbondale Area > Colorado
desc: This is a fantastic route that is very appropriately named.  Climbs through a loose roof band down low (stick clip)~ and then up the very hard to decipher left-facing dihedral system above.  Watch for fragile holds and a few large~ loose flakes up high.

location: Streaked Wall > The Falls Walls > Telluride/Norwood area > Colorado
desc: The White Belly is an amazing route~ especially the third pitch that climbs through the pocketed~ white overhang. You can link up the first two pitches and the last two ones. P1: 5.11b~ 11m~ 5 bolts; P2: 5.10b~ 19m~ 6 bolts; P3: 5.12b~ m~ bolts; and P4: 5.10d~ m~ bolts.

location: Third Flatiron > North > Flatirons > Boulder > Colorado
desc: Awesome route and wild exposure!  This route takes the huge overhanging/slanting dihedral at the top of the 3rd's North Face.  The best approach is by doing Northwest Passage.  However~ you can reach the big C-shaped gap at the start of the dihedral from College Dropout or another close by East Face route.    From the belay at the gap~ place a #0 TCU~ do a couple face moves and then step out into the void. The whole route can be aided clean (which is the way I did it) with a set of TCUs and cams.  There are two fixed pins and a fixed nut with a huge wire on it~ in the dihedral.  Every placement is bomber.    A small smattering of bird crap will not bother you (if your aiding it) as you enjoy the incredible exposure on this climb. About 3/4 of the way through the dihedral a small crack leads out and onto the east face~ where some runout 5.7 climbing takes you to the top (use slings~ quickdraws if you want to eliminate drag).
protection: A set of TCUs and a few cams (0.5 to 2).

location: Upper Mother's Buttress > Mother's Buttress > Main Canyon: Unaweep Granite > Unaweep Canyon > Grand Junction Area > Colorado
desc: Begin on an easy slab~ and place a finger-sized cam in the small~ right-facing corner above. Continue up the bolted face to the crux at the 3rd bolt. Difficult moves on a rounded~ small~ left-facing layback lead to easier climbing and a finger/thin hands crack.
protection: 0.75-1.5" gear and 5 bolts.  This shares anchors with the 2 unknown trad lines to the left.

location: The Gym > Shelf Road > Canon City > Colorado
desc: This starts just right of Spontaneous Combustion~ and like the others on this wall~ it starts out bouldery (the thunder) and eases up for a while until the technical crux up high (the lightning).

location: Middle Animal World > Animal World > Boulder Canyon > Boulder > Colorado
desc: Start as for Isn't Life Strange at central Animal World. Clip the first bolt on that route~ then lean left and clip a bolt at the base of the clean face. Trend up and right following a thin seam past two more bolts to a small overlap. Clip a bolt above this feature and step left (crux for all but the very tall)~ then go up the beautiful orange face to a double buttonhead station. Clip these with two long slings and head straight up through a large roof~ left to a stance~ then up through two smaller overhangs to the anchors on Talking Out of Turn.
protection: 11 QDs (including two longer slings) plus two for the anchor.

location: The North Gym > Shelf Road > Canon City > Colorado
desc: Squeeze has awesome rock with technical movement. I would recommend hanging draws from Orange (which shares a headwall and anchors with Squeeze). It is definitely harder hanging draws on lead.

location: Castle Rock > Boulder Canyon > Boulder > Colorado
desc: A few body lengths of cool climbing~ with long reaches and an exciting Mantle.  Climb The Sting to where the corner bends left to join Tongo.  Place some cams under the roof~ narrow cams(Metolius) work best.  Bust straight up then slightly right to end on the rightside of a big ledge.
protection: Take the normal Rack you would take to lead The Sting~ in addition to a #1 Friend and a #6 Metolius cam.

location: North Chasm View Wall > North Rim Routes > Black Canyon of the Gunnison > Gunnison > Colorado
desc: The crux is reach-dependent~ a .12 or .13 leftward traverse.    This route has bullet hard~ perfect~ face climbing the entire way (except maybe the 1st and last pitch). There are a few runouts~ but any falls would be clean. It would be best to have temps no higher than 60s!
protection: Bring doubles to #1~ 1 #2 and 1 #3~ RPs~ and nuts.

location: The Dark Side > Shelf Road > Canon City > Colorado
desc: The bottom 3/4s of this route is 3-stars great. It is very similar to its neighbors to the left and has probably 5.10+ ish climbing.    The top is a 1-move wonder. Once at the roof encounter~ the bolt is easy to clip. There are some sharp holds~ and a sharp sidepull flake is available to slice up your fingers. Figure out how to use these~ get your feet up~ and the climb is over.

location: South Rim Routes > Black Canyon of the Gunnison > Gunnison > Colorado
desc: This is truly one of the great routes in the Black~ and perhaps the world. Yes~ THE WORLD! Great rock and great gear throughout.  P1. Face climb trending right with gear and past 3 bolts to the base of an open corner and a two bolt belay~ 5.11.  P2. Climb the amazing corner to a stance~ 5.12-. Unbelievable.  P3. A short crack leads to a corner and a mantle and easier climbing to a stance below a bolt and corner~ 5.11+.  P4. Climb past the bolt into yet another amazing corner. Belay at a stance below a shallow corner/slot~ 5.12-.  P5. Climb the slot past a roof. 5.10. A ledge and a short difficult corner follows~ 5.10. At the next ledge~ bypass the corner on the face to the right. Belay at grassy ledges.  P6: Go up 5.8 corners trending slightly left. After 200' move right and continue with a little simul-climbing up stair step ledges to the base of open black corner.  Variation directly to 2 Boulder Bivy: Belay after 200' and then step a little right and go up obvious 5.8 flake corner (nice). Some slightly mungier and harder climbing tops out on the bivy.  P7. Climb a black corner (5.11a) stepping out left when convenient and finishing at the base of a obvious thin crack in a wide dihedral. An easy 50' traverse can go from here to the 2 boulder bivy.  P8. 50 feet right of the two boulder bivy. Climb a shallow splitter through a black streak. When the crack peters out~ step right~ then up and left to a bolt. A difficult leftward traverse (11d) ends at a two bolt belay~ 5.12. Stellar.  P9. Follow a shallow crack~ then faceclimb right to a bolt and mantle move to a ledge. Step left into a shallow corner and another ledge with a small crack for gear. Step down and right~ then up to a rampy corner. Follow this to the top and a good ledge~ 5.11.  P10. Ignore the flake going out left. Go up into twin cracks then face climb past a seam to a ledge (12-). Continue up a left leaning corner past a bolt (12-) to belay stance. Minus too much rope drag~ you can continue another 40 feet up 10+ to a chain anchor (the third station on Astro-slog raps).  P11. (The extra 40' in the above pitch can be added to this pitch~ too~ or done as a short pitch to reduce drag) Go up corners and face climb out right past some cracks. Climb the right leaning corner to a sloping ledge and a single belay bolt~ 5.11.  P12. A very difficult overhanging crack splits a short headwall to chain anchors (the second rap station)~ 5.12.  P13. Go up through chockstones to grassy ledges. Resist the temptation to go straight up. Head directly left under the prow to join the top of Astro Dog. Belay below 5.9 S-crack on Astro Dog~ 5.8.  P14. Climb 5.9 s-crack. Trend left to a 5.9 corner. Go through bushes and behind a flake. Chimney up and step across. Battle drag up pegmatite ramp past a pin. Belay at the top of pegmatite.  P15. Trend right up gully and under roofs. Step around the roof to a slab and head up and left. Climb chimney corner past chockstones~ 5.9. Belay at chains on top.
protection: Set of stoppers with extra 4 through 7.    "RPs" (those BD steel micros work wonders).   Two sets of cams from purple TCU size to hands with one micro-cam.

location: Free Form Wall > Sand Gulch > Shelf Road > Canon City > Colorado
desc: I am not sure how this route is supposed to go. You are either sucked three feet to the left of the bolt line or three feet to the right. The left is a corner crack~ and all the bolts are still within arms reach. This goes about hard 5.10. If you trend to the right~ it is about easy 5.11. Following the bolt line straight up does not seem to be reasonable. It is definitely not 12a as the guide suggests~ maybe something broke? Again~ I am not sure what the route developers had in mind. Any input would be great.

location: North Chasm View Wall > North Rim Routes > Black Canyon of the Gunnison > Gunnison > Colorado
desc: For the overall quality of stone~ brilliant face climbing~ and little if any munge~ I would put Apparition near the top of the list of the best climbs I have done in the Black.    There was an excellent mini-guide in Rock & Ice No. 81 with a story about the FA of this route and an adequate topo. According to this: three hundred feet below the second Cruise Gully rappel~ at the start of the traverse to Journey Home~ begin the route at the second tree. It may be a little confusing to sniff out the start of the route.    P1. Climb unprotected 5.8 to a right-facing corner with some 5.9~ to a ledge. This is a long pitch.     P2. Traverse up and right in an open book~ then move up and left to a bolt.  Traverse straight left (5.10+) past 2 more bolts to a semi-hanging belay at 2 bolts (strangely~ this anchor is just above a nice little stance). This is a patently dangerous pitch to follow; the second may want to practice the 5.10 moves still clipped into the first bolt~ then unclip to follow - if you blow it you could swing a long ways and get hurt. Variation: Andy Donson climbed straight up from the belay (5.11c R or X) instead of doing the 5.10+ traverse~ skipped the 2nd belay and joined the 3rd pitch.    P3. Move a little left~ then climb a continuous stretch of difficult face past 4 bolts through a bulge~ and punch it to the belay. This is brilliant climbing~ 5.12b. There is a small flake which you crank on that may snap on somebody.     P4. This is the crux pitch. Climb a difficult (5.12a) right-facing corner with poor pro (RPs~ TCUs) past a bolt~ then follow the bolts through some of the best face climbing in the canyon~ very spicy 5.12 b or c. The crux is a tenuous standup move on a tiny crystal~ using a shallow~ rounded crescent hold with your left hand and not much else. It is a long pitch ending at a nice ledge. This was bolted on the lead. Several very good climbers have backed down from this lead due to the fall potential from the crux.    P5. Climb up~ clip a bolt~ then follow a corner to 2 more bolts protecting some 5.11- face moves. Perhaps it is a little runout. Belay over a small roof.    P6. Move out and right with little gear~ then go up (5.10+) to a belay below the obvious~ overhanging corner capped by a massive roof.     P7. Climb up and into the corner~ then pull a hard move (5.11b or c). At the top of the corner~ head straight left to an amazing belay on the arete (2 bolts). This is a wild pitch.    P8. A mediocre pitch leads to the terrace.    P9. (Optional) Climb a vague 5.11 hand crack to the only tree on the rim.  It is better to just walk left and solo off.    I would recommend a stiff edging shoe for this climb. Also~ catch it in the shade or when temperatures are crisp- it would be a total grease-fest if you tried it otherwise. Plan on 6 to 8 hours.
protection: One set RPs~ one set Wireds~ doubles TCUs~ #0.5 to 2 Camalots~ one# 3 Camalot~ a haul line. All anchors are fixed and bomber~ and it is possible to rappel the entire route. Expect runout climbing on anything from 5.8 to 5.12 terrain.

location: Left Side > Plotinus Wall > Lower Dream Canyon > Boulder Canyon > Boulder > Colorado
desc: The Art of Dreaming starts just right of Sleepless in Boulder and climbs just below the obvious large right-leaning arch.     Climb up into a short right-facing corner. Clip the second and third bolt~ traverse right across the face (technical crux) on small holds~ making hard moves up to a small overhang. Tackle the roof (5.12a) and climb up beautiful rock to a two-bolt anchor.

location: The Brown Wall > Thunder Ridge > West Creek > South Platte > Colorado
desc: Thin face.
protection: Bolts and some gear up to 2 inch.

location: Upper Animal World > Animal World > Boulder Canyon > Boulder > Colorado
desc: This climb is on what is described here as the Upper Animal Wall.  If you approach from the Lower Animal Wall the climb comes into view right away as the left side of the bolted arete.  A good winter or evening route which sees its share of sunshine. The route starts upon a ledge 20' off the ground.  To reach the ledge~ you can clip the first bolt of Sun Dog with a long runner~ or scramble up 5.8ish.  Thin liebacks will take you through the first 3 bolts~ to the first 5.12 crux.  A ledge is then reached~ which provides little rest before more sustained climbing using the arete on the right.  The climbing eases slightly in the last 15' to the 2 bolt anchor.  70'   This sustained route is a hard to redpoint (I haven't).  The position is excellent.

location: Rincon - Center Route & R > Rincon > Eldorado Canyon SP > Boulder > Colorado
desc: This is the overhanging~ southeastly-facing fingertip splitter around the south face of Rincon Wall~ just uphill from Point Break. It runs through the left wall of a big dihedral capped by a roof and is very overhanging~ but with solid locks.    Traverse in from the left (below Spicoli~ the new bolt-route through the overlaps) and climb past 3 bolts and some fairly rotten rock to reach the base of the corner.    Power out on a flexing flake and head up the steep~ strenuous crack on good~ but sometimes distant fingerlocks.  An easy but flaky corner caps the roof.    Rappel 90 feet (?) off a tree (it may be a good idea to have someone second this pitch~ as it leans a lot and has a rope-slicing arete just right of the line).
protection: Three bolts take you to a finger crack with some fixed wires.  Bring supplemental gear in the small-mid ranges (set of stoppers~ small TCUs) and a hand-sized piece for over the lip.

location: Lost Angel > Upper Dream Canyon > Boulder > Colorado
desc: The route climbs up an obvious~ arching~ right-facing dihedral to the right of China Doll . Residual dirt and tiny loose crystals can still be found in places~ but all the crucial holds are solid. The line has moves somewhat similar to those on China Doll and IMO provides a good warm-up/training for later.    I suggest linking P1 & 2~ if you are comfortable pulling 5.11a moves above a small ledge.    P1. Climb short 5.9 to a small ramp with a 2-bolt anchor.    P2. Follow bolts past dihedral~ get over the ceiling and continue underclinging to chains.
protection: P1: 3 bolts to bolted anchor.   P2: 9 bolts to bolted anchor.

location: Ridge 1 > Eldorado Mountain > Boulder > Colorado
desc: This route is up the hill from Raging Hormones. The vertical section is thin and bouldery~ then goes through a steep section~ and finishes on easy ground.

location: Penitente - Entrance Area > Penitente Canyon > San Luis Valley > Colorado
desc: I haven't RP'd this thing as of this time~ but it seems like every time I go to Penitente~ I'm seduced by this tempting boulder problem.  This route is singularly unique for the area.  It always seems like a good route to try when my fingertips have been schralped (to borrow a phrase).     Located about halfway down the trail to the virgin painting~ you can't miss this sharply overhanging roof with two distinct pockets in it. Stick clip the first bolt~ then reach for the first big pocket~ dyno to the positive two finger...then start the crux...mantling over the lip.      Make sure your tendons are ready for this thing~ as the dyno to the two finger could seriously injur you.      I placed a #0 TCU at the very start to keep the rope out of my way.  This thing really needs another bolt down low to serve that purpose.
protection: 5 bolts or so~ two cold shuts at the top.

location: The Crystal Cave > Rifle Mountain Park > Rifle > Colorado
desc: This is the leftmost route in the Crystal Cave and climbs out the left side of a chossy bowl onto a mini-headwall of blocky stone. Pre-clip the first bolt or two (you can climb up and do this then down-climb) then make a big move off a horn/spike to some pockets in the face above the bowl. The anchors arrive sooner than one might expect.    Astro-glide is the best -- ask anyone in the biz!

location: West Ridge - part B - Long John to Verschneidung > The West Ridge > Eldorado Canyon SP > Boulder > Colorado
desc: This is a fun~ technical pitch in great position! It begins on the ledge directly above the anchors of The Unsaid.    Start by climbing 15' of chossy rock with poor pro (5.8 R) until you can clip the first bolt. A medium-sized cam can protect the easier moves to the second bolt. Transition onto the face and make crux moves~ featuring technical climbing on positive sidepulls with poor feet. From the final bolt~ step left to the arete and pull exciting 5.11 moves to the obvious anchor.    Note: Several of the key holds on this climb are fragile. It may be best not to try it if there are parties on the popular routes below.
protection: 4 draws~ a cam (I used both a #1 and a #0.5).

location: The Wasteland > Rifle Mountain Park > Rifle > Colorado
desc: Easy (5.10) climbing leads to a no-hands rest below the roofed dihedral. Technical stemming and a hidden crimp get you past the first roof and into the crux. Micro-holds and more stemming maneuvers get you to the second roof. Gather your wits for some heads-up climbing and a couple of good holds on the arete with a jug sidepull allows you to clip and pull over the third roof and onto the upper headwall slab. More rests on the upper slab headwall allow you time to contemplate the final crux at the last bolt. Sidepulls~ pinches~ a sloper~ and an optional kneebar will deposit you on the final section of vertical terrain that's pumpier than it looks.
protection: 17 bolts. Chains and steel carabiners have been installed at the anchors. A 70 meter rope is required to lower off this route. The protection for this route was generously provided by the Rifle Climbers' Coalition

location: The Graveyard > Clear Creek Canyon > Golden > Colorado
desc: This route starts similarly to The Walking Dead but traverses right up the face on small/slopey holds. Figure out your beta to make the tough traverse to gain a decent hold~ then finish up and left on easier climbing to the anchors shared with The Walking Dead.

location: Burro Wall > Main Elk Creek > Glenwood Springs > Colorado
desc: This is moderate until it's not~ then it's on you. A slightly overhanging arete takes you to the chains.
protection: Bolts to chains and lowering biners.

location: Basalto San Martín > Baños - San Francisco area > Ecuador > South America > International
desc: the crux is on the 4tho quick draw    very technique
protection: 8 quick draw    2 bolts anchor on the top

location: Profecia > Cerro San Martin > San Carlos de Bariloche > Rio Negro > Argentina > South America > International
desc: Super fun climbing on pockets and edges. Crux near the top.

location: Profecia > Cerro San Martin > San Carlos de Bariloche > Rio Negro > Argentina > South America > International
desc: Fun pockets and dihedral

location: Setor Parede Central > Pedreira do Garcia > São Paulo > Brazil > South America > International
desc: P1: 9 bolts + anchor P2: 5 bolts + anchor With a 60m rope it's possible to connect both pitches and rappel down. Once at the first anchor~ keep climbing to the left. The variation to the right is Linha Branca (5.12d)
protection: Total of 14 bolts with two anchors~ one at each pitch.

location: Nueva Colonia > San Carlos de Bariloche > Rio Negro > Argentina > South America > International
desc: About half way up there is a tricky section.

location: Las Terrazas > Inca Wakanka > Huaraz > Peru > South America > International
desc: Start by climbing up a small slab and then lieback up the arete and onto the terrace. Step onto the swiss cheese wall and haul through the jugs until you traverse into the second series of jugs to the anchor.

location: Anfiteatro Temp > Valle Cochamó > Chile > South America > International
desc: This is the first pitch of a longer route named “D’Arriba Abajo”. If you have a full rack and want a longer rack~ do the whole thing. But if you want something short and sport-y~ this will fit the bill.   A psychological test. 9 bolts spread over a 65m. You do the math. Extend runners~ especially the last 2 bolts.  About 10m runout to the anchor... It’s been climbed with a 60m rope but it’s very close. **Coming up short could be dangerous.** There is a walk off from the top. So it can be done with one 70m rope. Rapping requires 2 ropes.

location: Exodo > Cerro San Martin > San Carlos de Bariloche > Rio Negro > Argentina > South America > International
desc: Hard crux at the bottom gives way to interesting dihedral and jugs/pockets. Upper section turns into technical slabby face climbing.

location: Sector Deportiva > Chacay > San Carlos de Bariloche > Rio Negro > Argentina > South America > International
desc: Beautiful looking crack/face climb with some offwidth technique required.

location: Calabozo > San Carlos de Bariloche > Rio Negro > Argentina > South America > International
desc: Long and diverse climb. The slabby and thin lower portion leads into a vertical and slightly overhanging perfect hand jam crack~ then a rest ledge. From there climb up and right of the bolts through huge overhanging jugs to the anchor. An extension was added going up left at 5.12b to another anchor.
protection: 12 bolts to first anchor~ 3 more to the 2nd anchor

location: Anhangava > Paraná > Brazil > South America > International
desc: A route with with two pitches where the technical slabs predominates~ beautiful moves with good crimps in the vertical wall. You bcan rappel with 60 meter rope by the route that is called Maria Fumaça

location: Setor 3 > Paraná > Brazil > South America > International
desc: A very beautiful two pitches route and with great and difficult roofs to be transposed. The second pitch begins with an artificial climbing pass.

location: Anhangava > Paraná > Brazil > South America > International
desc: 5.11b~ feet in crack and great hand crimps~ the route that works the body resistance. Classic route!

location: Macheta > Colombia > South America > International
desc: Pumpy climbing with a bouldery start. Stiff crux followed by endurance climbing on decent holds.

location: Las Neveras > New Machetá (El Salón de la Justicia) > Colombia > South America > International
desc: See topo for full description.

location: Pedra de Urubu > Urca (Pao de Acucar area) > Rio de Janeiro > Brazil > South America > International
desc: Great route~ one of the best on the formation.  Three little cruxes with fun easier moves in between.

location: a) Hiedra Venenosa > El Escarabajo > Mendoza > Argentina > South America > International
desc: Moderate moves take you to a burly crux to pass the roof.

location: c) Capitan Excusas > El Escarabajo > Mendoza > Argentina > South America > International
desc: Very technical route which requires a lot of precise footing and powerful moves on small holds. The crux comes at past the 4th bolt.

location: Muralla del Refugio > Los Arenales > Mendoza > Argentina > South America > International
desc: An ultra classic for the area characterized by varied climbing~ lots of crack climbing and great rock.    P1) Climb a low angle slab to a nice~ tight finger dihedral. Then jam your way up the side of a boulder and head slightly left to a short hand crack to a 2 bolt belay below a roof. You can extend the belay back down to the ledge if you use the rope (5.10d~ 35m).    P2) Crux pitch. Excellent rock throughout and awesome climbing. Technical crux tips crack at the start to a rest. Then enduro crux through the roof and onto sustained fingers and .75 / tight #1 camalot crack up a beautiful~ vertical wall to 2 bolt hanging belay that's a bit uncomfortable. A classic pitch by any standards (5.11d~ 25m).    P3) Move left off the belay. Clip the bolt~ then jam in a slightly crumbly flare and get to the foot out right. Falling there could slam the belayer. Make your way up following blocks through a chimney. I went left at the block roof part of the chimney. Some loose holds through this chimney. Eventually gain a 2 bolt anchor in the chimney below a roof~ behind a big chockstone (5.10d~ 25m).    P4) A demanding pitch with all sorts of climbing. This is the only pitch where you need the 4s and 5. Start with a #3/#4 camalot roof and establish yourself in the vertical offwidth above. I dropped both #4s and the 5 in here. Get a rest after the OW~ clip a bolt and start the traverse (harder than it looks). The traverse is #3s then gets bigger at the end. Save a #2 and a #1 for the finish up steep blocks (5.11c~ 30m).    We descended from here so no personal experience on the last two pitches.    P5) Easiest pitch of the route. Climb the dihedral up to the big ledge~ passing some bushes to a 2 bolt anchor. Or if you wanted~ there is a 6c+ sport pitch straight up the face a little to the right (part of the route Flaca I think) (5.10a~ 25m).    P6) Amazing crack pitch up the face to a 2 bolt anchor (5.11a~ 35m).
protection: Double rack from green alien to #4 Camalot. 1 each micro cams & #5 Camalot. Nuts. Two ropes.     I suppose you could take 3x #4 if you were to place 2 in the OW and want one to make the traverse less scary at the end... but I don't know if it would fit.    Maybe it would be possible to rap the route with a single 70m or 80m but I'm not sure. Probably best to just take two ropes.

location: Boca > Morro do Moreno > Espirito Santo > Brazil > South America > International
desc: Here strenght and power won't get you to the top. Technical climb that demands a lot of balance in beautiful moves. Classic!

location: Los Sietes > Hatun Machay > Huaraz > Peru > South America > International
desc: Climb up a few knobs and then traverse right into a seam. Lieback up the crack until you reach a bush in the left. Climb up and then choose between the left side or right side of the bolts.

location: Zona 15 > La Mojarra - Cañon del Chicamocha > Colombia > South America > International
desc: Nice climb with different styles

location: La Cueva de Los Gauchos > Inca Wakanka > Huaraz > Peru > South America > International
desc: A fun route that involves serious lie backing~ heel hooking~ and pocket pulling up a black streaked section of the wall. Once you pull through the roof the difficulty eases off significantly.

location: San Félix, Medellín > Colombia > South America > International
desc: The crux is between  fourth and fifth bolt.

location: Zona 10 > La Mojarra - Cañon del Chicamocha > Colombia > South America > International
desc: Great overhang and then face climb

location: Exodo > Cerro San Martin > San Carlos de Bariloche > Rio Negro > Argentina > South America > International
desc: Short hard route

location: El Bosque > La Peña de Abejorral > Colombia > South America > International
desc: See topo.

location: La Piedra del Peñol > Colombia > South America > International
desc: ZONA III   It is the second pitch ofter Caballeros del sobaco

location: Corcovado > Rio de Janeiro > Brazil > South America > International
desc: This is one of the main free climbing test pieces in Rio.  It is a classic old climb that was established on aid~ but has since been climbed free.  The route is notorious and committing even on pitches that are bolted.

location: Ventana Sur El Escondite > Cerro Ventana Sur > San Carlos de Bariloche > Rio Negro > Argentina > South America > International
desc: Crux seems to be around bolt 3-4. Still an open project~ maybe needs another bolt added at the crux~ rock needs to be cleaned more.

location: Anfiteatro Temp > Valle Cochamó > Chile > South America > International
desc: Miranda Oakley described this route as "alpine cragging." It's certainly not the most continuous line. And unlike the typical long pitches of Cochamo~ the pitches on this route are almost all 35m or less. Still~ what it lacks in continuity it makes up for in rock quality. It's actually a super enjoyable route (IMO) with lots of good crack climbing.  P1:  Find a short steep crack that leads to a high first bolt~ about 100m down and left of the cave. Climb through a rough but safe boulder problem right off the deck~ then follow bolts and gear up the path of least resistance to a large ledge. The "Index 5.11c" pitch. 5.11c  P2: Do a very short (about 15 ft) 5.7 up to a large 3rd class slope. Hip belay or make a gear anchor~ bring up your partner~ and hike up the slope about 200m or so to the base of a buttress that features a cool crack that widens from fingers to OW~ and goes around a curve to a bulge. A bolted anchor at a semi-exposed stance marks the start of P3. 5.7  P3: Fight through a hard boulder problem (the upper bolt in the anchor protects it)~ then enjoy great and varied crack climbing until another two bolt anchor up and left. 5.11c  P4: The business. One of the best pitches I've ever had the pleasure of FA'ing. Climb a little bit of clean OW to reach twin finger cracks. Pull through a v-slot roof (1st crux)~ and catch your breath in the no-hands stance above. Make sure you have gear right at the lip below you so the rope doesn't get caught in the crack. Fire through the second roof on thin underclings~ and fight your way to the finish. 5.12  P5: "The Lightning Bolt Crack." Enjoy casual and well protected 5.7 squeeze OW to a short traverse~ and then do the 5.7 squeeze straight out of Yosemite to an anchor up and left. Yosemite 5.7  P6-7: Two forgettable but not bad pitches take you up broken but safe cracks and chimneys to an airy belay at the start of a knife-edge ridge. Can be linked~ or belay at an anchor mid-way. 5.8  P8: 4th class across the knife-edge ridge~ and climb low 5th class terrain around the blocks on the other side to the base of a clean dihedral. 5.7  P9: Climb a nice 5.10 dihedral of mostly hand cracks up to a bolted anchor. 5.10  P10: Climb discontinuous 5th class terrain past easier and harder sections using many slings until the angle eases off enough to stop climbing~ look around for the last anchor. I don't recall exactly where it is~ but it will make sense. 5.9  ALTERNATE FINISH  P8a: when you get to the end of the ridge~ don't go up~ downclimb an easy gully to the base of a wall to the left of the ridge. You will be below the ridge by about 50m at the start of a beautiful clean handcrack in a shallow corner. 5.5  P9a: Again~ one of the best pitches I've ever had the pleasure of FA'ing. Climb the beautiful steep splitter handcrack for about 40m until an exposed belay on a stance atop the enormous flake. 5.11  P10a: The quality continues! Make a wild traverse out left~ do a short downclimb~ and then figure out a sane way to make the short traverse left to the next thin crack/flake system. Eric did some sort of trickery to protect this from above~ then made the thin slab moves. Neither of us would mind if someone put in a bolt here to protect the traverse. Not a bad idea. Above the traverse~ climb an incredible and sustained fingercrack layback in a left-facing corner. An amazing pitch~ and a damn proud Eric Lynch onsight. 5.12a  P11a: Climb an OW flake (difficult to protect~ #5 would help a little~ but there's going to be some runout regardless). Belay on top. 5.11- R  P12a: Make a 4th/5th class traverse right keeping your eyes wide open for an anchor. You can rap the normal route from there.
protection: Doubles to #3. Single #4. A good selection of green alien/blue metolius to .4 camalot sized finger pieces for the crux pitch. A #5 would be nice on P3 if climbing at your limit~ otherwise~ you can probably get by without.  Can rap w/ single 70. Not single 60.

location: La Piedra del Peñol > Colombia > South America > International
desc: ZONA III

location: Pared Seca > Valle Cochamó > Chile > South America > International
desc: First pitch is the obvious flaring crack that shoots left. It is often done as a single pitch and goes at 5.11 Second pitch jumps further left from the top of P1 through some crack systems up to a face. Finishes up and right.

location: Macheta > Colombia > South America > International
desc: Sustained~ rests throughout.

location: Zona de la Nariz > Suesca > Colombia > South America > International
desc: Very technical climbing with a sequential mono sequence into a sequence of slopers~ crimps~ and then jugs.  Beautiful route.
protection: 7 draws~ either lower off the glue in or ideally just go up to the chains 20ft higher

location: Zona de la Abeja > Suesca > Colombia > South America > International
desc: Start on a rock and crush the roof

location: Las Neveras > New Machetá (El Salón de la Justicia) > Colombia > South America > International
desc: See topo for full description.

location: Odyssey > Kalymnos > Greece > Europe > International
desc: Steep boulder problem start leads to great tufa climbing.  A harder section of tufa leads to a tough exit then a couple easy moves to the anchor.

location: 3. Watermill > Kyparissi > Peloponnese > Greece > Europe > International
desc: Technical and balancy yet powerful moves on edges and small colonettes.

location: Lungern > Switzerland > Europe > International
desc: obvious crux at about 10 meters of the ground

location: Font Freda > Gelida > Catalonia > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Really good route~ shares a fun overhanging (but mostly juggy) start with 'Calma Tensa' before getting to a series of large jug rails. At this point Calma Tensa climbs left while Calma Intensa climbs straight up into the blank face using long pulls on barely-there holds. A long crux lock-off to a small crimp leads to a juggy sidepull to clip the last bolt. A few more engaging moves lead to a long runnout on easy climbing to the anchor. Apparently this route was previously listed at both 12d or 13a~ but according to a user on 8a.nu a hold broke in the crux making it harder. "A hold broke and now [the crux] is even harder than the original hard move. Before 7c / + . Now harder: 7c + or 7c + / 8a or 8a I don't know." My opinion is that it's solid at 5.13a~ but interested in other opinions.
protection: 6 Bolts and then something for the anchors.

location: Ali Baba > Mascun > Rodellar > Aragon > Spain > Europe > International
desc: This is a fun~ short but worth while route.    A bouldery start on thin edges and underclings leads to a few good holds near the middle. An upper boulder problem follows on sidepulls and small sloping edges.

location: Secteur Cascade > Ceuse > Southern Alps > France > Europe > International
desc: This route actually has a crux~ but the jug hauling surrounding it is not quite as good as on other routes around it. The crux involves pulling to and off of a mono on the steeper starting portion of the route. May be soft touch 7c+.

location: Tofana di Rozes > Tofana Group > Dolomites > Italy > Europe > International
desc: none listed

location: Raco de la Finestra > Margalef > Catalonia > Spain > Europe > International
desc: An absolutely excellent climb on pockets (surprise) underclings~ pinches~ and an odd crimp. A hard boulder kicks things off (stick clip the first bolt)~ then it's just continuous. No really hard moves~ just tons of kind-of-hard moves that chip away at the endurance. As the pump seems to get untenable~ the angle starts to kick back; keep it together~ it's not over until the anchor-clipping jug. Classic.

location: Las Ventanas and Behind > Las Ventanas > Mascun > Rodellar > Aragon > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Climb holds that look like stacked cards. Nice sharp jugs that jut from the wall. There is a rest about 20 feet up but it really does not do much good. Make 2 moves on a short tuffa then head out the roof on mostly underclings. Eventually you will be able to lean back onto the base of the finishing corner which juts out behind you. Head up the corner to the anchors.

location: Raco de les Espadelles > Margalef > Catalonia > Spain > Europe > International
desc: El Sistema climbs a spectacular gray tufa streak~ with the aid of the "juggy" pockets at the start of La Gomorra (to avoid the 8b+ direct start).  This is not as bouldery as many routes at Margalef~ requiring mostly good stamina.  However~ a good bit of finger strength is required for the strenuous crux traverse between the fourth & fifth bolts.    Begin with La Gomorra's burly start to reach the big hole below the fourth bolt.  Rest well~ then charge up and right into the gray streak.  Awesome textured pockets lead up the streak to a series of vertical pods & awkward rests.  The final perplexing pod leads to a smooth gray headwall and the redpoint crux: a strenuous highstep & lieback to reach a hidden jug.  Big moves left lead to the anchor.

location: Négociée > Valley Crags > Siurana > Catalonia > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Another technical masterpiece of Siurana. Easier climbing up the first 3 bolts to a good stance before the real climbing begins.
