Trend a little rightwards on good crimps and lower angle rock~ reaching the first Boulder~ which is quite nice and technical. The second Boulder awaits after a brief shake on a good left hand pocket. Amazing technical upper section.

location: Lacteo > Ayagaures > Gran Canaria > Canary Islands > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Route 8

location: Ash Tree Wall > Burbage North > Burbage Valley > The Peak District > England > United Kingdom > Europe > International
desc: Follow Happily Ever After but trend diagonally right at half height.

location: Limeri > Leonidio > Peloponnese > Greece > Europe > International
desc: Steep~ thuggy pulling through good holds on tufas~ culminating with a cruxy top section~ done either with a pinch or matching on a tufa~ then into a good finger lock.  Catch a breather here before a great rockover move to get established on the slab.  The bolt line on the upper 6b or so slab lies left of the climbing.  Sort this out carefully as it's just hard enough to keep you engaged after the hard work below.  A PE line that earns it's rating when you try to link it all together.
protection: Many bolts - 15?  10? for the overhung beginning then 5 or so for the upper slab after pulling the lip.

location: Topatrás > Fataga > Gran Canaria > Canary Islands > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Route 13

location: 5. Babala > Kyparissi > Peloponnese > Greece > Europe > International
desc: Stellar moves on tufas and spaced jugs.

location: Chico > El Cenobio > Gran Canaria > Canary Islands > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Route 6

location: Principal > Candelilla > Gran Canaria > Canary Islands > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Route 20

location: La Habitacion - Pared de Dandy > Zona de Arriba > San Bartolo > Cadiz > Andalucia > Spain > Europe > International
Principal > Candelilla > Gran Canaria > Canary Islands > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Route 24

location: La Boca > El Salto > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Alex~ Edgardo and I bolted this route as an alternative to Tears of Gold.     Pitch 1   Same as Tears of Gold.  Climb awkward slab with bulges. 5.11d   Pitch 2   Skip the hard 5.13 pitch of Tears for Gold and move right up a dihedral~ then back left to a belay on a ledge. Not super classic. 5.10   Pitch 3   Mega Classic. Much like Mothership Connection in the Potrero. Climb steep exposed wall up tufa with a crux connecting to another tufa.

location: The Prow Wall > The Chief > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Sustained~ varied climbing on one of the cleanest formations on the Chief.    1. 5.10c. Awkward flare leads to face traverse and right leaning crack.   2. 5.11c. Scruffy ramp to chimney. Pull out of chimney into pumpy~ vertical layback~ face climbing traverse past one bolt to the anchor.   3. "The Guillotine" 5.12a. A few face moves into lasercut dihedral. Tips crux widens to off hands jamming and laybacking~ undercling down and left to belay stance.   WARNING! A fully detached 50' X 60' flake is perched on the wall right of the lasercut dihedral~ the edge of which offers tantalizing hand jams and stemming opportunities. It is easily avoided by staying in the main corner. It is very loose and flexes alarmingly with very little pressure. DON'T TOUCH.   4. 5.12c. Fully (6) bolted. Overhanging stemming and laybacking. After the fifth bolt wild moves pull out and around the arete.   5. 5.12a. The cryptic pitch. Face traverse right to ramp. Finger crack to technical face trending back left to belay.   6. 5.12b. A short~ crisp splitter leads to deceivingly pumpy hand traverse. Overhanging tips crux quickly relents to vertical 5.9 hands in an amazing position near the edge of the prow.   7. 5.11c. Finger traverse and face climb around the edge of the prow into Teddy Bears Picnic~ a short pitch.   8. 5.13a. Changing corners pitch. Fully (5) bolted. Powerful and bouldery.   9. 5.12a. Up corner to crux reach to arete. The difficulty of this pitch varies greatly depending on reach.
protection: 1 X 00~ 0~ 3 metolius~ 2 camalot~ nuts.   2 x 1~2 metolius~ .75 camalot.   3 x 1 camalot.   Quickdraws and runners.   All belays are fixed~ it is possible to rap off at any point with 2 ropes.

location: Operation Iraqi Freedom Wall > Al Qaeda Area > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: none listed

location: Chanchullo/El Chonta > Chontalcoatlan > Central Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Climb steep but featured rock~ low 5.12 up past several bolts to a difficult boulder problem crux.  There are several ways to do it~ and a techy kneebar might help.  Above the crux the climbing eases back to low 5.12 with many rests~ especially potential kneebars.  However the climbing remains super enjoyable and taxing.  At the anchors there are two extensions "Revelacion Cosmica" 5.14a breaks left and "Mago Colibri"  5.13d breaks right.

location: 01. Jagueyana > Mogote del Valle > Vinales > Cuba > North America > International
desc: This is the only hard route at this crag.

location: 10. Milenio > Mogote del Valle > Vinales > Cuba > North America > International
desc: Power moves~ layback left~ undercling traverse~ layback right~ heel hooks~ big cut loose on a roof~ Power crimping to exit a roof~ technical face climbing~ exposure~ This one has everything you need to be happy!

location: The Bayon > Heart Creek > Bow Valley > Alberta > Canada > North America > International
desc: A hard boulder problem. Too high for pads so a rope is best.

location: Helheim > Valhalla Mountains > Kootenays West > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: none listed

location: El Fin de Semana (Weekend Wall) > El Potrero Chico > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: One of my favorite routes in the Potrero. Especially fun as there's not really a crux~ just steady~ in your face climbing the whole way.

location: Lower Wall > Acéphale > Bow Valley > Alberta > Canada > North America > International
desc: Extremely hard for one draw and then onto the regular route of Ice Cream Head. A non-direct start is just to the left which bumps down the grade to 12d (may not be possible~ no recent sends on sendage confirm if possible due to holds breaking off).

location: Atlantis Wall > The Lookout > Echo Canyon > Bow Valley > Alberta > Canada > North America > International
desc: Enduro climbing at it's best capped with a hard crux near the end. recommended by many.

location: Left Wall > 02. Cueva Larga > Mogote del Valle > Vinales > Cuba > North America > International
desc: Two different start both being very cruxy.   Technical climbing.

location: Carrot Creek > Bow Valley > Alberta > Canada > North America > International
desc: Start just inside the right end of the cave. Powerful moves lead to a crux and a rest. Finish with black coffees crux.

location: Titan Wall > Lion's Head > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: Start on the steep left side of the wall and climb up to a hard boulder problem to climb another full 35m line.

location: Upper Wall > Acéphale > Bow Valley > Alberta > Canada > North America > International
desc: Short cruxes separated by good rests lead to sustained climbing~ a stout deadpoint move and a dicey edit onto the upper slab. A final tough move below the anchor keeps things interesting.

location: 15. Cueva Cabeza de Vaca > Mogote del Valle > Vinales > Cuba > North America > International
desc: This is a direct start of Morirse a Plazo.

location: Tecolote Cave > El Salto > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: El Gallo de Oro is a mega link up that climbs the first steep section of Chi and traverses left into the headwall of Puro Pinxte Sloper~ doing a hard and powerful move at the base of the headwall before pumpy tufa climbing to the top. While still a link up~ this combines the fun beginning of Chi with an easier crux on the headwall. It has been called by some the best line in Tecolote.

location: La Palma (The Palm) Sport > El Salto > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: climb  tothe right  of  the big  tuffa  in the  middle  of the wall

location: 15. Cueva Cabeza de Vaca > Mogote del Valle > Vinales > Cuba > North America > International
desc: Starts on 5.11 climbing before a big ledge~ then it gets progressively steeper with mostly big holds for the majority of the climb.  The crux is the last moves to the anchor~ which is awesome overhanging crimps with plenty of air below you.  Skip the last bolt if you´re going for the send.  The extension to this climb is a .13d called One Inch Punch.
protection: All draws are fixed except for the first 3~ anchor is at the big hole above the double hole.

location: Lakit Lake > Kootenays East (Kimberly/Cranbrook) > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Start on moon shine then head out to right right after the roof!

location: The Balcony > The Lookout > Echo Canyon > Bow Valley > Alberta > Canada > North America > International
desc: Takes a distinct line just right of the large mid-height roof through a series of small overlaps.   Sustained climbing with multiple cruxes.

location: Atlantis Wall > The Lookout > Echo Canyon > Bow Valley > Alberta > Canada > North America > International
desc: Continue past the anchors after the top of all you can eat. 100m rope required

location: The Fin Wall > Lion's Head > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: This route starts 50 feet east (climber's left) of the Latvian Ledge area and contains several boulder problems up a varied face.

location: The Apocalypse Cave > Bow Valley > Alberta > Canada > North America > International
desc: See sendage for more beta. first cave climb on the right

location: Titan Wall > Lion's Head > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: Spectacular line. Start as if for Dr. Zeaus but move left at the fourth bolt into excellent face climbing before heading up the huge overhang. Jump off at the top after pulling the roof.

location: Lost at Sea Wall > Lion's Head > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: The first route to the right of the rappel dihedral~ an extremely varied~ extremely hard~ and extremely thin route.

location: South Pinnacle > Old Baldy > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: Height dependant~ one move wonder. Don't get your hopes up on this one.

location: Tecolote Cave > El Salto > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Chi may be a long route~ but it is quite bouldery. Steep~ pumpy movement all the way throughout~ with a very difficult powerful boulder in the middle. Be prepared to log some serious air time if you pitch off the runout upper headwall.

location: The Outrage Wall > El Potrero Chico > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Climb Cleetus (10a) up to a dihedral/seam thing and then pull onto the headwall. Climb repeatedly through boulder problems to big hueco features. This is one of the hardest pitches in Potrero and has seen very few ascents.

location: The Big Show > Chek > Sea to Sky (Squamish to Whistler) > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Start up the corner at the far left edge of the wall for a couple moves~ then break out right along a steep diagonal crackline. Pass a crux where the crack blanks out for a couple moves~ then rejoin it for a long endurance finish to the anchors. Steep and sustained.

location: Sektor Betlispfeiler > Weesen > Switzerland > Europe > International
desc: The airy arete on the right side of UFO 60.   Recognized as a separate route~ actually possible to link with both other routes adjacent to it.    From the mid-point belay ledge on the wall (reachable by one 60m rappel)~ head right~ keep going right~ until the arete.     Maximum exposure!
protection: Well-bolted. Would be possible to aid through the cruxes.

location: Gerakopetra > Ineia > Cyprus > Europe > International
desc: A fun technical climb. Crux was about mid way through the climb. I had to do some fancy footwork to get through it.

location: Milianos Cave > Kalymnos > Greece > Europe > International
desc: Fun vertical route with holds exactly where you need them.  A commitment move halfway up is rewarded with good holds.

location: Flakeout Walls > Mgarr ix-Xini > Gozo > Malta > Europe > International
desc: There are bolts going up this intimidating and mesmerizing pocketed white face~ but you may have to weave left and right to find the 5.11 way to connect them with quickdraws and your fancy climbing rope~ if that's your goal. Lots of Pockets~ and lots of thoughtful face climbing - be creative. I remember there was a crux or two~ but in general it was rather fun and sustained. Just be thankful this wall isn't overhung.

location: Futbolin > Santa Linya > Catalonia > Spain > Europe > International
desc: A classic 6c for the wall serving up intriguing moves on steep terrain. A no-hands rest on a small ledge just before the final~ crux headwall detracts only a bit while allowing you to rest up before the difficulties above.     Athletic and rewarding climbing on big~ positive holds get you through the first 60 feet to a good ledge/cave rest just right of the bolt line. Move out left and crank up smaller-yet-positive holds with nicely exposed climbing to the anchor.
protection: 10 bolts to a two-bolt anchor with a single steel lowering biner.

location: Zakrzówek > Poland > Europe > International
desc: Long climb to the right of the dihedral and ascends just left of the overhang and follows up rightward. Crux moves are above the overhang. Very fun.

location: Aiguille du Refuge > Argentière Basin > Chamonix Mont Blanc > Northern Alps > France > Europe > International
desc: A strenuous line which will offer something for everyone - cracks~ slabs~ and roofs.    Two ropes to descend

location: Magoulias Wall > Summertime > Kalymnos > Greece > Europe > International
desc: Start on easy tufas to access a sustain and delicate wall with a tricky bulge at the end.

location: Hetzendorfer Wand > Frankenjura > Germany > Europe > International
desc: Fun but powerful jug-hauling on an overhanging arete.

location: Spartan Wall Left > Spartan Wall > Kalymnos > Greece > Europe > International
desc: Xerxeseverybody knows this one~ right? Breakout single from nu metal pioneers~ The Deftones?     Right.    And everybody should come to know this climb: it's sweet like the baffled~ crying sustain off of Chino Moreno's drop-tuned Les Paul.    Walk up a gray~ underwhelming ramp. Careful not to clip "Spasspartour~" the line just a few feet to the right (and~ really~ starting just above the painted name "Xerxes" on the wall). Hump over a small and easy bulge. (Did you go around right? You didn't listen about "Spasspartour~" did you. Drop to the ground and start over~ nimrod.)    Now launch up the brown streak on the orange headwall. STAY OUT OF THAT BROKEN MESS ON YOUR RIGHT. That~ too~ is not your line~ tasty as it looks. Instead~ stay on the clean~ sparsely pocketed wall and roll up the blankness until it gets cruxy. Stay outta that broken stuff on the left~ too. No rests for you. Now thinner are the edges~ greasy are the feet...you're in the bizzness. Now send that sucker and let's go get some Mythos.
protection: 19 draws. Yes~ 19. This one goes the distance. Oh~ and you'll want to be bringing that 80m for Xerxes..ours reached with notta lotta room to spare. A mid-point station on "Spasspartour" right next door~ could probably come into play if'n you only brought the short cord.

location: Hexenküche > Hiltpoltstein > Frankenjura > Germany > Europe > International
desc: Climbs relatively obvious pockets~ but is surprisingly athletic and technical~ and is~ in my opinion~ one of the most sustained routes in the Hexenküche. You can get pretty pumped. The crux is around the 2nd bolt~ and above the bulge the climbing eases up. Continue to top.
protection: 4 bolts + anchor on top of the tower.

location: Galayos > Spain > Europe > International
desc: The route begin on Plataforma de las Flores~ a ledge on the base of the Torreon. You can get the ledge hiking the gully between the Tonino Re and The Torreon.  Pitch 1. Climb the beautiful crack (5.10) on the right facing dihedral. A bit of all: the route starts at the chimney~ then layback~ and wide to thin hands. The anchor has two bolts.  Pitch 2. The crux (5.11c) is a short wall protected with old pitons~ although you can add TCU.  5.11 fingers. You can link the two pitches with a 60 m rope.  Descent: rappelling the route.
protection: Standard rack with extra sets of cams to #3 Camalot. 1 #4 Camalot.

location: Fantasia > Chulilla > Valencia > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Challenging but manageable climbing leads to a rest stance out left below a steep intimidating~ left angling corner. Thin holds out right will get you to the base of the corner and hopefully your tall enough to reach the bolt over the lip. Continue up the corner until your forced straight right to some reachy but positive holds and then straight up to the anchor. It should be noted that the bolts on this route are well spaced and you definitely have to make hard moves above them.
protection: About 8 bolts to a two bolt anchor.

location: Oasis > Paredes del Pantano > Chulilla > Valencia > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Desperately thin and sharp is how I would describe this climb. But it’s still good and worth doing.
protection: Bolts to a two bolt anchor.

location: Footwork Sector > Hanshelleren > Flatanger > Trøndelag > Norway > Europe > International
desc: Long vert granite climb.

location: Can Toni Gros > Village Crags > Siurana > Catalonia > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Varied~ interesting climbing. It's a good warm up for the harder routes.

location: Rocca della Basura > Val Pennavaire > Oltrefinale > Liguria region > Italy > Europe > International
desc: Really fun climbing on a distinctive-looking rock.

location: Iliada Right > Iliada > Kalymnos > Greece > Europe > International
desc: Really fun and technical moves on small tufas and good pockets.  Gets steeper towards the top~ with some bouldery moves on good flakes and side pulls.  NOT named after the French capital~ as the guidebook states.  So I can only assume it's Paris~ Texas?

location: Espero Primavera > Valley Crags > Siurana > Catalonia > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Good climb that utilizes body position and sidepulls more than your typical Siurana crankfest.   It starts with some tricky climbing on slippery feet up to a good stance above the first bolt. Then layback your way up the rail to a move off of a mono lock (crux). Higher up trend left and slap up the arete~ clip the last bolt and head up the face on jugs to the chains.

location: Grotta Dell'edera > Finale Ligure > Liguria region > Italy > Europe > International
desc: Line that goes up the tofa'd wall and leads up over the giant black shark-fin tufa and then traverses about 6 feet horizontally in the overhang before popping out on jugs to a "bearhug" set of hole-jugs. No apparent crux but its overhanging all the way up~ with a good 10 feet of pure upside down moves on hero jugs at the end when your pumped enough to not feel good on them. Nothing about this route is anything but epic

location: San Martin de  Valparaiso > Valdegovia, Spain > Spain > Europe > International
desc: 10th from left

location: L'Argenteria > Collegats > Catalonia > Spain > Europe > International
desc: On the left side of the wall is a big~ obvious hole/cave. Sellui climbs up to and through this gaper with some wild stemming and tufa pinching.    Start up a few harder-than-they-look slabby moves to the right of a couple of right-facing corners and a small roof. Continue up past a small bush to the base of the hole. Stem your way up using cool tufas on the right to steep moves out of the hole to steep~ juggy climbing above.
protection: 12-14 bolts to anchors. Note the length--a 70m rope is probably necessary.

location: Tofana di Rozes > Tofana Group > Dolomites > Italy > Europe > International
desc: Spigalo means arête in Italian. This route essentially follows the arête on the left side of the south face of the second buttress of Tofana Di Rozes. The route parallels the classic (and busy) 1946 Costantini/Ghedina Pillar Rib route found in most guide books and this web site. Spigalo Sams crux 7th pitch (6c) crosses the Pillar rib and continues to the right of that route for two more pitches then traverses left into the classic route for about two pitches and finally finishes an independent line out right before moving up into the exit gully (or rappelling).  All belays are equipped for rappel   The route is a fairly serious line with bold climbing. It has occasional bolts supplemented by traditional gear and at times tricky route finding. Be ready for some hard 5.10 moves a fair distance above any gear although the crux pitch (6c+) is well protected at the hardest moves.   Pitch 1: Climb up to the bolt then up to the flake and crack. Under cling and layoff the flake then head up and slightly right looking for the second bolt. From here climb boldly out right and up heading for the point of a pillar that is on the arête proper. 30-40 meters~ 5.10c (6b)   Pitch 2:  Climb up the arête over several roofs following occasional bolts. 20 meters~ 5.10c (6b)   Pitch 3: A long easy pitch with rare bolts essentially straight up the arête on the path of least resistance. 55 meters~ 5.6 (4+)   Pitch 4: Slightly left then up just right of some roofs belaying just prior to a triangular roof. 30 meters~ 5.10 (6b)   Pitch 5: Climb just left of the triangular roof climb then up and slightly right 25 meters~ 5.10 (6B)   Pitch 6: Straight up ending just right of some roofs. 20 meters~ 5.10 (6b)   Pitch 7: Climb the bolted yellow rock up and right to a large roof with a crack in it. Clip the fixed pin or bolt over the roof. A very strenuous move gets you over the roof and is followed by a run-out section (look for a piton and some threads about 4-5 meters above the roof). Continue a long distance to the belay crossing the traverse of the Constantini-Ghedina route. 50 meters~ 5.11c/d (6c+)   Pitch 8: Steep juggy but a bit run-out climbing up and slightly right then over a roof leads to a belay. 20 meters 5.10a (6a)   Pitch 9: Continue up to a ledge below yellow rock. 25 m 5.10a (6a)~ consider rappelling from here unless the summit is your goal.   Pitch 10: Traverse left then join classic route and climb up to right of large roof and belay. 45 m 5.5 (4)   Pitch 11: Continue in the corner/gully just left of the main face moving just to the edge near the end of the pitch. 50 meters 5.5 (4)   Pitch 12 and 13: Continue up on the edge of the face for two pitches independent of the classic route~ or move slightly left and finish on that route. 5.9~ 5.6 100 meters.   Pitch 14: Work your way up and left into the gully and continue to the top. 100 meters 4th class.
protection: 8-10 quick draws~ a single rack of cams 0.4 to 2 inches~ a few wires~ many long slings~ a couple threads.

location: Valle dei Porci > Avane (Vecchiano) > Tuscany Province > Italy > Europe > International
desc: This route is the firs (leftmost) route of the last section.    Small crimps~ small pokers and micro foot holds on vertical wall makes this route technical and will pump you up.

location: Berdorf > Luxembourg > Europe > International
desc: Excellent vertical face climb on finger pockets and tiny footholds. The key is hand sequence and balance. The start is the crux and it gets a little easier after the 2nd bolt but still is quite sustained.

location: Main Wall > Dhiarizos > Cyprus > Europe > International
desc: Apparently this used to be a trad route but now it continues up the face a little farther and was bolted like most other trad routes in Cyprus. I didn't climb this one but It looked fun.

location: Hüttenwände > Strassenfelsen > Mount Kanziani > Kärnten > Austria > Europe > International
desc: Difficult slab to get established on a slick slab. After the 2nd bolt the difficulties ease up. Head straight up to the 3rd bolt and right to the anchor.

location: La Derobée > Falaise de l'Escalés > Grand Cañon - Partie Amont > Gorge du Verdon > France > Europe > International
desc: 200 m long 1.pitch 35 m 5c 2. Pitch 38 m 6c+  3. Pitch 25 m 6b 4. Pitch 45 m 7a 5. Pitch 35 m 6c  Watch out for falling rock at the start .
protection: The route is perfectly equipped with 65 glued bolts. The longest pitch has 14 bolts.   All belay stations are equipped with 2 glued bolts.

location: Weißenstein > Frankenjura > Germany > Europe > International
desc: The crux here is simply not falling. The start is somewhat difficult as the holds aren't as big as up above~ but up higher it's pumpy and overhanging. Though the first bolt is a little high~ the climbing isn't dangerous to reach it~ as long as 5.11d is within your reach.   Climb pretty much straight up to the 4th bolt~ then head up and right (roughly following a mini dihedral up there) to the 5th bolt which merges with and shares the anchor with Panische Zeiten.

location: El Pati > Valley Crags > Siurana > Catalonia > Spain > Europe > International
desc: This route is a full 35m of fun~ occasionally sequential but mostly juggy climbing. Quite a few rests with a tricky crux near the top. The Brasco guide gives it 7a (11d) but it feels a bit easier then that if you use the many good rests

location: Siuranella Este > Valley Crags > Siurana > Catalonia > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Start belaying stating on the one ft ledge and anchored to the wire. climb thin crimps with a little left traverse in the middle. It never really gets easy and has some tricky moves right at the anchor

location: Alcalalí > Costa Blanca > Spain > Europe > International
desc: A nice 7a that heads towards an obvious left leaning corner at the top. Start by scrambling up an easy slab to a bowl and clip the first bolt to the right. There is also a line of newer bolts climbing out of the bowl but this is a much harder variation on less than stellar rock. Continue up the vertical technical face heading slightly left toward the steep corner. The original route (7b+~ 12c) climbed the arete to the right of the corner and was reportedly “heinous”~ but the corner is no give me either.
protection: About 10 older bolts to an old two bolt anchor. There is a new bolt below the crux and the rest seemed fine but could probably use some updating.

location: Fruto De La Mierda > Tamadaba > Gran Canaria > Canary Islands > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Route 6

location: Dodlwand > Chinesiche Mauer (Great Wall of China) > Tirol > Austria > Europe > International
desc: Literally meaning 'Jug Parade'~ you'll find jugs here certainly~ but also crimps~ slopers~ sidepulls and underclings.

location: Central Sector > Quirra > Sardinia > Italy > Europe > International
desc: Just right of Take it Easy is this similarly steep route. An easy start leads to a strenuous stretch passing the break in the rock. Then climb steep~ featured rock and a stalactite to the anchor.
protection: Seven bolts to a two-bolt anchor

location: Hertenstein > Baden > Switzerland > Europe > International
desc: 7a    Worthwhile little project. Tight shoes and lots of chalk recommended... very challenging in high humidity~ with the crux holds being a bit round~ a bit worn~ and very limestone.

location: Main Wall > Jarlsberget (Jarberget) > Dokka > Oppland > Norway > Europe > International
desc: This is a great 'warm-up' on the main cliff at Dokka. The first few bolts are the crux~ but the route stays on you one way or another~ whether with hard moves or engaging run outs.  Start up the shallow dihedral and go straight up to the roof. Traverse out the base of the roof to the right and clip the anchor. There are extensions... not sure how hard they are.

location: Gerakopetra > Ineia > Cyprus > Europe > International
desc: Start on easy slab moves up to an overlap with some decent holds making it easier than it looks. another easy slab section leads up to a small cave. The crux is probably pulling up out of the cave and establishing yourself on the face above.  This climb was easier than Loco Re Loco 7a though the cyprus rocks website cyprusrocks.eu/crag_detail.…  gives it the slightly harder grading of 7a+. I didn't really think so.

location: Millennium Cave > Cala Gonone > Sardinia > Italy > Europe > International
desc: A pumpy journey up a left-angling seam full of good pockets ending in a corner between a tufa pillar and the wall on the right.
protection: 10 bolts to an anchor just above the tufa pillar. An absolute bear to clean--it's best to top-rope the route to retrieve your draws.

location: Eros > Telendos Island > Kalymnos > Greece > Europe > International
desc: Gigantic greasy holds with slippery feet make for a challenging route at the grade. Fortunately the hands are on buckets most of the route.

location: Mutiny Crack Area > Burbage North > Burbage Valley > The Peak District > England > United Kingdom > Europe > International
desc: The centre of the buttress through the three roofs.

location: Secret Garden > Kalymnos > Greece > Europe > International
desc: Stem up the right side of the HUGE tufa fin - actually between two tufa fins.  Multiple rests abound and one last hard move at the end.

location: Peña del Godo > Tamadaba > Gran Canaria > Canary Islands > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Route 8

location: Dalle à Patouche > Belgian Chocolates > Kalymnos > Greece > Europe > International
desc: Rock Shrimps Ext. Climb Rock Shrimps and continue straight up the vertical face staying left of a bush and loose looking block.

location: Misja pec > Osp > Slovenia > Europe > International
desc: Tough~ slopey~ slabby moves off the ledge gain the tufa.  Start on the right and make a difficult move to the left.  Ride it to the chains.

location: Raco de les Espadelles > Margalef > Catalonia > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Some powerful moves in the beginning~ and good sequences. The line moves back and forth a bit. Not a great warmup~ but a good climb.

location: Poets Main > Poets > Kalymnos > Greece > Europe > International
desc: So~ so fun. You start with a bouldery sequence and then you do a very long traverse right where the footwork is very interesting to solve. All that traverse will bring you to a roof that will be the crux of the route (easier if tall). Cool moves to get over it and the route is done. The whole thing is well protected and feel soft for the grade in the guidebook (7a+).

location: Paraiso > Moya > Gran Canaria > Canary Islands > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Route 6

location: Secteur 25 - Nombril > Buoux > Provence > France > Europe > International
desc: Start at the prominent arete and then move slightly left onto the face. Must do climb: youtube.com/watch?v=3Qln7Ui…

location: Appenroder Wand > Reinhäuser Tal Nord > Göttinger Wald > Germany > Europe > International
desc: Steep technical climb with a boulder crux that keeps you engaged all the way to the anchor.

location: Continuum Crag > Spectrum Crags > 7 - Upper Highway > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: A really fantastic route that will test you several ways. Climb easier terrain up to the easy looking dihedral ramp. Layback~ squeeze and jam your way up the dihedral to a large knob guarding the headwall.     Tiptoe your way onto the knob~ and make a big toss to get established on the face. Once on the steep headwall gymnastic moves on good (but hard to read) holds will lead you all the way to the top of the cliff.
protection: Bolts    Once we get a few other opinions~ one more bolt might be added between the last bolt and the anchors. Feedback appreciated....

location: Red Dragon > Mt. Elden Crags > Flagstaff Area > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Great bouldery moves up steepening overhang lead to a perfect lip encounter. Exciting slab finish.

location: Pumphouse > 2 - Bear Canyon > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Follow the first three bolts of Forged in Hell then break right following a right facing corner and flakes.       This route is named for two very fun and alternating heel and rock over moves in the middle of the route.  You also get some fun compression climbing and NO crimps!  That's right~ you heard it hear~ if you're crimping you ain't doing it right.       Solve your way through the middle crux and the difficulties ease off ending with a fun undercling and mantle series of moves just prior to the chains.

location: Pharaoh > 2 - Bear Canyon > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: This was one the mid-80s Arizona testpieces before rap bolting became widely accepted.  The route was originally led in two pitches~ the second being the crux~ the first a 5.11a warm-up.  (EFR's guidebook shows it going in two pitches~ but it was climbed as one pitch shortly after its first ascent).  Jim Waugh~ one of the state's leading climbers in the 80s~ came down from Phoenix to bag the crux pitch using crack-n-ups and the then-smallest microwires for protection.  I recall carrying three full sets of RPs for my ascent~ and so armed~ not having to use crack-n-ups.  However~ John Fowler~ who was likely the 3rd person to lead the climb~ recalls needing them.  We didn't have microcams~ offset HBs~ and other modern trickery during those days~ so whether crack-n-ups are mandatory is an open question; that is~ until you climb it and tell us.    According to notes I took shortly after my ascent (25 years ago)~ the climb is "very sustained~ multi-faceted" with "unique cruxes -- although no crux alone is probably harder than solid 5.11."  The 1985 guide says "[s]everal questionable holds may be encountered."  I don't remember a whole lot about it now~ of course~ so go climb it and find out for yourself.    The route begins in the obvious thin crack right of Cripple Creek.  The crack doglegs left across Cripple Creek about 40-50 feet up~ then continues diagonally up and left.  The thin crack is obvious in the beta photo for Cripple Creek~ showing that route in yellow.  From the crack's end~ a featured face leads to Cripple Creek's second belay.  Take any of the easier lines to the top.    By the way~ Ray Ringle named the climb after an Edward Gorey story~ the first line of which is~ "A is for Amy who fell down the stairs."  Dark themes continue for the rest of the alphabet.
protection: No fixed gear.  Double set of cams from smallest to 3~ full set of nuts~ at least a double set of micros~ maybe crack-n-ups?  The pro is all there~ it just takes some work.

location: Main Wall > Jacks Canyon > Winslow- Hwy’s 87 & 99 Corridors > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Start almost as for Genesis but climb slightly right to the first bolt.  Head up ever steepening ground on decent pockets~ making a tricky move around the third bolt.  Pull on a few more good pockets and head into the crux~ getting past the vertical section.  Pass this and it's easy going up to the anchors.

location: Ravelin, The > 8 - Summit Crags > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Steep start with a rest if your tricky~ transition to more vertical climbing with another rest soon. Easier climbing to the crux which if you're much shorter than 5'9" it might be more difficult for you. Follow the good holds to another rest and then figure out how to get to the anchors.

location: 6. Cwm Laude Wall > North Side > Volunteer Canyon (The Cwm) > Sycamore Canyon > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Haunting the Cwm Laude Wall~ this obscure line boards near the bottom of the canyon~ in the seldom visited talus. You may get a sense that you're not alone when you're down there~ so have your partner rap in first.  Two unique pitches are separated by a cozy midway belay. The first featuring a 'slice of Rifle' and the second an airy hanging stem corner. Definitely feasible to link the pitches for a long ride if you dont want to smell the roses.  P1: Steep~ sporty~ and pumpy. Chase a few bolts through an early sequential crux. Yard lightly on the Holloween Flake (don't worry~ crowbar tested) up to a nice rest and finish with some rather sharp holds turning the arete to an inviting belay stance and seat. 75'  P2. Stem above the belay past a couple of bolts and enter the committing and exposed hanging corner crux. A crack begins but immediately thins~ appropriately protected by a grey ghost (000 C3). Thoughtful stemming and finger-tip stuffing follow with several timely jugs and rails to more moderate jamming to the rim. 85'
protection: Top anchor/rapline could use a #3 C4 at the rim~ backed up to a bolt and RB(in small boulder 10ft back) The midway belay is 1 bolt supplemented with a #2C4 or #4C4. P1: 7 bolts and optional #.75C4 P2: 3 bolts~ single selection of micro cams and C4s #0.3-#3

location: North Fin > 4 - Windy Point West > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Yeah~ yeah~ this route has an admittedly overly-dramatic name~ but we wanted something classic to memorialize what we thought was a great route.  Ironically~ Gladiator apparently has faded into obscurity~ perhaps another victim of Tucson's late-80s sport climbing surge~ which by all accounts continues today.  (EFR in Squeezing II gives it no stars; . . . dude~ really?)  We worked this from the ground up~ consistent with the ethic just about to be swept aside~ figuring the sequence out by taking repeated falls and lowering to a rest.  I slightly remember there being a little suspect rock low on the route~ but it has cool position~ and from what I can recollect~ the climbing is not so much burly as tricky and sequential~ with height being an advantage.    Start up Histo~ but break left at the top of the right-leaning~ right-facing corner~ up a crack toward a face protected by a bolt and pin.

location: The Steep > 7 - Upper Highway > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Getting to the second bolt is a bit spooky but the holds you are trying to reach are good and easy to clip from.  There are no chains so you need a sling to donate to this climb.  This may be fixed by the time you get on it.  The anchors will probably be moved higher so the rope doesn't get hammered so badly when you lower off.  The crux is at the top which I always like.

location: Goosehead > 5 - Windy Ridge > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: This long crack line was originally climbed in 1969 by a young Dave Baker (the soon-to-be owner of the Summit Hut) and Kem Johnson (who moved to Australia years ago) using pins for aid.  Neglected for years until 1980~ it went free at 5.11b by Herb North and John Fowler~ who added a bolt to face climb into the lower part of the crack from the opening moves of Chung King Corner and found a free escape from the original aid line near the top of the pitch.  They named their version of the route Glide Path~ which has since stuck.  That same year~ though~ Phoenicians Jim Waugh~ Brad Smith (before he moved to Tucson)~ and Jim Zahn climbed the North-Fowler start then freed the upper part~ adding another 5.11 section.  Four years later~ the Verm and I managed to nab the entire crack free from its start~ which added the free crux and creates an action-packed mixed bolt and gear climb that I've always thought comes close to Histoplasmosis in quality and difficulty.     If I recall~ a number of the bolts were quarter-inchers~ some that could be backed up with gear and consequently ignored and others that~ well~ you'd take a leap a faith when clipping.  Not sure what's there now.  Although the bad bolts may warrant only three stars for this line~ if it were cleaned up I'm fairly sure it would be a Lemmon classic.

location: The Beach > Muscle Beach > Oak Creek Canyon > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: A bouldery crux right off the ground leads to fun sustained climbing. Shares an anchor with Muscle Milk. Stick clip the first bolt.
protection: 3 bolts to chain anchors with fixed carabiners.

location: Davidson Wall > Paradise Forks > Sycamore Canyon > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: This is one of the two bolted lines at the Forks.  The other being American at Arapalies.  While the question as to whether this should have remained a toprope will continue to be an issue it is a fun~ if not short~ route.  Start as you would for Loose Lips~ after the bouldery start make a blind stretch to clip the first bolt around the corner to your right.  With the bolt clipped ease your way onto the face and balance slap and pimp your way through to the next bolt.  With that clipped a little finese to a very cool throw and insecure mantel will get you to the top section of Loose lips.
protection: 2 draws~ same gear that you would use for the top section of Loose Lips.

location: Centipede Spire > Lost Dry Creek Cirque > Dry Creek Road Area > West Sedona > Sedona Area > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: The proud~ prominent corner system cleaving the pillar of Centipede Spire. The system is quite obvious on the approach~ and starts with an obtuse corner in the uppermost Schnebly banding and continues into a more defined Coco corner with a looming roof. A unique line that runs a full range of sizes and styles from sub-tips stem-shuffling to fist roof thuggery. It should provide challenges for all hand-sizes (unless you fingerlock green C3s and handjam #4 C4s that is...).  It is west facing~ and will hold shade until early afternoon (around 2pm) during most of the typical Sedona season.  P1--A bit of face and podded corner will quickly deposit you into the crux~ which consists of about 15' of sub-tips in a pretty smooth-walled corner. Invent beta to pass this (power-stemming and some body English scumming help). Fortunately~ the Schnebly is as solid and clean as it gets for these micro-cam placements! Continue with gradually opening tips and fingers until the corner rolls over~ and romp up the widening crack between stances and jugs (that once housed plentiful loafs and blocks--diligently turned into talus by Blake on the first attempt). Belay on a stance. .12-~ 100'  P2-- Ramble over a large block and size up the slanting roofcrack above. Fistfight your way out it and pull into the beautiful corner above. Mostly baggy handcrack with some wider bits and flared spots lead to the dramatically steep exit. The crack narrows quickly here as you pull onto the belay ledge~ but there are ample features all around to help the cause. A pretty memorable pitch and true blue-collar classic! .11~ 120'           ***Due to the steepness of P2~ you can't rappel from the top of P2 to the anchors atop P1. Either continue up or rap to the ground with           two 70m ropes. ***  P3--Up the corner to a bulge~ cut left and round the arete to the belay anchor atop P2 of Metamerism (which is joined from here up). There's a bit of suspect rock to avoid on this connector pitch~ but generally it's on pretty good patina still. .8~ 50'  P4--The crux pitch (P3) of Metamerism. An easy chimney (with some friable rock) leads past the only 2 pro bolts (use extended slings) on the route into the looming~ A-frame roof above~ reach out and sink some cams in the fat-finger crack out the roof~ and awkwardly work out it using a fortuitous patina footrail to pull the lip and exit the alcove on jams and patina jugs. Belay up and right on a small foot ledge. A very unique and cool pitch that looks like it could be way harder~ but pans out. 5.10+~ 50'  P4--Easy shelves lead to a final roof with a handcrack and patina jugs. Flop onto the flat summit. Belay from cams. 5.10~ 30'  Rap off of chained anchors that are about 40' or so south of where you top out. Skip the anchors atop P3 and hit the ledge atop P2 and walk over to the chains. The final rap to the ground is a full 35m--watch the ends of the rope! You will probably end up in an oak.
protection: (1x) .1 or purple C3   (2X) .2-#2   (4X) #3~ #4   All cams in BD C4 sizes.    (1X) 70m rope

location: Main Wall > Jacks Canyon > Winslow- Hwy’s 87 & 99 Corridors > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Jugs~ pockets~ under clings~ crimp jugs~ and even a sloper.  This line has some fun holds to pull on.  Like a lot of routes on this wall~ this route starts with a boulder problem.  After the bouldery but fun start~ there's a couple buckets to recover on.  Moving off the buckets~ the climbing becomes pocketed with some pockets being great and some being less than great. Find the good pockets then make one last difficult move to gain footing on the ledge by the last bolt.  From here easier climbing leads to the anchors~ traverse the ledge left a little before heading up to the anchors.   Don't let the back wall intimidate you~ you never get near it and of course you don't use it. You'll want to stick clip the first bolt and maybe even the second bolt to start the route.

location: 3. The Right Wall > The Waterfall > Oak Creek Canyon > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Barbarian Rising~ like it’s neighbor Locks of Dread~ has a gas pocket crux section over small gear. Overall~ Barbarian Rising packs in more sustained climbing and better rock.  Barbarian Rising and Tainted Love share the same blocky start~ followed by a nice section of hands. At the roof~ move out right underneath (5.11)~ and gain the rest just before the crux. A hand full of small TCUs should bolster your confidence~ and unconventional cranking will lead you past the crux (.12-). Though the grade backs off after the crux it is still a haul to the anchors.
protection: Bulk up on #00- #2 TCUS~ doubles on the rest to #1 Camalot.

location: Oak Creek Spire > Oak Creek Spire Area > Village of Oak Creek > Sedona Area > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Have you climbed 'Southern Revival' and felt a bit...unsatisfied? This 2 bolt variation might leave you feeling a bit less weak. Clip  the last bolt on the 1st pitch and move left past bolt to a belay. Now tip your head back and eye the next 39 meters carefully. Snort some 'roids and prepare to get raw ripped.     Move left on munge past a bolt and techy tick-tack through the tips crack. Sport layback to a rest and hope you didn't blow all your .5's yet...    More sports laybacking up through steep thin hands to the change in crack orientation and pretend to rest. Gather your wits for the final slightly tricky and exposed "5.10c Boulder Problem".     Barf up your protein shake onto the Tanning Salon. Perch out left to clip anchor.     You are now a Beast Master! For extra credit~ continue up the rest of 'Southern Revival'. Invent more stars!
protection: Gear:   2x #00 C3 - #.3 C4   3x #.4 C4 and #.75 C4   5x #.5 C4   2x #1 C4    Bonus cams for first encounter:   2x #2 C4   1x #.3C4- #1 C4   80m Rope Mandatory for lower!!!

location: Obscurity Wall > Paradise Forks > Sycamore Canyon > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Big Balls In Cowtown is a unique and varied route in the Forks norm. It features exciting technical face and a steep fingers finish on an isolated buttress amongst other obscurities.     Not as runout as its neighbor to the north~ the gear is good just non existent for the first 20ft off the ledge. A lucky jump back to the belay could be an option?    From the belay ledge step left through some wobble blocks and onto the clean face. Climb the unprotected technical face to the first sign of gear. Climb through a boulder problem to a mini-ledge. After a rest continue up the left leaning and steep boulder problem finish. Sporty.
protection: Belay: .75 C4 x2    Gear used:   .75 C4 w/48" runner at belay   Grey #000 C3   #4 brass offset   Purple #00 C3 12" runner   Green #0 C3 12" runner   .3 C4 24" runner   Red #1 C3   .4 C4

location: The Cuz Wall > Lucy Spire? > Camel's Head Area > Marg's Draw > Sedona > Sedona Area > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Intense~ amazing~ technical and unrelenting. That is Black Cobra.  P1 Same as Red Lung. Move belay right 50 feet on big ledge. Belay at bolt. 5.7 R 100 feet.  P2 Crank up black jugs and sidepulls to the Black Cobra jug at the 3rd bolt. Now prepare to strike! From the shelf~ power tech up the arête crux past the snake eye pockets to the jug ledge. A hard mantle awaits you before a respite from the pump is granted. Style cool features to an optional thin hands placement before the chains. 5.12-(+/-) 80 feet.  Bonus points available by finishing up P3 of either Heavy Metal Saturday or Red Lung.
protection: 1X BD#1C3-#1C4 for P1. P2 9 BoltZZZZZZ!!!!! 70m works best for 1st pitch rap.

location: The Prow > Paradise Forks > Sycamore Canyon > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: A thin and technical black crack/seam. Fairly engaging the whole way. Named after my favorite scene in Forrest Gump.
protection: (1) ea. 000 and 00 C3. (2) ea. purple metolious through 0.5 camalot.

location: North Fin > 4 - Windy Point West > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: A demanding mixed adventure that culminates in an outrageous overhanging prow~ with very few sharp crimps to be found anywhere on the line. A few heady moves on the first pitch and a do-not-fall section above the belay on the second make this line somewhat intimidating~ though the climbing through these moments is far easier than anything else on the climb. It may be possible~ perhaps even preferable~ to do the entire line as one pitch; thoughtful sling work would be mandatory. The cover of SQL2 featured a shot of climbers silhouetted on this line.
protection: singles rack to a #2~ stoppers optional~ draws~ and a few slings~ 2-bolt anchor P1

location: Miyazaki > Upper Boulder Creek > Crags along the Peavine Trail > Granite Dells > **Prescott Area > Central Arizona > Arizona
desc: Difficult climb with minute~ sharp crimps on a slightly overhung wall. The first crux is getting on the wall to the first bolt~ which requires some contortion and major balancing skills. The second crux is transitioning from the 8-inch long finger ledge to the finger crack up and to the right (there's a smaller crimp to the left that helps).  The climb was named after the wild black crystalline structures to the right after the top-out.
protection: 6 bolts to a 3-bolt anchor. Use all bolts at the anchor if you can~ but you can just as easily get by with using the lateral bolts only (the ones with quicklinks).

location: 6 - Swallow Wall > The Dry Canyon > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Cleaning the Slate climbs blocky incut features for several bolts before spitting you onto a section of technical vertical climbing.  Climb edges in sea of newly uncovered limestone to a crux just below the nice looking dihedral.      Rest up as the last moves in the corner before the chains will still get your attention.         This route redefined what it means to clean a route for me.  On the upside it did provide a lot of material for the trail at the base of the wall.       Enjoy!
protection: 9 bolts to chains with lower-offs.      First bolt is there to protect from falling off of the ledge.  The belayer should unclip this as soon as the climber is into draws above.

location: High Life Wall > Jacks Canyon > Winslow- Hwy’s 87 & 99 Corridors > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: This route was in the book but not on mountainproject and I haven't climbed it yet but look forward to it. I gave it a 2 star just to be fair and will adjust the rating later.

location: Solitude Wall > Solitude Canyon > Mt. Elden Crags > Flagstaff Area > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Derelicte climbs up a short dihedral with a ceiling~ then curves out left up an angling~ lazer cut crack with an initial jug opening.  Crank past shallow tips locks using perfectly faint smears. Joins Twist Off at the last bolt. A straight up variation - Derelicte My Bolts  11d/12a - was recently added. An interesting boulder problem with a less sustained finish.

location: Main Ampitheater > The Biscuit > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Climbs big flake features that are a little scary on the lower section~ but the position is pretty cool~ and the rock in the roof is awesome. Climb the snake flake then head up into a small square slot~ and right through holes into the bottom of the roof. Take a left trending path through two more bolts over the first two roofs. Moderate throughout except a bouldery crux revolving around a mysteriously attached blocky pinch in the roof. Easy climbing to the chains.  The large pillar/flake used to have a secondary pillar next to it that was solid enough to hand jam one year~ and fell off with a gentle push the next. The giant pillar could fall off at some point~ and would obliterate the belay~ so I strongly recommend checking it out before you fully commit to it.
protection: Lots of bolts~ maybe two runners. Lower-offs.

location: Cracker Jack Cliffs > Jacks Canyon > Winslow- Hwy’s 87 & 99 Corridors > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Bouldery roof start to easy climbing above. Think...Body tension going over the roof (crux)!

location: Hunchback Pinnacle > 3 - Windy Point East > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Green Ripper is to the right of Steve's Arete as you look down towards the Highway.  It is also easily identified by the four ring bolts.  The route starts off of the the ledge.  The first bolt is easily clipped from there.  This climb packs a lot of climbing into 35 feet.  Two of the local guides give it only one star.  Climb it and see for yourself.  The climbing is powerful and fun.
protection: Four 3.75" stainless bolts to chain anchors.

location: 5 - Bishop > Chessman Area > 2 - Bear Canyon > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Middle route of three sport routes on Bishop formation

location: 4. The Double Clutching Wall > The Waterfall > Oak Creek Canyon > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: The evil younger sister to The Chronic.
protection: Many tips and smaller. Shares anchor with Super Chronic.

location: Oaklands > Mt. Elden Crags > Flagstaff Area > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Joycone begins with some cool moves through a short dihedral and finishes on a very aesthetic arete feature - the Joycone. The arete section is short~ but hosts some of the best holds and moves at the cliff. Be sure to take in the view while topping out.

location: 3. The Right Wall > The Waterfall > Oak Creek Canyon > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: A Wonderful Life was a saving grace and needed distraction from reality for Dan when we were working on the pitch. He got so excited about the line that he actually wanted to add bolts to link the bottom and top~ though I am pretty sure I did the bolting. At the end of the day~ all was wonderful and life seemed right and just. A striking pitch with classic Waterfall climbing.  Start on a very pronounced finger crack 2 systems left of Resurrection. Work your way up to a shallow~ overhanging~ left facing dihedral passing three bolts. Once you reach the upper dihedral be ready to move and place thin gear on the run.
protection: Plenty of small/medium TCUs~ small/medium wires~ and Lowe Balls.

location: Lifeline Area > Jim Bryant Canyon > Sedona > Sedona Area > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: A good alternative to Lifeline. Starts off the same belay ledge. It would be wise to extend your belay to the lower ledge to make leads falls more enjoyable. It trends up and left passing two bolts at the start. Passing the second bolt is the thin lie-back crux. The corner starts as .1s and goes to #4. Steep with good rests. The corner holds shade hours after Lifeline is in full sun.

location: The Snake Flake > Black Mountains - Golden Valley > Kingman Area > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Shared chains with route to the left: The Mandible

location: Poseidon > Reef of Rocks > 7 - Upper Highway > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Warm up your cheeks for some all smiles feature hopping guaranteed to test all your Reef know how. Three beautifully sustained new pitches followed by a classic old school Reef romp really make this a special route.  Pitch 1 | 5.12: Start with 5.11 climbing on bolts to pleasant fingers and thin hands in a corner.  Clip a bolt at the top of the corner and begin a traverse left~ passing some fiddly gear on a brief moment of easier ground.  Ahead is a techy dihedral protected by thin gear followed by a power flake ending at a bolted anchor on the slanting ledge that the giant Om chimney/flake sits on. Plug a piece to prevent your partner from swinging and shredding the rope if they blow the last moves!!! Rack: 7 bolts~ single set to #1 C4~ with doubles in 00 - .4 C4~ nuts  Pitch 2 | 5.12 - : Start by sport clipping your way through classic steep and featured terrain just left of the anchor.  After the 3rd bolt place some gear then clip 2 more bolts taking you to the base of a curving flake and left leaning corner.  A fairly short crux comes at the corner and and is protected by RPs/00. Build an anchor with two 2s and a 1 in the splitter above.   Rack: 5 bolts~ double to #2 C4~ micro nuts  Pitch 3 | 5.11: The Concrete Dihedral.  Hands narrowing down to tips with an awesome roof traverse at the end.  Check your GPS~ you may not believe you are on Mt. Lemmon. Build an anchor on the ledge above the tree with a #2 and some medium nuts.   Rack: Doubles to #1 C4~ single #2 C4.  Extra .5 - 1 C4s could be useful.    Pitch 4 | 5.10+R: An old school romp up the last pitch of Snow Arch.  There is some really good climbing on this pitch but a lot to tip toe around and a spicy crux above the ledge.  Build an anchor on the summit.  Lots of options here. Rack: Doubles to #2~ nuts
protection: Doubles from 00 C3 - #2 C4~ nuts including micros~ draws/slings

location: The Jungle Wall > Paradise Forks > Sycamore Canyon > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: A unique line for the Forks~ save for one pinky lock there is no jamming on this route. The line starts in a shallow dihedral on bobble rock which leads to a short slab. From here reach high and place a #2 BD nut and a blue ball nut and launch into the refrigerator wrestling boulder problem~ followed by big moves on positive holds to the top.      NOTE : A lot of the gear is quite small and specific on the route~ I highly recommend sussing it before leading the route.
protection: Thin~ I used the following.    3x #000 C3   2x #00 C3   Blue Ball Nut   #2 BD Nut   #3 BD Nut   #5 Offset   #6 Offset   #8 BD Nut   .3 C4   #3 C4 (For the very top)

location: Pinhead Wall > 1 -  Lower Highway > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Ray says he drilled this line about 10 years ago for a girl named Anna who wanted to do an FA.  Then she abandoned the effort.  Ray never red-pointed it either~ so it sat as an open project.  It's hard to believe it would sit for long because it is a nice-looking line and there are zillions of climbers in the country that could cruise it.  In fact I saw a local flash it pretty easily yesterday (may 2016).  So I assume the FA is unknown.    I normally like routes that are at least slightly overhung.  This one seems dead vertical but I like it anyway because it has an unusual combination of good handholds but marginal footholds.  How is that possible ? Because the handholds are mostly side-pulls and underclings so they don't turn into good footholds as you climb past them.    Most of the route is about 5.11 but there is a definite~ height-intensive~ crux after the fourth bolt.  Climbers who are 6'6" might think it is 5.11d.  Climbers who are 5'2" will likely think 12c.  If you are my height (5'10") the crux is very pretty if you do it right~ and 5.12 seems right on.
protection: 8 bolts to fixed anchors.    May 2016: replaced bolts 2~3~4 with 1/2" x 5" SS with Ray's permission.

location: DWS East Side > DWS East Clear Creek > East Clear Creek > Winslow- Hwy’s 87 & 99 Corridors > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Traverse out of an alcove and gain a left angling crack. Follow the crack through pumpy 5.11 to a crux that exits the crack straight up in sandy~ white rock to the top.

location: Davidson Wall > Paradise Forks > Sycamore Canyon > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Bach's Celebration is an awesome route that throws it all at you.  A heady start leads to some long stemming moves to a complete rest on a ledge; this is then followed by steep~ athletic climbing up face holds and parallel seams.  It's quite a bit safer than it's neighbor~ The Flake~ but somewhat harder.    Do the same dicey start (PG13) as for The Flake~ but at the stance where you get the good~ high #3 Camalot~ instead of traversing out right~ continue straight up via difficult stemming and small wires for pro.  This ends at the top of the obvious pillar with the tree growing on it.  Rest up here~ because after this things are full on.  Continuous~ physical climbing up the overhanging wall with good gear leads to the rim.  This last section is hard to suss on the fly~ and requires traversing back and forth between the best holds of two~ parallel crack systems.  Neither one seemed to be climbable alone~ but by moving between them~ and using the occasional face hold~ upwards progress~ and gear~ is possible.
protection: 00 TCU to #3 Camalot.  No brass~ but a bunch of stoppers in the #5-#7 BD range is helpful.

location: Pumphouse > 2 - Bear Canyon > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Overhanging almost 20 feet this is not your standard Mount Lemmon crimp fest. Stout move about fifteen feet up is avoided if you are taller but then it is on. Once you pull on to the arete you make a hard move to a rail and traverse right for 7 feet joining Neon Highway or at least using some of it's footholds as you follow a left angling weakness to the anchors.
protection: Bolts~ one cable draw to make it easier to clean the lower half. Anchors.

location: Thing Area > Southern Walls > Peaks Crag > San Francisco Peaks > Flagstaff Area > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: A very steep nose that climbs like a upside down potato. Great movement on Peaks dacite tufa pocket weirdness. Show stopper dynamic movement to a wild thread through jug at the peak of the feature. Stay right and clip bolts on a low angle slab arete.

location: Mentor Cave > Virgin River Gorge > The Arizona Strip > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Left leaning diagonal sequence that shares the same finish as Mentor past the large/final roof to the head wall.

location: The Tool Shed > Tanque Verde Canyon > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Starts off slag pile on right side of crag.  Shares bolt with Crying Game and then branches right.  Nice movement mostly.  Gets steadily harder as you go.    Seemed like 12+ until EWod discovered better beta.  So maybe 12c now.

location: Atlantis North Side > Atlantis > Queen Creek Canyon > Central Arizona > Arizona
desc: A route that features non-challenging moves for the most part- except the crux. It shares the start with Armed and Dangerous so consequently a stick-clip should be considered. The crux has some very bouldery moves far harder then it's origional rating of 12a (felt 12c)~ not made any easier by a critical pocket whose floor is gone making the hangerless bolt that protects it a moot point (we placed a temporary add-a-bolt sling to protect this section).
protection: 7 bolts (tho the crux bolt is hangerless)

location: Vatican > East Twin Butte > Twin Butte > Sedona > Sedona Area > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Pitch 1: (5.12a) Climb the diagonal crack/seam past 5 bolts. Pitch 2: (5.10) Follow an awkward corner Pitch 3: (5.12c) Continue up a flared tips splitter to a face then past 3 bolts

location: Mentor Cave > Virgin River Gorge > The Arizona Strip > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: This line climbs up the orange swath of rock just left of Brutus. Various pockets and chipped edges lie between powerful pulls. Some of the best crimp and edge climbing round out the headwall which shares the anchors of Brutus

location: The Tombstone > 6 - Mid-Mountain > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Cowboy Junkie is an engaging technical route that offers the Junkie more than just sequential crimping. Be prepared for long reaches~ side pull shuffling~ a once-removed undercling~ a few mini-blocks~ and a smattering of slopey rails.

location: Main Wall > Jacks Canyon > Winslow- Hwy’s 87 & 99 Corridors > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Big powerful roof moves on a reasonably obvious line then follow the standard Jacks transition to thin crux moves~ then eases up a couple number grades at the top.  The crux can be pulled by at least two methods~ one almost straight up on pockets~ the other just slightly right on a mostly invisible crimp/nub. Very likely easier than the posted grade of 12c/d but a decent amount of fun for 15 ft of hard climbing.
protection: Clips down low aren't as bad as book makes out.   7 bolts

location: Aegir > Reef of Rocks > 7 - Upper Highway > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: This killer line requires delicate footwork~ strong nerves~ commitment to impossible looking sequences~ and more endurance than you would think: A complex and classic route. This climb starts just left of Doubt on a ledge. Navigate vertical and sparsely bolted terrain for ~60ft and then use wizardry to float up a thin seam as the terrain steepens. You may want to clip off you sorcerers staff at a decent rest~ because its on all the way to the chains from here! Big whips possible and likely. Do not expect to clip up bolts on this one.    Note: a 70m rope just reaches the ground from the extension anchors. It is likely you could do just Crankbugs on a 60~ but I have not done it.

location: 5 - Bee Cave > The Dry Canyon > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Veganator goes right~ Stranglehoff goes left and the best part~ the Cream Filling~ is right in the middle.    Climb the first five shared bolts~ but rather than diverting to either side continue up the engaging and improbable overhang where there are just enough holds to make for viable climbing.    If you can dispatch the thuggy middle section and it's long pulls you will be rewarded with a rest prior to the daunting white slab that guards the chains.
protection: 11 bolts w/fixed draws to anchors with lower-offs.

location: The Baby Gap > 1 - The Gap > The Farmhouse > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: HARD boulder problem crux off the ground leads to super techy edging and pebble wrestling on glassy limestone with dispersed chert crimps. Feet intensive beta and some of the most unique features I've ever seen. Extremely fun climbing that I wish could've gone on a little longer. Enjoy!

location: The Disenchantment Wall > Boynton Canyon > Dry Creek Road Area > West Sedona > Sedona Area > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: The Line on the Wall~ climbs the obvious prow on the right edge.  P1 | 11 | Crank some thin patina off the ground moving right out a mini roof and into a out facing corner. When it dies continue up more patina and bolts to a HUGE PARTY LEDGE.  P2 | 12+ | Head straight up from the anchor clipping bolts and cranking patina towards shallow left facing corners. Esoteric movement in a great position leads to a couple gear placements and more wild climbing. Amazing 40m pitch! 1 Med nut~ .4~ .5~ .75  Variation Pitch 2 | 12- | An alternate pitch that keeps the route at a more manageable grade. More 15' left on the party ledge and follow bolts up sweet patina into a short crack~ exiting right up and engaging offset. Continue up past more bolts and a some gear that leads to an anchor. From this anchor traverse right and up to rejoin the route.  P3 | 11 | Climb up the short feature then follow a rad horizontal right and up to a Swiss Cheese crack pillar and a ledge with an anchor.  P4 | 10+ | Follow the crack systems up and left into a dihedral to a ledge just below the summit.  Descent Rap the route with a 70m route. Be sure to use the anchor atop the variation pitch.
protection: 70m Rope   12 Draws   3 Runners   Singles 00c3 - #3   Medium nut

location: Swim Fin > 4 - Windy Point West > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: This line lies just left of 96 Degrees in the Shade on the same pillar feature. Start up the juggy arete with your feet on the slab to reach the first bolt at 15 feet. After clipping~ cast off onto the face. Surf right to a decent knob and prepare for the crux between bolts two and three. Grab the Terre de Siene crimp and move through the thin thin with deadpoints and lockoffs~ staying on the line of crimps and avoiding moving right until a jug just above the third bolt is reached. Rest up and then bust back left through slightly easier~ though highly intricate~ moves past two more bolts to the break. From here~ blast up through hero jugs to 96 Degrees' original two bolt anchor.    This route is contrived~ as the much larger holds on 96 Degrees remain technically within reach through most of the climb. However~ the line flows naturally up a completely independent line of holds. Only one is shared between the two: the jug right of the third bolt (left of the fifth bolt on 96 Degrees~ I think). You will be on route if you remain left of the faint seam splitting the face for the duration.
protection: Five bolts to a two chain anchor.

location: Beaver Wall > 4 - Windy Point West > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: The Plate is likely the worst route on the Beaver Wall.  Pull off the ground on good edges past the first bolt~ reach up high and clip the second~ then get ready for pain.  Pull down on disgustingly sharp~ tiny crimps in the black rock heading left towards the plate feature.  Pull some cruxy moves establishing on the plate and moving the feet up then make a big move left to another serrated edge.  Move up to a bigger hold to clip the 4th bolt and move left then back right to the chains.  Be careful of the fall up here~ the holds are slopey and there is potential to pendulum into the corner.    This isn't the worst climb I've ever been on~ but with so many high quality climbs on the wall~ this one deserves to languish in obscurity.

location: Rough Rider Wall > The Homestead > Central Arizona > Arizona
desc: Sustained climbing~ hard to read sequences on great rock.

location: 7. West End Wall > South Side > Volunteer Canyon (The Cwm) > Sycamore Canyon > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Steep and pumpy~ with tricky gear! Harry spotted this line after he sent everything else at volunteer in his three week stint. This line starts off the Phantasm ledge and shares a body length or two at its crux; other than that it climbs completely new ground on the ever impressive West Wall. Start off the same ledge as Phantasm~ instead of climbing the mellow finger/hand crack~ step right to a large tooth feature and climb the steep direct broken crack system on large holds. The crux comes right before you join Phantasm and involves a thin tips layback to a steep thin hands pod. After you pull through the hand pod~ fire the finger crack crux of Phantasm. Follow up the stem box until you reach the first bolt. Instead of clipping it~ reach right around the corner and place a .2 or .3 with a runner. Step right onto a ledge below a thin tips corner. Follow this corner~ encountering a tricky section right before it ends. Finish on easy~ bubbly basalt.

location: The White Wall > Paradise Forks > Sycamore Canyon > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Part mythical/magical bouldering beast; Part White Wall tradtastics. The White Narwhal is the unicorn of The Forks~ and worth chasing. Be like H.M. and get "tormented by an itch for things remote."      Several sections of the climb are unprotected~ the top runout being the most serious. Caution riding a beast with a magical horn.
protection: Micro Cams   Slider Nuts   Micro Nuts   Couple of finger sized Cams.     Runners   Rope

location: 2. The Main Amphitheater > The Waterfall > Oak Creek Canyon > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Another of my 50/50 routes where half is trad and the other half sport. There will be Blood stands out as an illogically steep route for columnar basalt~ with the upper half delivering everything from boulder problem cruxes to jug haul surfing on very exposed terrain.  Start at head height roof and then enjoy good moderate climbing with decent gear along a large right facing dihedral. Clip a bolt with a long runner at 50' just below the roof~ then head left via jugs to a plank rest. It's bolts to the top from there.  Eye the line well and be prepared for some serious cranking through the initial little roofs. From there~ enjoy interesting slightly off balance moves through the vertical section. It should be painfully obvious when you have to turn it on again~ if you had the luxury of turning it down at all. Long moves lead you past amazing holds and a variety of feet. Keeps after you until you clip the anchors~ though there is plenty of air around.

location: The White Wall > Paradise Forks > Sycamore Canyon > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: The route has two very distinct sections separated by an ok stemming rest. Scramble up low 5 class to the base of a laser cut dihedral. Execute an intricate boulder problem followed by interesting movement passing small cams/ball nuts. Where the crack splits~ head left. The top section is much steeper (overhanging) and requires one to fight off the inevitable pump while still placing small gear. End on a nice ledge with bolted anchors.

location: The Godfather Area > Upper Middle Elden Canyon > Middle Elden Canyon > Mt. Elden Crags > Flagstaff Area > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: This is such a cool line it has to go! This route remains undone but it's open for business. Climb through beautifully sculpted rock to a ledge and the hanging arete above. From the ledge the climbing becomes harder~ and suddenly impossible feeling when the arete becomes useless and the slab remains blank....for 8 feet. The holds resume again as one moves left for an airy little 5.10 dance on the slabby arete. One good hold in the blank section and this climb would go at 11a/b ***~ but unfortunately it's probably v8 slab. Hop on it! A first ascent awaits the best slab climber around.  There are a couple redeeming qualities of the route and one is that you can sport aid past one bolt and still climb the airy arete above to the anchor at 5.10. Also~ the beginning portion of the route leads to a ledge where another little 5.10 called Hide and Seek can be accessed. It leads to the same anchor as the arete. Climb the first 3 bolts to the ledge~ move right about 20 feet and get on it! Once you're in the anchor you can work the impossible arete or climb a variety of short top rope variations on the featured face. A decent amount of climbing can be had from this one anchor~ and it's the best way to get back to ground/trail level. Rapping a tree is the other option to get off the ledge.

location: Fire Wall > Oak Creek Canyon > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Low first bolt can (and should) be clipped from the ground.  Hard compression moves through an overhanging scoop transition to thin balancey slab.  Wear a shirt so the juniper doesn't scratch your back!

location: The Beach > Upper Devils Canyon > Queen Creek Canyon > Central Arizona > Arizona
desc: Spice has awesome movement right off the deck! You pull a small roof section to establish on the overhung slab face and will be confronted with small divots~ mono pockets~ and a perplexing crux that requires precision and power. Once you get into the upper roof section you'll be rewarded with hero pumpy jug climbing~ but it can still ruin your ascent so be wary.

location: The White Wall > The Pit (aka Le Petit Verdon) > Flagstaff Area > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: A three bolt variation of Stone Free that tacks on a boulder problem start in lieu of the easy beginning dihedral of the original line. Stick clip the first bolt.
protection: 11 bolts to chain anchors with fixed carabiners.

location: Main Wall > Higher Solitude > Solitude Canyon > Mt. Elden Crags > Flagstaff Area > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Climb moderate terrain on meh rock to a boulder problem~ surmount it and climb into the hole above. Clip high and punch it to the anchor.
protection: 6 Bolts 2 Bolt anchor with ClimbTech mussy hooks provided by the ASCA.

location: 3. The Right Wall > The Waterfall > Oak Creek Canyon > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Three shallow aretes split by two seams run nearly the entire length of the right wall.  Begin right of parting gift~ climbing polished edges left of a shallow thin dihedral.  Move up and right along a sharp flake to a flare beneath a roof.  Pull the roof and enter the Trident.
protection: The Trident protects entirely with gear.     Bring small through large wires and offset brass. Offset aluminum nuts work well.   Loweballs: 1 red and 2 yellows   Cams:  doubles from 000 through #1 Camalot   Runners for gear near the bottom.

location: Tufa City > The Homestead > Central Arizona > Arizona
desc: Face moves to tufa to hard boulder move at the top.

location: 3. The Right Wall > The Waterfall > Oak Creek Canyon > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: If you wonder what it takes to climb this route...look up turn down for what on YouTube...  lil Jon.      Climb broken but steep rock that is much more solid than it looks up to a ledge.  Launch into the high quality climbing above~ stemming and liebacking twin seams in a flake up to a ledge.  Mantle the ledge~ plug some gear and turn it up for the technical and very fingery boulder problem.  From here continue up the pocketed stem box...plugging occasional microcams in horizontals.  It would be possible to traverse right onto sweet dreams or left onto the finishing ledge of Flavor of the Day.... doing so reduces the grade a bit and the quality significantly.
protection: Double set of cams from 000 to .75 camalot.  Key pieces at top are green and red c3's.  Top is exciting with spaced out but good gear.

location: 4. The Double Clutching Wall > The Waterfall > Oak Creek Canyon > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: This route has a long history~ Back in 1993 Eric Muedt and John Govi hand drilled the one bolt on the route. Many years later a rumor surfaced that this climb was called White Lie and rated 5.11+. A couple of years ago I was curious about the line so I got on it. Much to my surprise the route was way harder and had no anchors. Luckily we had hardware that day and a project was born.
