After a few seasons and several partners the route was sent at the end of February 2013. Definitely one of the hardest pitches at The Waterfall and super quality.

location: Orifice Wall > The Fortress > 8 - Summit Crags > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Split left before the crux of Eureka for three bolts of glory and a harder boulder problem. This was the original exit for Eureka until the key hold was found on the right exit.

location: Mentor Cave > Virgin River Gorge > The Arizona Strip > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: A Mentor Cave endurance route~ links the most difficult climbing on Bowser and Wowser. Start on Bowser~ continue traversing through the roof across the lip to join the pockets and huecos on Wowser.

location: The Gallery > 4 - Windy Point West > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: This is another gem in this tucked away little spot.  Initially I wasn't really drawn in by the line~ but after working out the moves I found it as fun and engaging and slightly harder than Pucker Up.  The only thing keeping me from giving 4 stars is the crumbly band of rock above the bottom four bolts.         This route will test your climbing technique~ power~ and endurance.  It even has some very non-Mt. Lemmon trickery thrown in.  See if you can find it!

location: Black Pyramid > Mammoth Lakes Area > Sierra Eastside > California
desc: The south ridge of Black Pyramid (aka Peak 11~477) is a spiky black spine offering a pretty fun 4th-class scramble. This is a convenient side-trip for those hiking the Mammoth Crest/Duck Pass loop~ and a necessary passage for those attempting the full Blue Crag traverse (i.e. from Crystal Crag to Deer Pass). It is also the descent used for the route Slayer on the north face.  Directions from the large meadow at Deer Lakes Pass: Gain the ridge by scrambling up to the first major saddle along the crest (see annotated photo). Then simply follow the spine to the summit!  One may encounter some 4th-class terrain if trying to stick to the true ridge. Most of these sections can be avoided by dropping a few meters down on the east side of the crest. The most exciting section is a highly exposed class-2 catwalk between the two highest points.
protection: You could bring a rope~ but it would probably get snagged repeatedly. Better to do this as a scramble.

location: Lawson Peak > South San Diego County > San Diego County > California
desc: Head up a chimney into a cave.  Large chockstones combined with features on the wall make for good holds.  At the back of the cave an opening lets you pop out onto the summit.  very cool for non-climbers~ but heady for them too.

location: Graveyard Peak > Southern Sierra > California
desc: Do you like solitude? Do you like moving ropeless over easy terrain? Then this is a route for you    Scramble up tedious scree from the last of the Graveyard Lakes. Aim for the left side of the skyline. The fun begins when you reach the summit crest. Follow a beautiful sidewalk in the sky for a few hundred feet of 3rd class to low 5th class scrambling on perfect golden granite. Its possible to stay on the ridge crest the entire time. If you want to reduce the difficulty or exposure~ just down climb a little bit.
protection: None needed - this is best done solo

location: Tehipite Dome > Sequoia & Kings Canyon NP > California
desc: Hike up on the left (east) side of the ridge until it steepens slightly and climb a short exposed slab to an easier slab on the crest.  Then hike easily to the top.
protection: Bring a 100' thin rope~ as it is exposed.

location: Mt. Johnson > 08 - Bishop Pass & Evolution > High Sierra > California
desc: This ridge has plenty of enjoyable scrambling with a lot of solid rock and some loose stuff as well~ though not bad. First section of the ridge drops in elevations and the second half takes you back up and to the summit of Mt Johnson.  From the summit of Trapezoid Peak hike down toward the ridge (see drawn in photo) on easy 2nd class terrain until it becomes a ridge. For maximum fun stay on the crest of the ridge as much as possible all the way the the summit of Mt Johnson. There will be the small deviation here and there but for the most part it is pretty easy going.  NOTE: I think that if you were to climb to the left (south) of the ridge most of the way and cut across to the southeast face of Mt Johnson at the end that it would be more like 3rd class - though I haven't done it that way myself. And you would miss out on all that fun scrambling/climbing!

location: Thunderbolt Peak > 09 - Palisades & Surrounding Peaks > High Sierra > California
desc: AKA Undertaker Couloir.    Class 4 minus the summit monolith (5.9). Route of peak's first ascent.    Approach via the Palisade Glacier. Cross the bergschrund (gets bigger as the season progresses). Climb the righthand couloir~ passing a chockstone on the right - continue up a chimney to the notch between North Palisade and Thunderbolt Peak. There are two ways from here; either traverse ledges on the south side then up a gully to the summit ridge. Or (better) climb directly up the ridge from the notch to the summit monolith.    Better when there's snow in the couloir - the couloir is horribly loose when free of snow.    Descend the route -- (rap and downclimb-- there are fixed pins along the right-side of the gully at each rap station).
protection: Solo class 4 - ice-axe and possibly crampons. Summit monolith (5.9) may require a length of rope.

location: Unicorn Peak > Cathedral Range > Tuolumne Meadows > Yosemite National Park > California
desc: Dramatic peak visible from many places in the Tuolumne area. Nice summit view. Interesting climbing to reach the highest N summit~ but pretty short compared to the approach (shortest from the East side).     Difficulty of the N summit traditionally rated class 4~ but one obvious way of doing it has a slightly overhanging (or at least fully vertical) move with exposure to a deadly fall - seems more like class 5.   . (If you're more of a scrambler than a serious rock-climber ... unless you're partnered with someone with a rope who knows how to use it for protection ... better to plan toward getting only the Middle summit~ perhaps along with the higher mountain less than half a mile south along the same ridge as the Unicorn.)   approach: Trailhead is at Tuolumne Meadows campground (along S side of highway 120 about 8 miles W from the Yosemite N.P. east entrance at Tioga Pass) near group camp~ the B loop. Bear-proof boxes for day-hiker food storage.    Take the Elizabeth Lake trail South about 2.3 miles / 3.7 km (with vertical gain 900 ft / 270 meters) to near Elizabeth Lake. Hike / scramble up the East (or NE) slope of the Unicorn to the notch between the middle summit and the north summit (vertical gain approx +1300 ft / 400 meters).   climb: The highest North summit is close to the notch~ so it's tempting to want to "go for it"~ but it's not so easy. One way to get there is to cross over to the W side of the notch~ then make an exposed short traverse N. Next up to the crest of the ridge~ perhaps a little to its other side~ then perhaps a delicate move up~ and on to the summit. Before committing to any move~ keep in mind you'll have to do it again on the way back.    Middle summit is easier climbing and less exposed.   descent: Return the same way.   Some people like to also climb the (higher) hump about 0.3 miles / 500 meters to the South along the broad ridge - which is fun if you like scrambling on big granite talus.   Or to play with additional exposed climbing moves~ can find some in traversing the other Unicorn summits and narrow S ridge.   statistics: Total horizontal distance about 2.9 miles / 4.7 km.   Total vertical gain about +2200 ft / 670 meters.
protection: No fixed gear in place. It's a long ways to haul a rope and Trad rack for such a short amount of climbing. Most people solo it (or climb one of the other easier summits).

location: alpine / multi-pitch > Crystal Crag > Mammoth Lakes Area > Sierra Eastside > California
desc: Great summmit of a dramatic-looking peak surrounded by pretty lakes. Short easy approach.   Approach: See Crystal Crag alpine / multi-pitch area   for how to get to Crystal Lake. Then a short ways starting around East side of Crystal Lake~ then turn Left (E) onto an unofficial climber's track. Up on that a ways~ then bear Right roughly SE or S (perhaps with a track) and aim for the base of the cliff somewhere below the notch between the Middle summit and South summit.   (Or continue S along the base of the cliffs to a very large multi-trunk tree roughly below the South summit).   Climb: Find your way as best you can up to the notch between the Middle and South summits. Significant loose rock and dirt. Mostly class 3~ but likely some section will feel like class 4~ especially when getting back down.    Then Left and a little more climbing up to the Middle summit (on descent this likely will feel like class 4).   Optionally continue farther N along the ridge~ over the (lower) North summit (but returning from this requires a low class 5 move)~ and down a little to the unique bright-white crystal mini-tower.    Or from the notch go Right (S) along the crest of the ridge to the (highest) South summit (coming back down this will likely will feel like low class 5).   Alternate: From somewhere roughly below the (higher) South summit~ find your way up to the crest of the ridge (likely easiest to hit it a few meters North of the highest summit). Longer and more difficult and more interesting climbing than the above route further north -- perhaps with less dirt~ but still enough loose rock. Possibly it could all be climbed up at difficulty class 3~ but getting back some of the down-climb moves will feel like class 4.   . (Likely there are other routes) .   Descent: Back down the same way.   Do not attempt to descend the W face from between the North summit and Middle summit.   Statistics:    Totals for approach hike + climb to summit:   on Trail hiking distance 1.75 Miles / 2.8 km with vertical gain +675 ft / 210 meters. Off trail hiking distance 0.25Mi/0.4km with vertical gain +160ft/50m. Climbing length 600ft/180m with vertical gain +400ft/120m.   Grand Totals for approach + climb + descent + return hike:    on Trail hiking distance 3.5Mi/5.5km with vertical gain +800ft/250m Off trail hiking distance 0.5Mi/0.8km with vertical gain +160ft/50m Climbing + traversing + Down-climbing length 1200ft/360m Climbing + traversing vertical gain +400ft/120m Down-climbing + traversing vertical loss -400ft/120m Total horizontal distance = 4.25 miles / 7 km Total vertical gain = +1375ft/420m

location: Matterhorn Peak > 02 - The Sawtooth Ridge > High Sierra > California
desc: A beautiful ridge route that is worthy of the long walk to get there. People often start up the West Ridge but at the top of the so called 'dome'~ they veer right and follow the sandy chute to the south ridge just below the summit. The better alternative is to stay with a direct ascent of the West Ridge all the way to the summit. As with any 3/4 class route~ you can make your own adventure. I found some really wonderful situations on this ridge. The rock was solid throughout. About half way up you are sort of committed to staying with the ridge. At that point it begins to narrow and the exposure increases a bit. The elevation gain from the pass to the summit is about 1640 feet.  A full description of the trip is available at http://esa-rol.com/content/gallery/71/matterhorn-west-ridge
protection: There is no need for any kind of gear on this route. Even rock shoes are optional. I wore Salewa Rapace

location: West Face > Tuolumne Peak > May Lake Area > Tuolumne Meadows > Yosemite National Park > California
desc: From the true summit~ just walk west to the beginning of this exposed third and fourth class ridge. It's short~ but the rock is solid~ the exposure grand~ and the views are spectacular.     After a fourth class move or two to get on the ridge~ the ridge can be followed almost all the way to the west "summit" like a sidewalk in the sky. Alternately~ you can drop to one side or another if you'd prefer an opportunity to use some hands.

location: Wooly Spider Boulder > Stirrup Tank > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: Start off a boulder right of Arachnids and below the left of two parallel cracks which split the formation from above.     Climb easy face up and left~ going where the holds are larger and more secure~ to meet a horizontal crack (3" cam here) which is followed right as it turns into a off-vertical hand crack. Belay/rap from coldshuts between the two cracks.     Fun climbing on good rock with a nice mix of face and crack climbing make this a fun outing for beginners. One star out of five.

location: Tanglewood Slab > Tanglewood Slabs Area > Big Bear North > Big Bear Lake Area > San Bernardino Mountains > California
desc: Start in the small gully on the right side of the slab.  Either climb the face on the left to the left-leaning finger crack or stay in the gully for a couple moves and step left onto the face.  Clip the bolt once on the face~ or make a move or two and plug some small gear in the crack.  Follow the finger crack up and left to the top.
protection: Gear to 1". Two-bolt anchor at the top.

location: Iron Hand Rock > Indian Cove Campground > Indian Cove > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: Ah~ the Brown Cave ... what can you say about the Brown Cave?  It's easy to find -- even though it's a couple hundred yards up the hillside~ it's easy to spot from the road.  Beware~ though:  the cave is MUCH bigger and MUCH further away than it looks from the road.  Chimney up the back of the cave past a large chockstone and continue up a wide crack to the summit.  Taller folks will have a definite advantage in the initial chimney    The climb is pretty damn near unprotectable which~ coupled with the extremely crumbly rock~ can make this a slightly nervous experience.  Still~ it's an entertaining little adventure in a nice setting.    Descent is pretty straight forward -- keep heading back and the hillside will pretty much come up to meet you.  Then it's a long boulder hop back to the road.
protection: Not much.  You'll probably free solo it~ but I guess a short rope and a few small to medium pieces could be used if you wanted to.

location: Poker Face > Big Hunk > Echo Rock Area > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: Start just right of The Turn at an obvious crack/corner. This crack/corner is just left of the first bolted route~ Busted & Broke. Climb the easy crack/corner to the top.
protection: Carry a typical JT rack. Use the Busted & Broke anchor to descend.

location: Fat Freddie's Cat > East Wonderland Valley > Wonderland Valley > Wonderland South > Wonderland of Rocks > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: Traverse left on the obvious ledge~ and follow the dishes and bulges up the path of least resistance. Beautiful views of the Disney Land Dome. The route is just to the left of the large block on top with the tree growing next to it.
protection: No gear no bolts just trust the rubber and go for it! Added 1-19-09 The anchor at the top is a bit funky to setup~ I went deep into the "chimney" at the top and got in some good pieces but had to string a 50 foot line to get out... Be careful it is loose up there don't knock anything down on your belayer.

location: Lunch Rock > Mission Gorge > South San Diego County > San Diego County > California
desc: The route starts up and to the right of The Ramp. Follow the crack up to the bolted anchors. There's one bolt right below the anchors.

location: West Face > Herring Creek Dome > Sonora Pass Highway (108) > California
desc: A rare combination of very easy climbing and very fun movement.  Would be better if it was less dirty.  Follow the huge right facing crack/corner to its end~ then head up slab until you reach the slanting crack / alcove where you can set a belay.  Guidebook describes this as a good beginner lead - maybe it was at the time~ but I would not recommend it to new leaders in its current (May 2018) state.  When I climbed this the crack was full of moss and after the crack ends the next half of the pitch is (very easy) unprotected slab.  Finally the belay crack was thin and a bit mossy~ and the walk off is pretty exposed.  Good climb~ but not a good beginner lead in my opinion due to above factors.

location: Swidgeteria, The > Roadside Rocks > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: This easy ramp offers a quick way to the top of the rock.

route: Through the Hole and Up The Wall
location: Star Wars Rock > Virgin Islands Area > Geology Tour Road > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: Another Vaino Kodas concoction~ although I believe Mike Beck came up with the name.  It is not so much a climbing route as a spelunking adventure that emerges on the summit of the large boulder containing Between A Rock And A Hard Place.  From near the base of Light Sabre~ crawl into a hole in the backside of the boulder.  Go left 25'~ then head up a crack in a corner to pop out on top the boulder.  This is a nice vantage point for heckling your buddies on Light Sabre or Apollo.  Reverse the route to descend.
protection: To my knowledge~ all ascents to date have been free-solo (up and down).

location: Tower of Babel > Texas Canyon > Angeles National Forest > Los Angeles Basin > California
desc: On the right (east) side of the corridor is a low angle slab. Pull inclusions to a line of pockets. Trenchtown Slab - Center is 40 ft south of Bald Headed Men.
protection: 5 bolts to anchors with screw links.

location: Hogwild > Hogsback > Lover's Leap > Highway 50 Corridor > Lake Tahoe > California
desc: This is a good beginner's slab route on the same pillar as Innie. The name is unofficial (Triplet) and comes from a horizontal string of three vugs that look like belly buttons below the first bolt. Climb up and over a fun~ easy roof. There are some interesting moves after bolt 3. I used features and the left edge after the last bolt to keep it interesting and fun. The short crack/seam near the top takes a nice red alien placement. Name change on 9-22-18 based on info in comments section.
protection: 4 bolts and optional red alien or other 1" cam.

location: The Diamond > Diamond Clump > Virgin Islands Area > Geology Tour Road > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: Fun climb with an exposed~worthy summit.

location: First and Second Terrace > The Belly Button aka Vulcans Eye aka The Plug > Lassen National Park > Northeast California > California
desc: This ascends the wall above and to the right of the Second Terrace. Traverse around and right on the 3rd class ledge~ past 'Pinacoidal Cleavage'.   Rap 'Sweet Crack Center' to get back to the Second Terrace. To descend from the Second Terrace~ move down to the top of 'Clast von Bulow'.   This one star route ascends the first crack system in the shallow corner you get to on the traverse. Climb up and trend right to the large ledge.

location: The Citadel > West Side > Pinnacles National Park > Central Coast > California
desc: UPDATED ON 09-25-17: This route is a great introduction to multipitch climbing. The rock is surprisingly solid and the climb is very well protected for a 4-pitch 5.4 (original rating) sport climb. Be careful not to dislodge small rocks on the ledges~ which could bounce down the route. Some bolts are very closely spaced (especially pitch 3). There are several runouts on very easy terrain (5.0 or easier).    Pitch 1: 5.4 (crux at start)~ 120'~ 7 bolts. After clipping the first bolt~ aim up and left to the arete to find the second bolt; it's runout but very easy~ like 5.0~ and you can sling knobs if you feel uncomfortable. Attach a long runner to bolt 2 or you'll feel rope drag higher up. Afterward the bolts are closely spaced. Belay at bolts at the edge of a huge ledge.    Pitch 2: 5.3~ 95' (or 80')~ 6 bolts. If you wish~ you can shift the belay to another set of bolts 15' from the edge of the ledge~ at the base of pitch 2. Follow four closely spaced bolts up a groove and then traverse up and left past two more bolts~ across the arete~ to a bolted anchor with a small belay stance on the face.    Pitch 3: 5.3~ 85'~ 3 bolts. Climb up and then left toward the first bolt~ which is a few feet to the left of a big hole~ then up past two more bolts to a bolted anchor on a large ledge.    Pitch 4: 5.2~ 90'~ 4 bolts. Climb up past a bolt and then surprisingly far to the left to bolt 2~ then up past two more bolts to a bolted anchor on a large ledge just below the summit. From the anchor~ scramble 10' up a class 4 bulge to the summit; to be safe you can tie off about 20' of rope to the anchor.    The quickest and safest descent is rappelling the route~ but if climbers are beneath you be very careful throwing down the rope and try not to knock small rocks off the ledges. A 70 m rope will get you down in four rappels. A 60 m rope will leave you stranded 15' above the ground at the first bolt of pitch 1~ which should have a quick link on it for a fifth rappel. Two ropes will get you down in three rappels (pitch 4~ pitches 2-3~ and pitch 1).
protection: Quick draws for up to seven bolts per pitch. There are rap rings at each belay anchor.

location: Cleavage Rock > Indian Joe Caves > San Francisco Bay Area > California
desc: Located on the Leftmost side of the North Face of Cleavage Rock. Access Route for most other climbs on Cleavage rock. As stated in Supertopo guide: "Easiest way up and down the North side of the rock".
protection: Lots of options in the crack system at the bottom of this route~ two separate sets of bolts at the top~ for the variety of TR options around Cleavage Rock.

location: Crow's Nest > Towers of Uncertainty > Geology Tour Road > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: This is the third crack from left. Guidebook incorrectly states "second from left" when I believe it should be second from right.

location: North Dakota Dome > The Dakota Domes > Comic Book Area > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: Start on the west side of the formation in a small recess. Climb the left (south) side of the recess to a bush. Step right and go up cracks to the top.

location: Morbid Mound > Indian Cove Campground > Indian Cove > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: Start as for Brimstone Stairway (5.1 R). About half way up~ traverse right along small ledge and continue to top.
protection: Some long webbing and a few pieces if toproping.

location: Castle Rock - North Side > Castle Rock > Belle Campground > Belle Campground Area > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: This route ascends the lower angle section of the Northwest Face~ just visible from the picnic table there. This is right of Count Dracula and just right of Diagnostics.  The climb goes up a few face moves to reach a juggy wide crack (hands to OW) that appears to protect well with hexes or large cams. The crack stops before the climb tops out~ leaving the leader with a little space between them and their last piece to finish on the top of the big flake.  Belay on gear at the big flake before climbing up and to the right~ then down the standard downclimb.I do not feel that this is that great of a climb for ultra-beginners.  Despite the easy grade~ the anchor situation is not straight forward~ being in a lateral crack above the flake~ running side-to-side and opening up downward... A down-climb is the standard descent which may be mellow for most~ but not a 5.4 climber.
protection: Take the large end of a standard rack~ including hexes and cams.  Medium sizes pieces could assist with the building of the belay up top.

location: Kern Canyon Dome > Lower Kern River Canyon > The Needles / Kern River > Southern Sierra > California
desc: A very easy dihedral that slants to the right. Half way up it is easy face climbing to the top. Hike down to the right. I heard from a climbing bud that "We climbed this free solo for fun. It could be useful for a person new to trad climbing."
protection: Rack of nuts and cams. 3 belay bolts on top.

location: Dilbert Dome > Comic Book Area > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: This route climbs three bolts with some optional gear placements.

location: Beetle Buttress > Lost Horse Area > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: This is a very high quality chimney

location: Lower Lunchbox Area > Hospital Rock Area > Sequoia & Kings Canyon NP > California
desc: One of the best low-5th lines in the area. Follow a series of huge flaring cracks that move left and then back to the right after veering onto Holus Bolus~ then straight up to the boulder belay.
protection: Top Rope: Hike the descent trail to the top. Long webbing for the boulder at the top~ and always equalize with gear and super long webbing to backup on some trees.    Lead: Set of nuts~ set of cams~ slings~ webbing. Very protectable.

location: The Blob - North Face > The Blob > Hidden Valley Campground > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: Approach: Probably several. The easiest I've found is to locate Hobbit Roof at the base of the backside (west face) of The Blob. From here~ scramble up gully to the right to the base of the route.  At 5.4~ The Bong is a fantastic first trad lead and as well as an excellent free-solo. It offers excellent jams and is easy to protect. The crux is a small "roof". Beyond the crux~ the angle lessens and it's straight-in jamming to the top. Once on top~ a large boulder sits directly in-line with the route and offers a quick and easy anchor using a section of the rope or a long piece of webbing.  To descend~ walk to climber's left and downclimb low 5th class terrain with big face holds. This will deposit you about 50' left of the base of the route. Some sideways chimneying will bring you back to your packs. (Note: it might be better to lower off first-timers from the top of the route).

location: Cirque of the Climbables - Right Side > Cirque of the Climbables > Queen Mountain > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: Climb the face up the center of the formation which is steep for a section before kicking back towards the top. The climbing is on heavily featured solid rock with occasional protection. Fun climbing and easier than first appearances might suggest. One star out of five.

location: Mislaid Rock > Lost Rocks > Ryan Campground > Sheep Pass Area > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: This is the center or corner line up the large open book.  It starts at the 5.6 finger crack in the center and heads up the hand to OW crack in the spine of the Book.  Great climb to do in the evening on quality rock!
protection: Pro to 4" + #3 for belay along with med stoppers.

location: Cyclops Rock > Hidden Valley Campground > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: A great beginner route with excellent exposure.  Rated 5.1 in Vogel's guidebook~ this route in my opinion warrants a slightly stiffer rating.  Begin in alcove up low-angle crack.  Continue onto steep face with great holds for a full rope length (approx. 150') to the top.  Gear belay.    Also makes for a nice free solo at the end of the day.    Descent: walk east down the backside and back around (north) to your pack.

location: Camp Wall > Group Campsite  8 > Group Campsites Road > Indian Cove > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: The Far Side starts from a large block (comfortable for belaying on) to about 15' of face climbing to a couple of diagonal ledges on which you traverse up and right. It's mostly footwork until the upper~ more vertical crack far to the right allows good hand use.Our church group of mixed ages found this an appropriate beginner's challenge~ and enjoyed the fun~ unobstructed rappel on this huge slab.
protection: Lead: small nuts/sm.cams/tricamsToprope: med. hexes/med cams/tricams/cordelette and 4' ext'n over semi sharp lip

location: Southeast Base > Base Routes > El Capitan > Valley North Side > Yosemite Valley > Yosemite National Park > California
desc: This is a good route to take beginners and first-time climbers on. It has a nice flat summit to hang out on~ with great views~ and the route doesn't require any crack climbing technique. This is NOT a good route for first-time leaders because the opportunities for protection are sparse.    There are bolted anchors at the top of the pitch. You probably want a 70m rope to get down.

location: Reed's Pinnacle > p. Reed's Pinnacle Area > Lower Merced River Canyon > Yosemite Valley > Yosemite National Park > California
desc: The regular route up the Iota is a fun chimney climb. This combined with The Deer Route and The Remnant-Right Side makes for a great circuit of spelunking adventures. The start is approached by scrambling up and around the left side of the Iota. Here you will enter into a great chimney which divides the Iota from the main wall. Crossroads is a bolted 5.13 face which can be found in this chimney.    Start with a boulder problem and mantel to get into a tunnel which leads out onto the face and the top of Chingando (this is also how you can access a TR setup for Chingando). Climb straight up the obvious chimney to the top. There's not any pro.    To get down~ either rappel from slings~ or walk to the back left side of the Iota and make a short steep downclimb (there should be a fixed rope with knots tied in it that you can "batman" down).    Trip Report with photoshttp://www.supertopo.com/tr/The-Iota-Chimney-A-Super-Awesome-Must-Do-5-4-in-Yosemite/t11362n.html

location: Tiger Cage, Upper Tier > Courtright Reservoir > Southern Sierra > California
desc: Easy wide crack climbing up to a 2 bolt anchor.  (has rap ring and chains)  This would be a great first trad lead~ as every stance is solid~ and it takes a wide range of gear.  Falls not imminent.  If the first ascensionist has more information (and the correct name)~ please share.
protection: Cams of increasing size up to a 2 bolt anchor.  Anchor has a rap ring & chain.

location: Ken Black Memorial Dome > Lost Horse Area > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: a so-so hand crack.   This route gets little or no morning sun.

location: Summit or Plummet Rock > Roadside Rocks > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: Start about ten feet right of Gipfel at a vertical crack in a small corridor made up of two large boulders.     Climb the crack to a niche~ then go up and right along a flake and varnished patches to the top.    Route gets afternoon sun.
protection: Carry a standard JT rack. Scramble off.

location: North Buttress > Cathedral Peak > Cathedral Range > Tuolumne Meadows > Yosemite National Park > California
desc: Garden Party is on a small buttress containing a number of discontinuous~ parallel vertical cracks~ 400 feet right of the toe of the Buttress.    Climb the face~ the cracks~ or a combination of both.     This is a great route for practicing pro placement. Start on the finger crack on the left side~ then step over to the hand crack on the right side. Above the tree~ the crack widens from hand to fist to off width. The angle of the rock is low and it is very easy to place good pro almost anywhere on the route.    Clever pro placement to the right of the small tree half-way up avoids dragging the rope through the tree (which is covered with sap).    Several fun top-­ropes are possible from the anchors.  This is a very full 60-meter pitch.     Descend: Two 60 meter ropes required to rappel from a 2-bolt anchor with rappel rings.
protection: Cams: 1 each .3 - 3"~ optional 4". Nuts: 1 set. Bring two sets of cams if learning to place pro.

location: Opposite Main Wall > Burney Limestone (aka The Shredding) > Northeast California > California
desc: the obvious slab in front of you when descending down the gully with main wall to your R.

location: Easy Street > Echo Cliffs > Santa Monica Mountains > Los Angeles Basin > California
desc: Golden Slumbers (5.5) begins at the toe of the broad buttress~ ten feet left of "Golden Years."   Climb the apron until it steepens into a blocky~ cobbled buttress. Ascend the buttress passing    5 bolts to share the anchor with "Golden Years."
protection: 5 bolts to a shared 2-ring anchor with "Golden Years."

location: Upper Tier > South Face > Trapper Dome > Courtright Reservoir > Southern Sierra > California
desc: Face climb followed by pockets and a large crack. Can be don using only the bolts but the top section (easy) is run out.
protection: Bolts~ cam for the upper section

location: Middle Tooth > Dogtooth Peak > Courtright Reservoir > Southern Sierra > California
desc: This route takes the far lefthand skyline of the middle tower. Look up and you should see an obvious hand crack several pitches up~ aim for this! The route would be an easy solo or take a light rack and go for it.  Climb up easy slabs for about 1-2 pitches. Rope up when you start to get uncomfortable.  Pitch 1-2: low 5th - 60 meter pitches up exfoliating slabs lead to a big ledge. Pitch 3 - A fun 50 meter hand crack (crux) belay at boulder. 5.5 P4 - Easy 5th up to the right P5 - 4th class/Easy 5th leads to the top of the middle Down climb from the summit of the middle tooth to the sandy bench and climb up the 4th class bit to reach the summit of Dogtooth Peak proper.

location: South Flank > Daff Dome > Daff Area > Tuolumne Meadows > Yosemite National Park > California
desc: The rightmost and easiest of the Guide Cracks.  Fun easy and well protected crack/pod climbing.  A great  introduction to trad leading and crack climbing.
protection: Standard Rack. Bolted anchor with chains.  Shares anchor with 5.7 guide crack to the left.

location: Reggie Dome > North Wonderland Approach > Wonderland North > Wonderland of Rocks > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: The hairline crack between Speed Bump and Fender Bender (gained from the start of Fender Bender) and the cracks above.

location: Wall 1 > Panic Town > Santa Barbara > Central Coast > California
desc: Start at That Bastard Girard~ but move right traversing the dishes to gain the next crack. Follow the diagonal crack up~ crossing Dancing and finish the crack to the right of the rap station.    The path that is "The Bar Is Open"

location: Reggie Dome > North Wonderland Approach > Wonderland North > Wonderland of Rocks > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: This route starts up the gully several feet right of Ninny's Revenge. The crack runs to the right of another route (Pops Goes Hawaiian) with a single-bolt on the left face of the gully. The Chief is a fun route with good placements for pro and comfy stances for feet.    It is possible to rap from the top of Tender Flakes of Wrath (127 in Vogel's guide) or the route that runs up the center face~ about straight up from the pine tree next to the northwest face.
protection: Hexes or large cams for natural anchor would be handy.

location: Ruby Peak > 06 - Little Lakes Valley & Mono Recesses > High Sierra > California
desc: Traverse the gendarmes along the crest between Mt. Mills and Ruby Peak starting from the east and moving west.

location: Cerro Torre Tower > Comic Book Area > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: Start in a short~ hidden corridor on the SE face of the tower. Chimney to the top of the corridor then step left to a ledge (possible bivy here). Climb the grainy slab/arête to reach the summit ice field and the top.

location: Puppy Dome > Tuolumne Meadows > Yosemite National Park > California
desc: This route is on the far left side of the upper tier of climbs.  It is just to the right of the gully.  Start by climbing an easy face beyond a series of horizontal cracks to a large flake not obvious from the ground.  Traverse right a few feet to a off width left slanting crack.  When the crack runs out~ move right across the face on small foot holds until you reach the final dihedral for the final 15 feet to the top.  There is one big tree about 10 feet back that can be used as an anchor.  It's probably best to not use the small tree near the edge.
protection: Black Diamond 0.3 to 2.  The climb is generally well protected.  There are no bolts present or needed.  Use  the 6 inch diameter tree 10 feet back from the top for an anchor.  Either walk off directly over the back or use the bolts 50 feet climbers right to descend.

location: The Oven Mitt > Barker Dam Area > Joshua Tree National Park > California
desc: Climb a crack in a shallow right-facing corner~ making use of the left side of the "oven mitt" block when possible~ then continue past a recessed area to finish up a slot with a wedged boulder. Gear belay and walk off.

location: Altar of Algoot > The Others > Tahquitz & Suicide Rocks > California
desc: none listed
protection: Pro to 4" most anchors are off of bomber trees.

location: Whiskey Cliff / Eagle Creek Cliff > Eagle Creek Canyon > West Shore > Lake Tahoe > California
desc: On  the far right end of Eagle Creek Cliff and up around the corner is an obvious~ clean (as I remember)~ chimney. This is The Poop Chute~ and every area needs~ or has a Poop Chute. I think The music of Frank Zappa had something to do with this.

location: Main Wall > The Pie Shop > South Shore > Lake Tahoe > California
desc: Climb the left side of the prominent large roof of Sugar Daddy

location: Royal Wall > Temple Rock > Sphinx Rock Area (aka The Cliff Hanger) > Lake Arrowhead Area > San Bernardino Mountains > California
desc: Climb left corner dihedral~ to twin chains at top.

location: Confederate Cracks > Horseshoe Canyon Ranch > Arkansas
desc: Book has it as an 11a~ but felt a bit harder to me. Very sustained route~ crux was either mid-route or going for the anchors. Lots of fun.

location: Cool Breeze Area > Cave Creek > Sam's Throne & Surroundings > Arkansas
desc: The route starts in a thin crack system with a high first bolt. Move left out of the crack and through a series of bulges to the anchors.

location: The North Forty > Horseshoe Canyon Ranch > Arkansas
desc: Stick Clip the first perma draw on Corn Grinder free and boink up. Awesome moves on good rock through a dihedral makes for the crux. Typical North Forty top sections that is lower angle and full of chicken heads.
protection: All perma draws and perma draw anchors.

location: Wood Wall > Rock Creek > Cowell/Deer Area > Arkansas
desc: Great moderate at the creek!    Stickclip the first bolt and do a small but easy boulder problem to a good ledge. From here fire up small sequences that end on good ledges until you reach the base of a small roof.    Find the good holds and pull over the roof to a glory jug finish.    Awesome moves on this route.

location: Breakfast Wall > Mt. Magazine Proper > Mount Magazine State Park > Arkansas
desc: Climb easy terrain to a ledge met by the first bolt. From here~ layback and stem your way to the second bolt and transition onto the face to crank out some thin face climbing and a difficult 3rd clip. Cool holds and features will lead you to a showstopper crux at the last bolt~ just before the anchors. Named for the Snake Farms newest member (Baby Wall)!

location: Roman Wall > Horseshoe Canyon Ranch > Arkansas
desc: Tough~ awkward~ tic-tac crimpy start leads to easier face climbing.

location: New Roman Wall > Horseshoe Canyon Ranch > Arkansas
desc: Climb the orange rock to the ledge. Climb the difficult start on crimps to more enjoyable face climbing above.

location: Crackhouse Alley > Horseshoe Canyon Ranch > Arkansas
desc: Tricky face climbing leads to a fun crux pulling the roof.
protection: 4 permas~ 3 bolts and two sport anchors.

location: Strawberry shortcake wall > Jamestown Crag > Arkansas
desc: One of the best at Jamestown. Starts with vertical/technical climbing with a reachy crux move right off of the ground. The route continues with a couple more pumpy moves to a rest below the roof. The roof itself is pumpfest on jugs. Pull the lip onto the face and you are at the anchors. Don't grab the root.

location: Factual Boulder > Fern > Fayetteville Region > Arkansas
desc: It might be most accurate to describe this as a V3 boulder problem~ followed by 5.10 sport climbing. The crux is before the first bolt. Stick clip it~ or boulder it out. The landing is pretty flat and clean. Get a spot from your belayer. Quality rock.

location: Strawberry shortcake wall > Jamestown Crag > Arkansas
desc: Unique roof for the area with quality movement. Easy face to a dramatic roof and a bomber 3-finger pocket just before gaining the ledge.    If any 200 pound crushers get on this~ a hold or two might change shape. Watch out~ belayers.
protection: Four or five bolts on the face~ three hanging draws on the roof.    The second roof bolt is a spinner. Should still be solid~ though it may shortly be replaced with a glue-in.    You may notice two oddly place bolts (to the left of first roof bolt and to the right of the prow under the anchors). These were placed by the landowners before knowing how the line would climb.

location: Brick Attack Area > Cave Creek > Sam's Throne & Surroundings > Arkansas
desc: Climbs steep jugs and slopers. One of the best lines in Arkansas.

location: Valley of The Blind > Sam's Throne & Surroundings > Arkansas
desc: Thin and technical nearly vertical slab climb. Climbs past 4 bolts. Sustained climbing for a short pitch but lets up after the last bolt.

location: Gravity Slab/Meltdown Wall > Cave Creek > Sam's Throne & Surroundings > Arkansas
desc: A bouldery start (crux) leads to jugs and big slopers trending left. Be careful heading toward the second bolt-a ground fall is a definite possibility especially at the clip.

location: Goat Cave > Horseshoe Canyon Ranch > Arkansas
desc: Power over the hanging start to a horizontal crack under the first roof. Traverse left a move or two~ load up and make a long crux move to the base of the second roof. Reach out to jugs~ pull the lip~ and climb much easier ground to the top.
protection: 4 bolts with 3 of them fixed. Ends with a two bolt anchor

location: Valley of The Blind > Sam's Throne & Surroundings > Arkansas
desc: Challenging moves in a shallow dihedral lead to a no hands rest below the roof. Powerful and sequential movement through the roof crack finishes on glory jugs at the lip.

location: Candy Mountain > Sam's Throne & Surroundings > Arkansas
desc: Climb a short and easy slab to gain a ledge to clip the first bolt. Head up the long face to some interesting moves to gain a ledge beneath a roof. Traverse right under the roof and climb the headwall where you will meet up with the crux on some crimps.
protection: 9 bolts to anchor. A couple of the bolts have fixed draws.

location: Invasion Wall > Cowell/Deer Area > Arkansas
desc: Paradise for the horizontally inclined climber. Begin on the common start and keep traversing all the way left~ you will need 4 quickdraws after the permadraws run out. Finish at the anchors of supercollider.    Plan to either have a 2nd clean the draws or down climb and clean back to the final permadraw.

location: Candy Mountain > Sam's Throne & Surroundings > Arkansas
desc: Starts with a sandy overhang to pull a short roof to the left of the first bolt.  Then tackle the slab for about 3 more bolts before heading up a steep section of fragile honeycomb.  After the honeycomb~ the route is vertical and only hold before the ledge and the first set of anchors is a 4" round pocket.  Skip the anchors with mussy hooks and clip the bolt from the ledge~ then traverse left under the roof to one more bolt before climbing up to the chains with carabiners.  The plaque at the bottom of the route says "Hive Mind" and suggests the grades of both 11a and 12a.  I'm assuming the 11a is for the first set of anchors and 12a is for the second set of anchors.
protection: 12 quickdraws required to reach the second set of chains. 10 quickdraws required to the first set of chains.

location: The Sex Boulder > Cowell/Deer Area > Arkansas
desc: This link up climbs the best sections of two neighboring routes. Climb through the low crux of "A Fool and his Honey'. After clipping the third bolt (2nd chain draw)~ traverse left on good holds to a long chain draw. From here head straight up through great rock~ making powerful moves on good holds. The crux of the route is just before the chains~ so save some juice for the finish.
protection: 6 bolts (fixed gear after the first bolt)

location: Pirate's Cove > Steel Creek - Upper Buffalo River > Buffalo River Region > Arkansas
desc: P1~ ~90'. Climb the white flake to the top then venture up and left into the dark and sometimes dirty face. The anchors are on a ledge below a huge dihedral. P2~ ~50'. Climb the massive dihedral with bomber gear and a few bolts.
protection: Bolts and a handful of cams for p2. Fixed anchors.

location: Dardanelle Rock > Arkansas
desc: The Aid Route had no attention for years~ We decided to free climb the beast. Hard 5.11 climbing to weird off Angle sloper dyno.

location: Space Wall > Area 51 > Bigfoot Hollow > Fayetteville Region > Arkansas
desc: Slabby and thin project.  Open project~ unsure of the grade

location: Candy Mountain > Sam's Throne & Surroundings > Arkansas
desc: Roof Extension to the 5.11b/c low chains (unsure of name and first ascentionists currently)  Climb through the stellar terrain down low~ consisting of interesting tafoni features that are surprisingly bomber. From the base of the roof embark on the wild ride of jugs and a few large moves that guard the chains high above. About 25 feet of straight roof tugging on this monster will satiate your desire for a small pump or some serious arkansas air beneath your feet. Keep your morals straight or you just may succumb to some good ole fashioned frontier justice.
protection: Bolts~ Rap Ring/hanger combo up top

location: Rhyme or Reason Wall > Area 51 > Bigfoot Hollow > Fayetteville Region > Arkansas
desc: Open Project~ unsure of the grade    I would avoid this route until the slab gets cleaned up a bit. You'll find no traction in that sea of moss.

location: Coup D'etat Wall > West Main Bluff > Sam's Throne > Sam's Throne & Surroundings > Arkansas
desc: The crux is at the start and continues up past the 2nd bolt. Consider stick clipping the second bolt. Pumpy route from the start and does not let up for a ways.   (The route was put up on lead).
protection: 5 Bolts and sling for the chicken head after the fifth bolt. Shares anchors with Ode to a..

location: Fish Wall > Steel Creek - Upper Buffalo River > Buffalo River Region > Arkansas
desc: This sea beast will make a salty dog of ye yet~ buckle up for one of the longest single pitch climbs in Arkansas. This route features several technical cruxes in the first half and a wild encounter passing through a couple roofs near the top. Thankfully right before you're thrown into the overhanging swells you get a sit down rest in a cave to get yourself psyched for the steeps 100' off the deck. Stick the redpoint crux at the second roof and finish up with wickedly good grips to the anchors.
protection: ~18 bolts. Fixed anchors. Mandatory 70m; tie your knots.

location: Valley of The Blind > Sam's Throne & Surroundings > Arkansas
desc: This is a 45 degree overhanging finger crack with a bouldery start and finish. Sean's original name for this route is right on the money with pain tolerance being key. What this line lacks in length it makes up for in power. Find the crux exiting the crack and making it to the anchors. On the free ascent of this~ the first pitch actually ended at a no-hands stance above the anchors~ but below the second roof. Enjoy one of Arkansas' most difficult cracks.
protection: Protection is adequate and will depend on what parts of the crack you are willing to give up as holds. Emphasis on blue to red metolius tcu will do you just fine.

location: Strawberry shortcake wall > Jamestown Crag > Arkansas
desc: very hard start up to hard climbing once you reach the ledge it gets much easier. when first climbed it went at 5.13a new beta i believe makes it much easier. If you want to climb it the 5.13 way then use the horrible arrowhead looking hold near the start.

location: Fire Cave > Rock Creek > Cowell/Deer Area > Arkansas
desc: Climb through the same initial boulder sequence as  "Smokejumper" and continue straight up the face instead of trending left.     Pull some ninja like moves establishing onto the slab section and shake before the small roof.    From here pull hard to the big ledge where the redpoint crux awaits. Make it to the rest jug and fire through some steep 5.11 jug terrain to the anchors.

location: Obscure Rock > 4 - Windy Point West > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: After a tricky start (use a spotter if you want)~ clip a high first bolt.  Fairly strenuous climbing down low leads to big sloping ledge.  Move to the corner and pull the crux.  Great variety and a fun crux move make this a good climb.

location: Sunnyside > La Milagrosa Canyon > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: A brilliant~ exposed~ slightly overhung JUGGY arete/face climb.  Except for a couple of wild moves~ most of the route is left of the arete.    The 5.10 approach pitch is not bad and should not keep you off this climb.

location: Wall of the Dancing Dwarfs > Munchkinland Area > 6 - Mid-Mountain > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Easier climbing down low leads to a well-defined crux higher up.

location: Oasis II > La Milagrosa Canyon > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: The right-hand of the two routes. The name (courtesy of Joe Shiefman) is a play on a well-known Beaver Wall route. If the start seems a bit much~ go ahead and stick-clip the 2nd bolt.

location: Sphinx > 2 - Bear Canyon > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Slab~ laybacking~ roof~ bulge~ steep face and more slab.  Everything but jamming.

location: The Magma Gardens > The Mine Area > Queen Creek Canyon > Central Arizona > Arizona
desc: 4 Bolt thin face to 2 bolt rap (Karabin guide #75).

location: Wall of the Dancing Dwarfs > Munchkinland Area > 6 - Mid-Mountain > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: 2nd route from left on Wall of Dancing Dwarves. Stars just right of a tree~ almost in front of it.    SQII says 5.11~ the online guide linked from this website says 11a. Seems more like 11a to me. I'll let the consensus determine that.

location: Bone Town > The Homestead > Central Arizona > Arizona
desc: Very similar to Wish Bone and Bonehead. Good holds and good movement in the inverted section to a short face and anchors.

location: The Helmet > 5 - Windy Ridge > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: The 3rd route from the right on the vertical NW face is identified by a start bolt tucked below an arching flake. It joins Tony's Route for 3 cruxy bolts before heading straight up where Tony's Route goes right. Two more stiff cruxes high up are both preceded by good rests.

location: The Ruins > 1 -  Lower Highway > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Fairly easy face climbing up to the roof where the harder climbing starts.  Pull the well protected roof and up 4 or 5 more bolts to anchors.

location: It Cliff > 1 -  Lower Highway > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: The Crux as with the others on this wall is getting over the bulge.  There is a trick for those who don't live on a campus board and the name was inspired by a guy who is always on his heels.    This route gets very close to the roof to the left of it as you turn the roof.

location: Main Wall - Center > Isolation Canyon > Central Arizona > Arizona
desc: Just right of Doubts Even Here (5.9 crack) is a roof with a couple tough liebacks.  The crux is getting past the second small roof. Rest on a ledge and saunter up the last bolt to the anchor at base of Gone Grey.

location: Waterfall Area > Renegade > East Clear Creek > Winslow- Hwy’s 87 & 99 Corridors > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: This route has two starts the original which stays with the bolts and the Ukrainian start which is the bouldery start on the left. either way you end up in a chimney squeeze and have to pull through a small overhang to some lieback moves and finally finish with some mixed slab and jam moves. Excellent line!

location: 3 - Spine Cave > The Dry Canyon > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: This is a good one with the moves getting gradually more difficult as you go up.  You also get to use a very cool "loaf" hold that looks as if it is an embedded river cobble.  Another good one to get on before you work in the Spine Cave.

location: Pumphouse > 2 - Bear Canyon > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: This is what you get for a warm up at The Pumphouse.         The crux is from bolts 2-4 before the climb gives way to featured and more pleasant climbing above~ but there are still some tricks as you will navigate sloping ledges and longish moves to a final mantle right before the chains.        This climb is well worth getting on.

location: The Pond > Queen Creek Canyon > Central Arizona > Arizona
desc: Start by climbing up and easy ramp to a break.  Clip a bolt and make some pumpy moves to get over the overhanging crux section.  After the bulge the route eases off past another bolt or 2.  Short climb~ but a pretty fun sequence through the crux.

location: Wet Beaver Crack > Central Mogollon Rim > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: lieback through a ow section then steep hands pull the roof; technical crux above the roof is bolt protected then climb hands in a corner to the pinnacle summit.

location: Sixty Second Wall > 6 - Mid-Mountain > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: This is a fun route with a great view/exposure and a variety of moves. The climbing is easy off the deck but quickly turns into a technical face at approximately bolt #4. Some of the clip stances on the thin face and on the arete require precise use of feet and some smearing. Some of these clips will test the average leader~ but all of the falls would be safe. The roof higher up on the climb features some great moves using block holds. Deserves more than the one-star rating given in Squeezing II~ IMHO.

location: Sixty Second Wall > 6 - Mid-Mountain > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: From a large ledge clip the first bolt and move into a shallow dihederal.  Continue to gain ground by stemming~ avoiding crumbly flakes~ until a series of edges lead up and left.  From a no hands rest~ enjoy a tricky but short sequence where one can use the arete~ dihederal~ or both.  Finish by pulling a small lip with ample jugs.    In my opinion 60 Seconds Over San Manuel is both the better and more challenging route.  That said the stemming near the second bolt and crux sequence on 62nd Street are worth sampling.

location: Wailing Wall > 2 - Bear Canyon > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Not my route~ but I have this beta photo to round out the database.
protection: ~8 bolts~ plus 2 bolt anchor directly at top. (There are 4 anchors on top.)

location: Mormon Canyon > Sedona > Sedona Area > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: This line climbs nothing up a hold covered face. The line features minimal protection bolts and maximum outrageous gear placements. Place gear when you find it~ and always be on the hunt.    Route faces west and bakes in the sun in the afternoon. All anchors are bolted.    Pitch 1 - 120' - 5.10   Mini-quest up the slab to a small crack below a large roof. Plug some nuts and jam~ heel hook and jug your way through the roof and onto the slab above~ where your quest continues straight up to the top bunk belay ledge. (Its nice to extend the anchor so you can belay on the lower ledge)    Pitch 2 - 122' - 5.10+   Head up the chimney moving right at the bush continuing up the system until it ends. From here quest up and right to a lone bolt (Bolt out left here is the original line~ not quite as good~ a good option if you hate bolts. 2 pitches of 5.10 questing rejoins this line at base of p4)~ then keep questing to the system above~ pull a roof and belay on a small ledge.    Pitch 3 - 110' - 5.11-   Follow the bolts. .3/.4 could be helpful at the top of the pitch.    Pitch 4 - 80' - 5.11   Climb the center lead wall up and left to the obvious hand/fist crack. Burl onto the overhanging pillar~ and up to the offset above. Pimp slap~ boulder~ clip a bolt~ and pull into an alcove. Pull hero jugs to the belay ledge.    Pitch 5 - 120' = 5.11-?+....   Follow bolts up the arete slab. When they end work left and enable your geardar. Follow patina and weaknesses to the top.    Approach    Hike up Mormon Canyon to its end. Exit left past brush to a slab. Up right~ over limestone band to more brush. At the slab~ solo up to a bolt~ crank a move then hike up right (.5 c4 protects the follower from pendulum of the year)~ to an anchor. Follow bowl up~ at its top move right on slabs to the base of the wall. Route starts below roof band. Look for hand crack 40' up. 2HR. 5.10.    Decent   Rap Route. Watch you tails~ raps are close. 70m required.
protection: Doubles red c3 - #2 c4 Single #3~ green c3 Optional purple c3 Full set of nuts 10 Draws/Runners

location: Water World > La Milagrosa Canyon > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Big holds out the hand traverse to a powerful move over the bulge~ then hold on up the steep face to the top.    Steep fun moves~ on big holds out over the water. Very unique for the Milagrosa and Mt. Lemmon.   Draws can be stripped from the chains with less effort than it appears.

location: 1.The Left Wall > The Waterfall > Oak Creek Canyon > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: This is the same route as What are You On? but instead of finishing left on the 5.12 headwall splitter go right ten feet to the Midwestern Gangster anchors.
protection: Small wires~ a tiny cam and gear to #1 Camalot. Chain anchors.

location: Chimney Rock > 2 - Bear Canyon > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Take "8th & Main" or a "Boardwalk" variation to a bolted anchor~  climb off the belay clipping approximately 6 bolts up to and anchor with lower offs at the top. Climb overhangs approximately 10-15 feet in 40 feet.

location: Nurd Rock > 3 - Windy Point East > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Another Lemmon test piece. If you enjoyed Dragoon grooves like the first pitch of Be All End All or the second pitch of Sound of One Hand Thrashing~ then you will probably love this route. Established as a two pitch climb~ modern ropes and hardware now make this better done as one epic pitch. Balancey face and "crack" climbing off the ground launches you onto run-out~ bolt and gear protected face. Once you reach the third bolt (old anchor with new bolt)~ prepare yourself: things are about to get groovy! Worm your way up the burly~ unforgiving groove above using just about every trick in your bag. Finish in the large chimney and belay from a solid pinyon pine at the top. Before entering the chimney~ I used an orange Metolius in a horizontal on the right face to keep the rope from getting stuck in a notch at the top of the groove.
protection: Doubles in Blue Metolius through #3 Camalot~ 1x #4~ optional #5~ 1x purple Metolius~ stoppers

location: 1.The Left Wall > The Waterfall > Oak Creek Canyon > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Insomnia is a heady lead~ with steep~ thin~ and runout climbing on the menu. Start as you would for the Terminator~ but at the top of the pillar~ move left over blocky terrain towards the roof. Expect hard climbing for a bit~ but it backs off towards the top.
protection: Doubles from #00 to #2BD~ a single #3BD. Small and medium sized wires.

location: Mean Mistreater Wall > 4 - Windy Point West > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Starts 1 pitch off the ground~ at the P1 anchors of Mean Mistreater. Follow the bolt line that starts about 6 feet left and 10 feet up from the anchors.
protection: 7ish bolts. Bring small-medium gear for a few placements between bolts. Anchors at top. Walk off~ or rap down Mean Mistreater.

location: Mystery Spire > Boynton Canyon > Dry Creek Road Area > West Sedona > Sedona Area > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Inversion Virgins climbs the east face of Mystery Spire and is most notable for the wild roof crack. A must-do for offwidth lovers.  Pitch 1: Start in the middle of the face~ stemming a chossy tips crack through several little bulges. Jam a nice right-arching hand crack to the belay ledge. Many options for gear anchor in and below the limestone band. (5.10-~ 90 feet)  Pitch 2: Hop over the limestone band~ wiggle up the chimney~ and negotiate the offwidth roof crack. This is a well-protected yet rather devious bombay hatch. Belay from two-bolt anchor just above roof. (5.11~ 60 feet)  Options from here: 1. Rappel route with two 60m ropes. 2. Continue up to top of tower on left (4th class)~ walk across summit to gap between two southernmost towers~ and jump across to tallest tower. Very fun! Protect the jump-across with cams in horizontals. Rappel Cracked Code (south face) with one rope. Tree anchor at top; two-bolt chain anchor midway. 3. Boulder up tower on right (5.8 R) and rappel the original Mystery Spire route (north face) with one rope. Tree anchor at top; three-bolt chain anchor midway.
protection: Doubles from tiny to #3 camalot   Single #4~ #5~ #6 camalot    (new BD sizes)

location: Big Pine Towers - West Face > 3 - Windy Point East > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Balancy start to a hard bulge.

location: Cracker Jack Cliffs > Jacks Canyon > Winslow- Hwy’s 87 & 99 Corridors > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Fun overhung route climbing great pockets and edges.

location: 5. The Iron Wall > South Side > Volunteer Canyon (The Cwm) > Sycamore Canyon > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Steep and exposed stemming. 4 star movement on slightly blocky features.

location: Myth Wall > The Labyrinth > Superstition Mountains > **Phoenix Areas > Central Arizona > Arizona
desc: We top-roped this route and it was great~ a lead would be stout~ pumpy and would definitely feel even more difficult.  Clip two bolts off some crimps and aim for the finger crack.  Some big reaches will place you even further away from the security of the bolts and eventually to a wondrous~ horizontal jam and protection.  Clip one more bolt and punch-it to the top~ eases off after pulling past third bolt.
protection: 3 bolts~ small and medium cams for the lead. Two old~ rusty bolts at top.

location: Bastion Towers > Rockfellow Group > East Stronghold > Cochise Stronghold > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: The Maw is unique route with varied and exciting climbing - a little bit of something for everyone. Sporty face moves to start~ a short but sweet crack system~ wild chimney traversing~ and easy chicken-head runout.  Pitch 1 starts up a crumbly but fun corner for a short bit before reaching right to the first bolt. Easier climbing~ and an opportunity to place a smaller piece before committing to the face. Enter a fun series of face moves through the next three bolts in the 5.11ish range. Pull these face moves to gain a ledge up right~ near the base of the crack system. Pass some bolted placements~ using the crack and face holds. Short but sweet crack climbing takes you up to the anchor~ in mostly thin hands size. I felt like it was pretty straightforward 5.10- crack~ relative to climbs in the area. Fun pitch.  Pitch 2 is just wild to look up at now. Cast off up an intimidating but not too difficult corner to reach main course. A unique~ flaring~ bomb bay chimney that you'll be horizontally traversing. Traverse left~ well-protected through bolts~ on some small and some amazing feet. Mid pitch you reach the crux~ a bit of a bizarre down climb to a small ramp. 5.11 but no consequence. If you blow it here~ just act cool like you meant to dyno the ramp. Place a bigger piece before executing a final reach to big chickens. It can be kind of blind groping if you're short~ and it's more fun if your belayer tries shouting beta from afar. "Up left six inches! Down a little more! I'm getting cold!" Hero jug to the anchor above.  Pitch 3 takes you to the top. Interesting moves off the belay gain you a good chicken head to clip the first of three bolts on the pitch. Bolt clipped~ pull a fun move on decent features~ then cruise easy chicken heads up to a mid pitch ledge. Keep you eyes peeled for another bolt on this upper portion of the ledge~ protecting an easy 10- move. From there cruise a bit of low grade slab to the top.
protection: Single rack to #2~ doubles #3. Bunch of draws. 60m rope

location: Delta Dome > 7 - Upper Highway > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: A very pretty route. Based on looks alone I give it 3 stars~ even though it's not really my favorite style of climbing. A lot of people may love it.  A harder-than-it-looks slabby arete/stem trough....followed by a cool~ easier-than-it-looks overhang....then a delicate~ vertical~ bear-hugging arete with a hard-to-read crux bulge at the end.
protection: 13 bolts (I think) plus Mussys.    Long QDs to prevent rope drag.  Maybe double draw the bolt on the midway ledge.

location: Coffee Pot II (South Chief) > Coffeepot Rock Area > West Sedona > Sedona Area > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Pitch 1: 5.8 - 130'.  This pitch is the same as the 1st pitch on Coffee Pot Rock's Original Route. It is on the North side of the formation.  Climb the low angle chimney to the narrow notch between Coffee Pot Rock and Coffee Pot II (South Chief). OW gear is not needed after this pitch.  Pitch 2: 5.6 - 30' - Jump across!  Climb up the slab for 20' until you're standing on the protruding lighter band of sandstone.  Jump across to the ledge on Coffee Pot II.  Pitch 3: 5.11 - 25' - Traverse the bolted handrail from muffins to dimples and pull around onto a nice South face ledge. This pitch can be french freed if you're not into dimples.  Pitch 4: 5.7  - 50' - Continue straight up the slab and hang a left at the first bolt. Traverse to the obvious block and then up another 30' to the huge ledge. Gear belay - medium cams. *Note - you can continue directly up after the first bolt but the rock quality deteriorates*  Pitch 5: 5.0 - 120' - Traverse left along the ledge roughly 80' to the obvious chimney.  Wiggle up the chimney to the broad summit and Pine tree belay. Scramble to the top!  Descent: Rap 40' off of a slung bush on the South side of the summit back to the 4th pitch belay. Rap 80' off of two bolts down to the notch atop pitch 1. Rap 90' down to two bolts on a ledge part way up pitch 1.  Rap 40' to your packs.
protection: Single set of cams from fingers to OW. Assorted quickdraws~ slings~ etc. 1 rope All belays are bolted except the 4th If it's been a few years since 2020 bring 10-15 feet of tat to reinforce the webbing on the first rap.

location: The Druid > 6 - Mid-Mountain > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: While technically a mixture of two lines~ Jack The Slipper and the sport variation of The Pagan~ this route makes for a pleasant clip-up.    Climb Jack The Slipper to the chains.  Instead of lowering clip a shoulder length sling to the right chain and move right under the roof.  This is the sport variation of The Pagan.  Clip a half-yanked bolt that spins (as of June 2012) and pull the roof.  Continue straight up moderate jugs to the anchors.    Since the climbing is 5.9 other than the roof~ which is 5.11~ the line is not consistent at the grade.  It is consistent in quality however.
protection: Approximately 12 bolts to chains.  Two notes as of June 2012:    The bolt below the roof is half-pulled and the hanger spins.  It has been like this for quite some time and held our falls.  That does not mean that it will continue catch climbers forever though.  This bolt is under outward pressure from the roof above.  The tension on this bolt and rope drag above would be lessened by using a shoulder length sling.  That said it is in the middle of the crux sequence and above a small ledge so a short draw provides piece of mind.    The anchors consist of two unequalized bolts~ the lower of which has a rap ring.  There is currently a quickdraw equalizing the anchors.  We left the quickdraw in place.  A more permanent solution would be a chain.

location: Middle Earth > 5 - Windy Ridge > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Slabby technical start to a lieback to jugs as it gets steeper.

location: Swiss Tower > The Pit (aka Le Petit Verdon) > Flagstaff Area > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: A linkup of True Value into Shark Bait. Notable for it's rope drag.  Climb True Value to the bolt below the roof~ clip it with the longest runner you own~ then traverse left on easy terrain to Shark Bait.

location: Slate Nation > The Homestead > Central Arizona > Arizona
desc: Interesting and committing off the ground.  Stays on you to the roof where it jumps all over you.  Sequence is everything.  Dark grey rock over roof is only slightly unpleasant to pull on.

location: Main Wall > Higher Solitude > Solitude Canyon > Mt. Elden Crags > Flagstaff Area > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: The Scythe is a beautiful line and a cool feature of the Main wall. The pitch follows a black streak system to a conspicuous right trending crescent crack feature.     Start off on slabby~ juggy terrain to reach a high first bolt at 20'. Scamper past jugs and several "Peaks Crag" style mantel moves throughout the middle section.     The scythe feature is the hard bit~  though some jamming skill~ countless foot moves~ and some perseverance here will get you through this enigmatic section. Then enjoy very cool~ jug stemming to the top. Good stone throughout.
protection: 12 lead bolts 2 bolt anchor with ClimbTech mussy hooks provided by the ASCA

location: The Grail > Lime Kiln Canyon > The Arizona Strip > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: This is a pretty fun route that takes you near the top of the Grail Wall.  According to the book~ the first pitch is the crux at 5.11d and it’s probably the best pitch of the route.  It sees less traffic above this pitch for sure.  There is definitely some loose rock up high~ so keep this in mind if you choose to do this route on a busy day with lots of parties below you.  P1 (5.11d): A fun~ steep pitch up edges. 11 bolts~ 100’  P2 (5.11b): I felt this was a sandbag.  It’s tough off the belay but the crux comes just after a mantle move when you have to traverse right past 2 bolts to the anchor.  9 bolts~ 80’.  P3 (5.11b): This pitch is pretty straightforward and a bit shorter than the others.  7 bolts~ 70’  P4 (5.11b): Another long pitch that starts out vertical.  The crux of the pitch is passing a bulge.  Aftwards it turns to a thoughtful slab for a few moves.  Be mindful of a huge~ undercut block just left of the bolt line on this pitch.  It’s probably solid~ but we didn’t pull on it to find out.  Rappel the route with a single 60m rope.  On the last rappel~ it’s easier to go the Divine Vessel anchors if it’s open.

location: 2. The Main Amphitheater > The Waterfall > Oak Creek Canyon > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: How do you make a good climb better?  Add 30 feet of climbing and pull a roof!  Fierce Invalids climbs a thin corner~ demanding stemming and creative use of face features.  An imposing roof caps the corner~ so fire it!  Surmount the roof to the right and finish up the steep corner littered with pockets and edges.
protection: Cams from 000 C3 to #1 C4.  Double or triple in 00 and 0 C3.  Two bolts protect the steep upper section and can be supplemented with tips to finger sized cams in horizontalsq

location: Finktion Wall > Isolation Canyon > Central Arizona > Arizona
desc: At the east end of the Finktion wall Look for huge roof. Start near giant prickly pear cactus. Overhung start to 90' of edges and sidepulls~ stays on arete mostly. several cruxes~ awesome exposure!

location: Pinnacle Peak > Pinnacle Peak > **Phoenix Areas > Central Arizona > Arizona
desc: Work up the face past a low bolt that protects the initial moves to the horizontal. Traverse right place a cam or two at along the break.  Make some really hard moves~ passing 2 old leeper bolts and 1 new good bolt to a tree ledge with 1 glue in bolt for an anchor~ which can be backed up with a #1 or #2 camalot.

location: Yakov Wall > Euro Dog Valley > Queen Creek Canyon > Central Arizona > Arizona
desc: This sport route follows two (2) bolts of 5.11b just to the right of a crack which is in turn to the right of the central right-facing corner on the cliff. The halfway point is reached at a small ledge~ then two (2) more bolts worth of 5.11c slightly overhanging face.
protection: Four (4) lead bolts and a two (2) bolt anchor which might or might not have any descending hardware on them.

location: Spaghetti Western Wall > Isolation Canyon > Central Arizona > Arizona
desc: Getting past the lip of the roof is very difficult; a tcu could be placed in the crack if necessary to help you feel better about clipping the bolt past the lip. Cranking over the roof is easier if a foot jam overhead is used.
protection: all bolts plus one tcu maybe.

location: Tufa City > The Homestead > Central Arizona > Arizona
desc: Stickclip the first bolt and make some tricky moves up the blocky pumpy start. Rest up on the convenient ledge and pull Tufa moves over the steep bulge.  Here the 5th bolt is placed far right and difficult to spot.  Continue up on cool easy tufa moves to the anchors.     This is the first half of the 13b Nambla~ so if feeling strong continue up another 5 bolts for the 13b tick.

location: Pancake House > Upper Devils Canyon > Queen Creek Canyon > Central Arizona > Arizona
desc: A stiff little thing. After 3 bolts you're still not entirely sure what this route is asking of you. The climb does not surmount the roof of the Pancake House~ engendering further disillusionment. Fun nonetheless.
protection: 3 bolts to a pair of shuts.

route: Georgia the Goat Memorial Sport Route
location: Main Ampitheater > The Biscuit > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Standout pitch at the Biscuit~ named after a somewhat mythical goat. This is one of my favorite pitches I have ever climbed~ and I hope others will get a chance to enjoy it. Crux is right off the belay in the first three bolts~ then enters a golden~ immaculate slab-hedral~ eventually gaining the exposed arete. 5 more bolts of climbing on the grey stone takes you all the way to the summit of the Biscuit. Go sign the register and keep Georgia in your hearts.
protection: 12-ish bolts. Some alpine draws may help to reduce rope drag. Easy to rap back down to the midway anchors~ unsure if this is do-able with a 60m rope.

location: The Brick House > Marg's Draw > Sedona > Sedona Area > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: A technical shallow corner~ with gear and bolts. Easier than Crystal Gratitude~ but requires a bit more thought.

location: Turkey Dome > Village of Oak Creek > Sedona Area > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: none listed

location: Church Wall > Church Wall and Religion Wall > Church Spires Area > East Twin Butte > Twin Butte > Sedona > Sedona Area > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Castles In the Sand is a gorgeous line~ and a burly route. This stunning neo classic is a must do if you are in the area.     Pitch 1.  5.11- Climb striking off fingers/small hands crack in left facing dihedral. Belay below roof.    Pitch 2.  5.11+ Rodeo time! Climbing out the roof crack~ and riding the lip of the roof like a bull is the crux of the route.  Continue up moderate crack to a belay just under the largest roof above you.      Pitch 3.  5.11  A classic roof pitch that may remind you of Coatamundi Whiteout on Granite Mountain. Do what you have to do to work out the hands/fist crack in the roof~ and pull into the slot over the lip.   In November of 2012~ the original first roof FELL off the route subsequently changing the quality and difficulty of this section. The new first roof goes at 5.10+/.11- and can be protected with a #5 Camalot.  I have left the original description for history's sake.

location: Overlooked Pinnacle > 3 - Windy Point East > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Overhanging face.  Balance through the bottom portion to a distinct crux.  Finish on jugs to the anchors shared with Grapenut.  Climbing directly over the 4th and 5th bolts may not be a good idea.  Upgraded hardware as of Spring 2020~ thanks to our local bolters.
protection: Around 10 bolts will mussy hooks at the anchors.

location: TriTower > 7 - Upper Highway > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Interesting pulling up the left side of the little cave~ then stem across the top of the cave.  Slab above offers cool holds and a no-hands rest. Then an overhanging bulge gives you the business.  Start shares some holds with North Arete~ but clip bolts INSIDE the cave.    It's probably a stiff-ish 5.11 if you are my height~ but shorter folks are likely to think 11+ or 12-.  Harder in high humidity too.    I gave it 2 stars but it's really more like 1.5

location: Middle Earth > 5 - Windy Ridge > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: An epic endurance pitch consisting of endless technical face.  This route will test your physical conditioning~ crimp strength~ memory for beta~ and your belayer's patience.    Clip approximately four bolts before crossing Pull Me Up left-to-right.  One bolt may be shared by the routes.  Follow the closely spaced bolts as they veer right and upward by using small edges and crimps to gain ground.  Desperate moves give way to a grungy weakness that provides a much needed respite after the crux.  Summon up the energy for one last battle~ clipping three bolts~ before pulling onto a false summit.  Three spaced bolts up easy~ featured terrain lead the climber to the anchors.    While this route is no doubt amazing~ it lacks the perfect rock of its neighbors such as Silmarillion.  All in all a very memorable~ challenging pitch.    The route is named Centennial since it was Scott Ayers' 100th FA.  At 165ft the route is the entire length of a 50m rope~ which may have been used at the time.
protection: 19 bolts to anchors consisting of two non-rappellable bolts with leaver biners.  Two ropes are required to descend as the anchors for Earth Angel are too far away to comfortably reach.
