Alternatively it may be possible to walk off.  Cleaning the last four bolts on rappel requires a bit of work since the route trends right.

location: Southeast Face > The Fortress > 8 - Summit Crags > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Chimney from the narrow slot to obtain the detached outcropping or simply walk around to start ten feet above.  Commit to the the face~ minding the gap~ to reach the first bolt.  Tenuous face climbing leads into a right-facing weakness~ which is followed by a brief section of easier climbing.  Smear on down-turned crystals while clawing for edges to overcome the second crux.  Upon reaching a grungy looking pillar trend right~ clipping two bolts~ before finishing up the arete.   Chapalot is recommended for those who enjoy thin face.  The rock prior to the arete is absolutely stellar; the rock on the arete is actually better than it appears.  The bottom half of this route is sustained and delicate while the upper half has nice exposure.    Upon reaching the chains one can probably continue up by working behind the large pillar that Fort Stress ascends.  From here one can join numerous other routes.
protection: 9 bolts to a chain anchor.    One can belay from either the shaded passageway or use a belay bolt on the detached outcropping 10 feet above the base.

location: Poseidon > Reef of Rocks > 7 - Upper Highway > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: This cool climb was literally cleaned into existence. Unlike many of the newer hard trad lines at the Reef this one actually relies on bomber gear to protect the crux secton. It is a striking left angling weakness that leads to a clean corner with thin cracks and critical unusual holes in the lower angled left face. A double length Alpine runner can be used to sling a flake making the bomber thread in the holes a safe endeavor. The thread makes getting good gear in before attacking the corner very safe. Great pro is there but it takes a bit to work out how to get in position to place it. A small 1/4 inch stopper~ green camalot and a finger sized yellow Metolius cam were used here by the three of us who redpointed it. Most will step on to ledges below the bolted wide section and take a much needed rest. Be sure to pull back around do the fun laybacks up the wide section. Once you are back in it you will see why you left those ledges instead of wandering right and up. it also allows you to clip the second of two bolts.Two more cruxes above are protected by bolts and will keep you focused to the end. You will cross a section of the route Treebeard with gear to reach the last bolt. An actual ton of loose blocks and flakes were pried away to make it a safe venture. The caveat to this is that it starts by climbing the first 20 feet of Snow Arch which is maybe 5.8+/9-. The pro in this section except for the first piece~ a Green Camalot~ is thin and in rock that makes me not want to test it. Having said that~ the rest of the route is so good it is worth carefully climbing this less than ideal section.
protection: Doubles from 000 to red Camalots~ small wired nuts to thin fingers~ one alpine draw to thread hole and a double to sling the top of a big flake~ separate anchors with Steel lower off biners.

location: Finktion Wall > Isolation Canyon > Central Arizona > Arizona
desc: Very clean rock with steep edges thru a small roof with very clean rock. Sustained insecurity!

location: Heart of Marg's Draw. > Marg's Draw > Sedona > Sedona Area > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: A fine looking crack system on south facing wall behind Screaming Beseingi. While the line looks good~ choss~ munge~ soft rock and blocks try and ruin the day. They succeed.     P1 5.9~ 60 feet.    The Viagra pitch~ it never gets hard. Climb a mungey thin hands to a detached flake with a bolt. Stem~ pray and jam through softening rock to the rubble covered slab where another bolt awaits. Bolted belay in blocks of ultimate choss.     P2 5.11+ 110 feet.   "Crux pitch" Move left past blocks to hand crack in clean corner. Fortunately~ everything is covered in silt~ creating the perception of bad rock. Punch fists to sketch piller pulling. Crank layback past roof to looming big roof. Unpleasant contortionist crux on fragile holds and silt leads to bolted OW of dried pancake batter. Bolted belay.     P3 5.10+ 50 feet.   Step left past a bolt and execute terribly awkward sequence to corner. Awkward hand crack leads to EZ blocky terrain. Belay atop sofa block on fingers gears.    P4 5.10  75 feet.   "The almost good pitch". Step left to the leftmost crack above. Starts with fists and goes to hands. After a loose ledge punch up thinning crack to bolted belay. Climbs better than it looks~ looks better then it climbs.     P5 5.9+ 50 feet   "The good pitch" Wide Layback to slot. Enter no hands rest. Bizarre~ exposed and awkward.     Hike 3rd Class past terrible features to summit.
protection: 1x tip and thin fingers. 2x fingers to fists. Several runners. Low self esteem.

location: North Buttress > The Homestead > Central Arizona > Arizona
desc: Not a single crimp on the climb and very few holds that are horizontal.  Two big bulges and a steep finish will keep you interested to the end.  A long series of opposition moves through the first bulge make this one of the more unique climbs at the Rough Rider.  The second bulge doesn't flow as well as the first bulge due to a tricky crux.  The second bulge has a couple of less than ideal pockets and more side-pulls.  The finish passes another much smaller but fun bulge and leads to horizontal jugs.    Just before the big ledge there is some funky dirty rock on the left so stay right on the gray rock.  This gray rock looks bad as well but is solid.

location: Wall of the Marching Munchkins > Munchkinland Area > 6 - Mid-Mountain > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Like most Munchkinland routes the crux is low.  The tree is close but not in the way and not very helpful.

location: DWS East Side > DWS East Clear Creek > East Clear Creek > Winslow- Hwy’s 87 & 99 Corridors > Northern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Beautiful~ sheer~ sunny wall that gets great afternoon sun. Wander up features in the face to a crux at about the 25 foot level. Climb crimpy moves to a sloping ledge with an in your face redpoint crux over a bulge above. Finish on a good ledge about 25 feet before the top of the wall.

location: Poseidon > Reef of Rocks > 7 - Upper Highway > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: You can approach the route from the other Sea Gods by traversing the ledge or by descending from the first saddle you encounter on the hike down. From the saddle angle left through a notch in the boulders and follow paths angling down and right through the oaks to another boulder notch. Drop down and across one slabby gully then down the second to paths through the oaks. You will be contouring right and down to reach the top of Poseidon. 15 draws if you do it in 3 pitches 22 if you combine one and two.  1) 113 feet. Multiple cruxes on this with the last one coming just before the ramp to the anchors. 2) 85 feet. The first moves off the ledge are just like the start moves on the ground but easier. It then gets harder and with an awkward (if done wrong) move on to a big ledge. After that crux~ you will hand rail up and left on good holds for 20 feet or so then you will want to shake it out as a new fingertip rail traverse ensues. Committing to the moves leads big rewards. 3) 105 feet. move right and up from the belay to the crux 15 feet above. It is a little bouldery and is probably 5.11+/ 12-. Once you reach the horizontal you will need to stand up to clip one of the bolts. Foot jugs will allow you to move 15 feet right to a left angling finger seam. Easier ground leads to a two tiered roof with a hand crack exit then easy ground to the anchors. You can rap the route or descend via the gully.   Descent: Three rappels with a 70 Meter rope. Because the route makes some major zigs and zags a few chain draws have been left so you more easily reach the belay anchors.  The first two pitches have been lead as one spectacular 180 foot pitch but you need 22 draws to do it. It helps to extend the second and fourth bolts after the first belay. With a 70M rope you will have to rap twice. DO NOT TRY TO LOWER TO THE 1ST PITCH ANCHORS WITH A 70M ROPE. If you have an 80M rope you can lower to the first pitch anchors To reach the first pitch anchors back clip your way with chain draws to the right or you will end up in space. Has some lichen despite many 15  hours of cleaning but it should get better over time. People who can't handle lichen need not apply.
protection: Bolts Steel Metolious lower off biners

location: Tri-Level Spire > 3 - Windy Point East > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: A chossy start leads to killer dihedral climbing and an exposed~ testy finish. Start left of the bolt line shining ~25' above in a shallow dihedral with a small~ bushy oak tree. Follow this thin crack before busting out right for a ways to the first bolt. At the top of the dihedral decide how you'd like to finish: the direct finish follows the bolt straight up to the top~ while the easier variation heads out left along a lower-angle ramp. The old single 3/8"+SMC anchor has been updated to 1/2" stainless~ thanks to the ASCA for supplying hardware.
protection: 7 bolts~ nuts~ singles to #2 Camalot + a few more finger-to-hand size

location: The Ravens > 8 - Summit Crags > Mount Lemmon (Catalina Highway) > Mount Lemmon (Santa Catalina Mountains) > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: This route has 140 feet of stout climbing and overhangs 7 feet.  Two distinct cruxes one low and one high.  If you lower from the first set of anchors you miss the second crux and you can lower the grade. Take a 70M rope or tie a knot when lowering them to the half way anchors. Almost dropped someone when I did not tie a knot.

location: 6 - Swallow Wall > The Dry Canyon > Southern Arizona > Arizona
desc: Chalk up~ this might get sweaty...     Begin on a ledge and make juggy moves through two bolts up and right. From here~ a tantalizing crack demands three bolts of warmup-action before the main event of the evening. The next 35 feet are jam packed with a full inventory of movements~ so bring your A game. I'm talking about wild body positions~ challenging stances~ remarkable endurance~ a gentle squeeze and maybe even a foot-thing at one point. I'm not telling you what to do~ but I am telling you whips may be involved here.    Even though the crux has reached completion~ its not over yet. Remember~ they call you the whole package for a reason. Three more bolts of crack climbing lead to the chains.

location: Fuente > Sorrueda > Gran Canaria > Canary Islands > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Route 14

location: Berglerturm > Aufseßtal > Frankenjura > Germany > Europe > International
desc: This climb obviously doesn't get climbed much because it was still a bit dirty when I did it. It's also very technical~ being nearly dead vertical the whole time and staying on small holds. Therefore~ the difficulty is sustained and the clips not easy. I found this difficult for 7+~ but it's also not my style.
protection: 3 bolts + stopper placed in crack between 2nd and 3rd bolt + anchor.

location: Eros > Telendos Island > Kalymnos > Greece > Europe > International
desc: Pumpy with lots of hidden pockets.

location: Millennium Cave > Cala Gonone > Sardinia > Italy > Europe > International
desc: Lots of good rests and good moves

location: Tritoni > Cala Fuili > Cala Gonone > Sardinia > Italy > Europe > International
desc: Steep climbing off the ground leads to pulling a bulge. Climb tricky pockets to another bulge where it's natural to head left onto the neighboring route for a few moves and then back right at the break to the anchors. It does go straight up to the anchors but is much harder and fingery.

location: Hartensteiner Wand > Frankenjura > Germany > Europe > International
desc: Tricky climbing because there are a couple of options~ and the crux is not getting pumped out and losing concentration. Follow the positive pockets to the top. Consider stick-clipping the 1st bolt.

location: Ittlinger Wand > Reipertsgesee > Frankenjura > Germany > Europe > International
desc: This is a pretty difficult route to onsight~ so I'll provide a tip if you'd like to read it. At the third bolt~ avoid the really tempting underclings to your left and go right on the small pockets and difficult feet. You'll work up to a left hand crimp to pull yourself up over the bulge. Then head back left to the bolt and up to the last bolt.

location: Fuente > Sorrueda > Gran Canaria > Canary Islands > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Rote 11

location: Schillingsflüe > Switzerland > Europe > International
desc: 6c    Far right of amphitheater~ crossing over to the left-facing wall. Stay on the left edge~ or else end up on Damokles 7a+!

location: Main Wall > Dhiarizos > Cyprus > Europe > International
desc: Great climbing with a crux the comes just before gaining the large hole near the top.

location: Panorama > Kalymnos > Greece > Europe > International
desc: Easy start followed by a few pumpy moves on a sloppy tufa pipe in the middle. After the crux just take advantage of the rests while climbing to the anchor.

location: Mikri Varasova > Mt. Parnitha > Athens > Greece > Europe > International
desc: Route name written at the base. Pumpy climbing on spaced out pockets~ with good rests.

location: Peña del Godo > Tamadaba > Gran Canaria > Canary Islands > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Route 7

location: Hanfplantage > Kleinziegenfelder Tal 1 > Frankenjura > Germany > Europe > International
desc: A pretty decent~ very well protected route which climbs mostly edges or small pockets. The crux is in the middle.

route: No iba a Salir y me Líe (1st & 2nd pitch)
location: Palmeral > Chulilla > Valencia > Spain > Europe > International
desc: A really long pitch that is average at best but at least its long. Rap from the upper anchor to get down.
protection: Lots of bolts (maybe 26?) to a two bolt anchor.

location: Kugelhorn > Norway > Europe > International
desc: 25m~ Climb the detached flake (5.7)25m~ Step right then up into the clean RF corner system. Belay at a small stance (5.8)25m~ Continue up the corner~ traversing under the roof and up to a small stance (5.10a)50m~ Up then over a bulge trending left in the corner to a small stance (5.10a)50m~ Climb the remaining corner system to a semi hanging belay (5.10c)45m~ The traverse pitch. Head out left under the roof then up the airy corner for 5m before boldly traversing left 2m to gain the next crack system. An exposed~ technical & excellent pitch (5.11a)25m~ Easier climbing leads to a deluxe grassy ledge (5.9)45m~ A tough start on loose rock leads to a wider crack system & gradually easier climbing. Another bold pitch. The Crux? (5.11a)40m Continue up the wide corner~ before trending left under the roof & the final summit (5.8)

location: Poets Main > Poets > Kalymnos > Greece > Europe > International
desc: As with Omero to the right~ this is perfect face climbing on perfect rock.  O'Brothers is a weaving line that connects incredible pockets~ creating memorable sequences.  Crux is most likely the first few bolts.

location: Nuit de Temps > Mascun > Rodellar > Aragon > Spain > Europe > International
desc: This excellent wall climb offers interesting technical crimping & an airy position on beautiful orange stone.  You will pass the odd tufa~ but gernally this is a steep edging route on great rock.    Begin up Tam Tam~ or scramble around the corner up the the trail & ledges to an exposed perch on the arete.  Make increasingly harder moves up orange stine to a hard pinch move~ eventually arriving at a break.  CLimb an overhanging tan slab on jugs~ then the techy crux on the headwall: a hard step-up using a sideupll/undercling.  Easier moves lead up the gray slab.
protection: Many bolts to 2BA.  The route is about 30m high from the ledge~ but if you start from the ground a 70m rope will NOT reach the ground.  It is possible to TR with a 70 if you belay from up on the ledge.

location: Aquarium > Kleinziegenfeld Sawmill > Frankenjura > Germany > Europe > International
desc: A bouldery start leads up to the high first bolt. The rest is much easier. Continue straight up.   The landing isn't very safe to be trying different solutions~ so you should stick-clip the first bolt.

location: Iliada Right > Iliada > Kalymnos > Greece > Europe > International
desc: Nice steep and fun.  Clean on the lower if possible.  Was originally rated 7a.  Is now 6c.

location: Finsterlay > Mayen > Schwarze Saeulen > Hunsrück/Moseltal > Germany > Europe > International
desc: One of the best routes of the crag! I really enjoyed the perfect fists. The start is not to difficult with some perfect handjams. Than an awesome 25 foot fist crack.
protection: 5 bolts. Top anchor. It should be climbed clean =) (2~ 2x3~ 3x4)

location: High Neb Buttress > The High Neb Area > Stanage Edge > The Peak District > England > United Kingdom > Europe > International
desc: Serious~ bold and strenuous.

location: Mystery > Kalymnos > Greece > Europe > International
desc: Very good route. The first part is on pockets with some cool moves and at mid-height you hit the real crux on slightly overhanging wall where positioning will be the key. There's a second hard section at the top but not as hard as the one in the middle.

location: Harry Potter Wand > Frankenjura > Germany > Europe > International
desc: Nice juggy fun through an overhang. There are a bunch of holds~ so it can get pretty pumpy if you spend too much time looking for "the right one".

location: Iannis > Kalymnos > Greece > Europe > International
desc: Oh-sweet Zagori! Means: "WHY THE HELL didn't I buy that 80m rope when I had the chance?!"    Zagori starts with a bang. Work up to the first bolt from the left with a bear hug/iron cross  bouldering move off a small tufa pipet. Up more blah gray (I thought he said THREE stars?!?) until you start seeing steep orange walls and perfect pockets chiseled by Leonardolopis~ Da Vinci's older Greek cousin who never moved beyond sculptures of swiss cheese. Link the pockets and send around a hero bulge with great clips and great exposure.    At this point you'll swear you're back at Rifle. Except that you have good feet and fresh guns and there's nary a snotty ranger tagging your car with some bullshit parking ticket.     Fire up the endless headwall until the air starts thinning and you can see the curvature of the planet. Clip the chains~ and now start figuring out how the hell you're gonna reenter the earth's atmosphere with that midget of a 60m rope you brought. (I hear rumors that a 70 well managed can bring you back down to the ground. Sorta/kinda.)    Fantastic warm-up. May feel VERY soft for the grade~ but that's typical for a Boris~ Claude~ and Yves route. (Really? Who the hell saddles their children with "Boris~" "Claude~" and/or "Yves~" anyway? Is'n't "Yves" a Mongolian strain of TB or something? Yves. Honestly.)
protection: Seventeen thousand~ six hundred~ forty-three draws. And an oxygen mask. There's a 2-bolt/1-'biner anchor just inside the orbit of Mars.

location: Caidero > Fataga > Gran Canaria > Canary Islands > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Route 25

location: Koukouvas > E.T. > Kalymnos > Greece > Europe > International
desc: Lots of pockets with a couple delicate moves.

location: Breitenstein > Frankenjura > Germany > Europe > International
desc: Awesome route! Beautiful arete climbing with wonderful pockets and features. Sometimes the route is a bit reachy~ but it's always good. Very lightly overhanging and well bolted.   The route's name translates to "To a Nice View".

location: Sector Pink Panther > Fraguel > Mallorca > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Good pitch with some nice crimps and edges.  Not as good as Cous Cous for the grade

location: Branta Väggen > Hallinden > Bohuslan > Sweden > Europe > International
desc: Boulder up to a horizontal break and follow crack for another 10 feet to another horizontal break.  Traverse left 8 feet and follow the steep crack to a short offwidth to the top.  Belay from trees and walk off or rap from one of the numerous tree anchors.

location: Campi Qui Pugui > Village Crags > Siurana > Catalonia > Spain > Europe > International
desc: This start is shared with 2 other routes and is fairly easy. For this one in particular~ go straight up. The crux is encountered at the first bulge which then finishes off on some slab.

location: Exploding Galaxy Wall > Avon Gorge > South West > England > United Kingdom > Europe > International
desc: UK E4 6a  Anyone who climbs Yellow Edge should be intrigued enough by its close neighbor to want to come back for it. An appealing line from afar~ this most notably takes you on a grand adventure of varied climbing~ featuring a little bit of choss-eneering~ slabby moves to hidden holds~ and an excellent position moving along under the prominent roof/corner system before breaking free to finishing up with the ice cream van.  P1: (5c) Climb up the delicate flakes~ placing pro in a diversity of locations and never pulling too hard on anything. Continue up and right~ past a spike~ and to a small ledge.  The best belay requires going right with an awkward step down to a better ledge under an old spike.  The horizontal break will take small/medium cams & tricams.   P2: (6a) Go back left to the small ledge and climb up right (over the spike from the anchor) and find yourself the good hold. Peg with tatty sling on it here. Continue up joining Yellow Edge on large pockets and exciting featured rock. Be sure to get the good calcite threat below the stepped roofs.  Once this is secure~ go up and right into the stepped roofs and belay on a decent ledge with various options of nuts and cams in the roof for a belay. Look around for the large but easily missed thread!   P3: (5c) Continue up and right~ past 3 old bolts~ and go up to a pancake of rock and prominent peg~ both of which can be tied off (and are shared with Yellow Edge). Instead of going leftward along the scooped ramp of Yellow Edge~ pull over the bulge and finish up and left above.  Take care on the top out~ and then scramble up to use the fence for an anchor.
protection: Standard rack of wires and cams.  Tricams definitely can be useful. Thin slings very important for both threads and tying off spikes/protruding pitons

location: Secteur 15 - Mur Zappa > Buoux > Provence > France > Europe > International
desc: This climb is right of La Marine. The first two bolts are the most difficult on the route as the sharp pockets cut into flesh.

location: 4 Middle Fin - South Face > Lower Sharpnose Point > The Culm Coast > South West > England > United Kingdom > Europe > International
desc: UK E4 5c~ though low in the grade.   An excellent clean~ solid~ and well protected route going up the seaward end of the face.  Only 20m~ but thoroughly enjoyable~ and a friendly entry to the grade.  Exit off the end of the ledge and follow a thin crack right to more holds and another crack~ with a quartz break bringing you up and left at the end to the top.
protection: Single set of cams. Top anchor is a bit mank~ have a thin sling (thread) and maybe a couple wires to back it up for the belay~ and maybe replace the tat for the rappel. Possible to redirect this to abseil the opposite face~ though the anchor may not be equalized in that direction.

location: Salto Del Perro > Gran Canaria > Canary Islands > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Route 13

location: Alas en tus Pies > Tamadaba > Gran Canaria > Canary Islands > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Route 2

location: L'Olla > Valley Crags > Siurana > Catalonia > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Cap Rapat is a silly variation to El Caganer that avoids the best climbing on that line & adds an insecure traverse.  Begin up El Caganer to the first pod.  Bust left with no feet~ then up to a horizontal rail.  Follow the bulging groove to a thin finish.    Beware there is a behive ~10 feet to the left of this line~ in one of the big pods ~20 feet up.

location: La Vida Misma > Desplomilandia > El Chorro > Andalucia > Spain > Europe > International
desc: This long routes starts between the short groove of Si te gusta el pique~ pique and the right leaning ramp.  Climb directly up to a high first bolt.   Fingering climbing leads up to the second bolt which is again fairly spaced.   Move up the steep wall on small but positive holds to a tricky section at the top of the steep wall.   From here continue on up to some airy moves that give access to less steep ground above.  Move directly up to finish just left of the anchors.
protection: 10 Bolts to a sport anchor.   The bolting on this one is more old school~ and not nearly as friendly as the surrounding routes.

location: Salon/ sector X > Sorrueda > Gran Canaria > Canary Islands > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Route 3

location: Vudu > Zona de Arriba > San Bartolo > Cadiz > Andalucia > Spain > Europe > International
Abaix > Grau dels Massets > Village Crags > Siurana > Catalonia > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Amazing climbing up an arete to a striking crack feature. This one is pretty sparcely bolted even by Spain standards~ and be ready for a 30 foot runout to the chains.  Climb up into the slot~ and then on to the face at the second bolt. Continue up good smallish holds with good rests hidden through out the pitch. Continue by pinching the arete with your left~ and side pulling the crack with your right hand~ until you come to a final shake on a horizontal before the chains. Chalk up and quest up smaller than you would like hold to the top. Don't fall clipping the chains.  4 star climbing~ but the placement of the second bolt retracts from the enjoyment of the climb. I would recommend stick clipping the second bolt as it is really hard to reach from the slot out left.

location: Cala Luna > Sardinia > Italy > Europe > International
desc: Strenuous begin followed by easier climbing and then a perplexing finish.

location: Valdesi > Monte Pellegrino > Palermo Area > Sicily > Italy > Europe > International
desc: Climb easy terrain past a few bolts to a ledge~ follow by a crux section on thin edges and big reach to tufas

location: Cavadonna > Sicily > Italy > Europe > International
desc: A little sketchy at the beginning~ just on top of the little chimney section.  Fun and tricky when just starting the overhang!

location: Tana delle Tigri > Domusnovas > Sardinia > Italy > Europe > International
desc: A short but pumpy affair on the left edge of the cave. Climb up a pillar of sorts to an overhanging corner. Figure out how to commit to the face on the left of the corner through steep ground and the anchors.
protection: Eight bolts to a two-bolt anchor with rope/chain and lowering anchor

location: Neue Heimat > Frankenjura > Germany > Europe > International
desc: Maybe not exactly "classic"~ but a damn good 8- route for the Frankenjura.   The climbing follows jugs through the first three bolts~ then it gets serious. Instead of following pockets~ you're forced to rely on the features of the rock and correct body position to make it through the crux to the anchor.

location: Palmera > Fataga > Gran Canaria > Canary Islands > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Route 16

location: Vistas > Tamadaba > Gran Canaria > Canary Islands > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Route 3

location: Haselstaudener Right Wall > Haselstaudener Wände > Haselstauden and Untertrubach (Oma Eichler's Campground) > Frankenjura > Germany > Europe > International
desc: Cool~ slightly overhanging climbing on pockets and crimps. Climb a difficult start to the first bolt and climb easier rock to a great rest stance if you need it and then up to the 2nd bolt. Don't fall before clipping the 2nd bolt because it could be disastrous. Follow the bolts through fun climbing to the crux (at least for me) near the 4th bolt.

location: Dooser Wand > Frankenjura > Germany > Europe > International
desc: I thought I did this wrong to begin with~ but apparently you really do finish that far to the right of the anchor Climb alter weg up until where it veers right~ then continue up the arete and slab past 4 bolts to the anchor. The crux is rather cryptic~ very technical~ and lasts from the last bolt to the anchor. You should find yourself pretty far to the left and desperately stretching for the anchor. The first ascentionist said that was the safest place to place the anchor and safety preceeds comfort.

location: Arriba > Arico > Santa Cruz de Tenerife > Canary Islands > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Great climb with a cruxy traverse to the left. A test of your balance.

location: Forbidden Buttress > Legaston Quarry > North East > Scotland > United Kingdom > Europe > International
desc: Climb the smooth wall up to a small overlap~ and pull over this to gain a positive hold.  Move passed this to a second overlap which is crossed with difficulty.   Once over that climb up to the anchors.    A sustained and technical route.

location: Furia Latina > Mascun > Rodellar > Aragon > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Start mostly on sidepulls up to the break at about midheight. Climbing up and right through the bulge above is the crux on sidepulls and underclings. Continue up to the anchors above.

location: Hainbronner Pfeiler > Wachberg und Hainbronner Pfeiler > Frankenjura > Germany > Europe > International
desc: Nice arete climbing which makes some use of slopers and pressing~ in addition to the typical Frankenjura pockets. The last 2 bolts are shared with Nordwand. Caution: the 2nd bolt can be pretty tricky to clip on the onsight. It may be easier for you to continue a little higher up before trying to clip it.

location: Sex Shop > Chulilla > Valencia > Spain > Europe > International
desc: This route has a short crux down low but man is it hard. Felt much harder than the guidebook grade of 6b+ but maybe everyone that I saw get on it (myself included) was just missing something?
protection: Bolts to a two bolt anchor.

location: Dragonerwand > Frankendorfer Klettergarten > Frankenjura > Germany > Europe > International
desc: This isn't a very pretty climb~ but I found it really interesting. The book says it's easier after the 2nd bolt. However~ I found it to be a different kind of difficulty.   The route starts out bouldery up to the 2nd bolt. In fact~ stick clipping the first or placing a nut in the crack before it will do a lot for keeping this route comfortable. From the 2nd bolt~ you have to follow the odd crack up and left where you'll find that the crack climbs like a sloper rail in the middle~ making it pretty technically difficult.    Bemerkung: Cool bouldery start~ left hand in the pocket next to the 1st bolt~ right to crack in front of you~ twist left~ grab small block up with left~ and pull up onto shelf to clip. Rest~ two pockets to slopey crack~ balance up and left to right hand finger jam to clip anchor.

location: Gärdsås > Göteborg > Sweden > Europe > International
desc: Nice corner climbing 6+
protection: Small and medium cams and nuts

location: Nago wall > Arco and Surrounding Area > Italy > Europe > International
desc: This route climbs up a vertical section of rock almost exclusively on underclings. Start up to the obvious downward pointing flake and undercling this up~ then move to the next flake. More of the same will lead up to a delicate face crux~ followed by...another powerful undercling sequence. Sometimes seeps water.

location: Cima Ovest > Tre Cime di Lavaredo (Drei Zinnen)  Group > Dolomites > Italy > Europe > International
desc: This an absolute must if you're in the area!Super Classic! The first part is pretty easy~ and some bolts are found on the anchors. The hardest pitch is the first of the traverse~ it goes up and left trough a steep wall. It has many really bad pegs and a few bolts~ if you climb it at A0 take a hammer. This pitch had a fixed rope all the way in 2006. Please remove it if it is still there~ it's not a via ferrata after all. After the crux pitch you traverse for 60m (1or2 pitches) and then come the famous "17-Meter-Überhang"~ which goes free at 5.10+... The next pitch~ a horizontal traverse (5.8) can be very wet~ no problem though.  The rock is generally rather loose. After the traverse is completed the rock gets worse~ and some pitches are not that good.  When you get to the ringband~ keep going right around.  History: Two Germans were really close to the FA when the Italians Cassin and Ratti started climbing in the bad wheather and bagged another great FA. Much Mayr soloed this climb free and on-sight in 2002~ carrying only a 12m rope and a bit of equipment just in case in his backpack.
protection: A few bolts and many pegs. Fixed rope was found on the crux pitch in 2006... maybe~ hopefully not though~ it's still there. The pegs are all pretty bad. Take a rack of stoppers and camalots from .4 to 3.   Many draws for the harder pitches (15).   Take hammer and 5 pitons~ if you're able to use them. They are useful~ especially on the upper part.   Helmet is essential for the final pitches~ especially if the weather turned bad.   CAUTION: You cannot retreat from the route once you're behind the crux. The piches beyond this point are not much easier~ but also not harder except if they were in too bad conditions.Watch the conditions.The Comici should feel easy compared to this climb.

location: The Parthenos > West Coast > Lundy > South West > England > United Kingdom > Europe > International
desc: The climbing is sustained~ but with a low technical threshold~ and combined with some inspirational route finding provides a memorable experience.    Start below a beckoning flake above the left-hand end of the ledge-system. Climb the slab to reach the flake and follow it~ with escalating difficulty~ to its end. Pull through a bulge and move up into a scoop guarded by a black fang of rock. Pass the fang to its right into a second scoop and exit steeply leftwards to a black block (peg). Pull round the above into the base of a short black groove~ which provides a suitably wild finale.

location: Buena Sombra > Desplomilandia > El Chorro > Andalucia > Spain > Europe > International
desc: Another very natural looking line that utilizes the obvious tufa running through the bulge at mid-height.  This one is a bit harder and more  sustained than its left hand neighbor~ and much easier and more featured than the 7b to the right.

location: Tritoni > Cala Fuili > Cala Gonone > Sardinia > Italy > Europe > International
desc: Incredible route.  Sustained juggy and overhanging climbing. Don't even think about stopping at the first anchor.  The Crux above isn't as bad as you think although you better have the sequence right.  Past this the climbing turns stemmy & you enter a chimney.

location: Adrspach > Czech Republic > Europe > International
desc: A hard and new route up the North face of the tower~ Grade: VIIIc. Climb up easy terrain and stem between the two towers to clip the first bolt. Climb back down and get onto the more eastern side of the tower. Off a small stance with foot in the crack make a left then right hand double dyno then pull around the arete. Climb steep slab with minimal holds to a semi stance where you clip bolt 2. Make your way across to climbers right and meet up with the arete to finish the route. Trickery is involved.
protection: 2 bolts~ 1 fixed knot below the bolts.

location: Piton d'o Cuervo > Mascun > Rodellar > Aragon > Spain > Europe > International
desc: What looks like big holds from the ground aren't. Well you're partially right depending on how you climb this thing. Climb up to the first bolt however which way you desire. Going up to the right of the bolt line gives you some weird side pulls. Going left gives you big holds but a fall wouldn't be so wonderful. Some big holds and loose blocks after the starting crux gains a long reach to clip the anchor.

location: Callejon de las Tribus > Rancho San Lorenzo > Basaseachi > Chihuahua > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Revisar foto del topo para su localización.

location: E. Mur Principal (Adénosine) > Baldy > 15. Laurentians > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Start at the center of the slab and climb the 3 bolts and mantle~ climb straight up (or there is a small crack that goes to the left). The first 3 bolts are the crux followed by easier climbing. Be careful~ a last move awaits you at the top.  Départ au centre de la dalle et grimper les 3 bolts pour se rétablir debout~ grimper tout droit ( ou il y a une petite craque qui va vers la gauche ) 3 première bolts sont le crux suivi de grimpe plus facile. Attention un dernier mouvement vous attend au sommet .

location: 15. Cueva Cabeza de Vaca > Mogote del Valle > Vinales > Cuba > North America > International
desc: Power through the cruxy start using holds I named Spock and lobster claw into great jug haulin' and stalactite rompin'. Watch for wasps in the upper crack.   This is a must do route for the grade

location: McCrae Lake > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: One of Ontario's best 5.12's.   crack~ to overhang to slab climbing.    Packs a punch.
protection: 10 bolts & anchors. as of 2016 the anchors on this route are rendered unusable. (Needs retrobolting)  New anchor rings installed as of June 4~ 2020

location: Devil's Furnace > Cedar Park > Okanagan > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Traverses under the lip from the right to the farthest left anchors.  Climb easy terrain up questionable quality rock. Clip the lone perma draw below the roof~ perform your ceremonial chalk up and pull on~ clipping your second perma from an undercling or a positive right hand hold. Power up~ now the climb starts- gun for the obvious slot impossibly far to your left.  After settling your hands and feet~ skip the 3rd perma and directly clip the 4th (or clip them in the same motion). Gather yourself~ and power up for another big move to an impossibly farther hold to your left. Settle down~ clip the 5th perma~ and go fishing for holds. One last big move guards features that you can rest on and get something back~ before clipping the last perma and lone bolt~ moving up the arete to the anchors.
protection: 6 permas~ 1 bolt~ 2 bolt anchor with biners.

location: Gappage Zone > Higgyland > Powell River > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Climbs the leaning arete feature left of Major Attitude. Thin and technical climbing with an immediate balancy crux~ and a final bouldery finish. Final crux can be avoided by moving right and into the over hanging finish of Major Attitude~ which is still a very quality ending.  To set up a TR~ bring long slings to extend the chain anchors of Major Attitude. Route was not bolted due to the thin nature of the rock.

location: Mana wall > Panama > North America > International
desc: technical~ with a midway crux.

location: Claghorn Long Wall > Ontario North Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: the left side of the sharp arête to the top. seemingly spaced bolts makes more sense when the route is climbed staying on the left side of the arête.

location: Raven Crag > Banff National Park > Alberta > Canada > North America > International
desc: A hard opening move gains a crack in a left facing corner. From the 3rd bolt~ step left and execute cool moves between steep jugs that leads to a power draining~ sequential crux. Buckets finish it! * Completely Retrobolted (June 2016) by James Blackhall.

location: Quercus Cliff > Murrin Park > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Apparently the name (with proper pronounciation) might be a spin-off of a classic Yosemite pitch on the Rostrum...    Interesting climbing past some cool polish takes you past 5 bolts to a shallow left facing corner where an optional small cam could be placed. Either clip the intermediate chains and call it a 5.10~ or crank out a cruxy move clearing the overhang to some crimps and a tricky clip. (I believe this may have been an abandoned route from years ago and the bolts only were replaced?) From the ground~ this upper part looks super run out but it's really not bad at all and the bolts protect the hard moves and in between it is way easier. Another optional cam may be placed before clipping the last bolt. Finish with some cool and funky moves up a shallow layback and then up to the anchor.
protection: 7 protection bolts~ intermediate and upper anchor.    Optional cams from .5" - .75"

location: 15 - Sal de Mi > Jilotepec > Central Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: A balancey slab~ into a steep wave. A long power draining boulder problem on tiny crimps. Classic

location: Chanchullo/El Chonta > Chontalcoatlan > Central Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: This climb is a good introduction into the wild stalactite climbing of El Chonta.  With a moderate start~ wild steep climbing thru a roof and a crux finish~ this climb makes for a challenging OS.Climb up moderately steep heavily featured 5.11 ground to a nice rest below the super steep roof.  Jungle gym through the stalactites and battle through the crux finish.  Use many slings to keep the rope drag down.  Use caution cleaning and either TR the route~ or plan to tram off the fixed sling.
protection: Bolts to Anchors~ use alot of slings or the rope drag will get quite bad.

location: Forum > Costa Rica > North America > International
desc: This extremely technical climb is an instant classic with it’s variety of moves~ holds and climbing styles. La Via Lactea begins with tactful moves up the small arête to the left of the first bolt before a layback allows you to reach the two finger pocket (mono if your fingers are really large) and hoist up to the horizontal crack. Sneak a rest before using the sharp crimp to assist your attempt to the small jug. From here things really start to get fun with a gaston~ a high step~ a compression~ and a stretch for a taxing pocket that is deceivingly comfortable. If you find yourself on a right facing block handhold~ congratulations your work~ for the most part~ is complete. Finish the remainder of the route with everyone’s favorite type of climbing; big moves to big jugs. Just hope that the lactic acid in your arms hasn’t reached a tipping point that will see your send attempt take a downfall.

location: La Primera Plancha > Virgin Canyon > El Potrero Chico > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: If you like bouldery climbing with the crux right off the ground then you will like this route.    A large move off an undercling leads to a good hold and the first bolt.  From here make a hard move up and right~ clip the second bolt and move slightly left then up.  Eventually reach the large ledge that isn't nearly as good as it looks.  Shake here~ move up on some less than solid rock and clip the 4th bolt and pull a final 5.11 sequence before reaching easier ground and sharper rock before the anchors.

location: Labour Pains Ledge > Old Baldy > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: Prolonged difficult climbing on some of the best rock around~ crux at the bulge will have you fully contracted for a big move to a jug.

location: Valleycliffe Heights > Mamquam FSR > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: The next set of routes start off the ledge~  trail passes around large fir tree to get to base  I wouldn't try to scramble up to ledge super choss nothing was cleaned off that. -  "Danger"STICK CLIP FIRST BOLT.  Difficult start to a big jug~ to  hard steep finish .(

location: Land  Of The Free > El Toro (The Front Side) > El Potrero Chico > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: This climb is absolutely incredible sequential climbing on bomber rock with amazing exposure on the most beautiful rock in the Potrero; solid and crisp w/out being too sharp.  Vaguely reminiscent of~ but IMO~ much better than Levitation 29.  If off-vertical technical climbing heavy on the edges is your bag~ you'll be close to heaven on the upper half.     It's impossible to not love the upper pitches. Don't miss this one!    P1: We started with Apache Line (11b) which is excellent~ steep and a stout warmup~ but still probably easier than the 11d guidebook option. ~ 10 Bolts~ 35m    P2: 4th class on fixed rope up vertical terrain to another fixed rope on a 3rd class slab.     P3-5: Varieties of 5.10 slabbingon smooth rock with somewhat sparse bolting.  This section gives some people the willies.   Pitch 3: (10a)~ 5 bolts~ 25m. Head up a slab to a small crack. End up in the dihedral to below and left of a flaky roof. Can be linked with p4.    Pitch 4: (10c)~ 4 bolts~ 22m. Hollow flaky roof and then right up a larger crack.    Pitch 5: (10d)~ 9 bolts~ 30m. Head toward the wall center on thin crimps interspersed with good holds.     The next three pitches are one intricate~ stellar face pitch after another.     Pitch 6: 5.11b~ 9 bolts~ 30m. Tricky~ thin climbing up a nice edge.    Pitch 7: 5.11d~ 8 bolts~ 27m. Head up to the mini roof to a small pocket throw up to a nice crimp.    Pitch 8: 5.11b~ 9 bolts~ 30m. Fun traverse right to a dihedral for fantastic chimneying.    Pitch 9: 5.11c~ 12 bolts~ 28m. Crimpy sequence on a column feature. Head straight up and don't be confused by Prisoneros del Cielo on the right.    Pitch 10: 5.12b~ 12 bolts~ 20m. Hard immediately~ but stick the 3rd bolt and it's basically over. Cruz up jugs to the next wall and boulder around it to the end. Enjoy the view!     P10: 12b.  The final pitch is hard right off the belay and ends under a big roof. Supposed to be solid at the grade and tricky.    You should expect some loose rock~ vegetation and a little dirty climbing but over all the route is pretty solid and the climbing is great.     Descent: rap the route. A 70 meter rope works for all rappels on simul. Most pitches were about 30m except where noted. I've provided the guidebook ratings which are fairly solid but by no means sandbaggy by Potrero standards~ or at least compared to the Mota.
protection: About 16 and a couple of long slings.  A #1 and #2 can be used to tame some of the runouts. A few small nuts may come in handy.

location: La Primera Plancha > Virgin Canyon > El Potrero Chico > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Start off the ledge~ stick clip the first bolt then engage a very difficult boulder problem to easier climbing. Traverse far left to the anchor for one of the 11s. A decent route

location: The Pit > Surfers/Survival Beaches (Aguadilla) > Puerto Rico > North America > International
desc: Sustained climbing out a roof to a big undercling which is the only rest before the crux section of the roof. After establishing on the vertical face it’s easy climbing to the anchors.

location: Main Face > Flatrock > Avalon Peninsula > Newfoundland > Newfoundland and Labrador > Canada > North America > International
desc: Climb thin holds straight up the face and to the right side of a small roof before following the bolt line right to the bigger rough and a finishing crux.

location: Fern Hill > Mamquam FSR > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Funky climbing to a classic Squamish granite crux up high.

route: Where to Toss at the Beach
location: (b) Muscle Beach > (d) Maternal Group > Skaha > Okanagan > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: It’s all about the jugs!  Work your way up a left facing flake feature with an interesting combination of laybacking~scums~ and kneebars until you get to the obvious crux.  Some will dyno~ some will heel hook~ and some will go static; all fun options.  Traverse right at the sixth bolt to join Where’s the Beach.

location: Overhanging Wall > Metcalfe Rock > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: none listed

location: Fern Hill > Mamquam FSR > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Power endurance with a sting in the tail. Nice steep climbing. Bolts are a little more spaced than the average Fern route.  The top runout is easy.

location: Yellow Card Wall > The Swamp > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: none listed

location: A. Dévers des anges > Baldy > 15. Laurentians > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: In its softer version~ it is possible to avoid some harder moves that would make it 12+. Choose the way you want to do it.  Dans sa version plus douce~ il est possible d'éviter certains mouvements plus difficiles qui feraient d'elle un 12+. Choisissez la manière dont vous voulez la faire.

location: Food Truck Wall > Kioskos (Ciales) > Puerto Rico > North America > International
desc: This interesting route has a tricky crux getting past an overlap feature at mid-height.  Bouldery and technical on small holds then easier climbing near the top yet sustained enough to keep one thinking until the end.  The crux is not the overhang but the slight arete feature just above it.
protection: Ten stainless steel bolts to a titanium U bolt anchor.  Please rappel from the anchor when cleaning to save wear and tear on the bolts.

location: Baby Pneu > Western CWM > Gatineau Park > 07. Outaouais > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Bouldery climb on relatively thin holds and deadpoints.  Start in the pit and crank your way up this beautiful climb.    probably 5.12a for taller climbers.

location: North Shore Area > Lion's Head > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: Another face climb that starts from the ground~ might be a bit reachy.

location: Cerro Agujerado /the arch cave > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: This is the right-most route on the Dong Wall. Climb up under and alongside the big black stalactite. Lower-off anchors.
protection: Bolt hangers and lower off anchors.

location: c. Secteur Forteresse > F. Le Mur École > Palissades de Charlevoix > 03. Quebec City, Charlevoix, Portneuf > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Climb the line to the top.  Hard by all accounts.  Grimpez la ligne jusqu'en haut.  C'est dur aux yeux de tous.

location: Titan Wall > Lion's Head > Ontario South Bouldering and Rock > Ontario > Canada > North America > International
desc: Start up about 20 feet left of Drunken Master; head right after the second bolt.

location: Obsession Wall > Esler Bluffs near Williams Lake > Interior Plateau > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Follow the bolts through steepest part of the roof

location: Lower Wall > Acéphale > Bow Valley > Alberta > Canada > North America > International
desc: The wandery middle line starts easy then straight away tackles a boulder problem over a large bulge. Fun tech climbing gets to a good rest~ with another boulder problem lurking above. Great quality

location: Macho Crap > Cedar Park > Okanagan > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: A roped boulder problem on a big~ steep roof!  Climb up and left (~2.5 m) on dodgy rock to get to the start of the climb~ clipping your first 2 bolts from this stance. Leave your stance using mediocre holds to set yourself up for a monster V5 dead-point (climbing crux)~ and then figure out how to clip your 3rd bolt (clipping crux).  Then~ this rig is just big dead point after big dead-poin after big...nope~ just 2 more moves and you're effectively done~ reaching up to clip one last bolt that probably no one has ever fallen on. The anchors aren't far above!  Sadly~ this crux is very height dependent (call this the 180 cm height/wingspan grade). As this climb follows a seam in the roof~ there may be alternative solutions for shorter climbers~ but I could imagine adding a bonus letter grade or more!   If you can~ pre-hang your draws. Long draw bolt 3 for sure to make clipping more reasonable~ perhaps bolt 2 as well so you can reach it before lift off.   There is an old button head less than 2 m off the ground~ do not clip this and do not start going straight up this. Near as I can figure~ this is to aid in cleaning and can be used to help keep you out of the tick tree if you're being lowered.
protection: 4 bolts (one hidden over the lip)~ fixed anchor (1 bolt with a biner~ one hook)

location: a. Secteur de gauche > b. Lac Castor > Les Contreforts > 14. Lanaudiere > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: If you don't have strong fingers~ this route will let you know. Not a long one but intense.

location: Top Shelf > Mamquam FSR > Squamish > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Layback flake to a technical bolted arete (crux) and some nice cracks. Very sequency
protection: 5 bolts~ gear micro to hands. Optional 4 for the bottom

location: La Palma (The Palm) Sport > El Salto > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Fun~ kicked back climbing on (mostly) hand sized pockets interspersed with a few good rests. Long~ potentially heartbreaker move at the end.

location: La Boca > El Salto > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Incredible climb. Aptly named~ beware the flying might not happen where you expect.

location: 04. Guajiro Ecologico > Mogote del Valle > Vinales > Cuba > North America > International
desc: I would recommend stick clipping the second bolt since the start is really bouldery and before you can clip the second one~ you have to go far left~ right in the middle of the crux and the fall is in a pendulum. The crux involve monos/bi-doigts. Once you pull the crux~ the route gets thin and balancy. Be ready for some excitement just before the anchor.

location: Sorrow's End > Nova Scotia > Canada > North America > International
desc: A tricky start leads to a high first bolt and a rest ledge. Off the ledge follow the bolts through two horizontals before making a short traverse to the right. Head up~ following the bolts through the technical crux. Moving to the final horizontal at the top can be done statically or dynamically. It's big so choose your poison. An extended draw can be clipped before hitting the horizontal.

location: Conde de Mana > Dominican Republic > North America > International
desc: Follows the right side of Northwest wall. FA: Cody Roth 2012   Triple Doce 5.12c   Triple Doce 5.12c on NW wall
protection: Stainless bolts~ seems to be missing the first two bolts off the start

location: Main wall > Sanatorium > 03. Quebec City, Charlevoix, Portneuf > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Same start as Toux and Tuberculose~ climb the diagonal crack~ join the second one and then head left for something more delicate with small horizontals.  Même départ que pour Toux et Tuberculose~ on monte dans la fissure diagonale~ on rejoint la deuxième et on part vers quelque chose de plus délicat avec de petites horizontales.
protection: Fixed draws. The fixed draws will be removed shortly. They're old and worn. Suggest using your own draws.  Dégaines fixes. Les dégaines seront retirées prochainement. Elles sont vieilles et usées...Il est suggéré d'utiliser ses propres dégaines.

location: Las Animas Wall > El Salto > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Another classic route. Start with easy steep climbing that flows well to a bouldery crux 20 ft up finish on nice cryptic tufa climbing to the chains.

location: La Pared de Los Gatos > San Isidro Canyon > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Crux gabbing the uñas del gato and stepping up on delicate feet.

location: Lower Wall > Acéphale > Bow Valley > Alberta > Canada > North America > International
desc: Just right of Last Stop 305 Bus. Shares the start with Chawesome Corner~ 12b. Tread carefully through the ratty 5.10 start to a no hands rest below the corner. Steep pumpy climbing leads to a crux near the top of the corner and some exposed slab moves to a fixed draw. At the 13th bolt~ head left on the obvious bolt line into the steeper terrain. Steep juggy climbing takes you to the top of the wall~ complete with a tufa pinch crux!
protection: 17 Bolts - Clip-n-Go Anchor - Stick Clip the first bolt

location: Las Animas Wall > El Salto > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Begin near where the road meets the wall on slabby orange rock; the climb is easily identified by an obvious hand-sized hueco and a mono about 50 up.  Thin moves off the deck lead to rests on some tufas out right.  Then things get steep.  Follow tufas and then jugs until you can traverse up and left to the chain anchor on Tufalero~ but do not clip this anchor.  Instead~ bust up and back right past two more well-spaced clips to two stalactites and the anchor.  This pitch has been called 5.13a but I thought it was more in the mid-twelve range; either way~ great climbing.

location: La Palma (The Palm) Sport > El Salto > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Work up to a deceptively tough tufa that demands some clever dropknee~ lieback shenanigans. Maybe even a kneebar? Gain a rest in the rounded corner system~ then work up the arete.

location: Orange Corner > Paint Mountain (Haines Junction) > Yukon Territory > Canada > North America > International
desc: Future sport route. Bolted anchor up top for TR projecting. The line is probably in the high 12's. If you find a way to get up this thing~ let me know.

location: (f) Raven's Castle > (g) Southern Crags > Skaha > Okanagan > British Columbia > Canada > North America > International
desc: Quite a deceptive route with a slightly different character than other Skaha routes.  The crux comes about a third of the way up passing a right facing groove.  A welcome rest follows the crux and then another difficult and hard to read sequence leads to a pumpy run to the anchor.

location: Olla > Rancho San Lorenzo > Basaseachi > Chihuahua > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Revisar foto del topo para su localización. Comparte reunion con la Mochadedos

route: El Son del Viento (The Tune of the Wind)
location: El Diente > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: El Son del Viento~ 5.12d~ 420m~ 15 Pitches   -----   The north face of El Diente is an incredible wall that breaks the desert cut ridge of the Sierra Madre with its distinct tooth shape. The route takes a more or less direct line to the summit through various limestone formations including a number of tufa sections. The north face was attempted many years prior to this route and the old equipment can be seen once up on the wall and acts as a historic tribute to the boldness of the climbers of the era~ true visionaries~ generations ahead of their time.    P1: Climb the blocky slab to a wide crack that leads to a good ledge (5.10a)~ 25m~ 9 bolts + Anchors   P2: A steepening slab that has some great moves through its first dihedral. Above~ move through crimps to a belay below the roof (5.10c) 25m~ 6 bolts + Anchors   P3: The crux pitch of the route that can be easily skipped via some A0. Climb out right to the roof where you get 3D with some amazing tufas to a sharp and crimpy top out. (5.12d / A0) 15m~ 9 bolts + Anchors   P4: Traverse out left to some good but sharp holds and move up the small tufas to a belay below a small roof. Pumpy! (5.12a) 25m~ 11 bolts + Anchors   P5: Climb the small roof into easier ground through rain pockets. Move into the big black tufa~ finishing at its top (5.11d) 25m~ 13 bolts + Anchors   P6: Traverse left into the dihedral via tricky foot work and neat lay backs near the giant foot ledge. (5.11b) 15m~ 6 + Anchors   P7: Head up and right into the dihedral~ battling small stemming sections through the continuing small roofs to a belay at a cross and tribute to a fallen climber (5.11c) 35m~ 13 bolts + Anchors   P8: Scramble across the ledge and up the face~ pushing into the slab as the arête begins. (Some vegetation) Finish at a stance on a good ledge (5.11b) 30m~ 11 bolts + Anchors   P9: Climb up into the corner and battle the small roof on its right side (crux) Move up the easy slab to the chains. Some blocks move slightly but the pitch is mostly solid. (5.10c) 30m~ 8 bolts + Anchors   P10: A perfect fist crack that moves out right near the end and finishes on a ledge below a roof. (5.10b) 35m~ 9 bolts + Anchors   P11: Pull the roof on its right side (crux) and move onto the slab for some technical climbing through side pulls and good edges (5.12a) 30m~ 12 bolts + Anchors   P12: Delicately move left from the belay~ making progress into the large tufa corner. Climb up to the giant hanging tufa that rings hard and move past to its right into yet more amazing tufa. Move up into the corner through perm draws to the chains. (5.11c) 25m~ 11 bolts + Anchors   P13: Traverse out right under roof to a series of amazing tufas that almost feel manufactured. Exit the roof through technical moves. (5.11c) 25m~ 9 bolts + Anchors   P14: Climb the technical face through a number of good side pulls. Move out right near the 3rd bolt and make easier movement back left and to the chains. (5.11d) 30m~ 11 bolts + Anchors   P15: A short class IV sections with a single 5.6 move. (5.6) 1 bolt. 10m   Summit: Scramble some Class IV to the palm topped summit that also various other interesting fauna. 40m    Descent: Rappel the route using all the fixed draws along the way to ensure you can reach the anchor from the overhang. Rappel directly down from the anchor of pitch 7 to pitch 5 using the perma draws on the wall.    Equipped and FA & FFA Gaz Leah~ Sergio 'Tiny' Almada Barrera~ & Octavio “8” Aragon   January 22nd~ 2016

location: Carrot Creek > Bow Valley > Alberta > Canada > North America > International
desc: Clip a long draw on the anchor and continue up a technical wall to a hard and committing crux below the anchors.

location: 2. Zébrée > Mont-King > Val-David > 15. Laurentians > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: Formerly this route was known as Requiem (5.11b)~ but many holds broke and thus it got renamed and its rating upgraded. A short route that features an airy traverse. Start on the ledge where the Verrat de Vérot starts and where Gangrène ends. Go as far as you can right and do a downward move to get established on the horizontal. Traverse right on good holds until you reach Zébrée. Jam your leg~ place gear and get ready for not so good holds and hard to place gear. When you reach the end~ mantle onto a slab.  Autrefois cette voie était connue sous le nom de Requiem (5.11b)~ mais de nombreuses prises se sont cassées et elle a donc été rebaptisée et sa cotation a été actualisée. Un parcours court avec une traversée aérienne. Commencez sur la vire où commence le Verrat de Vérot et où se termine Gangrène. Allez aussi loin que possible à droite et faites un mouvement vers le bas pour vous établir sur une horizontale. Traversez à droite sur de bonnes prises jusqu'à ce que vous arrivez à Zébrée. Jammez votre jambe~ placez de la pro et préparez-vous à des mauvaises prises et de la protection difficile à placer. Quand vous atteignez la fin~ rétablissez vous sur la dalle.
protection: Up to BD Camalot #2  Jusqu'a un BD Camalot #2

location: Main wall > Sanatorium > 03. Quebec City, Charlevoix, Portneuf > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: The two first bolts added by David Gill were removed to keep Virus (an earlier route opened by Jeff Beaulieu) trad. Follow the left curving depression under the small roof~ exit the roof by the right and follow the fixed pro on the left.  Les premier deux ancrages rajoutés par David Gill furent enlevés afin que Virus (une voie ouverte l'année d'avant par Jeff Beaulieu) demeurent sur protection naturelle. Suivez la dépression courbant vers la gauche sous le petit toit~ le sortir par la droite et suivez les plaquettes à gauche.
protection: Trad pro for first few meters followed by bolts after the roof.  Protection naturelle pour les premiers metres suivi de plaquettes passé le toit.

location: Twin Ribs, Down Under > Gatineau Park > 07. Outaouais > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: First crux of the beast and exit to anchors on the right.

location: Cap des Pères > 15. Laurentians > Quebec > Canada > North America > International
desc: 30m. Great cruxy section mid-way.  30 mètres. Superbe section crux en plein milieu.

location: Las Agujas (The Spires) > El Potrero Chico > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Climb 40 feet of really weak~ chossy rock (about 5.10) up into to some cool stalactites. Then pull for 10 feet of hard climbing on really good rock and take it to the chain. The lower section could see a good bit of rock fall. Be very careful. Wear your lid!
protection: Bolts. Shares anchor with Jungle Honey

location: Upper Wall > Acéphale > Bow Valley > Alberta > Canada > North America > International
desc: Many intricate cruxes stand between you and the anchors including one at ground level. Start in a mailbox slot just left of the first bolt.

location: El Fin de Semana (Weekend Wall) > El Potrero Chico > Nuevo Leon > Northern Mexico > Mexico > North America > International
desc: Climb the first bolts of Scavenger and then continue straight up into the business. A few bouldery cruxes split by some technical climbing on small holds keeps you fighting the pump for a majority of the route.

location: Pierce's Pass > Blue Mountains > New South Wales > Australia > International
desc: 9 glorious Blue Mountains pitches with plenty of ironstone buckets~ as one might imagine.
protection: Good bolts and belays on comfy ledges~ no major runouts.

location: Sector 1 > Mount York > Blue Mountains > New South Wales > Australia > International
desc: The crux~ for some~ is getting off the ground--definitely a tricky start~ with no margin for error.  Two additional cruxes through the pitch.
protection: PG pro at best; bring a #5 Camalot for the run-out top.

location: Lost World > Fern Road > Western Australia > Australia > International
desc: Very sharp chrystally slab with a mean blank section at the middle. The crux can be skipped by going to the right and climbing up the crack.
protection: 3 glued in carrots. two bolt anchor.

location: Mount Rosea > The Grampians > Victoria > Australia > International
desc: Great route with fun moves and good protection the entire way.  Several traverses look difficult~ but the holds and protection are always there.  Continuously interesting and varying climbing.  Great views across the Grampians.  P1:  Up the featured wall~ moving into the corner~ up on the block~ then traverse right to a bolted anchor. P2:  Straight up the corner from the anchor.  Belayed on the left.  Could have easily linked up with P3. P3:  Short pitch up and a bit left to an alcove. P4:  Up left side of the corner system~ and moving right halfway up.  This was the crux for me.  Up to a block under a roof system.  Climb on the block~ then traverse right (better holds and pro than it looks).  Can belay after the traverse~ or make easy moves around right an up to a big ledge.  Watch for rope drag on this pitch.  If rope drag is managed well~ can easily link with P5. P5:  Very short pitch.  Right and up~ then left and up to summit.  Join hiking trail towards summit (left) for 5-10 minutes~ then down Giant's Staircase to base of cliff.
protection: Standard rack.  Used a #4 a few times~ but would have been fine without it.

location: Sector 5 > Mount Piddington > Blue Mountains > New South Wales > Australia > International
desc: This route ascends a beautiful right facing flake to a ledge with an anchor.  Lots of laybacking~ but with good rests and gear.
protection: A set of cams should be about all you need to 3" or maybe 3.5".

location: The Organ Pipes > (2) Central Left > Mount Arapiles > Victoria > Australia > International
desc: Start up a thin shallow crack to a highly-featured slab. Step slightly left when the features disappear~ then step back right into another crack. Pull through big holds as the rock steepens. From a good stance~ move up and slightly right as the column tops out. Belay off of bolts placed horizontally - extended anchor required for top-roping. A single 60m rope barely gets you down.

location: Medlow Bath > Blue Mountains > New South Wales > Australia > International
desc: A great little multi-pitch that has a ledge fit for 10 people at the first anchor.  Very straight forward.

location: Central Gully Left > (2) Central Left > Mount Arapiles > Victoria > Australia > International
desc: Climb up Beautiful Possibilities but continue straight up.
protection: single set of cams and nuts

location: Narrabeen Slabs > Sydney > New South Wales > Australia > International
desc: Vertical sport up to slightly overhanging finish with fun moves on jugs.

location: West Side > New York > Blue Mountains > New South Wales > Australia > International
desc: hand / fist crack in corner
protection: standark rack up to a 4. I placed a 6 but you dont need it

location: Mount Fox > The Grampians > Victoria > Australia > International
desc: This is a classic face climb up the silver screen wall of Mt. Fox.  Begin at the right side of the wall at a short~ 20' long jam crack in a small~ right-facing corner.  Ascend this pumpy crack (crux)~ and turn the corner onto the main face.  Runner gear in the crack well to prevent rope drag.  Diagonal left and up across the shield of immaculate grey rock~ clipping a few bolts along the way (supplemental small gear).  Finish high up the left side of the face; two ropes to rap.

location: Colosseum Wall > (1) Southern Crags > Mount Arapiles > Victoria > Australia > International
desc: Blast up the obvious crack on fingerlocks and handjams. Step left to the anchor.  Bolted anchor

location: Bells Line of Road > Blue Mountains > New South Wales > Australia > International
desc: Fun overhang start like a lot of routes on the wall. 5th from the left.

location: Preludes Wall > (3) Central Right > Mount Arapiles > Victoria > Australia > International
desc: Follow a faint crack that allows you to sneak wires in intermittently. There is a runout after the first piece but you will get gear when you start pulling harder. Finish on the top for anchors.
protection: single set of nuts and cams

location: The Atridae > (1) Southern Crags > Mount Arapiles > Victoria > Australia > International
desc: If you like smooth flaring cracks with some off width thrown in for good measure~ this is your line.
protection: single set of nuts and cams. doubles in hands

location: Left Main Wall > Kangaroo Point Cliffs > Queensland > Australia > International
desc: Face climbing with a mantle finish

location: Bundaleer > The Grampians > Victoria > Australia > International
desc: Great climbing~ good pro. Layback~ but there are always good rest options.
protection: Nuts and Friends work well. Bring ample.

location: Upper Yesterday Gully > Yesterday Gully > (6) Pharos Group > Mount Arapiles > Victoria > Australia > International
desc: Climb up into a big corner system and then peer over at the traverse you need to make. Fiddle with gear and try to get excited enough to pull around the corner. Do so am breathe a sign of relief as you just pulled the crux. The rest of the route should be very pleasant.
protection: Single set of cams and nuts

location: Left Main Wall > Kangaroo Point Cliffs > Queensland > Australia > International
desc: Go up following the line of 3 RB's. From the ledge at 2/3 height~ go left up the crack in the face (natural pro) to DBB
protection: 3 bolts then take trad gear for the last 1/3 of the route

location: (9) The Far Northern Group > Mount Arapiles > Victoria > Australia > International
desc: Good face clibing up and right to crack~ over a bulge got about 6 feet right to a shallow groove to anchors

location: Shipley Upper > Blue Mountains > New South Wales > Australia > International
desc: Steep and bouldery route on the far right side of the wall. Although its kinda short~ its good fun on steep jugs.

location: Wave Wall > Centennial Glen > Blue Mountains > New South Wales > Australia > International
desc: Jugs. The whole way! Pumpy though.

location: [CLOSED] The Gallery > The Grampians > Victoria > Australia > International
desc: More steep pulling on slightly smaller holds than the two climbs to the left. A bit more cruxy with some accuracy moves and a high pump crux at the lip of the roof.     Stick clip useful.

location: The Freezer > Blue Mountains > New South Wales > Australia > International
desc: Same start as Rat$ then head straight up from ledge using the undercling rather then moving left.

location: The Freezer > Blue Mountains > New South Wales > Australia > International
desc: No description

location: The Freezer > Blue Mountains > New South Wales > Australia > International
desc: No description

location: Betty Blue Area > Thompson's Point > Nowra > New South Wales > Australia > International
desc: Climb pockets and edges on a very nice gently overhung face with a crux around the 4th bolt.  Then continue up a small arete/scoop feature with some funky ( and potentially cruxy) sloper action guarding the anchors.

location: The Bluffs > (4) Bluffs > Mount Arapiles > Victoria > Australia > International
desc: This is a truly beautiful route put up by the bold and visionary Mark Moorhead.  Despatched presents a formidable challenge to the seasoned trad leader and is a good entry point to the hard trad lines of the Mount.      Begin just down and right of Thunder Crack on Bluff Major.  Climb up a fin and right past two bolts to a stance.  Punch it up a steep cruxy bulge to a pair of horizontals (good gear)~ and then punch it again up a thin groove (#2/#3 RP) to thank-god gear at a very poor stance.  From here perform the exposed crux traverse right past sequential holds and poor feet to a final~ good cresent-shaped hold.  A few more moves to the bolted anchor by the large horn.  A free-hanging rappel from here gets you down~ or continue up at worthwhile 5.11.      The anchor at the the top of the first pitch is the anchor for the infamous "Giant Rope Swing"... a great rest-day activity.
protection: A light rack to a #1 Camalot.

location: The Atridae > (1) Southern Crags > Mount Arapiles > Victoria > Australia > International
desc: After the second leftward traverse hard moves over a bulge. Additional difficulties gaining the slab at the top. Wandering line linking weaknesses up an impressive wall.
protection: Light rack to #1 camalot to supplement the few bolts~ bolt anchor to lower from.

location: Shipley Upper > Blue Mountains > New South Wales > Australia > International
desc: Begin just right of Jack High. The start is quite tricky and keeps asking for full attention. If one stops at the first anchors it goes at AUS 20 (5.10d/11a) otherwise continue into the corner above and know how to gaston.

location: West Rock > Tres Piedras > Taos Area > New Mexico
desc: Growth Spurt starts right and slightly uphill of the Alien on a brown face.  Climb a slab to the start of the route.  Face and crack climb past a couple bolts and gear until you step right~ climbing up past more gear and bolts. Eventually trends left to a fun technical finish ending at two bolts and chains.    Stays in the shade almost all the time.  Excellent for when the Mosaic Wall is baking or there are too many other climbers.
protection: couple of finger sized cams or nuts.

location: Tornado Alley > Last Chance Canyon > New Mexico, other Southern Areas > New Mexico
desc: Despite the more difficult grade this is probably the best warmup on Tornado Alley.  It feels easier than the 5.10's to the left to me.  Start up easy rock on good holds thru the first few bolts.  Above this the crux hits~ requiring some longer pulls and a few smaller holds.  Above the crux the difficulty eases~ and fun climbing leads to the chains.    Don't let the 5.11- grade deter you from getting on this line as it's the best moderate on the wall.

location: 1. Bat Cave > Vista Verde Crag > Taos Area > New Mexico
desc: The only climb remotely resembling a warm up in the bat cave proper area.    The crux is the start over a bad landing to a high first bolt.  So you might want to stick clip it.  Make a few hard moves up to and past the first bolt to easier climbing ahead.

location: North Cliffband > Cochiti Mesa > Capulin Canyon and Cochiti Mesa Area Crags > Jemez Mountains and Jemez Valley > New Mexico
desc: This is a good route on excellent rock.  Unfortunately the crux start demoralizes many would-be climbers.  Begin with a beautiful set of heavily chalked pockets that are unfortunately much more thin and slopy than they appear from the ground.  Once you are 3 feet off the ground the pockets improve dramatically and the climbing eases.  This is the first opportunity to clip the first bolt~ so a stick clip is recommended.  More good pockets lead to a horizontal break~ then a short thin section that leads to a sea of unusual nubbins and small chickenheads.  Follow the steepening wall to the anchor.
protection: [4] bolts~ 2 BA.  This ones easy to toprope.

location: Independence Gully > Tres Piedras > Taos Area > New Mexico
desc: This overhanging crack (right of Dependence) is unusually pumpy and sustained for TP.  It looks a little bit crumbly~ but climbs really well! Stem~ lieback~ catch a couple of jugs on the right side to a really steep finish!  Very unique for the area.  The crack is a little bit grainy in places~ so confidently placing good gear from pumpy stances can be a little bit tricky.
protection: Nuts and cams to 3"~ include micro cams and maybe doubles in finger sizes.   2-bolt anchor.

location: Below The Old New Place > White Rock > Los Alamos & White Rock > New Mexico
desc: One of the easier climbs at BTONP~ Instant Dogma is unfortunately not quite as fun as it appears from the ground. Climb up the pronounced arete~ using sharp~ incut pockets on both sides. The crux is probably the off-balance exit sequence past the third bolt~ but the climbing is pretty sustained for the whole route.

location: North/West side > The Overlook > White Rock > Los Alamos & White Rock > New Mexico
desc: An overhanging wall with monster pockets and some stellar climbing. The opening moves are a little tricky so don't blow the first clip as it is a horrible landing. Get the first bolt and let the fun pocket pumping begin~ and then continue to the thin and tricky exit up onto a shelf. The crux is at the last bolt.
protection: 4 bolts to a 2 bolt chained anchor. Stick clip recommended.

location: The Candy Store > Wild and Scenic > Taos Area > New Mexico
