desc: Start in the chossy crack system just right of the main crack system. Climb up 15 feet and place adequate gear before stepping over left into the main crack system.    The rock quality improves as you climb higher. The jams are steep but bomber. Near the top of the crack you will find the crux which is well protected by gear near your feet. Stellar line!   On the kid.
protection: Cams from fingers to #3 camalot. Maybe a single set of nuts.

location: Banshee Wall > Porvenir Canyon > Las Vegas / El Porvenir > New Mexico, other Northern Areas > New Mexico
desc: Lamia is a fun~ varied route climbing up to~ and through~ the major chimney system on the right side of the Banshee Wall. The first three pitches are great quality rock while the rock quality on the upper third of the route deteriorates a bit. Still~ it’s a worthy route to the top of the wall.  Pitch 1 (5.10-~ 25’)– A short pitch. Place big gear behind the massive detached flake’s left end and climb up around the outside edge of the flake (it’s too narrow to climb it as an offwidth) to a big ledge on top of the flake. While you could keep going into the next pitch~ it’s best to belay here to lessen the amount of rope out for the follower and makes for better communication. Gear for belay.  Pitch 2 (5.10+~ 100’) – Climb the rampy dihedral up and left to reach another rampy dihedral back right. Continue up the dihedral to a short~ step finishing dihedral to a small ledge. Gear for belay.  Pitch 3 (5.11-~ 200’)– Step left from the ledge into the splitter crack up the face. Good jamming leads to a tough pull over a small roof. Continue up the crack as the difficulty eases off and climbing easier~ blocky~ ledgy terrain all the way up to the huge ledge and terrace at the base of the huge chimney/corner above. Fixed nuts/webbing for belay on huge ledge.  Pitch 4 (5.9~ 50’)– Another short pitch. Climb the corner and wide chimney (trickier than it looks) up to a big~ comfy ledge out left. Gear for belay.  Pitch 5 (5.10~ 160’)– Tip toe up the corner and wide crack until the crack turns into a chimney. Chimney up the featured chimney for about 20 feet and exit the chimney to right on a good ledge at the base of a steepening wall. Gear for belay.  Pitch 6 (5.10-~ 90’)– Climb the face above the ledge with some trickier-than-it-looks moves until the angle backs off a bit. Climb up into the alcove at the top of the corner and climb through a cool hole in the top of the alcove blocks to the top of the wall. Gear for belay.
protection: A double rack from finger to hands. #3~ #4~ #5~ #6. Nuts. Long runners. The big cams are not really necessary if you cruise the start but could also prove useful on the fifth pitch (although we didn't have anything bigger than #4 on our ascent.)

location: Drunk Wall > El Rito > New Mexico
desc: Fun~ steep climbing through a bulge with an airy finish out left on a slightly-suspect but cool tufa-like feature.
protection: Six to eight bolts to anchor with lowering hardware.

location: My Secret Garden > La Cueva Canyon, Upper > Sandia Mountains > Albuquerque Area > New Mexico
desc: Quality. Climb either BWJ or Pocket Cougar to anchors then up the beautiful face to a top anchor.

location: Main Sector > Ice Cream Parlor > Capulin Canyon > Capulin Canyon and Cochiti Mesa Area Crags > Jemez Mountains and Jemez Valley > New Mexico
desc: The first half of the route is a shallow V-slot that requires a little bit of off-width-style heel-toe. The slot terminates in a small roof and then transitions via jugs to a steep finger crack. It's only 50 feet long~ but every bit of that is good climbing.
protection: Double set from #0.1 C3s to #1 Camalot. One one #2 for the top of the little roof.

location: South Side, Big Enchilada > Big Enchilada, The > White Rock > Los Alamos & White Rock > New Mexico
desc: If you're going to climb a 5.11 at the Big Enchilada~ this is a good choice.    Up a broken dihedral~ pull a small roof~ and layback (1st crux) up to another overhung crux passing over a bulge below the prow.
protection: TR~ or lead this with a standard rack up to 2"~ with 2 ea. of smaller cams and TCUs helpful.   2-bolt anchor~ reachable from the top.

location: Potrillo Cliffs > White Rock > Los Alamos & White Rock > New Mexico
desc: Difficult/steep crack climbing leads to a 5.6 finish.

location: The Sanctuary > Capulin Canyon > Capulin Canyon and Cochiti Mesa Area Crags > Jemez Mountains and Jemez Valley > New Mexico
desc: From the base of Nun Too Soon~ you can't miss this offwidth roof. Starts in #5s~ opens up to a #6~ then pinches down from #4s to #3s through the overhang.   Note: Currently (Nov 2019) there is only one bolt hanger with a leaver biner.

location: North Rabbit Ear > Rabbit Ears Area > Organ Mountains > Las Cruces Area Climbing > New Mexico
desc: This is a fairly intricate crack climb that hosts a few exiting crack to face transitions at the top of pitch 2 and the start of pitch 3.     Pitch 1 5.8   Pitch 2 5.9   Pitch 3 5.10   Pitch 4 5.10+/11-    Pitch 5 5.2
protection: Medium to large Stoppers. Double up the cams to BD #3 (offsets are nice!)~ 1 #4 Camalot is useful. Long slings.

location: Chilly Willy Wall > Las Conchas > Jemez Mountains and Jemez Valley > New Mexico
desc: Before I cleaned this and climbed it~ I thought it would be an average 5.9 route. Turned out much trickier~ difficult and fun than I expected.   Climb crunchy and licheny rock in the the dihedral right of No Sketching to shared anchors with that route. Climb up the dihedral using offset cracks and holds on the dihedral's right side. A strenuous pull between bolts one and two rewards you with easier climbing in the middle section. Stem your way up and climb the faint arête on the right. Move left to the finishing bulge and a perfectly-placed pocket to pull the bulge to the anchor.  I've done loads of brushing and cleaning on it because I think it's a good addition to the area but for sure it needs more brushing if one is so inclined. Expect parts of the coursely-grained rock to crumble with more ascents.
protection: Six bolts to the anchor of No Sketching. Recommend stick-clipping first bolt.

location: Possum Junction > The Terrace > Albuquerque Area > New Mexico
desc: The climbing is easy for two bolts and the action starts at the third bolt (look for the hidden left pocket for an easy third clip).  The next moves are relatively insecure.

location: Main Cliff > Capulin Canyon > Capulin Canyon and Cochiti Mesa Area Crags > Jemez Mountains and Jemez Valley > New Mexico
desc: Pretty fun thin hands. The blocks you climb over look pretty scary but seemed OK when pried on and jumped on.

location: South Rock > Tres Piedras > Taos Area > New Mexico
desc: Excellent friction climbing on this one.  Bolts close together at the crux make this a good one to try 5.11 slab~ but it does take climbing a section of 5.9+ or 5.10 slab with pro far apart to get there.    Pitch 1.  Clip the low bolt and make an awkward 5.10 move onto an easy ramp.  This section can be avoided by starting farther right~ but if you want to avoid this move~ you'll probably be better off avoiding the rest of the climb too.  A directional piece above this move is a good idea to protect the follower.  Follow the easy ramp up and left to a ledge below a vertical crack.  Build an anchor here~ unless you have reason to do the climb in a single 60m pitch.    Pitch 2. Start up the slab~ clip the first piton~ work left and up on thin slab to the 2nd pin (5.9+ or 5.10 R) It's rather heady between the pitons but they are bomber.  A few more moves gain a diagonal crack~ and you get more pro~ any cam 1"- 3" works.  An intimidating but easy move puts you within reach of the first bolt on the final slab headwall.  The well-protected face gets blanker and blanker with the hardest "surface tension" moves getting to the final bolt (crux).      An intermediate belay at the ledge below the pitons and/or the final headwall is recommended to reduce rope drag~ although I found it tolerable to climb the whole route in a single  58m pitch- a good idea if you have 3 people.
protection: 1 bolt down low~ then 2 fixed pins~ then 3 bolts~ to a 2-bolt anchor~ with some of your own trad gear in between..    1 60m rope works to descend the North side in a single rap.  Find the center.

location: (L1) John Nichol's Wall > Utopian Vistas > Taos Area > New Mexico
desc: Cool climbing up into a weird crux sequence.
protection: Ten bolts lead to a two bolt anchor. Use long runners on the fourth and fifth bolt.

location: Retirement Wall > Las Conchas > Jemez Mountains and Jemez Valley > New Mexico
desc: Strong start leads to a fun technical crux midway. From here the quality of rock unfortunately drops a notch.

location: Roadside Distraction > Red River Area > Taos Area > New Mexico
desc: Scramble up on top of the boulder to the right of most routes at roadside and begin following the obvious line of darker bolts on the face. Pull the roof with a fixed permadraw~ then continue on small holds to the anchors.

location: Leaning Tower > Las Conchas > Jemez Mountains and Jemez Valley > New Mexico
desc: Starts in a dihedral and then climbs up and left on big huecos past a challenging and devious crux over a small bulge. Follow easier terrain to the top. The best route in this area.
protection: 7 or 8 QDs to an anchor with fixed carabiners.

location: North Cliffband > Cochiti Mesa > Capulin Canyon and Cochiti Mesa Area Crags > Jemez Mountains and Jemez Valley > New Mexico
desc: Ascend an easy corner system until you're on a ledge and can clip the first bolt.  From here quality slabbing~ past a drilled pocket or two~ leads up the short face.  Fun climb marred by the obvious chipped pocket in the center of the route.
protection: 3 bolts and 1 drilled piton to open shunt anchors.

location: Los Huevos > The Subdivisions > Las Conchas > Jemez Mountains and Jemez Valley > New Mexico
desc: Steep climbing on jugs leads to crimps and lie-backing through an obvious left-facing dihedral. It gets easier for a bit with a little harder climbing at the last bolt.

location: Retirement Wall > Las Conchas > Jemez Mountains and Jemez Valley > New Mexico
desc: Fun short route coming out of the stash cave. Bottom reminds me of the Dungeon
protection: 8 Bolts to two-bolt anchor with chains/biners

location: East of Eden > Eden Canyon > Diablo Canyon > Santa Fe Area > New Mexico
desc: This is one of the easier 11's at the wall. It has some devious and fun movement~ but not too hard. Climb easy terrain to an arete~ mantle up to a steep bulge with another mantle over it into an upper corner with a  very thin crack.

location: The Crack House (aka Estante Edge) > White Rock > Los Alamos & White Rock > New Mexico
desc: This rout ascends black rock just to the right of some bubbly basalt knobs. The first 15 feet are the crux~ then some fun moves lead out of a scoop and continue up an overhanging wall to the top.

location: (03) Wall of Dreams > New Side > Mentmore > Gallup Area > New Mexico
desc: A nice crack with great movement~ TCT is the hardest trad lead at Mentmore to date~ and one of the best.  Only a discontinuous start and a bit of sandy rock at the base keep it from being a four-star route.  Scramble up some boulders at the base of the crack to reach the small roof.  Strenuous moves get you over the roof~ and a combination of face climbing and finger locks takes you to the top.  This route can be climbed almost entirely as a crack climb~ or with a great deal of face climbing~ but at least some jamming skills are probably necessary.      The crack is deep and varnished on the inside~ so the gear is good.  However~ the soft rock at Mentmore means that long falls are NOT a good idea.  Protection every body length is a good goal to shoot for.    Be aware that after heavy rain storms~ some sand may have been washed into the crack.  It's not a major problem~ but if no one has climbed the route in a while (likely to be the case at Mentmore)~ it may be worthwhile to brush the crack out on a toprope before leading it.
protection: Trad gear from 0.5" to 1".  Nuts work~ but cams are better.  A double set is plenty.  The crack is quite deep~ so four-cam units are recommended to get as much surface contact with the rock as possible.  Two-bolt anchor at the top.

location: (L6) Mud Palace Wall > Utopian Vistas > Taos Area > New Mexico
desc: Shared start and first bolt with Mud Palace. Traverse left under second bolt to rail at left. work up to reach obvious finger crack then power up to ledge. Interesting and tricky climbing to low anchor. Upper headwall projected (?13). Can use as alternate start for Mud Palace    Ansel Adams published his first book of large format photography from a trip to Taos Pueblo~ New Mexico in 1930~ where he met Paul Strand and Georgia O'Keefe. Shot  on one of his later trips~  Moonrise over Hernadez became one of his most famous prints.

location: Flowing Chi Wall > Wild and Scenic > Taos Area > New Mexico
desc: Right facing corner left of old cables anchor.  Three distinct cruxes with varied climbing.  Start in stiff finger crack with excellent pro to strenuous slab moves at lower corner.  A few rests exist before final overhanging crux moves to anchor.  Some exfoliating rock in steeper corner should clean up.  Beautiful position and views.  Some poison ivy at base was easily  avoidable.    A Sadhu is a holy man of Nepal.  Often called Baba~ meaning father or uncle. It was sort of miraculous Bob sent this first go~ hanging on a wing and a prayer.
protection: Doubles in finger size up to red camalot. 6 bolts protect slab and steep corner.  Rap from 2 bolt anchor.

location: Spaghetti Western Wall > Upper East Fork (UEF) > Jemez Mountains and Jemez Valley > New Mexico
desc: Grab the right side of the arete up high. The crux is right in the middle~ on tiny edges.

location: Cathedral Rock > Pecos River Canyon > Santa Fe Area > New Mexico
desc: Go straight up the bolt line underneath the giant roof. The face climbing is excellent~ but exiting the roof/arete is the crux. Every move on the route is great. Though the crux is very pumpy.

location: (07) Randy's Wall > Palomas Peak > Albuquerque Area > New Mexico
desc: Climb the step technical face to the anchor.
protection: 5 bolts to a bolts and chain anchor.

location: South Cliffband > Cochiti Mesa > Capulin Canyon and Cochiti Mesa Area Crags > Jemez Mountains and Jemez Valley > New Mexico
desc: Start up on the left side of the arete on jugs which quickly thin to yield some tricky moves on tweaky pockets~ despite the low angle I thought this was the crux of the route.    At the 4th bolt a nice rest is encountered and a suspicious pocket.  Head right (Rocket In My Pocket breaks left here) on steeper ground with big moves between good holds.  The holds can be a bit tricky to see from below.  Once established on the steep face things ease up to the anchors.
protection: 7 Bolts to a two bolt anchor with chains.

location: (04) Benny Silva Wall > Original Side > Mentmore > Gallup Area > New Mexico
desc: A fun route with a great start.  Pull a few moves on small crimps (5.11b if taller~ 5.11c if shorter) to a substantial and obvious clipping hold~ then another few great moves to the obvious lip (don't forget to use the bullet holes!).  Pull the roof above (strenuous but good holds)~ and then cruise the lower-angled terrain above.  This route shares the last two bolts and the anchor with Rapture.  Recommended for the bottom 20 feet alone.
protection: 6 bolts to a 2-anchor.  The boltline trends right to the anchor~ so if you're planning on TRing~ you probably want a directional on the third bolt.

location: Winter Wall > Mud Mountain > Truth or Consequences Area > New Mexico
desc: Hard~ thin~ technical climbing on steep rock.

location: Frog Prince > Enchanted Tower > New Mexico
desc: Short but sweet. A stick clip is helpful as the first bolt is quite a distance off the deck. Reach up in the overhang for your first hold and campus (or you can use your feet~ seen it done different ways) the first few moves. Continue up strenuous moves to the anchors.    Also a V6 bouldering start variation~ according to the guidebook.

location: New New Place > White Rock > Los Alamos & White Rock > New Mexico
desc: The buttress just right of Sharons Lead is a fun toprope problem.  You can begin on the face proper~ or start in a hand crack to the right. Above 15' up~ you get to the crux~ some small holds~ big reaches~ and use of the right arete will get you through to a good rest ledge. Above this~ for more interesting climbing~ stay right on the arete.  This one doesn't have much for gear~ at least~ not where you want it. I haven't led it or seen it led.
protection: Not very much.  Toprope from a 2-bolt anchor~ reachable from the top

location: Solar Asylum > John Dunn Bridge Area > Taos Area > New Mexico
desc: A great climb at Solar Asylum.  Boulder up just left of the arete to start.  The bolted lines split at the 2nd bolt- stay right to stay on Sunshine.  Pull through juggy blocky roofs to a large ledge.  Lieback up the headwall crack in the white wall~ rock over left~ and make cruxy pumpy face moves to a wonderful hold.  Face climb past another bolt to the chains.

location: Pirate's Wall > El Rito Sport Area > El Rito > New Mexico
desc: Start from a good but small stance halfway up the large boulder between Walking the Plank (aka The Buzz) and Pirated (look for the belay bolt with a tan hanger.) Alternatively~ belay from ground level underneath this belay bolt.   Pull up onto the slab and clip a number of bolts as the route gets steeper. This section is bolted pretty tightly on account of still-cleaning-up rock and the slab below. Crank hard on cool pockets and holds with the occasional smaller hold~ passing intermittent vertical cracks~ up to the massive cobble with the fixed draw. Steep~ harder moves past the huge cobble lead to licheny rock and the anchors.
protection: 12 bolts to a two-bolt anchor with lowering biners. The fixed cable draw in the massive cobble is fixed to facilitate the reachy clip and make cleaning easier.

location: Beer Block > El Rito Sport Area > El Rito > New Mexico
desc: While this climb looks chossy and bad~ it is not terrible. With traffic it could be a better route. Some find the slab behind you close enough to be scary~ though you can stem to it up high. Start up a steep prow and pull up onto the face. Climbing past some great holds to the steep finish~ pulling over the lip to the anchors.
protection: 7 bolts a 2-bolt anchor. The first couple of hangers are tan and blend in with the rock pretty well.

location: Rad Wall > El Rito Sport Area > El Rito > New Mexico
desc: Climb the right side arete of Rad wall.  Clip a low first bolt and start up the steep arete.  Pull difficult balancy moves past the second bolt for the crux.  From here endure the pump resting whenever possible climbing the arete or right side whatever is easier.  At the 6th bolt head onto the face and up easier ground to the anchors.

location: Cragacito > Upper East Fork (UEF) > Jemez Mountains and Jemez Valley > New Mexico
desc: Climb straight up the brown face just right of doniBrook then join Over the River (which joins doniBrook) for the last three bolts.

route: To Bolt on Lead or Not to Bolt (TBOL)
location: Mosaic Rock > Tres Piedras > Taos Area > New Mexico
desc: If you can ignore the ethical ideology in your face~ this is a very cool line up the best wall at Tres Piedras.  (I'm joking a little bit~ and respect that this type of thing was a big deal when this climb was put up. As for myself~ I'm much more concerned about climbing than I am about bolt ethics.  Search the forums for the answers to that.)  It is nearly as good as Techtonics and Techweenie to its right~ climbs in a similar style to those routes~ and maintains an independent line.  Although it's given an "R" for protection in the guidebooks~ I think its similar to Techtonics as far as headiness (you have to be willing to climb a bit more than usual above your last gear)~ and confident 5.11 leaders should give'r a go.    Go up thin edges and plates to a high 1st bolt.  A hard move after the 2nd bolt gains an obvious flake.  I wasn't so sure about gear in~ or behind this flake~ but you can get some pieces in a crack above it.  At about the 3rd bolt~ it looks like a blank face~ going left~ then up~ then back right~ is the way; don't get tempted to join Techtonics.  The difficulty eases soon after the 4th bolt.  While you're looking at the 4th and 2nd bolts~ old buttonheads~ and deciding whether to punch it to the next crack~ remember that Couleur put those in on lead from hooks~ as he on-sighted~ which must have been pretty fun.    I traversed right to the anchor for Techtonics~ but it might have been slightly easier to clean the route if I'd gone to the anchor for the new climb to the left.
protection: 4 bolts~ plus a light rack (I placed a couple finger-size cams~ the biggest was a #0.75 camalot).    Use the anchor for Techtonics~ or the new climb to the left.    Some of the bolts are not confidence-inspiring.

location: Eagle Canyon > Capulin Canyon and Cochiti Mesa Area Crags > Jemez Mountains and Jemez Valley > New Mexico
desc: Another excellent~ long Eagle Canyon face climb.  This line faces slightly more north than its twin "Unnamed Left"~ so it receives more shade~ and so is a bit mossy-er.  Despite the slightly less than ideal stone~ this route offers a rope-stretching pitch of great climbing capped by an intimidating roof.    Begin by scrambling up the ramp-like dihedral.  Head up the steep slab to a technical crux around the 4th and 5th bolts.  A timely jaunt onto the right arete provides some key relief before veering back left.  The final roof can be surmounted directly on good pockets~ or its possible to traverse left around it~ depending on your preference.
protection: 10 bolts~ shares the anchor with "Unnamed Left".

location: The Front Porch > El Rito Sport Area > El Rito > New Mexico
desc: The route trends left following a leftward ascending seam/corner. Encounter tricky moves involving figuring out the sequence for your hands around the third and fourth bolts.  Then enjoy a steep finish with big jugs with one last "make you think" move near the top. Enjoyable.

location: Trojan Wall (Right of Bat Cave) > Bat Cave Area > Caballo Lake > Truth or Consequences Area > New Mexico
desc: Start on the slab below the right side of the Bat Cave. The face steepens to near vertical and offers some trickery at the 5th and 6th bolt. Continue up the engaging and blocky face to a final blank wall. Do some difficult moves here~ first up~ then moving right. Hit the small left facing corner and climb straight up to the anchors above.
protection: 13 bolts to a chain anchor with lowering biners

location: Main Wall > The Shack > Diablo Canyon > Santa Fe Area > New Mexico
desc: I felt this climb~ just left of Fire on the Mountain~ was the best fully bolted climb at the Shack under 5.12.  Good rock~ and a sustained crux on a tricky arête made it rewarding.  The slab face passing the last couple of bolts has some lichen but it's no big deal.
protection: Bolts to fixed bolted anchors. (10 bolts? I didn't count.)

location: Hidden Tower > Las Conchas > Jemez Mountains and Jemez Valley > New Mexico
desc: Thin and technical old-school crimping on the bottom and big airy moves way up high. Nice and continuous with a more moderate middle section. Challenging crux to decipher with inobvious holds and long spans.    Many thanks to Aaron Chavez for his help as I bolted this and managed to drop my drill from the top of the route. Amazingly the drill landed in oak and wet dirt and survived unscathed except for a severely bent drill bit.
protection: 9 bolts (or something like that) with 2-bolt chain anchor. Bring longer QDs to reduce drag in the middle.

location: (02) The Corridor > New Side > Mentmore > Gallup Area > New Mexico
desc: Ascends a brown streak in between Cameron's Coming and Technorazor.

location: The Amphitheater > Upper East Fork (UEF) > Jemez Mountains and Jemez Valley > New Mexico
desc: The first pitch has been improved some--six bolts take you to the mid-way anchor. The climbing is about 5.8 and not too crappy~ though it would never get done without the second part.  Dribble glass follows the far right side of the head wall. It's protected by five bolts and overhangs at about 60 degrees and is on amazing rock. The whole route could easily be done in one pitch~ but it's nice not to have rope drag for the upper jug haul.

location: Left End > Early Wall > Diablo Canyon > Santa Fe Area > New Mexico
desc: A great face and arete.  Tricky start with thin feet and big moves.  Pass this to a tricky and hard to read move off a ledge to some thin face.  A hard move and tricky clip guards the anchors.  Good rests save the day between the cruxes.

location: Walt's Wall (aka The Outsider Wall) > El Rito Sport Area > El Rito > New Mexico
desc: Start up steep but juggy rock to clip the first bolt. The angle backs off immediately past the second bolt and up to the third clip. Pull on steep jugs and then climb as gently as possible through some questionable rock past the fifth and sixth bolts.  Breathe a sigh of relief as you grab the better rock on the arete to the left and finish up easier terrain to the anchor.    The rock in the upper-middle portion of the route is pretty dubious and I was a bit sketched to pull very hard on some of the jugs.
protection: 8 bolts with Spanish "lucky" hangers to a two-bolt anchor that's not well equalized.  Needs a few screw links. Rapping the route recommended.

location: Area 37 > Jemez Mountains and Jemez Valley > New Mexico
desc: A mostly-independent line of mainly 11-ish climbing with a tougher crux. The route is named after a not very positive but extremely ergonomic left-hand hold just before the crux at the bulge. After the crux the climb shares the diagonal roof seam of Branching Out for a couple moves but continues up the seam to left until its end. From there the line takes a more or less obvious way to shared anchors with Branching Out. However~ since the top section after the diagonal roof seam and bulge is not that obvious and the climbing not that exciting there is a separate anchor for this route at the end of the roof/bulge leaving the top section to those who can't get enough and may want to add some additional~ but slightly contrived~ climbing to the Branching Out anchors.
protection: Six bolts to its own anchor. For more climbing~ continue past the anchors~ past another bolt~ and to the anchors of Branching Out.

location: The Sewer Crag > White Rock > Los Alamos & White Rock > New Mexico
desc: A very nice~ steep arête route. As is the theme for the Sewer Crag~ this route climbs much better than the name implies.     The climb begins in earnest at the second bolt~ where a pumpy sequence on good edges but poor feet leads past bolts three and four~ culminating in a final desperate crux getting to the fifth bolt. Catch a well-deserved rest~ and finish on easier but still fun arête climbing.     Definitely solid at the grade~ but tightly bolted~ making it a good route on which to push yourself.
protection: 8 bolts to chains. Shares an anchor with the Unknown 5.11a.

location: Hidden Tower > Las Conchas > Jemez Mountains and Jemez Valley > New Mexico
desc: In December 2013~ New Mexico became the 17th state to legalize same-sex marriage leaving even the rhyolite of the Jemez Mountains feeling the love. That same week we discovered the heart-shaped hueco at the crux of this route as proof. Sustained face climbing on great-quality rock leads past the lower half of the route to a big sit-down ledge. An anchor on this ledge allows for climbing just the first half of the route at 5.11b. But look up and~ like cupid~ aim for the heart. Some easy slab climbing gives way to another steep bit of climbing in a shallow corner past the route's namesake heart-shaped pocket and the anchors.
protection: 60m rope and 14 bolts (I was feeling the love too~ apparently~ and put in a plethora of bolts.)

location: Upper Band > The Tunnel > New Mexico, other Southern Areas > New Mexico
desc: Place a TCU after the first bolt or stick clip high.

location: The Playground > White Rock > Los Alamos & White Rock > New Mexico
desc: Flying A Buttress is a fun thin face toprope problem~ taking on the buttress and face left of Flying A and right of Texas. It is rather sustained~ with about the first 30' of continuous face climbing at approx. hard 5.11 with a short section with one or two harder moves.    A bouldery start with sidepull holds and small crimps gets you to a   stance above the small bulge 8' up- this is a fun boulder problem in of itself.  Thin crimp move past the small roof and you can grab a larger flat-topped ledge.  Manteling onto this ledge is tricky~ then a weird move to more crimps~ lets you reach the thinnest and cruxiest section of the climb; bear down on tiny edges or find some trickery for 2 or 3 moves on the slightly overhanging face. Better edges & ledges are above~ and the hard part of the climbing is done after 30' up.    Obviously the "Flying A crack" is considered "off" throughout the climb but for the most part moving over to it is not too tempting~ so it's not unreasonably contrived.    The line as shown in 'Jemez Rock' is a little off- the start should be independent and just left of the chimney that is the typical start for Flying A.    (I toproped this route -as does virtually everybody else- and I think the only place you could get get any meaningful pro is the horizontal crack under the roof about 12' up. I think if you fell at what I think is the hardest part~ you would deck from about 25' up~ maybe landing on rocks. The climbing gets easier above~ but there are still no more gear placements until almost the very top. I think one would be better off soloing vs leading. Edit: See Lee's note below for beta from someone who's done more than I have with this climb.)
protection: Toprope~ from the 2-bolt anchor for Flying A.    If leading~ yellow TCU/Alien~ blue alien or purple TCU~ green .75 camalot~ possibly another for up higher~ couple of QD's for the first 2 pieces or the rope runs funky~ over the roof and around the corner.

location: Dead Cholla Wall > Taos Area > New Mexico
desc: The crux is a very thin slab move with horrible feet. Cool moves past the crux and fun finger crack to reach the anchors.
protection: Four clips plus thin finger size gear.     Two bolt anchor.

location: Main Wall > The Shack > Diablo Canyon > Santa Fe Area > New Mexico
desc: Technical start up to dihedral corner~ then technical transition to face~ then pumpy steep climbing to ledge anchors.    Great Route!!!  Will challenge all your skills.

location: West Face (a.k.a. Grid Wall) > The Land Beyond > Enchanted Tower > New Mexico
desc: A sustained climb up the arete on the corner.

location: Mid-Town > Shady Side > The Tunnel > New Mexico, other Southern Areas > New Mexico
desc: Use the start of sloopy; At the second bolt climb right and up under the roof. Cop a rest and glide around the roof to the right(first crux). Get another good rest then Crux on crimps to the 5th bolt~ Climb one more bolt on crimps and jugs until you reach the chains.

location: Bat Cave > Bat Cave Area > Caballo Lake > Truth or Consequences Area > New Mexico
desc: The route is a left to right traverse across the right side wall of the cave.  There's a crimpy big move crux between the 4th and 5th clip to a good rest at a huge undercling pod~ than another big move over the bulge~ followed by a few more moves on great holds to a mid anchor smack dab in the middle of the cave.  This route is a great warm up pitch and will eventually serve as an easy start to routes continuing up and out of the cave.
protection: Seven fixed chain draws to the anchor.

location: Main Wall > The Dungeon > Los Alamos & White Rock > New Mexico
desc: Very good route! A difficult start through steep terrain leads to a foot-intensive "slabby" middle section. Around the sixth bolt look for a no-hands rest before the final tricky roof. Bust through the tricky final roof making another couple of moves to the chain anchors.    (On 8/7/2013~ the chalky plate below the final roof was apparently removed by someone~ not me~ making the last clip a little bit different -- JH )    Warning: Not a good warm up... Ha~ but the only one we could find when the rain was coming down.

location: (07) Randy's Wall > Palomas Peak > Albuquerque Area > New Mexico
desc: The thin climb has some really fun climbing~ but much easier ground just left of the bolt line detracts from the quality.  In addition the large tree introduces some scaryness through the beginning.  Start up on easy choss to get to the first bolt.  Some fingerlocks and awkward seems get you to the second bolt.  From here climb slightly up~ then traverse left to obtain the third bolt.  Monkey See continues straight up.  Traverse left with difficulty and try not to end up on the ledge out left.  Or stop here for a nice rest~ you are only 3' left of the bolts.  Continue up finding a good clipping hold for the fifth bolt~ and continue up easier ground with some sketchy looking blocks to the anchors out right.
protection: 5 Bolts to Anchors.  Be aware of the large tree~ now reaching the second bolt~ a fall before clipping the third bolt would not be good~ as you would fall through the tree.

location: Below The Old New Place > White Rock > Los Alamos & White Rock > New Mexico
desc: This fine pocket-fest is the left route on a wide panel of stone that gets relatively early shade~ and features 3 5.12a's.  Begin up an easy slab to a high first bolt.  Two more bolts of easy climbing and the wall rears up to a slight overhang.  A good shake from killer pockets at the 4th bolt offer one last chance to recuperate before the crux.  A set of heinously thin pockets lead up and right to another jug.  A long reach heads back left to a horizontal break and a good rest.  From here~ hard-to-see~ black polished crimps and a cool hole lead up and left to the anchor.

location: (01) The Entrance > Palomas Peak > Albuquerque Area > New Mexico
desc: A very nice route with a tricky start. Begin to the right of a prominent crack going up the wall (Drop in the Ocean). My impression was that the crux was at the bottom though another thought it was at the top. Clip the first and second bolt~ and head through a tricky sequence through the bottom moves. Endure through the next few moves and take a few good rests before jamming a crack (or finding something to crimp~ if your name is Mike) at the top and hitting some nice jugs above. Could probably protect the top moves with a yellow Camalot if so inclined but not really necessary as a fall from there would be through air.

location: The Amphitheater > Upper East Fork (UEF) > Jemez Mountains and Jemez Valley > New Mexico
desc: Pull through a short bit of typical-for-UEF chunky rock down low using some nice~ solid huecos for three bolts to a big ledge. Traverse right and up on the ledge to clip another bolt and swing out left on steep rock but with big holds. Continue up trending right past a couple more bolts to a pronounced~ hard to read crux on overhanging rock in a green streak. Finish in a small left-facing corner and crack.
protection: 7 bolts to a two bolt anchor with carabiners and rap rings.

location: C: Root Beer Saloon > Alto Pass > Illinois
desc: Start on the arete~ and begin pulling through good holds. Angle up and right moving through a good side pull and edges to reach the anchor

location: H. Hobo Cave > A. North Canyon > *Jackson Falls > Illinois
desc: P1:Climb up the right most crack in the three crack system~ get behind large flake and traverse left to a semi spacious belay ledge and build anchor. Very very easy climbing the first pitch is simply to avoid the choss and rope drag. 5.5 P2:The fun climbing begins. Climb the corner crack which starts at small hands and slowly turns into fists of glory.
protection: Standard rack. One number six is convenient for first pitch. Anchor and rap off nearby tree at top.

location: E. Big Star Wall > A. North Canyon > *Jackson Falls > Illinois
desc: Obvious vertical crack in the center of Big Star Wall.
protection: Larger cams at the bottom~ smaller at the top. Build an anchor using two trees.

location: J: Amphitheater Wall > Mississippi Palisades > Illinois
desc: beta pending

location: A. Royal Arches Wall > C. North Falls > *Jackson Falls > Illinois
desc: Climb the crack

location: A: Playground Wall -Detention Area > Cedar Bluff > Illinois
desc: Climb the face~ clipping the two bolts as you move working into the crack. Work you way through the crack as it widens and becomes slightly overhung. Climb over the ledge and reach the bolted anchor.
protection: Two bolts and mid sized cams to the anchor.

location: D: Open Bible > Mississippi Palisades > Illinois
desc: Start in the middle of the west face~ and climb up and follow a thin seam in the back of a dihedral to the ledge. Move right almost to the corner and finish by surmounting the overhanging top block.  Variation - Tanglefoot~ 5.9: From the slanting ledge continue straight up the center of the overhanging upper face on good handholds.

location: A: Lily Wall > Pere Marquette State Park > Illinois
desc: Climb the crack to the anchor

location: A. Shelter 1 Bluff > Giant City State Park > Illinois
desc: This climb is similar to Drunkards in the way of how it angles to the right and is well protected. This is a great climb for those learning trad. Crux is either the crux of Makanda Layback or getting off the ground for The Gully

location: D. Lovely Tower > C. North Falls > *Jackson Falls > Illinois
desc: Fun chimney route.
protection: Can use tree as anchor at top of route (2016).

location: J. Railroad Rock Cliffline > A. North Canyon > *Jackson Falls > Illinois
desc: Wide~ offwidth~ squeeze~ grovelling fun!!!!
protection: Two #6 would be nice~ Big bro's~ anchor on tree

location: G. Main Pool > C. North Falls > *Jackson Falls > Illinois
desc: Good~ short sport route

location: E: Ryan's Balcony > Pere Marquette State Park > Illinois
desc: Climb the arete using both the arete and face holds to reach the anchor
protection: 3 bolts to the anchor    NOTE: There is a low bolt "hip height" for the belayer to anchor themselves into

location: H: Eagle Wall > Pere Marquette State Park > Illinois
desc: Dig through the thin seam~ placing gear when necessary to reach the anchor

location: B: Lucky Strike Pillar > Pere Marquette State Park > Illinois
desc: Begin in the dihedral and climb up 2 bolts. Cut left to a horizontal ledge and push it out. Fun climbing from here to the anchor

location: Moon Rock > Cove Hollow > Illinois
desc: The easier variation of Ralphie's Ruse. Fun pocket pulling ties your back into the main route.

location: A: Quetil Trail Bluff > Alto Pass > Illinois
desc: Begin on Dr. Feel Good~ but immediately move right after clipping the first bolt. Climb to cool iron blobs.

location: I: Meadow Slab > Pere Marquette State Park > Illinois
desc: Begin at the upside down stair feature and climb the slab. Eventually make your way up and left

location: The Dugout > Cove Hollow > Illinois
desc: 5.9 climbing to crux move at the roof when traversing right to the anchors on Middle Face. Very exposed move~ and has potential for pendulum swing into opposite wall. Not sure if anyone has climbed this route before. When traversing I knocked off a large rock that almost hit my belayer.
protection: Set of Cams #.5 - 3~ set of nuts. Save #3 for the traverse.

location: E. Big Star Wall > A. North Canyon > *Jackson Falls > Illinois
desc: This route is located just to the left of Express Checkout Line and use the same entrance.  Has a low and balancy crux.

location: C: PG Wall -Coal House Area > Cedar Bluff > Illinois
desc: Fun face climb with a wild roof!

location: K. La  Haceinda > E. South Canyon > *Jackson Falls > Illinois
desc: none listed

location: E. Exam Wall > B. West Falls > *Jackson Falls > Illinois
desc: Before entering the hallway~ climb up and right on the left side of the steep face.

location: H. The SS Minnow > E. South Canyon > *Jackson Falls > Illinois
desc: Continuous technical climbing~ close to vertical but not overhanging. Different in character than a lot of Jackson routes.

location: G. Main Pool > C. North Falls > *Jackson Falls > Illinois
desc: This is the second bolted line left of the corner from the hand line. A very weird start leads up to a bulge. Pulling the bulge ends up easier than it looks~ working the slopers above is not.

location: C. Cranial/Detox Wall > C. Hidden Peaks > E. South Canyon > *Jackson Falls > Illinois
desc: The rightmost route on the Detox wall~ start as for The Farmer but continue up the ramp for another 10 feet to a lieback crack. Continue up the crack and finish on edges.

location: F. Dynasty Wall > B. West Falls > *Jackson Falls > Illinois
desc: Climb the short cliff face just right of the crack system.

location: E. Exam Wall > B. West Falls > *Jackson Falls > Illinois
desc: none listed

location: I. Railroad Rock > A. North Canyon > *Jackson Falls > Illinois
desc: Nice movement to a crux 3/4 the way up. Classic.

location: E. Big Star Wall > A. North Canyon > *Jackson Falls > Illinois
desc: Fairly sustained route with a distinct crux about half way up

location: D: Community Effort Wall > Pere Marquette State Park > Illinois
desc: Begin under the first bolt and work up into ledge. from here use the split in the ledge and work left~ just using a few of the cracks holds and eventually gain purchase on some good horizontal pockets. Pull yourself over to the right and continue your way back up the route.    Huge thanks to Bill~ Ryan~ Nikki~ and Molly for helping to clean this wall up.

location: E. Big Star Wall > A. North Canyon > *Jackson Falls > Illinois
desc: 20ft left of Mary's Cookies.  Technical pocket start to the right-leaning crack 15ft up.  Pockets to horizontals to a halfway jug that starts the techy slab to the anchors.

location: E. Big Star Wall > A. North Canyon > *Jackson Falls > Illinois
desc: Battle through the first 20 feet to an easier section. Balance and finesse right then up through a shollow corner~ (sexy/cruxy)~ to easier ground.    Four stars compared to most of the Falls but not quiet as good as Wishbone and Big Star

location: D. Beaver Wall > A. North Canyon > *Jackson Falls > Illinois
desc: Start 6 ft. right of corner and go right at the 3rd bolt.  Fun!

location: C: PG Wall -Coal House Area > Cedar Bluff > Illinois
desc: Climb the face while following the bolt line.

location: B. Black Sheep Boulder > B. West Falls > *Jackson Falls > Illinois
desc: Super fun~ technical~ bouldery start using the huge roof feature directly below the first bolt. Navigate the juggy tufa into a couple shallow holds on your way to the huge rail. Easy pocket and hueco climbing diagonally out right to the anchors.    Couldn't find this in any guidebooks or in the memory of local John Paine. Let me know if you know anything about it.
protection: Route was bolted...a long time ago. Seems to have been forgotten about--bolts are a little rusty~ anchor chains/biners could use some love.    Also be ware. The hueceos and pockets up top are a little brittle so be gentle up there. This route is a little sandy/mossy~ so go climb it!

location: The Rubik's Cube > Draper's Bluff > Illinois
desc: The Crux is between 2nd - 3rd bolt and another b/t 4 and 5.  The route is very sustained so pace yourself.  The second pitch is a bit scary getting to the first bolt.  You will hit a ledge if you blow the move.
protection: Bring a small cam to supplement b/t the 1st and 2nd bolt on the 1st pitch and small - mid cams to protect from the ledge to the first bolt on the second.  Some like a mid sized cam to protect the final moves...but it is much easier climbing high on the pitch.

location: B. Sheen Wall > E. South Canyon > *Jackson Falls > Illinois
desc: Climb the slight arete feature until the horizontal break. Cut left and continue up to the anchor.

location: F. The Promised Land > *Jackson Falls > Illinois
desc: Two difficult~ technical cruxes on razor crimps separated by a section of more moderate climbing. Not for those afraid of a little blood.

location: I. Railroad Rock > A. North Canyon > *Jackson Falls > Illinois
desc: Back to back boulder problems on pockets lead into fun~ long moves between good crimps. Surpisingly powerful and dynamic compared to other routes at railroad rock~ especially if you happen to find many of the holds just out of reach.

location: 3 Air Thee Wall > Main Wall > Massacre Rocks > East Idaho > Idaho
desc: Pro your own line~ crack to slab~ to overhanging headwall~ classic

location: Quator Lake > Yellow Pine to Big Creek > Central Idaho > Idaho
desc: The first climb bolted at the crag climbs the most obvious feature on the wall~ a semi detached block. A slightly overhanging face boarding a large crack on the left side lends itself to interesting climbing.

location: Baron Spire aka Old Smoothie > The Sawtooth Range > Central Idaho > Idaho
desc: this is the beautiful tower northwest of baron spire.. start at the obvious off width in the center of the face. Branch right at the top of the 3rd and follow incipient face cracks aiming for the large roof block. beware of the 5th pitch~ as Mattie Wells is a bad mofo. stellar rock~ but quite runout..5.10 moves 20-30' above gear.  Gain the large roof and set a belay. The block is a bit spooky but... lieback the right side and mantle out~ awesome hands follow.  couple more pitches of steep blocky moderates lead to the stellar summit. run down the snow filled couloir climbers right of the formation.

location: The Alcove > Dierkes Lake > Twin Falls and the Snake River Canyon > South Idaho > Idaho
desc: Steep climbing on large holds that are sometimes hard to see from below.
protection: 8 bolts to chains~ shares anchors and last bolt with Ziplock.

location: Castle Rock - South Face > Castle Rocks > Castle Rocks > South Idaho > Idaho
desc: none listed

location: Checkered Demon > City of Rocks > South Idaho > Idaho
desc: This is a great line on the center of the Checkered Demon Cliff.  A hard~ funky start is protected by a bolt and a fixed pin.  After that easier climbing above in a nice stemming dihedral to a two bolt and chain anchor near the top of the cliff.

location: North Shore > Dierkes Lake > Twin Falls and the Snake River Canyon > South Idaho > Idaho
desc: Powerful crux move at the start leads to easier climbing to the last bolt~ then a tricky and pumpy finish to the chains.

location: Bumblie Rock > City of Rocks > South Idaho > Idaho
desc: Located on the far left side of the Bumble crag.  Scramble up 30 feet of class 5 huecos placing one or more cams before clipping the first bolt.  Use a variety of face holds~ stemming positions~ and laybacks to gain the third bolt. Make bouldery moves right and continue to a stance to clip the 4th bolt.  Run it out or place a #2 cam to gain the chains.  This route is called "Fifty Feet of Fun" in the newest city of rocks guidebook. Dave Bingham?  Also~ the description says "could place some cams". This should be specified. "Bring a 0.5 camalot for before the bolts~ and a #2 camalot for after the bolts"
protection: Bolts. Long way to first on easy 5th class. Bring a 0.5 Camalot for before the bolts~ and a #2 camalot for after the bolts.

location: 3 Air Thee Wall > Main Wall > Massacre Rocks > East Idaho > Idaho
desc: Bolted slab

location: Shark's Fin Rock > East Sector > Castle Rocks > South Idaho > Idaho
desc: Climb up to large flake above a small tree.  Ascend the finger crack over a small bulge until you are established on the face.  Step to the right and clip the first bolt.  Transfer in a layback up large patina jugs.  Make a few hard moves and follow crimps to the top.
protection: 2 or 3 tips to finger pieces~ 3 bolts.  Chains

location: Checkered Demon > City of Rocks > South Idaho > Idaho
desc: Climb start of Checkered Demon then move right past thin holds and bolts. Pull a couple reachy moves over bulge to gain awesome flake. Finish with great positive and airy moves up flake to chains. A great route.
protection: bolts and hand sized pieces for start

location: Morning Glory Spire > City of Rocks > South Idaho > Idaho
desc: In the guidebook~ Dave Bingham asks~ "the best face climb in the City?"... find out for yourself! A slabby crux down low & a pumpy one up higher with an amazing variety of movement in a truly spectacular location.
protection: A small stopper (#4 or #5) and blue and yellow TCUs are pretty key~ unless you feel like running it out and facing big/injurious fall potential. The climb is predominantly bolted. Chain anchors on top. Careful lowering~ it's a long one!

location: Dog Wall > Table Rock > West Idaho > Idaho
desc: Easy climbing leads to a challenging traverse.

location: East Face/Chimney Rock > Chimney Rock > North Idaho > Idaho
desc: Start up the Cooper/Hiser but take a right asap and climb up a bit of thin crack to a hanging belay below the wide crack and obvious roof.  Climb up through the roof on hands and stemming (the crux) and finish the tips crack on the headwall and then climb right into Free Friends.  Instead of traversing right when possible finish by the PG13 last pitch up the crack to its end finishing with face climbing and the mantels through the over laps.
protection: Full rack from small TCUs to a 4".

location: Rabbit's Tail > Rabbit Rock > City of Rocks > South Idaho > Idaho
desc: Crux is heavy right before first bolt. Stick clip is a pretty good idea. Eases off and climbs a double flake feature. And then slabs out to chains.

location: Building Blocks - West > Building Blocks > City of Rocks > South Idaho > Idaho
desc: This is a great route that probably has not seen more than a handful of ascents. As always I am in awe of Greg Lowe's ability- as this route was reportedly climbed without cams or sticky rubber-well before the free climbing revolution. When I did it I cleaned bushels of lichen and scale out of the crack. The rock at the start is pretty bad-both due to nesting birds showering the approach slab in debris in the area and simply being chossy granite in general. Once you get to the roof~ the rock improves~ the protection is great and the climbing is amazing. I think this route is the best hardish roof crack at the city of rocks- way better climbing than Skinners Roof!(for my big hands) With more ascents it will only get better.
protection: Cams from thin fingers to big hands. No bolts~ no anchor.

location: Face Canyon > Black Cliffs > West Idaho > Idaho
desc: Pull through an awkward start past the first bolt to a ledge. Easier climbing on good edges and sidepulls brings you to a shake at the 4th bolt.    The crux lies above and demands some fairly technical movement and a somewhat stressful fifth clip. Mantle and finish on a few feet of easy ground to the chains.     Aside from the start and the usual Black Cliffs contrivances (cracks on either side are off)~ this is a really good route.

location: The towers at 202 > Central Idaho > Idaho
desc: Follow the slanting groove up and over towards the right arête before moving back left to the shallow crack leading to a series of small undercling roofs. After arriving at the last and largest roof there are two variations.  Move left for easier glory climbing on the 'Aftershocks' variation (gear).  For a little more challenge and exposure~ climb the 'Afterthoughts' variation by moving right towards a pair of chicken heads and clipping a single bolt. Enjoy a no hands rest standing on the chicken heads and resist the urge to clip the bolt of Tower Block Neurosis around the corner. Stay on the face and use a crimp in the seam to the left to enter a final sequence finishing with a slap to good edge followed by jugs to the top. Might bump the grade closer to 11d.  Rap the route.
protection: Two bolts to start followed by gear to #1. One bolt up high for the Afterthoughts variation. The anchors are easily accessible from the anchors of Gas Leak.

location: 2 Dog Wall > Main Wall > Massacre Rocks > East Idaho > Idaho
desc: Starts on first three bolts of The Mongrel~ then straight up~ over kinky bulge to steep~ fun face.

location: The Alcove > Dierkes Lake > Twin Falls and the Snake River Canyon > South Idaho > Idaho
desc: Hard climbing that tends to wander back and forth.

location: The Head Wall > The Fins > Central Idaho > Idaho
desc: Positive pockets most of the way~ to a crux just below the last clip. Make sure to find the two finger jugs!

location: All American Wall > All American Area > Massacre Rocks > East Idaho > Idaho
desc: Shares first 5 bolts with Fireworks on the Fourth~ then traverse right at small roof finish up steep~ cruxy bulge on 3 more bolts.

location: Upper Main > East Pull Out > Laclede > North Idaho > Idaho
desc: A dynamic throw leads to a thought provoking slab.  Route was re-cleaned in 2011 and 2012.
protection: Bolts~ Chain anchor on the face.

location: In the trees > South Park > East Idaho > Idaho
desc: This route traverses the low roof in a series of powerful underclings~ then plumblines straight for the anchors.

location: The Right Flank > Bear Creek Wall > Lost River Range > Central Idaho > Idaho
desc: Goes up through the traverse somewhere.

location: Creekside > City of Rocks > South Idaho > Idaho
desc: An understated classic! Nairobi throws multiple cruxes at you - kicking off with pumpy~ off-balance moves departing a block and committing to the face before traversing right and moving up past several tough bulges. The anchors~ which are clipped from from a mail slot jug~ are guarded by an improbable but brilliant crux move. Steep~ slabby goodness and possibly high in the grade.
protection: 9 bolts. Having the draws in place (and possibly a few long draws) takes the sting out of this route. Otherwise clean airtime is definitely possible!

location: 4 All Star Wall > Main Wall > Massacre Rocks > East Idaho > Idaho
desc: Long and hard~ with several variations~ right finish is the best and hardesr

location: The Right Flank > Bear Creek Wall > Lost River Range > Central Idaho > Idaho
desc: Face climb to anchor at base of giant flake.

location: The King Wall > Massacre Rocks > East Idaho > Idaho
desc: Start with a short boulder section protected by a bolt to a ledge. This sustained line is an excellent combination of powerful moves and technical pockets. The anchor is typical of Massacre and could use replacing~ due to the sharpness of one of the fixed carabiners.

location: Odyssey > City of Rocks > South Idaho > Idaho
desc: This is the obvious left leaning crack on the west side of the Odyssey formation. This formation was originally known as the "Hershey kiss" as its pointy domed top resembles the famous candy. The story is the crack was supposed to be known as "Ought to See" (coined by Stan Caldwell?) but erroneously was recorded as Odyssey.  A bolt protected boulder problem guards the opening moves before one can gain the crack. Once in the crack (no small feat!) the climbing is overhanging~ athletic~ and well protected. The upper section (crux is 11a/b or so) was a bit dirty and quite sharp- you may want to protect those paws with some tape. Dave Bingham advises to "Sneak past the bizarre bottom crux and then contend with one of the best overhanging jam cracks at the City of Rocks." This description leads one to believe the start is really 12a and just requires one unlock a clever solution- I know many who have tried and tried not been able to free the opening moves and establish in the crack. This feels like the most 5.13 12a I've been on in the City. The good news is you can tug on that draw after you fail with the fight of your life and then reach up to the first finger lock in the crack- probably A0 11b- and damn good at that!
protection: A single bolt protects the balls hard boulder problem start~ then bring doubles of .5 to 2.5 inch cams. No anchor- it would be really nice if someone added one.

location: The Main Wall > Bear Creek Wall > Lost River Range > Central Idaho > Idaho
desc: A serious route with strenuous and technical climbing requiring gear placement on the hard sections. The route is based on the discontinuous cracks which angle slightly leftwards up the left center of the face. P1. Widely spaced bolts up scoops left of the feature to athletic committing laybacking up a thin seam rightwards to the anchor. P2. The upper pitch is a better-formed crack but deceptively hard.
protection: Small stuff for P1~ a full single rack up to hands for P2.

location: Wall of Zen > Massacre Rocks > East Idaho > Idaho
desc: Yang follows a light tan band of rock through the apex of the wall.
protection: 4 bolts; the line shares the first 2 bolts with Yen

location: The Head Wall > The Fins > Central Idaho > Idaho
desc: Start directly below a large pod about 50 ft up.  Climb up fun pockets with a couple big moves to a good rest.  Make a very difficult crux move (can be done several ways).  Once at the large pod move slightly right and meet up with White Rhino.

location: Eagle Wall - Right > Eagle Wall > Massacre Rocks > East Idaho > Idaho
desc: Thin crack/seam crux.

location: 03. JR’s Place > Teddy Bear Cove > East Idaho > Idaho
desc: This prominent line is on the pillar/buttress between JR’s Place and Send Town.  Climb up steep rock to a large andinteresting hueco feature.  Exit the hueco out left to excellent brown rock on crimpy moves. Continue to a ledge and follow fun but easier terrain to the top.

location: 04. Send Town > Teddy Bear Cove > East Idaho > Idaho
desc: Climb up to the right side of the same roof as Slave Boy and make a hard and balancy pull over the roof and onto the black slabby face. Dance through a tricky section with some rat poop and pull through the roof to a thin finish on excellent tan and brown rock.    During an FA attempt~ Terran unintentionally discovered that Mike and Chris had drilled the last bolt but forgot to put the bolt and hanger in it.  Unfortunately~ he took a massive whip on the hard finish at the anchors.  After the missing bolt was installed~ Terran went back and sent the route.  The crux is still pulling onto the slab above the roof 10 feet off the ground.

location: Brush Lake crags > Boundary County Climbing Areas > North Idaho > Idaho
desc: The beautiful thin crack splitting the right vertical face on the "5.9 wall". Enjoy the boulder sequence mid route!
protection: Small gear and two bolts protect the smaller than desirable crack at the crux. anchor for TR is easy to access.

location: West Buttress - South > Castle Rocks > Castle Rocks > South Idaho > Idaho
desc: This is the natural line just to the left of Olympus Wrecks.  Start about 20 ft to the left in a very thin tips/finger crack.  The meat of this climb is fairly short but hard right from the start.  Take a right leaning very thin tips crack up and into the crux of Olympus.  The two routes meet for 10 feet~ using the highest bolt of Olympus when gear disappears.  Once you have reached the good stance take the left crack/corner to the roof and out left to the anchors of Ad-vance to Idaho.
protection: small stoppers and micro cams.  the upper crack will take a few fingers to thin hands.  1 draw

location: The Right Flank > Bear Creek Wall > Lost River Range > Central Idaho > Idaho
desc: More face climbing.

location: Lower Ledge > Arcane > East Idaho > Idaho
desc: One of the finest routes in Southeast Idaho~ Esoteric is long~ steep~ and action-packed from ground to chains. Start in the obvious gray streak~ stem up between columns~ and into the cave. Save some energy! The finish is a series of dynamic throws on big holds requiring power and plenty of endurance. An area classic~ for sure. 60 meter rope necessary.

location: The Amphitheater > Riggins Limestone > West Idaho > Idaho
desc: Another wildy steep drilled out route.  This is basically half of Tractor Boy and stops at the pod rest.  Start with the high first bolt~ clip the second bolt way behind you and grab the rest you can.  After clipping the third bolt climb the big sequential moves up through bolt 5.  Tackle the crux a few different ways and get another rest at bolt 6 before the pumping finish to the pod.  You are only cool if you sink the kneebar before clipping the bolt!    Get some energy back and keep going on tractor boy!

location: Crank Cave > East Idaho > Idaho
desc: easily the best route in the cave.    fun~ tricky~ and dynamic movement. a knee pad proved useful.     not sure if the top has been opened yet~ but ending on karma police adds another cruxy move and some good pulling.
protection: fixed gear + 1 draw for the headwall. no anchor.

location: The Elephant's Perch > The Sawtooth Range > Central Idaho > Idaho
desc: Boomers Story is a good free route~ and if you just do the first five pitches~ I think most would bump it up a notch to the "great" category.  We followed the cleanest and most straightforward variations we saw~ and I think if you spent some time cleaning some dirt out of the cracks left of pitches 1 and 3~ you could straighten the curves and make this rig even better.  The highlight of the route is pitch 2~ a super-clean~ super-tech~ and super-aesthetic corner system you can see from the ground.  It's the kind that makes the angels sing in harmony when you look at it.  Pitches 3 through 5 are also pretty good~ but then the route quality and difficulty goes down a notch or two from there to the top.  You can definitely rappel the route from the top of pitch 4 with a single 70 m rope via slung trees~ horns~ and fixed passive protection (might need new webbing).  You might be able to make it down pitch 5~ also~ but I'm not sure.  You certainly could if you fixed a couple of stoppers part way down the pitch.    Here's the pitch by pitch breakdown:    Approach:  Scramble up ~50 ft to a large ledge with some pine trees on it. The P2 R-facing corner is a good landmark to shoot for.  Also~ to the left~ look for a thin futuristic 1-pitch splitter off this ledge.    P1:  Step right into a 5.8 wide crack in a left-facing corner.  After ~25 ft~ mantle out and step right on ledgy ground. Climb up and left via hand cracks behind flakes.  Belay on a large ledge with a slung constriction.  5.8~ ~60 ft.    P2:  The biz.  Step left~ boulder up past two pretty crappy pins~ get a rest~ and then fire the thin corner above.  Expect tech-9 stemming and sinker nut placements.  The stems themselves are stable and let you place gear~ but moving up~ well that's a different story.  After about 80 feet~ when the difficulty backs off~ switch to a crack system on the right.  Eventually~ step left around a bulge to a belay in an alcove. 5.12+/13-~ 110 ft.    P3.  Climb up and right out of the alcove on gritty rock (5.9+ slightly run) toward a crack.  Pull a committing bulge that suddenly speeds up the pump clock.  Continue up the shallow right facing corner to another ledge belay.  5.11~ 100 ft.    P4.  Get your legs ready for one more short section of thin stemming in the R-facing corner (5.12-) to gain a widening crack.  About 30-40 feet up~ cut left around a bulge on big face holds (really fun) to a L-facing corner.  Follow the corner up to a large ledge.  5.12-~ 90 ft.    P5:  Continue up the left-facing corner.  It starts thin~ but you can use a wide crack on the right wall.  Pull the roof at the top of the corner~ squirm up through a short wide section~ and belay at a tree visible from the bottom of the pitch.  This pitch looks like it's covered with slippery lichen~ but it doesn't really feel that slippery.  5.11-~ 115-130 ft.    P.5-6:  The route becomes much less engaging at this point.  Still fun~ but much slabbier and with grittier rock.  There are probably numerous ways to continue up from here.  We combined pitches 5 & 6 with a little bit of simulclimbing.  Climb up and right via 5.7 grooves with hand cracks in the back.  Above~ cut slightly left to belay at a decent-sized tree on the right side of a large ledge.  5.9+/10-.  230 ft.    P. 7-10:  We combined these into two pitches with some simulclimbing.  From the tree belay~ traverse down and left ~100 ft on an easy ledge to a large R-facing corner system.  Climb the corner and continue to angle up and right via cracks and ledges to the top.  5.8~ 500 ft.    Descent:  From the top~ hike down the standard descent gully with one single rope rappel near the bottom.
protection: 1 set stoppers (extra ~3-7~ selected brass optional)~ 2-3x tiny cams to green camalot~ 2x red and gold camalot~ single blue #3 and grey #4 camalot.  13-15 QDs and slings.

location: 04. Send Town > Teddy Bear Cove > East Idaho > Idaho
desc: Climb up to the start of a white crack.  Traverse left on tiny crimps to a blunt outside corner.  Continue up on small crimps.  Thought to be 13.

location: 2. Juniper Wall > 01. The Pit and Juniper Wall > Teddy Bear Cove > East Idaho > Idaho
desc: Ultra thin crimps over a big roof~ suspected 13.  Still waiting a clean ascent.  Comment and leave the grade if you send it.

location: Yellow Cake > The Fins > Central Idaho > Idaho
desc: Extension off of Fifty One.  From the chains head straight up.  Big moves between good holds leads to a powerful crux up high.  Finish in the crows nest alcove.
protection: 13 draws will get you to the second set of chains

location: Love Connection > Massacre Rocks > East Idaho > Idaho
desc: Link-up. Starts on French Connection to Aphrodisiac finish.

location: Weeping Cave > Palisades Creek > East Idaho > Idaho
desc: Great power moves right off the deck! 30 feet of sweetened condensed awesome.    Stand on the "cheat block" stone below the first bolt. There is an obvious positive jug to start on. Campus and power through this open book section till you get to the jugs above the second bolt.    Follow the line to a rail and undercling just above the 5th bolt. From here the crux moves up and around the left edge of the bolt line.    Good luck keeping it together for these last powerful moves to jugs and coldshuts!    I skip the 7th bolt.
protection: 7 bolts to coldshuts. Stick Clip. Knee Pad. Extend the 6th draw to make clipping easier. Skip the 7th bolt if you're serious about sending.

location: Weeping Cave > Palisades Creek > East Idaho > Idaho
desc: This left to right traversing route is amazing.  Crux is right off the ground.  Make sure to stick clip the first bolt.  This thing hits you with a nasty v6 boulder problem~ followed by some 5.11ish climbing to another v5 problem right below the chains.  Classic line!
protection: bolts~ some fixed draws~ and cold shuts

location: Martini Sector > The Discovery Wall > The Fins > Central Idaho > Idaho
desc: Climbing in a tan streak leads to a horizontal break around bolt 4. A large flake feature is on the second half of the route.

location: L-Buttress > Mini Fortress Area > Blue Mounds State Park (Luverne) > Minnesota
desc: Up the crack on the south side of L-Buttress.  Solid pro for leading.  The crux is the last ten feet to the top out.  Another fun Blue Mounds crack that sees little traffic.
protection: Standard TR set up - small/medium nuts and cams.  Long slings are helpful.    Nuts and cams for the lead - nothing too big.

location: Table Rock Buttress > Receding Ramparts Area > Blue Mounds State Park (Luverne) > Minnesota
desc: Prominent wide crack up the center of Table Rock Buttress.  It seemed like 5.7 climbing the whole way up rather than a distinct crux.
protection: Standard TR set up~ long slings helpful.

location: Little Foxx > Little Foxx Canyon > Duluth Bouldering > Duluth Rock Climbs > Duluth Area (Rock and Ice) > Minnesota
desc: Start with a little slab to a finger crack in a dihedral to a roof to a ledge to a fist crack/layback...so much variety for such a short route!  This is the only route in Duluth city limits that gives you better than 100 feet of exposure!    This route got its FA on Memorial Day but was named for the PBR Tall Boy that got smoked with a rock while scouting the start of the climb.

location: Section 13 > Lake County Road 6 Area (North Shore) > Minnesota
desc: Climb the striking detached pillar. This feature creates two distinct lines. On climbers right the pillar forms an off width crack. Or~ Traverse the base of the pillar. On climbers left the pillar forms a dihedral and hand crack. According to Farris these variations are 5.8 and 5.6 respectively. After surmounting the sharp pillar trend left on great rock to a thin crack. Rubble Trouble Direct (5.9) diverges into the finger crack to the right.
protection: Medium nuts~ large hexes~ and tri-cams. The unique surface of the rock makes placing cams difficult but lends itself to the placement of tri-cams. If you lead the off width bring a couple of pieces that are larger than 5 inches.

location: 3. Bottom Boulders Buttress > Prairie Walls Area > Blue Mounds State Park (Luverne) > Minnesota
desc: Follow the crack up on the right side of Bottom Boulders.  The cruxes involve cranking on loose rocks~ diminishing the quality of an otherwise nice climb.

location: Sun Drop II Tower > South Quarry Area > Blue Mounds State Park (Luverne) > Minnesota
desc: This climb isn't on sun drop tower. It's 30 steps to the north on the west wall. Not sure what that piece of rock is called?
protection: Cams for leading~ nuts for a anchor up top.

location: Mystical Mountain Zone > Wolf Ridge ELC Area (North Shore) > Minnesota
desc: A hard start for the grade. Can cheat start to the right a few feet and cut back left on a ledge a few feet up. The direct start is the route~ however. About 30 feet up~ cut left on a fortuitous hand traverse~ bushwack around some bushes~ and follow a nice corner up and to the top.
protection: Adequate gear for leading to 3 ". Placing pro at the start will likely fill the best jams. Extra small gear. Extra slings.

location: Winona, Sugar Loaf > Minnesota
desc: Fun route with varied climbing including some tenuous  slab to steeper finish. See if you use the sweet "six pack" hold while clipping the last bolt.
protection: 6 bolts to chain anchor with SS wiregates at the anchor.

location: The Slabs > M&M Hill - Crane Lake > Jeff's World (MN/CA border) > Minnesota
desc: Take a break from life for a while and climb some slab. This gently arcing route has one distinct crux around the third bolt and is otherwise consistent from start to finish.

location: BC's Wilderness Challenge (BWCAW) > Minnesota
desc: Snake Hole starts with an easy set of hand and foot holds with one 'leap of faith' in the beginning~ then settles into a nice line of classic 5.7 stuff. A great way to start the day and warm up.
protection: Pro can be a little spaced out~ and requires following 'You Crack Me Up' after the bottom 3rd. Mostly medium cams and larger nuts will work. This is a wilderness area~ so there is no fixed gear of any kind.

location: Foxx Rocks > Little Foxx Canyon > Duluth Bouldering > Duluth Rock Climbs > Duluth Area (Rock and Ice) > Minnesota
desc: First climbed ground up trad in 2007 with sketchy protection but has had two bolts (plus anchors) added to protect the crux.   This was originally rated 5.7 then 5.8 but people whined and suggested 5.10 (BS!) so we rated it 5.9 so as not to sandbag too badly.  It's a good safe lead now...   Solid start to a sequency and balancy crux that asks you to bear down hard on a crimp.  Follow the water groove up using the crimp to a side pull and then shoot for the horn!  Climb mellows above for 15/20 feet to the anchors.
protection: 2 bolts plus a few cams or nuts from #00 to #.75

location: Palisade Head > Tettegouche SP (North Shore) > Minnesota
desc: One of the classics of the area~ and the back cover of Mountaineering Freedom of the Hills 6th Ed.  Climb a somewhat chossy slab (5.6) with limited protection to a small ledge with a hand crack in it.  Jam the crack to the top (5.9).  Some people do this as one pitch or set up a belay at the ledge below the hand crack.  You can easily rap in with a single 60m rope~ not sure about 50m.   RCM&W #42~ p.214.
protection: Nuts and small cams for the bottom.  Hand sized hexes and cams for the top.  For the top rope setup I found a large cam (fist sized)~ nuts and tri-cams are helpful.

location: Secret Lake and Warmup wall > Jeff's World (MN/CA border) > Minnesota
desc: The first 30 feet or so of this route are on vertical clean rock with some interesting movement.  There is a difficult move after clipping the first bolt.  After the first half you turn a lip and finish the route on 30' of slab.  Like all good slabs~ this is smearing on little edges and dishes.
protection: 6 or 7 bolts.  The top is pretty run out~ but easy.  It can be protected with a #2 Camelot.

route: Prow Right AKA Dead Dog Arete AKA Gene Machine
location: The East End > Barn Bluff (Red Wing) > Minnesota
desc: This route used to be a toprope problem called Dead Dog Arete (or Prow Right) until Mike Endrizzi bolted it by mistake in 2006 (Mike~ please post an explanation~ sounds like an interesting story). Starts left of Dead Dog Face~ where the American flag is spraypainted on. Begin in middle of the prow~ follow the bolt line to where it diverges~ take a right around the corner to the last bolt and anchors on Dead Dog Face.  It's a good climb~ an arête hugger~ with a couple thoughtful moves.  Watch your rope for possible abrasion as you round the corner onto the face.      The name "Gene Machine" is in honor of Mike Endrizzi's mentor in life Gene Leonard.     RCM&W #49~ p. 126  mountainproject.com/v/minne…

location: 9. Chimney Buttress > Prairie Walls Area > Blue Mounds State Park (Luverne) > Minnesota
desc: Roofs goes up a broken crack system to an overhang (crux) and left facing corner.  The crack stays wet longer than almost any other route at Blue Mounds.  This route is a testy lead for the grade.
protection: Protectable (when dry) with nuts~ small to medium cams~ and probably hexes; otherwise use a standard Blue Mounds toprope (long slings helpful).

location: Section 13 > Lake County Road 6 Area (North Shore) > Minnesota
desc: Best 5.9 at the crag. Clean finger crack. The crux is committing to the slightly overhanging initial section. Nice exposure.
protection: Small to medium nuts and cams.

location: Keyhole Area > Interstate SP (Taylors Falls) > Minnesota
desc: This is a great route except for it's only a couple of moves.  Move up the finger crack on the arete also using the small ledges on the faces.  Balance and high stepping skilz are a must.    I have not found this route in any guide books but I'm sure someone has climbed it before.  Let me know if there is a name for this route.

location: Jeff's World (Proper) > Jeff's World (MN/CA border) > Minnesota
desc: Start on the slab below the left side of the large roof.  Work your way up to the top of the left side and make your way to the top.  The name will become apparent when you clip the 5th bolt.

location: Secret Lake and Warmup wall > Jeff's World (MN/CA border) > Minnesota
desc: This route is the second established route you will pass while walking along the ledge above the lake. There is an obvious horizontal flake on it you will see about half the way up the route where it starts to get steep.  Up to this point the route is easily protected with a few medium sized cams.  After you reach the flake~ there are 2 bolts that protect the crux because it is not easily protected with trad gear.  After the two bolts follow the overhanging corner to the anchors.  There is good holds and good gear here.

location: Mystical Mountain Zone > Wolf Ridge ELC Area (North Shore) > Minnesota
desc: Crack to the right of Cirith Ungol.  Start this from the ledge or the ground and stick to the left hand crack.  Great lead that eats gear!  Solid fingers to hands.

location: 9. Chimney Buttress > Prairie Walls Area > Blue Mounds State Park (Luverne) > Minnesota
desc: The Horizontal Tango starts up the dihedral in between Seduction and Rejection and In and Out.  Follow this dihedral up to the roof and continue straight up or stay in the crack that works to the right a bit for a harder version.
protection: Standard TR set up.  Long slings are helpful as usual.

location: Little Foxx > Little Foxx Canyon > Duluth Bouldering > Duluth Rock Climbs > Duluth Area (Rock and Ice) > Minnesota
desc: This feature fell but the route listing will stay up for posterity.  Just don't do it!!!   What looks like a sweet off-width roof crack will end up your demise (and your belayer's) if you try this.  The only feasable way seems to be to lie back the roof crack but this will likely enatil pulling down 12 tons of stone.  If your balls are this big then by all means...   but really~ enjoy the view but don't try to climb this.    A cave / passage about 40 feet left of Skittle Phlegm.  It looks tempting but should simply remain a cool land mark!
protection: A 2x4 slung and drapped over the top might work.  But do you really want to kill yourself?

location: New Vice Area > Barn Bluff (Red Wing) > Minnesota
desc: Climb the line of bolts following a basically straight path.  The climbing on this route is generally 5.8/9 except for the short 10c crux above the fourth bolt.   RCM&W #112~ p. 137.
protection: 4 bolts~ 2 bolt anchor.  Please use your own hardware for top roping whenever possible.

location: Tourist Rocks > Interstate SP (Taylors Falls) > Minnesota
desc: RCMW #2~ p. 155
protection: standard rack.  long webbing to setup top rope

location: Mystical Mountain Zone > Wolf Ridge ELC Area (North Shore) > Minnesota
desc: A tricky climb!  Fist crack in a dihedral leads to a wide roof crack.  Pull this to mellow climbing above and finish out on a perfect hand crack.

location: Cyclops Area > Barn Bluff (Red Wing) > Minnesota
desc: Around the corner from Sleeping Bat in a Ziplock Bag.  You'll run into a 8 foot block.  Stem your way up between the wall and the block to the first bolt about 15 feet above and meander your way through a number of small holes.  Work your way up~ then left to the slab and enjoy the slightly run out slabby finish.   RCM&W #13~ p. 117
protection: 5 bolts and a two bolt anchor that should be replaced soon.  The guide book indicates that the first bolt is missing.  It is not~ Jeff Engel - FA~ removed the original first bolt as it didn't do much to protect the climb.

location: Table Rock Buttress > Receding Ramparts Area > Blue Mounds State Park (Luverne) > Minnesota
desc: is pretty sustained 5.10 climbing the crux is the middle section trying to find feet.
protection: typical blue mounds top rope set up would not recommend leading this route

location: Winona, Sugar Loaf > Minnesota
desc: Rope Thief is the 3rd  bolted route from the left side of the North Face. Start by climbing easy big ledges leading to steeper edges and eventually using sidepulls and lay backs off the large flake feature that runs the majority of the climb. The pump builds to a crux right at the chains(were its supposed to be!).
protection: Glue In bolts with a little run out between bolts 2-3

location: Grandma' cabin, little vermillion lake > Jeff's World (MN/CA border) > Minnesota
desc: it goes from easy to hard.
protection: Cam it carefully or use those beautifull red pines at the top. Need One long sling.

location: Large Roof Area > Barn Bluff (Red Wing) > Minnesota
desc: The beginning of this route shares the dihedral and bolts with Talking with God. Climb up the dihedral to just under the roof.
