From here do a delicate traverse protected with a rusty~ unreliable bolt (use long draws under the roof!). Pull the lip of the roof on the left~ clip another bolt and climb to the shuts (some loose rock).     This isn't actually a bad route~ the moves are interesting and the traverse is fun. However~ given the combination of rusty bolts and rotten rock above the roof~ until the bolts get replaced~ climbing it should be considered very risky. If you fall from above the roof and the bolt rips~ you could easily deck.
protection: bolts.  please use your own gear for toprope.

location: Winter Wall > Barn Bluff (Red Wing) > Minnesota
desc: This is a pretty okay route that can be done if you have run out of other stuff in the 11+ or 12- range.  Find Jam and Jelly.  Go to the right of that maybe 15 feet and find a line of bolts that diverges into 3 upper lines.  Do the Right Thing is the right hand line.  Go figure.  It starts on Chinese Freedom and after the crux~ traverses right on a series of cool huecos with bad feet~ then find a small edge~ situate your feet~ and huck for the good ledge.  Up from there.    Strong people use this as a warm up and a way to get a TR on Paradigm Shift.  I actually didn't think it was any harder than Chinese~ but will leave the rating at 12a if only for historical sake.     RCM&W #42~ p. 125
protection: Bolts. Please use your own gear for top rope. Please bring an extra biner and if the ones up top look bad or don't easily clip or shut~ please replace it. It's good karma.

location: Swamp Wall > Jeff's World (MN/CA border) > Minnesota
desc: Hop off the raft and swim up a nice overhanging juggy section to the 4th bolt. Switch gears and punch it through an intricate crux section pulling onto the vertical wall.

location: Shovel Point > Tettegouche SP (North Shore) > Minnesota
desc: This route has recently been cleaned top to bottom (see below). Start on a 5.9 pitch~ and get set up at a belay below the roof. Second pitch is a really cool imposing overhang. Bolts for much of the route~ but as below~ it sounds like there are a couple of important #1 and a #0.75 cam placements to get through the upper section.  This route is well worth the effort of setting up to toprope~ and it is out of character for most of Shovel Point. The moves to get through the roof are classic~ and the exit from the roof is a tricky~ balancey little sequence.
protection: TR - make an anchor.   Lead - Some bolts~ but not enough.  Do some careful scouting~ or risk an endless fall on geriatric bolts.

location: Jeff's World (Proper) > Jeff's World (MN/CA border) > Minnesota
desc: Climb easy beginning straight up to slightly over-hanging~ left-traversing face.

location: Winter Wall > Barn Bluff (Red Wing) > Minnesota
desc: Easily overlooked because of its longer~ more popular neighbors to the right on the winter wall; Kelly's Arete offers superb~ delicate climbing up the arete just to the left of Jam and Jelly.  Start up the crack until you can reach left and clip the first bolt.  At this point it is possible to move out onto the arete proper and begin the real climbing.  A good sidepull allows a long reach to clip the second bolt before beginning the crux~ one of the best sequences you'll encounter at the bluff.  Reaching from a small left hand undercling~ the right is bumped up the arete until a decent pinch is found.  Smearing the right foot against a ripple in the rock~ the left is brought up to a good edge parallel with the undercling.  This position seems tailor made to generate an uncontrollable barndoor swing when the left hand is released~ but with a deep dropknee you can release your hand just long enough to make an enormous reach to a slopey pocket up high.  A few desperate bumps and you can reach a decent hold around the arete to the right~ leading to easier but still technical moves to reach the chains.  Unfortunately~ clipping the third bolt is very difficult and comes right in the middle of the crux sequence~ necessitating a horrible heelhook.  Some have chosen to skip the third bolt and climb through the crux before clipping.  This should be done with caution though~ as a large fall is risked on a very short climb~ and a grounder could occur.  Perhaps clipping the second bolt with a locking biner instead of a draw would help slightly~ and obviously an attentive belayer is a must!  However you choose to do it~ Kelly's Arete offers some of the bluff's most aesthetic climbing and should be high on everyone's ticklist.
protection: Bolts--Can also be easily TR'ed by leading Jam and Jelly~ which ends on the same ledge.  Please use your own gear for top rope.

location: Canidae Cliff  (Hammond) > Minnesota
desc: Start as for Latrans but veer right after second bolt and large sidepull to a rising traverse (potentially some dirty or loose stuff) to a stance below the ominuously overhanging and thin face above.  Excellent~ technical and sequency moves lead to twin underclings and a sustained finish (hint: gun for a softball sized hold over and down from the chained anchor~ but don't stop there....forge boldly to lip and a hidden clipping hold on slab beyond the lip for full value and an easier clip.     Camoflauged chains drop over the lip---don't clip around the chain~ but through the links themselves if no fixed biners are present!  Otherwise~ leave the biners there~ please.  Rapell hangers exsit along this route to back off the route (do not get lowered through them please.
protection: Bolts.  Chains with biners at the top.

location: Palisade Head > Tettegouche SP (North Shore) > Minnesota
desc: Start right of obvious thin crack and climb left up shattered rail to base of thin crack. Place small cams and/or bomber nuts as you climb thin crack and face holds on left passing a fixed piece below overlap/small roof. Pull small roof passing another fixed piece on crimps & side-pulls to gain shattered rail on the left. Work rightward up rail to a not-as-restful-as-you-think-it-will-be rest alcove with fixed pins. Go up trending slightly rightward placing gear in slots as you pass. There's a bit of a kick in the ass at the finish. Good gear (albeit sometimes awkard to place) throughout. Excellent route with great movement and interesting sequences! Reasonable lead as well as fun TR.
protection: Bring small to medium Stoppers~ Cams to #2~ Heavy on small (.3 Camalot) to Medium (#1 Camalot) cams. Draws and a couple 24" runners

location: Winter Wall > Barn Bluff (Red Wing) > Minnesota
desc: There is a huge block maybe 6 foot tall just to the right of Jump Start.  Start standing on that block~ the route trends a touch right on small holds and big moves.      I think this has to be close to the longest route at the Bluff (I think Looking for Lust has that honor~ or at least it used to before the anchors were lowered).     RCM&W #25~ p. 121
protection: Bolts. Please use your own gear for top rope. Please bring an extra biner and if the ones up top look bad or don't easily clip or shut~ please replace it. It's good karma.      It might be a good idea to stick clip the first bolt~ as the first crux is right off the block and if you blow it you could break an ankle in between the block and the wall.      Watch for some loose choss after the second crux.  Overall good rock though.

location: Palisade Head > Tettegouche SP (North Shore) > Minnesota
desc: Great exposure and fun pumpy face climbing up the arete to the left of Palisaid and Hidden Treasure.  Climb the obvious multi-layered juggy flake that does not appear to be attached to anything for 30 feet into a series of big holds followed by the balancy and technical crux on the right side of the arete. For full-value~ move back left past some calcite following a crack system with face holds to the top. For an easier escape~ climb to the right of the arete.
protection: Plenty of small cams (c3's and up to 0.75 c4's). Few good shallow placements in solid horizontal cracks. Some 'good looking' placements in questionable rock that would hold body weight. Burly crux protects with few decent pieces (including dyneema sling around the jug hold).    Gear anchor at the top.

location: Secret Lake and Warmup wall > Jeff's World (MN/CA border) > Minnesota
desc: Do you like cruiser trad climbing on excellent stone? Do you like pulling cruxes over the comfort of bolts with clean falls into space? Do you like a little funky~ full body trickiery in your diet that causes  your friends flop~ flail~ grunt and curse while you artfully mantle?    Then this line is for you!!    Certainly a one sequence wonder~ but the aesthetic position of the line probably makes up for it. Bring your leather chaps and A game if you don't want to get bucked off at this Rodeo.
protection: Single rack .3 - 2 inches~ two draws for the crux roof.

location: Potrillo Cliffs > White Rock > Los Alamos & White Rock > New Mexico
desc: none listed

location: Poultrygeist Area > Cockscomb Crag > Diablo Canyon > Santa Fe Area > New Mexico
desc: Presumably the crag warm-up~ providing sublime movement on stellar rock.  This route faces a bit more north than all the others~ so is the first route in the area to get shade.    Begin with sloping crimps on the slightly slabby~ lichen-covered wall.  At midheight several cool gas pockets appear and the difficulty eases.

location: Frog Prince > Enchanted Tower > New Mexico
desc: This route is great for that individual wishing to break into the 5.10 territory. Great holds~ slightly overhung~ falls are clean. One of the better 10s at the tower.

location: Area 37 > Jemez Mountains and Jemez Valley > New Mexico
desc: A short but nice slabby route at the far left side of the crag. Crux is from the middle to the top.

location: Dead Cholla Wall > Taos Area > New Mexico
desc: A straightforward line that is easier than it looks. Makes for a nice warmup for this area. Straightforward climbing with plenty of positive holds and only a couple tricky sections.
protection: 5 bolts~ option of gear down low if the easy runout is not comfortable.

location: Winter Wall > Mud Mountain > Truth or Consequences Area > New Mexico
desc: Easier climbing to a hard crux at the top.

location: (L5) Good Craic Wall > Utopian Vistas > Taos Area > New Mexico
desc: Curving crack trends to right at top and ends in alcove.  Share anchor with DB and INNA.  First route done here (ground up) to place anchors.   Craic=joke or news; Gaelic

location: Little Horse Mesa > Sugarite Canyon State Park > New Mexico, other Northern Areas > New Mexico
desc: Near the left side of the cliff at Sugarite is a gigantic roof.  The crack that passes the left side of the roof is the classic Great Roof Left.  Less classic but still fun is the crack that passes the right side.  Start up a huge flake that goes easy but unprotected (unless you have a #6 camalot or some big bros) to some dodgy-looking but solid blocks just below the roof.  Get some good pro in at the edge of the roof and pull some strenuous jamming and laybacking up around the roof to easier and fun hand jamming to the top. Heavy amounts of lichen on the left side of the crack keep the foot placements interesting to the top.     It's a fun route but not very consistent. Easy climbing to the roof~ a tough move around the roof and then easier climbing above.  Still worth doing~ though.     FA info would be greatly appreciated. Also~ suggested rating info would be nice too. The 5.10a rating is just our guess since we haven't seen anything published about this route. The move around the roof is definitely more challenging than any single move on Great Roof Left but overall the route is much less sustained.
protection: BD cams... .5~ .75~ 2x #2~ 2x #3 and some gear for the anchor (good anchor gear is a #4 and a #3.)

location: Campground > East Side > Luna Park > Red Rock Arroyo > Truth or Consequences Area > New Mexico
desc: The climbing gets a bit harder as one gets higher on the route.  The crux is on the upper headwall.
protection: 7 bolts to chains.  {lace longer slings on bolts 4 and 5 to reduce rope drag.

location: Percha Creek, Hillsboro > Truth or Consequences Area > New Mexico
desc: A short low-angled slab leads up to a nice roof problem. Easier for tall people. This short route feels like a boulder problem in the V0+ range. Failure only causes a fun clean fall~ so go for it.    This route is called "Unknown" (route #2) in Dennis Jackson's guidebook and is given a rating of 5.11.
protection: 2 bolts~ one mid-way up the slab~ and the other at the lip of the roof. 2-bolt anchor above the roof.

location: Bankruptcy Wall > East Side > Northern Box areas > The Box Climbing Areas > Socorro Area > New Mexico
desc: Climb a steeper section on good holds.  At the third bolt~ the route joins Line of Credit for the crux moves on good rock.

location: Judas Crag Sector > Eden Wall > Eden Canyon > Diablo Canyon > Santa Fe Area > New Mexico
desc: Obvious trad crack on great basalt. Fun climbing~ crux down low~ good gear on good rock.
protection: singles up to #3 cam.  Maybe doubles in zero-cams.  small wires useful.

location: Percha Creek, Hillsboro > Truth or Consequences Area > New Mexico
desc: A straightforward crack and corner climb with a distinct crux a little less than half-way. The crux is right above a good ledge and rest stance. Here a slight bulge in the wall is surmounted with a near perfect parallel sided thin-hands/ring-lock crack.
protection: 3" and smaller~ with many options. Chain anchor on top is about 30 m off the ground~ perfect for 60 m ropes.

location: Upper Wall > Capulin Canyon > Capulin Canyon and Cochiti Mesa Area Crags > Jemez Mountains and Jemez Valley > New Mexico
desc: This route looks a lot harder than it actually climbs.  Great jams and other interesting holds in the steep corner with overlaps.      Step up into a fun chimney and pop a cam above you before transitioning into the nice corner crack.  Step up onto an alcove~ catch your breath~ and cruise easier terrain to the anchors.
protection: single rack from 0.5 to #5 Camalot.  Bring an extra gold and blue camalot.  bolted anchor.

location: Possum Junction > The Terrace > Albuquerque Area > New Mexico
desc: The crux is above the fourth bolt getting to the anchor.

location: (09) The Far Side II > Palomas Peak > Albuquerque Area > New Mexico
desc: This is the 5.10 variation of Hangman.  Climb the first two bolts of Hangman~ go straight up to two new bolts and finish on Hangman again.  The crux is around the 4th bolt.
protection: 6 bolts to the shared anchor with Pussy Whipped.

location: High Rock > Left Side > Lower Juan Tabo Canyon > Albuquerque Area > New Mexico
desc: The crux~ above the 5th bolt~ is technical face climbing at the top of the route.
protection: 6 bolts to a bolt & chain anchor. It can be set by climbing left from the Gentle Touch anchor.

location: Red Wall > Northern Box areas > The Box Climbing Areas > Socorro Area > New Mexico
desc: A hard start with a few big pockets gets you to bolt 2~ where you'll angle to the right passing 2 more bolts protecting a somewhat awkward/thin crimpy crux~ then up and left to the chains on a ledge.
protection: 4 (or was it 5?) bolts to a 2-bolt anchor.  Rappel with 1 50m rope.

location: Upper Wall > Capulin Canyon > Capulin Canyon and Cochiti Mesa Area Crags > Jemez Mountains and Jemez Valley > New Mexico
desc: Methedras forms the back wall of Isengard fortress. This route is tucked away in a shady corner around the back of the tower (see beta photo). It never receives sun so is good on a hot day. Fun slightly wide climbing leads to smaller stuff to an anchor.

location: The Rim of the World > Pecos River Canyon > Santa Fe Area > New Mexico
desc: Climb the crack~ the crux~ then up and left to an anchor on a ledge.
protection: Mixed gear and bolts.  Shares an anchor with Access Card

location: The Grandstand > Pecos River Canyon > Santa Fe Area > New Mexico
desc: Pull the interesting start and then face climb to the anchors.
protection: Bolts to the shared anchor of the Three Stooges.

location: Old Stagecoach Road > John Dunn Bridge Area > Taos Area > New Mexico
desc: Bouldery start to undercling then mantle to small ledge.  Finish on pocketed face.
protection: Bolts to chain back on rock.

location: Campground > East Side > Luna Park > Red Rock Arroyo > Truth or Consequences Area > New Mexico
desc: Climb the face to the anchor.

location: Boot Hill > Albuquerque Area > New Mexico
desc: Climb up to the first two bolts on large blocks/ ledges. The bottom crux is tightly bolted in the crack over a small roof~ moving left after bolt 3. Continue on the left face (in close proximity to "Bolt Action") to bolt #4 ~ and follow the line back right on the the last 3 bolts through a more sustained section. An alpine draw is recommended for bolt #6 to reduce drag.  As of now~ there are two anchors in place. The lower one on the face does not have chains ( recommended for top ropes ). The anchor after topping out over the large flake to the left~ does include chains for cleaning. The grade currently stands at 10b/c after some rock fell off right around the crux. The move is fairly height dependent~ the taller you are~ the easier this climb should feel.
protection: 8 or 9 bolts to the high anchor w/ chains after topping out. Optional two bolt anchor lower on the face w/o chains.

location: The Wall of Voodoo > The Grotto > Diablo Canyon > Santa Fe Area > New Mexico
desc: Starting on the left side of the ledge~ work your way up some old school slot climbing to a low angle dihedral.
protection: 6 bolts~ 2 bolt anchor with chains and carabiners

location: Violince Wall > Last Chance Canyon > New Mexico, other Southern Areas > New Mexico
desc: A mellow start working up to the first bolt where the angle kicks up you will find some excellent pockets. The crux comes at the bulge an you near the white section.  The pockets disappear replaced by vague crimps and dusty slopers.  Work through the slab section.  The upper section adds a few more moves to the chains.

location: Flowing Chi Wall > Wild and Scenic > Taos Area > New Mexico
desc: Layaway leftfacing corner is immediate and committing. Follow finger to handcrack to stance at head wall.  Sparce but solid gear allows flow on good holds to exit right 10b (felt more natural)~ or straight through notch on good holds with powerful moves 11a.
protection: Standard rack with double finger sizes.

location: Super Slab > El Rito Sport Area > El Rito > New Mexico
desc: Clark's guide says of "Oreo"~ "Hard moves at bottom and top~ softer sweet stuff in between" and that's quite accurate. Thin moves to the first bolt if you go straight at it or start right-ish and move over to the bolt. Then 5.8-5.9ish monster jugs through the middle to a thin roof/bulge to finish.    The Foley "Taos Rock" book suggests to stem the start using the right wall and then to grab the chains for the finish--neither of which is necessary. For the chains-clip~ just go a bit further and grab the right edge of the Super Slab wall.
protection: 8 bolts to chains with steel carabiners.

location: Second Tunnel > Gilman Tunnels > Jemez Mountains and Jemez Valley > New Mexico
desc: This worthwhile route is a good option on a hot afternoon or chilly morning.  Certainly one of the best routes on the left side~ this route can be a bit dirty at times~ despite good-quality rock.  Begin by scrambling up to the belay stance.  Its possible to climb a mini-pitch up to a good ledge with a belay bolt for minimal rope drag~ but its perfectly do-able (and surely less of a hassle) to belay from the 2nd class ledges below.  Snake up the vertical wall~ occasionally reaching right around the arete.

location: Villain Wall > Bat Cave Area > Caballo Lake > Truth or Consequences Area > New Mexico
desc: 1st PITCH   (80') - 5.11a   Start at the Dirt Day crack. Step up and clip a bolt a few feet right of the crack/seam then trend further right to a shallow hueco and some thin 5.11a/10d moves after the 3rd bolt. Continue following the bolt line past more small holds. The moves generally get easier as you move higher but the climbing is always fun and on great stone. Reach the chains at a small ledge/stance after about 10 bolts~ there is a tree about 15 feet to the left. (10 bolts?)  2nd PITCH   (70') - 5.10a/b   Move up left from the belay. Easy 5.10 moves clear the first bulge on small holds. Continue past a second easier bulge using cool big pocket jugs to a yellow face.  Climb past the yellow face and easier terrain to a chain belay at another small ledge/stance. (7 bolts?)  3rd PITCH -   Unfinished and not cleaned- NO ANCHORS!!
protection: Bolts and chain anchors with lowering biners

location: Main Cliff > Capulin Canyon > Capulin Canyon and Cochiti Mesa Area Crags > Jemez Mountains and Jemez Valley > New Mexico
desc: Very fun wide climbing. Rap from upper ledge.

location: Muralla Grande > Chimney Canyon > Sandia Mountains > Albuquerque Area > New Mexico
desc: This long and excellent climb goes up the center of Muralla Grande~ passing the biggest obvious roof just to its left. It might be considered a major variation to Warpy Moople~ as "Out to Lunch" shares the start with that route. This may be a small step up in seriousness from Sandia 5.10 classics like Yucca Flower Tower and Mtn Momma. Expect good rock and possibly some complicated route-finding on what is maybe the best 5.10 line on the cliff.  Pitch 1: The first 1+1/2 pitches are shared with Warpy Moople. Start at the highest pine tree below the big roofs. Follow a shallow right-facing corner straight above~ then weave your way left then back right~ then back left again to a belay on a grassy ledge (5.7~ 130).  Pitch 2: Go up and right~ undercling right past a roof~ then go straight up passing a big flake. Move left to a ledge with a piton~ belay. (5.9~ 100).  Pitch 3: Climb above the ledge and work left to a belay ledge left of the biggest roof. This belay has a fixed pin and fixed nut (5.7~ 90).  Pitch 4: This crux pitch is full-on Sandia wildness. Climb right and up a tricky right-facing corner passing a piton (a 2nd pin shown on the topo is missing in 2018). Clip a 1/4 bolt below a roof~ make a thin traverse right 15 to a new bolt. Go straight up technical terrain with small knobs to a crack~ then turn a small roof and step right to a 2-bolt belay. (5.10b~ 110)  Pitch 5: (a) Traverse right and slightly downward 20~ to a short hand crack (rejoining Warpy Moople~ which traverses in from the right). Face climb~ continuing up and right~ sometimes with infrequent protection to a 2-bolt belay on a small ledge. (5.9~ 120). (b) Or go straight up from the belay (see comment from John Kear below).  Pitch 6: Straight up from the belay to a fixed pin. Make one tricky move just past the fixed pin~ traverse right~ and go up to a grassy ledge. Angle up and left~ first climbing past a small chimney~ then along an easy left-trending ramp to a belay at another grassy ledge (5.8+~ 160).  Pitch 7: Stem a weird dihedral off the belay; then straight up loose open corner to the top (5.8~ 180).  There are other options from the belay after pitch 4~ going straight up or to the left; one of those is probably the original route. Consult the guidebooks and see comment below.
protection: Cams and nuts to 4~ with some doubles in finger/thin hands sizes.

location: Hole in the Wall > La Cueva Canyon, Upper > Sandia Mountains > Albuquerque Area > New Mexico
desc: Climb straight up through the roofs on good holds (the crux).  A 60 m rope can be used but exercise care when lowering.
protection: Mixed route~ gear and bolts.  Standard trad rack to hand sized cam (gold camalot).  Anchors and chain at the top.

location: Crow Feather Wall > Mud Mountain > Truth or Consequences Area > New Mexico
desc: Fun~ technical climbing on slightly less than vertical limestone

location: Questa Dome > Questa Dome > Taos Area > New Mexico
desc: From the base of the south face~ walk down left to the toe of the dome~ then walk up left 150 feet along the base of the west side. There is a huge left-facing dihedral (with a dramatic hand crack on its right wall) 100 feet above the ground. This is NOT the climb. Look for a smaller left-facing dihedral~ with a few trees~ 50 feet left of the huge dihedral~ and also about 100 feet above the ground. Start directly below this smaller dihedral.  1. Clip a piton 10 feet off the ground~ move up and right across some small rounded overhangs. Continue up the crack that leads to the smaller dihedral. Pull up and past a small tree to the next level of slab.  Climb the wall of the dihedral to reach a ramp with a thin seam and little gear/no gear for 20 feet. Climb the ramp to where it steepens and place gear in a crack before making awkward moves to reach a 2-piton belay which can be backed up with a #2 cam. 160 feet~ 5.9. (If you arrive at a tree with rappel slings~ you are on the rappel route~ not the climbing route.)  2. Step up on friction and continue up small cracks. Climb a wide v-slot to gain a face with thin cracks and small pro. Traverse up and left across the slab to gain a large flake~ #2 cam. Pull up and over the flake to gain right facing corner with a large block. Look up to find  3 bolts on the face. Climb the corner/face clipping bouts to a comfortable belay at 2 pitons. 160 feet~ 5.10.  3. Step up on blocks to reach the bolt. Make thin face moves to pull up onto a slab/ledge. Cross the slab up and right to reach a wide right facing corner (not visible from the belay). Stem the corner working up and into the base of a finger and hands crack. Sustained stemming and jamming leads up the crack to a ramp with right facing dihedral and trees. Clip a pin and move left and up a second crack/ramp system for 15 feet. Place gear high and then traverse right to regain the crack in the dihedral. step on or over a tree to clip a pin. Continue up the flared crack past the third pin to reach the top of the crack.  Look right for a small belay ledge with one bolt and a slingable horn~ a thin crack left of the bolt provides gear placements to back up the bolt.  100 feet~ 5.10+.  4. Traverse left along a thin crack with little/no gear.  At the end of the crack make a reach to clip the first of two bolts. Make delicate moves on polished face/slab to the second bolt. Step down and left to reach a seam which you follow to the overhang.  Place solid gear~ #1-2 cams~ in the base~ middle and above the roof.  Make long reaches to gain large holds.  Work your feet up and pull on to the face above the overhang. Follow a wide crack for 20 feet to a treed sloping belay ledge with 1 bolt on the right wall of a left-facing dihedral. 80 feet~ 5.10.  5. Walk left to a gnarly tree to gain access to the finger crack splitting this smooth face~ which is prominently visible from the approach trail. Climb the crack and face holds for about 50 - 70 feet placing small cams and nuts.  From the end of the finger crack~ look for bolt 20 feet up and right above a flared crescent shaped crack. From the first bolt look up 20-30 ft to spot the second bolt.  Climb the face using edges and crystalized pockets to gain the second bolt. Pull up on to a tree covered ledge and belay 110 feet~ 5.10.  6. Follow the left arête to the top of the ridge. 100 feet~ 5.4.
protection: Carry a full rack for cracks from 1/4 inch to 3 inches.

location: Panorama Wall > Utopian Vistas > Taos Area > New Mexico
desc: Fingers to off width crack climb to left of Rambunctious arête. Starts in clean finger crack widening to off width at top~  small pro to be had in upper crack or bring large pieces.  Anchor can be reached to left or climb off.  Belay from rim rock with gear anchor possible. Saw a healthy Big Horn Ram today on the way into the crag.
protection: Finger to off width. Run out to anchor on awkward off width at top.

location: (L3)  El Grito Del Norte Wall > Utopian Vistas > Taos Area > New Mexico
desc: Crux at brief layback to large incuts and pockets after third bolt.  Rananim: the utopian community D.H. Lawrence intended to found in Northern New Mexico (Rananim is hebrew for "Land of Exultation")

location: The Anvil > Pinnacle Valley > Sandia Mountains > Albuquerque Area > New Mexico
desc: This 4 pitch route climbs the lower face of the Anvil to connect with the striking SW arete - crack  before finding in a right facing dihedral. P1 and P3 and P4 are very nice. P3 is "Sandia at its worse" - blocky and loose. Can do P3 and 4 for a nice 5.9 outing.(See Topo)    P1 (***) start at base of clean face in dihedral that forms the left side of a distinct petestal. Climb up and then move left to arete to a small ledge~ step right back (5.10 crux) to arete and follow up to 2 bolt belay.    P2 Short pitch:  loose and blocky - aiming for the base of the stunning crack on the arete. Has a tendecy to ruin the rest of the climb.    P3: climb this flake crack by lie backing for ~ 60 feet (5.8-) to the 2 bolt belay. Eats #4 Camelots - would be strenuous~ except the flake has a perfect foot ledge every 10 feet to shake out and place pro.    P4: Climb Straight up from belay~ (5.9) then drift left on a seam/ramp~ until you can fight your way back to large right facing dihedral finishing on top where you rigged your first rappel.
protection: All natural pro - from small sliders to #4 Camelot. 2 bolt belays on 2 of rap stations

location: The Red Tail Wall > Wild and Scenic > Taos Area > New Mexico
desc: The standard short start section of questionable rock~ not a big deal~ and a few bolts clipped~ leads to good quality crack in a corner system.  Moving into V-slot is a fun and interesting crux.
protection: A couple bolts to start~ then mostly finger sized gear.  I think I placed up to a 0.75 Camalot.  Doubles in everything else smaller.

location: Breakfast Wall > Last Chance Canyon > New Mexico, other Southern Areas > New Mexico
desc: Thin moves climb up for a short balancy crux.  Short~ sweet~ and steep.  Good distraction when you bring the noobs out for the moderate lines.

location: Runway (Lower Tier) > Early Wall > Diablo Canyon > Santa Fe Area > New Mexico
desc: Fun moves up the buttress.  Tricky thin moves between big holds down low and a 2nd crux at the bulge section midway up.  More easier steep climbing on big hold above this~ then the angle lessens for the last 2 bolts to the big ledge.      This climb is used to access You're Scaring the Horses.

location: Mavericks > Taos Area > New Mexico
desc: This is the route farthest to the left.

location: Top of the Grotto (Ojo and Evil Paradise Sectors ) > The Grotto > Diablo Canyon > Santa Fe Area > New Mexico
desc: This great climb has a little bit of everything.  It has crack climbing to laybacks to face to slab.  Might be easiest to skip the bolted belay and be careful getting to the first bolt~ at most 5.6.

location: Runway (Lower Tier) > Early Wall > Diablo Canyon > Santa Fe Area > New Mexico
desc: Climb the crack in the dihedral for 5 bolts then traverse right at the bulge. Work your way up the prow on good holds into the large corner system. Face holds lead to stemming as the route steepens~ capped off by jugs over the final roof. This route will seem a lot harder without solid trad skills.

location: (05) The Transition Zone > Palomas Peak > Albuquerque Area > New Mexico
desc: Slab climbing where half the route is covered with a black smear that offers bomber crimps.  The crux is at the first two bolts.

location: The Doughnut Shop > White Rock > Los Alamos & White Rock > New Mexico
desc: The crux is near the bottom. Climb a thin Playground type crack with small stoppers and then up to a pleasurable three bolt arete to a two bolt anchor which is shared with Greasy Hairnets.
protection: Thin stoppers and quickdraws. 2 bolt anchor.

location: The Amphitheater > Upper East Fork (UEF) > Jemez Mountains and Jemez Valley > New Mexico
desc: This shy route flirts with the difficulties of the steep dark streak left of "Nguvu" but avoids them with a short traverse.    Head up three bolts shared with "Nguvu" on occasionally flakey rock (10a?~ easier if you know where to grab). Cut left with an easy traverse to a no-hands stance below the fourth bolt. Clip the fourth bolt and climb steep but juggy terrain below a small roof. Pull the roof (crux) with the help of some killer hidden pockets. Clip one more bolt if you like and make a couple easy moves to the anchors.    Originally rated 5.10b~ the consensus seems to be that it's a notch harder. A fun route~ whatever the rating~ and it makes for a good warmup for the harder stuff in the Amphitheater.
protection: 7 bolts to chains with fixed carabiners

location: Bush Shark Area > Echo Canyon > Sandia Mountains > Albuquerque Area > New Mexico
desc: Starts and stays to the left of Bush Shark Spire and ends at the bolted belay on Bush Shark.  On the heady side for the emerging 5.10 climber.
protection: A few bolts and a few small cams.

location: Air Wall > Comales Canyon > Taos Area > New Mexico
desc: Fun and exposed with a wild finish through the big roof at top.  Three cruxes~ one passing a low roof~ one up the striking orange headwall~ and (you guessed it) the big roof itself.  Goes at a surprisingly moderate grade.

location: Solstice Cave > Last Chance Canyon > New Mexico, other Southern Areas > New Mexico
desc: Still needs some work to be good.  Some loose rock still off the main line makes a helmet essential.  This route climbs the prow that stands just right of the Hot Tamale.  For full effect~ stay out on the prow and avoid the crack on the left.  Overall~ a decent line that should get inconsistent ratings as it's much harder straight up.

location: (04) Showdown Wall > Palomas Peak > Albuquerque Area > New Mexico
desc: Tricky start past a low bolt (leave the tree alone) leads to easier climbing for the second and third bolts.  From here continue past shrinking holds heading right underneath the roof.  You can either try to get what you can palming and laying back the roof or crimp small holds on the face. Once you pass the sixth bolt enter the dihedral and continue to the anchors on easier ground.    First ascent was during some very cold conditions~ hence the name.

location: Super Slab > El Rito Sport Area > El Rito > New Mexico
desc: Start up the steeper rock toward the center of the crag~ levels out to lower angle. Then~ over the bulge. Two ways 1) go slightly left for the easiest climbing (5.10a)~ the climb is .10+ or .11- if you continue straight up the bolt line. Longest route at El Rito.

location: Dead Cholla Wall > Taos Area > New Mexico
desc: Arete and thin face climb on the arete just right of Fun.  Interesting moves and the ever-present question to step around the corner or to stay on the side you're on.

location: Capulet Side Canyon > Capulin Canyon > Capulin Canyon and Cochiti Mesa Area Crags > Jemez Mountains and Jemez Valley > New Mexico
desc: Delicate start leads to thin hands to fingers over a small roof next to the big flake.
protection: Two or three each from 0.4 to #1. One 0.2 size useful.

location: The Hinterlands > Capulin Canyon > Capulin Canyon and Cochiti Mesa Area Crags > Jemez Mountains and Jemez Valley > New Mexico
desc: Thin hands in a corner for almost the entire route. Starts with powerful laybacking or thin hands jamming if that's your thing. A pod near the middle allows for a no-hands rest before another strenuous thin hands section. Eases a bit at the top.
protection: Heavy on the 0.75 and #1 camalots. 0.5 near the top. A #4 BD goes nicely just above the big pod halfway up.

location: Middle Earth Sector > Mordor > Diablo Canyon > Santa Fe Area > New Mexico
desc: Great warmup for the area. Obvious bolted crack at entrance to the Inner Earth area~ left side. Gets earliest morning sun.

location: Huacas > The Subdivisions > Las Conchas > Jemez Mountains and Jemez Valley > New Mexico
desc: A really fun boulder problem down low leads to thin moves on marginal rock(needs traffic) in the middle on easy ground.

location: 3. Gold Rush Wall > Vista Verde Crag > Taos Area > New Mexico
desc: Climb the same crack start as for Gavilan but continue straight into the steep Inside corner (clip a long runner on the 2nd bolt of Gavilan).  Crux involves technical stemming up under the roof.  Turn the roof and clip 2 more bolts to then join the upper crux of Gavilan.

location: (L5) Good Craic Wall > Utopian Vistas > Taos Area > New Mexico
desc: Start with bouldery move off high ledge under arete and move into Left facing corner (share 2 bolts with "Oh~ Danny Boy").  Step right at third bolt then continue up  blunt arete.

location: Hall of Giants > Capulin Canyon > Capulin Canyon and Cochiti Mesa Area Crags > Jemez Mountains and Jemez Valley > New Mexico
desc: To slay this Giant~ weave up and through some large boulders to gain a ledge at the base of a flawless splitter that turns to a left-facing corner about 50' up. Climb fingers to hands for 120' through perfect rock that gives you just enough playful features to keep it under 5.11 while dishing out enough business to keep you focused~ all the while leaning gently back to finish nearly 20' overhung from where you started!!!  Stunning!!!
protection: 3 each Camalots from 0.5 to 3~ 2 each 0.4 and 4    Bolted anchor.

location: Training Wall > El Rito Sport Area > El Rito > New Mexico
desc: Another steep but short climb at El Rito~ this is the most natural and easier way to climb to the anchors for Just Another Pretty Face.  This variation is about 4' to the right of the original route~ so they are very close together.    The crux is a move getting to the 2nd bolt. At the last bolt~ step left~ which will put you on the line you'd be climbing for Just Another Pretty Face. There's one last pumpy section before the chains.     The grade felt soft for even "El Rito 5.11" to me~ but maybe it earns it if you stick strictly to the bolt line instead of following path of least resistance.

location: Grotto Left (East Side) > The Grotto > Diablo Canyon > Santa Fe Area > New Mexico
desc: The route is the second one you come to on your left on The East Wall of The Grotto~ right around the corner from A Day with Dr. Diablo. This is a very continuous route at this grade and is actually not as bad as originally thought. There is some vertical Diablo type climbing that starts in a dihedral for 3 bolts then continues through four more bolts to a two bolt anchor. The crux is right between the 3rd and 5th bolts on not so positive holds that are similar to the ones found on Good but a lot smaller and worse. I think the route is slightly technical~ very continuous~ and has an endurance crux. K.S.R. may also be used as an approach(5.8 runout) to The Skyline Arete and "Medusa" on the upper tier of The East Wall of The Grotto.
protection: Seven quickdraws to a two bolt chained anchor. Small to medium cams(optional) for the 5.8 runout if continuing to the upper tier. There is a bombproof two bolt anchor on the upper tier that you can get off with a 60 meter rope to the north side of the KSR buttress.

route: Liposuction Massacre, Rhonda Savage St. George
location: North Wall > Northern Box areas > The Box Climbing Areas > Socorro Area > New Mexico
desc: Scramble up onto the large blocks between North Wall and Corner block to get started.  Easiest to start scrambling just right of the start for "The Truth).  After getting on top of the blocks it looks like there is a scary run-out~ but there is a hidden 2nd bolt you can't see from below.  Boulder up past the first two bolts to some easier lower angle climbing.  Get a nice rest in the corner and continue up either the corner system or arete to the anchors.  A challenging but worthwhile 5.10.
protection: 6 Bolts to Anchors.  Second bolt is hidden until you are right on it.  (There are two extra bolts than what RC NM shows).

location: Captain Hook's Grotto > Enchanted Tower > New Mexico
desc: Start on a chossy slab~ best to traverse in from the right to clip the first bolt to miss some of the worst rock.  Continue up past the second and third bolt.  Whenever the holds die out utilize the arete passing the fourth bolt.  Catch a nice (slightly awkward rest) clip the 5th bolt out left (bolt was placed here to provide a cleaner fall) and head right to a hueco and traverse left to the next bolt.  Slightly harder if done direct.    Continue up easy ground for a few more bolts to the final overhang and anchors.  Leaver biners would be nice here as there isn't much of a stance for cleaning.    New route and still has some loose rock.  Should get better as the rock cleans up.

location: Major Wall > Southern Box areas > The Box Climbing Areas > Socorro Area > New Mexico
desc: Start up on large hueco's just to the right of the start for the "Demon".  Continue up traversing right past several good hueco's to a long move pulling over the lip.  Over the lip a no hands rest is encountered and several more trivial moves to the mid anchors.  Stop here or continue up the easier slab finish with some cool holds to make it worthwhile.    This route also is an easy way to set up a TR or hang draws on the Demon.
protection: Well protected with 8 bolts to chain anchors.

location: (L7) Where the Bobbalo Roam > Utopian Vistas > Taos Area > New Mexico
desc: Seriously~ it's climbing.  Start on sharp layback in corner.  Stem up to v-slot and make hard moves to easy climbing above. Bombay slot is crux.
protection: 6 bolts to ring anchors.  Might go on gear~ but why not just solo it.

location: Percha Creek, Hillsboro > Truth or Consequences Area > New Mexico
desc: Sustained face climbing for the first 4 bolts~ on a thin but elegant face. Trees have grown into the route~ causing an added element of difficulty. Dennis Jackson's guidebook states that the route is 5.11- if you refrain from using the corners. The bolt line takes you far enough away from the left corner where it doesn't help much~ and the arete on the right side doesn't offer any great advantage. After the 4th bolt there is a nice rest-stance before a small roof. Good holds pull you through the roof and the remaining 30' to the anchors.
protection: 5 bolts and pro (for the top section) to a 2-bolt anchor.

location: Monster Wall > Upper East Fork (UEF) > Jemez Mountains and Jemez Valley > New Mexico
desc: Steep~ fun climbing with good gear and multiple cruxes. Much more solid than it looks.
protection: Nuts to #2 Camalot.....EDIT to ADD~ others feel a #3 camelot is very useful.   2-bolt anchor.

location: Hole in the Wall > La Cueva Canyon, Upper > Sandia Mountains > Albuquerque Area > New Mexico
desc: This is the right route on the wall. Start below a right facing corner~ climb up into this then trend up an right on a ramp feature~ then blast straight up the wall passing several small roofs en route to the rap anchor at the top of the wall.
protection: Bolts and gear up to a #2 camalot.

location: Frog Prince > Enchanted Tower > New Mexico
desc: The Fazio-Rhicard/ Agee book names this route "*???????5.10b".  Find the route with the "Location" information below. Climb the sharp low angle rock to the actual climb. Follow the overhung pockets to the chains over the lip.

location: Petites Gorges n°2 Rive Gauche C > Todra Gorge > Morocco > Africa > International
desc: This is a placeholder. If you know this route~ please use the 'Improve This Page' link to make it better!

location: Jardin D'Hiver > Todra Gorge > Morocco > Africa > International
desc: L1 5.10b quite easy climbing~ to the left at the end L2 5.11a start to climb in the crack above the belay station...
protection: Well bolted~ 12 quickdraws~ anchor at the top

location: Dalle des Hollandais > Todra Gorge > Morocco > Africa > International
desc: 3 type of climb in the same route ! Overhang~ crack~ slab~ very nice!
protection: well bolted with a chain anchor

location: Petites Gorges n°2 Rive Gauche C > Todra Gorge > Morocco > Africa > International
desc: This is a placeholder. If you know this route~ please use the 'Improve This Page' link to make it better!

location: Sahara > Todra Gorge > Morocco > Africa > International
desc: This is a placeholder. If you know this route~ please use the 'Improve This Page' link to make it better!

location: Big Fig > Kenya > Africa > International
desc: There are two variations to this route. (P1 5.6) The route starts at the far left crack with a bouldery move to gain a good fist crack with good pro. Where the crack trends right~ make an exposed~ unprotected move to climbers left to gain another wide off-width that trends up and to the left. Follow this to a massive~ obvious ledge at the base of pitch 2. (P2 5.11a) Follow the obvious fist crack straight up for 15 feet to a solid finishing jug with a mantle top out. Belay partner up off roots of fig tree at the top of climb. The crack takes #2 and #3 camalots.   Variation start: (P1 5.5) From the top of the block~ step right onto an exposed face with good feet~ trending right to the base of the off-width crack of standard route P1. Follow crack up the ledge~ where you merge with P2 above.
protection: Standard rack camalots 0.4 - 3 with doubles of #2 and #3.

location: The Beach > The Island crags > Waterval Boven > South Africa > Africa > International
desc: From the high first bolt~ head slightly left to the corner and enter face. Specific crux~ specially if you are short~ to get over the little overlap. After~ very nice climbing getting quite thin at the end. (South African grade 22)

location: Harry Potter > Chosspile > South Africa > Africa > International
desc: Climb a few easy moves up to hard crux.  After deciphering that pull through some easy climbing to an easier crux and then push through at the end through an overhang to a pedestal. It has a hard third clip that has recently been made safer with the addition of a new bolt.

location: Main Crag > Silvermine > South Africa > Africa > International
desc: Start at the juggy roof section just where the trail comes to the first wall section. Straight up to the roof and then left. Up some laybacks to pockets in the wall to some ledges up top. Crux is (probaly at the end of the second layback section to the pocketed wall.
protection: All glued in bolts and double bolts as anchors. 10 bolts

location: The Ramp > Ngomakurira > Zimbabwe > Africa > International
Gaper Butress > The Restaurant crags > Waterval Boven > South Africa > Africa > International
desc: One of the best lines.
protection: 16 draws. Rope drag becomes an issue; possible to skip a draw or two lower on the route

location: Poissons sacrés > Todra Gorge > Morocco > Africa > International
desc: L1= 5.10b / L2= 5.11d / L3= 5.11b / L4= 5.11b / L5= 5.10c / L5= 5.11d Descent by rappel in the route or by "Bon courage"
protection: Some bolts but you need~ slings~ nuts~ friends.... Anchor at belay station ???? not sure !

location: Pedra Escrita / Writing Stone > Angola > Africa > International
desc: A beautifully striking crack that looks like it's going to be a pleasant outing of casual jams. Unfortunately~ as the name suggests~ it has some serious bite. The large quartz crystals in the crack are like spiked little vises on your hands. Alex and I thought it was probably the most painful pitch of rock climbing either of us had ever done.     Start with strenuous high step layback~ you can get a high .75 to protect this. Stay with it for a few moves to a good fingerlock where you can place some good gear and get ready to grit and bear it for the next 100 feet.     Taped hands didn't seem to help much~ perhaps some lightweight boxing gloves?
protection: A finger sized piece or two~ triples of .75-#2 camalot~ maybe a #3 for the top/directional. Two bolt anchor (no quicklinks)

location: C2 or the cave > Todra Gorge > Morocco > Africa > International
desc: Departure to the left to meet the route on the left after the third bolt and same end
protection: Well bolted~ anchor at the top

location: Mansour droite > Todra Gorge > Morocco > Africa > International
desc: This is a placeholder. If you know this route~ please use the 'Improve This Page' link to make it better!

location: The Superbowl > The Wonderland crags > Waterval Boven > South Africa > Africa > International
desc: Slightly overhanging climbing that gets progressively harder.     A 20 foot section of 5.7 gains the first bolt.  Step onto the pretty orange panel and follow enjoyable jugs up and left past a few bolts.  As the wall kicks~ negotiate increasingly difficult sections past small roofs to a pump crux below the chains.
protection: Bolts and a two bolt anchor.  Use a 60 meter rope.

location: Easter Face > The Restaurant crags > Waterval Boven > South Africa > Africa > International
desc: Short~ fingery climb. Follow the diagonal rail over the face and up.

location: Chaos 2 > Todra Gorge > Morocco > Africa > International
desc: Last move at the end is terrible!

location: Jardin D'Hiver > Todra Gorge > Morocco > Africa > International
desc: L1 5.11d like his name~ the start is overhang ... L2 5.10c not very difficult with a lot of holes.
protection: Well bolted~ 12 quickdraws~ anchor at the top

location: Legoland > Montagu > South Africa > Africa > International
desc: Overhanging and bouldery

location: Kleinmond > South Africa > Africa > International
desc: A bouldery crux to a crimpy head wall

location: Gullich > Todra Gorge > Morocco > Africa > International
protection: Quite well bolted~ 13 quickdraws~ anchor at each belay station. The quality of the belay stations are unknown~ if you climb it please update below.

location: Petites Gorges n°1 Rive Gauche D > Todra Gorge > Morocco > Africa > International
desc: This is a placeholder. If you know this route~ please use the 'Improve This Page' link to make it better!
protection: 5 bolts~ chain anchor at the top

location: Nemesis Crag > Lukenya > Kenya > Africa > International
desc: One of the best single pitch routes I've ever bolted!  Work up the rising traverse as the difficulty slowly builds through sequency climbing to a small crux to reach the rest jug. The third bolt can be clipped before or after reaching the jug but it's easier to clip it after once you dial the sequence. From here~ take a breath before heading straight up through the steep bulge on perfect crimps past a V7 crux. Hang tight until it finally lets off at the last bolt. Enjoy 10 more feet of perfect jugs to the anchor.  Named in honor of Jakob Gelfand~ RIP.

location: Demeuk > Todra Gorge > Morocco > Africa > International
desc: The rock is very sharp and sticky~ old hardware!
protection: Not well bolted~ 5 quickdraws~ possibly missing the anchor.

location: Demeuk > Todra Gorge > Morocco > Africa > International
desc: Climbing on a very nice slab.
protection: Well bolted~ 11 quickdraws~ anchor at the top

location: Demeuk > Todra Gorge > Morocco > Africa > International
desc: No comment!
protection: Poorly bolted~ unclear if there is an anchor~ 7 quickdraws

location: Tacos gauche & Tacos droite > Todra Gorge > Morocco > Africa > International
desc: This is a placeholder. If you know this route~ please use the 'Improve This Page' link to make it better!

location: Waterworld > Bad Kloof > Montagu > South Africa > Africa > International
desc: A very cool~ power-endurance start on sharp holds leads to a painful knee bar~ one more difficult move and then easy terrain to the chains.

location: Baboon Buttress > The Wonderland crags > Waterval Boven > South Africa > Africa > International
desc: Shorter climb on really small holds.

location: Passe-Muraille > Hữu Lũng > Vietnam > Asia > International
desc: Golden shower?

location: Doudouk area > Garni Gorge > Armenia > Asia > International
desc: This route starts in the cave formed by the Inverted Basalt Columns and traverses up and to the right out of the cave.
protection: Small Cams and long slings to prevent excess rope drag.

location: Sarkit > Antalya Geyikbayiri > Turkey > Asia > International
desc: Pretty fun face climbing up a sort of tubular type feature.  Technical and thin.

location: Shuanglang Hardcore > Dali Area > Yunnan Province > China > Asia > International
desc: Climb the tufa up the steep arete to gain the beautifully featured and significantly easier face above.

location: Passe-Muraille > Hữu Lũng > Vietnam > Asia > International
desc: Psychedelic trance

location: Dum's Kitchen > Tonsai Bay > Laem Phra Nang (Railay & Tonsai) > South - Islands & Beaches > Thailand > Asia > International
desc: Climb intriguing tufas and pinches to a thin technical crux.

location: The Hangover > Thakhek > Laos > Asia > International
desc: Some hard moves in the beginning. Once you pass the life let it get easier.    from 'Rock Climbing Laos~ 5th Edition (2016)" by Tanja & Uli Weidner and Volker Schoffl.

location: Tonsai Roof (Tidal Wave Area) > Tonsai Beach (Freedom Bar Area) > Tonsai Bay > Laem Phra Nang (Railay & Tonsai) > South - Islands & Beaches > Thailand > Asia > International
desc: Follow the line of bolts up and right up the steep cave wall.  Mostly decent but polished holds on a steep wall!

location: Mammut Wall > The Lost World of Tambun > Ipoh > Malaysia > Asia > International
desc: Two pitches 5.10a and 5.12a    The first pitch follows a vertical system of blocks and corners up very solid rock to a two bolt anchor.   The second pitch continues up a steep white wall on thin holds. Make sure you can see the last anchor chains before you go! At times the upper area can be covered in thick foliage.
protection: Bolts.   Two bolt anchors with chains at each station

location: Gua Ularsawa > Bukit Lagi > Perlis > Malaysia > Asia > International
desc: PC is the acronym for the Perlis Climbers. Climb this route and make them proud.

location: Main Wall (Babes in Thailand Area) > Tonsai Beach (Freedom Bar Area) > Tonsai Bay > Laem Phra Nang (Railay & Tonsai) > South - Islands & Beaches > Thailand > Asia > International
desc: Great route~ starts with some pretty bouldery moves up to the 3rd bolt~ milk the rest and bust through another couple of bolts to meet the red point crux at the anchor~ so good.

location: Canyon Left > Canyon > Thakhek > Laos > Asia > International
desc: At the start you have to come from the opposite wall; small crimps and technical climbing in the beginning lead up a steeper wall with good pockets. For sure - one of the best!     from "Rock Climbing Laos~ 5th Edition" by Tanja & Uli Weidner and Volker Schoffl

location: Cathedral > Bukit Takun > Malaysia > Asia > International
desc: This route was re-bolted with glue-in anchors.

location: Open All Hours > Thakhek > Laos > Asia > International
desc: Hard face climbing~ especially at the short crux in the beginning.

location: Monkey Buttress > Hong Kong > China > Asia > International
desc: Thin technical moves on small pockets and crimps with generally good feet (although small at points). Excellent climbing! Really just two boulder problems separated by a juggy rest.

location: Trebenna West Middle > Antalya Geyikbayiri > Turkey > Asia > International
desc: Climb the easy column to the bulging roof. Catch your breath and traverse slightly right on good holds until you can pull the steep hang~ manuevering into an overhanging cleft.

location: The Ranch > The Ranch > Wadi Khab Al Shamis > Dibba Inland > Musandam > Oman > Asia > International
desc: 25m F7a+/7B The route was bolted last spring and has yet to get a clean ascent. If you do get the FA please let me know. Climb ON!

location: The Hang > Koh Yao Noi > South - Islands & Beaches > Thailand > Asia > International
desc: Short~ steep~ powerful on good stone

location: White Mountain > YangShuo > Guangxi Province > China > Asia > International
desc: Far less frequently climbed than other routes of the grade here~ this is still a fun~ technical face climb that isn't too sharp despite the fact that its on the black (typically sharper) limestone... ok~ it gets a bit sharp up high~ but still not too bad. The crux is sustained~ balance-y and technical -- and fun. The route eases up a bit afterwards~ though its no gimme until you clip the anchors.
protection: Bolts to the 2 bolt~ fixed anchors

location: Phasak River Wall > Namphapayai Camp Saraburi > Central - Around Bangkok > Thailand > Asia > International
desc: Crux comes at the top to the chains. Moderate climbing to begin the route.

location: Main Wall > Jesselton Park > Malaysia > Asia > International
desc: The route was named after a remarkable "Feel The Sun" concept which was shared by an ex-Penang climber who has migrated overseas.

location: Sarkit > Antalya Geyikbayiri > Turkey > Asia > International
desc: A well worth doing 5 or 6 bolt extension of the the route Ückagicti Ask. Really thin and technical face climbing starts just above the first anchor and finishes with a pumpy finish.  I found one clip tricky to make.

location: Fire Wall > Waterfall Hill (Yaedagon Taung) > Mandalay Area > Myanmar > Asia > International
desc: A hard and proud route. Climbs vertical 5.11~ to easy and somewhat loose slab~ to a proud~ hard~ exposed~ continuous 5.12 crux that is essentially three boulder problems in a row with marginal rests to clip the bolts. Get ready for geometric climbing and compression on slopers and pinches with a few jugs and crimps thrown in as well. Finishes with a very exposed panel to the anchors hanging at the highest point on the wall. The rock in the crux is some of the better rock on a rather loose wall.
protection: Bolts~ carabiner anchors. Unlike most of the routes at Firewall~ this route is not missing any bolt hangers because the first couple of bolts are glue-ins. I would recommend extending the first 5 draws and also the 7th: It's not absolutely necessary~ but it helps with clipping the last bolt and anchors.

location: Pond Wall > Butterfly Valley > Cat Ba Island > Vietnam > Asia > International
desc: Shares the first 4 bolts with Argentina's Delight and extends straight up the center of the face.

location: Crazy Horse Buttress > Crazy Horse *TEMPORARILY CLOSED* > Northwest - Around Chiang Mai > Thailand > Asia > International
desc: Takes the same first two pitches for Headhunters but switches out the 5.11d 3rd pitch for a 5.12c. Takes the overhanging line up the right side of the horse's head. Fingery crux~ exposed~ exhilarating and really quite good

location: Sarkit > Antalya Geyikbayiri > Turkey > Asia > International
desc: This route climbs the obvious grey tufa in the middle of a smooth grey face.  Very impressive and beautiful line. The climbing is super fun. I thought the crux was clipping the bolts. There are definitely some hard moves in between the bolts though~ and I found it pretty technical. The extension looks really nice as well~ but apparently dealing with the rope drag becomes cruxy.

location: Gulag Wall > Bukit Keteri > Perlis > Malaysia > Asia > International
desc: Though this route seems to be the namesake of the area... it’s separated from the rest of the routes.  Crazy looking overhung route to get out of a big ole cave and up into a chimney.  The approach seems to be overgrown~ but the route itself is fine.

route: Happy Climbing Day (Kuai Le Pan Pa Ri)
location: Cave Crag (Dong Qiang) > Fumin Canyon > Kunming Area > Yunnan Province > China > Asia > International
desc: Route 5 on BETA PHOTO. Traversing right out of cave~ 20 m.

location: Left Side > Ballikayalar (Honey Crag) > Turkey > Asia > International
desc: Climb carefully the first boulder problem to reach the first bolt~ falling could be dangerous before the first bolt as the ledge at the base is narrow and it is a long way down.    Pass the first roof using a high flake and an undercling to reach an obvious good pocket. Continue left to the dihedral. Climb to the second roof using small pockets and edges. Pass the second roof using a downward flake.
protection: bolts + some gear between the last bolt and anchors.

location: Cool Banana > Butterfly Valley > Cat Ba Island > Vietnam > Asia > International
desc: Climb diagonally left through a very overhung roof.

location: Bat Cave Wall > Namphapayai Camp Saraburi > Central - Around Bangkok > Thailand > Asia > International
desc: Hard crux down low and then pumpy climbing to the finish.

location: The Thaiwand > Railay West > Laem Phra Nang (Railay & Tonsai) > South - Islands & Beaches > Thailand > Asia > International
desc: Thin looking moves on likely bad bolts. Lightner calls this cliimb 'tweaky.' If anyone has anymore info~ I'd be more than happy to add it.
protection: Stainless steel bolts with white glue- not ideal...

location: Phasak River Wall > Namphapayai Camp Saraburi > Central - Around Bangkok > Thailand > Asia > International
desc: Sustain face climbing leads into a thin crux at midway point then a no hand rest before another sustain pumpy run to the anchors.

location: Eye Cave (Yan Jing Dong) > Fumin Canyon > Kunming Area > Yunnan Province > China > Asia > International
desc: Route 8 on BETA PHOTO. 9 bolts~ 15 m.

location: Olympic Crag > Al Shafa > Saudi Arabia > Asia > International
desc: Technical face climbing. Incredible rock!   7 Bolts.

location: Trebenna West Middle > Antalya Geyikbayiri > Turkey > Asia > International
desc: Great long climb with good rests between some hard moves. Climb up to the 5th bolt on pretty easy climbing~ then pull the bulge by the arch to the right. Climb up a little higher to another rest by the start of the tufa section. Make the clip and a tricky move to get established on the tufa and enjoy awesome climbing up the tufa and pocketed face to a great rest out right of the final bolt. When you are fresh~ bust out the final boulder problem (crux) straight up with some bad feet and slippery holds to a sinker pocket and it's over. Don't try and go way up and right to bypass the crux.

location: Diamond Wall > Shigu > Lijiang Area > Yunnan Province > China > Asia > International
desc: Head right up the thin crimp fest. Awesome style of technical climbing. Strength will not help you here~ must be good on your technical abilities. Best to skip the last bolt if you're sending

location: Doucilin > Guanziling > Taiwan > Asia > International
desc: A very powerful route that tests your pinch power down low. Start on pinches and move up to a sharper finish on crimps and pockets.

location: Jin Gang Shan (aka KumGang Mountain) > Mashan > Guangxi Province > China > Asia > International
desc: The third pitch of this route is without a doubt one of the highest quality pitches I have ever bolted. Absolutely perfect stone in an exceptional setting. Do this route.   Pitch one is the clean 10d slab just left of the start to Golden Road 12c. Just before the anchor break left to a 2 bolt anchor with a nice stance. The second pitch starts with a short dirty tufa and then into a right facing crack to the first crux of the route around the 4th bolt. A towering pitch with a mix of climbing styles ~12d. The third pitch (~12d) is pure magic~ gradually getting harder as you get toward the chains. A very memorable route overall!   It is possible to wrap with an 80 meter~ but be mindful as you rappel because of how overhanging the second pitch is!

location: Nezer > Israel > Asia > International
desc: The classic Route of Neze   A beautiful line that starts on a big pile of rocks   Starts with the bolder problem and at the very top I dedicate face climbing
protection: You can usually find quickdraws in the routes   But if not you will need 6 Not including the anchor

route: A Wild Ride on a Crazy Horse
location: Crazy Horse Buttress > Crazy Horse *TEMPORARILY CLOSED* > Northwest - Around Chiang Mai > Thailand > Asia > International
desc: The hardest climb at Crazy Horse. Take the line immediately to the left of the ladder access rungs to the archway. The first 4 bolts go at around 5.11 climbing. From the 4th bolt the route is equipped with insitu quick-draws. The climbing gets increasingly hard and insecure with each bolt. Before maxing out with the 5.13c crux mantle as the last move before the anchors. A series of insecure slopers~ tiny side pulls and downright tenuous moves comprise the bulk of the hard climbing. Has only seen a handful of ascents.

location: Wall of Shadows > Tanomah > Saudi Arabia > Asia > International
desc: Raging Bull. Bouldering on a rope and magnificient slab.

location: Dum's Kitchen > Tonsai Bay > Laem Phra Nang (Railay & Tonsai) > South - Islands & Beaches > Thailand > Asia > International
desc: Shared start with Wake and bake. The line traverses left through crimps and slopers to a kneebar rest. Throw a dyno to a left hand pocket and climb up past the tufa to pockets on the right.

location: Namhansanseon Beomgul rock > South Korea > Asia > International
desc: Farthest route up the cave/hill on the overhanging face on the right.   Climb really overhanging crimps~ to really overhanging~ really bad crimps~ and try to clip somehow. Looks about v-4~ to bad rest~ to v-7 or so.
protection: 5 bolts. Scary death-triangle steel cable anchor.

location: Roof Right Side > Thakhek > Laos > Asia > International
desc: Big Smile is the hardest climb on the cliff to date. Lots of kneebars and heelhooks are required to manage the pump that will make most climbers arms explode. An easier steep start on big holds leads to the first crux: a funky undercling to reach a big hold in a hole (worst move of the climb). From here more steep fun climbing with good rests leads to a steep lip. Pull the lip and take a good long rest before the upper crux: a big reach to a small pinch and a small pocket. After sticking the crux move~ skip the clip and make one more hard lunge to a victory jug! If you fall off the last move (which I did numerous times) you have the pleasure of being lowered through a big ants nest in the tree below! Clip the anchors and then go grab a beer lao from uli and lounge in the sun all day.
protection: All bolts are equipped with permanent draws.

location: The Alamo > Bayin Nyi > Hpa-An Area > Myanmar > Asia > International
desc: Get ready for a pure power climb. Two hard boulder problems separated by a standing rest. Climb up the pile of stones/ladder (or if not available stick clip the first bolt and pull up) start on the crimps next to the first bolt~ climb through a hard boulder problem to the second bolt~ bust through the overhang on fun~ dynamic climbing~ mantel over the lip~ and then climb through another very difficult boulder problem (crux) involving small pockets (one of which is very sharp) to reach the anchor. Note: When this route was being established there were a series of flake jugs within reach from the ground~ during the bolting and cleaning process these jugs were flexing and eventually were cleaned from the wall~ leaving almost no holds at the very bottom of the climb~ thus the alternate methods to get to the first holds. I'm not sure~ but it might still be possible to climb it from the ground. At the time it was sent (01/26/19) it is the hardest in Bayin Nyi and Myanmar.
protection: 6 bolts and 2 anchors with rings. All bolts are stainless steel glue-in wave bolts~ installed 8/14/16.

location: Dragon Cave > Butterfly Valley > Cat Ba Island > Vietnam > Asia > International
desc: Shared start with Little Dragon~ move out right after the cave and onto the dragon's tufa teeth and up its face. Tie a knot in the end of your rope and take care with the big stalagmite underneath you at the mouth of the cave! Professional belay and good communication recommended.    Base floods during rainy season.
protection: 35m~ 14 bolts. Tie a knot in the end of your rope and take care with the big stalagmite underneath you at the mouth of the cave! Fluid belay and good communication recommended.

location: Future Rock Moraksan > South Korea > Asia > International
desc: Super overhanging arete with bad holds. Looks really hard and fun.
protection: 5 bolts~ really rusted~ scary chain anchors.

location: Jin Gang Shan (aka KumGang Mountain) > Mashan > Guangxi Province > China > Asia > International
desc: Tiny holds crux that will be largely determined by your finger size. Several options for beta through here until the holds get tiny and then there is only one method.. Great pitch!

location: Jebel Nassarani > Wadi Rum > Jordan > Asia > International
desc: 11 pitches of very quality sand stone~ while the 5ht pitch is the same of 'Jihad'. took us 4 years in total to bolt the route (all gluing bolts)~ including sending the line in the winter of 2017. in total we spent almost one month on the wall and i would say that the climbing goes all the way~ the wall is very steep with many hard parts. highly recommended~ my best line for sure!
protection: all bolted with gluing bolts~ only rope and quick draws needed

location: 1. Fairfield West > Fairfield Hill > Sinks Canyon > Lander Area > Wyoming
desc: technical grey streak with lip encounter low

location: 3. Mytho Wall > The Shipyard > Piney Creek Canyon > Eastern Big Horns > Wyoming
desc: Little Nemo (named after the orange fish) climbs up the pocket band on a beautiful hunk of rock. Expect a cruxy start to long pulls on good holds. After pulling through a small overhang~ hold on until the kick in the tail finish.

location: 4. Lone Pilgrim > 1. Left Side (Lunarscape, Tribal War, Poker-Face, Lone Pilgrim) > OK Corral > Wild Iris > Lander Area > Wyoming
desc: Lone Pilgrim climbs directly up the center of the clean slab on the Lone Pilgrim Wall.  Start from the obvious ledge and put your slab climbing hat on.  A few thin but reasonable slab moves with sharp pocket features get you to the first bolt.    Just before bolt 2~ it's 'game on' as you will encounter a challenging and committing crux with almost nonexistent shallow pocket features transitioning from right to left.  After the crux~ easier but still sustained and consistent movement through pockets and a bulge gain the anchors.  Steve Bechtel's 2011 guidebook gives this 11d~ I say the crux is easily 12a when compared to other 11's and 12's in the area.

location: Baldwin Creek > Lander Area > Wyoming
desc: Left side of wall.  Shares start with a 13a to its left and climbs up steep rock on good pockets.  Long move/dead point crux.

location: 1. Blooming Rose > 2. Central (Blooming Rose, Claim Jumper, Saddle Tramp) > OK Corral > Wild Iris > Lander Area > Wyoming
desc: This is the 2nd pitch of Medicine Show which starts with a short 5.7 pitch that leads to easy low angle terrain. The 1st pitch ends at a 2-bolt anchor underneath the overhang above.  Pull hard moves off the deck on pockets. The route is over after about 6 moves but they are tough ones!

location: Rusty Cage > Mondo Beyondo > Ten Sleep Canyon > Wyoming
desc: Good cranks on pockets and edges make for a fun ride.  You might end up dynoing a couple moves~ I found long cranks between decent pockets near the bottom with a cruxy move off a high undercling near mid height.  The moves eased off even as the holds shrink on the slab near \the anchors.

location: The Power Station Wall > Lower Canyon Granite > Cody > Wyoming
desc: Begin from grassy ledge and follow the broken crack system up and left for three clips.  Break off to the right and go straight up.  The gold colored rock begins the difficult section.  Awesome movement goes to the top of the formation.

location: Hardware Wall > Sinks Canyon > Lander Area > Wyoming
desc: A quiet classic.  First 3 bolt get dirty every spring run off don’t be scared take 5 minuted to stick clip up and brush that shit we’ll thank you all winter.  Thin start leads to a low crux involving either side pulles or gastons.  Leaving bolt 4 is nothing but overhanging 5.11 glory~ possibly the best in in canyon and it goes on for somthing like 7-9 clips.  Expect a spot of choss after the last bolt... can be avoided if you cowboy up and own that mono in the better stone it is a 5.12 after all.

location: Upper Blacktail Butte > Blacktail Butte > Grand Teton National Park > Wyoming
desc: Starts easy and ends easy. The crux is between bolt 2 and 3 ( don't go direct)

location: Upper Psychoactive Wall > Leigh Creek > Old Road Crags > Ten Sleep Canyon > Wyoming
desc: Choose your 5.10 entry method to attain the crack system. Pick your way through the first steeper roof to find a great jug undercling just below the small roof. Figure out and execute what could be the hardest '.12a' move in the canyon. Scamper up easy but off balance moves to the anchor.  Fun climbing but quite difficult to onsight.  Anchor should be moved 6 feet to the left to avoid rope drag. Anyone?

location: East and Northeast Buttress Approach > Devils Tower > Wyoming
desc: Can't remember much except that it was desperate.  Dennis Horning had bolted this line but failed to climb it and offered me the FA.  7/4/99 I did it after Dean Brault had fallen off.

location: Hobgoblin Boulders > Telephone Road > Vedauwoo > Wyoming
desc: This is the obvious hands to offwidth roof formed between two closely matched boulders.  It leans at a bit of an angle~ and the inside of the crack is polished smooth by the wind.  A great place to learn some tricks for offwidth roofs.  Pulling the lip is not too bad.
protection: A pad and a spotter are nice.  The landing is nice and flat~ but it would hurt to take a backslapper out of it.

location: The Ark > Mecca > Ten Sleep Canyon > Wyoming
desc: This is the farthest most right route on the Ark proper identified by the three fixed draws high up on the route.  Start up the right facing crack~ hand traverse out brown rust colored pockets then angle right toward the fixed draws.
protection: 6 or 7 draws to 3 more fixed nylon draws (questionable?) to a bolted rap anchor.  A long runner was useful to protect before the traverse

route: The Plume: Broken Arrow, NE Face
location: Warbonnet Peak > Cirque of the Towers > Wind River Range > Wyoming
desc: The East Face of the Plume above Jackass Pass. The steep monolith's only weakness is an overhanging corner on it's left side. This is the crux pitch. A big 40 meter pitch~ even with two no hands stances and 14 pieces of fixed protection. The corner is north facing. See topo.
protection: 2 sets of the smallest cams~ and 2 sets of finger size cams and 1 thin hand size cam~ 6-8 cams total~ 20 quick draws or equivalent.

location: Heavy Metal Rock Band > Shady Side > Sinks Canyon > Lander Area > Wyoming
desc: Random route up a gulley and off a ledge.  Stick clip 1st bolt.  Jugs initially to a very awkward and technical transfer crux to face holds.  Good rock.  Brief crux~ but~ hard!

location: Swift Creek Spire > Swift Creek Canyon > Jackson Hole > Wyoming
desc: The route climbs roughly the middle of the north face. Its a difficult flash at .12a

location: Rise Wall > The Sandstone > Sinks Canyon > Lander Area > Wyoming
desc: An Indian Creek Utah crack simulator. Thin crack in left facing~ stepped roofed corner~ crux tips above the last little lip. Rattly fingers to start.
protection: Small - Med Cams~ that’s tight hands~ rattly fingers~ fingers and tips.  no anchor on top except for junipers and blocks.

route: Where I lay my boots to rest "aka darkside"
location: North Side > Squaretop Boulder > Sinks Canyon > Lander Area > Wyoming
desc: Clean stone and cool movement on shallow pockets. First three bolts crux. Techy. Used to be a toprope.

location: (c) East Sector > Rock Springs Buttress > Jackson Hole > Wyoming
desc: P1: (5.9) weave your way up the face past a few fixed pins to the huge roof. Belay under roof on gear. P2: Work up under and then out the middle of the roof (11+/12- ). Easier if you’re taller. Save a few micro cams for the roof. Belay at 2 bolt anchor just over roof. P3: Climb the beautiful finger crack until it ends. An airy traverse left leads to the first bolt over a bulge. Continue up bolts (12a) and gear to the top. Gear anchor. Descent: Rappel Birthday Suit (70m or 2 ropes)~ or walk off.

location: The Sanctuary > The Granite > Sinks Canyon > Lander Area > Wyoming
desc: Set back in the alcove~ this is an obvious bolted arete going up black and white streaked rock.  Continuous thoughtful movement.  The crux is at about two thirds height~ but this one is pretty sustained technical climbing throughout.

location: Killer Cave > Sinks Canyon > Lander Area > Wyoming
desc: Some of the best pockets in Western Wyoming can be found in the large left-facing dihedral at the right end of the Killer Cave~ and Ring of Fire is no exception.  Climbing a beautifual swath of tufa-stone~ sinker pockets seem to appear at just the right intervals~ but be prepared to crank quite far between them.  Despite its length~ this line is not very sustained~ with the business involving a brief & powerful series of pulls over the obvious roof at 3/4" height.      Begin as for Bush Doctor~ etc~ with a stem off the boulder to reach the obvious crack system.  Grunt your way up the crack to the point where Bush Doctor & Bloodline undercling right.  Stay left for one more clip from the crack before launching onto the steep bulge.  Head straight up towards the obvious roof and a distinct crux involving excellent pockets.  Fight the pump through more great pockets for another two bolts to the anchor.    The pockets on this route are a little raspy compared to routes on the left side of the cave.
protection: ~12 Bolts or so~ but the first ~6 are fixed chain/cable draws.  Bring ~7 draws for the upper half.  2 Bolt anchor.

location: The Erratic > Wild Iris > Lander Area > Wyoming
desc: This route is amazing !  Roof is challenging

location: D. Hot Tamale Wall > The Main Wall > Wild Iris > Lander Area > Wyoming
desc: Full value classic.  Technical~ steep~ pumpy and powerful.  Climbs the technical to start through pumpy middle.  Crux comes higher on beautiful movement on decent pockets.

location: Camel Jockey > Sinks Canyon > Lander Area > Wyoming
desc: A great arete that gets evening shade. A series of hard~ bouldery moves establishes you into a right trending flake. Make some compression moves to a "rest"~ then crank small pockets and crimps to the top. Lots of movement on this one~ don't expect to be able to make long pulls to the top. Riki ticky tacky~ but rad.  Full value for the grade!
protection: Bomber Fixe glue-ins. Thanks BARF! Give them your money!

location: White Heat Wall > Sinks Canyon > Lander Area > Wyoming
desc: This is an excellent rock climb. The movement is really fun~ and the pockets are all pretty good. Start out with a mono on the ramp and make a big move out left~ get your feet up and make some moves off some smaller pockets to come to a good hold at the third bolt. Continue up with big moves to more pockets to reach the final bolt. Move left and up good holds to the chains.   *More beta**   I found a stick clip helpful as I thought the crux was right off the ground~ and it is easy to hang draws when you lower off central pillar. Searching for Blanton's does experience some run off during the wetter months~ so it may need a brushing if it has not been climbed in a while. Maybe height dependent?    Do it.

location: Metropolis > Mondo Beyondo > Ten Sleep Canyon > Wyoming
desc: This route is very continuous without every being easy or too hard.  There are some taxing moves and good pockets to clip from however this is no ladder of pockets and edges and the steepness sneaks up on you like its neighbor to the left.
protection: 8 clips of Getting Rich and one for its anchor.  Clip 6 bolts going up the headwall to a sport anchor

location: Roof Ranch > Vedauwoo > Wyoming
desc: This is the left line of the two bolted sport lines. It has very technical climbing most of the way up~ with a few exciting moves a ways over bolts.
