desc: Boulder up past two bolts using sidepulls and high feet to a great rest.  Get back what you can before launching into the crux.  Good footwork and body positioning will get you through the delicate crux and a insecure clip.  Get creative to find a path around the small bulge and keep it together till the chains!  Great route with moves different from you typical tunnel climbs.  Get on it!
protection: 7 bolts.  No quick links at the top so bring more draws or cleaning gear.

location: Heavenly Buttress > Eden Canyon > Diablo Canyon > Santa Fe Area > New Mexico
desc: A burly line.  Super interesting.

location: Filet de Papillon Wall (aka Dirt Wall) > Northern Box areas > The Box Climbing Areas > Socorro Area > New Mexico
desc: With excellent rock and challenging movement this new variation is one of the better~ lines on the wall.  It's only detractions are sharp rock~ and being slightly squeezed between the other lines on the wall.      Start up the first half of Dreadlock Holiday pulling one hard move at the second bolt.  Catch a no-hands rest at the mid anchors~ clip the first shared bolt and head straight up the upper headwall.  The climbing is entertaining with no hard moves.  The crux is enduring the pump~ a hard last clip~ and one final hard move getting established on the easy slab above the last bolt.    I'm not sure of the exact name of this~ or if it even has a independant name.  Also the grade is my best guess~ so climb it and post up your thoughts.

location: Bush Shark Area > Echo Canyon > Sandia Mountains > Albuquerque Area > New Mexico
desc: This is the route that goes directly out the series of large red overhangs on the Bush Shark Spire. Start 3m right of BSS route. It was first aided on lead by MB at C3-ish. The bolts are in now and LB sent it at 5.13. The crux is about 15 moves of bouldery and sometimes dynamic climbing through the roofs.    Amble up the somewhat loose and interesting face and corner system (5.10 gear and a couple of bolts) to the base of the roofs. Compose yourself. Start with a series of long moves to get out and established in the roof zone. Then start working the stepped corner and arete out right through the remainder of the roof. Finish with a few long moves on slots straight up to the stellar belay below the second pitch of Hammerhead.     For a truly burly outing continue up the second pitch of Hammerhead and finish off with Blood In The Water.
protection: small trad rack with 1-2 small TCUs~ a couple med wires~ and a couple med cams to gain the bolts. Another route takes the crack up Great White and exits right to gain the finish of Hammerhead.

location: Solstice Cave > Last Chance Canyon > New Mexico, other Southern Areas > New Mexico
desc: AMAZING route! Definitely the best one in the cave. Spectacular movement with no major rests.    Move up the left hand archway of the cave. Easy terrain (5.9ish) leads to a high first bolt - don't fall. Move up to a flat ledge~ and get psyched! Some people use a scummy kneebar on a small tooth under the roof to span the gap to small edges. Considering my noob kneebar capabilities~ I opted to deadpoint instead. Power up the overhanging wall~ then make the coolest move at Last Chance - mandatory rose move on pockets! I believe this is the area that can sometimes seep in warmer weather. More difficult crimping gets you through the next few bolts. The rest of the route is characterized by huge lunges between big holds. Perfect bolt spacing ensures minimal time trying to clip~ and awesome air time if you fall!    Endure through the final mantle~ touch the chains~ and take a victory whipper. Lowering off the chains causes some serious rope shredding.
protection: 6-7 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor - all fixed draws. You may not be able to stick clip the first depending on how well endowed your stick is.

location: Solstice Cave > Last Chance Canyon > New Mexico, other Southern Areas > New Mexico
desc: If you've climbed Buff and are looking for a step up this is the climb for you.  The jugs are fewer and further apart~ and there is an awesome crux section on sequential pockets prior to some more long pulls on jugs and then joining the final rail of Buff.        Some tricky rests~ of the kneebar varietal~ can be found~ but they are much less obvious than the two nearly no hands rests on Buff.      This is another Solstice Cave classic.

location: Cacti Cliff > Capulin Canyon and Cochiti Mesa Area Crags > Jemez Mountains and Jemez Valley > New Mexico
desc: The hardest route at Cacti~ Izimbra is long~ sustained and pumpy.  Not especially tweaky~ this route will test your stamina on thin 2-finger pockets.  There is one hold (Left Hand) that could be used as a mono~ though its possible to cram 2 fingers in.    The route begins in a leaning dihedral~ which soon kicks you out onto an overhanging wall.  Powerful~ shouldery~ un-Cochiti-like moves on large slopers lead to a decent rest just before the crux section.  A traverse left on good~ sharp crimps leads to the crux:  several long moves on thin 2-finger pockets~ a mono~ and one non-existent edge.  Good footwork and creativity will get you to the right edge of a large pod and a dubious shake before the final technical headwall. At the last bolt the angle kicks back to a slab~ and the holds decrease in size and depth to compensate.  One or two more tricky~ heady moves lead to the lip.
protection: 8 bolts; use the 2-bolt anchor for Crank Addiction.  There's no fixed lowering equipment on the anchor~ so you will need to scramble to the cliff top to clean your gear.  The anchor is slightly to the right of the top out~ near the end of Crank Addiction.

location: Shady Side Left > Shady Side > The Tunnel > New Mexico, other Southern Areas > New Mexico
desc: Direct start and finish to George. Starts just to the Right of George. Climb up past three bolts~ traverse left into the crux section of George~ clip the crux bolt on George. Make a few moves to the right~ skip the next bolt on George~ and instead of standing up on the ledge above the roof bust out left and make committing moves to a a giant slopper. Shares the last bolt of George and the anchors on George.
protection: First bolt is high~ meant to be stick clipped.

location: Jemez Cave (a.k.a. Crystal Cave) - CLOSED > Jemez Mountains and Jemez Valley > New Mexico
desc: Work up the right side of the cave with long pulls on jugs~ there is a slopy crack feature near where the route goes horizontal. Venture out and left across the roof on pods with holds in them or pinches. When the good holds end the first crux hits moving around a weird block with bad feet finishing with a throw to jugs in an alcove above the feature. Cop a painful knee bar rest. Once ready~ move left into the tough pocket section of Dope and up through the jugs. Finish here for "??" 5.13-~ or continue out left through the V6 boulder problem to the top.
protection: Bolts with fixed chain draws. I believe they have brown tape on them until they join Dope at which point the Dope draws are green.

location: Main Wall > The Dungeon > Los Alamos & White Rock > New Mexico
desc: Maybe the best line on the wall~ marred only by the fact that the crux is particularly desperate.  Starts right of Gangland and works up and right to a few crimpy and technical moves right to deposit you underneath the crux.  At least 2 solutions to the crux exist.  One very powerful~ one very crimpy and still powerful.  Climb to the top of the wall from here~ work out right using the seam in the upper roof to clip anchors just above the "triangle".

location: Solar Cave > Diablo Canyon > Santa Fe Area > New Mexico
desc: Left of the middle of solar cave~ this route climbs through steep roof resembling the shape of a Mastodon's chest.  Hard sustained sequences.

location: Shady Side Left > Shady Side > The Tunnel > New Mexico, other Southern Areas > New Mexico
desc: This challenging line offers several distinct difficult sections of climbing.  The route begins with powerful 12- moves out the steep overhang~ ending in a no-hands stem-rest below the final bulge.  From here~ a seemingly reach-dependant V6 or V7 crux dyno from an undercling at the 4th bolt leads to a technical~ pumpy 12- headwall finish.

location: Major Wall > Southern Box areas > The Box Climbing Areas > Socorro Area > New Mexico
desc: hard moves on crimps right of the deck to a crux revolving around a bad sidepull\undercling

location: Short Stack > The Lost Crag > Southwestern Highlands > Pennsylvania
desc: rap rings for descent

location: Short Stack > The Lost Crag > Southwestern Highlands > Pennsylvania
desc: Check out the teaching station to practice setting a belay from fixed anchors and also for cleaning anchors.

location: Shark's Tooth Wall > Main Wall > Donation Rocks > Central PA > Pennsylvania
desc: Easy 4th/5th class gully. No real point in doing it on TR~ but it's a fun place to practice short-roping~ or could be a super low-key 1st trad lead. Also fills in nicely with snow and ice in winter~ could be a fun~ easy mixed climb?
protection: Eats any pro~ large or small

location: 10 - Pillar 2 > White Rocks > Pond Bank > South Central PA > Pennsylvania
desc: Start at the top left of the sandy gully at a root system of a large pine tree high overhead.  Climb up and over the roots into a chimney~ up through the chimney stepping out onto the top of the right (south) side of Pillar #2.    This is a popular descent route for all three (3) of the pillars.  It is easily accessible and offers security for the novice descender as well as a quick path down for the more skilled.    Caution:   There is some really loose looking stuff on this route.  A simple word of caution~ so be careful.
protection: None required.  This is popular decent route.

location: c. Neophyte's Wall > Birdsboro Quarry > Southeastern Lowlands > Pennsylvania
desc: A ledgy climb up good incut holds.  Some holds are still loose and the climb is a bit dirty.

location: Brown Rocks > Brown Rocks > Pond Bank > South Central PA > Pennsylvania
desc: Climb up the gap in the rock.

location: Pole Steeple > South Central PA > Pennsylvania
desc: This is a standard chimney climb.  It has the usual dirt.  Just because the gear fits doesn't mean its good.  Check the quality of the rock.
protection: Standard rack.  Use a tree at the top & some long webbing or a static line.

location: 10 - Pillar 2 > White Rocks > Pond Bank > South Central PA > Pennsylvania
desc: Start up the left side of Pillar #2 halfway up the sandy gully at a large ledge that goes out toward the southwest outside corner of Pillar #2 and is the top of the arête on The Alley.  Climb the chimney up to a large ledge and the top of the right side of Pillar #2.

location: 6 - Hard Scramble Corner > White Rocks > Pond Bank > South Central PA > Pennsylvania
desc: Climb the obvious chimney behind the pinnacle.  Located on the north side of Hard Scramble Corner.

location: c. Neophyte's Wall > Birdsboro Quarry > Southeastern Lowlands > Pennsylvania
desc: Easy climbing the whole way~ good beginner route.

location: Balcony Rock > 1.5 Chimney of Horror Section > Safe Harbor North > Safe Harbor > South Central PA > Pennsylvania
desc: Climb a bulge right off the ground with a bolt and quartz pebbles. Continue up wind carved pockets and cracks to anchors.

location: Main Wall > Mocanaqua (aka Shickshinny) > Northeast Ridges and Valleys > Pennsylvania
desc: Great juggy climb on the center of Main Wall. Doesn't protect very well~ but can be set up as a top rope from the top access trail. Has some really fun moves.
protection: Some nuts and cams if you can find a place for them~ bolted anchors at the top.

location: Short Stack > The Lost Crag > Southwestern Highlands > Pennsylvania
desc: Follows the wandering line of 3 bolts up the back side of The Short Stack. This climb was bolted on lead by Norm Reed to gain access to the top of the block. Popular route at the Lost Crag.
protection: 3 bolts.  Note that the anchors for this climb are over the top of the block.  If you want to set a top rope for your second~ you will have to bring two 24" slings to extend over the edge.   There is a rap station to get off of this block that is just around the right side of the arete.  You can see them from the ground if you walk around the corner of the block.

location: Brown Rocks > Brown Rocks > Pond Bank > South Central PA > Pennsylvania
desc: Start on a small outward leaning ledge just left of dead 	tree in chimney.

location: c. Neolithic Wall > Ralph Stover State Park (High Rocks) > Southeastern Lowlands > Pennsylvania
desc: P1 - Climb the crack to a small overhang with an old pin.  Step up through the notch in the ceiling to the large ledge (Neolithic Ledge).  Belay at the bolted anchor.      P2 - Climb a left-facing corner to another ledge~ then climb another corner to a crack and overhang.  Step righ to bypass the overhang at the "H-shaped" cracks.  This pitch is dirty and almost never done.    Starting in the easier crack 8 feet further right on P1 makes the climb 5.5.

location: 2.5 Alpine Wall (aka tall wall) > Safe Harbor North > Safe Harbor > South Central PA > Pennsylvania
desc: On right (south) side of alpine wall starting from the ground on black rock   are 2 parallel routes. Of the 2 routes this route is on the climbers right.   (You walk under the rock fall fence and up a small slope to start)  Start at crack below 1st high bolt. Tending left and stemming corner on good holds gets you to the first bolt.   Move up to large slanting ledge with great feet to clip second bolt that is just out of view over head.   Continue moving over ledges and bulges.   Finish at bolted anchor.

location: Tunnel Block > The Lost Crag > Southwestern Highlands > Pennsylvania
desc: Start just right of the large ledge. Climb up and traverse left on the ledge. Clip the first bolt and climb up on large holds past the second bolt. Move left at the large ledge and step up to a pocket out left. Clip the third bolt and top out.  This climb is a sandbag at 5.6~ be prepared for a 5.7+.

location: Tomahawk Boulder > Indian Rocks > The Northwest > Pennsylvania
desc: Fun and casual way to get on top of the boulder to set up top ropes for other routes.  Good route on its own

location: b. Orange Sunshine Wall > Birdsboro Quarry > Southeastern Lowlands > Pennsylvania
desc: Climb easily up the left slab past 4 bolts to anchors with rings.

location: c. Neophyte's Wall > Birdsboro Quarry > Southeastern Lowlands > Pennsylvania
desc: None for now

location: 7 - Zorro Was Here Area > White Rocks > Pond Bank > South Central PA > Pennsylvania
desc: Start on the north west corner and climb the left hand diagonal flaring crack to the top.

location: f. Cramped Face > Ralph Stover State Park (High Rocks) > Southeastern Lowlands > Pennsylvania
desc: Follow Cramped Thumb to the first overhang and notch just below the original belay.  Veer up and right to a notch in the next overhang (right of the notch for Director Overhang) with numerous pitons.  Clear the overhang at the notch and climb the steep exposed face festooned with pitons.

location: 2.5 Alpine Wall (aka tall wall) > Safe Harbor North > Safe Harbor > South Central PA > Pennsylvania
desc: climb up large pinnacle type boulder~ normally has bird crap on it. Gain large slanting crack that goes up and right to Power and the Glory anchors.

location: Trailside > 1.5 Chimney of Horror Section > Safe Harbor North > Safe Harbor > South Central PA > Pennsylvania
desc: Start on Chossy rock for a move or two until you reach the better rock with finger crack. Follow crack up and slightly right to a small tree then move left to crack-a-lackin anchors.

location: 5.1 Dam Wall > Safe Harbor North > Safe Harbor > South Central PA > Pennsylvania
desc: Start directly under high 1st bolt. Balance up onto "nose" at chest height. Walk up slab and clip the 1st bolt using a 60 cm sling. Heel hook/mantle over the lip and climb up and right on easy terrain. Pull small roof and then again up and right to a third roof.  Skirt this roof on right side or don't and then climb up and slightly right to anchor 10' right of "Dam the Torpedoes"' anchors.

location: Mungo Jelly Block > The Knobs (Rob's Knob) > Southwestern Highlands > Pennsylvania
desc: Climb up passing a few shallow horizontals to reach the flake system.  Follow the flake system to its end.  Gain the short flaring vertical crack and top it out (crux).
protection: Mostly small cams or tri-cams.  An OK placement of a #2 Camalot can be placed in the upper flaring crack.  There is a set of old bolts on the top.  Its best to walk right and lower from the new shuts above Terror of Tiny Tom.

location: f. Cramped Face > Ralph Stover State Park (High Rocks) > Southeastern Lowlands > Pennsylvania
desc: Follow Cramped Thumb to the narrow ledge with pitons (original belay for Cramped Thumb).  Climb straight up from there to the overhang and clear it at an obvious notch.

location: j. Train in Vain Sector > Safe Harbor South > Safe Harbor > South Central PA > Pennsylvania
desc: Thin face climbing past 3 bolts to gain a dirty ledge then easier climbing past 2 bolts to the anchors.

location: k. The Wall of Immortals > Birdsboro Quarry > Southeastern Lowlands > Pennsylvania
desc: This climb is a sloping low angle left facing diehdral. The start shares the first two bolts with Son of a Blankety Blank. And the finish shares the last bolt and top anchors with Totally Unacceptable. But can also be finished to the right on Son of a Blankety Blank's finish. I enjoyed this climb very much.

location: Entrance Block > The Lost Crag > Southwestern Highlands > Pennsylvania
desc: Sport Route

location: Fun Block > The Knobs (Rob's Knob) > Southwestern Highlands > Pennsylvania
desc: Boulder start between cracks~ straight to top

location: 13 - Glen's Roof Wall > White Rocks > Pond Bank > South Central PA > Pennsylvania
desc: Start in the middle of the crag~ climb the awkward crack straight up to the roof~ stem up into and pull the roof (hint: right hand into the roof crack~ a bomber is in there~ trust me) and continue to the top.

location: 11 - Jim's Wall > White Rocks > Pond Bank > South Central PA > Pennsylvania
desc: Start at the left facing but right slanting flake 6 feet left of a pine tree.

location: xMann's Run > 1.5 Chimney of Horror Section > Safe Harbor North > Safe Harbor > South Central PA > Pennsylvania
desc: Start in front of Pole just right of exceedingly rotten rock. Make tricky move off the ground and clip the first bolt. Gain the very narrow slabby ledge. Following the slab ignoring  the wall on the left (questionable holds) and the cable. Move right on thin feet clip and then up passing more bolts. Gain a short fist crack and last bolt. Move up and left to anchor on thin feet.

location: The Edge > Southeastern Lowlands > Pennsylvania
desc: Similar climbing to the pumper along the left side of the face

location: Bulge Block > The Lost Crag > Southwestern Highlands > Pennsylvania
desc: Start just left of a rotting stump. Climb up the short technical face to a ledge and the first bolt. Make a move off the ledge passing the second bolt. Move right to the thin face holds and the third bolt~ continue up to the shuts.  Like its two neighbors to the left~ this route will most likely need brushed some more.

location: Main Block, Back Side > The Library > Mocanaqua (aka Shickshinny) > Northeast Ridges and Valleys > Pennsylvania
desc: Climb over a bulge just right of the previous route and follow the left side of the face to an easy top out.

location: Main Wall > Boxcar Rocks (Chinese Wall) > South Central PA > Pennsylvania
desc: Climb up the Margies Curves crack but instead of following the crack left or right~ go straight up onto the face and to the top.
protection: Top roped usually. Two bolts as top anchors.

location: Entrance Block > The Lost Crag > Southwestern Highlands > Pennsylvania
desc: Fun sport route that shares anchors with "Make Over."

route: High Hanging Fruit (A.K.A. Legends of the Green)
location: Furthest Right Wall > Breakneck > Southwestern Highlands > Pennsylvania
desc: There is a very sequential 5.9 section on the bottom of this route that is protected by two bolts.  The hand crack on the top is not more than 5.6.  The bolts on the face below will allow a new trad leader to feel safe as they work on their gear game.
protection: Two bolts and then one or two cams in the crack.

location: 3.0 Euro Wall > Safe Harbor North > Safe Harbor > South Central PA > Pennsylvania
desc: A fun route. The rock quality is not as bad as it looks.    Follow discontinuous and sustained lie back flakes with some clutch jams to ease the forearms. Seems longer than it is and way pumpy.

location: g. Lebowski Wall > Birdsboro Quarry > Southeastern Lowlands > Pennsylvania
desc: The climb just to the right to the Dude Abides. Just climb the approach route belay at the top off the bolts.

location: Paradise > Mocanaqua (aka Shickshinny) > Northeast Ridges and Valleys > Pennsylvania
desc: Climb ledges to a small roof. Work your way over the roof to the anchors.
protection: Black Diamond C3's up to a C4 #1 and anchors over the roof.

location: k. Hydroman Sector > Safe Harbor South > Safe Harbor > South Central PA > Pennsylvania
desc: Start below Ad 2 Vic.   Gain small ledge and clip buttonhead.   Move up right to flake (gear).   Move again up right to crack and gear.   Follow crack to big ledge and move right and finish on Deep "V" crack or 5.9 Crack.

location: f. Big Wall > Birdsboro Quarry > Southeastern Lowlands > Pennsylvania
desc: The Streak (whose first pitch is the same as Opposing Gravity's) is an apt description of this butt stain of a route. The holds are large. Follow up the right angling ramp onto the face. Careful for loose rock on the ramp (even still in 2010).
protection: 4 bolts~ anchors just out of sight above large finishing jug~ down and right of the visible hanging chains. Bring longer draws or runners to hang over the finish hold.

location: h. High Wall > Mount Minsi > Delaware Water Gap (PA) > Northeast Ridges and Valleys > Pennsylvania
desc: Same start as Osprey.  At 35'~ trend left~ staying on the arete and face~ staying 10-20 feet away from the crack system that makes up Osprey.  Pass a small overhang.  At a steep headwall~ climb the obvious~ right slanting crack to a stance below the intimidating final roof system.  For the full 5.10 value~ finish on the roofs above~ toping out by pulling on clumps of grass to reach rap station~ shared with Osprey

location: e. Machismo Sector > Safe Harbor South > Safe Harbor > South Central PA > Pennsylvania
desc: Climb left facing corner/slab on trad. Gain roof~ move left under roof~ clip 1st bolt at 25 '. Follow bolts to 2 bolt anchor. Crux is unlocking sequence to move beyond and just left of first bolt.  Direct Start: Start below bolt~ scramble up to left facing corner and stem up to roof. Move right to first bolt. 5.9(R/X)
protection: Nuts~ blue alien~ pink tricam sized stuff.   Recommend clipping first bolt with 2 slings as the lip is sharp.

location: Main Wall > Boxcar Rocks (Chinese Wall) > South Central PA > Pennsylvania
desc: A near vertical face with some fun crimps and pinches. Climb the thin face straight up.

location: S.B.R. Block > The Lost Crag > Southwestern Highlands > Pennsylvania
desc: Start just right of the low roof off of the ground. Climb up and move left to the clean steep face. Climb the face and arete to the top.  As per SWPACC Guide - Must have 24" slings to lower off.

location: Trailside > 1.5 Chimney of Horror Section > Safe Harbor North > Safe Harbor > South Central PA > Pennsylvania
desc: Begin on the front face below the first bolt. Balancey lie back up corner and then flakes. Move slightly right and follow thin seam with pods to large hold. Far right is chossy. Move back left on jugs and pull on to low angle slab to anchors.
protection: 8 bolts plus 2 bolt anchor.  SAFETY NOTICE: The bolts are very close at the start of this route. You may feel like you don't need to clip them all. CLIP THEM ALL. Many of these bolts are not for the leader~ but to direct the rope away from a razor sharp flake that WILL cut your rope.  When TRing have the leader remove the last (8th) draw and move the rope to the right. It's easier on the rope if you lower on the right side of the bolt line.

location: k. Hydroman Sector > Safe Harbor South > Safe Harbor > South Central PA > Pennsylvania
desc: Climb up a steep left-facing dihedral most of the way to the top~ then work around the arete on your  right to the finish.
protection: 4 bolts to anchor~ the first 3 of which are shared with both variations of Parabolic Corner.

location: h. West Wall > Birdsboro Quarry > Southeastern Lowlands > Pennsylvania
desc: Starting from below crackalicious~ head up and left off the ledge~ then straight up 8 bolts to rings.  Crux is 2 bolts from the top.  There are a couple of tombstone blocks on a ledge halfway up that look scary like they might pull out and hit your belayer.

location: Entrance Block > The Lost Crag > Southwestern Highlands > Pennsylvania
desc: Start about 10 ft to the right of the left side of the main face.  Climb up a shallow arete~ then head a bit left~ then straight up.   Nothing but jugs~ but fairly pumpy.

location: Short Stack > The Lost Crag > Southwestern Highlands > Pennsylvania
desc: Climb the face up to a large horizontal and place some gear. Heel hook and crank/ lunge to the crescent shaped ledge. Follow the flake past the bolt to the top.

location: Rear Wall > The Library > Mocanaqua (aka Shickshinny) > Northeast Ridges and Valleys > Pennsylvania
desc: Up the crack and through the roof~ up the left-facing corner.    . (the Holzman print guidebook 2011 edition has the difficulty as 5.10b).
protection: No bolts.    Top-Rope: Could set up top anchor on flat area at top of cliff~ using a static line from trees.   Reaching the top flat is possible by a tricky 4th class scramble around the right (SouthEast) end of the wall.

location: h. High Wall > Mount Minsi > Delaware Water Gap (PA) > Northeast Ridges and Valleys > Pennsylvania
desc: Climb the low angle rock passing 1 bolt to a grassy ledge.  Continue on good holds past 2 bolts to the crux at bolt #3 find the incut pinch and get high feet and make another move on thin holds to reach the low angled terrain with good holds.  Plug some gear (I used a .5 camalot) and continue up to the small roof with a bolt (kinda runout).  Pull past the roof on the left and past 1 more bolt ending at the chains.
protection: 5 bolts I felt only a .5 camalot was the only trad gear required~ but moving up to the roof bolt was a little runout on easy terrain so additional pro may be warranted.

location: 2.0 International Area > Safe Harbor North > Safe Harbor > South Central PA > Pennsylvania
desc: Begin with a bouldery move below 1st bolt (optional) right of Namaste. Pull up right onto a large ledge and 2nd bolt. A Few easier moves up and right to the third bolt. Powerful moves with tricky feet up the crack clipping 2 bolts along the way. Finish on Namaste (last 2 bolts).

location: The Dark Room > Peavine Island > Susquehanna River, Muddy Run > South Central PA > Pennsylvania
desc: This climb spirals up a cylinder formation in the rock. The river does some crazy things~ this route is wild looking and possibly one of the more unique climbs you will ever do!

location: Brutal Block > The Lost Crag > Southwestern Highlands > Pennsylvania
desc: Climb the green grungy face past three bolts to the shuts.

location: Little Yosemite > The Lost Crag > Southwestern Highlands > Pennsylvania
desc: Climb the obvious crack 8' right of the arete.  Follow to top.

location: 4.50 Cemetery Wall > Safe Harbor North > Safe Harbor > South Central PA > Pennsylvania
desc: Start on dubious rock. Move up to good rock and corner /roof. Pull around lip with thin moves to head  wall. Continue up steep wall to bolted anchors.   Staying right of last bolts is easier and scarier. Recommend moving over last bolt. A harder move~ but safer.

location: 4.50 Cemetery Wall > Safe Harbor North > Safe Harbor > South Central PA > Pennsylvania
desc: Just left of Smooth operator is a line of bolts called Nini wont stay down.   Follow the first few bolts to a small roof(5.9). Then go around roof on the left on steeper slab with an insecure stance to clip the crux bolt(5.10).   Next figure out how to climb a tiny right facing seem through the crux to the next bolt(5.11). From here~ climb much easier terrain to a large roof exiting right then up to the anchors.

location: Paradise > Mocanaqua (aka Shickshinny) > Northeast Ridges and Valleys > Pennsylvania
desc: Start just to the right of Rambo under a bolt and a small ceiling. Fly to a horizontal under the ceiling and then move left to join the Rambo route.

location: 4.50 Cemetery Wall > Safe Harbor North > Safe Harbor > South Central PA > Pennsylvania
desc: Begin on wavy rock and slanted rail up to thin seam at 4th bolt. Climb seam to anchors. Tenuous holds~ thin and technical with a wild crux.

location: Corridors > The Lost Crag > Southwestern Highlands > Pennsylvania
desc: Climb the short~ thin slabby face up the center of the wall.

location: The Bridge Pillar > Pittsburgh > Southwestern Highlands > Pennsylvania
desc: Easy start. The crux comes between the 2nd and 3rd bolt. It is possible to bail to the left into a large crack which runs all the way to the top.
protection: 3 bolts. Setup a top rope off the two brackets on top (20 feet of webbing and 4 carabiners).

location: Ocean Block > The Lost Crag > Southwestern Highlands > Pennsylvania
desc: This route climbs much like a boulder problem.   And with it's short stature~ you could probably protect it with a few pads if you like.  Start below the right line of bolts.  Find some nice finger locks and crimps to clip the first bolt.   Make a reachy move to a sloping horizontal to clip the 2nd bolt(crux).   Continue straight up to reach the bolt anchors on the top or head slightly left and lower off the drop in shuts above Tidal Wave.   Use some caution near the top~ some of the holds are a bit crispy.

location: d. Tenuous Odyssey Sector > Safe Harbor South > Safe Harbor > South Central PA > Pennsylvania
desc: One bolt with possibility of gear at weakness on overhang.   Unsure of redpoint and grade.

location: Brown Rocks > Brown Rocks > Pond Bank > South Central PA > Pennsylvania
desc: Start on North Face left~ traverse left over the roof until you straddle the arete.  Climb up and left onto the face in the rear of the pillar.

location: 3.6 Zero Wing > Safe Harbor North > Safe Harbor > South Central PA > Pennsylvania
desc: Open Project~ go get it.   If you've ever had a man on a bike with a fanny pack stop you near cemetery wall to talk to you about birds and show you pictures of them~ then you've met Brad. He is a local and likes to help with the Fish and Game commission to help monitor the birds. Take a minute and talk to him if you see him stopped at a bench~ he's a good guy.  Stick clip highly reccomended. Start on crystalline rock about 5 feet right of "granola in the gri gri". Go straight up into the alcove~ using thoughtful beta to climb right of the hollow block on the left (crowbar couldn't move it~ but I wouldn't go yanking on it). Move up and right out the alcove utilizing very thin holds and thumb presses. Find a way to make your feet stick to pop up to actual holds and follow to the anchor. Theres about a 10 ft runout to the anchors~ but clean falls.

location: Main Slab > Waterfall Wall > Crane Mountain > G: Indian Lake Region > Adirondacks > New York
desc: Scramble up rock steps to a vertical seam/thin crack~ which becomes a shallow groove as it runs up to a large right-facing corner (the right edge of The Tempest block). Near the top~ the corner is overgrown; either thrash through the vegetation or wander out right on unprotected slab to reach the top. Alternatively~ you can traverse straight right along a horizontal break to access the upper part of the "Right-Steep" Wall.
protection: Assortment of cams from .3 to 3"~ full length runners.

location: a2. The Uberfall - right > The Trapps > The Gunks > New York
desc: Struggle up the wide crack~ and wonder how this climb is possibly 5.3.
protection: Bring wide gear (#5 or #6) or be prepared to run it out at the start (crux).

location: a2. The Uberfall - right > The Trapps > The Gunks > New York
desc: Start on top of a car-sized block below an overhang~ 20 ft left of Harvard. Climb up onto the overhang (crux?). For a short person (I'm 5'0")~ it's awkward because there are no footholds~ but the move is protectable. Diagonal up and right to the top of another large block. From here you will see a chockstone followed by a short crack system - go up here~ and continue diagonaling right up several ramps to the top.    Note: the grey Dick Williams puts this at 40 ft~ but it seemed more like 80 ft if you go all the way to the top.    Also: the overhanging chockstone seemed precarious~ but I did pull myself up on it cautiously and it didn't budge. I checked it from above~ and it seemed pretty solidly wedged. Be careful~ though~ things can change!
protection: Standard Gunks rack~ lots of opportunities for passive pro. There are several trees at the top that you can use for anchors.

location: Upper Beer Wall > Beer Walls > B: Chapel Pond Pass > Adirondacks > New York
desc: Climb the crack with good holds and rests. Good to warm up on or something to do while waiting for Seven Ounces.
protection: Takes good gear. Trees for a TR anchor.

location: j. The Yellow Wall and The Seasons > The Trapps > The Gunks > New York
desc: Some climbs look good but suck. Some climbs look like they suck but don't. This is one the latter. A fine outing for the beginning climber.  About 140' right of Airy Aria and 120' left of Double Crack lies what appears to be a hideous~ wet~ vegetated corner.     P1: The first pitch is a nice surprise - clean white rock on the buttress just right of the ugly chimney. Easy climbing leads to a nice belay ledge.     P2: The second pitch looks nasty but the climbing is quite fun - a ladder of good holds on the left wall allows you to avoid ever entering the dank chimney. A classic Gunks pitch - steep but easy. A little vegetated in the last 20' but not enough to ruin the climb.     P3: You could add a quality 3rd pitch by traversing left to the 5.5 pitch above the GT Ledge on Lisa.

route: A Long Walk For Man, A Short Climb For Mankind
location: l. Sleepy Hollow > The Trapps > The Gunks > New York
desc: An obvious left arching corner way~ way~ way away from the crowds.  The only reason to climb this is to be able to say you've done every route in the Trapps.  Don't expect a line of chalked holds.

location: White Water Walls > B: Chapel Pond Pass > Adirondacks > New York
desc: Climb good holds up past a small white pine tree on a ledge. Continue up past a single bolt(crux)and then wander up over the bulges to the top.
protection: Takes good pro. 1 bolt. Tree anchors at top.

location: d. Harvest Moon to the End > The Near Trapps > The Gunks > New York
desc: In an effort to continue exploring "Far Nears" climbs likely untouched since the Reagan administration~ my partner and I worked our way up this "moderately interesting" route.      Make your way up P1 past a small right-facing flake to a ledge with some pine trees.  (60 ft)    Continue up P2 jug-fest~ and enjoy the nice views the exposure grants you.  Top out under a giant ridge-top boulder~ and then scramble around it to the trail for a walk-off.  (150 ft)
protection: PG - Standard Gunks rack    BEWARE OF LARGE LOOSE ROCK EVERYWHERE!

location: Eagle Falls > I: Old Forge Region > Adirondacks > New York
desc: Climb up and right~ around the overhang to the top.  Buy the guidebook Adirondack Rock for more detailed information.

location: h. The Arrow Wall - CCK > The Trapps > The Gunks > New York
desc: P1 Climb the right face of the corner to the GT ledge. 5.3PG~ 100 ft.    P2 Walk right about 50 feet to large oak tree~ just below and to the left of a flaky right facing corner.    P3 Climb the short face to big ledge. Climb the flaky right facing corner to overhang; traverse right about 15 feet to brown groove~ follow the groove~ and go right into corner. Traverse right about 20 feet to flaky left facing corner. Climb the corner to a small ledge~ and move up left then right to a small belay ledge.  5.4~ 90 ft.    P4 Move up to big horizontal~ traverse right and up to the top. 5.2~ 40 ft.    Descent: Three rappels from bolted anchors over No Glow will get you to the ground with a single rope.

location: Poke-O-Moonshine Main Face > Poke-O-Moonshine > A: Lake Champlain Region > Adirondacks > New York
desc: Slightly difficult start on black-stained rock. Several options to the left and possibly the right to gain the slab up to the first bolt. Walk the slab up to the second bolt not far away. From there the climb goes more vertical again~ yet still slabby. A couple of enjoyable delicate moves bring you up to the anchors.
protection: A few cams are useful to protect the opening moves. From there you'll find a bolt~ another bolt~ room for maybe one more piece of gear and then the chains.

location: a. Beginning of cliff to Gelsa > The Near Trapps > The Gunks > New York
desc: A fun route that will test your chimney and layback technique.    Start about 10' left of Inverted Layback at a left-facing chimney/corner with a big chockstone about 15' up.  This is about 75' left of Disneyland.    P1: Struggle to the top of the chockstone~ climb up to the corner~ and layback (what else?) up to a good belay ledge with a fixed anchor (slings and rings). 5.5~ 60'.    P2: Climb up right to the airy arete~ pass an overhang~ and continue to the top. 5.4~ 60'.    The climb can be done in one pitch without too much rope drag. To descend~ walk climbers' right along the clifftop until it is possible~ just before the road~ to easily scramble down to the base.

location: Right-Steep Side > Waterfall Wall > Crane Mountain > G: Indian Lake Region > Adirondacks > New York
desc: Originally a short route used to set a TR on its harder neighbor~ this line has been extended to the top of the cliff. It is well worth climbing the entire route for those who lead at this difficulty~ or of course to access the anchors of harder routes to the right.   Step out from the top of the foot ramp~ traversing straight right to a crack in the base of a left-facing corner~ at the point where the slab drops off into the steep face below. Climb up around the corner to a vertical crack just left of the anchors of I'll Fly Away~ then climb up to a horizontal crack~ above which the vertical crack closes up. Traverse right to another vertical crack~ then climb up to a ledge and belay at an oak tree to climber's right. The climbing to this point is 5.5 G.   The short headwall above has been climbed via a line of knobs and holds following a vertical seam/crack about 4m right of the rounded~ left-facing corner system. The climbing here is 5.5 PG.
protection: Small trad rack with nuts~ and cams to 2"

location: Beaverview > Crane Mountain > G: Indian Lake Region > Adirondacks > New York
desc: A long~ staccato route up the left section of this crag. Cleaned up it would be a three star route.  P1: Climb the ill-defined right-facing flake and face to its right to reach a left-rising horizontal crack. Traverse 8' left and climb an unprotected~ dirty~ rounded rock rib to an overhang~ at the point where a vertical crack runs through it. Climb through the overhang via the crack~ then weave upward using thin cracks and seams to reach a sloping belay ledge. 80'  P2: Climb a pair of cracks and the slab between them to a wide crack~ and take it to another sloped~ wooded ledge. 50'  P3: Climb a left-leaning diagonal crack and corner to low-angled slab~ then climb directly up the right side of the seam on gorgeous black rock. 100'
protection: Full Adk Trad Rack; doubles of #1 and #2 C4s. A 4" cam comes in very handy. No anchors or fixed gear anywhere on this route; rappel from trees.

location: Rogers Slide > Rogers Rock > F: Lake George Region > Adirondacks > New York
desc: P1 - 200ft - Follow the crack straight up to a reasonable belay spot in a depression. There are two pitons that can be backed up with gear. The crux of the climb is likely the final 50ft of P1 (5.5-5.6). Great protection.  P2 - 150ft - Continue to follow the crack system straight up. (5.5G) Once again~ great protection. This pitch ends below a roof~ just to climbers left of the weakness in the roof. This is a half-hanging gear anchor involving mostly hollow flakes. Easy gear can be placed using these flakes. Looking just above the flakes~ about a foot below the roof~ is a bomber 0.3 (small blue) cam placement in solid rock.  P3 - 180ft - Climb up and right through the weakness in the roof. Perhaps the second crux (5.5-5.6G). Continue to climb up in the crack system that turns more into a dike and belay from a bolted belay station.  DESCENT - Rap with 2 60M ropes. Two rap options are 50ft climbers right about 50ft where the edge of the slide meets the trees. Option #1: Easily traverse 50ft right and slightly down to two trees that have obvious rap burns around them. Many people just rap directly from around these trees (unfortunately). I am not sure why these trees do not have a rap station around them instead. Option #2: climb a 4th pitch up and right about 80ft through a wet and mossy slab to a fixed (tat) rap station that can be seem from the top of P3. I believe its easier to pitch this out than traverse right and scramble up unprotected~ although the latter is also an option (you'll see why people are just using option #1). Use knots at the end of your ropes for the first rap. Rap a rope-stretcher (from option #2) to a hidden rap station (tat) climbers right of the the rap line in a small right-facing corner that becomes apparent once you're over the bulge and near the end of a 60M rap. Rap from this station to 3rd bolted rap station about 50M down. You may be tempted to try and reach the a ledge below--it's easier~ however~ to do a third rap all the way down to a lower ramp/trail closer to the water to climbers left. The risk of the rope getting caught is low.
protection: Two 60M ropes. One set of nuts~ one set of cams 0.2-2. Save a 0.3 (small blue) for the 2nd belay station. A canoe.

location: d. Breakfast Wall > Peterskill > The Gunks > New York
desc: The crux is about 1/2-2/3 of the way up.  Very balancy face route with small holds.
protection: Small~ barely adequate~ definite ground-fall potential if you blow a move near the top.  Gear anchor only.  3rd-4th class scramble left from top of route to reach top of cliff.

location: Blueberry Ledge > Crane Mountain > G: Indian Lake Region > Adirondacks > New York
desc: Climb the right slanting crack up to a small ledge~ step out left and up to a larger ledge~ move up and right (crux) to gain the main hand crack~ follow crack to the top. Protection is G except for at the crux section.    V1-5.5PG at the larger ledge step out left and up  a series of flakes(some loose and thin)
protection: standard trad rack(off-set nuts very helpful to protect the crux). Tree anchor at top.

location: Lower Ridge > Moxham Mountain > G: Indian Lake Region > Adirondacks > New York
desc: The first lead route established on this cliff.   The base of the slab has a class 3 scramble to a ledge 40' up~ which begins at a boulder pile below a notch. This route begins about 20' left of the boulders~ just right of a right-facing open book that begins 6' up a slab and terminates another 7' higher~ at an overhang.   It is possible to use the class 2 scramble to climber's right to avoid the first pitch.  P1: Step left across the slab to the open book~ go up it to its end and climb through the overhang via a vertical crack~ wrestling a tree at the edge of a sloping~ stepped tree ledge. Move up the ledge to the highest step~ below the main face. 50'  P2: Step up right-facing corner to a crack veering right. Take it to its end~ at a small overhang. Traverse right 6' and climb through the overhang~ reaching a left-rising ramp leading to a vertical crack. Climb to and up the crack~ then climb easy runout slab directly up to the top.
protection: Standard Adk Trad Rack~ double #2 and #3 C4s or similar.   No bolts.   Either make a gear anchor in the overlap and right-facing corner at the top~ or climb all the way to a usable tree.

location: South Colton > K: Northern Region > Adirondacks > New York
desc: Climb up a corner below the obvious roof. Move right below the roof and continue up the right-facing corner using one of two small cracks(the right one is easier) to access a ledge with a small tree and a fixed anchor. From there it is possible to step right and then scramble up a few moves to the top of the crag.
protection: BD size .3 or .4 cam can be used in the roof. Small stoppers helpful above~ but the right placements can be tricky. Two bolts at tree ledge. Top-roping from here is not recommended because the top edge of the route is very sharp. A large nut can be placed in the very top of the route and backed up off the bolts if top-roping is desired.

location: Nestle Wall > Spanky's Area > B: Chapel Pond Pass > Adirondacks > New York
desc: Both this route and "chock full o' nuts" can be climbed as one long route with a 70m rope or broken up into 2 pitches.
protection: Full rack of cams Doubles helpful up to 2". Pink tri-cam also useful.

location: k. The Slime Wall > The Trapps > The Gunks > New York
desc: Start at a very short right-facing corner~ approximately 50ft right of The Blue Stink. The first couple moves were not protectable and worth a spot.     P1. Climb up and left to the top of a large pedestal. A small group of trees on the left side makes for a good belay station. ~50ft.    P2. Continue to the left of the belay into and up the obvious large corner. There are two rap/belay stations in this corner.  I opted to belay from the second station because of the overall arc of the climb. Rope drag would have become a major issue if I continued. ~50ft    P3.  Traverse out right on an easy ledge just above the roof. I found a #2 placement at the end of this traverse.  The climb goes up and right diagonally to the GT ledge. Lots of lichen and dirt on this pitch. ~50ft    P4.  A bit of a scramble to the top with several large ledges. I came across a piton about half way up this section.  The route ends in a sea of brambles~ which I had to beat a hole in to even get over the lip~ then search for a living tree to belay from. Lots of lichen and dirt on this pitch. ~60ft    We scrambled another 10ft to get to the true top.
protection: A standard rack of cams and nuts up to a #2 protects this route well.     There are several rap stations in the major corner on P2.  I came across a piton in the upper section but may have been off route.  We topped out and used two rap stations about 60ft to the right~ these were long two-rope rappels.  The first rappel ended with three options within 40ft of each other for the second rappel~ the middle one is the obvious one.  The second rappel goes down and right to a large pine tree. From here you may scramble down to the right or rap for a third time off the large pine.

location: Owls Head Mountain > C: Keene Region > Adirondacks > New York
desc: Climb the handcrack past some flaring~ balancy sections to the top of the cliff.
protection: Takes great cams and nuts...it's a crack.

location: f. The Guides' Wall (Madame G's) > The Trapps > The Gunks > New York
desc: This is a good link up of the first pitch of Immaculate Conception~ and the second pitch of Son of Bitchy Virgin.    The start is located at a creaky flake just right of Son of Bitchy Virgin's right-facing corner. Begin by climbing the flake and pulling a short roof to a ledge.  Continue straight up the face towards a slung block and belay here (or on gear above).      For a second pitch~ climb straight up the face following the best clean holds (trend right; some might find this section a little run out...it gets a PG rating in the Williams guide) before jug-hauling the last bit to the GT ledge.  Rap to the ground in two ropes~ or to the slung block with one.    Overall  a nice (2 star - Williams) route to do in you are in the area.
protection: Mostly standard gear...saving small stuff (blue and black aliens) for the second pitch.  One rap with doubles or two raps with a single.

location: i. High E > The Trapps > The Gunks > New York
desc: Ascending an appealing natural line~ In The Groove climbs an obvious corner with nice moves on the easy side of 5.6~ and is a good warm-up for other nearby climbs.    P1:  Start up the corner~ using the crack and face holds on the left to advance.  At the roof about 15-20 feet up step left and continue following the corner upwards.  There is a crux bulge~ but in my opinion all of the climbing is pretty straightforward 5.6 or easier~ and is well-protected.  As you get higher there are numerous left-facing flakes in the corner that provide good holds.  At about the 80 foot level~ there is a dirt ledge at which you can build an optional gear belay-- I did not; I finished the climb as a single pitch.    Original P2:  A shorter~ easier pitch.  After a few more moves upward~ the rock to the right eases off to a stairway of blocks up which it is easy to climb to a large oak tree with a rap station.  Dick Williams describes this as a dying oak tree in his 2004 guide but as of June 2010 it seemed to me to be very much alive and thriving (but see comment below; as of 2013~ not so alive).  From here~ a single 60 meter rope rap just makes it to the ground.    Direct finish:  Williams describes a new direct finish in his 2004 guide~ which climbs straight up from the end of pitch 1 to a small roof (crux)~ after which one climbs straight to the top.      I explored up to the roof~ found the hold just under the roof to be a bit less of a jug than I expected~ and then couldn't tell where to go.  There is a lot of lichen over the roof and it seemed unclear to me whether to go left or right; there were no obvious holds I could see.  It did not appear this variation had seen a ton of traffic.  The tree at the top is higher than the traditional finish~ so you will likely need two ropes to rap~ or you can walk a short distance to the Ursula rap station~ which will get you down with a single rope in two raps.

location: d. Harvest Moon to the End > The Near Trapps > The Gunks > New York
desc: Start same as Eowyn (it's actually better to start with the Eowyn overhang~ as it is more interesting)~ then head up around the right side of the overhang.  Go across the slab to a right-arcing corner~ up this~ and continue up until you can make a left traverse on steep blocky terrain (a bit of optimism here).  Climb up to another right-facing corner and follow it (crux) until it ends~ then climb a short blocky face to a nice exposed belay ledge on the arete.  Make a belay.    P2 - the only real reason to break this up into two pitches is the exposure of the beautiful belay. Head up and left avoiding loose rock and lichen for 30 more feet on not as nice terrain (5.2 or so).    Rap with 2 ropes from the Eowyn pine tree
protection: Normal Gunks rack. Small nuts are useful~ nothing bigger than a #2.

location: Hooper Garnet mine > G: Indian Lake Region > Adirondacks > New York
desc: Start by taking your first steps up the big rock to a platform at the beginning of the route. Then follow the diagonal cracks left for an easier climb~ or just head straight up.  Around the half way point there are a couple of heavy~ loose rocks on the left.  Stay right of these!  Shortly after this the face gets flat~ so borrow a huge~ obvious left jug from Princess Garnet~ then veer right and cruise to the top.
protection: Looks like tricams would be handy~ but we didn't try to lead.  Easy TR anchors with a quick walk-up.

location: 6.2 Fairy Tales > s. Books Tier > Powerlinez > New York
desc: Start up left side of low trees. Finish up right side of top left-facing corner   warning: The rock on and around this route has not been climbed much yet~ and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber - (and if possible~ behind a large tree).    . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2016. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches~ and dealing with holds slippery with grass~ lichen~ moss~ dirt).
protection: Trad: Standard rack.  For ideas to set up Top-Rope~ see the Description of this Fairy Tales sector.

location: Noonmark Mountain > E: High Peaks Region > Adirondacks > New York
desc: Find the human sized detached block~ climb up and over it from the left.  Climb a crack to the top.
protection: Good gear can be had~ and a good top rope anchor can be found on the summit.

location: e. The Mac Wall (Something Interesting) > The Trapps > The Gunks > New York
desc: START: Eleven feet to the left of Organic Iron at the base of a broken corner facing left. This is also directly below a notch facing left where the second overhang jumps down a step size.     FIRST PITCH: Climb up 5.1 corner to roof. Aid over roof and through notch. At the top of overhangs follow diagonal crack left to a ledge.     SECOND PITCH: Climb diagonal crack through overhangs and on to the Grand Traverse Ledge.     THIRD PITCH: Climb 5.2 face that is 20' to the right.

location: 4. Dave's Wall > k. Tower Wall area > Powerlinez > New York
desc: Thoughtful and/or fun moves all the way.    Up past right side of obvious tree~ next up a bit right~ then diagonal up left about ten feet~ and finish up roughly straight.   warning: Loose rock is still a concern here. Belayer or other members of party should not stand anywhere near underneath the climber.    . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2016. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches~ and dealing with holds slippery with grass~ lichen~ moss~ dirt).
protection: Trad: The protection is a little tricky~ a red tricam and some micronuts are helpful.  To set up Top-Rope~ see Description of Dave's Wall area. It's likely easier to reach a good top anchor by finding a way down below top of cliff like thirty to fifty feet west from top of this route.

location: Eagle Falls > I: Old Forge Region > Adirondacks > New York
desc: Gain a ledge then follow the arete to a large perched block at the top. Over this to another perched block with a fixed anchor on the left.

location: c. Moe (closure) to Harvest Moon > The Near Trapps > The Gunks > New York
desc: Climb the two cracks to a stance and then go up a low angled dihedral to a ledge. Move right and rappel from a bush.

location: 9. Basilisk > h. Revolutionary Ramparts > Powerlinez > New York
desc: Starts up in a small alcove to an obvious left leaning crack to the top. It is the first major crack right of TT Arete. If you can bear the sharp rock there are some solid opportunities for jams.
protection: Standard rack~ eats nuts. Great opportunity for a cordelette off the solid tree growing out of the crack directly above the route. Easy TR set up. Great for gumbos and kids.

location: Beaverview > Crane Mountain > G: Indian Lake Region > Adirondacks > New York
desc: This obvious crack begged to be cleaned and climbed. With thorough tidying~ this would be a classic route.   The start is the crux; once above the initial moves~ the climbing settles down to pleasant crack action. Step left at the top to belay off a good pine tree.   There is potential for a second pitch above.
protection: Standard Rack~ doubles of .7 and #1 C4s.

location: e. The Mac Wall (Something Interesting) > The Trapps > The Gunks > New York
desc: 1. Start by climbing the right side of the left-facing corner~ up to an overhang.  Swing around right~ then traverse right ~40' until you're below a stance in a right-facing corner.  Climb up to the ledge/stance and build a belay.  70 feet~ 5.6.    2. Climb the corner about 8-10 feet to an obvious horizontal~ then traverse out left to a bolt. Pass the bolt (crux) and then go up and right for about 25 feet to some ledges. There are several you can use; one has two old pins and a fixed piece. 70 feet~ 5.7.    3. Climb straight up to a corner system then on to the top. 60 feet~ 5.4.    From the clifftop~ walk right to various rappel stations.

location: Bluff Island > K: Northern Region > Adirondacks > New York
desc: Climb the obvious thin crack and steep face in the whiter rock left of the main face. (See "topo" posted to "Diagional Crack") Wire nuts are very useful.     The climb was brushed on a terribly hot summer day~ the brushed-off lichen becoming the "dry rain". Fortunately it was easily washed off in the lake!
protection: Wired stoppers~ couple of quickdraws.    The climb was wire brushed in July 1999.

location: Neanderthal Cave > Shelving Rock > F: Lake George Region > Adirondacks > New York
desc: Climb a corner then up slab to an overhanging face.  Power up through a series of monster jugs to the anchors.    There's a variation (5.8) that extends the route. Just before the anchor~ step left and follow the bolt line to an anchor left of Diva. Watch rope drag.

location: Statebrook > H: Southern Mountains > Adirondacks > New York
desc: Start at thin crack on the left side of the rounded buttress. Climb straight up the crack 10ft and then move around right onto the face at the two horizontals. Climb straight up the crack to the top.

location: Phoenicia, Sportsman's Wall > New York
desc: Fun climbing past some bulges to the anchor.
protection: Sport. 7 bolts to a 2 bolt chain anchor.

location: c. Moe (closure) to Harvest Moon > The Near Trapps > The Gunks > New York
desc: The route basically goes straight up~ from the start at a thin crack or seam.  I found the challenge of creatively placing gear on sometimes thin stances the most fun. It is G but takes some creativity.  It goes over an overhang 25 feet up and then up through some horizontals.     The shrubbery 20 feet above the climb has some tat that should be removed (sorry I did not have a knife) as it has things growing out of it.  There are a few places for a directional then a rap anchor about 20 feet to the right.
protection: Standard Gunks rack~ be sure to have some small nuts

location: Ark Wall > Shelving Rock > F: Lake George Region > Adirondacks > New York
desc: Climb overlap to the first bolt~ then make a reachy move right.  Follow the bolt line up past ledges to another smaller overlap~ through this to the top.

location: 9. Basilisk > h. Revolutionary Ramparts > Powerlinez > New York
desc: Start at the bottom of a big detached boulder that forms a left facing corner. Head up the corner and gain the top of the block. Move right and head to the next left facing corner. Use the face/corner to head straight up to the top.    The route name comes from the route being great for kids. If they have trouble gaining ground on rock - just hug the tree!
protection: Trad: Standard rack.  The move to top out is awkward and feels at least a grade above the rest of the climbing~ but appropriately enough there is a small stump within reach.  Long static for top rope anchors.

location: Over The Measles Wall > Measles Walls > Crane Mountain > G: Indian Lake Region > Adirondacks > New York
desc: Hand traverse out the first horizontal (crux) to its end~ then make a delicate step up to another horizontal and another step up (crux) to reach a vertical crack as the angle eases.
protection: Small to medium cams; tree anchors at top.

location: The Dihedrals > Little Falls > New York
desc: Interesting short crack. I would say it's pretty sustained~ several tricky sections. Good warm-up.    During a lap on this one I decked 10ft because I was distracted by a low-cut top. She found it quite funny. Keep your eyes on the rock~ boys...
protection: Good gear. Small stuff upto the horizontal (BD#2).    Quick clip anchors at the top.

location: c. Frog's Head - the Arch > The Trapps > The Gunks > New York
desc: Begin at the ledge that marks the start of Bloody Bush.     From Rick Cronk: The FA of the offwidth below the Bloody Bush ledge~ originally known as Rusty Jam and now appearing as a variation at 5.9~ was done by myself~ Matt Muchnik~ Kevin Bein~ Rich Perch and John Bragg in 1975. It involved a complete ascent of three pitches to the top. Bein~ Perch and Bragg continued on their way along the Trapps from the top of the first pitch. Not knowing of the undocumented 1950's ascent of Bloody Bush (Easy Street)~ Muchnik and I continued up that corner to the GT. Our third pitch wandered up just left of Rusty Trifle to the top. After 9 years Swain and party added a new separate 2nd pitch and a new name. So it goes.    From the ledge~ make a big step up and out left onto a smaller ledge~ then climb up 10 feet or so to a small roof; just above the roof there is a shallow seam. Move slightly left until you are standing on good footholds~ then go straight up to a large horizontal. Back right a few feet~ then climb straight up to a large pine tree. As described~ this pitch is often empty~ and has good protection (albeit with a bit of work) and interesting moves.     There are several pitches to be climbed from the GT ledge. Straight up from the rappel tree is easy~ 5.5 or so~ jugs and overlaps to a right-facing white corner (this is P3 of Rusty Trifle?).      Next-left is a runout~ somewhat harder pitch.      Over further left (30' or so)~ you can climb trending right up discontinuous cracks at about 5.8 and PG; the Williams guide describes this as the top pitch of Trusty Rifle.    Rappel from trees -- watch for pine sap.

location: Hyphen Section > Horseshoe North Cliff > Thacher State Park > New York
desc: Climb the sometimes awkward corner

location: New Buck > F: Lake George Region > Adirondacks > New York
desc: Climb (mantle) the ledge~ then up and left to a flake~ lay this back to the anchor.

location: Unnamed Slabs > Belleview > Crane Mountain > G: Indian Lake Region > Adirondacks > New York
desc: Like its neighbors~ Unclaimed's crux breaks through the headwall. This route has the most difficult solution to that obstacle.   Climb up tilted block to its end~ then friction w/out pro on chocolate-colored rock until it becomes dirty. Work right across the filth~ then up and left to the headwall~ belaying behind a spruce tree at the base of a 6' tall vertical crack.   Climb the crack into the corner above~ then step across right~ crossing a left-facing flake with a good crack in it~ to ascend the unprotected~ knob-riddled slab on top of the flake. The knobs end as the angle eases; weave upward~ veering to the occasional protection crack as you head for a spruce tree that blocks the final 20' of low-angle slab.
protection: Standard Rack plus a wire brush.

location: Unnamed Slabs > Belleview > Crane Mountain > G: Indian Lake Region > Adirondacks > New York
desc: Climb up slab~ heading to the oak tree for a belay. Originally~ the first belay was at a small pine tree growing at the base of the headwall~ but this tree is now dead.   Climb up to the dead pine tree and through the short headwall behind it~ using cracks in a shallow concave section of the slab above. Move onto the blunt outer corner and continue upward along the edge of a steeper slope to the right. There is no gear for about 80' on this section.   Continue up the ill-defined nose~ passing right of a spruce tree partially blocking the way~ and up one final patch of low-angle slab to a small~ open stance.
protection: There is adequate protection for the crux moves~ but extremely long runouts on 5.4ish friction.

location: b. Gelsa to Moe (closure) > The Near Trapps > The Gunks > New York
desc: Definitely worth doing if all the 7's over in the popular part of the cliff are occupied.  If possible~ engage in a dialog with passing climbers:  What route are you on?  Up Yours!  Walk past Birdland to the chossy section of the Nears. You'll step down a small gully system after Lonely Challenge~ about 200' past Birdland. Just past this is a section of good rock. Elder Cleavage starts up a hard boulder problem to the right~ and Up Yours starts up a short lieback to the left~ aiming for the obvious right-slanting crack above.  P1: First~ pass a roof~ which can be protected with high gear and a good belay~ and climb up to the right-slanting layback crack. Climb this and work up and right to easier ground. Next~ work up to a corner capped by a small overhang which is taken just a bit left (crux)~ with committing but solid moves. Finish by climbing the pleasant face up right to easy ground and up to the higher of two trees~ and a belay/rappel station. 5.7~ 80'.

location: b. Gelsa to Moe (closure) > The Near Trapps > The Gunks > New York
desc: Climb straight up to the thin vertical seam that has~ as of 2012~ only one one vintage piton of dubious quality remaining as your only protection for this move. Climb up the seam (crux)~ move right and climb an easy roof~ then move left to the edge of the face and climb past an overhang to the top~ or move around the corner and up an easy face to the ledge.    Rappel from a tree over Fat and Weak~ to climbers' right.
protection: Very small nuts~ e.g.~ RPs and/or tiny camming units. The pitons don't look very trustworthy.

location: 6. The Tower Wall > k. Tower Wall area > Powerlinez > New York
desc: Interesting thoughtful moves in a variety of rock situations.    Up the left arete of the Sharks Tooth detached flake to its top - (extra points for standing up straight on top in balance with no hands).   . . Variation 1 (less exciting but perhaps better protected for Leading): Start up the gully+face behind left side of Sharks Tooth.    Step (or fall?) across to the main face into a shallow alcove just left of a right-trending crack. Trend right up crack~ or up to top of alcove then exit right to crack~ and up to a ledge.     Next up shallow gully on right side of bulge.   . . Variation 2 (more interesting but not protected): Step left on ledge~ then up over left side of bulge.   Move left to base of arete with fins which forms left edge of upper Tower Wall.    Up the arete with fins~ perhaps with moves both strenuous and balancy (crux)   . . Variation 3: Climb a few feet on the face to right of arete up to overhang~ then escape left to join the arete.    Finish up a short slab.   warning: The rock around this sector has not been climbed much yet~ and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber.
protection: Lead: normal NY style Trad rack.    The 2011 print guidebook and the Rakkup phone app (as of 2017) seem to imply that this route is reasonably protectable~ but a substantial percentage of climbers think it's more like PG-13.    Perhaps this route might be said to be reasonably protected if the leader "does everything right"~ including:    - uses Variation 1~    - takes extra care to make sure one of the low pieces does not pull out after climb past it~    - makes at least one strenuous placement which does not seem necessary at the time but is the last chance for awhile~    - accepts that a lengthy less-difficult section in the middle has no protection~ and    - is prepared that while the tricky balancy sequence of the upper crux section may be 5.8 after you know it~ on sight it might feel more like 5.9 and need more finger endurance/strength just to hang on while working out each move.   Top-Rope: Likely easiest with a very long static line (at least 100 ft) - to reach tree set way back from top of cliff - also likely want to rappel or down-climb below the top 20 or 30 feet to set the carabiners lower~ so to avoid dragging / abrasion of the rope over the cliff top edge.    Reaching the top of the cliff: One simple (but not short) way is to hike left (WNW) past the base of sectors Three Bears and Daves Wall to the intersection of the Tower Wall tier trail with The Good Book access trail. Turn Right and follow The Good Book trail up a steep slope~ then after it gets gentle~ find a way off it right and upward toward the mini-summit view at the top of the Tower Wall cliff.

location: Sunshine City > Spanky's Area > B: Chapel Pond Pass > Adirondacks > New York
desc: Climb up past 2 bolts in a black~ sometimes wet~ right facing corner to a ledge. Follow the line of bolts~ trending left up the face.     A great route with fun movement throughout. The bolt spacing keeps the ledge in play for several clips afterwards. An exciting lead if 5.8 is your level.
protection: Sport. Fixed anchors at the top.

location: Panther Gorge > E: High Peaks Region > Adirondacks > New York
desc: This line is surprisingly interesting and more appealing than it appears from below.    Climb to flaring chimney and follow to roof. Drift left around dangerous blocks to a small ledge. Climb handcrack in right facing corner to adequate belay on the left.   Rappel or walk off to climber’s right.
protection: Good gear all the way with standard rack.

location: Fossil Wall > Horseshoe North Cliff > Thacher State Park > New York
desc: Follow left-facing corner to bolts

location: Statebrook > H: Southern Mountains > Adirondacks > New York
desc: Stem across the walls when possible and climb straight up to the small roof (bolt) and up the small crack (crux). Continue up the crack through easier climbing to a sloping ramp and into the corner. Move out left  passing about 8ft right of the Uncle Hal anchors to the anchors for this climb which are about 20ft higher.
protection: Trad with 2 Bolts~ 2 bolt anchor/lower off

location: j. The Yellow Wall and The Seasons > The Trapps > The Gunks > New York
desc: Blistered Toe is a fun~ steeper-than-it-looks pitch of climbing with two starts. To keep the grade at 5.8~ start at obvious (but somewhat suspect) flakes about 10 feet left of the crack~ climb up 10-15 feet~ and traverse right towards the crack. Climbing the crack directly from the ground ups the ante to 5.9+. Climb the crack above~ with some jamming and stemming~ to a large ledge~ and traverse left to a bolted anchor in a right-facing corner.  P2 is loose and possibly inobviously wet - not recommended! Diagonal up right via 5.4 face climbing~ to the path of least resistance up to a large overhang (5.6~ loose); traverse left here~ then pull past the overhang to easier rock. P3 climbs easier rock to the top.
protection: Standard rack~ up to a #3 Camalot.

location: c. Moe (closure) to Harvest Moon > The Near Trapps > The Gunks > New York
desc: A long~ meandering climb. It can be done in 3-4 pitches.      P1 (5.7): Go up a corner~ then up right through grooves to a small overhang. Pull this and head left to tree with rings/slings.      P2: We climbed the face rather than the broken corner. It seemed like 5.6 any way we went.      P3: Go up and right to make a belay below the big roof. You'll need some small gear to protect the crux.      P4: Make the airy traverse out left. You can combine this with P5 by exiting the traverse and running up the slabs.  Most of this climb was pretty dirty and had some suspect rock.  That said~ it was a blast and it's easy to avoid the sketchy stuff.
protection: Standard gunks rack~ some small gear for P3.

location: Pitchoff Chimney Cliff > C: Keene Region > Adirondacks > New York
desc: This is a link-up that combines the first pitch of Rugosity with the second pitch of Bogeyman. The chimney pitch of Rugosity sports an easy chimney with an unlikely exit move. The second pitch of Bogeyman changes gears and offers some exposed face climbing initially~ followed by some spicy technical face climbing above. A diverse and lesser-traveled route for the confident 5.8 leader.  P1 (5.8 G): Climb the obvious chimney (easy~ no gear) until you reach the roof and horizontal crack on the right side. Protect with your 3.5-4" cam and hand traverse out the horizontal to pull "the move" to get your feet underneath you and climb briefly to the perch atop the stacked boulders under the roof (belay here).  P2 (5.8 G): Gain the highest block that allows one to by pass the roof. Face climb up and left passing horizontals (protection) to a semi-detached block with a bolt at its left. Climb up to a wide horizontal and a left-leaning sloping ledge. Move left on the ledge to a bolt and climb technical face to the last bolt. Easier climbing past a moss filled horizontal (no gear) leads to a final horizontal with a dirty but welcomed pod of cleared vegetation for protection. One last section of face climbing leads to the fixed anchor atop the cliff.
protection: A light rack to 1.5" cam (#1 camalot) and a 3.5"-4" cam. 3 bolts. Fixed anchor atop P2.

location: j. The Yellow Wall and The Seasons > The Trapps > The Gunks > New York
desc: An excellent pitch that is atypical for the Gunks - more subtle and balancy than usual.  Look for a right-slanting crack system that starts about 55' left of The Spring (P1).  P1: Climb up and right~ then left through a small overhang~ up the crack~ and finish with a funky rightward traverse to a fixed anchor that deposits you over The Winter (or continue to the bolted anchor on the huge ledge up and right) 5.8~ 80'.  P2: If you keep going~ work back left and skirt the roof above on the left. Then climb somewhat vegetated rock to the GT Ledge. 5.6~ 100'.

location: Sunset Slab > Mount Helena > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: Lots of holds~ great for beginners! Bolted well for a 1st lead. Can be top roped easily by heading up the approach gully.

location: Upper Rock > Cow Patty > Grasshopper Rocks > Castle Mountains > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: Start in a chimney at the base~ then transition onto the spire to the right around the second bolt.  Then ascend the easy stairs to the anchor
protection: 4 bolts to chains.  Extra protection can be used to protect the run-out between bolts 2 and 3 and bolt 4 and the anchor.

location: The Watchtower - Lower > East Side > Gallatin Canyon > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: Clean and simple this well protected variation start to Mothers Day keeps your feet clean and the leaves out of your hair. Steep and littered with holds~ the short North Crack is a nice way to bypass the first pitch of Mothers Day. Climb the jagged~ blocky crack on the right side of the face. Top out on the large knob and traverse the rim up and left to a belay ledge. This short line has no fixed anchors. Watch out for loose rocks.
protection: A couple of slings~ and a rack of cams to 3 inches.

location: Cowen Massif > Paradise Valley > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: From Elbow Lake hike up the creek on the east end of the lake to another small lake and meadows on the east side of the main Cowen massif (Eenie~ Minnie~ Miney and Moe).  Continue up the meadows and grassy ledges to a pass which is descended on or next to a snowfield.  A hidden gully starts a just below the snowfield~ leading to a notch on the northeast ridge of Cowen.  From this notch~ cross another gully and start climbing up the arete.  The arete is super fun 4th and low 5th class climbing~ with a several 5.6 steps thrown in depending upon route finding.  The route ends at the summit block which is gained by a 5.4 chimmney.  We climbed the route in one long pitch followed by three simul pitches.
protection: A light alpine rack is sufficient~ lots of long slings.

location: Fish Face > East Side > Gallatin Canyon > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: This route might be intimidating to a new leader. The top portion looks unprotectable from the ground~ but there are some good placements the entire way.  Don't be swooned into the dirty chimney to the right! Climb the face just right of the arete! That's where the 3 stars are. The chimney is terrible.  Descent: Walk off left.
protection: Mostly small cams and nuts~ up to BD 0.75. Two bolt anchor (no chains or rings).

location: South Buttress > Blue Cloud > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: An easy sport climb that moves from right to left up a slabby arete.
protection: Quickdraws are all you need. There is a two bolt anchor at the top~ no chains or rap rings. Belay from here and walk off~ or lower off two draws and then walk back up to retrieve them.

location: The Wafers > Revenue Flats > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: A fun short climb up a chert littered slab.  Makes for a good first lead due to the liberal bolting.

location: Pinnacle > Barretts > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: Neat route~ which is the standard~ easiest way to the summit of this free standing spire.    Start at the chimney on the south side of the Pinnacle~ climb the face past three lead bolts.  Step around to the left and onto a shallow ledge.  Follow cracks/weaknesses to the summit on the west face of the spire.      Take care for some loose/crumbly rock.    Neat position~ fun climbing~ and a nice spire summit all make for a great~ short little route.
protection: 3 lead bolts~ standard rack (selection of small/medium cams and set of stoppers).  Fixed anchor on top for the rappel back down the West Face of the spire.

location: Practice Rock > Hyalite Canyon > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: This is the easiest way to the top of the Pinnacle formation on the west side of Practice Rock. Climb the crack past the low crux to a good ledge. From here continue up the ramp. You can climb right against the main wall~ but I prefer the crack system in the middle of the ramp. The last twenty feet or so are the best of the climb. It is a good hand crack to the finish. The top of the Pinnacle is a great spot. A small ledge with air on all sides! There is a less popular 2nd pitch that steps onto the face~ then a runout to the anchors to the left.
protection: A standard rack is great for this climb. I like to have an extra #1 BD~ and a #4 could be useful depending where you decide to start. There is a bolted anchor with chains at the top. Please put a carabiner through the chains while toproping on this anchor (or any anchor!). They have been seeing some wear from lowering.

location: Blow-Hard Wall > Blackleaf Canyon > Northwest Region > Montana
desc: Long easy route. First bolt is above a narrow ledge.

location: Split Pinnacle > Homestake Pass > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: Thin hands crack followed by a traverse~ then up the south arete to the top. Two anchors to choose from. As the Bishop guide indicates~ you can chimney up a ways to a good stance before pulling into the crack~ but the direct start is good climbing on solid jams. A little harder~ maybe 5.9 if you don't use the opposite wall.
protection: rack to 3"~ extras around .75 and 1.  You can place a 4" piece on the traverse but not needed.  Beware some hollow sounding rock inside the crack half-height~ protection is good above and below.

location: The Nuggets > Revenue Flats > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: Head up into a large groove like formation and head to the crack in the back.  A little run out to the first gear placement but really easy.  Continue through hero jugs up the groove and then it ramps down.  Use either the left or right side anchors.
protection: Some small TCU's and #.5-3.  A number 4 is handy if you wish to protect the upper section.  Kind of hard to select a rack for due to the spastic crack sizes.

location: Fish Face > East Side > Gallatin Canyon > Southwest Region > Montana
