desc: Crystal delight starts on the L side of fish face wall. This route doesn't look like much from the ground~ but ended up being a blast! Climb up the white crystal dyke passing by a few pins along the way. Pro is great on this pitch~ so don't hesitate to jump on it!

location: East Buttress > Frazier Cirque > Ainger Lake > Bridger Range > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: Put on your dad pants and get ready for some adventure! This fun mixed route takes a somewhat wandering line up the shear~ west most side of the buttress and follows cracks and face features on mostly great rock for its length. Even though the route sports sustained easy climbing~ it was established on lead in alpine style so expect some long run-outs between pro and bolts. If you think a little spice is nice you will enjoy this line.    Pitch 1~ 5.7   Start at the base of the very obvious left slanting crack system about 80ft up and left from the toe of the buttress. Climb 40ft of very easy but unprotected 5th class to and obvious ledge and clip the first bolt. From the first bolt follow the obvious vegetated crack past bolts and gear to an obvious small overlap with a #3 camalot (or equivalent) placement. Once over the overlap~ place a small piece in a left facing flake and follow a few bolts trending up and left towards a small pillar of rock to a bolt belay. Runner things well. This is a long pitch and takes almost all of a 70m rope~ so be sure to tie in the follower before sending off the leader!     Pitch 2~ 5.8   From the belay~ climb up and right and follow spacey bolts on great rock to a heady section getting to the last bolt on the pitch. Climb through awesome runnels to a bolted anchor. This pitch is all bolts.     Pitch 3~ 5.5   Climb up to a single bolt then climb straight up the face trough spaced natural pro to the ridge line staying to the right of a small group of trees. Once the ridge line is gained~ follow it up and left to an obvious tree belay on a large ledge at the base of a final triangular headwall.     From the tree belay~ walk left about 15ft and belay un-anchored on the comfy ledge. The first bolt is roughly 12 ft off the ground.     Pitch 4~ 5.6    Climb up the perfect grey rock to a bolt~ then continue straight up to some natural pro in a flake just up and left of a small shrub. From here~ follow two more bolts to the top of the feature. Once on top of the triangular feature~ cross a small gap to a 15ft section of easy 5th class to a tree belay.     To descend~ see the descent beta listed on the East Buttress page.
protection: Natural pro and bolts. Single rack to #3~ nuts~ 6 quickdraws~ 6 alpine draws~ and a 70m rope. Wear your helmet.

location: Gregory > Billings Rimrocks > South Central Region > Montana
desc: This was a good route bitd. Unfortunately the top has fallen down(note nearby boulders) leaving a route of dubious quality.

location: Blue Collar Wall > Avalanche Gulch > Big Belt Mountains > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: Very obvious route that begins on road; positive flakes and holds to the top.
protection: Bolts to chains (shares chains with Belly Full of Beer~ to the right)

location: Recess Wall > Bozeman Pass > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: Climb the slab past bolts to a chain anchor.

route: Don't Put Your Hand In It
location: Sidewinder Buttress > Rattler Gulch > Northwest Region > Montana
desc: This is a great climb on good rock~ very similar to its neighbor Snake Eye. Heads up the left most bolted line to a dihedral~ then up to ledge to share anchors with Snake Eye.
protection: Quickdraws~ chain anchors~ one fixed pin.

location: Guardian Wall > Kila Crags > Northwest Region > Montana
desc: More or less straight up. Not as much smooth rock as the other 2 on this wall. A lot has splintered out over the thousands of years since the glaciers carved this face.   A small roof about 2/3 the way up adds some fun to an otherwise simple route. You can also go left around this crux if desired.   2 stars for the crux - 1 without

location: Holds Up Bluff North > Stone Hill > Northwest Region > Montana
desc: classic line up the left facing hand finger crack with a block wedge at the bottom of the crack. route continues up the face past two bolts.
protection: Use Gear 2" for 60mm (18m) to one hanger and a chain

location: Fish Face > East Side > Gallatin Canyon > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: If you don't like this pitch~ you don't like crack climbing... Bring all sizes of cams up to 3 Camalot. Maybe bring a 4 Friend for the top? Steep climbing with good pro. What are you waiting for? Walk off to the climber's left.

location: Prospector Crag > Memorial Falls > Northwest Region > Montana
desc: Follow broken 4th class rock for about 20ft. Pass to the left of a small overhang and up a steeper face (crux 1) with good holds. Pull over the ledge and onto the face above. Move through a series of crimps in the middle of the face straight to chain anchors (7 bolts to chains).

location: The Coliseum > Avalanche Gulch > Big Belt Mountains > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: Pretty standard face climbing for the area. Crux is between bolt 3-4.

location: Recess Wall > Bozeman Pass > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: Climb past a few bolts up a slab to a stance~ pull the steep bulge on good pockets to the chains.

location: Gregory > Billings Rimrocks > South Central Region > Montana
desc: Nice slabby 5.9 face climb. Good warmup and intro to rims climbing. Danger: There is a large block above the anchors which looks like it could roll/drop sometime soon. Barney/Betty Rubble also present rockfall potential/danger.
protection: Bolts. Chained anchors which need to be replaced.

location: Prospector Crag > Memorial Falls > Northwest Region > Montana
desc: Simple Math - 5.9 (sport) 80ft    This climb ascends the face 5 feet right of 'Stuffer'. Move through well-spaced hand and foot holds towards and interesting triangular block that juts out from the middle of the wall. The hand holds are good~ but at times sparse. Fun movement on well spaced clean rock.

location: Nude Beach SW Face > Avalanche Gulch > Big Belt Mountains > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: Interesting direct start to jugs the whole way.  Bring an apline draw or sling to to clip the upper bolt of Hemingway.
protection: 6 bolts to chains.  Shared anchors with Hemigway.

location: Ojibway Peak > Northwest Region > Montana
desc: This route could have very well been climbed before as early as the 1960's by any number of very talented people who have climbed in the area in the last 50 years. I'm adding it to the database in case anyone has looked to the right from the original route and wondered what it's like "over there" or if it's been climbed at all.     One summer day my partner and I decided to just go have a look starting from the bottom. What we found was a route that compared~ in difficulty~ to the original route. The first pitch didn't protect very well due to the compact nature of the slab. The pitch through the big roof I'd describe as traveling through nearly the highest point of the right side on good~ protectable cracks. Higher the rock quality worsened~ but never to the point that we had to debate the value in continuing upward. Overall~ this route traveled through a lot of 5.6-5.8 difficulty loose terrain. It is significantly looser than the standard route for comparison and therefore I can't recommend it. Choss aficionados and seekers of the obscure may enjoy it.    The first pitch was probably the technical crux and we finished by traversing left and off once we hit the large ledge separating the bottom of the face from the upper headwall.
protection: Standard rack to 3". Something to equalize gear at belays.

location: Wall of Smiling Faces > Buck Creek > Big Sky Area > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: Fun sequential climbing. Use your tall powers. Careful of loose rock when topping out and pulling rope.

location: New Rock (Butte) > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: Climb is in two sections with a ledge rest in the middle before pulling back onto the rock above.  You can stem the first few moves.
protection: Bolts to chains.  You can reach the anchor to top rope by scrambling around left~ then bouldering up the East side of the formation.

location: Pinnacle > Barretts > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: Make an awkward move up~ after clipping the first bolt~ and~ clip the second bolt making sure the belayer is paying attention~ and the lead climber is solid for the clip.  A spot from the ground may be prudent.    Interesting but short climbing up the shady aspect of the spire.
protection: 4 lead bolts.      Some supplementary pro may be availble past the first two bolts~ but~ optional for the confident folks at the grade.

location: Bukowski Buttress > Avalanche Gulch > Big Belt Mountains > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: Decent climbing up over a bulge and onto a very exposed feeling face above.

location: Flathead Buttress > Blodgett Canyon > Northwest Region > Montana
desc: no gear was left on first ascent.first 3 pitches end on arête tower one double rope rap to ground on west face.these are free climbable with clean pro~incl. the obvious 30 foot roof!4thru 8 ascend s face just left of s.e. buttress.
protection: small pin rack incl.knifeblades and usual free rack(x larges for roof(pitch 2)

location: 7-11 Crag > Allenspur > Paradise Valley > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: A fun~ techical corner leads to the large bench. Head left and finish on the thin vertical seam and a slight~ easy run to the chains. The bottom can also be linked into the fun upper half of YPA for a longer pitch.   In loving memory of Ted Morris.

location: The Heap > Northwest Region > Montana
desc: Start is the same as Dike's Edge.  Climb the vertical dike and move right at the gully onto friction climbing past a couple of bolts.

location: Pollock Mountain > Glacier National Park > Northwest Region > Montana
desc: 2nd pitch with lighting bolt crack is crux. Good overall climb.
protection: Various Trad Gear: wires~ nuts and cams to 3"-4"   No bolts or fixed gear. No Anchors. Carry pitons for rapping off in emergencies.

location: Ant Wall > Upper Bear Canyon > Bear Canyon > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: This climb trends right across the face with some fun moves throughout and some early~ questionable rock. Still worth the time~ The Ant Route is accurately graded and will build character. Finish down and right of a large dead tree.

location: Fire Spire > Avalanche Gulch > Big Belt Mountains > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: This is an absolute gem of a route. Great exposure~ fun climbing~ and a sweet summit.  Pitch 1: (5.9~ 90') Scramble out on a small ledge to the right of Sunfire Slab. Belay at a bolt. Work up a small dihedral into a crack followed by some face climbing. All bolts. Belay on a good sized ledge.  Pitch 2: (5.9~ 90') Start up the left side of the ledge~ past bolts onto a face split by a crack. Finish on the crack system. 3 bolts~ finish on gear. Enjoy the view and the top of the spire!  Descent: Rappel route.
protection: Mixed route with bolts and some gear. Bring 12 draws (a few extendable)~ assortment of stoppers~ and a few small to medium sized cams. Chain anchors.

location: Phipps Park > Billings Rimrocks > South Central Region > Montana
desc: Great trad lead! A smaller~ easier~ mirror image of Corona Corner. Offwidth to tight hands in a right facing corner. No particular crux~ just sustained crack jamming. Excellent protection~ very good rock. The Ripples on the face right of the crack can be top roped from the anchors and await a free ascent~ I'm guessing 11/12ish. Get after it!
protection: #5 to #1 camalots~ double up on 2's.  Good anchors at top though scary to approach~ consider a belay.

location: The Coliseum > Avalanche Gulch > Big Belt Mountains > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: Climb up the right side of a wide water worn trough over bulges and face moves. Steep route. Very airy feeling.  Descent: Rappel route.

location: South Stone-Bikini Area > Stone Hill > Northwest Region > Montana
desc: Nice route in the middle of the cliff band. 1st bolt is high. If you are leading~ looks like a critical hold down low broke off~ so clipping the first bolt is a little spicy.
protection: Clip the bolts and motor past them.

location: Black Line Buttress > East Side > Gallatin Canyon > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: Starts from the same ledge where If Pleides Could Dance and French Lace start from; this ledge is reached with a 40' 5.4ish scramble~ either from the right or up the obvious dihedral on the left.     Begin just left of Pleides~ and pull diagonally left off of the ledge on steep~ solid orange rock (crux). Once the arete is met~ follow the left side of it until the obvious horizontal crack~ cut right onto the arete proper~ and follow this into a thin crack to the upper ledge. Good climbing~ but there is some hollow rock and lichen. Done on-sight~ ground-up~ so not much cleaning was done.
protection: Double set of stoppers and cams~ cordalette or long slings for upper anchor. Small tree and marginal gear anchor on big upper ledge. Walk off to the east.

location: Main Crag > Allenspur > Paradise Valley > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: A fun slab leads to a short roof crux and a rest. From there~ follow a broken~ blocky corner for several bolts until you transfer onto the face~ following the slanting crack up and far right to chains.

location: The Foyer > Natural Bridge and Falls > South Central Region > Montana
desc: This left-leaning flake makes for a great jughaul.  The holds are all there~ and you really get your pump going.

location: Wall of Smiling Faces > Buck Creek > Big Sky Area > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: A committing bouldery start with fun pockets above.

location: Upper Wall > Kila Crags > Northwest Region > Montana
desc: Good clean line that has a fun bulge at the start.  LOOSE ROCK (hence the name!)

location: Right Rock > Sheep Mountain > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: The crux is up high. Protected by bolts. Easier climbing gets up up to it. Use cams to protect the lower part of the climb and balance your way through the thin crux clipping bolts.
protection: cams or nuts and some quickdraws

location: Ojibway Peak > Northwest Region > Montana
desc: From the pillar where the regular route traverses left and off~ continue up on bolts following the line of Charles Wallace the Party Rabbit. From a belay at 80-90 feet. CWtPR continues straight up while Modern Direct takes a slanting line to the apex of the headwall.    This route has either gear or a bolt every 10-15 feet. Stopper and small cam placements were excavated from the discontinuous cracks in the wall~ but bolts were placed whenever the cracks run out for any distance. It is not a run out route~ but you will need to spend some time placing gear to sew it up. Take a nut tool in case the cracks fill in again.
protection: Standard rack to 3"~ maybe some extra TCUs. Small/medium stoppers particularly useful.

location: Elk Rock > Northwest Region > Montana
desc: Good slabby route~ clean and well protected.
protection: Four bolts? Bolted anchors with rap rings.

route: No Animals Were Harmed During the Bolting of This Route
location: Style Wall > Rattler Gulch > Northwest Region > Montana
desc: No Animals starts in a broken crack system with some loose rock~ but good gear. Head directly up the wandering cracks to gain a small ledge. Place a couple of pieces here. Pull onto the next face for some fun moves on good rock~ clip the first bolt~ and then head through one more to reach the anchors.
protection: Single rack from #1 Metolius to 1"~ quickdraws~ chain anchors.

location: Skyline South > Skyline Buttress > East Side > Gallatin Canyon > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: Start on a lower angle~ balancey face into some large pocket/dish features. Move through the second pocket/dish (crux)~ over the bulge~ and through some slightly easier~ but still thought provoking terrain~ to the chains.  Descent: Rappel route.

location: Prospector Crag > Memorial Falls > Northwest Region > Montana
desc: Start just right of 'Meat Grinder' with large overhang directly over head. Follow crack under the overhang into corner. Step out and right around the overhang. Crack continues through short facing climbing going toward the next overhang above. Pass this overhang on the right past a large boulder on a ledge. Proceed from the ledge behind the boulder straight to the top. Finish is in a small dihedral. Chains at finish.
protection: Standard rack~ medium to small size mostly. Chains up top. Walk off or rap the route.

location: Bear Claw Buttress > Indian Creek > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: Sharp~ crisp~ low-angle pockets to chains.

location: Tor Rock > Northwest Region > Montana
desc: Starts in cave below Main Face. A boulder start (crux) leads to an "up there" first bolt. Runout between second and third bolts; 3 bolts to chains.

location: Main Wall - West End > Blackleaf Canyon > Northwest Region > Montana
desc: Follow simple crimps on chert up through some balance moves. Continuous crimps are pumpy~ but fun. Lots of petrified animals in this area

location: Hidden Crag > East Side > Gallatin Canyon > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: Climb just left of the right edge of the cliff's north side~ aiming for the colorful rock at the top~ where you'll be right on the arete. Fun movement~ good position. Mixed gear and bolts.
protection: Mixed gear and bolts~ chain anchor.

location: Rho > Crystal Theater / Babcock Spires > Northwest Region > Montana
desc: Climb the hand to fist to finger crack until it becomes a chimney.  Follow the chimney past a few bolts until you can face climb onto the large waco covered wall to the right.  The belay is next to a large boulder on top of the rock (gear).
protection: Bolts and gear~ 110 foot rappel from chains on the northwestern corner of the rock above Go Rho Your Boat.

location: The Waltz Formation > East Side > Gallatin Canyon > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: Alternate first pitch to the Waltz with good climbing and a fun roof. Start under the obvious roof at the base of the Waltz formation on the river side. Climb up and through the bulge and continue up the fun~ juggy dihedral. A nice long pitch that tops out on the first of the three buttresses

location: Shredder Wall > Rattler Gulch > Northwest Region > Montana
desc: Shredder is located on the left side of the shredder wall~ 2nd route from the left. The namesake and classic for the wall~ it has great moves and solid rock~ as well as very sustained and stiff. Head up through a few easy moves to a good stance at about 20 ft~ then start up the sustained and techy face.

location: Sprinkles Rock > Northwest Region > Montana
desc: A sweet 5.10 that I wish went on forever...Start on boulders and pull up through big pockets through nice edges to a crux up top. If you're feeling adventurous at the anchor~ climb above and enter the sky garden--it's sick.

location: Medicine Hole Wall > Indian Creek > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: A short face with pockets~ jugs~ and crimp rails.
protection: Three bolts to a two bolt anchor (lap link and quick link).

location: Parking Lot Wall > Blodgett Canyon > Northwest Region > Montana
desc: Climb starts 20 feet left of the Swiss Route on a blank looking slab. Climb through middle of slab (easy) and head directly for a few small left facing dihedrals. You will find bolts there that head to a sling belay. 2nd pitch. You will see a bolt to the right. Take this straight up passing through a break and some cracks. Bolts and gear.

location: Nude Beach SW Face > Avalanche Gulch > Big Belt Mountains > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: Pretty fun~ albeit typical for the area crimpy~ balancey route. Some technical crimpy sidepulls through here~ with challenging feet.  Descent: Rappel route.

location: Pineapple Buttress > East Side > Gallatin Canyon > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: Follow the bolted arete 10' left of the first pitch dihedral of Thunderpussy. Finish the pitch on the final handcrack bit of Thunderpussy to the pod belay. A beautiful~ airy pitch! For a really great outing~ skip the manky belay pod and string Savor the Flavor together with Thunderpussy's second pitch for a spectacular single pitch (a FULL 60m) which is on par with the best in the canyon!
protection: 7 bolts and a standard rack of cams and stoppers. A cordalette or double-length runner is handy for the belay. Bring extended slings if you plan to do this in one pitch.

location: Main Crag > Allenspur > Paradise Valley > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: Decent~ wandery climbing up flaky~ uninspiring rock that gets good right at the top. Don't pull too hard.

location: Dihedral Wall > Stone Hill > Northwest Region > Montana
desc: The first route established on the wall and the splitter looking dihedral you can catch a glimpse of from the road. There isn't an easy way to get to the top of this cliff so it was first climbed aid solo.  Starts with some interesting moves as you try to wiggle in a small cam in the seam. A couple moves later and you get a good .3 placement. Or bring a big cam~ #5 or 6. Continue up into the dihedral and get some good jams and locks higher up. Shares anchors with Extrovert.

location: Identity Wall > Kootenai Canyon > Northwest Region > Montana
desc: An awesome moderate trad route with nearly a 20 foot horizontal overhung crack. While it looks like an off-width from the ground narrowing to hands~ there are good holds within the roof crack. Gear is plentiful.    The climbing from the cracks to the right of the dihedral to the roof is nothing more than 5.9~ but its super enjoyable.
protection: A single rack up to #4 BD Camalot. Rap off of slung tree with permanent carabiners.

location: Tango Tower > East Side > Gallatin Canyon > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: Starting uphill from the 'watercolor'~ begin with underclings behind a tree and work up and right. Thin face climbing above minimal and marginal gear leads to a hollow dihedral where one wants to traverse into the watercolor for the last 10' to the anchors.
protection: Thin gear up to a #2 Friend. Spicy.

location: The Aquarium > Revenue Flats > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: Belay from the obvious brush clearing in the boulder field. Climb up onto the ledge and traverse left over balancey moves to the crack. Smearing and lie-backing mainly~ with a few feet out left. Crack is fat fingers down low~ small hands up top. Plug some gear under the roof~ and move up and over the roof (crux). Don't get stuck trying to place pro in the awkward stance above the roof. Keep moving. The pro thins out from roof to anchors.  Super fun~ albeit short~ route!  Descent: Clean your anchor and walk off left.
protection: Can easily set up a toprope (directional cam suggested). Small rack up to 2". BD#2 protects roof. Bolts with some very weathered slings/rap ring attached.

location: Main Area > Frog Rock > Southwest Region > Montana
desc: Great rock~ fun moves~ neat fossils (hence the name).

location: Upper Major Mass & Jungle Gym Tower > 5.3 - Doorway Rocks - Major Mass > East Bluff 05 - Potholes Area > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: A nice well protected 5.4.

location: 1. Misery Rocks > West Bluff 02 - Misery Rocks & The Pantry > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: Fat Man's Misery climbs inside the "cave" at Misery Rock between Wailing Wall and Pillow's Edge. Use the west face at first and then onto solid corners of "the pillow" to get into a body sized chimney. Don't go too far into the chimney otherwise you'll feel the route's namesake. Finishes on top of "the pillow."
protection: None until you are ready to pull out of the chimney.  Standard rack from there.

location: 5.4 - Doorway Rocks - Minor Mass > East Bluff 05 - Potholes Area > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: Flotsam and Jetsam are two climbs on the east face of the Minor Mass of the Doorway Rocks.  They can be easily located by finding the large pine tree that lays across the chimney below Pigeon Roof.    The right variation of the route is the longer of the two.  Make your way up to the "Saddle".  From the saddle climb around so that you're above the fallen tree at the bottom of an inside corner about 10 feet above the "Saddle".  Climb up the inside corner on easy holds to the south face of a small tower.  Use ledges to gain the top of the tower.    The left variation climbs up the chimney that contains the fallen tree.  This variation is the more awkward variation and is less recommended than the right variation.

location: U Haul Overhangs > Near East > East Bluff 02 - East of the Quarry > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: A fun romp up 2" wide edges.  Swartling & Mayer describe some contrived 5.7 start~ but if you are leading~ the obvious place to begin is the crack system at the right end of the formation.  Continue up edges on the east facing wall~ near the edge.  At the top~ add some more free mileage by shifting right to the crack before topping out.
protection: The key is small stuff in the horizontals.

location: Condor Corner > East Bluff 02 - East of the Quarry > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: Clean and straight~ very nice.

location: 13: Four Brothers > East Bluff 04 - East Rampart > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: Climb the inside corner and layback or stem past overhang into the gravel.
protection: Standard rack. Lots of placements available for a beginning leader to sew up the climb.

location: Great Tower > West Bluff 04 - Great Tower Area > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: The first problem is squeezing in behind the twin pine trees and making your first move off the ground in that cramped space. There's actually two chimneys stacked on top of each other separated by a narrow slit that you have to climb around to get from the lower chimney to the upper one (minor crux). The bottom chimney is easy stemming using obvious features. The upper chimney is more awkward with fewer features for stemming. Finish at the level of Cracker Barrel or continue up and finish right of Greatness.  (This is a named climb in Knower and is #15 in S/M.)

location: 17: Hawk's Nest > East Bluff 04 - East Rampart > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: This starts in the same "Funnel" (5.6) as bucket brigade. At the top of the funnel~ take the right dihedral~ and at the dirty ledge~ instead of continuing up bucket brigade~ stick to the broken crack system to the right of the dihedral.
protection: Gear. Setting a toprope anchor is possible~ but requires some scrambling to get down from the top of the bluff to the top of the climb.

location: Lower Major Mass > 5.3 - Doorway Rocks - Major Mass > East Bluff 05 - Potholes Area > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: Inside corner with small overhang about 20 feet up. You can continue by traversing to the northeast over to an inside corner that leads up to slab at the top of Keyhole butress~ also 5.4.

location: 5. Hole-In-The-Wall > East Bluff 06 - Balanced Rock > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: Start in awkward crack with a couple moves to the shallow chimney~ not worth the trek out here but if you're here anyway...      #11 p172 Swartling

location: Rattlesnake Ridge > East Bluff 02 - East of the Quarry > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: Climb face past a 3-foot flake 10 feet up on the right.

location: 2. Dutchman Rampart > West Bluff 02 - Misery Rocks & The Pantry > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: Fun lead that shares the start to Oh Rats. When you get to the top of the large ledge (referred to as the "second ledge in Swartling)~ head South West (climbers left) up short 4th class scramble to thin crack to top out. Walk off climbers left.  This is route number 3 in this area~ in the Swartling Guide.
protection: After the initial moves~ the start eats cams... master cam #1 up to C4 #2.  Nuts also work well...

location: Aladdin's Castle > Near East > East Bluff 02 - East of the Quarry > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: Three variations to this~ go left for 5.6~ pull the over hang for 5.10+ and go right for 5.5

location: The Cleo Amphitheater > West Bluff 03 - Cleo Amphitheater > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: The wide crack to the right of King's Throne. Follow it and it has two finishes. Either the North face or the East face. Fun crack.

location: Main Cliff West > Rattlesnake Mound > Central Sandstone > Wisconsin
desc: Excellent short route accented with a mix of short pulls~lay backs~ balancing~ and cracks.  Would be a great second pitch to Solo~ Anniversary~ Black Hornet~ or Slab Cracks. Named for the timber rattlesnake found in the area and the dead pine felled off route face. TIMMMMMBERRRR!
protection: Easy top rope access/set-up. Bring a set of wired nuts~ small/med cams. First pro placement is at about 20 ft.

location: Main Face > Owens Rock > Central Sandstone > Wisconsin
desc: A route smack dab between Slings and Things and Left Crack. I'm sure this has been climbed many times before~ but I'm finally going to put a name on it. If you haven't climbed Main Crack do it and you'll learn how this route got its name...
protection: Typical Owen's Rock. Easy TR setup~ otherwise small pieces for trad.

location: 06: Gill's Buttress > East Bluff 04 - East Rampart > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: These twin cracks follow either a right facing dihedral or left facing dihedral just to the right of Fantasy & Weasels Ripped My Flesh. Relatively interesting and sometimes dirty.

location: 02: Dark Wall > 1: Prospect Point Rampart > West Bluff 05 - West Rampart > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: 35' down dark wall there is a recess in the wall. Climb the short crack with small ledges on the right side of the recess.    Climb isn't that fun couple of bushes and shrubs exist.

location: 7.2.1 - Birthday Rocks > East Bluff 07 - Railroad Tracks > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: This route is nice easy climb with a number of ledges where the climber can rest. The route is in the inside corner to the right of Flying Delorean. The route starts on the same ledge as Flying Delorean. Stay in the corner through the route. The top 10 feet is class four.     If anyone knowns the name of this route~ or who did the first assent make a comment and I will edit.
protection: The route protects well. Most of the pro can be placed with the leader is on good footing.

location: 7.2.1 - Birthday Rocks > East Bluff 07 - Railroad Tracks > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: The route starts 5' to the right of the ledge Flying Delorean. That is not on the ledge but 5' to the right of it. The bottom section has some nice blockly hand and foot holds that go straight up. Midway up there is a ledge. At the ledge move back toward unknown route. There is a narrow  squeeze. You have a choice to go in the squeeze or above it. The crux is a small overhang just past the squeeze. The crux holds are good. The last 10 feet is class four.
protection: Protection on this route is good. It has options for both large and small pro. I believe I placed two #4s~ one #3~ and one .5 cam. There were other options.

location: 03: The Monster > East Bluff 04 - East Rampart > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: Up the short wall~ just left of the "Body Snatcher~" then up the crack and flake.

location: 5.1 - Ramsay's Pinnacle > East Bluff 05 - Potholes Area > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: Cool little slab~ wall~ ledges and edges~ side pulls~ and finger crack.  Start out on long reaches to small in-cuts and insecure feet(moss and lichens)up to a strange glued-in square block~ then up edges and ledges to the upper finger crack with slopey ledges for feet!  Super Fun.
protection: Small to medium wired stoppers and cams.  There is one crack/pod that would take a size 2-3 C4 cam.

location: Lower Major Mass > 5.3 - Doorway Rocks - Major Mass > East Bluff 05 - Potholes Area > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: A straighter version of "Catwalk."  In the initial dihedral of "Catwalk" continue straight up to the top of the block on the right (dirty).  Continue up the face to the left~ ending just under and left of the final boulder perched on top.    Not as aesthetic as "Catwalk~" but better protected~ and links well with "Archeopteryx" to take you to the base of "Jungle Gym."
protection: One large piece (a #4 or a #5 BD C4)~ and one or two pieces < 1 inch.

location: Lower Major Mass > 5.3 - Doorway Rocks - Major Mass > East Bluff 05 - Potholes Area > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: Cat Walk starts in the inside corner where the Seventh Buttress and the adjacent wall meet.  Use the crack in the corner (large gear) to get to a small ledge system that traverse left across the face.  Move carefully to the left outside corner~ finding a small~ shallow piece of gear along the way.  Finish by moving up to "No Rest For the Wicked" or "Archeopteryx."

location: Wisconsin Strip > Interstate State Park > Wisconsin
desc: Head up the face to the the obvious jam crack at the top of the cliff.  This is the crux.  There's a way to avoid hand jams using the under cling.

location: 17: Hawk's Nest > East Bluff 04 - East Rampart > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: Charybdis is a fine route located about 15 feet east of the giant boulder at the base of Coronary.  The route starts out on challenging holds and remains challenging all the way up.  Follow the small slanting crack up and right~ though you may not use the crack much during your ascent as it is very thin.  There is a slight overhang near the top~ but the holds are large and copious.  I thought the route was very reachy~ but with a few runs on it I'm sure the sequences could be honed to make it more graceful.  This is a fun~ challenging 5.7 which~ due to its continuous difficulty~ could be considered harder than many 5.7's at the Lake.
protection: Small nuts on your rack~ big nuts to get the nerve to lead this thing.

location: 08: Two Pines Buttress > East Bluff 04 - East Rampart > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: Start up the same inside corner as Anemia and Hypoglycemia. Climb the inside corner to the overhang 30 ft up. Step to the right side of the overhang and surmount the overhang to get to the crack above it. Follow crack to top.  Most people stay below the overhang and traverse to the right before surmounting the overhang~ but I have done an interesting variation where you use handholds above the overhang to traverse to the crack on the right.
protection: Pretty decent pro at the overhang. Good pro above the overhang all the way to the top. Take a standard rack. Maybe some micronuts for the seam under the overhang if you don't feel like sticking a cam where your hands might go.  (Thx to Brandon White for this pro beta)

location: Cleopatra's Needle > West Bluff 03 - Cleo Amphitheater > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: This route is on the opposite side of the regular route up Cleo's Needle. The route starts below an overhang between the two obvious cracks. Surpass the overhang by climbing the right crack. Once over the overhang follow the rib up to the ledge below summit block. Traverse left to another ledge at same level. Once on this ledge climb to the top on small edges and right corner (crux of the route). Belay at the top from the summit ring.
protection: To protect up to the ledge below the summit block use medium size nuts and cams( up to 1"). The move left from the rib to the ledge is well protected with a red allien(0.75"). Once on ledge  a #3 BD stopper can be used on horizontal crack at the base of the summit block.

location: 12: Rainy Wednesday Tower > East Bluff 04 - East Rampart > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: Cliff's Coitus is aptly named since it is situated after Foreplay but before Orgasm.  Climb up the slab just right of Foreplay.  The crack of Foreplay is off.  Attempt to climb this line as a pure face climb.  It is a very enjoyable route with sustained thin moves all the way up.

location: Above Anthrax > Necedah (Petenwell Bluff) > Wisconsin
desc: A short gear lead using the face and a thin crack system in an obtuse dihedral.
protection: Small gear for the climb~ med+ for the anchor

location: Tree Tower > West Bluff 06 - West Bluff Towers > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: Start at lowest point. Climb northeast ridge on nice ledges to a sweet lieback at the top. Be careful of loose and brittle rock near and on top. Descend at route 3.
protection: Setting a toprope: take the south side of the tower (descent route) to the top. Use east side of tower to set up. See my anchor photo below.

location: Turk's Head > West Bluff 03 - Cleo Amphitheater > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: An alpine route at Devil's Lake?  Turks Head Ridge~ with the Wiessner Wall finish is seven to nine pitches long.  Sure the pitches are short~ but its all we've got.     To approach~ walk north past the cabins on Tumbled Rocks Trail until you can see a tower about 50 yards above the trail. This is the first pitch (5.3).  Descend the tower~ and continue on long~ mostly unbroken ridge to the base of Wiessner Wall.  Continue up Wiessner in two pitches and complete the longest route in Wisconsin.    Pitch two (5.6)~ an ugly wide inside corner~ protects well with big cams. The third pitch~ a left slanting finger crack is the crux (5.8) and difficult to protect.  It is short~ though~ and the 5.6 face to the right might afford the leader some respite. After this~ it is 5.4 climbing to the top.    For what it's worth~ I have usually climbed the ridge in this order:    Pitch 1: The Tower~ 5.2     Pitch 2: The Dirty Inside Corner~ 5.6     Pitch 3: The 30 Foot Wall~ 5.8 or 5.6     Pitch 4: The 15 Foot 5.1 Groove     Pitch 5: The 40 Foot Inside Corner/Ridge~ 5.4     Pitch 6: The short Rightward Diagonalling Crack~ 5.4     Pitch 7: The Double Cracks~ 5.5     Pitch 8: Wiessner's Chimney~ 5.4     Pitch 9: either Wiessner's Face~ 5.7 or The Crack Above The Tree~ 5.2    I feel as though~ when climbed this way~ you maximize both the quality and the quantity of the climbing. There are~ however~ numerous variations possible.
protection: Standard Rack--Maybe some big cams. Gear to set belays.

location: 7.1.3 - The Turret > East Bluff 07 - Railroad Tracks > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: A blank looking face above leads to feature that seem to come out of nowhere!

location: Hillbilly Routes > Hillbilly Hollow > Wisconsin
desc: Two cracks broken up with some ledges~ first crack 10-15 feet~ second crack around 15 feet. First crack is about fist sized~ fun and interesting~ exciting mantle moves to leave the crack. Second crack is more hand sized~ and a lot more fun. Topping the route wasn't too bad~ but this thing needs some loving. Get on it.
protection: Hand sized cams and some hexes~ probably could use a nut or two if you wanted.   Finger sized cams and some nuts for the anchor.

location: Main Wall > Steinke Wall > Steinke Basin > Devil's Lake Bouldering > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: #7 in the 3rd Edition guidebook. Face and crack right of route 6.
protection: Trees at the top for anchors~ set of nuts for lead

location: 03: Big Toe to Great Chimney > 1: Prospect Point Rampart > West Bluff 05 - West Rampart > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: Climb cracks in shallow left facing inside corner to small roof. Surmount roof and finish on the overgrown top of the pedestal.  This is #44 in Swartling/Mayer and is listed simply as "Unnamed 5.7" in Knower.

location: 05: Lost Face Area > 1: Prospect Point Rampart > West Bluff 05 - West Rampart > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: Rightmost of 3 climbs on separate wall right of Lost Face proper. Climb crack at north end of small overhang.  This is Swartling/Mayer #73~ and is named "Unnamed 5.7" in Knower.

location: Stettner Rocks > West Bluff 01 - Stettner Rocks > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: Climb thin finger crack just to the left of the prominent arete using only the crack- no stemming out left. Follow this up 10 feet~ crux~ and then make good moves on decent edges and horizontals to the top. Protects pretty well.
protection: Brass offsets down low~ medium cams or tri-cams up higher.

location: Squirrel's Nest Tower > East Bluff 06 - Balanced Rock > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: Yet another great moderate!  Left of the rib~ through the alcove~ up to a crack~ and exit.

location: 7.3 - Horse Rampart > East Bluff 07 - Railroad Tracks > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: Located at the Eastern end of  the Horse Rampart (the last climb on the continious cliff line before Teetering Tower)~ this jam crack poses interisting moves that will have you wondering why you havn't found this rout at the lake earlier.
protection: Good anchor for top rope and well protected crack placements for trad

location: 6. Porkchop Buttress > West Bluff 02 - Misery Rocks & The Pantry > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: Sweat Box is found on to the left of the outside corner between The Bone (route 50) and No Exit (52).  Climb up the thin crack to a ledge~ then ascend the outside corner using face holds.  Move up under the slightly overhanging block and delicately pull straight over the block to the top.

location: Hillbilly Routes > Hillbilly Hollow > Wisconsin
desc: Swiss Cheese was the first bolted line one encountered upon entering the canyon proper (before all of the new bolting).  Generally speaking there is a pile of cheater stones at the bottom of the route to assist in the direct variation.  The stones are there to overcome the overhang~ and avoid tumbling into the hollow/cave below.  These cheater stones may be considered a sage tactic by some~ and in my humble opinion are more sketchy than pulling the move outright.  The actual route starts in the corner (getting up the corner and over to the first bolt is the crux) to the right and traverses into the route.  The route proper is slightly off angle and follows a line of great patina holds~ that seem to define the phrase "great patina holds" - up the beautiful sandstone wall.  This is a great route~ especially for someone learning to lead.
protection: 4 Bolts to a pair of chains - a stick clip might be useful for the first bolt.

location: 7.1.1 - Railroad Amphitheater > East Bluff 07 - Railroad Tracks > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: Start on the frontside of the Pillar (not the chimney side)~ using the wide crack to ascend to the top of the pillar. From there~ move up the small roofs above. Use some good underclings and come out of the roofs on the left face to topout.
protection: 1 #4 Camalot for the beginning~ many small cams. Pro was descent until the second large undercling roof. Up and left is the next gear spot~ and it is all hollow/loose. There was a shallow cam spot that was solid~ but very shallow.

location: 04: Great Chimney Area > 1: Prospect Point Rampart > West Bluff 05 - West Rampart > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: This is the obvious long and tall splitter chimney on the backside of the "Coup D' Etat" formation. Starts off as tight ( really tight) squeeze chimney and eventually flares into a nice width.     Long clean cracks like this perfect for practicing technique aren't very common at the lake. Get on this!
protection: TR~ (big bro's and maybe real long slings for slinging chock stones.) Might as well solo the route for hard-man status. If you slip you aren't going far.

location: September Wall > East Bluff 02 - East of the Quarry > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: Good stances to place gear in this crack system with some nice hand jams. Follow the crack slightly left.

location: 04: D'Arcy's Buttress > East Bluff 04 - East Rampart > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: While not nearly as grand of a traverse as its namesake in the Tetons~ the Devil's Lake version of the Grand Traverse offers an interesting alternate start to Last Gasp. Instead of starting in the pit below Last Gasp~ start on the good holds around the corner to the right~ where the vertical wall meets the roof of Zschiesche's Roof. Traverse up and left to the corner~ and finish on the upper section of Last Gasp.
protection: Same as Last Gasp; not much~ maybe a pair of Blue TCUs in the horizontal.

location: 02: The Guillotine > East Bluff 04 - East Rampart > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: #52 on page 99 of Climbers Guide to Devils Lake. Described as: "Narrow face with small holds". Everyone agreed this was a 5.8+++~ it's harder than most Devils Lake 5.8s. Do not use either corners of the face or you are off route. It's a bare climb with small holds~ two ledges to rest on~ nothing more.    I named it The Pike as it's part of The Guillotine~ and what's left to do with a decapitated head? Put it on The Pike.
protection: Top rope it with ease~ climb does not lend itself well to lead climbing.

location: 3. The Frigate > West Bluff 02 - Misery Rocks & The Pantry > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: Starts with a boulder problem on the right face of the South arete.  You generally follow this corner up~ avoiding the main crack of Can Can.  At the top~ move back onto the South face into a seam.    The hard part is spotting the crimps - there is usually no chalk on this route.
protection: Some~ mostly small nuts.  It is also possible to use the Can-can crack in the mid-section.

location: Wiessner Wall > West Bluff 03 - Cleo Amphitheater > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: Somewhat of an awkward start. The places you would like to have a hold for your feet are not there. Start on the far left of the wall on large blocks. Climb the corner (pretty easy) up to the overhang. Go right around the overhang to access a crack. The crack is the crux. Follow the crack to the large ledge above and viola~ you're done.

location: Fire Spire > Necedah (Petenwell Bluff) > Wisconsin
desc: Features a roof~ and then a dihedral. Tell your partner what you see through the window mid-way up.

location: Condor Corner > East Bluff 02 - East of the Quarry > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: A couple of moderate moves~ then coil up and reach high for the crux holds.  (Figuring out which crimp to use is part of the crux.)  Somehow get your feet up onto the good foothold~ then continue on to the top.
protection: Looks mighty thin through the crux ....

location: 15: Pseudo Hawk's Nest > East Bluff 04 - East Rampart > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: This route has three distinct sections~ and a number of variations.    The lower section is a strenuous layback.  Take this up to the shallow alcove (similar to the alcove on "Chicago").  From here~ launch up using face holds until you can sink your hands in horizontal crack.  This may look dubious on sight~ but the holds are there (like "Brinton's Direct") and there is even some gear.  For the final 6-8 feet~ move left.  The top-out on the ledge is always dirty.    You could continue to the top of the bluff (5.7 or 5.8 I think)~ but most people stop here and walk off to the side toward the Leaning Tower gully.    Variations:  for the lowest part~ you can TR on or just to the left of the rib's arete - it wouldn't make a great lead.  At the top~ instead of moving left you can struggle straight up through the last alcove~ making this a 5.10 - this has good gear.
protection: Gear to 1 or 1.5 inches~ plus some bigger pieces for the belay at the top.

location: 11: Bill's Buttress > East Bluff 04 - East Rampart > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: Prophet's Honor begins on the slabby ledges to the right of Dark Corner. Climb the slab into a shallow overhanging alcove. Place good pro in the hand crack~ traverse slightly left and go up the face to the top. Cool and fun climbing that protects reasonably well by Devil's Lake standards~ especially with double ropes. Plenty of hidden crimps. Top moves are a bit run-out. Couldn't find info on first ascents. Swartling just lists the route as 5.9 without mentioning any names. I felt it was more like a solid 5.10.
protection: Up to #4 BD cams (#4 fits nicely on top of the shallow corner). Offset micronuts (Wild Country Superlights or HB's)~ Ballnuts.

location: 02: The Guillotine > East Bluff 04 - East Rampart > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: This route starts about 15 to the left of Levitation. Climb to the right of the corner by about 6 feet. Use small sidepulls and crimps to gain a decent ledge then follow thin crack to another ledge and take it to the top.
protection: If Rhoads leads this before me I'll quit climbing.

location: 5.1 - Ramsay's Pinnacle > East Bluff 05 - Potholes Area > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: Start in the center of the face~ and contrive a way to stay centered.    Swartling & Mayer suggest there is a 5.7 here ... maybe if you start on the left-hand side?

location: 11: Bill's Buttress > East Bluff 04 - East Rampart > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: This climb tackles the arête/face/slab that lies between the route Escalation (left) and Coatimundi Crack (right) and just behind the large mature and prominent tree.  There are two cruxes.  The first is just a bit off the deck at the 20 ft. mark and involves the temptation to lean into the tree to make the move easier.  Don't do it and keep it legit and 5.9+.  The second crux is up high at 3/4 height on the upper slab face and involves thin crimps and side pulls off good feet at a nice horizontal.  The climb ends at the big ledge shared by both the adjoining routes and climber finishes climbing to the top via the upper groove of the normal Coatimundi Crack.  I am quite sure this climb has been top roped over the many years but it does not appear in any guidebook I have checked.  I practiced the moves on TR and planned out the gear   placements then went back and led from ground up.  I gave it the R safety rating because of the small gear options at and above the first crux.
protection: The protection is bomber but at the feet at both cruxes (good deep and stacked cams in solid horizontal cracks).  There is a deep but small RP#3 placement at the first crux to keep from hitting the ground.  Above the first crux there is a small run-out but on easier moves.  There is a nice bomber #2 Ballnut placement that protects the move off the ledge up the arête onto the face and into the horizontal that protects the upper crux.

location: Qual Wall > Governor Dodge State Park > Wisconsin
desc: Fourth route from the left hand side.

location: Qual Wall > Governor Dodge State Park > Wisconsin
desc: Far right bolted line on warm up wall. Kind of jacked.

location: 02: Dark Wall > 1: Prospect Point Rampart > West Bluff 05 - West Rampart > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: 40' Down darkwall... This is the face just past the first recess. Climb the faces starting on the lower right up to a small ledge 10' up. Then climb up thin finger tip crack to a jug. Then finish using the double cracks and finish at the top.
protection: This is possible to Trad. Safer to TopRope.

location: North Slope > West Bluff 07 - North Woods > Devil's Lake > Wisconsin
desc: Climbs the faint crack line left of the more obvious "North Country Crack".  The crux is pulling up and past the major horizontal via a nice but maybe a bit insecure side-pull and then long reach to secret hold and a cross-over move all with the gear at your feet.  The more broken rock above the crux is sustained 5.8.
protection: Medium cams and wired stoppers. In the horizontal to protect the crux place a couple of a couple #2-3 C4 sized cams and equalize them.

location: The Ranch > The Ranch > Wadi Khab Al Shamis > Dibba Inland > Musandam > Oman > Asia > International
desc: There are a few ways to tackle this route. At the start the easier way is to stay to the right for an 6b climb. For more of a challenge follow the direct line of bolts for very balancy bouldery moves 7a. The over hang is the easiest part of the route with many options for knee bars and body jams. Follow right and rock over with a right heel hook to come out of the overhang. Continue up the the concaved face with sharp small holds.
protection: 30m bolted route; 13 bolts to the chains.

location: Forgotten Wall > Hatta Crag > North-West Oman > Oman > Asia > International
desc: Steep and very nice moves through overhanging start then harder and interesting moves at the second overhanging section. After the overhanging sections it turns in delicate face climbing on the exposed slab without using the arete on the right.
protection: Bolted route with rings at the top.

location: Little Monkey Cove > Crazy Horse *TEMPORARILY CLOSED* > Northwest - Around Chiang Mai > Thailand > Asia > International
desc: An interesting and unconventional route. Has been offered grades ranging from 5.10d - 5.12a. Seems very sequence dependent

location: The Defile > Phra Nang Beach > Laem Phra Nang (Railay & Tonsai) > South - Islands & Beaches > Thailand > Asia > International
desc: First 30 feet are the business. After that it's not as steep but still a few hard spots.

location: Area 2 > Chongkurchak > Kyrgyzstan > Asia > International
desc: This is a short climb~ but it is tougher than you think.  There were originally 4 bolts and then an anchor~ but the first bolt has been chopped.  This makes the climb a bit R rated as the second bolt (now the first bolt) is at least 6 metres from the ground and is not at a great spot for clipping.  There is~ however~ a small crack where you could stick in a nut about 4 metres from the start.  The crux is halfway up the climb at the (now) second bolt.     The original rating on this climb was a 6a but I disagree with the rating on this climb as I've climbed all the other 6a climbs at this crag and this one is much harder than those.  Definitely closer to 6c but not a 7a.  Potentially the original rating was based on the fact that this is a much shorter climb than the others.    Also~ a little safety hazard that you may or may not see~  There are a few tiny rusty nails that are hammered into the crack in a couple places.  Not sure what they are there for~ but if you can~ just take them out (update: September 2013~ I was able to get one out).  There are at least 3 for sure~ but they are pretty hard to get out with just your fingers...
protection: The first bolt has been chopped~ so the first bolt that is on the route is at about 6 metres up.  A bit R rated as this is a pretty good size fall if you screw up.      There is a crack were you could get in a nut though at about 4 metres up so that could make it a bit safer.      After the first bolt there are two more and then the anchors.      So~ a total of 3 draws are needed~ plus a small nut if you want that extra protection.

location: Olympic Crag > Al Shafa > Saudi Arabia > Asia > International
desc: Follow the left trending undercling rail. Mantle finish. Belay from the ground.  5 Bolts.

location: Garden Buttress > Hong Kong > China > Asia > International
desc: F6c or 7a. 7 m. Shares the first two bolts with Morning Walk but heads straight up the face. Two variations: (1) Direct up the bolt line is the harder of the two. (2) Using patina~ ledge and crack on face right of bolt line is easier.

location: Roadside Crag > Khao Yoi > Central - Around Bangkok > Thailand > Asia > International
desc: Short~ sharp~ and thuggy.    Stick clip is recommended for the first bolt.   The original route continues pass the overhanging crux and traverse right to join up with L'herbe rouge for another 10+meters.  Due to poor rock quality above~ it is recommend to end the route at the first set of anchor (bolt 6)
protection: about 8 quickdraws~ including anchors.     Route is fully equipped with Titanium Glue-in bolts

location: Olympic Crag > Al Shafa > Saudi Arabia > Asia > International
desc: Directly up the two bulges.  6 Bolts.

location: Main Shaft > Ganesha Area > Badami > Northern Karnataka > India > Asia > International
desc: Hand-heel match for the first bouldery move. From there~ it's almost all flaky jugs and side pulls to the top.

location: The Keep > Railay East > Laem Phra Nang (Railay & Tonsai) > South - Islands & Beaches > Thailand > Asia > International
desc: This is the right of the two climbs that start off the boulder. Balancey~ technical~ classic.

location: White Mountain > YangShuo > Guangxi Province > China > Asia > International
desc: Another great route in this area~ this route has some really fun pocket pulling up quality rock. A low down~ traversing crux leads right and then up to some perfect finger pockets.
protection: Bolts to a two bolt fixed anchor.

location: Staircase Wall > Square Mountain > YangShuo > Guangxi Province > China > Asia > International
desc: Technical vertical climbing to a slightly overhanging insecure crux up high.  This route would get more stars if the crux (and most of the route for that matter) wasn't so dirty.
protection: 15 or 16 bolts to a two bolt anchor.

location: Gulag Wall > Bukit Keteri > Perlis > Malaysia > Asia > International
desc: Climb up and to the right over lots of little caves.

location: Main Wall > Beacon Hill > Hong Kong > China > Asia > International
desc: There are two bolt lines immediately left of Blue Cross.  Moon Night's Snake follows the line furthest left.  Easy climbing to a bulge~ with a big dyno to the top.

location: Worldtrip > Thakhek > Laos > Asia > International
desc: Once you are on the ledge say your energy for the big moves. Great long run.    From "Rock Climbing Laos~ 5th Edition" by Tanja & Uli Weidner and Volker Schoffl.

location: Wall of Shadows > Tanomah > Saudi Arabia > Asia > International
desc: Mr. Clean~ named for the effort to make this crag. Steep and Juggy.

location: Heart Wall > Crazy Horse *TEMPORARILY CLOSED* > Northwest - Around Chiang Mai > Thailand > Asia > International
desc: Steep climbing leads to a vertical face with a technical crux
protection: Titanium glue-ins with Hilte RE-500 resin.

location: Peha Ayam > Bukit Jernih > Perlis > Malaysia > Asia > International
desc: Very high first bolt~ but it’s safe if you approach it the right way. Climb up the slick slab to the cave and climb inside of the cave~ set up a sling on a tufa and clip in. Now you can go for the first bolt.  Climb out of the cave and over the tufas to more tufas.

location: Cantabaco, Toledo City, Cebu > Visayas > Philippines > Asia > International
desc: Begins with the same start as "Sadako" or you can do a direct start that is more difficult to a high bolt (20+ feet). Clip the first bolt on "Sadako" then immediately start going up and right to the first bolt on "Natre" the route goes slightly right and straight up from here. This route is slightly overhung and characterized by outstanding exposed movement with most of the moves challenging and slightly below 11b. The crux is 3/4 the way through the route and features a potentially dangerous fall if you blow it. The movement and the exposure make this a classic must do for those solid at the grade.
protection: I took 12 draws. Several Bolts and Slung huecos to a two bolt anchor.

location: Al-Hariq "Wadi Al-Akhu" > Saudi Arabia > Asia > International
desc: Boulder of the ground then sustained to the top

location: Al-Hariq "Wadi Al-Akhu" > Saudi Arabia > Asia > International
desc: Climbing on pockets

location: Plus Valley > Pune > Maharashtra Region > India > Asia > International
desc: The grade is not known yet. Very new bolts so may be just recently bolted. Looks very blank and hard.

location: White Mountain > YangShuo > Guangxi Province > China > Asia > International
desc: Before the recent re-bolting~ this route was scary and held potential bad falls. Now~ its a fun and varied route~ with interesting sequences. It has every thing from pure and unusual tufa jungle climbing~ delicate face~ and a hard crimpy crux lip at the top.
protection: Bolts to a two bolt anchor.

location: The Guardian > South Valley > Liming (黎明) > Lijiang Area > Yunnan Province > China > Asia > International
desc: This route is full-on for its first half before it even considers giving you a breather. This route will also vary in difficulty based on how big your fingers are. Those with skinny fingers may find this much more cruiser~ while those with 'meat paws' may find it ridiculous...  Start 8 feet right of Flight of the Locusts and 6 feet left of The Sphinx in a thin and steep corner crack. Climb the pedestal and begin stemming (a few committing moves off the pedestal if you're not careful) and skinny jamming your way up the crack until some pods/discontinuous crack appear on your left. Creatively weave your way through these two cracks. The crack will thin ever so slightly and the left crack will disappear as you reach a small stance where the crack widens. From here~ hold off the fatigue and climb the slightly wider/easier crack to a semi-decent stance. A few more moves above the pod will yield a bunch of ledges and the chains.
protection: - 0-1 TCUs (green~ yellow~ red)   - One .1 X4   - One .2 X4   - Two .3s   - Two .4s   - Three or four .5s   - Two .75s   - One 1

location: Andagi Rock > Usa Beach/Cape Hedo > Okinawa > Okinawa Prefecture > Japan > Asia > International
desc: the crux is around the 2nd or 3rd bolt. This route follows a flake over a small bulge to a vertical face.

location: The Mitt > Koh Yao Noi > South - Islands & Beaches > Thailand > Asia > International
desc: This route was put up first~ but it shares a finish with "Mixed Fruit Shake" which is a much more natural line.  Neither is really more difficult than the other.

location: Upper Wonderland (Qi Ji Shang Duan) > Wonderland (Qi Ji) > Western Hills Escarpment > Western Hills (Xi Shan) > Kunming Area > Yunnan Province > China > Asia > International
desc: 2-pitch line up spectacular buttress 4 m left of Yellow Start.    Pitch 1-5.11b/c~ 8 bolts to 2-bolt anchor (hanging belay). 18 m.    Pitch 2-project~ 8 bolts to 2-bolt anchor. 22 m.

location: Plus Valley > Pune > Maharashtra Region > India > Asia > International
desc: Bhumi. The name comes from the fact the Bhushan and Mike (who bolted the route) had to struggle a lot to clean the route from the very beginning. Bhu+Mi    Pitch 1 (80ft/6a): Easy~ balancy moves on slab till 3rd bolt. Rest of the pitch has 6a moves. Precise footwork needed. Shift towards left to reach the 1st station.    Pitch 2 (50ft/6c+): Move towards left~ bolts can be easily spotted. After 2 easy clips~ there's a crux section. There are two methods to tackle the crux. There is a fairly wide (open hand) under-cling. One can go from left of it(towards the bolt)(6c+ move)or from slightly right side using a tiny flake(6c move). Taller climbers have an advantage as they are able to clip before attempting the crux move. Rest of the pitch has moves ranging 6a-6b. station 2 is above the hump/roof towards right after climbing 20-25 ft past the crux section.     Pitch 3 (50ft/4+): Easy Traverse towards right with 5 bolts to clip. Go around the big block of rock to reach Station 3.   Pitch 4 (70 ft/6b+): Vertical+ Overhanging crack. Starts with a nice vertical hand crack(6a+/6b)for approx. 55ft. Slightly overhanging finger crack approx. 15 ft. Then top out with some high feet moves. Station 4 is in the shape of kitchen sink towards left. Probably the best pitch in the whole climb.   Pitch5 (60ft/6a+): 2-3 relatively harder/scary moves. High feet and knee bar can be used in these sections. There will a point where you may not find the last bolts~ climb towards left and not  towards right~ then you can see the bolts. Very firm tree on the top can be used to set up belay for the follower. Tree is on a near flat ground. One can belay very comfortably.
protection: Route is completely and nicely bolted. Very firm tree and comfortable belay stand at the top of the climb i.e. end of 5th pitch.

location: Güzeloba Manzara > Antalya Geyikbayiri > Turkey > Asia > International
desc: First pitch is a 6a~ good footwork will get you through the roof. Second pitch is a 6c+
protection: Glue ins~ fixed anchors with chains

location: Sector 1 > Beit Meri > Lebanon > Asia > International
desc: Sporty route that stays on you through the first four clips.
protection: Five bolts. Two bolts with rap rings at the top.

location: Quarantine Roof > Morning Buttress > Hong Kong > China > Asia > International
desc: This is a wide off-width or narrow chimney~ depending how thick or thin you are. Scramble up slab below roof. Reach out for the first roof bolt~ then launch into the roof moves~ eventually gaining vertical crack up high.

location: Trebenna West Middle > Antalya Geyikbayiri > Turkey > Asia > International
desc: Fun extension! Climb up a steepening face with multiple tufas~ and some tricky moves in between. Worthwhile!

location: (3) Long Lane > Long Dong (Dragon Cave) > Taiwan > Asia > International
desc: Fun 5.10 climbing to the overhang. From here a finger rail sets you up for powerful moves to gain the roof. Fight to the anchors on thankfully sharp rock.
protection: 316 steel (2005)    Two bolts added on the slab (2014)

location: Hidden World > Railay East > Laem Phra Nang (Railay & Tonsai) > South - Islands & Beaches > Thailand > Asia > International
desc: crux down low. quite hard.

location: Getu Valley > Guizhou Province > China > Asia > International
desc: This is the first pitch of Dani Andrada's RimRim in the Lazy Dragon Cave I haven't climbed the second pitch so only info for the first is given here    Delicate~ thin climbing on dark rock at the start gives way to slightly easier climbing on beautiful Getu white/gray limestone.

location: Batman Wall > Gunung Sireh: Fairy Caves > Sarawak > Borneo > Malaysia > Asia > International
desc: Batman start~ as usual. Climb the overhanging rock using pockets and tufas to the anchor.

location: Marley Wall > Tonsai Bay > Laem Phra Nang (Railay & Tonsai) > South - Islands & Beaches > Thailand > Asia > International
desc: A fun 3 pitch route.  The first 2 pitches can be easily linked and are super fun.  I didn't do the third pitch so I can't really comment on it.

location: Left Cave Sag / Right > Antalya Geyikbayiri > Turkey > Asia > International
desc: Scramble up to the cave and go right  of the big tufa on good but some times spaced holds. At the bulge traverse left~ follow the crease and head for the little roof~ this is the easy part.

location: Wadi Al Akhu Crag > Hariq > Saudi Arabia > Asia > International
desc: Stout face climbing on pockets
